Title: Uncaught (in promise) Error: Cannot find module '../node_modules/string_decoder/index.js'
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When the `github` package starts up its filesystem watcher the following stack trace is thrown to the console:

```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Cannot find module '../node_modules/string_decoder/index.js'
    at Module._resolveFilename (module.js:470:15)
    at Module._resolveFilename (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\electron.asar\common\reset-search-paths.js:35:12)
    at Function.get_Module._resolveFilename (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\src\module-cache.js:354:58)
    at Module.require (file:///C:/temp/atom/553dec3e7/Atom%20x64/resources/app.asar/static/index.js:40:43)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at customRequire (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\static\<embedded>:96:26)
    at get_Decoder (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\split\index.js:12:37)
    at split (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\split\index.js:20:28)
    at C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\what-the-status\index.js:37:18
    at Promise (<anonymous>)
    at parse (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\what-the-status\index.js:16:16)
    at C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\github\lib\git-shell-out-strategy.js:567:60
    at Generator.next (<anonymous>)
    at step (C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\github\lib\git-shell-out-strategy.js:92:197)
    at C:\temp\atom\553dec3e7\Atom x64\resources\app\node_modules\github\lib\git-shell-out-strategy.js:92:367
    at <anonymous>
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable "Filesystem Event Diagnostics" in the `github` package
2. Open a project folder that contains a git repository
3. Open the console and see the errors when the `fs watcher` starts up

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

No errors.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Errors.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% of the time.

Note that if the `github` package's `fs watcher` doesn't initialize, this doesn't show normally.

### Versions

This started happening on builds after https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/553dec3e7a84ccb1965f557a1aad36822025905e.

Seen on both Windows (10 x64 Enterprise) and macOS builds.

### Additional Information

The changes to `text-buffer` brought in by that commit can be found here: https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/compare/v13.12.4...v13.13.0. The suspicious commit being merging https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/280 as it introduced `cpy-cli` as a direct `dependency` instead of a `devDependency` as it should have been. That package has `string_decoder` as a dependency, and although `string_decoder` was already in the tree that PR moved it from a `devDependency` to a regular `dependency`.

I _believe_ that https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/296 will fix it, but have been unable to test without a version of `text-buffer` on NPM that includes it.
Label: bug

Title: Unable to save when the encoding is set to Nordic
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom is unable to save any file if the file encoding is erroneously set to Nordic.
I use a Windows 10 box with atom version 1.25.0 x64. As part of configuring settings either I or one of the plugins set the Nordic from Western(Windows 1252). This was causing Atom to not be able to save *any* file. Also the error message string , while trying to save, was empty. Hence we didn't had an idea about what was Atom barfing about.

NOTE: This problem may be more widespread ie there may be bugs about switching "File Encodings" to other values as well even though the problem I encountered was about Nordic locale.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Settings
2. Change file encoding to "Nordic"
3. Create a new file, write some gibberish and try to save it

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
File should get saved. The * (showing unmodified file in cmd line) should disappear

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
File doesn't get saved. The * (showing unmodified file in cmd line) is present.

*Edit by @rsese mentioning the console error*


On Windows, the error in console is:

```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Invalid encoding name: ISO-8859-10
```

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% reproducible

### Versions


**atom.cmd --version **

Atom    : 1.25.0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

**apm.cmd --version **
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0
python 2.7.14
git 2.15.1
visual studio 2015

** OS **
Windows 10 x64
Label: bug

Title: Dock Bug: Crossing dock toggle with drag and drop breaks dock positioning
Body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: Attempted. None of the directions to enter safe mode or attempts to work around them worked. Might because this computer is running beta and there is a space in the file name (but everything from atom to 'Atom\ Beta' errors when executing from within the Contents/MacOS/ folder). * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: N/A * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: None found. * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: N/A ### Description Dragging a file from the finder so the mouse path crosses the dock toggle of a closed left dock (tree-view pane) triggers the dock toggle, but does not redraw the rest of the window to accommodate the pop-out. ### Steps to Reproduce (Note: I have vertical tabs and tree-view enabled.) 1. With Atom open and the tree-view pane closed, open file manager/finder to the left of the window. 2. Drag a file from the file manager/finder to the Atom window so it crosses the toggle control on the closed dock. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] File appears in new tab with no other events triggered. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] The tree-view pane opens, but the rest of the window does not redraw to accommodate it. Toggling the dock after this moves the rest of the window back and forth as if the dock were toggling but not the dock, which remain open over overlaps the other content in the window. Only resolved by restarting Atom. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% Only occurs when dragging and dropping. Just dragging over the window with the left button pressed and nothing selected has no effect. ### Versions Various. Tested both on Mac (beta) and multiple Windows boxes (current non-beta and older standalone). ### Additional Information Disabled vertical tabs and toolbar, both to no effect. Reproducible on bottom dock as well. Nothing docked to right. Maybe the toggle is looking for a mouse event without checking whether the event occurred over the toggle or entered the toggle after occurring elsewhere? The dev console doesn't show any listeners for the toggle or its immediate parent divs.
Label: bug

Title: `atom.config.get` inappropriately referring config.cson value in test-spec
Body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Here is the excerpt of test-spec for my cursor-history pkg. Maybe because of bug of v1.25.0-beta3, `atom.config.get` return actual config defined in `config.cson` rather than it's default value in the very first executed section. Which make `f`-ocused spec tested in wrong condition. Also very first test is executed in environment dependent config value. From quick code check(not tested throughly), maybe these lines does set env specific config. https://github.com/atom/atom/blame/master/src/atom-environment.js#L213-L225 May be because of change in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16628#issuecomment-367172653? ```javascript fdescribe('initial state of history entries', () => { it('1', () => { console.log('1-1', atom.config.get('cursor-history.columnDeltaToRemember')) console.log('1-2', atom.config.get('cursor-history.columnDeltaToRemember')) // v1.24.0: 9999(default value) // v1.25.0-beta3: 5(my local config set in config.cson!!) }) it('2', () => { console.log('2-1', atom.config.get('cursor-history.columnDeltaToRemember')) console.log('2-2', atom.config.get('cursor-history.columnDeltaToRemember')) // v1.24.0: 9999(default value) // v1.25.0-beta3: 9999(default value) }) }) ``` ### Steps to Reproduce 1. write sample test spec I explained above using whatever config you want(e.g. `atom.config.get('editor.atomicSoftTabs')`). 2. See how `atom.config.get` return value change in 1st and 2nd section of test spec. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Test spec should be executed in default configuration like in v1.24.0. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Test spec is executed in env-dependent config for very first call of `atom.config.get`. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] ### Versions ``` $ atom-beta --version Atom : 1.25.0-beta3 Electron: 1.7.11 Chrome : 58.0.3029.110 Node : 7.9.0 $ atom --version Atom : 1.24.0 Electron: 1.6.16 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` ### Additional Information Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: bug

Title: Improve soft-wrapping by breaking words like web browsers
Body:
### Description

Current soft-wrapping behavior is not aggressive enough and sometimes leads to bad results.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable «Soft Wrap» and «Soft Wrap at Preferred Line Length» in «Editor» tab of Settings
2. Copy an URL in a text editor tab or a sequence of non-spaces characters that have more characters than the Preferred Line Length setting

**Expected behavior:**

* Break character sequences on spaces, dashes and slashes, like in a web browser
* Break character sequences at most at the «Preferred Line Length» setting
* Show a grayed out character, like those for EOL or spaces, when Atom break a word that had no spaces in it. Suggestion for default character: broken bar `¦`, which is present in the same Unicode block than  `¤¬»`.

For example, if Preferred Line Length is set to 20, then it should behave like this (`|` character represent the wrap-guide):

```
https://github.com¦ |
/atom/atom/issues¦  |
/new                |
                    |
Averylongword-¦     |
thatshouldbreak     |
                    |
Averylongword-    ¦ |  # four spaces after the dash and we see where it stops
thatshouldbreak     |  # ¦ allows to differentiate with the previous example
                    |
Averylongwordwithnos|¦  # no space, dash or slash in the word
eparator            |
```

**Actual behavior:**

* Character sequences break only on spaces
* If the character sequence doesn’t contain space and fill the whole line, the word is cut at the window edge instead of the expected Preferred Line Length (see screenshot).
![screenshot of current work-wrapping behavior](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2446451/37145899-785416b2-22c2-11e8-8229-d8eefa909d57.png)

```
https://github.com/a|tom/atom/issues/new
                    |
Averylongword-thatsh|ouldbreak
                    |
Averylongword-      | # four spaces after the dash but we can’t see it
thatshouldbreak     |
                    |
Averylongwordwithnos|eparator
```

### Versions

```
Arch Linux
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.8.2
Chrome  : 59.0.3071.115
Node    : 8.2.1
```
Label: enhancement

Title: [Atom 1.24.0] atom.showSaveDialogSync doesn't return the result
Body:
The issue is pretty self-explanatory and is a result of a botched conversion from CoffeeScript in https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/bc774773f74557f50fc9b039ec90cdacf9412341:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/9b733c8c78798b418339cde30c42f056bfe072c0/src/atom-environment.js#L1120-L1122

I see it's fixed in `1.25-releases`,
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/95863010fada6d9a4f3ed6a34a6f1ac606d22229/src/atom-environment.js#L1179-L1184
but not in `1.24-releases`:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1cd820e25cf7e8f8cb7340de7eacbe93f8a0fff5/src/atom-environment.js#L1120-L1122

Please fix this in 1.24?
Label: bug

Title: Color settings can't pass to the main process
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

It looks like `color` type values aren't being synced properly to the main process after https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16628 was merged.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open two windows of Atom v1.25.0-beta0+
2. Have a package that has a `type: color` setting (eg. `atom-material-ui`)
3. Open Developer Tools on the main window
4. Open theme settings in the second window, and open the `atom-material-ui` config
5. Change one of the colors in the second window
6. Watch the first window fail to validate the color

**Expected behavior:**

The `color` setting properly transfers to the main window.

**Actual behavior:**

The following `Error` is thrown:
```
Error: Validation failed at atom-material-ui.colors.abaseColor, {"_alpha":1,"_blue":131,"_green":20,"_red":117} cannot be coerced into a color
    at Function.coerce (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:1379)
    at Function.executeSchemaEnforcers (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:389)
    at Function.coerce (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:1339)
    at Function.executeSchemaEnforcers (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:389)
    at Function.coerce (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:1339)
    at Function.executeSchemaEnforcers (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:389)
    at Config.makeValueConformToSchema (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:1136)
    at Config.set (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:702)
    at transact (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:953)
    at Config.transact (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:815)
    at Config.resetUserSettings (C:\temp\atom\src\config.js:950)
    at disposables.add.applicationDelegate.onDidChangeUserSettings.settings (C:\temp\atom\src\atom-environment.js:786)
    at EventEmitter.outerCallback (C:\temp\atom\src\application-delegate.js:194)
    at emitThree (events.js:121)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:197)
```

From what I can tell so far the bug is that the [`Color`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f866978d119e48734c82cad4a685ed7c9261d04f/src/color.js) Object from the second window is being `emit`ed to the main window... but the problem is that it only has `_name` properties defined _directly_ on it, the main `name` properties are all `get`ters. This means that when it gets to the main window all that is left is an Object like `{"_alpha":1,"_blue":192,"_green":107,"_red":92}` instead of a real `Color` object. Since that Object isn't a `Color` object, it fails the schema enforcer for a `color` setting.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

This started happening in this version, based on https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/e74ea4797521c845f040638d01d41a1677c9ddb8:
```
Atom    : 1.25.0-dev-e74ea4797
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

A build based on https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/a48624dc0255458a4bd73ffca02a545080a9d34a (right before #16628 was merged) **doesn't** show this issue:
```
Atom    : 1.25.0-dev-a48624dc0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
```

OS: Windows 10 x64

### Additional Information

This was originally filed at https://github.com/atom-material/atom-material-ui/issues/462, but further investigation showed this to be a bug here.
Label: bug

Title: Certain custom themes can load in Safe Mode
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If certain custom themes are selected before entering safe mode, they are loaded and activated during safe mode instead of being forced to One Dark temporarily.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set a custom theme (`atom-material-ui@2.1.3`)
2. Close Atom
3. Launch Atom in safe mode using `atom --safe`
4. Note that the custom theme is still active and shows as an option in the list.
5. Select a built in theme (`one-dark-ui`)
6. Close Safe Mode and launch Atom in Safe Mode again
7. Note that only the built in themes show as options in the theme selection list.
8. Close Atom, launch in normal mode
9. Select a _different_ UI theme (`city-lights-ui@1.3.3`)
10. Restart Atom in safe mode
11. Note that One Dark is selected as the theme as it should be.

**Expected behavior:**

Custom themes are not loaded or available in Safe Mode.

**Actual behavior:**

Certain custom themes can continue showing in Safe Mode if they was selected before entering Safe Mode:

![2018-02-17_00-06-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/36339306-3516a432-1377-11e8-9a7f-c76d44e39acb.gif)

Atom Material UI is the only one found so far that does this.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

**Not** a beta bug 😆.

OS: Windows 10 x64 Enterprise

```
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.24.0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.1.windows.4
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

I've tested this back to Atom v1.17.2, all Atom versions behave the same. I also tested with `atom-material-ui@2.0.0` and found the same behavior.
Label: bug

Title: Dragging to closed Dock impossible
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you attempt to drag an item to a closed Dock panel, the panel goes into a fit of opening/closing and doesn't allow you to place the item in it.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom v1.25.0-beta0 in safe mode
2. Have a closed Dock item
2. Attempt to drag something into the closed Dock item

**Expected behavior:**

The Dock panel opens and allows dropping the item in it.

Here is how Atom v1.24.0 behaves:
![2018-02-16_15-13-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/36338643-cb7acd94-1369-11e8-83cc-5c0594845f60.gif)
_Note: You can see that the Dock panel has a little "hiccup" that looks similar to what is now happening, but resolves itself._

**Actual behavior:**

The Dock panel rapidly opens and closes, preventing the item from being dropped there until you can open it (with another item).

![2018-02-16_15-10-35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/36338656-00291050-136a-11e8-8e5a-f68d0e2f6487.gif)

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Windows 10 x64 (Enterprise and Pro tested)

```
Atom    : 1.25.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.1.windows.4
visual studio 2015
```

Compared against:
```
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: bug

Title: Project path deduplication no longer happens
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom is no longer deduplicating project paths when a request to open a path is made, this means that you open multiple windows to the same location instead of focusing the current window.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a folder in Atom
2. Open the same folder again

**Expected behavior:**

Atom simply focuses the instance that is already open.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom v1.25.0-beta0 opens a new window on the same folder, so there are now two windows open to the same folder.

![2018-02-16_12-10-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/36327178-a682d4d4-1312-11e8-9ca1-556d984181a6.gif)

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: Windows 10 x64 Enterprise

```
Atom    : 1.25.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.1.windows.4
visual studio 2015
```

Also tested with the following as a point of comparison:
```
Atom    : 1.24.0
Electron: 1.6.16
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

I _know_ I've seen discussions related to this in one of the other issues or PR's, but my search-fu is failing me!
Label: bug

Title: atom --wait doesn't work as git editor on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When attempting to use `atom --wait` as the `git config core.editor` setting as introduced in Atom v1.25.0-beta0 by https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16497, it seems the functionality attempted in that PR doesn't work under Windows, since the Atom window that the editor was spawn in still needs to fully close for `git` to consider the message as ready.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set Atom as your `git` editor
    * Git (all platforms): `git config --global core.editor 'atom --wait'`
    * PowerShell: `$Env:GIT_EDITOR='atom --wait'`
    * CMD: `set GIT_EDITOR='atom --wait'`
2. Make a commit with `git`
3. Close the tab for the file that was opened

**Expected behavior:**

As soon as the tab is closed `git` considers the message done and does the commit.

**Actual behavior:**

`git` waits for the _specific_ window that the message was opened in to close before considering the commit ready.
![2018-02-14_09-34-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/36219525-995e4b3c-116c-11e8-8866-77a4fb8f5c74.gif)

Note: Although not shown in the GIF above, I have tested both the `git` and PowerShell methods described above, as well as using `atom --wait --safe` as the editor command.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.25.0-beta0
Electron: 1.7.11
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-beta0
python 2.7.14
git 2.16.1.windows.4
visual studio 2015
```

OS: Windows 10 x64 Enterprise
Label: bug

Title: 1.24.0-beta3 Some grammars are not applied at start to opened editors
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On a fresh Atom 1.24.0-beta3, grammars like the ones in [language-babel](https://github.com/gandm/language-babel) do not get applied at start on already opened buffers.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Remove all atom configs.
2. Open atom and install language-babel
3. Open or create a `.jsx` file
4. Restart atom (ctrl + shift + f5 or close and open)

**Expected behavior:** The opened jsx file has the jsx grammar applied

**Actual behavior:** The opened jsx file has the `NullGrammar` (Plain Text)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.24.0-beta3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS: Archlinux

### Additional Information

NB: When you close the file and open it again it works as expected.
It works with some other grammars.
Downstream issue: https://github.com/gandm/language-babel/issues/476
Label: bug

Title: Debian package missing dependencies
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I downloaded the Debian package from atom.io and installed the package inside a Docker container with Ubuntu 16.04.
Prior to `dpkg -i atom-amd64.deb`, I installed the dependencies via `apt-get`.
When I tried running Atom, it failed with an error message about missing libX11-xcb.so.1.

The full list of missing packages is:

- libx11-xcb1
- libxss1
- libasound2
- libxkbfile1

Since I started with a minimal Ubuntu, there might be more missing dependencies.

The full working Dockerfile:

    FROM local/ubuntu-minbase:xenial
    
    ARG DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive
    ARG install_recommends=--no-install-recommends
    ARG packages="\
    git \
    gconf2 \
    gconf-service \
    libgtk2.0-0 \
    libnotify4 \
    libxtst6 \
    libnss3 \
    python \
    gvfs-bin \
    xdg-utils \
    "
    ARG missing_deps="\
    libx11-xcb1 \
    libxss1 \
    libasound2 \
    libxkbfile1 \
    "
    
    RUN apt-get update && \
        apt-get install -y ${install_recommends} \
            ${packages} ${missing_deps} && \
        rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
    
    COPY atom_1.23.3_amd64.deb /tmp/
    RUN dpkg -i /tmp/atom_1.23.3_amd64.deb
    RUN rm -f /tmp/atom_1.23.3_amd64.deb

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** I expect the atom-amd64.deb package to list all dependencies.

**Actual behavior:** At least four packages are missing:

- libx11-xcb1
- libxss1
- libasound2
- libxkbfile1

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.23.3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.3
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

$ cat /etc/lsb-release 
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=16.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=xenial
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 16.04 LTS"

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: bug

Title: Unable to open project directory while it's removed
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Every time when open atom show error message that "Unable to open project directory", while a project folder was add to the sidebar before, but now is removed while atom wasn't opened, and it's not able to remove that project cause it's not showed in sidebar.
![tim 20180130002122](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2271900/35521210-2421b544-0554-11e8-854a-6a8c8e13c922.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Create a folder on disk somewhere
3. File -> Add Project Folder, Choose that folder we created
4. Close Atom
5. Delete that folder
6. Open Atom
7. it goes the message

**Expected behavior:** maybe notify the user to remove the project or not?

**Actual behavior:** only goes the error message. If I want to remove that, I have to recreate that folder and open atom to remove it from the sidebar

**Reproduces how often:** everytime

### Versions

Atom    : 1.23.3
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.3
python 2.7.13
git 2.12.2.windows.2
visual studio 2015

windows 10 x64 1709
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'style' of null
Body:
1. Open Atom in safe mode from `cmd.exe` using `atom --safe`
1. Open a new untitled buffer and paste the following contents:
```
<html>
</html>
```
3. Change the language grammar to HTML
1. Place the cursor after the h on the first line
1. Press <kbd>Ctrl+Space</kbd> to run the command `autocomplete-plus:activate`
1. Press <kbd>Ctrl-Shift-P</kbd> to run the command `command-palette:toggle`
1. Search for the `autocomplete-plus:navigate-to-description-more-link` command
1. Run this command from the command palette

**Expected:** To navigate to the description more link. Or nothing to happen because opening the Command Palette closes autocomplete-plus.

**Actual:** This exception is thrown.

**Gif of reproduction:**

![style exception](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/35213060-a5ac590a-ff5c-11e7-8a11-b1eb720eec51.gif)

**Atom**: 1.23.3 x64
**Electron**: 1.6.15
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.13.2
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'style' of null

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/autocomplete-plus/lib/autocomplete-manager.js:241

TypeError: Cannot read property 'style' of null
    at HTMLElement.autocomplete-plus:navigate-to-description-more-link (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/autocomplete-plus/lib/autocomplete-manager.js:241:39)
    at CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:388:36)
    at Object.didConfirmSelection (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/command-palette/lib/command-palette-view.js:143:35)
    at SelectListView.confirmSelection (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/command-palette/node_modules/atom-select-list/src/select-list-view.js:327:26)
    at HTMLDivElement.core:confirm (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/command-palette/node_modules/atom-select-list/src/select-list-view.js:84:20)
    at CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:388:36)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:621:22)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:412:28)
    at WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:108:40)
```

### Commands

```
     -9:39.9.0 application:add-project-folder (input.hidden-input)
     -1:53.9.0 application:open (input.hidden-input)
     -1:21.4.0 command-palette:toggle (input.hidden-input)
     -0:04.9.0 core:move-down (input.hidden-input)
     -0:03.9.0 core:confirm (input.hidden-input)
     -0:03.9.0 autocomplete-plus:navigate-to-description-more-link (input.hidden-input)
```

### Non-Core Packages

```
atom-soda-dark-ui 1.1.0 
monokai 0.24.0 
```
Label: bug

Title: Atom out of memory crash when copying lines
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

![tree-sitter-memory](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/35063287-f19c9634-fbc6-11e7-89f2-beb028b4cdc1.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable `Use Tree Sitter Parsers` setting
2. Open a JavaScript file with the following contents:
```js
    /**

    function a(b) {
        var c = 15 + b;
        return c;
    }
```
3. Copy and paste these lines a couple of times

**Expected behavior:** Lines to copy without Atom crashing

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashes because out of memory

**Reproduces how often:** 100% when reaching ~4000 lines

### Versions

**Atom**: 1.25.0-dev-3d8902d x64
**Electron**: 1.7.10
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 7 Professional

### Additional Information

/cc: @maxbrunsfeld

Title: Uncaught TypeError: grammar.tokenizeLines is not a function
Body:

Title: [Regression] Auto indentation fails when moving multiple lines up or down
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
![sigh](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/490562/34974740-7444f40c-faf3-11e7-844e-63bc8fb1d69a.gif)


### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a new editor.
1. Set the language grammar to javascript.
1. Type code as in the example, e.g.

```js
    //Create change(s)
    for (const item of items) {
      await mongoose
        .model('Change')
        .create({type, item, timestamp, isDeleted});
    }
```
1. Select from 3 lines from `await` to `  .create({type, item, timestamp, isDeleted});`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/35422236-7da0eb86-01fc-11e8-8ad2-947d707768b9.png)

1. Move the 3 lines selected down by running the `Editor: Move Line Down` command.
1. Observe that auto indentation breaks the indentation.
1. Try the same when moving the code back into the for loop using the Move line up command.

**Expected behavior:** Correct indentation

**Actual behavior:** Incorrect indentation

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.25.0-dev-390ab7449
Electron: 1.7.10
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-dev-390ab7449
python 2.7.10
git 2.14.1

OS X 10.11.5

### Additional information
See also https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16556

This is a regression that only started happening in the last month or so in Atom's dev builds.
Are there no tests in place around these kind of indentation actions?
Label: bug

Title: Readonly editors can be edited using middle click paste (Linux)
Body:
### Description

Readonly editors can be edited using middle click paste on linux using atom 1.24 beta.
https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/16294

### Steps to Reproduce

1. You will need to write a custom package that opens a readonly editor
2. Open the readonly editor using the custom package
3. Split the panes so you will have a normal editor on one side and a readonly one in the other
4. Type some text in the normal editor and select it.
5. Middle click on the readonly editor.

**Expected behavior:** Readonly editor should keep unmodified

**Actual behavior:** The selected text is pasted on the readonly editor.

**Reproduces how often:** always

Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.12
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.23.3
python 2.7.6

Title: Can't see text after selecting it
Body:
### Description

Using a recent dev build of Atom (1.25.0-dev-dced608f4), selecting a line makes the line's text invisible.

### Demo

![demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/34727862-2ba26b26-f526-11e7-8b2f-7f1d61bba5a7.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build Atom from source at https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/dced608f4
1. Start Atom in safe mode
1. Select a line of text

**Expected behavior:** The styling should show that the line is selected and you should still be able to see the line's text.

**Actual behavior:** The styling shows that the line is selected, but you can't see the line's text.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

On macOS 10.13.2...

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.25.0-dev-dced608f4
Electron: 1.7.10
Chrome  : 58.0.3029.110
Node    : 7.9.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.19.0
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.25.0-dev-dced608f4
python 2.7.10
git 2.15.1
```
Label: bug

Title: toggleLineCommentsForBufferRows not respected
Body:
Reported in halp: support/9de8cd36f0dc11e794c1b414dfdb471a

> Atom used to take commentStartString verbatim; however, in recent versions, it no longer respects user wishes/configuration -- instead erroneously imposing arbitrary and undesired formatting. Specifically, toggleLineCommentsForBufferRows (in text-editor.js) is hardwired to trim commentStartString, then subsequently append a space, as opposed to simply respecting the value set in commentStartString. If a user has gone to the trouble of removing trailing space from commentStartString of any/all grammars, toggleLineCommentsForBufferRows should not be reintroducing them.

Behavior changed in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15977.
Label: bug

Title: Menu showing wrong key binding
Body:

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Description

The menu for my package ([atom-xterm](https://atom.io/packages/atom-xterm)) shows an incorrect key binding. See the following.

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: DISPOSE of MENU item not functioning as expected.
Body:
### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode. * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide. * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions. * Checked that your issue isn't already filed. * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality.
### Description Tags: API, menu, atom.menu.add(), dispose() If a menu object is disposed, this object is not disposed properly when one of the object's items is a 'separator`. Building the object would be with the instruction `favoritesMenu = atom.menu.add( .. )` Disposing of the object would be.. `favoritesMenu.dispose()`
### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open the development console in Atom. 2. Execute code in the console to create a complex menu entry. `favoritesMenu = atom.menu.add( .. )` 3. Execute code in the console to dispose of the menu entry. `favoritesMenu.dispose()` - - - - #### Scenario1 - Does work Execute code in the development console... * Creates menu items as expected.
Notice the `- - - -` item. ```js favoritesMenu = atom.menu.add ([{ label: 'Extra', submenu : [{ label: 'Test', submenu: [ {label: 'item1'}, {label: '- - - - '}, {label: 'item2'} ] }] }]) ``` * Dispose all menu items as expected. ```js favoritesMenu.dispose() ``` - - - - #### Scenario2 - Does not work Execute code in the development console... * Creates menu items as expected.
Notice the `separator` item. ```js favoritesMenu = atom.menu.add ([{ label: 'Extra', submenu : [{ label: 'Test', submenu: [ {label: 'item1'}, {type: 'separator'}, {label: 'item2'} ] }] }]) ``` * Attempt to dispose all menu items with unexpected result. ```js favoritesMenu.dispose() ``` - - - - **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] All items are removed from the menu if `dispose()` is executed. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Scenario1 occurs as expected. Scenario2 does not work as expected. Scenario2: Items `item1` and `item2` is removed as expected. however `Extra -> Test -> separator` remains. Restarting Atom brings back normality. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% ### Versions * Atom V1.23.2 * Atom V1.24-beta 2 * Windows 10 Professional ### Additional Information Originally reported by @gliviu on https://discuss.atom.io/t/menu-refresh-fails-for-separators/51255. @gliviu constructed similar coding in `init.js` which led him to discover the behaviour. Thanks for your attention. \- Dan Padric
Label: bug

Title: Fold current row regression
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`Editor: Fold Current Row` behavior seems to fold too much in some cases.

ref: https://discuss.atom.io/t/few-small-questions/50743/16

### Steps to Reproduce

Save a JavaScript file with this content:

```js
switch(color) {
  case 'black':
    printBlackBackground();
    break;
  case 'red':
    printRedBackground();
    break;
  case 'blue':
    printBlueBackground();
    break;
  case 'green':
    printGreenBackground();
    break;
  default:
    printYellowBackground();
}
```

1. Click on line 13 (`break` in the `green` case)
2. Run `Editor: Fold Current Row`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Expect the fold to run up to line 11 (`  case 'green':`).

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Folds up to line 1.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```
atom -v

Electron: 1.7.10

Title: AtomEnvironment instance properties missing in 1.24.0-beta2
Body:
### Description

[AtomEnvironment](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.23.2/AtomEnvironment) is decaffinated in the Atom v1.24.0-beta2 release; however, the instance properties for this class are no longer documented. This means that they don't appear in either the `atom-api.json` file or (presumably) the online documentation itself.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Grab the `atom-api.json` file from the [1.24.0-beta2 Release Page](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.24.0-beta2).
2. Attempt to search out any of the properties for the AtomEnvironment class, such as `textEditors`.
3. Note the absence of any of these properties.

**Expected behavior:** The properties for AtomEnvironment should be available within an array under the `instanceProperties` key.

**Actual behavior:** The `instanceProperties`, and all of its children, are missing for AtomEnvironment.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%.
Label: bug

Title: Give <atom-text-editor> a unique identifier attribute derived from the corresponding TextEditor object ID
Body:
### Prerequisites

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm currently writing a package where I modify the DOM-elements within every atom-pane element through JS, but a problem arises because new unsaved files have no unique identifier. Other files have a name or path attribute which also exist on the TextEditor object, but the new unsaved file panes and the TextEditor object have no common data. I think it would be ideal for every atom-pane to have an ID attribute derived from the TextEditor object.

**Update:** slight misunderstanding of the inner workings of the DOM, see [new reply](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16434#issuecomment-355865346) for the correct description of the issue.

Title: Atom can open the same file twice in the same pane
Body:
Repro steps from https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16364#issuecomment-353061571

I noticed this bug also when following this routine:

1. `atom . filename`
2. close atom leaving the file tab open
3. `atom . samefilename`

Expected: should open same file
Actual: opens a new file


Reported in halp: support/052c0592d8b611e7852aa652e371c508

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom can open the same file twice in the same pane if you drag a file that's already opened in a project to an empty Atom window (and that project isn't already opened).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `atom --safe`
2. Set `Restore Previous Windows on Start` set to `no` in `Settings > Core`.
3. Open some project and then open some file.
4. Quit Atom.
5. Start Atom.
6. Drag the same file you had open in step 3 from Finder or Windows Explorer to the Atom window.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The project opened in step 3 opens and the file dragged is open in 1 tab. 

This would seem to match other behavior where if you have a file open, dragging the file from Finder to the same window just focuses the already open file?

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

The project opened in step 3 opens and the file dragged is open in 2 tabs in the same pane.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```
atom -v
Atom    : 1.24.0-dev-4f73e8108
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
apm -v
apm  1.18.11
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
atom 1.24.0-dev-4f73e8108
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.6
```

macOS 10.12.6

### Additional Information

Step 2 isn't necessary, you just need to make sure the project opened in step 3 isn't open in some window before step 6.
Label: bug

Title: Confusing apm/API response after user revokes OAuth token
Body:
https://github.com/atom/apm/issues/759 revealed an issue where the atom.io API responds with a confusing/misleading error message if the user has revoked their OAuth token.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Authorize atom.io to access your GitHub account (https://atom.io/login)
2. Copy your atom.io API token (https://atom.io/account)
3. Use this token to log in to apm:
    1. `apm login`
    2. Paste in your token
4. Go to github.com and revoke atom.io's access to your github account (https://github.com/settings/connections/applications/e2c0e43b4a123468e341)
5. Attempt to publish a package associated with a repository that you own: `apm publish minor`

**Actual behavior:**

`apm` responds with the error that it got back from the atom.io API:

> Registering package in jasonrudolph/atom-test-package repository failed: That repo does not exist, isn't an atom package, or you do not have access

In this example, jasonrudolph/atom-test-package *does* exist, *is* an atom package, and I *do* you have access to it.

**Expected behavior:**

`apm` responds with an error explaining that the user needs to reauthorize atom.io to access their GitHub account. Ideally, the error message would include a link to allow the user to go back through the OAuth flow.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

---

/cc @lee-dohm (since we both looked into https://github.com/atom/apm/issues/759)
Label: bug

Title: Right clicking on selected text deselects the text
Body:
### Prerequisites

Title: Overlapping text when cutting folds
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Occasionally when there are a lot of folds, cutting folds results in overlapping text such as the following.
![folds-overlapping-text](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2766036/33350721-9598be46-d4a0-11e7-943a-d19387b62286.png)

I've managed to reproduce it twice now on https://github.com/atom/language-php/blob/3e45569d8fb3af6747f6e4208b16d17deb577b97/spec/php-spec.coffee while moving heredoc and nowdoc specs into their own `describe`s.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open https://github.com/atom/language-php/blob/3e45569d8fb3af6747f6e4208b16d17deb577b97/spec/php-spec.coffee
2. Fold everything and then unfold the top-level describe
3. Try cutting and pasting some folds until it reproduces?

**Expected behavior:** Text to appear in order

**Actual behavior:** Text occasionally overlaps

**Reproduces how often:** Unknown, I'm guessing ~10-20%.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.24.0-dev-f76a7a6ed
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
Label: bug

Title: Mapping ctrl-tab's key behavior to a different key, key doesn't work the same as ctrl-tab does
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Default `ctrl-tab` key does `pane:show-next-recently-used-item`. I would like 
`ctrl-pagedown` to do the same. but even after I mapped `ctrl-pagedown` to act the same-
Using `ctrl-tab` works smoothly but using `ctrl-pagedown` is glitchly.
They should be acting the same but for some unknown reason they don't...

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Map `ctrl-pagedown` key as `ctrl-tab`:
open `keymap.cjson`, type:

```
'body':
  'ctrl-pagedown': 'pane:show-next-recently-used-item',
  'ctrl-pagedown ^ctrl': 'pane:move-active-item-to-top-of-stack'
```
Save `keymap.cjson` file.
2.  Have at least 2 open tabs: call it `tab1`, `tab2`, edit both, finish at `tab1`.
3.1 scenario:
go to `tab1`
Hold `ctrl`, type `pagedown` **once**, wait 10 secs (3 secs should do it), release `ctrl`
OR
3.2 scenario:
Hold `ctrl`, type `pagedown` several times **fast** , to move between the open files (in popup, see image below), 

**Expected behavior:** 
Switching **smoothly** between the open files in the popup screen.
Just use the default keys to see _Expected behavior_:
3.1 scenario:
After releasing of `ctrl`, it should switch from `tab1` to `tab2`

3.2 scenario:
Hold `ctrl`, type `tab` several times **fast** , and see how it works **smoothly**, like it should.
The files in popup (open by the first `ctrl-tab`) are being switched quickly.


**Actual behavior:** 
3.1 scenario:
After releasing of `ctrl` (after waiting 10 secs), not switching from `tab1` to `tab2`, staying in same tab: `tab1`
3.2 scenario:
Switching **glitchly** between the open files in the popup screen.
(If you type `pagedown` fast enough) You need to click `pagedown` 2 times (instead of once) for it to switch a single file in popup.


**Reproduces how often:**
100%, All the time.
### Versions
`win 10 pro`
```
    Atom    : 1.22.1
    Electron: 1.6.15
    Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
    Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information
Glitch **only** occur **when you click fast enough (or to be more accurate: not slow enough)**
If you hold`ctrl` then click -`pagedown` wait 3 secs, click `pagedown`, wait 3 secs- It will kinda work.
Just try it- easy to see once you try it. It works **differently** for some reason, not like the default `ctrl-tab`. 

Popup displaying used flies:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3532929/33127609-c9d0cc76-cf91-11e7-81d2-dfc0b17bcdef.png)
Label: bug

Title: Discarded changes doesn't refresh file
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

*Edit by @rsese - steps to repro from [below](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16250#issuecomment-358185518)*

1. `sudo sysctl fs.inotify.max_user_watches=400` - setting it to a super low value to generate the error (was set to 65536 on my Ubuntu vm)
2. start Atom in atom/atom `atom --safe .`
3. Open devtools console <kbd>ctrl-shift-i</kbd> and see the same error [as @stratacast](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/16250#issuecomment-357391904) ("NSFW was unable to start watching that directory")

Now if you open a file in Atom and then edit that file in some other program (e.g. vim), any changes outside of Atom won't reload the file in Atom and you can save over the changes.

### Description

If I make some changes within a file, which is linked with Git, it marks the changed lines. If I then discard my changes, the color of the filename changes from modified to grey, which is fine. But the modified lines won't get unselected and I still see those line if I've still open the file. If I close and open the file again, the lines are gone.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make some changes within a file within a Git Repository.
2. Save.
3. Discard the changes while the file with the changes is still open.

The current visible file should be refreshed.
The discarded changes should also be thrown away with the file you are currently looking at. Furthermore the modified lines color should disappear.

**Actual behavior:** 
The file doesn't show the new, discarded changes. It still has the "old version".

**Reproduces how often:** 
Every time.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.22.0
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Debian 9 (stretch)
Linux version 4.9.0-4-amd64 (debian-kernel@lists.debian.org) (gcc version 6.3.0 20170516 (Debian 6.3.0-18) ) #1 SMP Debian 4.9.51-1 (2017-09-28)

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
![screenshot_2017-11-21_09-53-28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29232849/33064225-431234c8-cea5-11e7-9e8b-e5d8c71fe80c.png)
Label: bug

Title: Support scope/language-specific fontFamily, lineHeight
Body:
The flight-manual lists a very limited set of [Language Specific Configuration Settings](http://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/#language-specific-configuration-settings).

As [discussed](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-can-i-specify-a-different-font-family-for-different-sources/33083/15), it would be great, if `fontFamily` and `lineHeight` could be supported as well. Then you could e.g. do:

    ".gfm.source":
      editor:
        lineHeight: 2
Label: enhancement

Title: Protocol handler - can't remove, does not fix path on upgrade
Body:
Right now there is no way to remove this OS integration and manually doing it involves registry hacking on Windows and who-knows-what on macOS.

I think the button should allow you to de-register using the Electron `removeAsDefaultProtocolClient(protocol[, path, args])` api.

Additionally the new remove code path should be called from squirrel-update.coffee on the `--squirrel-uninstall` path so we clean up properly and also it should be rewritten for the newest exepath if it exists on `--squirrel-updated` as the binary moves on Windows with every update.

cc @BinaryMuse
Label: bug

Title: Registration of protocol handler prompts when set to 'never'
Body:
I get this with every launch even when I set the config to never;

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/118951/32871886-7ee98b48-ca38-11e7-943a-d1cc4c934e36.png)

I put some debugging in and at run-time when it does the check it is 'prompt' although when I examine it with atom.config.get after launch it is 'never'.

I suspect the check happens too early in the start-up to get the actual value.

Additionally we want to make sure this dialog doesn't come up when running specs?  It looks like it interferes with some of the UI tests.  @BinaryMuse
Label: bug

Title: Use default theme instead of first theme in safe mode
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If the user has a custom theme selected and launches Atom in safe mode currently the first theme in the list is selected (`Atom Dark`). It would be great if Atom's default theme (`One Dark` currently) was used instead as it is a _much_ better theme, considering the Atom Dark themes have essentially had no updates in years.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select a custom theme (e.g Atom Material)
2. Launch Atom in Safe Mode

**Expected behavior:**

Atom's default theme (`One Dark`) is used.

**Actual behavior:**

The first theme in the list (`Atom Dark`) is used as a fallback.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Toggle line comments on blank line indents with spaces instead of tabs
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After the fix of the #15850, I guess, `editor:toggle-line-comments` works incorrectly in tab-indented file on empty indented lines.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open file with tab-based indentation
2. Go to the empty line
3. Indent
4. Run `editor:toggle-line-comments` (`ctrl-/`)

**Expected behavior:** Line indented by tabs (like the rest of the file) and starts with comment symbol(s).

```
» » foo
» » #·
```

**Actual behavior:** Indentation becomes by spaces.

```
» » foo
····#·
```

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

$ atom --version

Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.18.8
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.14
git 2.15.0
```

### Additional Information

No.

Title: editor: escape key no longer consolidates selections
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When using multiple cursors, I used to be able to press <kbd>esc</kbd> to go back to a single cursor.

On a recent build from master, pressing the escape key after creating multiple selections has no effect.

Note:  everything works _as expected_ in the 1.23 beta, so this must have been introduced recently.  Everything also works correctly when I use other commands (like `editor:add-selection-below`) to 

Everything also works correctly if I invoke `editor:consolidate-selections` from the command palette, so it appears that for whatever reason the escape key is no longer dispatching that command.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new editor
2. Create multiple cursors (either by using `editor:add-selection-below` or `find-and-replace:select-next`, for example).
3. Press the escape key

**Expected behavior:** All but one cursor goes away.

**Actual behavior:** Multiple cursors remain active

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```
? atom -version
Atom    : 1.24.0-dev-a1b09dcf1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
Label: bug

Title: When undo/redo, cursor is not restored on different editor where original change was made.
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
  * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Btw, this is very old issue, just I haven't opened issue.

When undo/redo-ing by `core:undo`, `core:redo`, cursor is restored and autoscroll happens appropriately.
So we can see textual change done by undo/redo.
But after copy-ing editor by `cmd-k right` and did undo/redo, cursor is no longer restored, autoscroll not happens, so textual changes happens in off-screen.

I noticed this behavior at about end of last year.
https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/617

In following GIF, I made `CHANGE-1` and `CHANGE-2` on editor-1, then split-and-copy editor.
Undo/redoing on this new editor does not scroll to textual changes. 
![change-happen-offscreen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/32737102-882f975e-c8dc-11e7-9c33-32745ffbf8ef.gif)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open editor-1, insert text in 3 different places. Each changes must be made in very different place which require editor scroll.
2. Undo/redo and see undo/redo restore cursor and scroll to restored cursor.
3. Split and copy active editor by `cmd-k right` then do undo/redo.
4. See cursor is not restored, no scroll-to-cursor happens. So textual changes by undo/redo happens at completely off-screen.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

When undo/redo-ing on editor I want to see changes, want cursor restored as long as underlying text-buffer is same.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Atom/text-buffer does not restore cursor and doesn't autoscroll to changes made by undo/redo.
So user cannot see changes.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.22.0
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

I also tried to find a way to **detect** if cursor restoration was happened or not on undo/redo timing by observing marker's change event.
But I couldn't find concrete way for that.
If this issue is not fixable, I still want to know the way to distinguish cursor restoration was succeeded or not on undo/redo timing.
Label: bug

Title: Main process gets into a state where input is blocked for hundreds of milliseconds
Body: The Atom main process is intermittently getting into a state where it blocks keyboard input for long period of time, on the order of 500ms or more. It's happened to me at least twice over the past few weeks. Nov 9th 2017: The timeline below happened today. I'm experiencing intermittent pauses of ~500ms. Notice there's no main thread JS being executed, but input handling is being delayed. ![screen shot 2017-11-09 at 5 22 19 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1789/32636802-9c0f2a4e-c573-11e7-818a-f492fcc2fc9d.png) Oct 17th 2017: Here I dug in deeper with native tracing on the main process. It definitely seems like we're blocking running some kind of script in the main process. To fully diagnose this, it would be helpful to upgrade to the latest Electron so it's easier to profile the main process with the standard dev tools. In the meantime though, we should probably consider precautionary action. * There is still some sync I/O happening in the main process. Could that be the culprit? It has no business being there anyway and should be eliminated. * Are we doing any spawning in the main process? We know that can be problematic. * Are we doing any output sync IPC in the main process? Lurking intermittent performance issues like this are the weakest link in our performance story. Getting into this state even a couple times a week is enough to undermine months of performance work spent on known code paths. We need to get to the bottom of this ASAP. /cc @as-cii @maxbrunsfeld @iolsen
Label: bug
