Title: Setting default text on atom-text-editor element does not work
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When creating a text editor through the DOM like `<atom-text-editor mini>Example text</atom-text-editor>`, the initial text content is not properly converted into actual buffer text.  The buffer correctly gets its content set: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/4fd0345e8488d2fa09151316b4e99656e7861644/src/text-editor-element.js#L92
but `this.textContent` is never cleared and the raw text is also displayed.
![duplicate-text-editor-text](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/26454371/e0aa5094-41a1-11e7-9921-df0e92a2a491.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an `atom-text-editor` tag that contains some text.
2. Render it.

**Expected behavior:** A TextEditor to be created which does not have any textContent, only buffer text

**Actual behavior:** A TextEditor with both textContent and buffer text

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-3a758eeb8
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

See also https://github.com/atom/styleguide/issues/58.  Maybe the Etch code is incorrect? https://github.com/atom/styleguide/blob/3111cb60f3f337ff77a190d306551160c645a663/lib/styleguide-view.js#L465
Label: bug

Title: Workspace Item API documentation is truncated
Body:
The [Workspace](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.21.2/Workspace) documentation has a section on "Workspace Items", which is truncated to just the following:

> ## Workspace Items
> 
> The term "item" refers to anything that can be displayed in a pane within the workspace, either in the [WorkspaceCenter](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.21.2/WorkspaceCenter) or in one of the three [Dock](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.21.2/Dock)s. The workspace expects items to conform to the following interface:
> 
> ### Required Methods
> #### `getTitle()`

However, the [documentation in source](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.21.2/src/workspace.js#L31) goes in-depth, describing the contract for `getTitle()` and numerous optional methods.
Label: bug

Title: Improve performance of converting screen position to pixel position
Body:
When calling `pixelPositionForScreenPosition` on a `TextEditorElement`, `TextEditorComponent` will unconditionally re-render itself:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/62774596919fdce190a1c5c6378f56535547aac3/src/text-editor-component.js#L196-L198

Instead, the following should happen:

* If the line is already on screen, it should just be measured.
* Otherwise, we should **partially** re-render the editor to account for the requested line, and then measure it.

Even with the above changes, however, `pixelPositionForScreenPosition` makes it inconvenient to measure multiple lines that are off-screen. In particular, calling it multiple times will cause layout thrashing because the editor component is unable to cluster writes and reads to and from the DOM due to the non-batched nature of the API. 

Therefore, I propose we introduce an additional API `getPixelPosition` or `pixelPositionForScreenPosition(position, {async: true})` on `TextEditorElement` that returns a `Promise`. Such promise will resolve when the position has been measured, allowing the component to batch consecutive requests to measure screen positions and fulfill them all in a single shot. 

The promise-based solution would also allow the component to decide *when* to measure a collection of screen positions, allowing us to defer the measurement until the next animation frame or in an idle callback.

/cc: @nathansobo
Label: enhancement

Title: editor:delete-to-previous-word-boundary and editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary does not work properly with newlines
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

editor:delete-to-previous-word-boundary and editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary does not work properly with newlines

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom and insert the following js code snippet
```javascript
function doubleNumber (num) {




  return num*2
}

```


2. Put your cursor before the `r` in return.  
3. Open command palette and run `Delete to previous word boundary`



**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Should go to the {

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
deletes the white space before the return and sees each newline as a new word.  


If you repeat this step by putting your cursor on the new line after the `{` and run `editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary`  It just deletes 1 newline but doesn't go to the return statement.


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-cbc2bdb20
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0


### Additional Information


This issue was broken out from  https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4026#issuecomment-338884328 from @bcorcoran and @PhiLhoSoft as it is a separate issue.
Label: bug

Title: Can we drop our application bundle size by removing snapshotted scripts?
Body:
In Spring 2017, [we shipped v8 snapshots](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14080) to improve startup time, which combine most of the source files that we ship into a single binary snapshot. Unfortunately, at that time we were unable to step the debugger through snapshotted code, which made us decide not to enable snapshots in development mode so that package authors could step through Atom source code when debugging their packages.

@as-cii, you mentioned that @hashseed had reached out to you with a patch that fixed the debugging issue. If we apply that in Electron, do you think we'll be in a position to remove any snapshotted scripts from the application bundle? It would save a ton of bandwidth for our users.

I think this is something we should follow up on fairly soon. The potential savings are huge and we've already done 95% of the work.

/cc @damieng @iolsen
Label: enhancement

Title: [Bug] text re-rendering on save
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    *  Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

### Description

When I hit `Cmd + S` to save some text i just changed, folded text above the current line is sometimes re-rendered to the right of what is already there.

2. Hit `Cmd + S` to save, and see text re-rendered

No re-rendering

re-rendering

Approximately 75% of the time

Title: Cannot show pane in workspace.open() without activating it
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Provide an option in workspace.open() to show a pane without activating it. Currently the activatePane option controls whether to activate the pane to which an item is added, and the dock containing the pane only shows itself when it is activated. Decoupling activation from display would allow the extension author to show an item without it taking input focus from the currently active pane.

### Steps to Reproduce

`workspace.open(URI, {activatePane: false, showPane: true})`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
show the pane without activating it

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
pane not shown if not currently visible

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
always

### Versions
latest

### Additional Information

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1722273630bf8b306ac34bb7b4b38ffa40135cab/src/dock.js#L58-L61
Label: enhancement

### Description

```
<embedded>:25444 Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
    at Project.module.exports.Project.setPaths (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/project.js:271:44)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/project.js:143:30
```
![screen shot 2017-10-25 at 1 34 06 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26739/32013452-30cb0f8c-b989-11e7-80ff-c763783d62ba.png)

Happens with or without `atom --safe .` 


### Steps to Reproduce

1. `git clone git@github.com:mozilla/balrog.git`
2. `cd balrog`
3. `docker-compose up`
3. `atom .`

Note. The `docker-compose up` creates a bunch of files in `.cache` and a bunch of files in `ui/node_modules`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
That it opens without errors and that I can open files.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
It never opens properly. No side-pane. See screenshot. 

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
Every time. 

### Versions

```
▶ atom --version
Atom    : 1.21.1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
▶ apm --version
apm  1.18.5
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.9.0
```

I'm on macOS Sierra, 10.12.6

### Additional Information

I don't know how to debug (or even share) what extensions I have installed that might affect this. 

Note that the error only happens *after* you've run `docker-compose up` which creates a bunch of files. But it's nevertheless reproducible. The files that are created should all be in `.gitignore`.
Label: bug

Title: Massive memory leak when opening projects with symlink loops
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Hi!
First of I know this sounds silly, but I experience this problem only when opening one of my projects, so bear with me.
When opening a ~checkout of my project (https://github.com/thetechnick/nginx-ingress)~ project folder in the size range of >150MB atoms memory consumption is rising constantly at about ~30 MiB per second until it reaches around 14GB and freezes my system.

First I suspected the golang plugin `go-plus` and `ide-go`, but now I have disabled all community packages and the `atom-fuzzyfinder` and the issue still occurs. (same for `--safe` and `--clear-window-state`

I have done a short CPU Profile in Chrome, but it shows nothing I can identify as a Problem:
[CPU-20171022T113255.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1404767/CPU-20171022T113255.zip)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open the project
2. Look at the `top`/`the gnome taks thingy` or whatever shows the amount of memory atom uses

**Actual behavior:** Atom allocates ~30 MiB of memory per second until it crashes the system

**Reproduces how often:** 15~20 times before opening this issue

### Versions

OS: Fedora 26

`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.21.1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

`apm --version`
apm  1.18.5
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.6

### Additional Information
- all community packages are disabled
- can reproduce this issue when opening the content of this ZIP in atom:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByW_Oz6LLJGWVVAwbUdoS3pwS00/view?usp=sharing
Label: bug

Title: Unfold all does not work
Body:
Reproduced by folding the last 2 describes in the `tree-view-package-spec.coffee` file and then trying to unfold all.

Repro steps from @ungb of gif:
1. checkout `https://github.com/atom/tree-view`
1. `atom tree-view`
1. open `tree-view-package-spec.coffee`
1. go to the bottom of the file.  
1. fold the last describe block at line `4141`
1. fold the second to last describe block at `4124`
1. put your cursor on line `4123` (dunno if it matters)
1. open command palette and run `unfold all`

**Expected:** all are unfolded

**Actual:**  all are unfolded but line `4124`.  If you try to unfold this line it won't do anything.
Also noticed that the carrot in the gutter looks like it's unfolded but it isn't.  If you click on the gutter twice it will unfold. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/31797404-f49ff98c-b4e2-11e7-88a5-e036d6ca30fc.png)


![unfold all](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1058982/31791223-377f0a42-b518-11e7-8f05-946a90ebf47f.gif)

/cc: @nathansobo since you could also reproduce @50Wliu since you have also seen folding issues
Label: bug

Title: window:reset-font-size behavior changed
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I think the functionality mentioned in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9060#issuecomment-145878664 has been changed to match the original poster's (on #9060) expectations.



### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set custom font size in Editor Settings that isn't 14 (the default default). For this example, assume 12.
2. Go to a document and CTRL + or CTRL - to increase/decrease font size (or CTRL+Scroll, as I often do by accident with a touchpad).
3. Press CTRL+0 to trigger window:reset-font-size.

**Expected behavior:**
Font size should be reset to 12.

**Actual behavior:**
Font size is cleared from configuration (set back to 14).

**Reproduces how often:**
100% of the time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.21.1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information
This was not previously the behavior (it used to reset to the value I set in Editor Settings), but I just noticed this today when I was using my laptop by itself (normally plugged into external display/keyboard/mouse).
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'toString' of undefined
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When the File System Watcher is set to be `Emulated with Atom events` and a new empty tab is opened an error is thrown to the Console.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set the File System Watcher to use emulated events
2. Open a new blank tab

**Expected behavior:**

No errors reported to the Console.

**Actual behavior:**

The following error is reported 2-3 times to the Console:
```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'toString' of undefined
    at Object.realpath (fs.js:1585:8)
    at Object.fs.realpath (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:338:25)
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:63:26
    at getRealPath (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:62:22)
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:72:36
    at Generator.next (<anonymous>)
    at step (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:5:279)
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:5:449
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\path-watcher.js:5:105
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\workspace.js:729:22
    at Function.module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\node_modules\event-kit\lib\emitter.js:25:20)
    at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.emit (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\node_modules\event-kit\lib\emitter.js:141:34)
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\workspace.js:583:34
    at C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\workspace.js:584:19
    at Function.module.exports.Emitter.simpleDispatch (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\node_modules\event-kit\lib\emitter.js:25:20)
    at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.emit (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\node_modules\event-kit\lib\emitter.js:141:34)
    at PaneContainer.didAddPaneItem (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\pane-container.js:270:24)
    at Pane.addItem (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\pane.js:632:48)
    at Pane.activateItem (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\pane.js:574:18)
    at Workspace.<anonymous> (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\workspace.js:1175:20)
    at Generator.next (<anonymous>)
    at step (C:\Users\abneyl\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.22.0-beta1\resources\app\src\workspace.js:11:279)
```

Note that on initially opening Atom it was only reported 2 times, switching the watcher to `native` events and then back to `emulated` causes it to be reported 3 times on each open.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.22.0-beta1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.8
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.14
git 2.14.2.windows.3
visual studio
```

OS: Windows 10 x64

### Additional Information

When the File System Watcher is set to use `Native operating system APIs` no errors are thrown to the Console.
Label: bug

Title: Difficult to select hard tabs
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When dragging to select a hard tab, the selection flickers between not selecting and selecting the hard tab.  I think the root problem may be that the halfway point of the tab isn't being calculated properly - in most programs, once you pass the halfway point of a tab, it should be highlighted, or in the case of moving the cursor, the cursor should be placed on the other side of the tab.  In Atom, this behavior is erratic.  I'll showcase a GIF of Atom and a GIF of the developer tools to visually explain the difference.

| Atom | Chrome |
| ------ | --------- |
| ![atom-hard-tab-selection](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2766036/31688405-8ca5a7b6-b38c-11e7-8eb2-3e46fd74ce43.gif) | ![chrome-hard-tab-selection](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2766036/31688414-91c74d80-b38c-11e7-8cf1-00029b590897.gif) |

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a hard tab
2. Place the cursor at one end of the hard tab
3. Attempt to select the hard tab

**Expected behavior:** Hard tab to be consistently selected past the halfway mark

**Actual behavior:** Selection flickers between hard tab being selected and not being selected

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-274b809b1
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```


### Additional Information

/cc @nathansobo: Possibly caused by the text editor rewrite?
Label: bug

Title: `atom --test` not showing exceptions, simply exiting with no message
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When running `atom --test spec` and there is a problem encountered that will not allow the tests to start, this is the result:

```
[master][~/Source/atom/keybinding-resolver] atom --test spec
Error Downloading Update: Could not get code signature for running application
[master][~/Source/atom/keybinding-resolver][1]
```

It turned out that the problem was that I had forgotten to run `apm install` on the repository before attempting to run the tests. When I finally attempted to run the tests in the GUI, I was able to find this in the JavaScript Console

```
Error: Cannot find module 'etch'
  at Module._resolveFilename (module.js:470:15)
  at Module._resolveFilename (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/electron.asar/common/reset-search-paths.js:35:12)
  ...
```

This led me to the solution of running `apm install`. We should output any exception like this at the command line to help people figure out why things aren't working.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Execute `git clone https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver.git ~/keybinding-resolver-test`
1. `cd ~/keybinding-resolver-test`
1. `atom --test spec`

**Expected behavior:** An exception message (or even better a real error message explaining the problem)

**Actual behavior:** Program simply exits with an unhelpful error code

### Versions

Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-dec47761f
Electron: 1.6.14
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.8
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.14.2
Label: bug

Title: [BUG] Fix resize behaviour when soft wrapping is enabled
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When soft wrap is enabled, resizing the window with a long file causes your current position in the file to be lost. This is because Atom seems to keep the viewport at a fixed position from the top of the file during a resize, causing the file content to be pushed down (by the addition of new soft wrap lines) and your current position in the file being lost.

Why is this feature important? Here are two common use cases where this issue occurs:

- Opening/closing a vertical split
- Toggling the tree view

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable soft wrapping (`preferences -> editor -> soft wrap`)
2. Open a long file and navigate to a position a decent way down the file (in my example below the file is 1000 lines long and I have the cursor on line 878)
3. Resize the window and observe your current position in the file being pushed down below the viewport

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

When a tab is resized, your current position in the file should stay visible within the viewport instead of being push down below the viewport due to the addition of soft tab lines.

This expected behaviour is the default behaviour in both VS Code and in Vim (maybe in other editors as well, they are the only two I tested).

Here is an example of the expected behaviour, in VS Code:

![gif_vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3773641/31256183-a5f9b176-aa7c-11e7-9b96-7793a05ac7e9.gif)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

When a tab is resized, the current position in the file is pushed down below the viewport by the extra soft wrapped lines being added to the file. This results in you losing your place in a file everytime you open a vertical split, toggle the tree view, etc.  Here is an example of this, using the same file and line number from the VS Code example above:

![gif_atom](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3773641/31256196-b3106ecc-aa7c-11e7-8eea-0cac38d5b8b0.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% of the time this is reproducable

### Versions

apm: 1.18.5
 Atom: 1.21.0 
OS: MacOS Sierra 10.12.3
Label: bug

Title: FR: Enable native/built-in spellchecking in atom
Body:
The [atom spell-check package is really cool](https://github.com/atom/spell-check), but I think it would be great to enable builtin system spellcheck (e.g. macOS builtin spellcheck) to also be able to work through atom.  It seems that this would enable a smoother (and more native-feel) UX, in addition to reducing the overhead required of atom (and associated packages).  Already customized dictionaries from the system would then automatically apply without requiring additional customization.

Other references for the same idea:
- [discuss.atom.io](https://discuss.atom.io/t/can-atom-use-native-mac-os-x-spellchecking-dictionaries-or-ui/35527)
- [stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39698458/atom-native-macos-spell-check-and-autocorrect)

Related points:
- https://github.com/atom/spell-check/issues/11
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom does not remember last-opened state if a spec window is closed last
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When a normal Atom window as well as an Atom spec window are open, closing the spec window last results in Atom attempting to save the state of the spec window rather than the actual project window.  Spec windows should probably be ignored when saving state.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open any project
2. Run specs using the GUI
3. Close the project window
4. Close the specs window
5. `atom` in terminal

**Expected behavior:** The project from step 1 to be reopened

**Actual behavior:** Atom appears un-maximized (same dimensions as the spec window) and with no project state.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-c30cc9bc8
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This may be harder to reproduce on macOS due to its special Quit behavior.
Label: bug

Title: Cursor jumps, changes are reverted after IME composition pops up on input-disabled-editor.
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When IME composition pops up on input-disabled-editor, it incorrectly create checkpoint.
After enable input and start insertion, buffer-state is reverted to wrongly created checkpoint(so cursor jumps, changes are reverted).

At final timing in GIF, text `a` is inserted elsewhere, and text-deletions are reverted.

![ime-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/31051857-69ddbd26-a6ae-11e7-9e6f-d5f7240cf547.gif)

**This is really critical issue for vim-mode-plus user who use IME(e.g. Japanese, Chinese)**
Since vim-mode-plus fundamentally depends on disable/enable input(`editor.component.setInputEnabled(true/false)`) to achieve modal-editing.

### Steps to Reproduce

##### Steps for explanatory purpose

1. Disable input `editor.component.setInputEnabled(false)`
2. Enable IME and pops up IME composition by entering some text.
3. Move cursor, also delete line by `editor:delete-line`(`ctrl-shift-K`).
4. Enable input `editor.composition.setInputEnabled(true)`.
5. Type some text to insert text.

At first char input timing.

- Char inserted at cursor position where last IME composition pop up happened.(position in step-2).
- Also all the buffer-text changes done after step-2 are **reverted**.


##### Steps for easy to observe.

1. Open non-empty editor.
2. Paste code bellow on chrome dev-console, at this point editor-input is disabled.

```javascript
(function emulateVimMode() {
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  editor.element.classList.add("vim-test")

  startInsert = () => {
    if (!editor.component.isInputEnabled()) {
      editor.component.setInputEnabled(true)
      console.log("start insert")
    }
  }
  stopInsert = () => {
    if (editor.component.isInputEnabled()) {
      editor.component.setInputEnabled(false)
      console.log("stop insert")
    }
  }

  atom.commands.add(editor.element, {
    "vim-test:start-insert": () => startInsert()
    "vim-test:stop-insert": () => stopInsert()
  })
  stopInsert()
})()
```

3. Enable IME and type some keys to make IME composition pops up then stop IME.
4. Move cursor, also delete line by `editor:delete-line`(`ctrl-shift-K`).
5. Enable input by executing `vim-test:start-insert` via command-palette.
6. Type some text to insert text.(see cursor jumps, changes are reverted)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Text is inserted at cursor position and changes are NOT reverted.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Text is inserted at different position and all changes are reverted.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% with safe-mode

### Versions

Issue not happens in v.1.18, so I believe this issue started after editor-rewrite.

- Could reproduce: v1.19.7, 1.20, 1.21-beta2

```
Atom    : 1.19.7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.20.1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.21.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

- could NOT reproduce: v1.18.0(haven't check all patch versions)

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

- Original issue in vim-mode-plus
https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/875


Other reported issue like "content reverted" might shares same cause with this issue.
al
Label: bug

Title: Dock Handle for Git Tab (right hand dock) not available
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Windows 10 Pro 64ibt
Atom 1.20.1 x64
Dell 4K monitors

I don’t know the name of the UI element that shows up when you hover over the Tree View and Git Tab. It’s a half circle with > or < that allows one to toggle these panes. Dock Handle?

InTree View this UI element shows up when you have the pane open or close by hovering the pane when open and close to the edge of the window when closed. It’s working correctly when the Atom interface is anything else except Maximized

On the Git Tab it does not show up when the tab is closed and one hovers close to the edge or on the edge AND the app window is maximized. It worked as expected when this feature first came available but the last 4, or so, updates it has not worked correctly. If I don’t have the editor sized maximized I can use it by hovering over the right edge of the editor. The half circle slides into view.
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom > Window Maximized >Toggle Git Tab 

**Expected behavior:** I expect the tab handle to appear on mouseover

**Actual behavior:** Tab handle does not show up

**Reproduces how often:**  100% of the time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.20.1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
![git-tab](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/759023/30777443-dfffe3e0-a077-11e7-8532-e05549bc90e8.png)
Label: bug

### Description
The popup panel will jump from top left corner to the bottom of current line when using Chinese pinyin IME(includes macOS built-in and squirrel and others).

It should keep under the bottom of current line.

### Steps to Reproduce

2. Choose a Chinese IME
3. Try to input something

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/30604864-ef5eee4e-9d20-11e7-8ace-8d6ad21e8558.gif)

You can see more [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14911#issuecomment-330604185) and [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14911#issuecomment-330606144)

**Expected behavior:** The popup should keep under current line, not jump from top left corner.

**Actual behavior:** The popup jump from top left corner when try to type something.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

Title: Soft wrap flickering when very close to needing a vertical scrollbar
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

It seems that when the editor height is very close to needing a vertical scrollbar, soft-wrapped lines will rapidly flicker.  Possibly the vertical scrollbar is showing up for a fraction of a second before realizing it's not needed and hiding again.  On occasion, the cursor is also rendered incorrectly.  In the GIF, it is incorrectly appearing as a blue block below the line where the cursor actually is.

### Steps to Reproduce

This might be difficult to repro because on my screen there's only two pixels before the scrollbar is required.

1. Have a file with soft-wrapped lines that _almost_ reaches the threshold necessary for vertical scrollbars to appear
2. Move your cursor around the file, make some random selections, etc.

**Expected behavior:** Editor contents to stay static

**Actual behavior:** Soft-wrapped lines jump around as the scrollbar appearance is constantly recalculated

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

![uh](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2766036/30564290-d83a26cc-9cc4-11e7-8f96-ac8db91fe700.gif)

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.22.0-dev-b269b2086
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

If it's helpful, here's the contents of the file I was working on: https://gist.github.com/50Wliu/6d516fd9b32c1191303a5ac64ff39fe7

/cc: @nathansobo @ungb
Label: bug

Title: Text is pulsating at regular intervals in v1.21.0-beta0
Body:
### Updated Repro Steps from @ungb (consolidating info from this issue):
1. `apm install minimal-syntax-dark`
1. Open atom and set the following for your theme:
UI Theme: One Dark
Syntax Theme: Minimal Dark
1. Open `styles.less` and add the following and save:
```less
atom-text-editor .cursor {
  transition: opacity 0.333s;
}
```

1. Look at the less file where the number `0.333s` is:
![pulsing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/31413621-06f7a686-adcf-11e7-88b8-0e2c32927b61.gif)


### Description

![atom-pulsating-text](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3703530/30348478-c6336416-980f-11e7-823a-900f7f5d4b12.gif)

I have a `transition: opacity 0.333s` on my cursor element, which causes this annoying pulsating effect. I assume that the transition causes Chromium to switch to a different way of rendering the texts, and voila. This was not an issue in either v1.19(.7?, latest stable version) or v1.20 (beta7 I think?), both used today.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install `minimal-syntax-dark` (or add the transition on the cursor manually)
2. Create an empty JavaScript file
3. Enter some basic code, like `const test = "test"`

**Expected behavior:**

No pulsating text.

**Actual behavior:**

See .gif in description.

**Reproduces how often:**

Consistently.

### Versions

Atom v1.21.0-beta0 on macOS SIerra 10.12.6
Label: bug

Title: Revert buffer / Revert to saved / Refresh from source
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[`revert-buffer` package](https://github.com/atom/revert-buffer/issues/3) should be rolled into core.  This package has zero documentation and appears to not be maintained. 

The functionality provided by this tiny package is just a single command to reset the buffered text to the content saved on disk. I am quite surprised this functionality is not already in core. We shouldn't need to install a package to do this. 

Atom should move this to core and make it available to various menus and deal with any open issues brought up on that package's repo.

### Steps to Reproduce

**Expected behavior:** 
Opening `File` menu or context clicking on a file in `Tree View` or typing `"revert` into `Command Palette` displays an option to revert file to it's saved state. `File` menu and `Command Palette` also displays the wisely selected default hotkey for this command.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
In order to revert file to saved, I must close and reopen the file or install the undocumented and poorly interfaced `revert-buffer` package.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Windows:    10
Atom    : 1.19.6
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio

### Additional Information

None
Label: enhancement

Title: Editor is empty if you scroll up after splitting

1. Open Atom in that folder

1. Close the preview using the X icon on the preview
1. `pane:split-right-and-copy-active-item`

Title: [1.19.6/1.20.0-beta6] Block decorations mess up editor content when destroyed
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Block decorations mess up line numbers and editor content once destroyed.
The issue was originally reported by @srk-srinivasan on the Hydrogen repo: https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen/issues/981

This worked correctly till Atom 1.19.5 and 1.20.0-beta5.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open file with a few lines of code
2. Execute the following code in dev tools:
```js
function createBlock(row) {
  const item = document.createElement("span");
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]\n[block decoration]\n[block decoration]";
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor();
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([row, 0]);
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: item });
  return marker;
}

const marker = createBlock(5);
```

3. Destroy marker with
```js
marker.destroy();
```

**Expected behavior: (Atom 1.19.5 / 1.20.0-beta5)**
Editor correctly renders as if the block decoration was never there.

**Actual behavior: (Atom 1.19.6 / 1.20.0-beta6)**
Editor doesn't correctly re-render and messes up line numbering and editor content:
![destroy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/30168951-3632efee-93eb-11e7-95f0-9df28a50a798.gif)


**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom 1.19.6 and 1.20.0-beta6

### Additional Information

@as-cii This regression was likely introduced in #15503 or #15528
Label: bug

Title: Cursor rendered incorrectly when horizontalPixelPositions are measured while not visible
Body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Cursor is rendered in incorrectly when cursor style updated when editor is not visible. ![cursor-displayed-wrong-position](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/30166338-f693b408-941d-11e7-965b-00fdbc8ed038.gif) Condition this happens is - Cursor's style is updated when editor is not active pane item(= not visible in screen) - In addition to update style, cursor has to be moved(without no move, issue not happen). When issue happened cursor's style's `translation`, `width` is not measured correctly, result in rendered incorrectly. Following GIF is before and after the cursor move right by `ctrl-f` after I reproduce issue. Notice lower GIF have odd width, translate value. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Prepare following style in your `style.less`. ```less atom-text-editor.test-cursor-marker { &.is-focused { .cursor { border: none; background: none; opacity: 0.5; background-color: @syntax-cursor-color; visibility: visible; } } } ``` 2. open editor-1 and set text "aaa". and open another editor-2. 3. Set editor-1 active. place cursor at eol of first line. 4. open chrome-dev console and paste following code. ```javascript (function reproduceIssue() { const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor() atom.workspace.onDidChangeActivePaneItem(item => { if (item !== editor) { editor.moveLeft() // This is necessary editor.element.classList.add("test-cursor-marker") } }) })() ``` 5. click editor-2's tab, then click editor-1's tab(re-activate) 6. See cursor style become odd. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Cursor is rendered correctly after tab-switch and back. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Cursor is rendered incorrectly after tab-switch and back. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100%, in safe-mode. ### Versions Can reproduce ``` Atom : 1.20.0-beta5 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` Cannot reproduce with 1.18.0(so I believe this issue introduced by editor-rewrite). ### Additional Information Actual Issue in vim-mode-plus is here https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/855
Label: bug

Title: Open with Atom option for multiple files opens each file in different instance
Body:

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### "Open with Atom option" for multiple files opens each file in different instance

Opening multiple files using systems context menu by selecting multiple files causing the opening of each file in different instance

1. Select multiple files.

Node : 7.4.0

Windows 10 Pro 32 bit

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: Add the TextEditor.element to the public API
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I would like to request that the `TextEditor.element` property be added to the public API, because it contains very helpful methods for package development such as the `getFirstVisibleScreenRow()` and `getLastVisibleScreenRow()`, which return which are the lines that are currently visible in an editor.

Note: I am also using these methods on my own package: [srt-helper](https://atom.io/packages/srt-helper). Previously I was using the `TextEditor.presenter.startRow` and `TextEditor.presenter.endRow` properties, but since the `presenter` no longer exists I had to start using the `element` property. This is another reason that I would like to request that the `TextEditor.element` be added to the public API: so that my package remains stable on the next versions of Atom.

### Steps to Reproduce

N/A

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.5
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS: Windows 10

### Additional Information

Link to discussion in the Atom forums: https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-get-visible-lines-numbers-in-atom-editor/47065/7
Label: enhancement

Title: Opening a split causes original pane's scroll position to reset
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After splitting a pane, the original pane's scroll position appears to reset to (0, 0).  This is most noticeable when attempting to horizontally scroll the original pane.

![file-position-reset](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2766036/30082487-40ddbd90-928b-11e7-8794-4d6f1605eaa1.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file
2. `pane:split-<direction>-and-copy-active-item` (note: I have only tested with `right`)
3. If there is no horizontal scrollbar, resize the panes so that the original pane can be horizontally scrolled
4. Look at the scrollbar positions of the original pane and then attempt to horizontally scroll

**Expected behavior:** Scrollbars to correctly represent where the current file is, and for horizontally scrolling to horizontally scroll the file while maintaining the vertical position

**Actual behavior:** Both scrollbars reset to (0, 0) - that is, the vertical scrollbar resets to the top and the horizontal scrollbar resets to the left.  When attempting to horizontally scroll, the file position is reset to the top of the file.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.22.0-dev-700fdc592
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

/cc: @as-cii @nathansobo
Label: bug

Title: MacOS Opening native tab toggles fullscreen
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In MacOS when the "Prefer tabs when opening documents" is set to "Always", File->Open on a non-fullscreen session will toggle the fullscreen if atom remembers the new project as being fullscreen. This is really annoying when I open new tabs and get jerked out of my element into fullscreen. Atom should not toggle fullscreen when opening a new tab, only a new window.

### Steps to Reproduce

First we set up the scenario:
1. Navigate to ```Dock``` in the macOS System Preferences
2. Change ```Prefer tabs when opening documents:``` to ```Always```
3. Open up atom to a directory
4. File->Open another directory (You should now have 2 native tabs in the same window)
5. Enter the macOS native fullscreen mode
6. Close one of the native tabs [Taking note of that path] (So only one project is left open now)
7. Exit native fullscreen
8. Quit Atom

Now we can reproduce the bug:
1. Open up atom to the directory that was last open (Atom should open and NOT enter fullscreen)
2. Now File->Open the path you took note of in step 6

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
The new native tab should open and the app should not enter native fullscreen.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
The app enters native fullscreen.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% of the time

### Versions

Atom: 1.17.2
MacOS: 10.12.6

![out](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6372893/30006052-712a1ab6-90b5-11e7-83c8-a7c02318ad9f.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Highlight decorations on large ranges inconsistently rendered
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Decorations of type `highlight` (possibly others) that cover a large range are inconsistently rendered in the editor.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install [large-decoration.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1264748/large-decoration.zip) as a package.
2. Open Atom.
3. Trigger `Large Decoration: Decorate` from the Command Palette

**Expected behavior:**

The entire text should be decorated with an underline.

**Actual behavior:**

The underline is inconsistently applied, skipping entire lines in a repeating pattern:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/29890018-027760a2-8d7b-11e7-940d-87c6506ed54e.png)

It looks like what's happening here is the highlights are in a separate `<div>`, and for some reason instead of creating one sub-`<div>` for each line, it creates only two: One for the first line and one that "covers" the rest of the lines in a "rendering block" which seems to contain 6 lines in the `TextEditor`.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/29890386-46f5644e-8d7c-11e7-9280-d78ac4a7bc4c.png)


**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.20.0-beta5
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.14.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Note: This has been reported by users since at least the v1.19.0 betas, possibly earlier.

### Additional Information

Originally reported in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/398, but I'm unsure how long this has been an issue.
Label: bug

Title: uninstaller to remove all leftovers(clean uninstall tool)[FR] - Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Why not have an uninstaller for atom separately since the atom doesn't completely uninstall in windows.
A lot of leftovers are left behind.

Mostly while reinstalling atom. It doesn't install properly due to registry errors(leftovers) and leftovers of the previous installation

I have added few leftovers of uninstallation. one or two may be removed automatically by windows, but most of them isn't removed. Having to tool to clean this automatically would be nice.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Uninstall atom with windows uninstaller

**Expected behavior:**  The uninstaller should Remove all the unwanted registry entries(Invalid entries) that are not needed when atom is uninstalled

**Actual behavior:** Leftovers are not removed properly which sometimes causes installation problem when we install atom back

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions
Version: All
OS: WIndows 

### Additional Information
Some leftovers that are easily found are
**Folders**
```
C:\Users\{user_name}\.atom
C:\Users\{user_name}\AppData\Local\atom
C:\Users\{user_name}\AppData\Roaming
```
**Registry Entries**
```
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\*\shell\Atom
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\.atom
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\atom.exe
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\Background\shell\Atom (this creates problems with adding atom to context menu)
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\shell\Atom
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\*\shell\Atom
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\Applications\atom.exe
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\Directory\Background\shell\Atom
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\Directory\shell\Atom
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Editor Scrolls Down When Clicking Directly Above Horizontal Scrollbar
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The editor view scrolls down/up if you click near the bottom/top of the page. This is particularly annoying because whenever I try to scroll horizontally, the editor scrolls down. Is there anyway to fix this?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Click right above the horizontal scrollbar
3. The editor window scrolls down

**Expected behavior:** The editor does not scroll

**Actual behavior:** The editor scrolls down

Gif from @rsese https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15489#issuecomment-325751074

![click-scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/734194/29837029-a65cbfec-8cbc-11e7-9ce4-085329e95390.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

### Versions 1.19.4

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

I'm running macOS Sierra version 10.12.6

From @rsese:

Should set `System Preferences > General > Show scroll bars` to `Always`.

Doesn't reproduce in 1.18.0.
Label: bug

Title: Clicking on either scrollbar moves the cursor in the editor
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Clicking on either scrollbar moves the cursor in the editor, which, as a side effect, deselects any text you've selected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open any text file
2. Select some text
3. Click/drag on either scrollbar and note the position of the cursor

**Expected behavior:** Clicking on a scrollbar has no effect on the cursor's position

**Actual behavior:** Clicking on a scrollbar affects the cursor's position

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.19.4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 3.5.2
git 2.12.2.windows.2
visual studio 2015
```

On Windows 10. This bug was also present in Atom 1.19.3

### Additional Information

It seems others started noticing this problem recently as well:
* https://discuss.atom.io/t/clicking-on-scrollbar-moves-cursor-in-the-editor-erratically/46732
* https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3284#issuecomment-324958746
Label: bug

Title: Middle-clicking causing scroll to show up instead of closing tabs if atom has multiple tabs open
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Middle-clicking causing scroll to show up instead of closing tabs if atom has multiple tabs open

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a empty atom window
2. open a new tab like 20 times `cmd+n` on mac
3. middle click on a tab

**NOTE**: on mouse up of middle click on mouse, it causes a scroller to pop up to get rid of the scroller you have to click again.
Gif:

![scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/29781715-fdf4b80c-8bce-11e7-9232-c8332c78ae6c.gif)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Closes the tab

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Scroller pops up that lets you scroll.


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions


```
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

```

This issue is verified that it is occurring on Mac and Windows. 

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information
This use to work in 1.19.2 and broke in 1.19.3.  Related to change in https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/515


Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

/cc Both @Ben3eeE and @MattCz reported this issue.
/cc @nathansobo @as-cii this is a regression from https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/515
Label: bug

Title: Scroll bars not showing in center pane items
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Scroll bars not showing in pane items (text editors, settings view, etc)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Go to System Preferences
1. Click General
2. Set "Show Scroll Bars" to "Always"
1. Launch Atom in your local Atom repository
1. Open `README.md`

**Expected behavior:** Scroll bars are visible in the text editor

**Actual behavior:** Scroll bars are only visible in the tree view

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.14.0
```

### Additional Information

Reproduces no matter what the OS preference is for scroll bars, "Always" just makes it more obvious.
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'id' of undefined
Body:
Steps to reproduce by @mangecoeur https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15441#issuecomment-325651325

[test.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1260242/test.zip)

Steps:

1. unzip the file and open test.md in atom
1. Make the Atom Window narrow
1. trigger `preview-inline` on BOTH image links
1. Scroll up and down
-> Error seems to be triggered when the top of the block decoration of the first decoration enters or exits the viewable window.
1. Close the first preview
-> Error seems to be triggered when the top of the block decoration of the remainding decoration enters or exits the viewable window. NOTE that if you close the second preview, but keep the first, the error is not triggered `¯\_(ツ)_/¯`

Title: File save dialog does not get focus
Body:
### Description

### Steps to Reproduce

Title: Request: Maintain Assigned Syntax of Unsaved Buffers
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Syntax assigned to unsaved buffers is not preserved when restarting Atom.

I do a lot of work that involves editing HTML fragments, often from locations that either aren't directly editable or have no syntax highlighting. I will usually copy this into Atom, make the necessary changes, and paste it back. This provides a lot more than just syntax highlighting, such as auto-complete and auto-indent. However, if I restart Atom or my PC, the assigned syntax is lost and I have to re-assign it every time, on all buffers - there's no point in saving the copied HTML to actual files, as I'd have to regularly clean these files from my computer.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom and add a project root
2. Open a new tab and add some content in a defined language, e.g. HTML or Python
3. Assign the correct syntax to the buffer
3. Do not save the content to a file
4. Restart Atom

**Expected behavior:** Atom re-opens with everything - content, settings, etc - preserved

**Actual behavior:** Atom re-opens with syntax set to plain text on unsaved buffers

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time, every time

### Versions

1.17.2 when I first started using Atom, currently on 1.19.2 ia32 and this behaviour has always been consistent. OS is 64-bit Windows 10 Pro 15063.483 running on an i5-6400 with 8GB RAM.
Label: enhancement

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'firstChild' of undefined
Body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

Opened sidebar of conflicts in files after doing a pull on a branch... Some popups started appearing that stated the issue was already reported, so I closed the sidebar. The popups kept showing up, and then some showed up that prompted me to create an issue, so I assumed it was a different one.

Only showed up when I was on the tab of the conflicted file! I changed to tab of settings and the popups stopped, and started again when I switched back to my conflicted file. As soon as I resolved the conflict issues, the popups stopped. I still have another conflicted file to correct, will update this to see if behaviour is the same.

So it seems only after opening the git tab (where it shows on the bottom right corner of the screen how many files have conflicts) the errors occur, since I switched to my second conflicted file and was able to scroll (although unsure if the markup of "ours vs theirs" changes had updated already, since I didn't see anything). Then again the same, even after closing the tab, whenever I scroll more errors are thrown.

**Atom**: 1.19.1 ia32
**Electron**: 1.6.9
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 10 Home
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'firstChild' of undefined

```
At C:\Users\Marta\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.19.1\resources\app\src\text-editor-component.js:2171

TypeError: Cannot read property 'firstChild' of undefined
    at TextEditorComponent.measureLongestLineWidth (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.19.1/resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:2171:112)
    at TextEditorComponent.measureContentDuringUpdateSync (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.19.1/resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:383:16)
    at scheduler.readDocument (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.19.1/resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:270:20)
    at ViewRegistry.module.exports.ViewRegistry.performDocumentUpdate (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.19.1/resources/app/src/view-registry.js:191:15)
    at ~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.19.1/resources/app/src/view-registry.js:3:65
```

### Commands

```
```

### Non-Core Packages

Title: control-mousewheel to zoom font may throw uncaught type error
Body:
Version: 1.19.1 x64 on mac

Steps to reproduce:
Start atom in safe mode: `atom --safe`

Download and open this markdown file: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/twineworks/tweakflow/master/site/content/reference.md

Scroll down to about line 200.

Press ctrl and use your mouse wheel to zoom the font.

An exception appears:
```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:2171
Hide Stack Trace
TypeError: Cannot read property 'firstChild' of undefined
    at TextEditorComponent.measureLongestLineWidth (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:2171:112)
    at TextEditorComponent.measureContentDuringUpdateSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:383:16)
    at scheduler.readDocument (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor-component.js:270:20)
    at ViewRegistry.module.exports.ViewRegistry.performDocumentUpdate (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/view-registry.js:191:15)
```

After that atom becomes unstable and many actions generate follow up errors.

Thanks to @Ben3eeE for helping to find a usable repro path!
Label: bug

Title: [Bug] Code folding does not apply consistently to JS files
Body:

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
