### Description

Code folding does not apply consistently to JS files

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Edit a JS file
2. execute editor:fold-at-indent-level-1 (ctrl-k ctrl-1)


**Expected behavior:** All functions should be folded (as per previous versions)

**Actual behavior:** Some functions are folded, some are not

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
Running Beta to see if this was also an issue in Beta (it is), but first saw this on the current production version.

Atom    : 1.20.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information
Here is some sample code to use (custom JS layout used within an app)

The 2nd function doesn't get folded at all

```
pageOnLoadChecks : function() {
	var AuthorisedUserIDs = new Array('ddfdfd','dfdfdfd');

},

onChangeQuestion_SI_89847 : function(obj) { //handset colour 
	if(a == b){
		c = a;
	}

},
//apply current pricing until change date
pricingChanges : function() {

}
```
Label: bug

Title: [Bug] Scroll Sensitivity doesn't change
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After upgrading Atom from 1.18.0 (or 1.18.1, I don't remember) to 1.19.1, changing scroll sensitivity in settings doesn't produce changing of scroll sensitivity in text editor.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom
2. Go to editor settings: edit > editor
3. Change value in scroll sensitivity section.
4. Open text file and check for changes.

**Expected behavior:** Changing value in scroll sensitivity section produce changing amount of lines, scrolled by mouse wheel down action.

**Actual behavior:** Changing value in scroll sensitivity section doesn't produce changing amount of lines, scrolled by mouse wheel down action.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Linux Mint 18.2 Cinnamon x64
Kernel: 4.10.0-32-generic

### Additional Information

[empty]
Label: bug

Title: [FEATURE REQUEST] Expose option to allow / disallow updates of Packages.
Body:
### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * ~~Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/~~ _not a bug_ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description [Description of the issue] ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open Atom, close all open panes 2. Open development console 3. Open Settings >> Updates (do not trigger button for getting updates) 4. Close Atom 5. Disconnect from internet 6. Open Atom 5. Observe messages in console (2) and settings (3) (Reopen if required) 6. Reload Atom by `ctrl-shift-f5' 7. Observe messages in console (2) and settings (3) 8. Re-do (6) and (7). **Expected behaviour:** Reload of Packages should not update so soon after being updated a short time earlier. If the internet connection is not there, the message should not be an ERROR but rather a WARNING. Suggest to have the user selectable option to not have the system update the packages. This option is available for the core. **Actual behaviour:** [What actually happens] Each time Atom is reloaded, the package updating is triggered. An ERROR is triggered if the connection is not made, influencing start-up times. **Reproduces how often:** Always ### Versions Atom V1.19 under Windows7 SP1 ### Additional Information (Full Description) SUBJECT: [FEATURE REQUEST] Expose option to allow / disallow updates of Packages. Good day. May this message find you well. #### Symptoms The behaviour is observed Atom V1.19 under Windows7 SP1. Each time Atom is reloaded (opening Atom | command: `reload()` | shortcut: `ctrl-shift-f5`) the update service for the Packages is triggered. This happens _each_ time a reload occurs, regardless of time gone by since the last trigger. #### Problem The impact of triggering the `update of Packages` is most prominently observed when regular `reload()` is done in the process of developing customizations for Atom. This behaviour causes extended start-up time especially when working offline from the internet. Also consumption of internet data is a concern for those who use expensive (capped) mobile data as internet source. Some more details can be found on.. [Atom community discussion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-prevent-atom-to-update-packages-at-each-reload/45638) The mechanism of the `update of Packages` is here: [Link to code](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/blob/ea7f18e089fcd4fbcb549aa04dd963437e26f2c0/lib/main.coffee#L70) #### Suggestions 1. Record the time of last `update of Packages`. Do not execute the update if the elapsed time is too short. 2. Expose the option as a setting to prevent the `update of Packages` to occur. This is the same concept as "Automatic Update" option in the "Core Settings". ![Automatic Updates only applied for CORE](https://cdn-business.discourse.org/uploads/github_atom/original/3X/1/0/10027aa2523229818dcc9058781ce9ca212606c7.png) 3. Downgrade the message from ERROR to WARNING that tells the user that an internet connection could not be made. ![ERROR: having no internet connection is a sin](https://cdn-business.discourse.org/uploads/github_atom/original/3X/c/e/ce0432891c088e6a6b764fcc636f4c754a926092.png) Best regards,
  dP
Label: enhancement

Title: Block decoration scrolls instead of registering mouse clicks
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When interacting with a block decoration near the bottom of the text editor, the decoration scrolls up instead of registering the click event:

![scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/29250800-3ed964f8-8049-11e7-8ceb-97c405851c0b.gif)


This issue came up with the [Hydrogen](https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen) package which uses block decorations to display interactive outputs with "clickable" elements. But this is a general problem also present in safe mode.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file with at least 10 to 20 lines of code
2. Run the following code in the dev tools:
```js
function createBlock(row) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  const item = document.createElement("span");
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]\n".repeat(10);
  const button = document.createElement("button");
  button.innerText = "Click me!"
  button.addEventListener('click', () => {
    alert("CLICK!")
  });
  div.appendChild(item);
  div.appendChild(button);
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor();
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([row, 0]);
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: div });
}

createBlock(8)
```
3. Scroll the block decoration to the bottom of the text editor and try to click the button.

**Expected behavior:** The button click is registered and a alert box pops up.

**Actual behavior:** The editor scrolls up and the click isn't registered. A second click on the button is necessary to show the pop up.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS 10.12.6:
- Atom 1.20.0-beta0
- Atom 1.19.0
Label: bug

Title: Quickly input enter and quickly delete enter,  package makes atom crashed.
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Quickly input enter and quickly delete enter, atom crashed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install my package [backspace-until-not-whitespace](https://atom.io/packages/backspace-until-not-whitespace).

2. Open a file.
3. Write a lines with a tab at beginning like this:
```
    aaaa
```
4. Save the file (e.g. "test.html")
5. Move the cursor to the end of line.
6. Press enter to create a new line.
7. Quickly press backspace to delete the new line.
8. Repeat step5 and step6 for about two or three times.

![packagetc480](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29246905-c19b49c6-8038-11e7-939f-20b06156881e.gif)


![imagexxx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29246903-b835fb24-8038-11e7-815e-47b04718f37b.png)


**Expected behavior:** Not crash.

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashed.

**Reproduces how often:** About over 90%.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

OS: macOS Sierra Version 10.12.6

### Additional Information
I have disabled all the other community packages, and even disabled language-html and language-xml, only left my package as mentioned in step1.
I think my package is invoking some atom api not correctly so the atom crashed. 
I tried the steps in atom 20.0, also crashed.

Title: No elevation of privilege prompt when attempting to edit files owned by root
Body:
Prior to v1.19, when attempting to save over a file that is owned by root on macOS, Atom would prompt for elevated permissions. It doesn't any longer and just gives an error.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom with `atom --safe /etc/profile`
1. Type `# testtesttest` and press <kbd>Enter</kbd> on the first line of the file
1. Save the file with <kbd>Cmd+S</kbd>

**Expected:** Dialog comes up asking for privilege elevation
**Actual:** Permission denied notification

## Versions

### Atom

```
Atom: 1.21.0-dev-b0622d224
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome: 56.0.2924.87
Node: 7.4.0
```

### apm

```
apm  1.18.3
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.14.0

```

### OS

Mac OS X 10.12.6

Title: Horizontal scrolling is always favored over vertical scrolling
Body:
Hey,

I can't see anything about it in the release notes but it's possible I've missed something. I've just updated to Atom 1.19.0 (OS X 10.12.6, MacBook Pro) and for some reason the horizontal scroll seems to have started catching when it shouldn't. It's hard to explain but, if you're using two fingers on the trackpad to vertically scroll up and down a file then, since the update, as you scroll it seems to catch horizontally much more often and start scrolling that way instead.

Has any of the sensitivity been changed? Am I missing something?

---

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On long files where horizontal scrolling is possible the horizontal scrolling sensitivity is now higher and kicks in when scrolling vertically.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make sure you're using a Mac.
2. Get a long file with lines that exceed the width of the screen.
3. Use two fingers on the trackpad to scroll vertically down the screen, if your fingers are at anything other than perfectly aligned then the horizontal scroll kicks in much sooner than it did before.

**Expected behavior:**

To scroll vertically, smoothly.

**Actual behavior:**

As you scroll vertically, it start scrolling horizontally

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Label: bug

Title: Pressing "Cancel" on an unsaved buffer dialog will not cancel a restart
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

**Pressing "Cancel" on the unsaved buffer dialog will not cancel a restart**

Atom requests a restart in some situations, such as when a plugin has been updated. If one has an unsaved buffer open in a project-less window, after pressing "restart", the normal unsaved file dialog is presented with, on macOS at least, "Save", "Don't Save", and "Cancel" buttons. In this scenario, "Save" and "Don't Save" work as expected, but pressing "Cancel" will immediately re-present the same dialog. This can be especially problematic when the unsaved buffer is in another tab in the same window as one cannot switch tabs to inspect the file and determine if it should be saved or not.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new project-less window and buffer
2. Type in some content
3. Trigger a restart by either updating plugins or opening a developer console and entering `atom.restartApplication()`
4. Press "Cancel"

**Expected behavior:**
The restart operation should be canceled, returning me to the state I was in before I pressed "restart".

**Actual behavior:**
I am immediately presented with the same unsaved buffer dialog

**Reproduces how often:**
Every time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
macOS: 10.12.6
Label: bug

Title: Weird when editing text which is partial selected. (with required Prerequisites)
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Select a part of a string and type a letter, the selection should disappear but not move to the right part of the string, this is a DEMO


![demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29136116-cede213e-7d6e-11e7-89b6-916e08ab2999.gif)



### Steps to Reproduce

1. File -> New File;
2. Input a string `aaaaabbbbbccccc`;
3. Select the middle part of the string `bbbbb`;
4. While still holding down the mouse button. Type a letter `x`;

**Expected behavior:** The text becomes `aaaaaxccccc` and no charcters are selected.

**Actual behavior:** The text becomes `aaaaaxccccc` but the middle 4 `c` are selected.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% reproduce.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

MacOS Sierra 10.12.6 

### Additional Information
I did the steps more than 10 times, every time it reproduce. But it will not reproduce when you use undo to get the selection back after type the letter `x`, like typing `cmd-z`.

Another problem is when I select some strings and hit backspace, the selected strings are deleted but strings next to the deleted one are automatically selected.
Label: bug

Title: TextBuffer::onDidReload never fires for external changes
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`TextEditor::onDidReload` appears to not be firing, at least within the 10 second timeout of package specs.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Check out [`linter-eslint@8.2.1`](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/tree/v8.2.1)
2. Run the package specs
3. Note that [two](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L241) [specs](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L285) are failing.

**Expected behavior:**

`TextEditor::onDidReload` fires when the file is reloaded due to the external process changing the file.

**Actual behavior:**

The specs are expecting [a notification](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L92-L95) that the fix was complete from ESLint (which triggers), as well as Atom declaring via `TextBuffer::onDidReload` that it has finished reloading the file after the external ESLint process has finished changing the file [here](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L82-L87).

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Using Atom version:
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
Using APM version:
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.13.0
```

Tested on Windows 10 x64, and Ubuntu 14.04 x64.

### Additional Information

Possibly related to the problem in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14189, likely caused by https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14435.

This is a regression from Atom v1.18.0, where these specs worked properly.
Label: bug

Title: 1.19, Linux: Middle-clicking an unsaved tab causes entire desktop to be unresponsive to clicks
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm on Ubuntu 16.04. Atom 1.18.0 was fine, but since updating to Atom 1.19.0, if I have a file with unsaved changes and I try to close the tab by middle-clicking on the tab, then a modal pops up (Are you sure you want to close the file without saving?), but I can't click on anything. The cursor doesn't change no matter what I hover over and no clicks register on the modal's buttons or even other (non-Atom) windows. Clicking another window doesn't focus it, bring it to the front, or get any reaction.

My computer is still responsive to keyboard inputs, though even if I alt-tab to another window, nothing reacts to my mouse still. I have to press escape on Atom's closing-confirmation modal or otherwise close it before anything reacts to my mouse again.

If I close the file tab in any other way (clicking the X button, or pressing ctrl-w), the modal and my mouse work perfectly normal. With little non-web UI experience, I'd guess the issue has to do with some kind of blocking call (like the modal) happening or a lock being hogged improperly during the middle-click event handler.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Be on Ubuntu 16.04 (?)
2. Open Atom, open a file in Atom, and make some changes to the file without saving.
3. Middle-click on the file's tab.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

My mouse to work as usual: for the modal to be clickable, and to have the ability to click on other windows freely even while the modal is still open.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

See description.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%, tested with safe mode and a new ~/.atom directory too.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
$ cat /etc/lsb-release 
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=16.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=xenial
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS"
$ uname -a
Linux canyon 4.4.0-89-generic #112-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jul 31 19:38:41 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Title: 1.20.0-beta0 unable to load on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

Note that clearing the state would fix this issue, but the issue should still be fixed in some other way.

### Description

Can't open projects from the previous version of Atom Beta

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install 1.19 beta 7
2. Open a project, some tabs, and the About page (maybe the Settings View too)
3. Update to 1.20 beta 0 automatically (Squirrel should download the update and you need to Restart and Install once it's downloaded)
4. Reopen Atom once the update completes (the error should happen automatically)
5. If the error doesn't appear, open a project from `File > Reopen Project`

Note that if you manually add a project with `Add Project Folder` or open a project you had already opened in 1.20 the issue doesn't appear

**Expected behavior:** Projects should open in tree view and tabs should be restored

**Actual behavior:** Instead, the error pop-ups and no editor is opened

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

This happened when updating to 1.20.0 beta0 on Windows 10 x64

```
> apm --version

apm  1.18.3
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

```
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:137:23
    at Package.module.exports.Package.measure (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:99:21)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.finishLoading (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:133:25)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.loadAvailablePackage (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package-manager.js:521:38)
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package-manager.js:479:25
```

Title: Folding with soft wrap enabled doesn't update text editor view correctly as of 1.19
Body:
### Prerequisites

- [x]    Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
- [x]    Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
- [x]    Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
- [x]    Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
- [x]    Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When folding text using `editor:fold-at-indent-level-2`, the visual representation of some of the folds is not updated correctly

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open [this file](https://github.com/calebmeyer/git-links/blob/f5100a252734bc4b4de55dcc4b85b743d456d551/lib/git-links.coffee)
1. Run `editor:toggle-soft-wrap` to enable soft wrap if it is not already on
1. Run `editor:fold-at-indent-level-2` using the command palette

Size of the Atom window may be related /cc: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15190#issuecomment-322209970

**Expected behavior:**
Each element at the second level of indentation is folded, and shows as folded

**Actual behavior:**
Some (or none) of the elements are showing as folded.
Moving the cursor with the arrow keys navigates inside the fold
Moving the cursor with vim-mode-plus `hjkl` navigates over the fold

**Reproduces how often:**
I am able to see the problem in safe mode about 80% of the time. Almost always, at least one fold gets folded correctly, sometimes two. Very rarely all folds will show correctly.

### Versions
Windows 10 creator's update
`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
`apm --version`
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015

### Additional Information
Screenshots:
My configuration:
![mine](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3342777/29088025-8273c790-7c3d-11e7-9744-4fda97adbe34.png)

Safe Mode
![safe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3342777/29088034-89210670-7c3d-11e7-8fa7-8d14888a8c93.png)
Label: bug

Title: [from v1.19] highlight decoration node can be re-rendered which cause keyframe animation restart.
Body:
### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description This issue started from v1.19 which use new editor-rendering with etch. CC @as-cii #### Short summary From v1.19, highlight decoration node is re-rendered in it's lifetime which cause keyframe animation unwillingly re-started. This was not issue in v1.18 where highlight decoration node was stable in it's lifetime. See, each removal of brackets-matcher's highlight cause fadeout animation re-started. Which is because highlight node of `class=t9md-test-flash` is re-created at that timing. ![decoration-node-unstable2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/29040638-b6cee3ce-7bea-11e7-9aa3-4168238b2b6d.gif) ### Detail When highlight decoration is created by `editor.decorateMarker`, corresponding `
` node is created at top of LinesComponents. Child nodes of this div represent actual decoration style. - Till v1.18 these nodes are stable in its lifetime. - From v1.19 with new editor-rendering, these nodes can be re-rendered during it's lifetime. This is not problem when highlight class is simply set `background:` color. But it's become problem when highlight class specify animation. Lets' say - I have set decoration which `class=flash-anime` which will be destroyed after 1.0 sec - `flash-anime` css class have keyframe animation which fadeout flash during 1.0 sec. - When Atom re-render(re-create) this decoration node within 1.0 sec, it cause re-start fadeout keyframe animation. - This issue is more likely to happen when brackets-matcher involved, which create/remove decorations and it cause existing highlight node in the same LinesComponents **re-rendered**. GIF: Animation in 10sec is separated into three because of re-render of highlight node. GIF: style recalculation highlight decoration re-created which cause animation restart. ### Steps to Reproduce I can reproduce this issue with safe-mode. 1. Prepare sample.txt and custom-style. - sample.txt `{a: 1}` - style.less ```less @keyframes t9md-test-animation { from { background-color: #5b91c8; } to { background-color: transparent; } } atom-text-editor .t9md-test-flash .region { animation-name: t9md-test-animation; animation-fill-mode: forwards; animation-duration: 10.0s; animation-iteration-count: 1; } ``` 2. Open sample.txt, place cursor at first line. 3. Paste following code in chrome-dev-tools console. This code does. - highlight inner range of `a: 1`(inner range of curly brackets). - marker will destroyed after 10sec. - highlight class is `t9md-test-flash` which fadeout background color in 10sec. ```javascript (function flashreproduceIssue() { const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor() const cursorPosition = editor.getCursorBufferPosition() const scanRange = editor.bufferRangeForBufferRow(cursorPosition.row) editor.scanInBufferRange(/{.*?}/, scanRange, ({range}) => { const innerRange = range.translate([0, +1], [0, -1]) const marker = editor.markBufferRange(innerRange) editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: "highlight", class: "t9md-test-flash"}) setTimeout(function () { marker.destroy() console.log("destroyed"); }, 10000); }) })() ``` 4. Within 10sec, move cursor left/right to cause add/remove brackets-macher's highlight. And see how keyframe animation is re-started because of re-creation of highlight node. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Node used for highlight decoration is stabled(not re-rendered). **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Node used for highlight decoration is re-rendered, cause keyframe animation re-started. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100%. ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.19.0-beta7 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` ### Additional Information I use fadeout flash effect with keyframe animation a lot in [vim-mode-plus](https://atom.io/packages/vim-mode-plus) to give feedback to user. E.g. when yank inner range of brackets, flash inner bracket range. From v.1.19 cursor move cause brackets-matcher's highlights add/removal which cause vmp's flash effect re-started unwillingly.
Label: bug

Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

Title: Pane.destroyItem() can return a non-boolean value
Body:
`Pane.destroyItem()` claims to return a promise of a boolean value. In the force case, or if the user does not need to save, we instead return the result of `item.destroy?()`.

I'll open a pull request to address this.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/pane.coffee#L629

cc @matthewwithanm @hansonw
Label: bug

Title: Persist undo history when reopening a previously-closed buffer
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Undo/redo don't work after the file has been closed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open existing file (or create the new one)
2. Edit this file
3. Close this file
4. Restore the last closed tab (`Ctrl+Shift+T`)
5. Undo/redo don't work!

**Expected behavior:** Undo/redo work after reopening closed file.

**Actual behavior:** Undo/redo don't work after reopening closed file.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15

apm  1.18.1

Linux Alex-ArchMainPC 4.11.9-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Wed Jul 5 18:23:08 CEST 2017 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Missing.

Title: Atom doesn't correctly indent lines with combining diacritics

Paste the following text into a new plain text tab. ``` x = 1 γ = 1 φ̄ = 1 ``` **Expected behavior:** All three `= 1` should be indented to the same distance. **Actual behavior:** The third line doesn't indent fully: **Reproduces how often:** Always. ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.18.0 Electron: 1.3.15 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ``` ### Additional Information Tested on macOS 10.12.5.

Title: Atom crashes when copying contents from one editor tab to another. MacOS Sierra
Body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description I received the below message **after** pasting all the text of a 33.8MB file into a new untitled file. > The editor has crashed. Please report the issue to https://github.com/atom/atom ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a large file (e.g. [The file causing Atom to crash - Hosted On Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B2YHKXTPh6ezTU5hQkJ4TzN6cXM)) 2. Press (Cmd + A) then press (Cmd + C) to put the contents of the file on your clipboard 3. Press (Cmd + N) to open a new untitled document. 4. Press (Cmd + V) to paste your clipboard contents into the new untitled document. **Expected behavior:** Editor does not crash **Actual behavior:** after about 10 seconds the editor will paste the contents into the new untitled document. However, the user interface will remain frozen even after the editor is filled with the contents from your clipboard. After another 5 seconds the editor crashes. Opening Atom in safe mode from the terminal yields the below results ``` $ /Application/Atom\ Beta.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Beta --safe <--- Last few GCs ---> [21851:0x7f8c91847a00] 83407 ms: Mark-sweep 1405.7 (1465.1) -> 1405.6 (1434.1) MB, 1254.6 / 6.0 ms (+ 0.0 ms in 0 steps since start of marking, biggest step 0.0 ms, walltime since start of marking 1255 ms) last resort [21851:0x7f8c91847a00] 84607 ms: Mark-sweep 1405.6 (1434.1) -> 1405.6 (1434.1) MB, 1199.2 / 2.3 ms last resort <--- JS stacktrace ---> ==== JS stack trace ========================================= Security context: 0x1662a60519c1 2: new Symbol [:~206370] [pc=0x16f63ecca07](this=0x29340d1c9239 ,text=0x29340d1c8c21 ,scopes=0x29340d1c8a31 ) 4: recomputeSymbolsForEditorInBufferRange [:~206487] [pc=0x16f63fa77f2](this=0x9505fd55d81 ,editor=0x38f711946929 ... ``` **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions ``` $ /Application/Atom\ Beta.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Beta --version Atom : 1.19.0-beta4 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` Specs: ``` MacBookPro13,2 (A1706) macOS Sierra: Version 10.12.5 ``` ### Additional Information I am running the 64-bit build of atom. Interestingly the amount of RAM that was in use by Atom when I pasted the contents of the first editor into the untitled document jumped. **These tests were done on a file 33.8MB in size.** With no document loaded Atom sat at around ~330MB With the document loaded Atom sat between 520MB - 700MB When I copied the document to a new untitled document, Atom jumped to ~2.0GB - 2.14GB then crashed. [Atom Beta Helper_2017-07-27-211501_Ethans-MacBook-Pro.crash.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1195136/Atom.Beta.Helper_2017-07-27-211501_Ethans-MacBook-Pro.crash.txt)
Label: bug

Title: Can't switch tabs with keyboard when tree view is focused
Body:
Running Atom 1.18.0 on OS X 10.10.5

Using keyboard shortcuts <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>?</kbd> and <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>→</kbd> doesn't switch tabs when the tree view is focused.

I have keyboard shortcuts assigned to specific gestures on the mac trackpad and they should work everywhere in the app, regardless of where the cursor is. This is also inconsistent behavior as closing and reopening tabs with <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>W</kbd> and <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⇧</kbd>+<kbd>T</kbd> works as intended.

### Steps to Reproduce

With 2 file tabs open and the tree view visible:

1. Click to focus the tree view.
2. Use <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⌥</kbd>+<kbd>?</kbd> to switch to previous tab.

**Expected behavior:** To switch to previous tab.

**Actual behavior:** Tab switching doesn't work with that key combo.
Label: bug

Title: Gutter decoration regression in v1.19.0
Body:
### Prerequisites
_Note: As only custom gutter decorations are affected, this is unable (?) to be tested in safe mode._

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The positioning of gutter decorations has regressed between Atom v1.18.0 and Atom v1.19.0-betaX (confirmed on -beta3). It seems that they are being shoved to the right ~50 pixels... and as their Z-index is below the editor's this effectively makes them invisible.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a package installed that creates a custom gutter. (ex. `linter-ui-default`)
2. Get that package to decorate a line.
3. Note that the gutter decorations aren't showing visibly.

#### Expected behavior:

Custom gutter icons show as they did in Atom v1.18.0.

Linter UI gutter on right in Atom v1.18.0:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-42-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393440-9f830d02-6c9b-11e7-9606-2022bde8283c.png)

Linter UI gutter on left in Atom v1.18.0:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-42-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393446-aefaf542-6c9b-11e7-951d-2cb46219944a.png)

#### Actual behavior:

Custom gutter icons are shifted to the right by a constant value (~50 px?), and background highlights don't show.

Linter UI gutter on right in Atom v1.19.0-beta3:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-49-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393471-c4c60448-6c9b-11e7-914d-6df2990ec239.png)

Linter UI gutter on left in Atom v1.19.0-beta3:
![atom_2017-07-19_15-48-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/28393474-c80f7b98-6c9b-11e7-8bde-4e27f5491ad0.png)

#### Reproduces how often:

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
OS: Windows 10 Enterprise x64
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.3.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

The gutter decorations were first reported by @ooJerryLeeoo in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/359, with the background highlighting pointed out by @50Wliu in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/pull/190#issuecomment-316501642 and elaborated on in https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/385.
Label: bug

Title: "Editor is not responding" after leaving "Save As" dialog open for some time on macOS Sierra
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If the save dialog is open for too long, when it closes, I get an "Editor is not responding" dialog. If I click "Keep Waiting", everything is actually fine. I suspect there's a synchronous call somewhere when opening the save dialog.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new file in atom.
2. File -> Save As
3. Stare at the "Save" modal for a couple minutes.
4. Input a file name and save the file.
5. Now the "Editor is not responding" dialog pops up.
6. Click "Keep Waiting".
7. Everything is fine and working as normal.

**Expected behavior:** "Editor is not responding" dialog should not pop up.

**Actual behavior:** "Editor is not responding" dialog pops up.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS Sierra Version 10.12.5
Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

### Additional Information

N/A
Label: bug

Title: Window dimensions and position not being saved
Body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Atom 1.18.0 is not saving window positions on multi-monitor Mac setups, in particular circumstances. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. On a Mac with 2 monitors, arrange them so that the secondary monitor is positioned higher and to the left of the primary monitor, like so: 2. Open Atom and mentally note the window size and position. 3. Open settings to ensure that "Restore Previous Windows On Start" is set to "always". 4. Move Atom's application window fully onto the secondary monitor, so that the top left corner of it is positioned above the height of the primary window. Optionally, resize the window to be noticeably different than the original size. 5. Open the Developer tools and enter `atom.getPosition()` into the console. 6. Observe that the current widow position x and y values are both negative, like so: ![screen shot 2017-07-13 at 5 56 51 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5263654/28193853-eca1fd56-67f4-11e7-99c3-f00acfeca7d0.png) 7. Quit Atom via CMD+Q or via the File menu. 8. Open Atom. **Expected behavior:** Atom should restore the window position and size due to the "Restore Previous Windows On Start" setting. **Actual behavior:** The window will open in the position it was in at step 2. **Reproduces how often:** 100% (if the above steps are followed) ### Versions **Atom:** Atom : 1.18.0 Electron: 1.3.15 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 **apm:** apm 1.18.1 npm 3.10.10 node 6.9.5 x64 python 2.7.10 **MacOS:** System Version: macOS 10.12.5 (16F73) Mac Model Identifier: MacBookPro13,2 ### Additional Information The issue appears to be caused by an assumption that window positions are calculated relative to the monitor they reside on, not relative to the primary monitor position. The validation logic is found in the `isValidDimensions` method of `atom-environment.coffee` at line 635: ``` # Returns true if the dimensions are useable, false if they should be ignored. # Work around for https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/473 isValidDimensions: ({x, y, width, height}={}) -> width > 0 and height > 0 and x + width > 0 and y + height > 0 ``` The intent seems to be to prevent saving positions that would place the window outside the viewable area of the monitors, but in our case it generates a false negative due to the way the position data is calculated, and therefore the window position is not saved if your setup is as described above.
Label: bug

Title: Atom doesn't reflect changes in environment for subsequent invocations of `atom .`
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm running Atom on Windows (with command prompt), so I'm not sure if the issue is reproducible on other platforms. All invocations of `atom .` seem to reflect the state of the environment from the first time I invoked atom. Moreover, when using WSL (Bash on Windows), atom seems to completely ignore any environment variables I've set in the shell beforehand. This might be an unrelated issue, but I've ruled out using WSL as a workaround.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In one command prompt window, `set FOO=bar`
2. In the same command prompt window, `atom .`
3. In another command prompt window, `set FOO=foo`
4, In this other command prompt window, `atom .`
5. Print `process.env` in the Javascript console for both atom windows.

**Expected behavior:** `FOO` in the first window should be equal to `bar` and `FOO` in the second window should be equal to `foo`.

**Actual behavior:** Both windows report `FOO` as `bar`.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Windows 10 Build 15063.332 x64

### Additional Information

I've noticed related closed issues or merged pull requests, but they seem to focus more on OS X. Whatever the fix was in the past, at the very least it doesn't work on Windows.
Label: bug

Title: A cursor position is not restored when switching to and back from a pane without cursor
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When switching between panes using keyboard, if a pane you switched to is cursor-less (like About or Welcome pane) the cursor position is not restored when returning back to an editable pane. This is similar to #6662 but without a mouse. Mouse works as expected

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new file, enter some text in multiple lines
2. Open About pane (on macOS Atom -> About Atom
3. Switch between text pane and About pane using keyboard Cmd-Alt-Arrows or Cmd-Shift-[, Cmd-Shift-]

**Expected behavior:** When returning to a pane with an edit have a cursor where I left it and move it using arrows or other navigation keys

**Actual behavior:** Only line number is highlighted and no cursor is visible in the line and no reaction to arrow keys and other typing or navigation inside a pane

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

macOS Sierra 10.12.5

### Additional Information

Clicking on panes does not behave the same way and does what expected.
Label: bug

Title: Feature: Titlebar like Github Desktop (Windows)
Body:
## Atom
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21206831/27933793-251d231a-62a3-11e7-9d2d-3a8542da53fa.png)


## Github Desktop (Beta)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21206831/27934049-3bec3044-62a4-11e7-9a4b-27a3ae9a9902.png)


## Description
The new Desktop Client for Github has a really sexy Titlebar. 
Not only because it matches the color of the application but also because it doesn't use the OS default application menu but a custom one inside the Titlebar. 
Unfortunately, the windows default Titlebar and the application menu are very ugly. Especially the application menu looks like Windows 95 when Microsoft introduced this grayish style which they didn't changed since for it. Sure, it's sad that developers have to come up with custom solutions but the windows version would look soo much better with a custom title bar like the Github Client.

A custom Titlebar would also be nice on other platforms but on macOS, the application menu isn't in the window but in the menubar wich looks great and it should be there. On most Linux distros the Titlebar and the application menu have at least the same style so it doesn't look so bad there. Therefore the windows version of Atom is worst one and needs this feature the most.

Other Issues:
#13249 
#4599
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature: disable update download on metered connection
Body:
### Description

FEATURE: Disable update download on metered connection, so data plan does not get drained

In Windows users have the ability to mark Connection as 'metered'
this option is to indicate spare use of data connection.

Atom does not ask to download update, therefore it drains the data plan.

This is an improvement for users on mobile connections

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Got to Network & Internet Setting in Windows 10 (Win 8 too)
2. Click WiFi Tab
3. Click Manage Known networks
4. Choose Desired Network SSID
5. Click Properties
6. Scroll down to metered connection
7. Turn metered connection On
8. Start Atom editor (old version)
9. Observe huge (~200MB) data usage whe Atom downloads update.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Atom should check if connection is metered to not automatically download update

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Atom downloads data with update

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
always

### Versions
C:\Users\jagod>atom --version

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Windows 10 64-bit

### Additional Information
Label: enhancement

Title: ⌘ + ⌃ + ? (command + control + space | cmd + ctrl + space) does not open the Characters selector on macOS with system lang with non-English system language
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

*edit by @rsese: need to set the system language to something other than English (`System Preferences > Language & Region`)  first before trying the steps below (confirmed with German, but reports also with French and Dutch)*

⌘ + ⌃ + ? (command + control + space | cmd + ctrl + space) does not open the Characters selector on macOS.

_edit by @lee-dohm: This reproduces on Windows as well using the <kbd>Win+.</kbd> keyboard combination as [reported below](
https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14963#issuecomment-442403546)._

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom (either in `--safe` mode or just `atom`) on macOS Sierra
2. Open a new file: press ⌘ + N (command + N)
3. Open the macOS built-in special character selector: press ⌘ + ⌃ + ? (command + control + space)
4. Wait forever.

**Expected behavior:** The Character selector opens.

**Actual behavior:** The Characters selector does not open.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% (`n_trials < 10`).

### Versions

`atom --version`:
```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
`apm --version`:
```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.2
```
`sw_vers`:
```
ProductName:	Mac OS X
ProductVersion:	10.12.5
BuildVersion:	16F73
```

### Additional Information

The Atom keybinding resolvers (⌘ + .) does detect that ⌘ + ⌃ + ? is pressed, but no Atom action is bound to it, nor does it trigger the system's Characters selector.
Label: bug

Title: Dock toggle rendering issue
Body:
### Prerequisites

_Note: Unable to reproduce in safe mode._

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The Dock toggles will sometimes develop a rendering glitch, causing a bar to appear around the button.

### Steps to Reproduce (_Updated_)

1. Install the `docks-test` package found here: [docks-test.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1109683/docks-test.zip)
2. Install `atom-material-ui`. Tested with v2.0.4.
3. Open a file.

**Expected behavior:**

No graphical bugs with the Dock item.

**Actual behavior:**

When the "flow in" animation for the Dock toggle finishes a rectangular shaped region of the screen as high as the button but much wider will appear colored in the `@app-background-color` (I think), sometimes it will have content from the status bar showing in the bar. This status bar content is _not_ from the area "under" the bar, so it's not something that is getting translated up with the button.

"Normal" blank bar:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649520-e67c8668-5be6-11e7-896d-38285a96c1b9.png)

Status bar content:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649153-d0a616a2-5be5-11e7-9b60-f0499731681a.png)

GIF:
![2017-06-28_09-48-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27649602-1607e576-5be7-11e7-9487-c512ba257bf7.gif)

Note that with the updated steps to reproduce the behavior is actually worse than shown in the screenshots as the window starts out with a glitched rendering bar:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27652328-239b7a78-5bf0-11e7-83ac-a714a4f3488f.png)

There is actually a line number hidden behind the bar as well, as can be seen (briefly) in this GIF:
![2017-06-28_10-55-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/427137/27652371-4b9adafa-5bf0-11e7-9978-912ad8265ab2.gif)


**Reproduces how often:**

Almost all windows seem to eventually show this behavior, but I can't determine a reliable way to reproduce this.

- I can't seem to replicate in safe mode, or with a stock theme (One Dark).
- I use `atom-material-ui` with One Dark Syntax.
- ~~This _might_ be dependent on `linter-ui-default`,~~ but it may just be that that is the only bottom Dock item that I usually have running.
- I only ever see a brief flash of the right side Dock toggle showing this when Atom is loading, once loaded I don't see it from that toggle.

### Versions

 I've seen this since at least v1.18.0 betas, possibly since v1.17.0 betas.

Currently seeing this in:
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

Related issues:
https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/issues/344
https://github.com/steelbrain/linter/issues/1501

<details>
<summary>Here is a list of installed packages</summary>


Title: Settings lost
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Sometimes when updating packages, Atom loses most of its settings. E.g. right now, I updated Hyperclick, and after the restart I was greeted with the welcome message, my font was reset to the default settings, my settings for linter-pycodestyle and linter-pylint were lost, and I assume all the others as well, but I didn't bother with the rest much, so no impact there in my case.

This is difficult to reproduce; I can update packages dozens of times, but every once in a while, it loses all my settings. It's not a disk full issue, as I have 56GB available.

The data loss appears to be limited to the things in ~/.atom/config.cson - the other .cson files and styles.less appear to be unaffected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Update packages
2. Restart

**Expected behavior:** Atom restarts with upgraded packages, and settings intact.

**Actual behavior:** Atom restarts with upgraded packages, and lost settings.

**Reproduces how often:** Less than 10%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1

OS: Linux Mint 17.3 Rosa
Kernel: 3.19.0-32-generic #37~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Oct 22 09:41:40 UTC 2015 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: bug

Title: [Feature request] Support YAML as configuration format along with JSON/CSON
Body:
YAML has several obvious advantages:

  * Comparing CSON it's language agnostic and widespread (build systems, etc)
  * Comparing JSON it supports comments and has neat more "human readable" syntax

I would be cool to have it before crucial #5168
Label: enhancement

Title: [Feature Request]: Option to download update manually
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

There is an option to `Enable/disable` automatic updates but there is no option to download update manually. Once we click on `Check for Updates` the update starts downloading automatically.

An option for `enable/disable automatic download` is must. It should not start download as soon as the user checks for update. 

Also the name states that `Check for Updates` not to download update

### Steps to Reproduce

Go Atom -> Check for Updates

**Expected behavior:**

Once the Use checks for update. It should pop showing the newer version to user with option to update or update later. If the user selects update. then download can happen.

The Popup can also have a link for the latest versions release notes.

**Actual behavior:** 

Once the user checks for update, the newer version gets downloaded

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

Atom Version: 1.18.0

### Additional Information
I tested in macOS Sierra
Label: enhancement

Title: [v1.19-beta] Cannot scroll manually created editor
Body:
In this gif, editor have 100 line from 1 to 100 text in each line, but not scrollable by mouse or `ctrl-p`, `ctrl-n`.

![scroll-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/27237721-4358411e-5305-11e7-905a-257383d01943.gif)

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Cannot scroll manually created editor(by `new TextEditor()`.
- In v1.18: scrollable by mouse(trackpad) and normal motion command(`core:move-down`)
- In v1.19-beta: cannot scroll by mouse nor normal motion command(`core:move-down`)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. launch atom in safe mode.
2. Open dev-console and paste code below, it create editor and put 100 lines text.

```javascript
(function reproduceIssue() {
  const {TextEditor} = require("atom")
  editor = new TextEditor()

  // this is also not work
  // editor = atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()

  const lines = []
  for (let i = 1; i < 100; i++) {
    lines.push(i)
  }
  atom.workspace.open(editor)
  editor.setText(lines.join("\n"))
}())
```

3. see you can not scroll by mouse, and also `ctrl-n`(`core:move-down`).

- v1.18: have no problem with same reproduction steps.
- v1.19: have issue, it might be regression by rendering logic rewrite.

### Versions

macOS
```
ProductName:	Mac OS X
ProductVersion:	10.12.5
```

Atom
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

My [atom-narrow](https://atom.io/packages/narrow) affected by this issue.
Label: bug

Title: Can't scroll the editor when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I can't scroll the editor when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen. Also happens when I close the right docks.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in full screen with a long enough file so that there will be a vertical scroll bar.
2. Move your mouse to the very right most edge of the screen and try to scroll by clicking the scroll bar. It doesn't work.
3. Move it slightly to the left and you can click and scroll.

**Expected behavior:** I can click the scroll bar even when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen.

**Actual behavior:** I can't scroll. I have to move the mouse slightly to the left.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.1.windows.2
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10.0.15063 x64

Title: macOS custom titlebar does not hide titlebar when reloading editor in fullscreen mode
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Hello all!

I just noticed weird behavior of Atom that it does not hide its titlebar when reloading editor in fullscreen mode on `macOS`.

Here are the captured screenshots where in safe mode:

When not in full screen mode:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217319-58e116ce-52b4-11e7-9ae8-c8cfe850e02c.png)

When in full screen mode:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217324-5dc3373a-52b4-11e7-94a9-bc0a4aab9bce.png)

When in full screen mode after reloading right after previous step:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217327-6073889a-52b4-11e7-91c6-15dccc987f2d.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Prepare `macOS` environment. 🤑 
1. Open Atom.
2. Go to `Settings` and change `Title Bar` option to `custom` or `custom-inset` from `Core` setting.
3. Toggle fullscreen by `ctrl` + `cmd` + `f`.
4. Reload editor by `ctrl` + `alt` + `cmd` + `l`.
5. Hang tight until editor titlebar show up

**Expected behavior:** Titlebar hidden when reloading editor.

**Actual behavior:** Titlebar keep showing even in fullscreen mode.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time you follow above steps.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

`macOS Sierra 10.12.5`
Label: bug

Title: File removed outside of Atom does not close tab in Atom
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Let's say I have a git repo with a single file, `a.txt`, on `master`.  The `add-b-file` branch adds a new `b.txt` file to the repo.  When on `add-b-file` with both `a.txt` and `b.txt` open in Atom, switching branches to `master` does not close `b.txt` even if there are no unsaved changes.  I have "Close Deleted File Tabs" checked.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a git repo and commit a file
2. Switch to a new branch and add a different file
3. Open both files in Atom
4. Switch back to the original branch

**Expected behavior:** Only `a.txt` to exist in Atom

**Actual behavior:** Both files are still open, with `b.txt` marked as having unsaved changes.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-dev-c6bf86c9b
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This looks like a regression from #693.  The steps to reproduce I gave are what I believe to be a simplified version of what I'm experiencing.  If they don't actually work, the actual scenario I'm facing has to do with switching between the `wl-split-grammars` and `master` branch on atom/language-php.

Tentatively /cc'ing @iolsen because of atom/tabs#306.
Label: bug

Title: "Save As" for new file doesn't default to a sensible directory location
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When creating a new file and hitting Save, the save dialog doesn't seem to have any particular directory set and defaults to a platform-dependent location.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new untitled file
2. Save it

**Expected behavior:**

"Save As" dialog should default to a sensible location (most likely the project root, which definitely _used_ to be the behaviour)

**Actual behavior:**

**On Ubuntu**, Save dialog opens at "Recently Used", sometimes making it a pain to find the logical place to save the file.

**On mac**, seems to default to project root directory, but **only** for the first window opened (I assume it defaults to the process's cwd)

Can't speak for windows right at the moment I'm afraid

Directory is set fine if you're hitting "save as" from a file that already exists.

**Reproduces how often:**

Every time

### Versions

Currently 1.18 beta but basically every version since #13978 was reported

### Additional Information

I guess #13978 got closed because the desired behaviour was fixed on mac for the first-opened window and for already-existing files. Looks like this was also reported in #14304 but that was closed because it didn't follow the template.
Label: bug

Title: Docks documentation points to non-existent get{Left|Right|Bottom}Dock methods
Body:
(Issue template does not apply)

The [Docks](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.17.2/Dock) documentation links to `getLeftDock`, `getRightDock`, and `getBottomDock`.  However, there are two problems: those methods exist in Workspace and not Dock; and those methods are not publicly documented.
Label: bug
