Title: Atom doesn't handle .gitignore/exclude files with trailing whitespace
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Atom doesn't handle .gitignore/exclude files with trailing whitespace. This means that files that are followed by trailing whitespace in .gitignore/exclude always show up as new.

Obviously no one is going to create such files on purpose. I only got bitten by this due to Windows being Windows and adding a trailing whitespace when I innocently did a simple `echo` command. 😛

I checked the git-diff package first and saw that the actual calculation is implemented in Atom using the git-utils npm package, which I think uses libgit2. This might be an issue in libgit2 or it's usage in git-utils or it might be an issue in the way Atom is using git-utils.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Execute in a Windows console (Not Git Bash):
```sh
git init test-repo && cd test-repo
echo. > test.txt && echo. > test2.txt
echo test.txt > .gitignore
echo test2.txt >> .git/info/exclude
```
2. Open `test-repo` in Atom with the default VCS exclude settings.
3. Look at the tree view.

**Expected behavior:** test2.txt doesn't appear in the tree view or in fuzzy finder since it's ignored.

**Actual behavior:** test2.txt appears in the tree view as a new file and also appears in the fuzzy finder. But is ignored by standard Git (`git status`).

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
Windows 10.0.14393 x64
Label: bug

### Description

It would be nice if the new Dock feature released in `1.17.0` were in its own package so that users can enable and disable as needed. In my own personal use-case, its highly annoying to mouse over to the tree view and have the arrow always animate in and out. Since I don't use docks, I would like to disable. Alternatively, it would be nice if this functionality was behind a setting that I could toggle off.

2. Mouse out to main editor window, see arrow disappear
3. Repeat.

1.17.*

Title: Opening a pending pane no longer correctly correctly triggers activation
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Opening a file as a pending pane no longer triggers activation as expected. The end result is that `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor` returns `undefined` until the user interacts with the text editor in some manner (e.g. moving the cursor or making the pane non-pending).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom in any folder that contains some files that can be opened.
2. Click on any file in the tree view (ensure it is opened in a pending pane).
3. Open up the developer tools console.
4. Execute `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()`
5. Notice the method returns `undefined`
6. Click anywhere in the (pending) text editor.
7. Execute `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()`
8. Notice the method returns a `TextEditor` object.

**Expected behavior:** Opening a file in a pending pane should immediately mark the text editor as active.

**Actual behavior:** The text editor in the pending pane is not marked as active until the user directly interacts with the pane/editor.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time.

### Versions

Atom v1.7.2, and v1.19.0-dev-85e65ffd1.
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

### Additional Information

This regression is the cause of the following issues:
* https://github.com/atom/status-bar/issues/194
Label: bug

Title: Grave accents causing visual problem with multiline selection
Body: ### Prerequisites Reproduced it in `--safe` mode. (Didn't have time for the other steps). ### Description Cursors are misplaced after selecting multiple lines for the first time and typing in grave accents (`). As far as I can tell it is just a visual bug as the next characters are placed correctly behind the accents. ![foo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11627131/26406077/87e5e334-4097-11e7-9350-b284fac8a459.gif) As you can see in the gif, the cursors are placed correctly after the initial faulty placement. ### Steps to Reproduce See the gif above. Reproducible each time. *Edited by @rsese, updated steps:* 1. Open new Window 2. Enter the following lines ``` foo bar baz ``` (Don't move the cursor after you are done. It should be right behind baz) 3. Selection -> Add selection above 4. Selection -> Add selection above You should now have all three lines selected (IMPORTANT: Don't move the cursor. The bug only happens if you add the grave accents right after the "Add selection above" action) 5. Add the grave (`) character (on macOS, type option-e The result should look like this: ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.17.0 Electron: 1.3.15 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ```` ``` apm 1.17.0 npm 3.10.5 node 6.9.5 x64 python 2.7.10 git 2.12.1 ``` ``` macOS Sierra 10.12.4 ```

Body:

### Description

I am able to destroy a Dock without its contents being destroyed.

**Actual behavior:** The right dock is destroyed, but the Git panel remains

```

Title: Geometry support
Body:
I often need to record screencasts with Atom, and need it in a specific position and size on screen. 

Most X11 based application allow for a `-geometry` switch.

I realize Atom is Electron-based, and not X11. However, is it possible to support this switch?

Perhaps as follows:

`atom --geometry 1280x720-37+50`

where the value is `[{WIDTH}][x{HEIGHT}][{+-}{XOFF}[{+-}{YOFF}]]`
Label: enhancement

Title: Opening directory with spaces and trailing slash opens invalid file
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you attempt to open a directory using a path with spaces in it, and include the trailing `\`, Atom opens to the parent directory with an empty "file" of the directory name with a `"` on the end.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a directory with a directory that has spaces in the name as one of it's parent folders.
    * For example: `C:\foo bar\foo`
2. From the CLI (`cmd.exe` or PowerShell) attempt to open the folder with a trailing slash in the command.
    * For example: `atom 'C:\Temp\foo bar\foo\'`
3. Note that Atom has opened the _parent_ folder, with the desired folder name open as a "file" with an `"` on the end.
    * For example: Atom open to `C:\foo bar` with an empty "file" of `foo"` open.

**Expected behavior:**

Atom opens the desired folder, regardless of whether there was a trailing `\` on the path.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom opens the _parent_ folder, with an empty file named after the desired folder with a `"` on the end open.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/25925238/38cb37c8-359c-11e7-9b06-3f58f081a577.png)
_The window on the left is the behavior of the first command, the window on the right is the second command (and the expected behavior)._

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

Tested on Windows 10 x64 on:
```
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta5
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

Also tested on:
```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-fb9fd2fbf
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
(A build based on https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14372/commits/fb9fd2fbfcf2f6fa07f43efcde20d4ee109df6a4)

### Additional Information

I tested the following variations...

Working:
* Anything that doesn't have the `\`, or doesn't have a space in any parent folder

Failing under both PowerShell and old fashioned `cmd.exe`:
* `PS C:\Temp> atom '.\foo bar\foo\'`
* `PS C:\Temp> atom 'C:\Temp\foo bar\foo\'`
* `PS C:\Temp> atom "C:\Temp\foo bar\foo\"`
Label: bug

`atom.workspace.getCenter().onDidChangeActivePane` and `atom.workspace.getCenter().onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem` do not work.

I'm looking to use these methods for my [tree-view-extended](https://github.com/hswolff/tree-view-extended) package.

Title: Focus taken away when dock was hidden( not respect original activeElement ).
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When dock was hidden, it **force** focus on workspaceCenter's active pane( Ignore original focus ).

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14143/commits/73f04fdaed30b774d1f5134a1df05eba30202aab

So hiding dock means "focus is taken away from originally focused element".
I want hiding dock not cause focus change unless hidden dock was originally focused.

When package-author try to implement action which hide dock and want to keep focus on `select-list` or mini-editor.
It's unnecessarily difficult since hiding dock force focus to workspaceCenter's active pane.

- Actual situation

In my [project-folder](https://atom.io/packages/project-folder) package, user can add/remove multiple project with keeping focus on select-list.
The `space` key in `select-list` is keymapped as "confirm and continue" action which confirm current item on select-list and keep focus on `select-list` so that user can continuously remove/add project folder.
From atom v1.17(which introduced dock), when project paths get emptied, tree-view destroy itself and tree-view's dock is hidden.
At this point, **focus is taken away from select-list to workspaceCenter's active pane** and `blur` event is fired on `select-list`'s element. which cause `cancel()` of select-list.
I don't want `cancel`, or `blur`, just want focus kept on originally focused `selec-list`'s mini-editor.

This is new issue from atom v1.17.0. Was not problem in v1.16.0.

https://github.com/t9md/atom-project-folder/issues/9#issuecomment-298679687

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set following commands and keymap.

- `init.coffee`

```coffeescript
atom.commands.add 'atom-workspace',
  'user:focus-taken-away-repro': ->
    for dir in atom.project.getPaths()
      atom.project.removePath(dir)
```

- `keymap.cson`

```coffeescript
'.select-list':
  'space': 'user:focus-taken-away-repro'
```

2. Start atom-beta(v1.17) with at least one project-folder listed on tree-view.
3. `cmd-t` to start `fuzzy-finder`.
4. type `space`, which invoke `user:focus-taken-away-repro` comands.

- In atom 1.16.0: focus remain in `select-list`'s mini-editor.
- In atom 1.17.0-beta3: focus taken away from `select-list` to activePane.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Want atom not take away original focus when dock was hidden.
Want keep focused on `select-list`'s mini-editor.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Original focus was taken away from `select-list` to activePane.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%, allways.

### Versions

```coffeescript
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
Label: bug

Title: Feature Request: Always discard project state when "Restore Previous Windows On Start" is false.
Body:
### Prerequisites
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Hey Atomizers! I wanted to kick a little feature request your way, if it's not too much trouble. I've noticed that in the beta build of Atom, reopening a project in a window with a preexisting tab gives one the option to discard Atom's autosaved project state. I was wondering if it wouldn't be more consistent with the "Restore Previous Windows on Start" setting if, when "restore windows" was flagged `false`, opening any project---from the menu, via drag-and-drop, from the CLI, from a project management package---automatically dropped its state on the floor.

I'm ultimately trying to get back to a world like the one I enjoyed when setting `hot_exit` to `false` in Sublime Text, wherein projects never remember expanded directories or opened tabs. (Unsaved buffers are another story: losing those was a part of the deal with Sublime, but Atom's behavior could in theory be gentler there.) Nineish times out of ten, rather than dropping me helpfully where I was working six minutes ago, the state restoration drops me annoyingly where I was working six weeks ago; it's easier just to get back to where I was on my own.

The behavior is _so close_ to what I'm looking for in `1.17.0-beta3`, _except_ that reopening a project in a clean window always restores its tabs (which focus themselves in the Tree View as I close them, ack):

![screenflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2207980/25434235/84b25d5e-2a59-11e7-9d2e-4a45d685fadc.gif)

Can't imagine this being super-high-priority by any stretch, but I also don't quite have the Atom-fu to tackle it on my own. Would be grateful if someone looking for an easy PR would consider it. :pray:

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a whole mess'a tabs in an Atom project window.
2. Close the project without explicitly closing your tabs.
3. Open a new window and reopen that selfsame project.
4. Tabs. Why did it have to be tabs.

**Suggested behavior:** When "Restore Previous Windows on Start" is disabled, Atom should discard all preexisting project state---including opened tabs.

**Actual behavior:** Atom selectively remembers some preexisting project state regardless of the setting---including opened tabs.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
? atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
? apm --version
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.12.2
```

```
? system_profiler SPSoftwareDataType
Software:

    System Software Overview:

      System Version: macOS 10.12.4 (16E195)
      Kernel Version: Darwin 16.5.0
      Boot Volume: Macintosh HD
      Boot Mode: Normal
      Computer Name: Zbornak
      User Name: Daniel P. Shannon (daniel)
      Secure Virtual Memory: Enabled
      System Integrity Protection: Disabled
      Time since boot: 1 day 12:19
```

### Additional Information
💖
Label: enhancement

Title: Incompatible packages detection makes incorrect assumptions about directory structure
Body:
In package.coffee ([here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f4cfe7603fbe99c8f717eb92fdff20d33b3fd90a/src/package.coffee#L679 ) and [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f4cfe7603fbe99c8f717eb92fdff20d33b3fd90a/src/package.coffee#L664)) we expect to find native modules at paths that look like `module_root/build/Release/module.node`. However, not all npm packages conform to this "standard": for those that don't, we are sometimes unable to locate the package.json of the npm package containing the native module in question.

This causes Atom to not be able to determine the incompatible npm package's version. Also, if a single npm package contains multiple incompatible native modules, we will report it multiple times.

/cc: @iolsen @ungb
Label: bug

Title: distiguish soft-wrapped lines (=parts) from non-wrapped lines
Body:
this is a mix between an issue and a feature request. ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: ... ### Description There is no chance to distinguish a normal line from a part of a soft-wrapped line. Additionally I want to distinguish the first line and the last line from the other wrapped parts. I see these possibilities: * class `.line` could be the whole line including all continuation lines and the wrapped partial lines have a different class (something like `.wrapped-line`) ```
line beginning
line continuation
line continuation
``` * if this breaks too much, it could be the other way: the wrapped parts could be wrapped by a class `.soft-wrapped-line` ```
line beginning
line continuation
line end
``` * if this still breaks too much, it could be without the outer level: ```
line beginning
line continuation
line end
``` This would allow to make display of continuation lines more usable. E.g. currently you see indent markers etc. which is wrong IMHO while visible whitespace seems to be correct. I would add wrapping markers in front of continuation lines and also at the end of a line being wrapped. These are the points where you look while reading. Currently you have to look in the gutter instead which is not convenient. Here is an example (SciTE-Editor): ![continuation-lines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4707597/25387860/7a7a2200-29cc-11e7-967b-2a7cfc8501f0.png) This would probably affect other issues like #14294
Label: enhancement

Title: Missing behavior when dropping a tab in another editor window
Body:
Receive highlighting and pane splitting don't happen when drag-and-dropping a tab into another editor window.

I'd expect drag-and-drop to work the same everywhere, no matter which editor window is receiving the drop.

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The split-pane layout management feature doesn't work when dragging tabs to a new window.

In fact, dropping a tab anywhere outside the tab bar just gets ignored.  This is surprising because that's not how dragging works in the main window.

This is related to this excellent PR: https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/252

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project
2. Create a new window with `cmd-shift-N`
3. Drag a tab from the project to the window you just opened

**Expected behavior:** Ideally, you'd see the shaded regions allowing you to open a new pane left/right/top...  But I'd settle for a drop in the content area working.

**Actual behavior:** The drag is ignored.  You must hit the tab bar exactly for it to work.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

![bug3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1776/25256002/af8eb80e-25e2-11e7-9f14-9629488d2fce.gif)

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

MacOS Sierra

```
~$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
~$ apm --version
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.9
git 2.2.1
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Update application.json only on change
Body:
### Description

File .atom/storage/application.json is updated with every window context switch. But as there is no change at all in 99% of cases, the only thing that is really changed is modification timestamp of the file.
This is not nice, as it constantly writes to disk when you are switching between application widows.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom and some file in it
2. Switch focus to another program window (even another Atom window)
3. Switch back
4. Switch focus to another program window (even another Atom window)
5. .atom/storage/application.json gets updated (just new timestamp) even though the list of opened "initialPaths" stays the same

**Expected behavior:** 
File application.json should be updated only when there is a change to it's content or when Atom is closing.

**Actual behavior:** 
File application.json gets updated at every focus switch even though there is no change of it's content.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions 
I am now on version below running Fedora 25, but it happens since I started using Atom two years ago on Fedora 21. I hoped it will get fixed eventually, but it still happens.

Atom    : 1.14.4
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.9.3
Label: enhancement

Title: Saving and renaming different files causes conflict
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

File handle conflict detecting file renames, when saving and renaming files at the same time.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. <del>Open a file named `fft.cpp`.</del>
2. <del>Create another empty file, enter something in it, and open the "Save File" dialog, but do not save the file at the moment.</del>
3. <del>Rename the file `fft.cpp` into `fft2.cpp`.</del>
4. <del>Save the newly opened file to the same folder, and call it `fft.cpp`. This wouldn't cause any conflict, as they are mutually different files.</del>
5. <del>**At this point, you may notice, both open tabs turn into `fft2.cpp`.</del>
6. <del>**If you save any of the two files, the other would change its content into this one, rendering the previously available content unreachable.**</del>

As I was alleged of not stating the stati clearly enough, this is a modified version of the reproduction steps.

1. Create a file / open a file **in Atom** whose location is `D:/a.cpp`.
2. **In Atom**, create another file and add arbitrary things in it, then open the `Save File` dialog. **DO NOT INTERACT WITH ATOM AT THE MOMENT.**
3. **IN EXPLORER OR CMD, WHERE YOU WOULD NOT INTERACT WITH ATOM**, rename `D:/a.cpp` to `D:/b.cpp`.
4. **In the Save File dialog**, there should only be a file `b.cpp` on Drive D.
5. **In the Save File dialog**, save the new (empty) file as `D:/a.cpp`.
6. **Currently in Atom**, both open tabs should appear as `b.cpp - D:/`.
7. **IN ATOM**, saving any of the two files would result in the other having its contents change into this one.

**Expected behavior:** The first file should turn its name to `b.cpp`, while the newly saved file should retain its expected name `a.cpp`.

**Actual behavior:** Both files turn into `b.cpp`, and are duplicates of the same *file handle*.

**Reproduces how often:** **This can be reproduced at a rate of 100%, regardless of the file names.**

### Versions

**Affects Atom versions `1.8.x` through `1.16.0`, as far as I am concerned.**

Operating system: Windows 10.0.14393.

### Additional Information

I've never read any of the related code, and decided that there's something to do with the file system journal. Probably this requires a big fix.

**To regulators:** Change the issue title if you consider it inappropriate.
Label: bug

Title: api reference issue on function arguments
Body:
for instance `Workspace.observeTextEditors` api, the code is `observeTextEditors (callback)`, while the doc is `observeTextEditors(callback, editor)`. 

It's a common issue throughout all reference docs.

https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.16.0/Workspace#instance-observeTextEditors
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.16.0/src/workspace.js#L304
Label: bug

Title: onDidReload getting fired before onDidChange
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
onDidReload getting fired before onDidChange

### Steps to Reproduce
Was able to get a isolated repro with @Arcanemagus help.

1. `git clone https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint.git`
2. `git checkout arcanemagus/atom-repro-case`
3. run `atom .` from the repo cloned in step 1.
4. run package specs(test will always pass)
5.  open devtools in the spec window


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
onDidReload gets fired after onDidChange.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
`onDidReload` sometimes gets fired before `onDidChange`,  This causes issues as `onDidReload` is being fired when the editor is blank.  

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
~75%


### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-9202160ca
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information
Here's a screenshot of the issue you'll see after you open dev tools

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/24980007/3b5fae46-1f8b-11e7-9911-7f4beceeeea2.png)

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.


This is probably the underlying cause for issues #12243 and #5730
Label: bug

Title: Duplicate tabs can be opened
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When opening files (eg from the Tree View, which is where I experienced this), it is possible to open the same file multiple times.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Rapidly double-click on the same file in the Tree View

**Expected behavior:** The file to open once, become permanent (if applicable), and further double-clicks on the file to refocus the editor.

**Actual behavior:** The file opens multiple times.

**Reproduces how often:** Almost 100%.  @nathansobo mentioned that it's more likely to occur the faster you click, probably because of the new async methods.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-e8ae30217
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

![multiple-files](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/24919739/a16fc5ba-1eb2-11e7-846d-eeeed3a46472.gif)

/cc: @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @matthewwithanm
Label: bug

npm  3.10.5

python 2.7.12

(Also note the strange dock resizing after I start hovering over it - not sure if that's related)

Title: Data loss when adding and removing project folders
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

There are already lots of unsaved buffer loss related issues, mostly of files with no project folder. However, this data loss scenario can also happen to a file with a project folder, without unusual or unintended behaviors such as crashing Atom, opening multiple windows of Atom, etc. It can be reproduced by the following steps.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom with project folder A and make some change. Be sure that the changes are not saved.
2. Close Atom.
3. Open Atom with project folder B.
4. Add project folder A, and then remove project folder B.
5. Close Atom.
6. Open Atom with project folder A. (Or possibly with no project folder)
7. Now the changes are gone!

**Expected behavior:** The changes must be preserved at a certain step. If Atom handles unsaved buffers separate from project folders, the changes should be shown in step 3. This was what I expected (as Sublime Text does) before I search for the related issues and find out that Atom integrates the editor's state with project folders. Since Atom integrates them, the changes in step 1 may be expected reappear in either step 4 (when adding project folder A) or step 6.

**Actual behavior:** Data loss

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.15.0  
Electron: 1.3.13  
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82  
Node    : 6.5.0
Label: bug

Title: The build instructions for Arch Linux demand installing the non existing packages libX11-devel and libxkbfile-devel
Body:
In the [build instructions for Linux](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md) in the section for Arch it says one should execute `sudo pacman -S --needed gconf base-devel git nodejs npm libgnome-keyring python2 libX11-devel libxkbfile-devel`, but the packages `libX11-devel`  and `libxkbfile-devel` don't exist in the Arch repos.
This can be tested by [searching for them on the Arch Website](https://www.archlinux.org/packages/?q=libX11-devel) or via pacman (`pacman -Ss libX11-devel`).
The the dependencies where added in the context of #12985.
However I could build Atom even without installing these packages. Maybe I already had installed the equivalents of these packages maybe they aren't even necessary on Arch.
Label: bug

Title: atom.showSaveDialogSync broken in version 1.15.0
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`atom.showSaveDialogSync('some/chosen/path/to/file')` used to work (still worked in version 1.14.0) but doesn't work in version 1.15.0.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in debug mode
2. Open console panel
3. Create a new file and edit something in the editor
4. In the console panel, type `atom.showSaveDialogSync('some/chosen/path/filename')`

**Expected behavior:** A save dialog pops out with the filename and path pre-set according to the param. 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] The save dialog doesn't set to designated path and filename.

**Reproduces how often:** Always in version 1.15.0.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Another example: 

This function is used in the Markdown Preview package (https://github.com/atom/markdown-preview/blob/master/lib/markdown-preview-view.coffee#L292). When the markdown preview pane is opened, right clicking on the preview and selecting "Save as HTML" used to lead to a popped out save dialog with the "Save As..." field auto-filled with a filename ending with ".html". But in version 1.15.0, the filename is just "Untitled".
Label: bug

Title: Copying or cutting without selecting text results in unexpected paste behaviour
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I copy a line without selecting any part of it, whether using Ctrl-c or right clicking and choosing "Copy", and then try to paste the contents of the line, they get added to the beginning of the line instead of being put where my cursor is.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file in Atom. It doesn't matter if there are other lines in this file or not.
2. Move your cursor to the very last line of the file. Type some text there. Press Ctrl-c.
3. Place your cursor on any line in the file, at any place in the line, and press Ctrl-v.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I would expect the copied text to be pasted where the cursor is, without any newlines being pasted.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Instead, the copied text is added to the beginning of the line and, if the cursor is not on the last line of the file, it moves down a line.

Here's a simple example, where I copy `a`, type `b`, then paste repeatedly:

![copy-paste-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17225098/24438786/e53b6fd8-1417-11e7-9fd5-62bacd7a0fec.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

This happens every time.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

I'm using Ubuntu 16.04, but I've seen the same issue in Windows 7 as well.
Label: bug

Title: Folding keybindings duplicated
Body:
The keybinding for Fold All is `ctrl-alt-{` and for Fold Selection is `ctrl-alt-shift-[`. On a US keyboard, these are the same. I didn't override these bindings, and they remain duplicated when I start in safe mode.

Secondary problem: Under Settings => Keybindings, Fold All is shown as `ctrl-alt-{`, while in the command palette it's shown as `ctrl-alt-shift-[`. See screenshots below. Result: even on a keyboard layout that shouldn't be susceptible to this key binding duplication (on my Belgian layout, `[` and `{` don't share a physical key), Fold Selection still gets overridden by Fold All.

Keybindings according to Settings:
![2017-03-17 13_49_46-mint - vmware workstation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/570247/24043897/212eb746-0b19-11e7-9f9b-b81464623e7d.png)

Keybindings according to Command Palette:
![2017-03-17 13_51_44-mint - vmware workstation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/570247/24043898/212f1a88-0b19-11e7-9abe-2c18d07525e5.png)
Label: bug

Title: .gitignore file not adjusting the visual aid off the Tree View
Body:
Similar to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3429#issuecomment-286594653

### Description

I have downloaded atom. Installed it. Opened up a project and the `.gitignore` is not being detected and the Tree View is not changing (reducing the opacity of the folder).

It used to do this in the past. I have tried several projects and all do not work. These projects all work in other applications/IDE so I do not believe it's a project issue. I feel like I'm doing something really silly..

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a fresh install of Atom with no setting changes
2. Set `tree-view.hideVcsIgnoredFiles` to `true`
3. Create a new directory `~/test`
3. Change to the `~/test` directory
3. Execute `git init` within `~/test`
3. Open Atom with the command `atom ~/test`
3. Create a folder named `should-be-ignored`
4. Create a `.gitignore` file
4. Add a line containing `should-be-ignored` to the `.gitignore` file

**Expected:** Folder named `should-be-ignored` to disappear

**Actual:** Folder named `should-be-ignored` remains and does not change color

### Original Repro Steps

1. Have a fresh install of Atom with no setting changes
2. Enable the VCS settings
3. Create a folder, name it eg: `should-be-ignored`
4. Create a .gitignore, add that folder to it
5. Nothing changes

**Expected behavior:** I expect it to tint/opacity change the folder in the Tree view so it's visibly different.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens, no visual que.

### Versions

- Windows 10, 64bit
- Downloaded Latest atom from https://atom.io/
    - Atom 1.15.0
    - Atom Beta 1.16.0 also doesn't work

No plugins.

### Additional Information

Screenshots

![](http://i.imgur.com/sFu4nhx.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/vvOg6jH.png)
Label: bug

Title: Passing {activateItem: false} to Workspace::open causes the item not to be added to the Pane
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`atom.workspace.open` takes a parameter called `activateItem`, described as:

> A Boolean indicating whether to call `Pane::activateItem` on containing pane. Defaults to `true`.

While accurate, `Pane::activateItem` is responsible for calling `Pane::add`. Thus, if `activateItem` is false, the opened item does not get added to the pane at all.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run `atom.workspace.open('file.txt', {activateItem: false})` in the Atom JS console

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Expect `file.txt` to be opened in a new pane item in the background

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

No new item is added to the pane

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

### Description

This text will only scroll as far as the length of the second line even though there's more text on the first line:

```
１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?１２３４５６７８９?

```

The characters in the first line of text are fullwidth Unicode characters.

### Steps to Reproduce

Title: src/config.coffee should use _.deepClone from underscore-plus
Body: Subj, just a reminder (following @50Wliu's request) to make a code cleanup. Line 999 in `src/config.coffee` implements its own deep clone function, but `underscore-plus` already has it (accessible as `_.deepClone`), so that one should be used instead of own implementation.
Label: enhancement

Title: 'Save as' opens a save dialog in a semi-random dir with 'Untitled' as the file name
Body: ### Prerequisites * In safe mode * Was unable to find an existing issue * Seems like it started happening a couple weeks ago. Electron upgrade? ### Description Save as used to open a save dialog in the directory of the focused file with the file's name as the filename in the dialog. Now it opens in the root of the project (most of the time), with the filename as `Untitled`. Also the dialog is much larger than before. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open atom in safe mode 2. open a file 3. cmd-shift-s to save as 4. Get kind of useless dialog **Expected behavior:** Open a dialog in the current directory of the active file, with the name being that of the active file **Actual behavior:** The above dialog **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions On master HEAD as of today: e35a00
Label: bug

Title: Should use name of symlink for determining file type (or have an option).
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Feature request:

I have a symlink in my source directory "main.c", which is a link to "main.c.variant1" (or perhaps one of the other variants). Atom nicely follows the link, but the fact that the destination file isn't ".c" causes it to not do any syntax highlighting or other language-specific stuff.

It would be nice if it made that decision based on the name of the symlink, or perhaps only when the destintation file is of unknown type, or perhaps with an option setting.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Find, say, "sample.c" in your source directory.
2. Rename it "sample.c.notype".
3. Create a symbolic link "sample.c" to point to it.
4. Open "sample.c" in Atom.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

It should be able to figure out that it's a C program.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

It doesn't.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Label: enhancement

Title: Newly added project folder in tree-view disappears after window:reload
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->
From @ungb:

I was able to repro by doing the following:
1. Open a empty Atom window with no project
2. Open context menu and click `Add Project Folder`
3. Add a folder
4. Open command palette and run window:reload

Actual: Atom will reload with empty atom with no project
NOTE: if you open Atom with a project or `atom .` and reload the project will persist.

Expected: project will persist

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Added project folder in tree view would _disappear_ after dispatching command `window:reload` in current beta `1.15-beta-4`;
however, in current stable version `1.14.4` it _shows_ in tree view.

__NOTE__: 
  - this issue happens in both `tree-view`: `0.213.1` and `0.214.1` which are versions along with Atom `1.14.4` and `1.15-beta-4` respectively.
  - if doing `atom.restartApplication()` rather than `window:reload` then added project folder would show.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `$ atom-beta` in terminal to launch Atom beta
2. atom shows some project folders in tree view from last session
3. add a new project folder to tree view
4. `ctrl-shift-f5` to reload atom

**Expected behavior:**

added new project folder would appear in tree view

**Actual behavior:**

added new project folder disappears in tree view, tree view remains same as in step no.2.

**Reproduces how often:**

always

### Versions

```
$ atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.15.0-beta4
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0~
```
Label: bug

Title: workspace.open() opens two editors when called in quick succession (with searchAllPanes = true)
Body:
### Steps to Reproduce

`atom.workspace.open('/path/to/file', {searchAllPanes: true}); atom.workspace.open('/path/to/file', {searchAllPanes: true});`

**Expected behavior:** Only one editor

**Actual behavior:** Two editors

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

1.15.0-beta4

### Additional Information

@ebluestein found this while working on a feature for Nuclide. It's occurring because the item's being searched for synchronously but then added asynchronously. To solve it, we probably have to introduce a queue so that the second call doesn't happen until the first completes. (This can be as simple as storing a promise per-URI while the `open()` is in progress and chaining to that.)

cc @maxbrunsfeld @ebluestein
Label: bug

Title: Window close does not trigger save window state
Body:
### Description

Closing the Atom window does not save the window UI state, _read_ window size and position. To save the window state I have to **blur** (click outside) the window, then close it. Reopening the window after blurring it works.

According to the code in `window-event-handler.coffee` the window state should be stored both when a window closes and when blurred:
```coffee
handleWindowBlur: =>
    @atomEnvironment.storeWindowDimensions()

handleWindowBeforeunload: (event) =>
  @atomEnvironment.storeWindowDimensions()
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `atom .` to open project of your choice
2. Resize window, maintain window focus
3. Close window
4. Back to terminal, `atom .` again

Redo step **1-2** and before closing the window in step **3**, **blur** the window, click your desktop. Then close the window and continue with step **4**, the new window should open with the same dimensions as the window you just closed.

**Expected behavior:** The window you open in step **4** should be restored to the resized state, when you closed the window.

**Actual behavior:** The window you open in step **4** is restored back to the state before you resized, in step **2**.



### Versions

Atom    : 1.14.4
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
macOS 10.12.3

### Additional Information

I did try to start Atom in safe mode, and also with the `--clear-window-state` flag. Even deleting my `~/.atom/storage`.

You can also reload the window and see the same behaviour, instead of closing and re-opening a window. Resize Atom window then reload, watch it reset back to old dimensions, before reload. Watch the gif for a demo:

![window-state](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/979555/23480337/e966c98c-fec7-11e6-9ecd-91e23df89891.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Improper display of long indented hyperlinks in text files with soft wrap
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] All done! Including "safe mode" and "factory settings".

### Additional information:

This issue was originally opened here: https://github.com/atom/language-hyperlink/issues/16. But as commented by @lee-dohm this may not be "a flaw in the language-hyperlink package itself and more of a problem with rendering". @AndreaGriffiths11

### Description:

Long indented hyperlinks produce these ugly ugly lines when soft wrap is enabled in atom:

![atom_lorem_link_circled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19208670/23333215/175be1b2-fb88-11e6-8d6f-cb271c7ed9c8.png)

How do I get rid of these lines? The blank spaces should not be underlined since they're not part of the hyperlink.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Optional: Reset to factory defaults with `mv ~/.atom ~/.atom-backup` under linux.
2. Copy-paste a long hyperlink in a .txt file.
3. Indent it with a few tabs.
4. Enable Soft Wrap with: `View > Toggle Soft Wrap.`
5. And disable the Indent Guide if it's activated: `Settings > Editor > Show Indent Guide`

I get the ugly lines 100% of the time on two different computers.

### Configuration:

`atom --version`:
Atom: 1.14.3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome: 52.0.2743.82
Node: 6.5.0
`apm --version`:
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 3.6.0
git 2.11.1

Please let me know if you need more info.

And thank you __so very much__ for the work you're doing!! :D
Label: bug

Title: Atom closes without prompting to save
Body:
Hello,
I am using Atom 1.14.3 in Mint-17 64-bit and the following scenario causes Atom to close without prompting to save the modified file.

Core setting is:
"Restore previous windows on start" -- UNCHECKED
"Open Empty editor on start" -- CHECKED

Scenario 1 - With just one Untitled tab (as expected)
1) Launch Atom editor from Menu
2) In the Untitled tab (document), type something to make it into a modified but DO NOT save the document
3) Close Atom and it will prompt you to save or to discard the Untitled document.

Scenario 2 - With one Untitled document + One unmodified file (The bug scenario)
1) Launch Atom editor from Menu
2) Open a document but do not modify it
3) If TreeView is shown, toggle it off
4) In the Untitled document, type something to modify it but do not save it. It does not matter how many "Untitled" documents are opened. 
5) Press Ctrl-Q or hit the X to close Atom. Atom does not prompt the user to save the Untitled document and simply discarding it and exit. OOPS! This is difference from Scenario 1.

I have been using an unmodified version of Atom other than to choose the themes from standard ones.

Rover
Label: bug

Title: Raster text cursor doesn't scale and doesn't look native
Body:
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

By default, Atom uses a base64 encoded image as the text cursor in the atom-text-editor component. There are some problems with this:

- It's not the native text cursror - looks out of place
- It doesn't scale well - the first image below is the default cursor, with macOS cursor scaling enabled. The second shows the native OS text cursor (pixellated..). The native cursror was scaled correctly as a vector but the screenshot tool for some reason renders it at the normal 1x size (just imagine it scaled properly :))

![cursor-img](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4211302/23124134/4f4b3998-f763-11e6-9534-90431208c23e.png)

![cursor-reg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4211302/23124137/55d5812e-f763-11e6-9f83-e5fcbe1fa98d.png)

Fix is to use something similar to this: 

```css
atom-text-editor.editor .scroll-view {
    cursor: text;
}
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Hover over a text field

**Expected behavior:** Cursor should be native text cursor, should scale with accessibility settings

**Actual behavior:** Cursor is a custom raster image - therefore becomes pixellated when scaled

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```fish
> atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.15.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.
```

macOS sierra 10.12.3
Label: enhancement

Title: Don't let run atom as root
Body:
In particular for experienced users is [pretty known](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10566#issuecomment-278616243) they shouldn't run atom as root, not only for problems this make on .atom folder but also because of security issues. [In this post Martin Gräßlin](https://blog.martin-graesslin.com/blog/2017/02/editing-files-as-root/) (Kate and Kwrite developer) say:

> Today I pushed a change for Kate and KWrite which does no longer allow to be run as root. Instead it educates the user about how to do the same with sudoedit.

Probably Atom should do the same.
Label: enhancement

Title: Soft wrap settings reset when saving new file
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If soft wrap is enabled on a new, unsaved file and you save that file, then soft wrap is disabled on that file.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new, untitled window.
2. Put in enough text so as to require horizontal scrolling, and enable the soft wrapping under "View" -> "Toggle Soft Wrap"
3. Save the file

**Expected behavior:**

I expect the file to save and retain the soft wrap settings.

**Actual behavior:** 

The file saves but soft wrap is reset, and you get a single long line of text.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% reproducible. Only happens when saving a *new* file - if you enable soft wrap again, make some changes in the file and save it again, then the soft wrap settings are retained.

### Versions

Atom:
```
Atom    : 1.14.2
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
Apm:
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.1
```
OS: OSX Sierra 10.12.3
```
$ uname -mprsv
Darwin 16.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.4.0: Thu Dec 22 22:53:21 PST 2016; root:xnu-3789.41.3~3/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 i386
```

Title: Atom icon doesn't override pinned icon in Windows 10 taskbar
Body: Windows 10, started happening in 1.14.1: if the atom launcher is pinned to the taskbar, when the program launches it creates another icon that doesn't override it. It's not that big a problem but when shortcutting with <kbd>Windows key</kbd> + <kbd>#</kbd> (number of the application on the taskbar), it will open a new window instead on focusing on the one you were working on.
Label: bug

Title: Atom keeps trying to wrap long lines on markdown file causing text to blink
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I open an specific file (described below) with an specific windows size (see screencap) atom will try to accommodate the text by wrapping the long lines, then revert it and try again,resulting in the text alternating between this too states in a loop. The bottom half of the text will show and disappear while the top is being rearranged.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open this file on atom https://github.com/docker-library/wordpress/blob/d8e5577dcc7096d2b694dda433e2b5c7c4561a82/README.md
2. If the text is still, resize the window until it reproduces the bug.

**Expected behavior:** 
The text should be rendered and stay still until the window is resized.

**Actual behavior:** 
The text will "blink" between these three states.
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921798/22718325/e6cf5998-ed86-11e6-864b-f93cbe79ad14.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: Unable to save a CPU Profile
Body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description A security error is produced when attempting to collect a CPU Profile through the developer tools in Atom. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Launch Atom in your local atom repository 2. Press Alt+Cmd+I to open the Developer Tools 3. Click the Profiles tab in the Developer Tools 1. Ensure "Record JavaScript CPU Profile" is selected 1. Click Start 1. Do a couple random things in the editor 1. Click Stop 1. Observe that a SecurityError regarding temporary storage is displayed 1. Click the Save link next to the new profile record 1. Save to `~/Downloads` 1. Get info on the new `*.cpuprofile` file **Expected behavior:** The `cpuprofile` file to be longer than zero bytes **Actual behavior:** The `cpuprofile` file is always zero bytes ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.15.0-dev-ae9d949ee Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ``` I also reproduced this using v1.13.1 and v1.14.0-beta4. ### Additional Information
Label: bug

Title: The Reopen Projects menu is empty when atom is opened without a project
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [x]  Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x]  Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Unexpected restart causes Atom to lose project state

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom, go to settings -> core and unselect  `Reopen Previous Windows On Start`
2. Close Atom and open Atom from spotlight
3. Go to content menu and try to open recent projects.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
It has recent projects
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
It's empty,  when you open a project, it gets populated. 

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

No Project loaded:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/22668453/a47be014-ec75-11e6-990e-e43baf81b55b.png)



After opening a project:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5624870/22668474/b306971e-ec75-11e6-9e57-4eff8eef9ad9.png)


### Versions

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```
### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

Title: Unexpected restart causes Atom to lose project state
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm currently grappling with a problem with my laptop where it restarts when resuming from sleep without an external power source.  This causes Atom to lose the project I was working on, and I have to reopen it.  The Reopen Projects menu is also empty, though it is populated once a folder is opened.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a folder in Atom
2. Somehow trigger an unexpected restart (I don't know if holding down the power button will work for this)
3. After restarting, reopen Atom

**Expected behavior:** The project to be displayed

**Actual behavior:** An empty editor with only an Untitled tab (if that option is enabled)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.15.0-dev-4eb3f22
Electron: 1.4.15
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
```
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
Windows 10 x64.

### Additional Information

This may be related to #11406, though I have not been able to specifically reproduce that as 1) all open files are always saved before I put the laptop to sleep, and 2) there is no way for me to be typing in Atom when the restart occurs, as it happens as soon as Windows attempts to recover from sleep.
Label: bug

Title: With invisibles on, hard tabs render larger than they should
Body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description With `editor.showInvisibles` set to `true` and `editor.tabType` set to `hard`, tabs render one character larger than they should: Setting `editor.showInvisibles` to `false` corrects the problem: ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Launch Atom in your local atom repository 2. Open Settings View using Cmd+, on macOS or Ctrl+, on other platforms 3. Click the Editor tab 1. Check "Show Invisibles" 1. Set "Tab Type" to "hard" 1. Set "Tab Length" to 6 1. Open a new file using Cmd+N on macOS or Ctrl+N on other platforms 1. Type `1234567890` on the first line and press Enter 1. Press Tab on the second line **Expected behavior:** The cursor to align between the 6 and the 7 from the line above **Actual behavior:** The cursor aligns between the 7 and the 8 from the line above ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.15.0-dev-7e7224c67 Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 ``` ### Additional Information `config.cson` ```coffee "*": "advanced-new-file": suggestCurrentFilePath: true "advanced-open-file": createFileInstantly: true "atom-color-highlight": hideMarkersInComments: true hideMarkersInStrings: true markersAtEndOfLine: true "tab" defaultProvider: "Fuzzy" scopeBlacklist: [ ".string .comment" ] core: audioBeep: false customFileTypes: "source.git-config": [ "gitconfig" ] "source.ini": [ ".flowconfig" ] "source.ruby": [ "Brewfile" ] "text.slim": [ "slime" ] "text.xml.plist": [ "plist" ] disabledPackages: [ "background-tips" "fonts" ] followSymlinks: true ignoredNames: [ ".git" ".hg" ".svn" ".DS_Store" ".keep" "._*" "*.pyc" "Thumbs.db" ] openEmptyEditorOnStart: false projectHome: "/Users/Lee/Source" telemetryConsent: "limited" themes: [ "one-light-ui" "one-light-syntax" ] editor: fontFamily: "Anonymous Pro" fontSize: 16 invisibles: cr: "↩" eol: " " tab: "⇥" preferredLineLength: 100 scrollPastEnd: true showInvisibles: true tabLength: 4 tabType: "hard" "find-and-replace": scrollToResultOnLiveSearch: true fonts: fontFamily: "Anonymous Pro" "fortune-background-tips": fortuneCommand: "fortune -s Computers" "fuzzy-finder": preserveLastSearch: true "highlight-selected": showInStatusBar: false "markdown-preview": openPreviewInSplitPane: false useGitHubStyle: true "markdown-table-formatter": formatOnSave: false minimap: charHeight: 4 charWidth: 2 ignoreWhitespacesInTokens: true plugins: "status-bar": cursorPositionFormat: "L:%L C:%C" fullWidth: false tabs: enableVcsColoring: true "tabs-to-spaces": changeSoftTabsMode: true onSave: "untabify" "tree-view": hideIgnoredNames: true Title: Open a new file from terminal from same project, clears old tabs and unsaved buffer from that project
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Open a new file from terminal from same project, clears old tabs and unsaved buffer from that project

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a project in terminal with `atom .`
2. Open a file and modify it, don't save.
3. Close Atom(this won't repro if there's other atom windows open.  Only if all Atom instances are closed)
4. On the same directory in terminal, do `atom <new file name>`


**Actual**: Atom opens new file with the current folder.  The changes on the file that was modify in step 2 are gone.  When you close Atom and reopen with `atom .` or opening recent projects, it shows the new file from step 4 only.

**Expected**: old tabs and unsaved changes should exist(if there are any) and new file should open in new tab 

**Reproduces how often:** 100% if you don't have another atom instance open, If you do, the new file will be opened there.

### Versions

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1
```

This issue was found while testing https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/306#issuecomment-276861137
Label: bug

Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
