    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have created a new package [toggle-mode-modules](https://atom.io/packages/toggle-node-modules) and tried to use the following as a default keymap, but it does NOT appear when selecting `Packages -> Toggle Node Modules -> Toggle`

I have since changed the default to `ctrl-shift-t` which now works...

```
'.platform-linux atom-workspace, .platform-win32 atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': 'toggle-node-modules:toggle'

'.platform-darwin atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': 'toggle-node-modules:toggle'
``` 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. This can be replicated by trying to create a new entry in `keymap.cson`

```
'.platform-darwin atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': **'toggle-node-modules:toggle'
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I expected the defined keymap to appear in `Packages -> Toggle Node Modules -> Toggle`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

No menu keyboard equivalent appears

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Had discussion on Slack channel with @BinaryMuse and @lee-dohm who requested I create this ticket
Label: bug

Title: 1.13 Regression: Font Family setting causing CssSyntaxErrors
Body:
### Prerequisites

Note: I am only able to reproduce some of the issues.

### Description

Starting with the release of Atom 1.13.0, we have received [a](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-wont-start-up/38354) [number](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-1-13-update-non-functional/38189/10) [of](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13586) [bug](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/900) [reports](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13631) about the Font Family setting causing a `CssSyntaxError` to be thrown.  These errors did not appear in versions prior to 1.13.0, and while they may be correct, should at the very least be displayed in a more "pleasing" manner.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Enter a quote or some otherwise malformed CSS into the Font Family box.  Some reports also suggest that a semicolon can cause the error, but I couldn't reproduce it.

**Expected behavior:** Nothing

**Actual behavior:** CssSyntaxError

**Reproduces how often:** 100% for quotes or otherwise invalid CSS, 0% for semicolons

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Not relevant, this is a 1.13 regression.  Appears to happen on all OSes.
Label: bug

Title: Entire buffer cleared when file changes causing scroll position to be lost
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When using linters with auto-fix enabled (for example linter-eslint), it will fix code style errors for you upon saving the file you're working on, e.g. missing semi colon, incorrect indentation, etc.

For a while now, when this happens, Atom tends to momentarily blank out the window and then re-insert the fixed contents, causing the window to scroll up. This is problematic, as it causes you to lose your scroll position and as such your focus of the area of code you were working on.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install/enable only core packages and linter as well as linter-eslint
2. Use the following rules for eslint:

```
{
    "parser": "babel-eslint",
    "env": {
        "es6": true
    },
    "rules": {
        "semi": [ 1, "always" ]
    }
}
```

3. Open these file contents (thanks @dwelle) http://pastebin.com/raw/Yk6K1w5k and save as `test.js`.
4. Scroll to the bottom and remove the last semi colon.
5. Save the file

**Expected behavior:**
Contents remains visible, then is fixed/replaced by a fixed contents, while maintaining scroll position.

**Actual behavior:**
The buffer is cleared, then contents re-appears and the scroll position is at the top.

**Reproduces how often:**
Nearly 100% with the provided example file.

### Versions
OS X: 10.11.5
Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-157e8e1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.2

### Additional information
Note that while the example file is quite large with 3000+ lines, this behaviour *does* occur quite regularly with smaller files as well. It's just not 100% reproducible in those cases. But it could be that the file size/length emphasises the issue.

### See also
- https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/issues/620
- https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/issues/774
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11483
Label: enhancement

Title: Adopt Sublime Text's handling of punctuation at the start of alt-left/right
Body:
### Description

Atom alt-left/right and alt-shift-left/right (skip over or select word) should ignore certain punctuation characters in front of the cursor. This makes it easier to select parts of a JavaScript property chain, for example.

### Steps to Reproduce

Tab through this text in Atom vs. Sublime Text:

    this.props.horse.cart.battery.staple

Tab through this text in Atom vs. Sublime Text:

    this.props.horse.cart['battery'][staple]

Screencast showing Sublime Text vs. Atom behaviour:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qovtU8MIygo&feature=youtu.be

**Expected behavior:**

In the first example when you start a selection before a period Sublime Text includes the period and continues to the next punctuation character. In the second example Sublime Text also skips over `['` at the beginning of the selection.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom stops at every punctuation character.

### Versions

Atom 1.13.0 x64 Mac
Label: enhancement

Title: Window title is `untitled` when no files are open
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The title of the window is `untitled` even when there is no new/untitled file open.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project folder
2. Ensure all file tabs are closed

**Expected behavior:**
The title of the window should show the location of the project folder, so that when you are viewing the window and the tree view happens to be scrolled down (moving the root folder out of view) you will still know what window you're looking at.

Are present, if you have multiple windows open, they will all say `untitled` which isn't very helpful. I'm pretty sure this has been introduced in one of the latest releases and that it didn't use to be like this.

**Actual behavior:**
The title of the window says `untitled`

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions
Atom 1.14.0-dev-157e8e1
OS X 10.11.5
Label: bug

### Description

Zoom using `Ctrl-MWheel` does not work in Atom 1.13.0. It worked in Atom 1.12.9.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in safe mode using `atom --safe`
2. Open the `settings-view` and ensure you have the `Zoom Font When Ctrl Scrolling` setting enabled.
3. Try to zoom using `Ctrl-MWheel`.

**Expected behavior:** Font size to change depending on scroll direction.

**Actual behavior:** The Text editor scrolls.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

#### atom --version
```
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

#### apm --version
```
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.11.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

`event.target` in [this check](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/c6db4df6c09d3863043c1ff0e767578db611cdd5/src/workspace-element.coffee#L105) in different in Atom 1.13.0.

### Atom 1.12.9

![1 12 9](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/21962470/2b31f4fa-db27-11e6-9932-fedc599ddb78.PNG)

### Atom 1.13.0

![1 13 0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/21962471/2fb09aea-db27-11e6-83a2-d26d43bd26ba.PNG)

----

For some reason I can't scroll zoom in/out in the editor even with the option being checked. Any ideas?
Label: bug

Title: Rename, reveal in tree view, and show in finder with split files can affect the wrong split
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I open 2 files in horizontal split and try to rename (RMB on file tab -> "Rename") the right one, it shows the name of the left one and renames it, not the right one.  Reveal in tree view and show in finder are similarly affected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open two files
2. Drag one of them to the right until editor highlights a right split for it
3. Focus the file on the left.
3. Right-click the file on the right and try to rename it.

**Expected behavior:** a pop-up appears with an input box for renaming the "right" file

**Actual behavior:** a pop-up appears with an input box for renaming the "left" file

**Reproduces how often:** was able to catch it once

### Versions

Xubuntu 16.04
atom v6.5.0
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

### Additional Information

*none*
Label: bug

Title: Arabic sentences between double quotations are rendered out of the quotations
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Arabic sentences between double quotations (") sometimes are rendered out of the quotations.


![arabic-in-atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4347943/21939092/e592949c-d9c6-11e6-8a6e-45e66bfc29ad.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create `test.js` file (the syntax must be JavaScript, plain text does not reproduce the problem)
2. Write البنك المركزي المصري between double quotations ("البنك المركزي المصري")

**Expected behavior:** The sentence inside the double quotations "البنك المركزي المصري"

**Actual behavior:** Part of the sentence is out of the quotations pound

### Versions

`atom --version`:
```
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
`apm --version`:
```
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0
```
OS: Arch linux
Label: bug

Title: The entire editor breaks when a UI theme's ui-variables.less causes the Less compiler to error
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

The problem cannot be reproduced in safe mode, as safe mode does not load packages and themes. I recognise that the problem is caused by a package external to Atom. I believe that this is a valid issue despite this. I have met the other prerequisites.

### Description

When a UI theme is selected with a `styles/ui-variables.less` file which would cause the Less compiler to error, and Atom is reloaded, the editor fails to load, and the window remains an empty white box.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone [atom-community/ui-theme-template](https://github.com/atom-community/ui-theme-template).
2. Append `#` on a new line to `styles/ui-variables.less`. Alternatively, `@foo: @bar;` can be appended, where `@bar` is undefined. This also reproduces the issue. 
3. Run `apm link --dev` in the root of the repository.
4. Open Atom in developer mode (`atom --dev`), navigate to the themes section of the settings screen, and select "Ui Theme Template" from the UI themes dropdown list.
5. Reload Atom in developer mode (I tried both `ctrl + alt + r`, and simply closing Atom and re-opening it with `atom --dev`).

I have only reproduced the problem in developer mode. I have not attempted to reproduce the problem in Atom's normal mode, as I fear being unable to reverse it.

**Expected behavior:** The editor loads.

**Actual behavior:** The editor does not load, and the window remains an empty white box. The Chromium developer tools automatically open to the console.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 3.6.0
git 2.11.0.windows.1
visual studio

Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]

### Additional Information

Here is the stack trace:

    index.js:61 Error
        at new Parser (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\node_modules\less\lib\less\parser.js:333:27)
        at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.parseLess (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\node_modules\less-cache\lib\less-cache.js:255:16)
        at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.cssForFile (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\node_modules\less-cache\lib\less-cache.js:286:20)
        at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.readFileSync (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\node_modules\less-cache\lib\less-cache.js:274:19)
        at LessCompileCache.module.exports.LessCompileCache.read (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\less-compile-cache.js:36:25)
        at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadLessStylesheet (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\theme-manager.js:280:33)
        at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadStylesheet (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\theme-manager.js:256:21)
        at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.requireStylesheet (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\theme-manager.js:174:24)
        at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.reloadBaseStylesheets (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\theme-manager.js:236:12)
        at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadBaseStylesheets (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\theme-manager.js:231:19)
        at new AtomEnvironment (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\atom-environment.js:272:19)
        at module.exports (C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.12.9\resources\app.asar\src\initialize-application-window.js:26:19)
        at setupWindow (file:///C:/Users/Matt/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.12.9/resources/app.asar/static/index.js:81:12)
        at window.onload (file:///C:/Users/Matt/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.12.9/resources/app.asar/static/index.js:41:9)
Label: bug

Title: Select to beginning or end of word in macOS Sierra save dialog not working
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom is not respecting the system keybinding for select to the beginning or end of word (shift+option+left arrow/right arrow) in macOS Sierra save dialog boxes.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new blank document or open an existing one.
2. Choose File > Save As… 
3. Enter a multi-word file name in the Save As: field and use shift+option+left arrow or shift+option+right arrow to attempt to select individual words in the file name.

**Expected behavior:** The preceding or proceeding word should be selected.

**Actual behavior:** Atom invokes the Selection > Select to Beginning of Word/Select to End of Word menu item.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.8
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.2

OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.2 (16C67)

### Additional Information

This issue happens in both states of the expanded or non-expanded state of the macOS Sierra save dialog.
Label: bug

Title: Cursor::getPixelRect calls deprecated TextEditor::pixelRectForScreenRange
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`Cursor::getPixelRect` calls deprecated `TextEditor::pixelRectForScreenRange`. Causing a deprecation warning in latest Atom Beta 1.13.0-beta9.

`This is now a view method. Call TextEditorElement::pixelRectForScreenRange instead.`

### Steps to Reproduce

Use the color-picker plugin on latest beta, check deprecation warnings.  Throws this call stack in the warning:

```
TextEditor.pixelRectForScreenRange - /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:3559:12
Cursor.getPixelRect - /Applications/Atom Beta.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:675:26
```

I'm sure this happens in other plugins, this just happens to be the one that shows it for me.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.0-beta9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS X El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G1212)
Label: bug

Title: Atom can't save over hidden files
Body:
### Info
**OS:** Windows 10 64-bit
**Atom Version:** 1.12.8

### Description
Atom can't save over hidden files

I have some hidden files (.js .css etc..) I'm able to open and edit them but once I try to save changes I get a message saying: **"Unable to save file <path to my file> - EPERM: operation not permitted, open  <path to my file>"**

the files are just hidden and NOT set to "Read-only", once I unhide the file I can save it just fine.

### Steps to Reproduce
Under Windows OS
1. create or open a file with whatever file extension
2. right click the file and choose **Properties** from the context menu
3. check the option **Hidden** and apply/OK
4. open the file in atom and make some changes
5. try saving the file through **File > Save** or **ctrl + s** and an error message will appear and changes will not be saved
Label: bug

Title: Error: nothing provides libXss1 needed by atom-1.12.8-0.1.x86_64
Body:
Hi,

It seems like you've patched one problem, only to expose yet another with the release of Atom 1.12.8. As while you may have fixed a CentOS dependency issue there's a new Fedora dependency issue. Trying to install Atom 1.12.8 with Fedora's DNF package manager (namely on Fedora 25) gave the error:

```bash
Last metadata expiration check: 1:00:11 ago on Wed Jan  4 07:13:30 2017.
Error: nothing provides libXss1 needed by atom-1.12.8-0.1.x86_64
(try to add '--allowerasing' to command line to replace conflicting packages)
```

Thanks for your time,
Brenton
Label: bug

Title: Paste indentation issue with auto-indent off
Body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Paste apparently takes the current indentation into account, even when Auto Indent and Auto Indent On Paste are off. This happens in any grammar, including plain text.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Type the following:
```
a
  b
    c
```
2. Copy from (and including) the new-line at the end of the first line, upto the end of the second line. Go to the end of the third line, and paste.

**Expected behavior:** The result should be:
```
a
  b
    c
  b
```

**Actual behavior:** The result is:
```
a
  b
    c
      b
```

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome : 52.0.2743.82
Node : 6.5.0

apm 1.12.9
npm 3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio 2013

Windows 8.1

### Additional Information

![gif](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24660923/21487661/17adbdc2-cbcf-11e6-95b4-5e271dd68e8e.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'isGreaterThan' of null
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When on the first column of an empty line, trying to increment the indentation through the `editor:indent` will raise an exception instead of increasing the indentation. This does not occurs when the cursor is no longer at the beginning of the line nor when the line is not empty.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Place the cursor at the beginning of an empty line
2. Trigger the `editor:indent` command

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The line should have been indented and the cursor moved to the new position

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

An uncaught exception is raised.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

Title: Some editor DOM operations stop working correctly after a certain number of lines
Body:
#### Scrollbar

We render a scrollbar by creating a div with a height that reflects the editor's screen line count. Unfortunately DOM nodes' heights seem to be bounded:

![max-height](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/21280897/adccf898-c39d-11e6-8e62-fb6b682ed2c2.png)

Reported by @ungb and @Ben3eeE 

#### Decoration rendering

Absolutely-positioned elements like cursors stop rendering correctly after a certain number of lines. It seems that DOM nodes' `top` property has a hard upper bound.

/cc @nathansobo @as-cii Any ideas on how to solve this?
Label: bug

Title: Overriding nonWordCharacters is unwieldy
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

(Some pre-reqs have been omitted because they don't apply)

### Description

Paraphrasing from my comment over at https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/pull/249#issuecomment-264072613...

There's no way to respect the user's setting when overriding `nonWordCharacters` in a scope-specific setting since `nonWordCharacters` is a single string.  That means it's an all-or-nothing change, rather than being able to add or remove characters as necessary.

For example, $ is a valid identifier for many languages. However the default `nonWordCharacters` includes `$`, which means attempting to double-click to select a variable with `$` in it will only select part of it. The best way to fix this currently is to override `nonWordCharacters` in the language settings by copying/pasting the default value and removing the `$`. However, this totally disregards any customizations the user may have made.

**Possible solutions**:
* The best one I could think of is adding some type of new setting that takes scenarios like these into account.

### Steps to Reproduce

N/A - this is an API limitation.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-d3d06fb
Electron: 1.4.7
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
```
on Windows 10 x64.

/cc @nathansobo
Label: enhancement

Title: Grapheme clusters are not properly supported
Body:
**EDIT: The emoji is now rendered properly but does not behave properly.  See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13360#issuecomment-272671671.**

I'm running Atom 1.12.6 on macOS Sierra 10.12.1. While many single-codepoint emoji like 👻 are properly supported, emojis consisting of multiple codepoints (connected via [zero-width joiners](http://emojipedia.org/zero-width-joiner/)) like 👩?👩?👦?👦 are not.

Pasting the first into Atom:

![screen shot 2016-11-30 at 8 08 31 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1620098/20753399/3f48f3fc-b6d4-11e6-82c2-af4b637237c3.png)

Pasting the second:

![screen shot 2016-11-30 at 8 08 43 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1620098/20753407/451c35dc-b6d4-11e6-9503-e29e7f79bd68.png)

It seems the joiners are removed, and the individual codepoints are inserted as separate characters. You can reproduce this by simply copy-pasting the emojis from this issue, or using the emoji selector (Ctrl + Command + Space) on a Mac.
Label: bug

Title: Selection highlight moves when scrolling horizontally
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Selection highlight changes when scrolling horizontally using a trackpad.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom in your local Atom repository
1. Open the file `src/gutter-container-component.coffee`
1. Highlight from the beginning of line 37 through the first few characters of line 38
1. Shrink the editor horizontally to enable scrolling
1. Use the trackpad to scroll horizontally

**Expected behavior:** Selection highlight to not change

**Actual behavior:** End of selection highlight moves to always remain visible

![scroll-jump](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/20681755/da7b87f8-b559-11e6-836f-9912bb603838.gif)

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

Also reproduces on `master` at f6043af.
Label: bug

Title: Problems editing mixed German/Syriac text
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [YES ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [ YES] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [NO ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ NO] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ YES] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ YES] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

When editing a mixed-language document (German and Syriac, which is an RTL language), the behaviour at the junctions of these languages as well as inside of Syriac text is erratic at best. I noticed four distinct problematic behaviours:

- it takes around three dozen presses of the left or right arrow keys to step into a half-dozen-letter Syriac word, through it, and back out of it again
- it is almost impossible to place the cursor at the intended Syriac letter using the mouse
- once you click into a Syriac word, the cursor disappears
- (this one is minor) Syriac letters don't obey the letter width of fixed-width fonts such as Courier New

Taken together, these issues are unfortunately a deal-breaker for me. I also have to edit documents combining other RTL and LTR languages and it is day-to-day work for me. This is unfortunate, because I really like that Atom always keeps the document left-aligned instead of deciding alignment line-by-line as e.g. gedit does.

I suspect a connection of what I'm experiencing here to what is described in #4682.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open atom
2. paste below text into the editing area
3. position cursor before the first letter
4. keep right arrow key pressed; notice time it takes the cursor to move through non-Latin parts of the document
5. try other things described above

```
Olafbeṯ I - *Alphabet I* - ?ܳܠܰܦܒܶܬܼ ?. In dieser Lektion lernen wir das Alphabet. Haus, *b*ayto, *ܒ?ܰ*?ܬ?.
```

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.5
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12+
git 2.10.2
$ cat /etc/debian_version 
stretch/sid
$ uname -a
Linux t430 4.8.0-1-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.8.5-1 (2016-10-28) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
I also tested the same atom version under Windows 7 Professional.
Label: bug

Title: Codepage 850 (European DOS) support
Body:
Many older DOS files in Europe used codepage 850 which is the European equivalent of 437 which sacrifices some block-drawing characters for common accented symbols in France, Spain etc.

A sample file can be found http://cd.textfiles.com/simtel/simtel9703/disk2/UTILS/TRANSLAT/ESPANOL.TRN

None of the existing codepages can reliably translate this and the codepage is already supported by the underlying iconv-lite library we use.
Label: enhancement

Title: change the atom.sh script to launch the local build
Body:
The `atom.sh` script (which gets copied to the `out`directory during the build process) [seems to be looking](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/0122b7726a1e4eace2a9650b94d9e03c2926c944/atom.sh#L66-L82) in common system-wide locations for an installed Atom version before looking for a local binary, which makes it impossible to use the script to run the locally built atom from the `out` directory.

[According to](https://atomio.slack.com/archives/atom/p1479831997006512) @50Wliu, the batch file on Windows is set up differently and always runs the relative Atom binary. It would be nice if the atom.sh script did the same.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom silently dismisses some serious (though non-critical) startup errors
Body:
I had configured (via /etc/environment) the TMP var (which specifies the temporary directory on most GNU/Linux) to point to ~/.tmp, but as I already know, node-based apps don't recognize it (though other apps, like Thunderbird, do).

This dir is where node-based apps store a temporary unix socket for IPC. What I see as a problem (I understand this is not a bug, but a implementation decision, though IMO it would be better to change it) is that when Atom is not able to create an IPC socket (or on any other significant, though not critical error), it silently ignores the error and continues as if everything was OK. Then we observe a degradation in user experience without understanding the real cause. In my case it was that Atom was not detecting correctly that there was already a running instance so it was creating a new window for each new file opened externally (via shell/cli). Though, it does create an error file ~/.atom/nohup.out with the following content:

```
Application server failed { Error: listen EACCES ~/.tmp/atom-1.12.3-userx.sock
    at Object.exports._errnoException (util.js:1008:11)
    at exports._exceptionWithHostPort (util.js:1031:20)
    at Server._listen2 (net.js:1240:19)
    at listen (net.js:1289:10)
    at Server.listen (net.js:1378:5)
    at AtomApplication.module.exports.AtomApplication.listenForArgumentsFromNewProcess (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/main-process/atom-application.js:282:14)
    at AtomApplication.module.exports.AtomApplication.initialize (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/main-process/atom-application.js:120:12)
    at Function.module.exports.AtomApplication.open (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/main-process/atom-application.js:59:38)
    at App.<anonymous> (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/main-process/start.js:68:21)
    at emitTwo (events.js:111:20)
    at App.emit (events.js:191:7)
  code: 'EACCES',
  errno: 'EACCES',
  syscall: 'listen',
  address: '~/.tmp/atom-1.12.3-userx.sock',
  port: -1 }
```

For a comparison (and this is how the error was discovered) Visual Studio Code (which is also node-based) reports the error on initialization and fails to start.
Label: bug

Title: Unsaved buffer state isn't silently preserved when the Window has no project folder
Body:
Unsaved buffer state is preserved as part of the project system. When there is no project, it doesn't get saved. Prior to [this fix](https://github.com/stereobooster/atom/commit/c6a89a4abe560c22758ea3c755dacc0fc4368039) this behavior could result in data loss. That's now fixed, but seamlessly preserving state as Atom does for projects would be more convenient and is the more elegant fix.

We would readily accept a well-tested PR providing this functionality.

See also #10474.
Label: enhancement

Title: In some scenarios, opening Atom on Linux results in 100% CPU usage of a core
Body:
* When some Linux users open Atom via .desktop files or via the gnome launcher, they experience 100% CPU usage due to the way we are invoking the shell to patch the user's environment
* This does not happen for all Linux users
* This does seem to happen consistently for users on Arch Linux
* The shell is invoked with `detached: false` and using the `-i` flag for an interactive shell
  * The intent of shelling out to get the environment is to run the same shell initialization scripts that are run when a user opens a terminal window and invokes atom from there
  * Removing the `-i` flag is not the solution, because it doesn't result in the desired behavior; it does result in the shell exiting as expected without consuming 100% of a CPU core
  * Adding `detached: true` to the options used for `child_process.spawn` _does_ fix the issue and retains the desired behavior, but it requires additional code to manage the process lifecycle if Atom exits or an Atom window is reloaded while the shell process is still running

The below is a copy of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13084#issuecomment-262507036, included here to open up a new issue:

@phw says:

~~~
I debugged this a bit and can reproduce it with the following test script (extracted from [src/update-process-env.js](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1b2d2f029945c58cf4cd474ef1423856b35cf26c/src/update-process-env.js)):

```javascript
const childProcess = require('child_process')
const cmd = 'command env'
const shell = process.env.SHELL  // zsh or bash doesn't matter, behavior is the same
// const shell = '/bin/bash'

const child = childProcess.spawn(shell, ['-ilc', cmd], {
   encoding: 'utf8',
  //  detached: true,
  stdio: ['ignore', 'pipe', process.stderr]
})
child.on('error', (e) => {
  console.log('error', e)
})
child.stdout.on('data', (data) => {
  console.log(data.toString('utf8'))
})
child.on('close', (code, signal) => {
  console.log('close', code, signal)
})
```

Launching this directly from a shell works, even if I set an empty environment like so:

    env -i SHELL=/bin/bash node spawn.js

Launching the same from a desktop file in Gnome 3.22 leads to the shell task endlessly consuming 100% of CPU. I used the following desktop file:

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Spawn Node Test
Exec=env SHELL=/bin/bash node /home/phw/devel/spawn.js
Icon=atom
Type=Application
```

Two things help to solve this issue:

a) Enable `detached: true` when spawning the child process
b) Remove the `-i` flag from the shell call

I think b) would actually be correct anyway, since this is in no way an interactive shell.

EDIT: Just to be clear: I still don't know exactly *why*  this is happening, I just know the issue can be circumvented removing the `-i` flag.
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'unmodified' of undefined

Title: File > Reopen Project. Option to reopen in current window.
Body:
Currently, choosing `File > Reopen Project > [MyProject]` reopens the chosen project in a new window.

I request an option to have it open in the same window (unloading the currently loaded project then loading the chosen project).

I'm on:

Atom 1.13.0-beta4.
Windows 10 Pro.
Label: enhancement

Title: Scrollbars move to the top of the file when splitting panes or closing split panes
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

- When I open a large file and move the cursor to the bottom, and then click View->Panes->Split Right.
I found the scroll bar position of previous pane rewind to the top but the cursor is still on the last line.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom using `atom --safe` from `cmd.exe`
2. Open any file and resize the Atom window so you have a vertical scrollbar visible
3. Scroll to the middle of an opened file
4. Run `pane:split-right-and-copy-active-item`
5. Expected: The scrollbars to stay in the same position for both files. Actual: The scrollbars in both files moves to the top of the file
6. Close the right pane
7. Expected: The scrollbar position of the first file to not change. Actual: The scrollbar in the first file is displayed at the top of the file.

![scrollbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/20443729/5a67cab4-adce-11e6-821b-b1784f161afc.gif)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
scroll bar position should no change

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
I found the scroll bar position of previous pane rewind to the top but the cursor is still on the last line.


### Versions
Atom    : 1.12.0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0

![atom-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3035071/20433492/c8b1edc8-adde-11e6-9ede-f003873eaaf8.png)
Label: bug

Title: First dead key not working in editor
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

The first dead key used in the editor will ignore its first keystroke.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use a fresh install of Atom
2. Set Windows' keyboard mode to United States-International (preferably while using a keyboard with the same layout)
3. <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>N</kbd> to get a new file.
4. <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>"</kbd> then <kbd>Space</kbd>

**Expected behavior:**

A double quotation mark character `"` should be inserted.

**Actual behavior:**

A space character ` ` was inserted. When repeating step 4 after this a double quotation mark character is inserted as expected. This issue will not occur again in the same window unless it is reloaded or Atom is restarted.

### Versions

- Atom 1.12.4
- Electron 1.3.9
- Chrome 52.0.2743.82
- Node 6.5.0
- Windows 7 Enterprise SP1 x64
- Windows 10 (1611?) x64
Label: bug

Title: Move "Fold all" menu entry to above the "Unfold all" entry
Body: In the Edit > Folding menu, it would make sense, to match Fold/Unfold entries, that "Fold All"/"Unfold All" were also paired, above the separator. Like so: ### Versions ``` $ atom --version Atom : 1.12.4 Electron: 1.3.9 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 $ apm --version apm 1.12.9 npm 3.10.5 node 4.4.5 python 2.7.11 git 2.5.4 $ sw_vers ProductName: Mac OS X ProductVersion: 10.10.5 BuildVersion: 14F2009 ```
Label: enhancement

Title: Code folds are not restored after closing Atom
Body:
I am finding that after closing Atom and re-opening my session and tabs are restored by code folds are not.

I am writing a lot of functions and I do not need to see all of my code all the time so I depend on code folding to make things manageable.

Code folding does not make things easier for me if I have to go through and re-close every function each time I open Atom before I can begin.

Should folds be remembered? I can't see any mention of this in the documentation so I am not sure if it is a bug or a missing feature.

I am aware of the remember-folds package but this only saves folds when opening and closing tabs - not closing and restoring Atom.
Label: bug

Title: Package settings Keybindings disappear after unchecking Enable box
Body:
### Description

When the **Enable** box in a package's **Keybindings** section is un-checked and Atom is re-started, the **Keybindings** section disappears, making it impossible to re-enable the package's default keybindings by checking the **Enable** box.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Uncheck the **Enable** box in a package's **Keybindings** settings (e.g. the bracket-matcher package).
2. Re-start Atom.
3. Notice that the **Keybindings** settings section has completely disappeared from the package's settings; therefore, there is no way to re-enable the package's **Keybindings** by re-checking the **Enable** box, because there is no **Enable** box to check.

**Expected behavior:**

After unchecking the **Enable** box in the packages **Keybindings** section and re-starting Atom, it should still be possible to see the **Keybindings** section with an un-checked **Enable** box.

**Actual behavior:**

On the package's settings page there is no longer a **Keybindings** section between the **Settings** section and the **README** section.

**Workaround:**

Edit the Atom config file and remove the entry for the package from the `packagesWithKeymapsDisabled` section.

### Versions

On Ubuntu:

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

```
On Windows:

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.2
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

```
apm --version
INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
The system cannot find the file specified.
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio
```
Label: bug

Title: Add Project Folder should open something relevant to the current context
Body:
### Description

Issue is similar to #6762, but it happens when adding a project folder. It then opens the "Recently Used" view on Linux, rather than something more relevant.

1. I'm assuming that just like #6762, this issue is not OS specific.
2. I see two potential candidates for a "more relevant" default:
    * The parent folder of the project folder that was added most recently.
    * The parent folder of the project folder of the currently opened file.

The former "feels more correct" (opinion), the latter is more in line with the fix for #6762

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In the menu, click on File
2. Select "Add Project Folder..."

**Expected behavior:** An open folder dialog should appear, and show either the parent of the most recently added project folder, or the parent folder of the currently selected file's project folder.

**Actual behavior:** An open folder dialog appears, showing "Recently Used" items.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.3
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
Linux Mint 17.3 (Rosa)
Label: enhancement

Title: Support MacBook Touch Bar
Body:
Would be really nice to have the ability to create Packages for Touch Bar actions. I think it would be nice to maybe have a basic package from Atom. If you want to go specialised you can write your own and add or replace the standard actions.
For example, I would love to see Indent and Outdent buttons. The `⌘+]` shortcut is on my german keyboard pretty hard to remember as I have to press `⌘+alt+6`.

**What do you guys think? What would you like to see on a Atom Touch Bar?**

PS: I know this has been tracked as Issue for Electron (electron/electron#7781), but let's discuss here what you think about the integration in Atom.
Label: enhancement

Title: Double click English surrounded by Chinese selects whole line
Body:
### Description

Now when I want to select English from surrounded by Chinese with double click, it would select whole line including those Chinese characters.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. input some text "基于MapReduce的分布?"
2. double click on "MapReduce"
3. the whole line is selected instead of only "MapReduce".

**Expected behavior:** only "MapReduce" should be selected

**Actual behavior:** "基于MapReduce的分布?" is selected

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.2
Electron: 1.4.5
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.113
Node    : 6.5.0

on archlinux.
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature request: return promise when dispatching commands
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom 1.12.1 crashes on Ubuntu 16.04.1, refuses to start
Body:
### Description

I have checked all the ways, started in safe mode, cleared up and removed `~/.atom` and `~/.config/Atom`. Atom crashes in a very early state, the message is:

```
$ atom -f .
[9575:1111/113317:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(231)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/linux_suid_sandbox_development.md for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
```

It crashes right on startup and I cannot get it up and running at all.

### Steps to Reproduce

I did the following:

1. Had Atom already open
2. Update Atom (and Chrome) via the apt channel.
3. Switched back to Atom window.

Then Atom crashed, and refuses to open again.

### Versions

```
$ atom -v
Atom    : 1.12.1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

Edit: In case it is relevant, I also have `google-chrome-stable` installed, version `54.0.2840.100`.
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught Range Error: Maximum call stack size exceeded
Body:

1. open any file (in my case JS) 
2. select any text to delete, it doesn't matter if it's three characters or thirty I still get the issue.

Title: RPM Install: error while loading shared libraries: libXss.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
Body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Updated Atom by official RPM.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens

**Actual behavior:** `/usr/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libXss.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

### Versions

`atom --version` returns nothing.

```
$ rpm -q atom
atom-1.12.0-0.1.x86_64

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

Fedora 24 Linux 4.8.4-200.fc24.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Oct 25 13:06:04 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Workaround

```
$ pkcon install libXScrnSaver
```

... so, it seems this dependency is missing in last RPM.
Label: bug

Title: Keystrokes involving ctrl on Linux resolve to the default layout instead of the active layout
Body:
### Prerequisites

Atom 1.12beta7 on Debian Stretch (testing).

### Description

My keyboard is using Colemak. Shortcuts only work in their QWERTY positions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use Colemak layout
2. Open a file
3. Modify it
4. Try to save it via Colemak's Ctrl+S (which corresponds to the QWERTY position of Ctrl+D).

**Expected behavior:**
It should save the file (or prompt to save it as...)

**Actual behavior:**

It does not offer the options stated above.

** Workaround:**

Try to save it via QWERTY's Ctrl+S (which corresponds to the Colemak's position of Ctrl+R). It will work.


### Versions

Atom 1.12beta7 under Debian Stretch (testing).
Label: bug

Title: Failed to remove '/usr/local/bin/atom'
Body:
### Description

I'm seeing a misleading error message when cancelling installation of the shell commands.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5474861/20025751/ecfaa84a-a2ae-11e6-9754-d0db1cb2962d.png)

This is misleading because `usr/local/bin/atom` doesn't exist.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. If you already have the shell commands installed, execute the following from the terminal before launching Atom:
    1. `rm /usr/local/bin/atom`
    1. `rm /usr/local/bin/apm`
1. Launch Atom
1. Install the shell commands using the menu (Atom > Install Shell Commands)
2. When prompted by OSX for your username and password, click "Cancel"

**Expected behavior:** For Atom to do nothing after I click "Cancel"

**Actual behavior:** Atom prompted me with this error message

### Versions

MacOS 10.12
Atom v1.11.2
Label: bug

Title: Multi-cursor movement shouldn't jump to the last cursor
Body:
Repro steps:
- Open a file with a few hundred lines
- Find a word that's used in many parts of the file
- cmd-ctrl-g on this word to create a cursor on all the occurrences
- see that it moves to the last occurrence. **Intended behavior:** shouldn't move
- scroll all the way up to the first occurrence
- hit the right arrow
- see that it moves to the last occurrence. **Intended behavior:** shouldn't move

Why does it happen?

The screen movement logic is encoded in the single cursor implementation:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/0e992326154d387611543f618ad5872dc4665586/src/cursor.coffee#L255-L268

And the cursor movement action just delegates to all the cursors:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f726dcc81bcd88eb7aff1e61bd77484b875f0854/src/text-editor.coffee#L2153-L2154

So, what happens is that we're going to iterate over all the cursors, and set the screen position on all of them and the last one is going to win.

Instead, **what should happen** is that if the screen is currently under any of the cursors, don't move. If not, then find the nearest cursor and move to that one, instead of the last one.

cc @nathansobo do you have advice on how I can refactor this piece of code to solve the issue?
Label: enhancement

Title: Shelling out to collect environment variables is creating runaway 100% CPU processes on Linux
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

I'm fairly sure this will end up being an Electron issue, but here goes ...

When I start atom-beta (1.12.0b4, though was present with b3 at least), it spawns a shell ('env') subprocess which burns 100% CPU, attempting to read stdin forever:

```
systemd,1,1 --system --deserialize 126
  ├─atom,15392,10213
  │   ├─atom,15403,10213
  │   │   └─atom,15466,10213
  │   │       ├─zsh,15497,10213 -ilc command env
```

strace on the shell shows this looping forever:

```
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_SETMASK, [], [TSTP TTIN TTOU], 8) = 0
read(0, NULL, 0)                        = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_BLOCK, [TSTP TTIN TTOU], [], 8) = 0
getpgrp()                               = 10213
ioctl(15, TIOCGPGRP, [11445])           = 0
getpgrp()                               = 10213
ioctl(15, TIOCGPGRP, [11445])           = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_SETMASK, [], [TSTP TTIN TTOU], 8) = 0
read(0, NULL, 0)                        = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_BLOCK, [TSTP TTIN TTOU], [], 8) = 0
```

Sometimes this process blocks Atom startup, and you have to kill the shell for Atom's window to show. Sometimes Atom works just fine despite this, and you only realise later when you wonder why your system is slow, and kill the extraneous process. Sometimes closing Atom takes the rogue shell process with it, and sometimes it outlives Atom. Sometimes everything works fine and I can't reproduce it at all.

Either way, safe mode or not has no effect on it, and nothing bright turns up with `--enable-logging`. Timecop shows 'window load time' taking an ungodly amount of time, but with no insight into why.

Happy to supply more details or attempt debugging as needed, with the caveat that I have no idea what I'm doing in JavaScript.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have my system
2. Run Atom beta

**Expected behavior:** 'What a nice normal text-editing experience this is'

**Actual behavior:** WOOOOOOOOSSHHHH goes the laptop fan
### Versions

Atom 1.12.0b4 (also occurred with b3)
Fedora 25 (kernel 4.8-rc8+, glibc 2.24, etc)
Label: bug

[Description of the bug or feature]

Title: subword selection behaves differently for UPPER_CASE and lower_case
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I stumbled upon this subword selection feature (really nice :smile:). However I do have some painpoints related to how the selection stops.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Write this on an empty editor.

```
this is   an example
this_is_an_example
THIS_IS_AN_EXAMPLE
THIS_is_anExample
this_is   an_example
thisIsAnExample
this__is___an__example
```
1. Position your cursor on the beginning of the file and execute `editor:select-to-end-of-word` 4 times, take note of the behavior.
2. Position your cursor back to the beginning of the file.
3. Execute `editor:select-to-next-subword-boundary` 4 times.
4. If there are more lines, go to the beginning of the next line and go to step 4 until all lines are processed.

**Expected behavior:**
Every line had the same behavior on step 4 compared to what happened on step 2.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
On step 4...
- :x:  Line 1 stopped at spaces which is ok, but the next execution should select the spaces plus the next word.
- :white_check_mark: Line 2 behaved just as expected. 
- :x: Line 3 behaved like line 1 but with underscores instead of spaces.
- :x: Line 4 just like line 1 did the same on the first underscore, but not on the second one.
     It did stop at the "camel case".
- :x: Line 5 worked as expected selecting the underscores worked, but not the space.
- :white_check_mark: Line 6 as expected.
- :white_check_mark: Line 7 same.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
Linux 4.4.0-38-generic #57~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP x86_64 GNU/Linux
Label: bug

Title: Case where TextEditor::getLastVisibleScreenRow() is off by one
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

This function:

```
atom.commands.add 'atom-text-editor:not([mini])', 'editor:scroll-down': ->
  ed = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  ed.scrollToScreenPosition([ed.getLastVisibleScreenRow()-1,0])
```

on many/most files behaves as expected, visibly scrolling the cursor down one line.

But performing it on [atom-keymap's keymap-manager.coffee](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/blob/master/src/keymap-manager.coffee), it consistently scrolls down 2 lines.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open [atom-keymap's keymap-manager.coffee](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/blob/master/src/keymap-manager.coffee)
2. Execute both lines in the function above via the dev tools console.

It might be necessary to change text size to reproduce, but I've seen it at the default size, too. A couple cmd-+'s then cmd-0 usually does the trick.

**Expected behavior:**

Scroll the editor down one line.

**Actual behavior:**

The editor scrolls down two lines
### Versions

Atom 1.11.1, 1.12-beta3, or master as of 18609f8
macOS 10.12 (Sierra)
Label: bug

Here's what I get in console:

```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: this.tokenizedBuffer.reloadGrammar is not a function(…)

module.exports.Emitter.emit @ .../resources/app.asar/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:129
(anonymous function) @ package-manager.coffee:457
```

Title: CLI flag to load only particular packages
Body: I think it would be really useful for debugging purposes if we could basically launch Atom in safe mode, but with the ability to pass specific packages to activate, enabling you to easily completely isolate a package that might be conflicting with others. Maybe something like `atom --safe -a package-name -a another-package`?
Label: enhancement

Title: [proposal] Improve scrollbar behavior with infinite edges
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

I've just installed Atom and the current scrollbar implementation is very frustrating. If I want to scroll with my touchpad, I have to target the scrollbar explicitly, instead of just dragging the cursor to the rightmost edge and drag the code down.

This is a human-computer interface antipattern.

Please read this: http://particletree.com/features/visualizing-fittss-law/ especially the section "Rule of the Infinite Edge"

I could just repeat everything that the article says. For a text editor where I can spend most of my time during the day, this should be a no brainier to implement.
Label: enhancement

Title: 1.12.0-beta1 ctrl+backspace resolves incorrectly in combination with numlock/scrollock/capslock
Body:
### Description

With `v1.12.0-beta1`, using a keyboard with standard swedish layout, it seems as if `ctrl+backspace` is bound to the wrong action, even if defined properly in the keymaps file.

(This worked in the latest stable release AFAIK.)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Download latest beta releas https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.12.0-beta1
2. Toggle keybinder resolver `Ctrl+Period`
3. Type `Ctrl+backspace`
4. Observe that it says `Editor:delete-to-end-of-word`
5. Open the keymaps file by clicking the link in the keybinder resolver bar
6. Search for `ctrl-backspace`
7. Observe that it says `Editor:delete-to-beginning-of-word`

**Expected behavior:**
1. keymaps and keybinder resolver information matches
2. `ctrl+backspace` is bound to `Editor:delete-to-beggining-of-word`

**Actual behavior:**
1. keymaps and keybinder resolver information does not match
2. ctrl+backspace`is bound to`Editor:delete-to-end-of-word`
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.0-beta1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git 2.8.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
Label: bug

Title: Slow response of script/build when --help toggles
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

```
$ script/build --help
```

lags since we need toggle `--help` to see available options for manually building different packages (_windows-installer_, _*.deb_, _*.rpm_).

Plus, some may try `script/build -h` for help but it is not available.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. clone atom then checkout to release branches
2. `$ script/build --help`

**Expected behavior:**

It prints out available options immediately then return.

**Actual behavior:**

It's lagging on terminal result: `Installing script dependencies` and finally prints out available options.
It looks like processing on this line of code (`script/build`, line 7): 

``` javascript
require('./bootstrap')
```
### Versions

``` bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.1
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.12.0-beta1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

Title: Remember previous window state for multiple fullscreen windows
Body: Hi, I use Atom for developing multiple micro services so will have at least 3 projects open at a time - which I usually keep in fullscreen mode on macOS. When I cmd-q and quit Atom, then reopen Atom, all the previous windows will be opened but only one of them will be in full screen and the rest will be dumped onto the main desktop. Here's two images of before and after quitting and reopening Atom. Is this something that is possible to implement? If I can be pointed in the right direction I would be happy to see if I can scratch my own itch and submit a pull request. Bonus points: remembering the order of the windows - don't know if that's posible. Thanks

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

If you execute `pane:close` the dialog asking you to save appears twice when you press the `Dont Save` button. This does not happen with `core:close` command in combination with the `Close Empty Panes` configuration option.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode.
1. Ensure you only have one pane, this bug does not reproduce when closing a split pane.
1. Open a new untitled tab (Or any tab it is not limited to untitled tabs).
1. Make any modifications to the tab.
1. Run `pane:close` from the `command-palette`, this doesn't reproduce when the pane is closed using the `Remove Empty Panes` option.
1. In the dialog that appears press `Don't Save`.

![pane close dialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/19284692/4c058c8a-8ff7-11e6-936f-60b2b748e0c4.gif)

**Expected behavior:** Pane to close.

**Actual behavior:** Dialog asking to save appears once again.
### Versions
###### atom --version

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```
###### apm --version

```
apm  1.12.5

node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.10.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Title: Can not dismiss "No update available" window if opening menu again before the update check finishes
Body:
### Description

So I just discovered a weird little issue. If I use "check for updates" from the menu, and before the window pops up I open the Atom-menu again I can not dismiss the "No updates available" window neither press something in the menu. The only way to exit Atom is to kill the process using Activity Monitor.
- It happens in safe mode as well.
- I am running version 1.10.2
- No error pops up
- Trying to close in any other way that using Activity Monitor fails.

I am using a Macbook Pro Retina 13" (late 2013) with MacOS 10.12 (sierra) installed.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom.
2. Go to Atom menu and select "Check for Update"
3. Before the window appears (telling you there are no updates) open the Atom menu again.
4. Wait a bit.
5. When the update-check window appears try to click whatever. It is no longer possible to close the menu, ok the update-check window.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
Label: bug

Title: editor:duplicate-lines should only duplicate once per line with a cursor
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

`editor:duplicate-lines` should only duplicate at most once per line when using multiple cursors. 

This would allow for easier duplication of many use cased such as duplicating and changing inputs, imports, markdown tables etc.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create an empty document
2. Add the following content -
   
   ```
   <input name="foo" id="foo"/>
   ```
3. Highlight either of `foo` texts
4. Press `shift-cmd-D` or whatever your associated keybindings for `editor:duplicate-lines` is.

**Expected behavior:** One new line should be created with both `foo` strings highlighted on the new line.

**Actual behavior:** Two new lines are created with the highlighted `foo` strings being one per line.
### Versions

Running  OS X El Capitan - 10.11.6 (15G31)

```
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.8.0
```

Title: Disabling atomic soft tabs does not work on a whitespace-only line
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [Y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The "Atomic Soft Tabs" setting cannot be disabled - or more clearly, the checkbox that is on by default can be unselected, but the effect of cursor skipping over soft tabs does not change.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Ensure that "soft tabs" and "show invisibles" settings are on, and Tab Type is set to auto/soft.
2. Create a new file, and press the tab key to indent.
3. Observe that 4 "dots" appear to represent the tab as four spaces, i.e. a soft tab.
4. move the cursor using the keyboard, and observe if the cursor skips over the spaces as a whole, or allows the cursor to move over each space one by one. Also try and select a middle space using the mouse cursor.

**Expected behavior:** with the 'Atomic Soft Tabs' setting off, I would expect the cursor to be able to select spaces within a soft tab.

**Actual behavior:** the cursor skips over all the spaces, i.e. Atomic Soft Tab behaviour.
### Versions

RHEL7.2

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.5
git 1.8.3.1
Label: bug

Title: implement smooth scrolling speed setting
Body:
a general scroll speed setting in the same manner sublime "scroll_speed" (http://docs.sublimetext.info/en/latest/reference/settings.html)  

why ?
the current atom editor has all the proper looks like any other major one, but severely lacks the feeling. Sublime, textmate and others have implemented smooth scrolling which gives an easy to fallow sensation when scrolling thru the code, this is a feature that makes an incredibly difference in terms of comfort and new users adoption.

whats wrong with the current alternatives ?
the css wont work with the new tile rendering system, see https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5359
"scroll sensitivity" works only when using a mouse or trackpad, besides the "steeps" between every scroll update aren't smooth at all.

I propose an artificial delay in the same way that a linear transition of -webkit-transform would work over the tiles.

rel https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1666
Label: enhancement
