Title: AtomIDE does not recover well after force-close
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom IDE recovers poorly when it's forced-closed after encountering a performance issue.  I searched for this issue but don't see it, although maybe it's worded differently.
### Steps to Reproduce
1.  Cause AtomIDE to hang.  To do this, create a file with very long lines that must be syntax-colored.  In most operating systems a dialog prompt will appear to "force close" the app.
2.  Force close Atom when prompted by the OS.
3.  Wait several seconds for any OS logging/recovery.
4.  Re-launch Atom.
5.  Atom re-opens the same files already open during the previous session.  The same long-lines must syntax-colored and Atom will hang again, repeating this entire cycle.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
It seems like a good idea to remember the documents that were open last.  However that backfires in this case.  Might as well detect a crash and clear the previous documents list to avoid an infinite loop of use-cases.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
AtomIDE re-opens the same files that were open before hanging and force-closed, and ends up the same cycle.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
Label: enhancement

Title: editor:delete-line should preserve line position
Body:
### Description

The command `editor:delete-line` should preserve current cursor position after removing line.
### Steps to Reproduce

For example we have file `data.js`:

``` javascript
var arr = [
        'main',
        'user',
        'settings',
        'lang',
        'billing',
];
```
1. Put cursor in file at line `settings` after first quote.
2. Call delete-line command

**Expected behavior:** Cursor is at the `lang` line after first quote. Line position is 9.

**Actual behavior:** Cursor is at the start of  `lang` line. Line position is 0.
### Versions

Atom 1.10.2, macOS 10.10
Label: enhancement

Title: Return the last active tab when close a tab
Body: For example, open a project-wide search tab by `ctrl-shift-f` then close it, it should returns to the last _used_ tab in MRU order, but current version it returns to last tab in display order.
Label: enhancement

Title: Setting Default Syntax for New Documents
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [Y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Opening a new document defaults to "Plain Text" syntax. You can save the file with a select file extension or manually select a syntax but cannot set the default syntax for new documents. An official init.coffee solution exists on the [Atom FAQ](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-can-i-make-all-new-files-open-with-a-specific-grammar-or-syntax/20754) however new documents still default to "Plain Text" and rather only opening a new tab defaults to the desired syntax:

```
atom.workspace.observeTextEditors (editor) ->
  if editor.getTitle() is "untitled"
    editor.setGrammar(atom.grammars.grammarForScopeName('text.html.php'))
```

Other developers have noted the bug appears to be, "Open Empty Editor On Start option enabled is required as this issue only occurs on the first editor created by that option."
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Edit init.coffee with above code
2. Restart Atom
3. Open Atom and notice default syntax is still Plain Text

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Default syntax (based on above code) should be PHP
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
It is still Plain Text (unless you open another tab via shortcut or Menu). Opening New Window view menu or shortcut also results in same issue.
### Versions

1.10.2, Mac 10.12 (16A313a)
Label: bug

Title: editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor return undefined as special condition
Body:
### Steps to Reproduce

Given a markdown file with **a list** with link:

```
- _https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/new
```

Where `_` represents the cursor position (at the start of the link, and after the list head `-`)

And I try to get the buffer range for scope link:

```
editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()

cursor = editor.getLastCursor()
cursor.getScopeDescriptor().getScopesArray()
// => ["source.gfm", "markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink"]

// since markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink scope is there, when i try to get the buffer range
editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor('markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink')
// => undefined
```

**Expected behavior:**

It should return the correct buffer range. 

The undefined buffer range only happens in list links. E.g. `- link` or `- [ ] link`.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```
Label: bug

Title: Fail to Auto Detect ISO-8859 encoding
Body:
### Description

Atom's Auto Detect is detecting the **ISO-8859** file below as a **Windows 1251** encoding resulting the word "Documenta**çã**o" to open as "Documenta**зг**o".

**Content of the [western-iso-8859-1.txt](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/files/477390/western-iso-8859-1.txt) file:**

``` txt
<?php
$var = "Assistente Documentação e Pesquisa"
```

**Check the encoding:**

``` bash
$ file western-iso-8859-1.txt
western-iso-8859-1.txt: PHP script, ISO-8859 text, with CRLF line terminators
```

**Detected encoding:**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/129185/18596194/55406e9c-7c1e-11e6-8180-af7cc0c836ae.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Download and open this file: [western-iso-8859-1.txt](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/files/477390/western-iso-8859-1.txt)
2. Select Western ISO-8859 and confirm text is correct: "Documenta**çã**o"
3. Select Auto Detect and notice that encoding changes to **Windows 1251** and text is corrupt: "Documenta**зг**o"

**Expected behavior:** Encoding should be correctly detected thus resulting in correct text.

**Actual behavior:** Encoding is not detected correctly and thus corrupts the text.
### Versions

``` bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm 1.12.5
npm 3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.3
git 1.7.9.5
```
Label: bug

Title: Cursor in unexpected position when moving it while selecting
Body:
Observed in Atom 1.10.2 on Windows 10 Home using Atom One UI Theme and Atom Light syntax theme.
1. Create a new file and enter some lines of text in it. Make sure there are around 40 characters per line.
2. Position your cursor somewhere halfway the second line (say, column 20)
3. Hold Shift and move the cursor up one line using the arrow Up key
4. Observe: The cursor is in the expected position, line 1 column 20, exactly one column above where it was before, and text from where the cursor is now up to where it was before is now selected
5. Release the Shift key
6. Press the Up key on the keyboard
7. Observe: The text is no longer selected (expected)
8. Observe: The cursor is now at the beginning of the line (column 1) (**not** expected)
9. Press the Down key on the keyboard
10. Observe: The cursor is now on line 2, column 1.

Expected behavior: Since we started on line 2 and are on line 1 at step 6, it's not possible to go up one more line so I would expect the cursor to remain where it is. I do expect to lose the selection when I attempt to move the cursor, but I don't expect it to move to the beginning of the line. 

The problem with the current behavior is that when you do Up, Down, you don't return to where you were before. This gives unexpected cursor 'jumps' when editing.

I compared with Microsoft Notepad and Notepad++

**MS Notepad:**
Behaves as I would expect. The cursor remains at it's position when we press Up on line 1, selection is lost

**Notepad++**
Has some mysterious behavior of itself. It also moves the cursor to column 1 when we press up (like Atom), but, crucially, when we press Down it moves the cursor back to where it was. This is actually also unexpected

I guess it's a minor issue. But I've found myself selecting the wrong stuff / deleting the wrong parts of a line etc when editing from muscle memory and I've traced it back to this quirk. I think it would improve the editing experience if it was fixed.

Also, note that if we don't hold Shift when moving Up and Down, Atom behaves as Notepad++:
When we press Up while the cursor is on line 1, it visually moves to the beginning of the line, however if we then press Down it actually moves back to where it was before, therefore maintaining command symmetry. This behavior changes (for the worse imho) when we hold Shift to select some text.
Label: bug

Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

### Description

After the Electron 1.3.5 upgrade, I've noticed a complete loss of subpixel antialiasing in Atom.  Code, tree-view, status-bar, you name it are all grayscale antialiased.  If there's any way I can help debug this please let me know because it's starting to hurt my eyes :(.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `atom --safe`
2. Zoom in using Magnify

**Expected behavior:** Colorful subpixel antialiasing

**Actual behavior:** Grayscale :(
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-dev-4f1833a
Electron: 1.3.5
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

```
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.9.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64.

Title: Upgrading packages doesn't recalculate canDeferMainModuleRequire using new code
Body:
Recently, we (the Nuclide team) got bitten by what seems to be a bug in Atom's package manager when we switched from loading our "sub-packages" during Nuclide's activation phase to its loading phase.

It seems that, if you upgrade a package from within Atom, its new metadata (including the version) will be loaded immediately but `Package::load()` will still load the old version of the package ([because of the require cache](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.11.0-beta5/src/package.coffee#L441)). It'll then use that code to determine whether requiring the main module can be deferred and cache that in local storage. The next time Atom's loaded, it uses the (potentially inaccurate) cached value.

We noticed this because our code changed from allowing the deferment of requiring the main module to not, but Atom continued to defer loading.

Related:
- facebook/nuclide#698
- facebook/nuclide#699
- facebook/nuclide#700
- facebook/nuclide#701
Label: bug

Title: Sub-pixel rendering does not occur when unlocking Atom on Macbook external monitor
Body:
### Description

When unlocking mac OS on a macbook when atom is on a second monitor, the color of syntax highlighting is muted. The color fixes when the pane is updated by changing tabs. The screenshot below shows the muted color on the left, and the correct color (by changing the tab) on the right.

This does not appear to happen when waking the computer if atom is on the laptop screen. Its hard to tell, but the color appears to be fine for a split second, and then muted once the window is force-resized. This may happen on a desktop, but I don't have one to test with.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1187432/18359997/297866f2-75b1-11e6-898f-417644b42c35.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom on a second, external monitor on a macbook
2. Allow Mac to lock from inactivity OR lock from the lock in the toolbar. The System "Sleep" command will not work.
3. Wake the mac, and unlock the screen

**Expected behavior:** Color should appear normally

**Actual behavior:** Color is <s>muted</s> not sub-pixel rendered. Thanks to @simurai  for noticing
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```
Label: bug

Title: Spell check markers do not reposition when soft wrapped and closing a split pane
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Closing a split pane when soft wrapped does not cause the spell check markers to get repositioned. Doing almost any action while in this state causes them to reposition correctly. Actions that cause them to reposition are: resize the Atom window, click in the `TextEditor`, scroll the `TextEditor`, switch to another tab and back, use the arrow keys to move the cursor.
I can reproduce this with all themes in safe mode on both Windows 10 and Windows 7.

Discovered and discussed over in https://github.com/atom/language-gfm/issues/167#issuecomment-244906162 where @nathansobo told me to open a new issue.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode.
2. Ensure you have `Soft Wrap` enabled.
3. Ensure you have `spell-check` enabled.
4. Copy [this file](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/Ben3eeE/6b9a8d5c3fbdd38bda3b70b63617b280/raw/77e0fc174f27160e82bd3c27f2d8182771770fb8/gistfile1.txt) into a new untitled `TextEditor` 
5. Split the pane right and resize the Atom window so there is soft wrapping.
6. Close the right pane that you just opened.

Gif of reproduction Windows 7 safe mode:
![split pane close](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/18268989/8712b448-7426-11e6-814c-adf8b998e353.gif)

Inspect markers in dev tools:
![markers in dev tools](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/18305056/0283dc00-74e6-11e6-82f9-70e28581873d.png)

**Expected behavior:** Spell check markers to be correctly positioned.

**Actual behavior:** Spell check markers are incorrectly positioned. Doing anything like moving the cursor, clicking in the pane causes them to reposition correctly.
### Versions
##### Atom 1.11.0-beta4 on Windows 10
###### atom --version

```
Atom    : 1.11.0-beta4
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```
###### apm --version

```
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.8.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
##### Atom 1.10.2 on Windows 7
###### atom --version

Title: missing first letter on file operations (cut/copy/rename exc.)
Body:
Hi there. This is not an Atom bug but one of its dependencies. I open this issue here because I couldn't find the responsible package. 

I also encounter this bug in gulp (3 & 4), glob and a couple of other packages.
### Description

When you use capital 'i'  ( İ ) in directory names on Turkish environments,  first letter of directory vanishes at the end of the operation. 

Ex: When I rename a file like this in Atom (`\project-dir` is the root path of the project folder) `C:\Dev\İpler\project-dir\subdir\file.js` the renaming window opens file as `ubdir\file.js` 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a directory that contains/starts a capital `i` (İ) letter on its path names.
2. Create a sub directory in that directory that going to be a project folder.
3. Open Atom with that path
4. Create a file under sub directory.
### Versions

Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git 2.9.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015

Title: Whitespace preceding a comment is not the comment itself
Body:
#12507 ## Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

I reported this issue gandm/language-babel#234 and @gandm very eloquently explained what the underlying cause of the problem is. Rather than attempt to rephrase, I shall simply quote from [here](https://github.com/gandm/language-babel/issues/234#issuecomment-242779428):

> Little bit complex but it appears that [autoflow](https://github.com/atom/autoflow/blob/master/lib/autoflow.coffee#L18) attempts to determine the line that the cursor is on is part of a paragraph. This eventually calls [language-mode](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/language-mode.coffee#L196) which eventually determines [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/language-mode.coffee#L212) that this line isn't a comment line because my grammar doesn't set the whitespace preceeding the // as a comment ( **because it isn't!** ) and therefore determines that this line is part of a paragraph including the line above.

Thus, I'm reporting the issue here.

It might be a design decision, and in fact not a bug at all, but intended behaviour, but such considerations are beyond me, so I'm posting here anyway, feel free to close if this is the intended behaviour.
### Steps to Reproduce

Unfortunately I'm not sure if I can make a reproduction now as @gandm has already changed the approach taken by the language-babel plugin which circumvents this issue.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4
Label: bug

In Atom version 1.9.9 on OS X, when you try to open a Project from the File menu after closing the editor window, the FInder file selection pane does not pop-up as expected.  

To reproduce this:

3. Try to Open a project or Add a project folder

The Atom menu bar remains open after closing the main window after launch, so you would assume that you could Open... a new project from the menu and I'm sure this used to work in version 1.8.x.

Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75

Title: `console.log` in a plugin causes a "EPERM: operation not permitted, write"
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The bug has since been reported in several places. The current use case that bothers is that `console.log` is used in the [`eslint-plugin-react`](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react) which is used in the widely adopted [`eslint-config-airbnb`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-config-airbnb) which is in turn consumed by [`eslint`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint) and [`AtomLinter/linter-eslint`](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint).
- https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/issues/579 (closed because the AtomLinter team cannot do anything with that)
- https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/416#issuecomment-177119027 (closed because the issue was not stated properly, or simply comments on closed issues were ignored)
- https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/978#issuecomment-241332995 (can't be fixed in eslint-config-airbnb yet because of other dependencies)
- https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/783#issuecomment-241778161 (looks like a won't fix because eslint-plugin-react "is a Node module, so using console is valid")

Here's the exception that pops up in Atom:

```
Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, write
    at Error (native)
    at Object.fs.writeSync (fs.js:706:20)
    at SyncWriteStream.write (fs.js:2064:6)
    at Console.log (console.js:39:16)
    at EventEmitter.Program (__CENSORED__\node_modules\eslint-plugin-react\lib\rules\require-extension.js:103:17)
    at emitOne (events.js:95:20)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:182:7)
    at NodeEventGenerator.enterNode (__CENSORED__\node_modules\eslint\lib\util\node-event-generator.js:40:22)
    at CodePathAnalyzer.enterNode (__CENSORED__\node_modules\eslint\lib\code-path-analysis\code-path-analyzer.js:608:23)
    at CommentEventGenerator.enterNode (__CENSORED__\node_modules\eslint\lib\util\comment-event-generator.js:97:23)
```

Here's one of the faulty lines:
https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/v3.16.1/lib/rules/jsx-quotes.js#L52

``` js
      /* eslint-disable no-console */
      console.log('The react/jsx-quotes rule is deprecated. Please use the jsx-quotes rule instead.');
      /* eslint-enable no-console */
      isWarnedForDeprecation = true;
```

There are more occurences of this pattern in `eslint-plugin-react`:
https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/e84af68a3bf48c9a34f14e73a8b4dc1ed7488bab/lib/rules/require-extension.js#L103

``` js
        /* eslint-disable no-console */
        console.log('The react/require-extension rule is deprecated. Please ' +
                    'use the import/extensions rule from eslint-plugin-import instead.');
        /* eslint-enable no-console */
        isWarnedForDeprecation = true;
```

https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=console.log&type=Code
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install `atom-linter`, `atom-linter-eslint` plugins, `eslint` and `eslint-plugin-react` modules.
2. Use a `.eslintrc` that uses one of the `eslint-plugin-react`'s deprecated rules; for example, the `eslint-config-airbnb` base config.
3. Run the linting on a JS file.

**Expected behavior:** No error.

**Actual behavior:** The exception mentioned above.
### Versions

Atom 1.9.9 on Windows 7 64bit

`atom --version`

```
Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

`apm --version`

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.0
git 1.9.4.msysgit.1
visual studio
```
Label: bug

Title: Atom doesn't remember added projects on start up
Body:
This is a known limitation of the window state system; it only saves when changing focus, adding and removing windows. We should save when adding and removing project folders in addition.

## Repro Steps
1. Launch Atom in a local repository
2. Add a second project folder using <kbd>Cmd+Shift+O</kbd>
3. Exit Atom
4. Launch Atom using the Dock icon

**Expected:** Both project folders to be listed in the Tree View
**Actual:** Only the first project folder is listed in the Tree View

Info:
- version 1.9.9 (the bug also existed on 1.9.8)
- Mac OS 10.10.5
- "Open empty editor at start" is unchecked
Label: bug

Title: Feature Request: Separate themes in config.cson
Body:
Right now, the themes in `config.cson` are defined under one key.

```
"*":
  core:
    themes: [
      "one-dark-ui"
      "firewatch-green-syntax"
    ]
```

[Over on the forum](https://discuss.atom.io/t/per-project-themes/16064), a few people have requested to be able to change the theme according to their project. Some people design themes for specific languages or tasks. It seems like it would be a trivial change to split these to be under two keys, and that would allow packages or `init.cson` to more easily manipulate the themes without having to mess with an array and identify which theme is which based on the last word of the name.

```
"*":
  core:
    theme-ui: "one-dark-ui"
    theme-syntax: "firewatch-green-syntax"
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Command-a in Menubar/Help doesn't highlight search input.
Body:
To reproduce: 
1) Press <kbd>command</kbd><kbd>shift</kbd><kbd>/</kbd> to trigger `Menubar / Help` search input. 
2) Type anything to populate the search input. 
3) Press <kbd>command</kbd><kbd>a</kbd>. 
- Expected behavior (convention for Mac OS native and major third-party apps): Typed search input should highlight entirely. 
- Observed behavior: Keyboard focus is lost from the search input, and the file's contents are highlighted entirely instead. 

Mac OS 10.11.6
Atom 1.9.9
Label: bug

Title: Open project folder dialog defaults to current filename
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When you press <kbd>ctrl+shift+o</kbd> to open a project folder the dialog defaults to the current file name, which is not a valid folder.

Screenshot where I had a file in the spec folder open and wanted to open that folder in a separate Atom window using <kbd>ctrl+shift+o</kbd> and then <kbd>enter</kbd>.
In addition I also noticed that the entire file name is not shown in the dialog. Compare error dialog text with open folder dialog text.
![not a folder](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/17764625/bd71fb3a-6520-11e6-9347-936b3f1fa73d.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode, add a project folder and open a file.
2. With the file focused press <kbd>ctrl+shift+o</kbd>
3. Try to open that folder by just pressing <kbd>enter</kbd> on the dialog, error because the folder is set incorrectly to a filename.

**Expected behavior:** The current open files folder opens as a project folder in a new Atom window. 

**Actual behavior:** Error because file name is set to a file instead of a folder, if you clear the file name from the dialog before opening it opens the folder as expected.
### Versions

Windows 7.

```
Atom    : 1.9.8
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11

visual studio
```

Title: Negated patterns from .gitignore_global are still included in VCS ignored paths
Body: ### Prerequisites - [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)? - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? - [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? ### Description ### Steps to Reproduce ``` $ mkdir gittest $ cd gittest $ git init Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/swrobel/Code/gittest/.git/ $ touch this-should-be-tracked $ echo 'this-should-be-tracked' >> ~/.gitignore_global $ git status --ignored On branch master Initial commit Ignored files: (use "git add -f ..." to include in what will be committed) this-should-be-tracked nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track) $ echo '!this-should-be-tracked' >> .gitignore $ git status --ignored On branch master Initial commit Untracked files: (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed) .gitignore this-should-be-tracked nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track) $ atom . ``` **Expected behavior:** According to the [gitignore docs](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore), `.gitignore` files local to a project take precedence over `.gitignore_global`. In this case a simple single-file rule has been added to `.gitignore_global` and then negated in the project's `.gitignore` file, which means that it should be tracked in git, and thus, in my mind, is not a "VCS Ignored Path." Note: I have avoided using `git check-ignore` because of the [rather confusing behavior](https://public-inbox.org/git/1418323355-23935-1-git-send-email-florian.hassanen@gmail.com/) where it returns files that match any gitignore rule, including negated rules, rather than only returning files that will actually be ignored. **Actual behavior:** File is not available in Fuzzy Finder, Tree View, or other areas that respect the VCS Ignored Paths setting. I don't know any way to get the array of VCS ignored files from the developer console, otherwise I would've done that instead of using this crude screenshot-based method. ### Versions Tested on Atom stable & beta on two separate Macs, one running 10.11.6 and one running 10.12 PB5 ``` $ atom --version Atom : 1.9.8 Electron: 0.37.8 Chrome : 49.0.2623.75 Node : 5.10.0 $ atom-beta --version Atom : 1.10.0-beta5 Electron: 0.37.8 Chrome : 49.0.2623.75 Node : 5.10.0 ```
Label: bug

Title: Indent guides don't show up on existing editors
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Existing editors (ie those that are opened automatically upon opening an existing project) do not show indent guides.  New editors (ie those that are opened after Atom loads the existing project) do.  In addition, closing the existing editors and reopening them will cause them to start showing indent guides.  I believe this started after the TextEditor extraction PR, though I'm not completely sure.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom and add a project folder (making sure the indent guides option is enabled)
2. Open some files
3. Close Atom
4. Open Atom again, making sure it restores the project folder and files added in step 1
5. Note that no indent guides are shown
6. Open a different file and note that indent guides are shown on that file only
7. Close one of the existing files and reopen it and notice that indent guides are now shown on that file as well

**Expected behavior:** Indent guides to always show if the option is enabled

**Actual behavior:** Indent guides do not show on existing editors until they are reopened
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.11.0-dev-351bad4
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.9.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64.

Title: The '/tmp/Atom Crashes' directory vs multiple userids
Body:
Hello...  Just last week I started trying to use Atom on MacOS 10 (Yosemite), and my main interest right now is in the languages ruby and crystal.

When Atom.app starts up, it creates a directory "Atom Crashes":

``` cr
# ls -l /tmp/Atom\ Crashes/
total 8
drwxr-xr-x  2 gad  wheel  68 Aug 14 21:42 completed/
drwxr-xr-x  2 gad  wheel  68 Aug 14 21:42 new/
drwxr-xr-x  2 gad  wheel  68 Aug 14 21:42 pending/
-rw-r--r--  1 gad  wheel  40 Aug 14 21:46 settings.dat
```

The problem is that this is created with a generic name, but it is owned by the active user and no other users can modify it (which **is** how it should be -- in fact, it could be argued that no other users should be allowed to read it).

The problem comes when I try to switch users in MacOS 10, using fast-user switching.  If I try to start up Atom on a second userid, and if I have the console.app running, I'll see an endless stream of error messages:

``` cr
<timestamp> PM crashpad_handler[<pid>]: [0814/212739:ERROR:file_io_posix.cc(153)] open /tmp/Atom Crashes/settings.dat: Permission denied
```

I have to switch back to the first userid, bring up Terminal, and `rm -rf /tmp/Atom*`.  And of course this means that Atom.app cannot be left running on two different sessions at the same time, which is disappointing.

If Atom is going to create a directory in /tmp, then it should include the userid (or the user's UID) in the name of the directory.  I think the directory should also be created with permissions 700, not 755.

I notice that in MacOS 10, the directory has the attribute:

``` cr
# ls -ld@ /tmp/Atom\ Crashes
drwxr-xr-x@ 6 gad  wheel  204 Aug 14 21:42 /tmp/Atom Crashes/
    org.chromium.crashpad.database.initialized    1 
```

if that helps to track this down.

FWIW:

``` cr
# atom --version
Atom    : 1.9.8
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

# apm --version
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.9.1
```
Label: bug

Title: Atom reverted to base install, deleted all themes/packages
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?

Not entirely sure about this.
- [ ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

Yes. I have "install new updates on restart" enabled.
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?

I asked on Slack (atomio.slack.com) and one user mentioned how I should definitely file an issue for this. I've never seen or heard any application delete all packages and user settings based on application close. 
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

Just performed cursory search, no issues like this open. 
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?

This happened to the Atom editor. 
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

Just did, this was not a crash (closed properly), but when it restarted all the packages were missing.

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom deleted all of my packages and themes upon application restart. Not really sure how else to elaborate on this, but pretty much reverted to base install (maybe more basic as file explorer is not present on left-hand-side as well).  
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have a lot of tabs open (I had my React project open at the time and had my README.md, and many Javascript files)
2. Notable installed packages include those needed to run .eslintrc file (eslint-plugin-{react, lodash, etc.}, eslint)
3. Delete tabs by using shortcut Cmd + W really fast
4. Reopen Atom by typing in Terminal atom . in targeted directory
5. cry

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Atom closes and starts up again with all packages and themes present. File explorer present on left hand side. 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Atom deleted all themes and packages. ~/.atom directory still exists, ~/.atom/packages does not. No green square on bottom-left-hand-side (not sure if I should be looking for this.)
Still present: all directory files (Atom did not touch any of my files, and since I had just pushed to devel branch there weren't any unsaved changes to any files so I don't know if those would have been lost or not).
### Versions

Atom 1.9.8 
apm 1.10.0
OS: OS X 10.11.5
Label: bug

Title: Use generic icon in linux .desktop file instead of hard coded path
Body:
Instead of hard coding the icon path in the `.desktop` file it is much more common to just state the appname and place the default logo at `/usr/share/icons/hicolor/`_`resolution`_`/apps/atom.png`. Chrome for example does so. However this is not simply a cosmetic change! It also allows for themes to replace certain icons while preserving the icons of apps with no altered icon.

The bug is still present in the master branch as of now.
Label: enhancement

### Description

When calling Workspace::scan with the `paths` option set, any ignored paths due to `core.excludeVcsIgnoredPaths` or `core.ignoredNames` are not ignored.

This was originally reported in atom/find-and-replace#621, and seems to be a problem with Workspace::scan.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Merge my PR with additional specs (see below)
2. Unskip the new tests (xit -> it)
3. Run `apm test` and observe the failures

**Expected behavior:** Tests pass - ignored paths are correctly ignored when the `paths` option is set.

**Actual behavior:** Tests fail - ignored paths are not ignored when the `paths` option is set.

Electron: 0.37.8

Title: Add prevent option to ::onWillDestroyPaneItem()
Body:
Might be useful as a reference: [::onWillDestroyPaneItem() documentation](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.9.7/Workspace#instance-onWillDestroyPaneItem)

**Steps which explain the enhancement**

``` coffeescript
atom.workspace.onWillDestroyPaneItem (event) =>
    event.prevent()
```
1. Call `.prevent()` on the event given as argument to the callback function in `::onWillDestroyPaneItem`.
2. `.prevent()` can toggle a boolean variable on the `.item`, letting the system know it should not be closed.
3. Instead of closing the pane item, the boolean variable will be toggled back.

**Current and suggested behavior**

Currently there is no way to prevent closing a tab via the JavaScript of a package. But a user of my package [pinned-tabs](https://github.com/ericcornelissen/pinned-tabs-for-atom) suggested [a feature](https://github.com/ericcornelissen/pinned-tabs-for-atom/issues/20) that requires this functionality. All this suggestion should really add is a way to prevent closing a tab when Atom reached the 'WillDestroy' state.

**Why would the enhancement be useful to most users**

It will mostly be useful for people that want to create a package that in one way or another have 'priority' tabs that they don't want to be closed when for example the close-all-tabs command is fired.

**Atom Version:** 1.9.7
**OS and Version:** Windows 10
Label: enhancement

Title: Scrollbar not refreshing when pasting code
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When pasting a long one-line text that forces the view to scroll horizontally or vertically, the scrollbar stays at its initial position. The problem seems to only occur if there is no scrollbar present. When trying to achieve the same result when there is already a scrollbar visible, it will work fine.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode
1. Open a new untitled tab
1. Paste the contents of  [this file](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/Ben3eeE/6b9a8d5c3fbdd38bda3b70b63617b280/raw/77e0fc174f27160e82bd3c27f2d8182771770fb8/gistfile1.txt) in to the new untitled tab.
1. **Expected:** Scrollbar to be at the bottom since the TextEditor is scrolled to the  bottom. **Acutal:** Scrollbar stays at the top of the file. This bug applies to both vertical and horizontal scrollbars.

**Expected behavior:** 

The scrollbar should appear and then indicate that the view has been scrolled.

**Actual behavior:** 

The scrollbar didn't indicate that the site was scrolled. It stayed at its initial position on the left.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.5
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
macOS/OSX El Capitan
Label: bug

Body:

- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

### Description

My package has a `grammar-used` activation hook, as per #8313 it is triggered on opening a new file but not on opening a previous session.

I have observed this working correctly at some point in an earlier version, but can't say how long ago.
### Steps to Reproduce

(as per #8313)
1. Install language-purescript and ide-purescript
2. Open a file with `.purs` extension - observe package starts
3. Close atom
4. Re-open atom (so file is still open)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

-  Package can be observed to neither be started nor activated (via console.log on startup)

Title: Cursor keeps switching back to pointer instead of i beam
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The cursor keeps switching back to a pointer instead of an i beam.

[![https://gyazo.com/86f19cdd229d3db894a327cfeb6eee80](https://i.gyazo.com/86f19cdd229d3db894a327cfeb6eee80.gif)](https://gyazo.com/86f19cdd229d3db894a327cfeb6eee80)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Focus away from atom window
2. Bring atom window into focus
3. Click on a few lines of text
4. Watch the cursor revert to a pointer

**Expected behavior:** The cursor should remain an i beam

**Actual behavior:** The cursor reverted to a pointer
### Versions

1.9.2 | 1.9.3 | 1.9.4
### Additional Info

OS: OS X El Capitan: 10.11.6
Syntax and UI Theme: Atom One Dark

Moving the cursor to the sidebar and back to the editor temporarily fixes the problem.
Label: bug

Title: Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'bufferId' of null
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

`ctrl+alt+cmd+L` (or `cmd+R` with the dev tools open) with an unsaved editor will reload to an empty window because of:

```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'bufferId' of null
module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:51
module.exports.TextEditor.deserialize @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:98
module.exports.DeserializerManager.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/deserializer-manager.js:45
(anonymous function)  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/pane.js:37
module.exports.Pane.deserialize @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/pane.js:36
module.exports.DeserializerManager.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/deserializer-manager.js:45
module.exports.PaneContainer.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/pane-container.js:64
module.exports.Workspace.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/workspace.js:174
module.exports.AtomEnvironment.deserialize  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/atom-environment.js:1031
(anonymous function)  @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/atom-environment.js:752
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Using either Atom 1.9.0 or Atom 1.10.0-beta0 (in safe mode or not), have an unsaved editor and no project
2. Press `ctrl+opt+cmd+L`,
3. Reload to a blank screen (check the console for the error),
4. Press `ctrl+opt+cmd+L` to re-reload,
5. Works again.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

For the `ctrl+opt+cmd+L` reload to work fine the first time.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Had to reload twice because the first time throws an error that leaves Atom in an unusable state.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom 1.9.0 and Atom 1.10.0-beta0, on macOS 10.11.
Label: bug

Title: Darwin: Unable to confirm prompts by shortcut in Atom v1.9.0

Title: DeserializerManager should throw an error if a registered deserializer returns undefined
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

This drove me up the wall while trying to figure out why deserialization wasn't working in the rewritten about package (damn you CoffeeScript implicit returns!) – deserializer functions must return an object, but we currently don't provide any feedback to package authors that this is the case. We should either throw an error or log a warning to make this clearer, and also update the docs [here](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.8.0/DeserializerManager#instance-add) to specify the expected return value of a deserializer.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.0-dev-e8f1591
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom doesn't automatically refresh archive hosted in another machine
Body:
When editing files hosted in another machine, if the file changes (outside Atom), then it will not refresh them, not even signalize that they are out-date. There isn't also an option to force the refresh of the file (os is there?). This is very annoying when I can change the file outside atom (for instance by updating my repository).

Other editors detect when the file changes, signalize it and offer the user the ability to reload it, or to overwrite it.
- the autorefresh mechanism **works when working on files hosted on the same machine**.
- I'm on OS X El Capitan
- I'm using **samba** to mount the external files in my machine.
  
  atom --version
  Atom    : 1.8.0
  Electron: 0.36.8
  Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
  Node    : 5.1.1
Label: bug

And reproducing it is unreliable. It happens sometimes after restarting Laptop.

Title: when opening a file with a line number, atom should scroll down to display that line number at the top of the view
Body:
### Description

When opening atom from the command line, to a specific file and line number, atom does not scroll the content in the most desirable manner...
### Steps to Reproduce
1. atom text/someFile.txt:115

**Expected behavior:** I expect Atom to scroll so that line number 115 is at the top of my editor

**Actual behavior:** Atom scrolls to the line number, but only far enough for it to be presented at the bottom of the screen. Furthermore, plugins like JSHint that are displayed at the bottom will cover the desired line number. Therefore, the user still has to scroll the content to view the line number, defeating the entire purpose of this feature.
### Versions

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
Label: bug

Title: Redoing changes that include a new line mixes up line endings on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When editing a text file, any changes including new lines that are applied using the redo option appear to be coerced to LF endings instead of CRLF endings as one might expect on Windows. I've only noticed this recently while editing files with some linter packages, which immediately highlight inconsistencies with line endings.

See my screen capture below for an illustration of this problem.

![redoproblem](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2031402/16984950/df07d2ce-4eaf-11e6-8c07-4e8b300ec2a9.gif)

I had a quick poke around the Atom code base but nothing stood out to me. It's probably something to do with the `text-buffer` dependency.
### Steps to Reproduce

Enabling invisible characters will help visualise this problem.
1. Open a new file in Atom and add some lines using the <kbd>ENTER</kbd> key.
2. Undo all the lines (i.e. <kbd>CTRL</kbd> + <kbd>Z</kbd>).
3. Redo all the lines (i.e. <kbd>CTRL</kbd> + <kbd>Y</kbd>).

**Expected behavior:** All the line endings inserted by the redo action should use CRLF endings instead of LF.

**Actual behavior:** Redo actions insert LF endings.
### Versions
- Atom 1.8.0
- apm 1.9.2
- Windows 10 Pro
Label: bug

Title: editor:move-to-beginning-of-screen-line moves cursor to the end of the previous line
Body:
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open file with at least one line of text
2. Turn Soft Wrap on, if it's not already
3. Indent line at least once
4. Resize window so line soft wraps
5. Fire `editor:move-to-beginning-of-screen-line` with cursor positioned anywhere on any screen line, except for the first screen line or any other screen line's first character

![Soft-wrapped lines with indentation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6350880/16905560/65cb0ce4-4c6d-11e6-9349-32f29b808eb3.png)

**Expected behavior:** Cursor moves to beginning of current line

**Actual behavior:** Cursor moves to the end of the previous line
### Versions

OS X 10.11.5
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
Label: bug

Title: Linux installation packages on atom.io are broken
Body:
## Symptoms

You downloaded Atom from https://atom.io and are experiencing unhandled exceptions like the ones in these Issues:
- https://github.com/atom/git-diff/issues/106
- https://github.com/atom/status-bar/issues/157
- https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/888
## Workaround
1. Uninstall the version of Atom you have installed now
2. Download the appropriate package from https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/latest
3. Install the new package according to [the installation instructions](https://github.com/atom/atom#debian-linux-ubuntu)
## Root Cause

It appears that the CDN cache on https://atom.io of the Linux packages is some unreleased branch version rather than the packages from https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/latest. We're investigating the problem and will update this Issue with current status.
Label: bug

Title: Invisibles enhancements and fixes
Body:
In order to clean things up, I'm unifying a number of invisibles-related enhancements and fixes under this one Issue and closing the others.
- [ ] When `showInvisibles` is off, non-visible characters should be non-visible
- [ ] When `showInvisibles` is on, all normally non-visible characters (control characters, zero-width spaces, other Unicode weirdness, etc) should be rendered in some way #1839
- [ ] There should be some way of customizing which non-visible characters are displayed when `showInvisibles` is on (Perhaps by class? i.e. whitespace, control characters, Unicode groups)
- [ ] All displayed invisibles should be visible anywhere on the line when `showInvisibles` is enabled #2572
- [ ] Make it possible for invisibles tab characters to span multiple spaces #3051 (see [implementation suggestion](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3051#issuecomment-183003834) by @natbraun)

Related: #6669
Label: enhancement

Title: Install Node.js modules to build directory
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

Following the [Linux build instructions](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md#custom-build-directory), passing the [build directory](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md#custom-build-directory), the Node.js modules are installed in the source directory.

```
$ /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/source/script/build --build-dir /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/build
Node: v6.2.1
npm: v3.9.3
Installing build modules...
=> Took 54004ms.
[…]
$ /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/source/script/grunt install --build-dir /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/build --install-dir /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/image
Grunt command does not exist at: build/node_modules/.bin/grunt
Run script/bootstrap to install Grunt
$ cd /dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/
$ find . -name grunt
./source/node_modules/bootstrap/grunt
./source/script/grunt
./source/build/node_modules/.bin/grunt
./source/build/node_modules/grunt-cli/bin/grunt
./source/build/node_modules/grunt
./source/build/node_modules/grunt/lib/grunt
```

In my opinion, the `build` directory should have been put into `/dev/shm/bee-root/atom/atom-1.8.0-0/build`.
Label: enhancement

Title: lineTextForScreenRow returns invisibles
Body:
### Description

I would expect `lineTextForScreenRow` to return whitespace rather than the associated invisibles. This behavior was changed ~1.9beta, likely with the layered rendering stuff.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().lineTextForScreenRow(2)` on a line with invisibles

**Expected behavior:** whitespace!

**Actual behavior:** invisibles :(
### Versions

Master @ 57faec

Title: Vertical Scroll When Horizontal Scroll Bar Is Visible
Body:
### Description

If horizontal scroll bar is visible you can scroll vertically (using mouse wheel) even if the content does not run off the bottom of the screen. In my case I only have 1 line of text.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open new tab
2. Type really long string that runs off edge of screen causing horizontal scroll bar to be displayed
3. Use mouse wheel to scroll vertically

**Expected behavior:** Since there is only 1 line of text there should be no need for vertical scroll

**Actual behavior:** Vertical scroll happens when not needed
### Versions

Atom: 1.8.0
OS: Linux Fedora 23
Label: bug

Label: bug

Title: Issue changing focus to a fullscreen Atom instance on OSX
Body:
### Description

I have an Atom instance running in fullscreen mode and a terminal in fullscreen mode. If I use the `atom` command to open a file from the terminal the file opens but the window does not come into focus.

Some additional information is available in [the original discussion post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/issue-changing-focus-to-a-fullscreen-atom-instance-on-osx/30458), though the relevant information is reproduced here.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open an Atom workspace and put the window in fullscreen mode using the green button in the upper-left corner.
2. Open an terminal window and make it fullscreen as well.
3. Run the command `atom foo.txt:7` in the terminal (where `foo.txt` is an actual file).

**Expected behavior:** The file should open in the existing window and the Atom window should be in focus.

**Actual behavior:** The file is opening as expected, but the _desktop_ is in focus.
### Versions

Running on OS X 10.10.5.

output of `atom --version`:

```
Atom    : 1.9.0-beta0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

output of `apm --version`:

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.0
```

Label: bug

Title: Implement clear for TextEditor in mini mode
Body:
It would be useful to implement a "clear" function on TextEditor when mini is enabled, that is optional and would allow to easily clear a field with a click as well as provide an event that is fired when the fields value becomes an empty string.

Visually it can look something like this and is only visible when the field has focus: 
![clear_field](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7757/16361433/61a15ed0-3b91-11e6-965b-e044f6cf695f.png)

If this would be an acceptable feature I would start implementing it to introduce it into [atom/settings-view](/atom/settings-view) to clear package searches.
Label: enhancement

Title: Spec stacktrace cut off
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

### Description

When running specs through the UI, the stacktraces have the potential to be cut off, like so:
![spec-stacktrace-cut-off](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/16358793/4dfee28e-3aed-11e6-9503-73f08a737efa.png)
In that picture the column number isn't visible.  In more extreme cases the line number or even parts of the filename can be cut off as well.
(the stark white/black contrast also looks really ugly)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have a sufficiently long directory structure to where the specs are located
2. Purposely create a failing test
3. `window:run-package-specs`

**Expected behavior:** Being able to view the entire stack trace without having to resize the window (maybe by clicking on the stack trace)

**Actual behavior:** Stack trace is cut off at the end
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.0-dev-9705b3d
Electron: 0.37.8

Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11

visual studio
```

Windows 10 x64.
Label: bug

Title: Running `atom` from the command line can un-set `process.env.NODE_DEV`, causing performance degradation & JS crashes
Body:
Unless Atom is running in dev mode, it sets `process.env.NODE_ENV` to "production". (The relevant code is here: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/a5fdf3e18a512349e7efb91b3c297b1a2b91bf63/src/initialize-application-window.coffee#L20) This improves the speed of React by disabling its debug mode.

But if Atom is already running, and already has `file.txt` open, and one runs `atom file.txt` from the command line, the command line's environment is used to overwrite Atom's current `process.env`. Most people don't have `NODE_DEV` set in their environment, so React falls back to its slow debug mode. 

The code responsible for "cloning" the environment is https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/a5fdf3e18a512349e7efb91b3c297b1a2b91bf63/src/environment-helpers.js#L75 Notice that it deletes the existing environment.

If React starts in production mode, it won't create some key debugging data structures. If it later changes to dev mode (because `process.env.NODE_DEV` becomes undefined), it will try to access those structures and crash.

This bug is responsible for several reported issues in packages that I maintain: https://github.com/Floobits/atom-term3/issues/63
https://github.com/Floobits/floobits-atom/issues/121
Label: bug

Title: Opening a file fails if update is ready (Mac OS X)
Body:
### Description

If Atom is running and an update is downloaded and ready to be installed, opening a new file from an external application (like Finder) will fail - rather than opening that file in the existing application instance a new instance of the application starts up, without any files. Worse yet, after closing the second instance and restarting the initial one the update is not installed and has to be downloaded again.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom 1.8.0-beta4
2. Run Atom
3. Go to Atom menu, click "Check for Update" if that menu item is present.
4. Wait for the update to be downloaded (Atom menu will show something like "Restart to install Atom 1.9.0-beta0") but don't restart Atom.
5. Run from command line: `open -a 'Atom Beta' ~/.atom/init.coffee`

**Expected behavior:** A new tab is opened in the running Atom instance, allowing to edit the Atom init script.

**Actual behavior:** A second Atom instance starts up, without any tabs. Closing that instance and restarting the initial instance won't install the update, the update has to be downloaded again instead.
### Versions

Atom 1.8.0-beta4 on Mac OS X 10.11.5. However, I've been seeing this issue at least since Atom 1.3, merely didn't realize what was causing it before now.
Label: bug

Title: Developer Tools splits source files if space in user name on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

It seems that the Developer Tools has major issues determining the proper paths to files on Windows when the logged in user account has a space in their folder name. See the Actual behavior section for details.

I'm sure this bug has to have been reported before, but I couldn't find it when searching.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Log into a user with a space in their user folder name (`C:\Users\Landon Abney\`)
2. Open Developer Tools

**Expected behavior:**
All files are correctly identified to their proper location, meaning _all_ package files are identified and shown properly in the Source tree.

**Actual behavior:**

Files that are recognized as under the `file://` domain are split between `C:\Users\User Name\` and `C:\Users\User%20Name\`.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/15867853/f6bb0b12-2c99-11e6-9b4b-01e6b20e9a5f.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/15867871/108ab6c8-2c9a-11e6-8b66-316d1564aab7.png)

The files under `file://C:/Users/Landon%20Abney/` also exhibit the odd behavior that the path is duplicated, but a few package's path's aren't:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/15868263/f29ca048-2c9b-11e6-87e6-27d11e8beff8.png)

While many files are only listed under the `(no domain)` categorization.

One group of these are shown as `/C:/Users/Landon%20Abney/.atom/packages/...`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/15867942/556b99f6-2c9a-11e6-814a-5b19323f585c.png)

The majority of files are shown as `C:\Users\Landon Abney\.atom\packages`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/15867998/92d16fe6-2c9a-11e6-9dca-b113a7f3e618.png)

I would expect _all_ of these files to be recognized as coming from the same folder, and shown properly in the Source tree. Often when working on a package the source file isn't listed under the `file://` domain, and I have to hunt through the huge list of `(no domain)` files, if it's even listed there.
### Versions

OS: Windows 10 x64 Enterprise

`atom --version`:

``` text
Atom    : 1.9.0-beta0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

`apm --version`:

``` text
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.4.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Note that I've seen this since before Atom hit 1.0 till current, so it's been a long standing issue.
Label: bug

Title: Create mixins @base-font-size @base-line-height for reuse
Body: ### Prerequisites - [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? - [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide. ### Description **UPDATE: A simple mixin proposed solution is located at** https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11905#issuecomment-224336832 **PROBLEM: The functionality for `CMD +` is not accessible by packages and themes.** Instead, [it is hardcoded to modify `atom-text-editor` element for `font-size` by hardcoding `#px` pixel value](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/6f1c1fd0e0242b096f4781698066788b26af2fa4/src/workspace-element.coffee#L54). This does not allow the reuse of this functionality for custom packages and CSS. The proposed solution noted at https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11905#issuecomment-224336832 is to move the variable it is modifying to a global mixin, for reuse at this same `atom-text-editor` element and `font-size` attribute. An example use-case: When resizing the font size with CMD-+ (or CMD-SHIFT-+), only the Editor window is resized - not the TreeView, Tabs, StatusBar, ScrollBar, Dialogs (Find, Packages, etc), or anything else. BEFORE: Atom default font... AFTER: pressing CMD-+ several times to greatly increase font size... ^- Only the Editor is resized, making the Treeview and Debugger and other dialogs extremely hard to read in screencasts/meetup presentations. This is really needed, especially for doing Meetups Presentations, Screencasts and even Screen sharing/Code pairing sessions. Just make a few CMD-+ to blow everything up to enormous size and everyone is happy. This was originally mentioned back in November 2015. > Does anyone know how could I make @font-size change along with zoom levels? E.g. ctrl+/-/scroll-up/down. Thanks! > https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2530#issuecomment-153580043 If we compare to VSCode, VSCode resizes everything with CMD-+ (Editor window, TreeView, Tabs, StatusBar, Scrollbar, dialogs, and everything else). For example, here's VSCode before and after: BEFORE: VSCode default font size... AFTER: pressing CMD-+ a few times blows everything up large. ^- that's a fullscreen shot at 3840x2400! In summary, the root issue is that `CMD +` is modifying the base stylesheet directly. We cannot access this functionality with custom packages and custom CSS. If a mixin was used instead, simple CSS overrides for the user could reuse them, as noted above. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a code file 2. Press CMD-+ a few times **Expected behavior:** When pressing CMD-+, I expect a global mixin or some other variable to access for custom packages and custom CSS. **Actual behavior:** There is no global mixin - it is hardcoded to change the base stylesheet. ### Versions ``` $ atom --version Atom : 1.8.0 Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 ```
Label: enhancement

Title: TextEditor removing folded blocks when deleting preceding lines
Body:
### Description

When you have a folded code block and delete lines using OS X "forward delete", `Fn-Delete`, the whole block is deleted when the blank line preceding the folded block is deleted.

This is 100% reproducible for all grammars (tested on Python & JavaScript).
### Steps to Reproduce

Starting with code like:

```
# Blank line
<line for the folded block of code>
```

Delete the blank line using `fn+delete`, both the blank line and the folded block are deleted.

**Expected behavior:**

Not deleting the folded block.

**Actual behavior:**
### Versions

apm --version

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.8.0-rc2
```

atom --version

```
Atom    : 1.7.4
Electron: 0.36.8
```
