Title: Windows: Press+Release Alt or F10 key does not go to the application menu; Shift-F10 does go to the system menu
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?  
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

On Windows: 
1. Press+Release Alt key does not go to the application menu the visual feedback is a quick blink of the underscore characters that should be bound to Alt-letter key combinations (those do not work either, but that's a different issue); https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menu_bar#Microsoft_Windows
2. Press+Release F10 key does not go to the application menu it doesn't give any visual feedback either; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menu_bar#Microsoft_Windows
3. Press+Release Shift-F10 keys does go to the context menu https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context_menu
4. Press+Release Alt+Space keys does go to the system menu https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_menus_in_Microsoft_Windows#System_menu

Notes:
- I'm on Windows 7 x64 Pro (all updates applied) using Atom 1.7.4 default install in `C:\Users\jeroenp\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.7.4\`
- Language/Keyboard in `Region and Language` is `Dutch (Netherlands) - United States-International`, but it also reproduces with  `Dutch (Netherlands) - US`
- I've searched using https://github.com/atom/atom/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+alt+key+windows
- I'm pretty convinced this is not a duplicate of #10732 or #4057 or #35 (it fails with either Left or Right Alt keys and also reproduces for `US` keyboard)
- It reproduces both through Remote Desktop and when physically logged on to the machine.
- Other Windows Applications I tried do not fail this.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Atom (safe mode or regular does not matter)
2. Press+Release the Alt-Key

**Expected behaviour:** The menu to get focus.

**Actual behaviour:** the visual feedback is a quick blink of the underscore characters that should be bound to Alt-letter key combinations (those do not work either, but that's a different issue)
1. Start Atom (safe mode or regular does not matter)
2. Press+Release the F10 key

**Expected behaviour:** The menu to get focus.

**Actual behaviour:** No visual feedback at all.
1. Start Atom (safe mode or regular does not matter)
2. Press+Release the Shift-F10 keys

**Expected behaviour:** The context menu to get focus.

**Actual behaviour:** No visual feedback at all.
1. Start Atom (safe mode or regular does not matter)
2. Press+Release Alt+Space keys

**Expected behaviour:** The system menu to get focus.

**Actual behaviour:** No visual feedback at all.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
#### Atom

```
C:\Users\jeroenp\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.7.4>
Atom    : 1.7.4
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

(funny, that Chrome itself reports `Google Chrome   50.0.2661.102 (Officiële build) m (32-bits)`)
#### apm

```
C:\Users\jeroenp\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.7.4>apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python
git
visual studio
```
#### Windows

Windows 7 x64 with latest updates and patches installed.
Label: bug

Title: "Open" opens file in wrong window when multiple windows exist
Body:
### Description

When multiple windows are open, attempting to open a file with the "Open..." dialog in an empty window opens that file in the wrong window, if that file is in a folder that is open in another window.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create an Atom window.
2. Add a folder to it.
3. Create a second, empty Atom window, and select it.
4. "Open" from the file menu (e.g. Cmd+O)
5. Select a file that's the folder that you added to the first window.

**Expected behavior:**
Atom opens that file in this new second window.

**Actual behavior:**
Atom fronts the first window and opens the file there. Since Atom windows can freeze opening large files (e.g. #8154), I want to avoid this.
### Versions

Atom 1.7.4 in safe mode (and OS X 10.11.5).
Label: bug

Title: Move Line Up
Body:
### Description

If I want to move the last line in a file up I can do it by pressing Ctrl+Cmd+Arrow (Mac)

**Proper behavior:** 

If there is a newline character at the end of that line, it will change from 

```
Previous line
Last line
```

to

```
Last line
Previous line
```

**Wrong behavior:** 

But if there is no newline character at the end of the last line, the hotkey will just concatenate it with the previous line

```
Last linePrevious line
```

---

Version 1.7.4
Problem persists in safe mode.
Label: bug

Title: Code folding based on grammar instead of indentation
Body:
The actual folding mechanism is simply wrong and unreliable.
I often work with big files and use folding to speed up my work.

But, if the file has a wrong indentation (something not rare if the files are human edited) atom also fold the code in a wrong manner. 
This in some case can be extremely dangerous , because if you don't remember to check every time what is folded you take that as given and work on the other parts of the file in a wrong manner.

The actual code folding is based firstly on indentation then on grammar.

I think that the code folding should be based ONLY on grammar.
Because, actually, even when you have a correct grammar (with correct folding rules) you can't be sure that the editor fold the code in the right manner.

Here is some examples to show , editing an XML file (**i want to fold at line number 10**):

**Unfolded text (with wrong indentation at line 18 and 19)**:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4760358/15536250/ce8dff60-2270-11e6-9307-8247d72f057e.png)

**Folded text (WRONG because of wrong indentation)**:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4760358/15536276/ef14bfd0-2270-11e6-99be-cec427338a9d.png)

What the correct folding should be:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4760358/15536312/19aa2244-2271-11e6-8548-e1a5aa3345bc.png)

But for achieve this we must fix the indentation (on line 18 and 19):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4760358/15536453/8e0a602c-2271-11e6-91a7-0076bec79f33.png)

I think that correct indentation CAN'T be a requirement to correct code folding.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom command line opens up a Windows shell in Git Bash.
Body:
### Description

The atom command line no longer opens files in the editor in Windows 10. Instead it opens up a type of shell and expects input. This happens in Git Bash but not `cmd`. It's happening on multiple Windows 10 machines around the office.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open up Git Bash on Windows
2. Cd to a folder you want to open in atom
3. Run `atom .` or `atom foldernamehere` to open up a folder

**Expected behavior:**
Atom will open up a new window with the folder added as a project folder

**Actual behavior:**
A type of shell opens up and expects input from the user. See screenshot.
![atom-command-line](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6545164/15471686/dd6205c8-20bc-11e6-9aee-8c5e93775901.PNG)
### Versions

Atom 1.7.4
Windows 10
Git Bash 2.8.3 MINGW64
### Workarounds

These workarounds may or may not work depending on your bash versions.

**Running atom.cmd**
Running `atom.cmd .` will produce the expected behavior. (@mikew)

**Aliasing atom.cmd**
Add an alias in your .bashrc `alias atom='atom.cmd'` (@DGempler)
Label: bug

Title: Configure verticalScrollMargin through Settings
Body:
**tldr**: [verticalScrollMargin](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/73525a1bcc309ff64c6f930401cedc052ddcf408/src/text-editor.coffee#L71) should be configurable through Settings (`config.cson`).

I had a hard time searching for vim-like [scrolloff](http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Make_search_results_appear_in_the_middle_of_the_screen#Scrolloff_option) feature in Atom.

Finally, I figured out that for this you have to write something like this in your **init.coffee**:

```
atom.workspace.observeTextEditors (editor) =>
    editor.setVerticalScrollMargin 8
```

There is even a [package](https://atom.io/packages/atom-scrolloff) where they tried to implement this feature because users experience difficulties trying to configure this.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom autosave opened blank files when a location is mounted
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? I tried even in the beta
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? I know exactly what's happening
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? I assume that is not suitable
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? Maybe
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? I tried

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

A file present in a position not mounted get autosaved by a blank file and there is not a possibility to revert.
This bug happens to me since a script automatically mount in a folder my working dir thanks to my `~/.bashrc`. But sometimes it fails, and since I don't realise but I open atom as soon as the system finish boot, once I open up a terminal, bash automatically runs the script and try again to mount my working dir and all my files opened in Atom workspace get automatically saved and replaced with blank files.
**Please help me provide a better title and ask for more information if there is some need for a better understanding.**
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enable autosave
2. Mount a drive
3. Open a file in the mounted folder
4. Enable the option for atom to save the workspace
5. Close atom
6. Unmount the drive
7. Open atom (Atom opens the file as blank, not finding it)
8. Mount the location

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The file gets reloaded as soon as the mounting point is available or you get prompted regarding that.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The file get replaced by atom automatically without options to reverting back (ctrl+z as example).
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
and
Atom    : 1.8.0-beta3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
Label: bug

Title: Wrong line and cursor position with block decoration
Body:
While playing with block decorations I noticed that on master the cursor is wrongly positionned when on a line with a block decoration:

![block-decoration](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/15425757/c8f10adc-1e8a-11e6-8b1b-f2b6316932f1.gif)

To reproduce you can use that snippet in your `init.coffee` file, it creates five block decorations randomly at the top of a file through the `editor:test-block-decorations` command:  

``` coffee
blockDecorations = []

clearBlockDecorations = ->
  blockDecorations.forEach (d) -> d.destroy()
  blockDecorations.length = 0

atom.commands.add 'atom-workspace',
  'editor:clear-block-decorations': clearBlockDecorations
  'editor:test-block-decorations': ->
    e = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
    b = 0

    for i in [0..4]
      b += Math.round(Math.random() * 300)
      start = b
      b += Math.round(Math.random() * 300)
      end = b

      startPos = e.buffer.positionForCharacterIndex(start)
      endPos = e.buffer.positionForCharacterIndex(end)

      marker = e.markBufferRange([startPos, endPos], persistent: false,   invalidate: 'touch')

      props =
        type: 'block'
        item: document.createElement('div')

      props.item.textContent = "Decoration #{i}"
      props.item.style.cssText = 'background: red; width: 100%; height: 50px;'

      blockDecorations.push e.decorateMarker(marker, props)
```

``` shell
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.9.0-dev-8f1a691
Electron: 0.36.12
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: bug

Title: Unfold tree (unfold everything under definition) feature
Body:
When I open a file, I first use the `Editor: Fold All` command to get a high-level view of the file, and then locate the function I want to look into. Now, to actually look at the code of that function I unfold the line where the function begins by clicking the little `>` arrow to it's left.

The problem is when functions contain other functions, then all the sub-functions are by default folded too. So to see the full code of the sub-function, I need to manually click and unfold each of them, and possibly the sub-sub-functions too. In a language like OCaml, where it's common coding practice to have many nested `let ... in` structures, this makes it a huge pain to use the folding feature.

**Suggested enhancement**

Instead of toggling between fold and unfold when clicking the arrow, instead cycle through "fold", "unfold", and "unfold entire tree".

**Current and suggested behavior**

Currently, after a fold-all, my code looks like this:

```
> def foo(n): ...
```

If I click the arrow once, I get:

```
 def foo(n):
>    def bar():...
>    def boo():...
```

And to see everything I need to click and unfold `bar` and `boo` manually. Clicking the arrow next to `foo` once more just returns it to the folded state in the first code block above.

Instead, I suggest that clicking the `foo` the second time produces this instead:

```
 def foo(n):
     def bar():
         pass
     def boo():
         pass
```

**Why would the enhancement be useful to most users**

It would save users of languages like Ocaml many clicks, and they'd be able to easily see the entire code of a function.

This feature exists in Emacs, for example, the default behaviour of <Tab> folding in org-mode does exactly this.

**Atom Version:** 1.7.3
**OS and Version:** OS X 10.10.5
Label: enhancement

Title: ctrl-alt-cmd-up shortcut not working
Body:
I'm setting up a new machine from scratch with OSX 10.11.5 and Atom 1.7.3. This happens in safe mode too.

For some reason using `ctrl-alt-cmd-up` doesn't work.

```
'atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
  'ctrl-alt-cmd-up': 'editor:delete-line'
```

I've tried using the shortcut with other functions and it doesn't work either.

```
'atom-workspace atom-text-editor:not([mini])': 
  'ctrl-alt-cmd-up': 'editor:duplicate-lines'
```

If I change to `ctrl-alt-cmd-down` it does work so it may seem like a problem with the key combination.

This used to work... Since this is a fresh machine I don't know whether it's an Atom problem or an OSX one or a combination.
Label: bug

Title: Force Touch support
Body:
[Link to Force Touch's Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_Touch)
### Description

I'd like to be able to use a Force Touch trackpad to perform some tasks. There could be default ones.

Default actions : 
- Force Click : Go to declaration
- Force Click : Rename in tree-view (would mimic Finder's behavior)
- Force Click : On the gutter to insert a bookmark
- Force Feedback : On end of scrolling (at bottom and top of a file)
- Force Feedback : When moving a tab in the tabs-bar (feedback when the placeholder line moves)

After, an API could be made available to package developers to allow things like : 
- Force Click :  On the minimap to open another split tab of the same file at that place
- etc.

**Expected behavior:** Have an immersive Force Touch experience

**Actual behavior:** No Force Touch support
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
Label: enhancement

Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'id' of undefined
Body:
This issue started to appear on master today (as far as I can tell), and was not occuring before so I guess it was introduced by a regression recently.
1. With pigments installed, open a big CSS/Less/Sass file (100+ lines)
2. Select a bug portion of text at the begin of the file (in my case it was around 20 lines, I found that below 5-6 lines the error started to occur randomly)
3. Try to cut/delete the selected code.

@as-cii Maybe it's me that is not doing things correctly given the recent change in the API, but since it was working before I think something must have changed in the TextEditorComponent/TxtEditorPresenter stuff.

**Atom Version**: 1.9.0-dev-e1a200a
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.4
**Thrown From**: [pigments](https://github.com/abe33/atom-pigments) package, v0.26.3

Label: bug

Title: Sanitize Config String Before Writing to config.cson
Body:
- Go to a package with at least one config field of type string. (for example, Ignored Name field in fuzzy-finder package)
- Try typing something like `#{ a }` to the string field
- Atom will display an error message saying that config.cson cannot be loaded. And configuration will not work anymore unless you go to the config.cson file and delete the error line manually.

This probably is because config.cson is treated as a regular coffee script file and `"#{ a }"` is treated as a coffee script string interpolation which translated to `"..." + a + "..."` in javascript. Since `a` is not presented in the scope, it causes the error.
I think sanitizing the string before writing to config.cson should make this problem go away.
Label: bug

Title: Error in gitbash with atom shell command not handling directories with spaces in Windows 10
Body:
### Description

Attempting to use the `atom .`  command was producing the following error in git bash. Running the atom command in the windows command prompt worked fine but gitbash gives the following error.

![Image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12580197/15162400/8ddc48c4-16b7-11e6-89f4-a030b70eb11f.PNG)
### Solution

I noticed that my user folder "Terrell Big T Vest" was being cut off at just "Terrell". I guess the shell command wasn't dealing with the space in the directory path. The solution that solved this issue just involved adding double quotes around a portion of the pushd command like so. 
#### Previous Code

[Link to specific line of code](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f00ac5ca0a4c64f4f1b05c394ec4ecfb70fa59ff/resources/win/atom.sh#L2)

``` sh
pushd $(dirname "$0") > /dev/null
```
#### Solution Code

``` sh
pushd "$(dirname "$0")" > /dev/null
```
### Atom Version

1.7.3
### OS Version

Windows 10 version 1511 (OS build 10586.0)

**Expected behavior:** open folder in atom at directory of bash

**Actual behavior:** gave the error provided above via a screenshot and did not open atom.
### Additional Comments

Again, I tested the original code in the windows command prompt and everything works as expected. The original code also works on windows when the user folder does not contain any spaces.
Hopefully this change can be made to the atom.sh folder to prevent this issue with others who have a user folder that contains spaces.
Label: bug

Title: Incorrect selection with tabs
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Occasionally when selecting an area with the cursor, anything with tabs is (visually) incorrectly selected.  This happens randomly so I haven't tried safe mode yet.

![incorrect-tabs-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/15095252/8e1fb54c-148b-11e6-94eb-bce8a3cead96.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Select a region of text that has leading tabs
2. Get (un)lucky

**Expected behavior:** The selection to be correct, like so:
![correct-tabs-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/15095255/b55695b8-148b-11e6-9e54-d9326efed277.png)

**Actual behavior:** See the first image.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.9.0-dev-02d7bde (Electron 37 branch)
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64.
Label: bug

Title: Atom fails to open new windows from command line
Body:
Atom Editor v1.7.3

I used to open new atom windows using:
`atom -n .`
A few months ago that quit working. Now, from the shell, atom only opens a window if atom is not already running.
I can still open a new window from inside the editor, but not from a shell.

Now, if I open the first atom instance in the foreground, with logging enables, ie, with
`atom -fnl`
I get a log of the error when I try to open another window from a different shell instance:

Title: Atom doesn't register as a `public.plain-text` editor on OS X
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?

> I haven't actually tested safe mode, because I can't see how it'd be relevant (the problem is determined by Atom, but actually happens outside Atom).
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

> I'm running v1.7.3, which the check updates function reports is the current-latest version.
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?

> I didn't check the debugging guide because this is about a missing `Info.plist` entry and I can't see how debugging would help.
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

> I found [getting Atom to handle different extensions](https://discuss.atom.io/t/recognizing-different-file-extensions-zmc/27428) and [making Atom recognise a given extension as a particular language](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-do-i-make-atom-recognize-a-file-with-extension-x-as-language-y/26539) but I don't believe this is an instance of either of those.
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?

> Pretty sure this is the only repository that can control Atom's `Info.plist` file.
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

> I searched both open and closed issues for `UTI`, `public.plain-text`, and `"default text editor"` but nothing seemed relevant.

Happy to be corrected about any of this.
### Description

After installing Atom on my Mac, many files (especially those without extensions) still open in (shudder) TextEdit. I took a look in Atom's `Info.plist` file, and also used [duti](http://duti.org/duti.1.html) to check the list of handlers, and it appears that Atom doesn't register for the `public.plain-text` UTI. As a text editor, it really should register with OS X to handle the editing of text files.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom v1.7.3 on OS X
2. Open a Terminal window
3. Type `touch MyAtomTestFile` and press return
4. Type `open MyAtomTestFile` and press return

**Expected behavior:** I expected the file to open in Atom

**Actual behavior:** The file opens in TextEdit (or perhaps another editor depending on what you have installed).

(You'll probably also want to `rm MyAtomTestFile`, too.)
### Versions

OS X 10.11.4 (15E65).

`$`**`atom --version`**

```
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

`$`**`apm --version`**

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Using Atom to edit commit-messages shouldn't open new window
Body: If I use Atom as Git's editor as described [here](https://github.com/atom/language-git#git-editing-support-in-atom-), a new window opens when I run `git commit`. It should first check if the containing folder's already been opened and switch to that window. ### Expectation ### Reality

Title: Selection stuck on mouse movement
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

After I click in an editor window, moving the mouse will select the text. Atom behaves as if I did not release the mouse button.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start atom (in normal or safe mode) and open an editor
2. Press and release the left mouse button
3. Move the mouse cursor

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Text should not be selected because I clicked and  released the mouse button

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Text is selected as if I had not release the mouse button
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
on
Ubuntu 15.10 (Wily Werewolf)

Title: Shouldn't be able to resize a pane when there is only one
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Atom gets into a perplexing state for some people ([for example](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-editor-width-bug/28439)) whether by some combination of keys or package actions where there is only one pane, but it does not take up the full width of the editor window. Atom should not be able to get into this state.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch Atom
2. Ensure there is only one pane in the window
3. Press <kbd>Cmd+Alt+-</kbd> multiple times

**Expected behavior:** Nothing to change

**Actual behavior:** The pane area for the single pane shrinks even though the window does not change size
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.0-dev-5a9bd28
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.3
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.8.1
Label: bug

Title: Package doesn't work correctly after update when something new is added to atom.config
Body:
### Description

I updated my package [language-markdown](https://github.com/burodepeper/language-markdown) yesterday and I received the following issue report: https://github.com/burodepeper/language-markdown/issues/108

I haven't heard back from @MGallow yet, but I'm relatively certain that the issue is related to what I've mentioned in my initial response to the issue report. **The underlying issue** (I think): Whenever I add a new option to `atom.config` in an update, this causes the package to malfunction when it is updated.

I haven't experienced this issue on my development machine (because I think the new config item is already created during development), but I have seen it multiple times when updating on my secondary computer. Reloading Atom fixes the issue.
### Prerequisites
- I'm sure I can technically reproduce this, but it's quite the hassle. Each reproduction gives only a single opportunity to look at what's wrong. I'm also relatively certain (at least I hope so) my own code isn't the cause of these issues. See https://github.com/burodepeper/language-markdown/blob/master/lib/main.coffee (L22-26 for config, L50-51 for subscriptions, and L166-180 for execution)
- Atom v1.7.3 (detected on earlier versions too) on Mac OS X 10.11.4
- Haven't found any relevant issues; search terms are rather generic.
Label: bug

```

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The title bar color (Windows 7 classic theme) does not always update and is sometimes grey (non focused window) while the window is focused and should be blue (focused window).

//cc @damieng Windows only issue?
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Classic mode windows (I don't know if needed I only use classic mode)
2. Open atom in safe mode.
3. Ctrl-shift-o and move the dialog over the blue title bar, title bar gets colored grey where the dialog was moved over. Other operations such as making a new snap in the snipping tool also changes the color of the title bar.

See example of title bar of focused application where open dialog was moved around.
![atom title bar color](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/14931437/b8afb67a-0e6b-11e6-98a0-0082e3673450.png)

**Expected behavior:** Title bar color to update consistently as other windows applications and be completely blue when the application is focused.

**Actual behavior:** Title bar color is incorrect and depends on how some dialog was moved or other actions while having atom open.
### Versions

Windows 7 classic theme
Atom 1.7.3
Label: bug

Title: Window not redrawing when some dialogs are open
Body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The window does not redraw while the help menu->check for update dialog is opened and moved.

//cc @damieng Windows only?
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Check for update using the help menu.
2. Move around the dialog that appears stating atom is the latest version.

![window doesnt update with dialog open](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/14552189/00a32da4-02dc-11e6-88df-cf2edbc4862a.PNG)

**Expected behavior:** I expect atom to not look like I am winning in solitaire.

**Actual behavior:** Atom looks like I won solitaire.
### Versions

Windows 7
Atom 1.7.3 safe mode.
Label: bug

Title: [Feature] Notification about update (instead of auto download + install)
Body:
I had to disable "check for updates" under Help > About because Atom would download updates over a roaming connection (wifi tethererd via phone). But now I have to remember to check for updates. Wouldn't it be better if it would still check for updates but give a notification for it when one is available?

The default behaviour could still be to automatically download and install them, but instead of a checkbox with "Check for updates" I'd rather see a "Automatically download updates" option and a notification if it isn't checked.

Or maybe this is an idea for a package? I have no experience with building those for atom so... uuhm.. I'd need help with that :)
Label: enhancement

Title: Filenames display with normalized spaces in tabs
Body:
Opening a file with multiple spaces in the filename displays as one space.
It appears to be normalizing whitespace in the display of the filename.
For example a filename with 2 or more spaces displays in the tab as one space:
"811347  1_por.xml"
displays as 
"811347 1_por.xml"

This screenshot shows two filenames where one has multiple spaces and one that has only one space. They look identical in the tabs title.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1869259/14918625/993d12f0-0dea-11e6-887b-5dc2f45b54dd.png)

Atom 1.7.2 Windows 7 64bit
Label: bug

Title: Editor hangs forever when navigating to the end of a long line
Body:
### Description

When the cursor is at column 0 of the line after an extremely long line, and the left arrow key is pressed to move the cursor to the end of that line, Atom freezes forever.

Moreover upon relaunch, it reopens the SAME FILE to the SAME CURSOR POSITION and hangs again, meaning the user is stuck in a permanent hang-restart loop. Atom is reduced to an annoying emulator of DLL Hell.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set Atom to open
2. Open a 200kB XML file, encoded in UTF-16 LE, that has all its text distributed on two lines.
3. Atom opens this file with your cursor at the top left.
4. Move the cursor to column 0 of the second line.
5. Press the left arrow key.
6. Atom wraps around and then hangs forever.
### Versions

1.7.3, tested on OSX 10.11.4 and Windows 10 x64.
Label: bug

Title: Mouse buttons 8/9 cannot be listened to from Atom
Body:
Most mouse devices today not made by Apple have more than two button.
To be precise, my mouse is this one: http://myego.cz/img/razer-logitech/mx518.jpg
I would love if I could use all of my buttons in Atom. Currently I tried:

``` javascript
document.addEventListener('mousedown', (e) => console.log(e))
```

But that doesn't trigger when I use my mouse's back/forward button.
I did a quick search and came to:
https://github.com/jostrander/mouse-forward-back

I would be perfectly satisfied if I could at least listen to 5 buttons left click, right click, middle click and those forward/back buttons.

My versions:
Atom    : 1.7.1
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11+
git 2.7.4
Label: enhancement

Title: Enable NotificationManager.addError() to handle Error-Objects
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?

- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

This would enable just adding an Error-Notification with an Error as parameter and probably saves some developers some seldom Exceptions complaining about the wrong data type of the message.

As a nifty Addon, the Notification could treat `err.stack` as the detail-option.

? ☕ 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Deliver an (NodeJS) `Error`-object to `atom.notifications.addError()` as `message`-parameter.

**Expected behavior:** Atom should display the `Error.message` as `message` and `Error.stack` as `detail`.

**Actual behavior:** Atom raises an Exception:

```
Error: Notification must be created with string message: <...>
```
### Versions

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.4
```
Label: enhancement

Title: cursor in wrong column in soft wrapped line when using tabs
Body:
### Description

The cursor looks like it is in the (`x`-1)th column to the left of where it actually is. Where `x` is the tab width.
![animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/97994/14867272/5b2f4090-0c8d-11e6-919c-9b295cb31b9a.gif)

In the above GIF I am pressing the [Backspace] key and the character after the blinking cursor is being deleted then the cursor moves one character to the left
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Type a long string with tabs so the tabs are past the edge of the editor (make sure tabs are used not spaces)
2. Turn on Soft Wrap (`View -> Toggle Soft Wrap` if it isn't on)
3. Turn on Invisible Characters
4. Try to edit the wrapped part of the line

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Same as editing the non wrapped part of the line

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The cursor looks like it is the width of a tab - 1 characters to the left of where it actually is

Title: Opening a file should open a new window if no window present on current Ubuntu workspace
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

On Ubuntu, when opening a file from the file manager in Atom, it will first open a new window on the current workspace (A). Opening a second file opens in the same window in a new tab. This is expected.

After changing to a different workspace (B) in Ubuntu where no Atom window is present and then opening another file, the file will open in the Atom window present on the first workspace (A). However, the expected behavior is that the file is opened in a new window of Atom.

My notion of expected behavior is derived from what is done by Gedit, the default text editor on Ubuntu. It also seems more intuitive to me that the file is opened on the workspace I'm currently viewing, even if Atom is already present on a different workspace. This follows an idea of using different workspaces for different tasks.

Some might disagree with this suggestion, but I would still like to see this as an optional behavior because this issue is one of the most often mentioned by those I know who use Atom.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a file in Atom from the file manager in Ubuntu on workspace (A).
2. Change workspace to workspace (B).
3. Open a second file in Atom from the file manager.

**Expected behavior:** Two Atom windows open, one on workspace (A) with the first file and one on workspace (B) with the second file.

**Actual behavior:** One Atom window opened on workspace (A) with both files.
### Versions

Ubuntu 15.10 and Ubuntu 16.04 running Unity 7.

``` bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.7.2
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

$ apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11+
git 2.7.4
```
Label: enhancement

Title: git not interfacing with Atom correctly
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [**Yes**] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [**Yes**] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [**Yes**] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [**Yes**] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [**I think so**] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [**Yes**] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

'm a new user of Atom and Git. I've configured git to use Atom as its core editor. Mostly Atom works for me; and mostly, git works for me. Together, they aren't happy.

Atom is configured as the editor in this manner: git config --global core.editor "'C:/users/[user]/appdata/local/atom/bin/atom.cmd' --new-window --wait"

I've also tried it without the "--new-window" flag, with no difference in result.

When I issue a "git commit" command, I get some form of the following, IF THERE'S NO CURRENT
INSTANCE OF ATOM:

```
App load time: 545ms
[1228:0424/183520:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1228:0424/183520:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1228:0424/183520:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1228:0424/183520:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1228:0424/183522:INFO:CONSOLE(52)] "Window load time: 1483ms", source: file:///C:/Users/[user]/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.7.2/resources/app.asar/static/index.js (52)
[1228:0424/183525:INFO:CONSOLE(1282)] "Error refreshing repository status:", source: C:\Users[user]\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.7.2\resources\app.asar\src\git-repository-async.js (1282)
[1228:0424/183525:INFO:CONSOLE(1283)] "Error: Reference 'refs/heads/master' not found", source: C:\Users[user]\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.7.2\resources\app.asar\src\git-repository-async.js (1283)
[1228:0424/183525:INFO:CONSOLE(392)] "Uncaught (in promise) Error: Reference 'refs/heads/master' not found", source: node.js (392)
[1228:0424/183526:INFO:CONSOLE(0)] "::shadow pseudo-element is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/6750456638341120 for more details.", source: (0)
error: There was a problem with the editor ''C:/users/[user]/appdata/local/atom/bin/atom.cmd' --new-window --wait'.
Please supply the message using either -m or -F option.
```

If there IS ALREADY a current instance of Atom, then instead I get this:

```
App load time: 815ms
error: There was a problem with the editor ''C:/users/[user]/appdata/local/atom/bin/atom.cmd' --new-window --wait'.
Please supply the message using either -m or -F option.
```

In neither case does the commit succeed.

I don't know whether the "-m" or "-F" option would solve the problem, but if it will I'm not sure how to supply one of those.

I've done very little configuration with git and Atom, so they're both very close to "out of the box" with regard to customization.

Can anyone help?

-boster
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Configure Atom as the default editor for git, in gitbash, with this line of code:

```
git config --global core.editor "'C:/users/[user]/appdata/local/atom/bin/atom.cmd' --new-window --wait"
```
1. Commit a change to a repository

**Expected behavior:** 
I expect an Atom window to open with git commit details, and a place for me to enter a commit message. Upon closing this Atom window, I expect the commit to be executed and succeed.

**Actual behavior:** 
The Atom window does open, and I edit my message and close the window. But instead of executing the commit, the commit fails.
### Versions

**From apm --version:**
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.1
git 2.8.1.windows.1
visual studio

**From Windows command ver:**
Windows 10.0.10586

**From atom --version:**
Atom 1.7.2
Electron 0.36.8
Chrome 47.0.2526.110
Node 5.1.1
Label: bug

Title: Decompose ligatures when the cursor is in/beside them
Body:
### Description

I use FiraCode2 with ligature support in Atom, and for the most part it's very nice.

However, I find it very difficult to edit ligatures. For example, I often need to change <$> to <*> in Haskell, but Atom does not show where in the ligature the cursor is, and I often lose time erasing the wrong part of the ligature.
Similarly, I will often try to delete the space before an arrow -> , but I end up deleting the first dash - because the cursor is shown beside the ligature, even when its actual position is in the middle.

Ideally, when the cursor was at the edge of, or inside a ligature, it would be rendered not as the single character, but as the actual simple characters which make it up.

Is this possible? If it is not, consider this a request that it be added, or at least supported in a package.

Thanks!
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set the font to FiraCode, HaskLig, or another ligature-supporting font
2. Enter a ligature, such as `->`
3. Move the cursor from one side to the ligature of the other

**Expected behavior:** The ligature is decomposed into its constituent characters, or the cursor is shown inside the ligature.

**Actual behavior:** The cursor remains to the right of the ligature.
### Versions

I've tested in 1.7.1, but it showed up in all previous versions I'd used.
Label: bug

Title: "Keep Waiting" dialog blocks until closed
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The "keep waiting" dialog that appears when Atom becomes unresponsive blocks until it is closed, preventing Atom from ever becoming responsive again until "keep waiting" is selected.  This is because Atom is performing a synchronous call to `dialog.showMessageBox` instead of an async one.  In addition, there is no code in place to automatically close the dialog if/when Atom does regain responsiveness.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Get Atom into an unresponsive state and have the "keep waiting" dialog appear
2. Wait for Atom to become responsive again
3. :zzz:

**Expected behavior:** Atom to regain responsiveness

**Actual behavior:** Atom hangs forever until an option is selected
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.9.0-dev-8ece1ee
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64.
Label: bug

Title: `core:paste` of text copied using `editor:copy-selection` pastes at start of line, instead of cursor.
Body:
### Background

Hi, pressing ctrl-c on an empty line, copies the whole line.  Which is fine, except it deletes what's on the clipboard which is incredibly annoying.  I'd select the line if I wanted it.

A work-around, from this merge: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8025
and described here: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7103
is to use this in keymap.cson:

```
'atom-text-editor':
  'ctrl-c': 'editor:copy-selection'    # linux and windows
```

But unfortunately that pastes at the start of the line, instead of the cursor.  I'm using Atom 1.5.3 on Ubuntu 14.04.

Thanks!
### Steps to Reproduce
1.  Edit -> Preferences -> keybindings -> tiny link at top: 'your keymap file'
2.  paste above code
3. Save `keymap.cson`
4.  Open file.  Select some text in middle of line.  ctrl-c
5.  Ctrl-v and it's pasted at start of line.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

pasted at cursor

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

pasted at start of line
### Versions

Title: [Feature Request] When pressing Ctrl-Tab key, display a panel of tab list in MRU order for cycling
Body:
### Description

The MRU tab switching in 1.7 is great, however it would be even better to pop up a tabs list panel in MRU order when pressing `ctrl-tab`, so that I can choose which specific tab to go to by holding `ctrl` and pressing `tab` key. The current behaviour would just jump to the first tab in the MRU stack, which is fine but really doesn't cover the most of editing scenarios.

What I mean is something like this package does [enhanced-tabs](https://atom.io/packages/enhanced-tabs).

Thanks!
### Versions

OS X: 10.10
Atom: 1.7.2
Label: enhancement

Title: Fedora Dependency Problem for 1.7 Upgrade, nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.*.x86_64
Body:
### Prerequisites

None, 
### Description

Cannot install Atom 1.7 on Fedora 22 or 23, but can install 1.6.
### Steps to Reproduce

```
[root@dev02 ~]# dnf install atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:20 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Error: nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
(try to add '--allowerasing' to command line to replace conflicting packages)

[root@dev02 ~]# dnf --allowerasing install atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:36 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Error: nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64

[root@dev02 ~]# dnf list ffmpeg
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:45 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Available Packages
ffmpeg.x86_64                                               2.6.8-1.fc22                                               rpmfusion-free-updates
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Atom 1.7 to install
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Atom 1.7 install fails
### Versions

See above
# reference:

Mentioned the problem at the link below.  Problem was confirmed and @lee-dohm suggested I create this issue.  
https://discuss.atom.io/t/fedora-dependency-problem-for-1-7-upgrade-nothing-provides-libffmpeg-so-64bit-needed-by-atom-1-7-0-1-x86-64/27940
Label: bug

Title: Separate file type icon for Windows
Body:
In reference to #10818 I would like to see file associations in Windows taken a step further by differentiating Atom's associated files with distinct file type icons. As of 1.7 all associated files take Atom's default icon as its own. At the very least all associated files should have a generic file icon separate from Atom's stock icon.

Ideally all file type icons should be changeable depending on the file extension thus conveying a visual difference between for example a .txt and a .py by visual recognition; however, starting with a separate generic associated file type icon would be significantly better than what is in place as of 1.7.

An example of files associated with Atom 1.7 on Windows 10 desktop:
![2016-04-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11142424/14588863/ae1dd722-0499-11e6-9cc1-e2a70c7fa6c2.png)

An example of the proposed generic file icon next to an Atom shortcut:
![2016-04-17 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11142424/14588947/0566d16c-049c-11e6-8b75-60e7aa33cc1c.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Specify git location instead of looking in PATH
Body:
I am using a portable version of atom from a flash drive. I also have a version of Portable Git. It would be nice to give the path to that portable git. Although this would need to work when the Windows drive letter changes due to it being on a flash drive.
# atom.exe -v

```
Atom    : 1.7.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: enhancement

Title: CRTL+F4 should close tab
Body:
Atom partly follows browser tab handling (e.g. CRTL+SHIFT+T to re-open the last closed tab).

It should also implement the usual browser shortcut for closing a tab (CTRl+F4) (whether instead of CTRL+W as is presently the case or additionally I have no opinion).

This regularly trips me up, as I'm used to this shortcut from both any desktop browser I've ever used and quite a few applications which implement a multi-document interface.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom 1.7: bad scrollbar behavior
Body:
Windows 7, Atom 1.7.1 started in safe mode.

I load a medium-sized file, around 500 lines of JS code.
I jump to the end of the file with Ctrl+End.

The scrollbar thumb isn't at the bottom of the scrollbar.
I try to click on the middle of the thumb (to drag it). The thumb goes up. I can repeat this a few times, until the thumb goes in the first half of the bar. There, I can catch it...

Actually, I can drag the thumb if I aim at where it should be (the bottom of the bar).
Label: bug

Title: Reloading wipes undo history and scroll position
Body:
Prior to v1.7.0, it was possible to undo changes to an opened document after reloading the window (as long as it'd been running in development mode). I always assumed this was a feature of dev mode... make changes to a package repo, reload window, see what's wrong, undo last change, repeat.

Since upgrading to v1.7.0, I'm no longer able to do this. I'm unsure if this is by design or just an honest bug (or even if the previous behaviour was a bug to begin with...)

Also, the scroll offset isn't preserved after reloading the window: it reverts back to the top of the document. This wasn't the case before.

For the record, I'm using the _Reload window_ command from the _View -> Developer_ menu (which I've assigned the keyboard shortcut of <kbd>⌘ + shift + R</kbd>).
Label: bug

Title: Download for Mac is broken
Body:
The file that is downloaded when I click "Download for Mac" on atom.io is corrupted. I've tried several times, but after the `.zip` is extracted and I try to run the `.app` a Mac OS dialog is shown with the message "You can’t open the application “Atom? because it may be damaged or incomplete."

Atom Beta seems to work just fine.
Label: bug

### Description

On two different OSX versions (10.11.4 and 10.9.5), the upgrade to 1.7.0 relaunched Atom with my multiple open documents replaced with Untitled empty tabs. This did cause some loss of work (my fault, obviously, but still a nasty surprise).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Restart Atom to install the 1.7.0 update with multiple files open

**Expected behavior:**

All open docs were replaced by empty Untitled tabs - for unsaved docs, this was fatal.

Title: Electron 0.36 broke stdout on Windows
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? (I think...)
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

It seems that the version of Electron bundled in Atom fails to report any data back on `stdout` when called as Node. `options.env.ELETRON_RUN_AS_NODE` is set (to `1`), but the `stdout` callbacks are never called. If you have Node installed on the machine and replace `process.execPath` with the path to Node everything works as expected (tested with Node v5.9.0).

This has been reported as an issue by users updating to v1.7.0 on the following linter plugins:
- `linter-jshint`
- `linter-htmlhint`
- `linter-csslint`
- Possibly `linter-bootlint` as well (Looks like this might just be user error)

Note that none of those linters have AppVeyor (Windows) CI testing configured.

The following Node based linters _are_ being tested on AppVeyor, but it turns out all of these are directly being `require`'d, and as such aren't being ran as an "external" Node process:
- linter-stylelint
- linter-js-yaml

`linter-eslint` is interesting in that it _is_ working, but it utilizes a worker process that is being created with [`child_process.fork()`](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v7.2.0/src/helpers.js#L15).

This _might_ be a duplicate of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2887, is probably caused by https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/9627, and might be related to https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/11162.

If there is any further information or debugging information that would help please let me know. I'm almost always available as @arcanemagus on Atom's Slack instance if anything is needed.

@50Wliu, @joshaber, @joefitzgerald I'm tagging you three as it seems you have all worked on parts of the Electron update and might know more about how to further test this.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom v1.7.0 or above
2. Use something that attempts to load a Node process (ie: BufferedNodeProcess, or more indirectly  [linter-jshint](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-jshint))
3. Observe that the `stdout` callbacks are never called

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Calling a Node process works as expected

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The `stdout` callback is never called, so the process `stdout` never gets any data.
### Versions

OS: Windows 7 - 10
Atom: v1.7.0 - v1.8.0-beta0

Atom v1.8.0-beta0:

``` raw
Atom    : 1.8.0-beta0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: bug

Title: Error moving files across mounts or drives, "Failed to move entry EXDEV: cross-device link not permitted"
Body:
*Edit by @rsese to add issue template details*

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

You can't drag and drop a file across mounts or drives and will get an error.  From @50Wliu /cc https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11456#issuecomment-373248850:

> You can't I looked into this error code and this happens when attempting to move files across mounts (Unix) or drives (Windows). Seems like the correct thing to do in this case is a copy + delete.

### Steps to Reproduce

Reproduced on macOS 10.12.6:

1. Plug in a flash drive
2. Create a text file on the flash drive
3. `atom --safe`
4. Open some project
5. From Finder, try to drag the file from step 2 to the project in step 4

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The file to be moved from the flash drive to the project directory (this is what happens if you drag a file from some other directory on the same drive).

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

You get a "Failed to move entry EXDEV: cross-device link not permitted" error and the file isn't moved.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```
$ atom -v
Atom    : 1.32.2
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

$ apm -v
apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.2
python 2.7.10
git 2.14.3
```
---

win 10 x64
atom v1.6.2

I got an error when I tried to move a directory from my desk to my project in atom tree. I cannot find any help from issues list. I googled it and found it may a npm problem. I am a layman for nodejs. I am not sure if here is a right place I can get help.
![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2533629/14516152/c1ec84b0-0232-11e6-96e3-09fba04a6252.png)

Title: Windows install/update does not always create/modify bin folder in appdata
Body:
When the windows installer runs or the auto-updater executes the following files should be created/overwritten in c:\users<username>\appdata\local\atom
- atom
- atom.cmd
- apm
- apm.cmd

Each one acts as a simple shortcut to it's associated script in c:\users<username>\appdata\local\atom\app-1.x.y\resources\cli  (suffixless ones link to the .sh ones)

Various reports of this, using this bug to correlate them into a single issue. Doesn't always happen, need to find out why. Success/fail for these is not part of the squirrel log right now.
Label: bug

Title: Scroll to center is ignored if already visible
Body:
### Description

When scrolling to a position that is already visible with the `center` option set to `true` (as described [here](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.6.2/TextEditor#instance-scrollToBufferPosition)), no scrolling is performed.
### Steps to Reproduce

``` javascript
editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor() /* open a file with 100 lines */
editor.scrollToBufferPosition([50, 0]) /* scroll to line 50, line 52 is visible now */
editor.scrollToBufferPosition([52, 0], {center: true})
```

**Expected behavior:** According to the API docs, line 52 should be scrolled to the center of the editor.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens.
### Further information

Before e3dabd5200afea5074fb63003951ef677539413e, the behavior was as expected. Maybe the change was intentional, but then I don't understand why.

The problem can be fixed by removing

``` coffeescript
unless @getScrollTop() < desiredScrollCenter < @getScrollBottom()
```

in [text-editor-presenter.coffee](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/text-editor-presenter.coffee). I can open a PR with this change if necessary.
Label: bug

``` ### Versions Atom 1.6.2 apm 1.6.0 OSX 10.10.5

Title: Duplicate tabs
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

This is very likely a very low priority issue caused by a race condition in the deduper (@lee-dohm  theory) but it is possible (if you are fast enough) to open the same tab multiple times (I managed twice at least).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open tab from tree view by clicking on it.
2. Immediately after step 1 press enter.
3. Observe you have 2 tabs of the same file open, in the case where pending pane items option is true you have the one pending tab and one confirmed tab, without pending pane items option you have 2 confirmed tabs.

For me this was easier at my work computer and with the first tab that i open in that atom window, as the first tab takes several seconds to load you have a bigger window to execute the 2nd step.
At home I can reproduce it but I have to try for a long time.

**Expected behavior:** Atom to switch to already open tab at all times.

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens multiple (at least 2 confirmed) tabs of the same file.
### Versions

1.6.X
Windows 7.
Label: bug

Title: "Uncaught (in promise) GitRepositoryAsync.destroyed: Repository has been destroyed" on spec runs
Body:
# When I run spec, spec passes, but it put error like blow.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/155205/14286799/4dbc8944-fb8b-11e5-998b-49cfc1c823e4.png)

AFAIR this error start from Atom v1.6.2.
This error is not by my code change.

When I re-run previous spec(which was not includes this error in logs of previous run) via Travis-CI, new result includes this `Repository has been destroyed` error.
This error is not my package specific, see [status-bar](https://travis-ci.org/atom/status-bar)

Minimum spec to reproduce error is below, spec passes but console.log put `Repository has been destroyed` error.

```
describe "git-repo-error", ->
  [editor] = []

  beforeEach ->
    waitsForPromise ->
      atom.workspace.open("sample").then (e) ->
        editor = e

  it "test", ->
    null
```
Label: bug

Title: Modified files remain marked in Atom after repo is commited
Body:
In Atom 1.8.0-dev-435dcc7, modified files remained marked as modified (e.g. coloured in the tabs and in tree view) even after a commit.

To reproduce: edit some files, commit the repository, go back to atom. The modified files remain coloured. Expected result is for them to lose their git status and revert back to unmodified.

This is on OS X 10.10.5

Spoken to @thomasjo in slack channel (Recommended posting here), opening files on my PC are fine, network drive issues, SAMBA mounted network drive in windows, no issues before this.

Coming back to work on Tuesday atom had auto-updated, I believe to 1.6.1. This caused issues where the application would hang for 30-40 seconds upon basically any action, maybe get as far as clicking a button for it to hang again.

As you can imagine, hard to develop anything! So I completely uninstalled everything, removed all traces from %appdata% and my user folder (.atom - This is backed up) - I reinstalled a fresh copy of 1.6.1 from the site, everything seemed to be working, until I added a project folder and opened a file... Blank. Nothing, Nada. Even stranger, if I then close atom, relaunch, close the file and undo the close tab, it has it's contents... But no other file does.

Again, after this I removed all traces again and installed 1.6.0 with no luck resolving the issue, followed by trying out the 1.7.0 beta 3.

Title: Include version number in released .deb files
Body:
### Description

It's difficult to determine the currently available version of the .deb files. It's also confusing if you download to a directory which already has an `atom-amd64.deb` file.

This change could also be applied to other releases; `atom-xx.yy.zz-mac.zip`, `atom-xx.yy.zz-windows.zip`, etc
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Download atom.
2. Wait a month or two.
3. Download atom again.
4. Get confused when looking in your downloads directory.

**Expected behavior:**
File is named `atom-1.6.1-amd64.deb`.

**Actual behavior:**
File is named `atom-amd64.deb`.
### Versions

All versions appear to be affected.
Label: enhancement

Title: [1.7.0] process.env keys on Windows are not case-insensitive anymore
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

On Windows, environment variable names are case-insensitive.

In Atom 1.7.0 for Windows, `process.env.PATH` is returning `undefined` if the path environment variable is defined as `Path` (it is then accessible as `process.env.Path` only).

In 1.6 the environment variable is accessible as both PATH and Path.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. On Windows, ensure your path environment variable (`%PATH%`) is defined as `Path` (not `PATH` as is customary on UNIX).
2. Launch Atom and open the dev console (ctrl+alt+I)
3. Evaluate `process.env.PATH`.

**Expected behavior:** `process.env.PATH` should return the contents of the Path environment variable, regardless of what case its name is spelled in (as in Atom 1.6).

**Actual behavior:** `process.env.PATH` evaluates to `undefined`. Only `process.env.Path` returns the proper contents of the environment variable.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.0-beta0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
Label: bug
