Title: Mix of Arabic and Latin rendered incorrectly
Body: ### Prerequisites - [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? - [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? ### Description I don't understand Arabic myself, and it's the first time working with a RTL language, but I'm experiencing some rendering issues with a specific text. I have the following SQL insert statement: ``` sql INSERT INTO `dwp_terms` VALUES (19,'عين المدينة','3ayn-almadina',0); ``` Which renders incorrectly. It seems it might be a Webkit bug, but I'm not sure. It might also be that the text is ill formatted, but it seems to render correctly in Firefox and Apple Notes, albeit with the words in reverse. I've included a screenshot from Sublime Text 3 which seems to render as I expected. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Use the following piece of text as a template `(19,'','3ayn-almadina',0),` 2. Paste `عين المدينة` into the empty quotes 3. Incorrect rendering I do not know if this applies to more RTL scripts, but I've been working with about 40 terms that were "converted" to `INSERT` statements, and this was the only one causing trouble. **Expected behavior:** here rendered with Sublime Text 3 (however, seems to not render arabic correctly) **Actual behavior:** rendered with Atom 1.6.0 The generated HTML, which looks correct: ``` html ( 19 , ' عين المدينة' , ' 3ayn-almadina' , 0 ), ``` ### Versions ``` sh $ atom --version 1.6.0 $ apm --version apm 1.6.0 npm 2.13.3 node 0.10.40 python 2.7.11 git 2.7.2 ```
Label: bug

Title: Add manual pages for Atom and APM
Body:
Every time, I get bitten by this:

```
$ man atom
No manual entry for atom
$ atom --help
Atom Editor v1.6.0

Usage: atom [options] [path ...]
⋮
```

Same with `apm`. For Unix-like systems, a manual page should be included to supply this information, even if it's ultimately just copying what's available with the `--help` switch.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom crashes when attempting to step into Atom code without the Atom source repository available
Body:
### Description

Atom crashes when setting breakpoints in my package.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set breakpoint in package code, wait for it to be hit
2. Step in or over the code
3. Atom crashes

**Expected behavior:** 
I expect atom to allow me to step through the code and be able to debug it.

**Actual behavior:**
Atom crashes every time.
### Versions

1.6.0
### Temporary fix

I've discussed the issue [here](https://discuss.atom.io/t/setting-breakpoints-crashes-atom/27060) , and @lee-dohm suggested I clone the atom repo in `~/github/atom`. After doing that, I'm able to use breakpoints without atom crashing.
Label: bug

Title: Soft Wrap doesn't respect word boundaries
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I'm using Atom to write HTML emails (yay). These include long URLs, so I have Soft Wrap turned on.

![soft-wrap](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5524469/14026882/f29a84a2-f1c2-11e5-9d48-b918985b3407.png)

Note how the line gets broken in the middle of the word "Final". There are lots of better places for a line break.

When I go into my Settings, there's an input box for "Non Word Characters"; these characters define word boundaries. It seems to me that it would make sense for Soft Wrap to break lines at word boundaries instead of only at spaces.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enable Soft Wrap (in the View menu)
2. Write a line of text that exceeds the width of the buffer, thus triggering soft wrap. The line should include some of the Non Word Characters: `/\()"':,.;<>~!@#$%^&*|+=[]{}?-`

**Expected behavior:** Line wraps at a word boundary.

**Actual behavior:** Lines wrap only at spaces.
### Versions

1.6.0
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom not respecting Electron CLI switches
Body:
This is a follow on from [a discussion in Atom's Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-and-electron-cli-switches)

I'm using Atom 1.6, which is built on Electron 0.34.5. In the [Electron docs](https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/v0.34.5/docs/tutorial/debugging-main-process.md) it mentions the `--debug` and `--debug-brk` switches.

Running `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom --debug-brk=60131` hangs. Normally node processes print out that they're waiting for a listener before proceeding. Using `--debug` allows Atom to run, but as I'm running a test (`--dev --test`) I'd like the process to block so I can connect my debugger.

There may be other Electron switches that Atom also doesn't respect that I don't know of.
Label: enhancement

Title: Hide atom-overlay when not visible
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

This issue came up [here](https://github.com/atom/one-dark-ui/pull/127).

Currently `atom-overlay`s overlap the rest of the UI. I think it's ok, but only as long as the current line is visible. If you scroll it "out of sight", it looks odd having the overlay still be shown.

A possible solution might be to try to detect when the current line is not visible and then hide the `atom-overlay`. I think autocomplete kinda already tries to do that by jumping to the top when scrolling down, but doesn't hide completely. And would be nice if it's part of the core behavior, so all packages would get it. Maybe with an option to opt-out if a package wants stay visible all the time.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open find + replace `cmd-f`
2. Have autocomplete enabled and type something to open the autocomplete overlay.
3. Scroll down until the current line is underneath the find + replace panel

**Expected behavior:**

The autocomplete overlay should disappear

![overlay](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/13974127/810694a6-f0ec-11e5-897b-f80c7d7fbb52.gif)

**Actual behavior:**

It stays on top of the find + replace panel, even tough you can't see the current line anymore

![screen shot 2016-03-23 at 11 47 53 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/13974215/2793be34-f0ed-11e5-8209-8bd9754f4e6a.png)
### Versions

Title: File icons for default languages outside of Atom (icons in Finder)
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [ x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x ] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I would like to be able to distinguish my Objective-C .h, .m, Markdown, and Swift (and any other programming/markup language) files from one another in the Finder when Atom is set to be the default app for opening these files. Currently all the files show the same Atom document icon. When files are set to be opened by Xcode by default the file icons are different based on their type. Additionally it would be nice if external packages could dictate different images for different file types.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set Atom to be the default app for opening Objective-C and Swift files.
2. View file icons in Finder

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

File icons are different based on the file type.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

File icons are all the same Atom document icon.
### Versions

1.6.0
You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.
Label: enhancement

Title: Add warnings for broken keymappings definitions
Body:
Atom seems to be missing any kind of warning when a certain class of mistakes slip into the `keymap.cson` file. For example:

``` cson
'atom-text-editor.vim-mode-plus:(.insert-mode)':
  'ctrl-w h': 'window:focus-pane-on-left'
  'ctrl-w l': 'window:focus-pane-on-right'
'atom-text-editor':
  'alt-k': 'editor:move-line-up'
  'alt-j': 'editor:move-line-down'
'atom-text-editor.vim-mode-plus:not(.insert-mode)':
  'tab': 'vim-mode-plus:move-to-pair'
  'y s': 'vim-mode-plus:surround'
  'y s w': 'vim-mode-plus:surround-word'
  'D s': 'vim-mode-plus:delete-surround'
  'c s': 'vim-mode-plus:change-surround'
  'D s': 'vim-mode-plus:delete-surround-any-pair'
  'c s': 'vim-mode-plus:change-surround-any-pair'
# ...
```

will fail to load any of the keybindings in the file. Can you spot why? I spent a considerable amount of time uninstalling, and reinstalling packages, and then adding parts of the `keymap.cson` file selectively in order to figure out that I had forgotten the `not` before the paranthesis.

This could have avoided by either having Atom either:
- report some sort of warning 
- or have Atom fail silently _only_ for the failing selector (hope that's the right term), instead of the whole file.
Label: enhancement

Title: Uncaught TypeError: patch.getChanges is not a function
Body:
1. Was working on (existing, gfm) document for some time
2. Error occurred on hitting enter (not for the first time)

Now every time causes this error. ~~Pasting (or vim putting) a `\n` character is fine, though; it's the actual keypress that is triggering a (attempted) call to `patch.getChanges`.~~ (That seemed to be true for a while; no longer the case.)

It's now also happening with other characters; mostly space.

Seemingly related (I imagine - without looking at the source - it needs the result of `getChanges`) the cursor is now positioned _after_ e.g. a closing paren, rather than inside the pair, on typing an open.

Title: Assertion Failed Error on Git repos with missing path
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

If a git repo has a missing submodule path (compared to what's set up in git), Atom throws assertion errors.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a git repo
2. Include a submodule
3. Delete the submodule path from your working tree, but don't really "remove" the submodule
4. Open the project directory in Atom

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

A usable Atom

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Atom throws C++ "Assertion Failed" errors repeatedly, and throws uncaught errors in console:

```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Failed to resolve path 'C:\path\to\submodule\dir': The system cannot find the file specified.



    at Error (native)
```

![screenshot 2016-03-17 19 53 53](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/165937/13872651/51ab7132-eca9-11e5-8703-d82f45fc3a7a.png)
### Versions

apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.3
git 2.7.1.windows.1
visual studio 2013
Label: bug

Title: Atom 1.7.0-beta0 fails to open from dock

Since Atom 1.7.0-beta0, Atom fails to open when initiated from the dock (Mac). It seems to work fine when opened from the terminal.

When called from the dock, a debugger window appear with the traceback

Title: Show closing brace/tag when folding code blocks for clarity
Label: enhancement

Title: Finding MarkerLayers after they are created
Body:
I'm looking to access the `MarkerLayer` created by another package in my own package. It appears that when `MarkerLayer`s are created, they are assigned an `id`, but there doesn't appear to be a way to find a specific `MarkerLayer` via its current `id` without knowing the `id`.

Can we get a way to access (non-default) `MarkerLayers` outside of our own packages once they are created?
Label: enhancement

Title: Move font settings into a single group so they are displayed together
Body: ### Prerequisites - [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)? - [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide. ### Description The "Line Height" setting has a significant visual separation from the "Font Size" and "Font Family" settings when people will often want to change them in concert with each other: ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Launch Atom 2. Open Settings view with Cmd+, on OS X or Ctrl+, on other platforms 3. Scroll down so "Font Size" and "Line Height" both appear in the same screen **Expected behavior:** "Line Height" to immediately follow "Font Size" **Actual behavior:** Large visual separation (see picture above) ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.7.0-dev-4798d6d Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 ``` ### See Also - #11151
Label: enhancement

- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The `atom` module can no longer be required in a task created using the `Task` class. It breaks the `fuzzy-finder` as well as any other packages that uses core classes from that module (like the `Emitter` or the `Disposable` classes).

For instance, when running in safe mode, the `fuzzy-finder` package is failing with: 

```
Cannot find module 'atom' Error: Cannot find module 'atom'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:338:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:289:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:366:17)
    at require (module.js:385:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/fuzzy-finder/lib/load-paths-handler.js:12:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/fuzzy-finder/lib/load-paths-handler.js:180:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:425:26)
    at Object.defineProperty.value [as .js] (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:208:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:313:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:366:17)
    at require (module.js:385:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js:110:13)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js:112:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:425:26)
    at Object.defineProperty.value [as .js] (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:208:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:313:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:366:17)
    at require (module.js:385:17)
    at [eval]:2:1
    at Object.exports.runInThisContext (vm.js:54:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> ([eval]-wrapper:6:22)
    at Module._compile (module.js:425:26)
    at node.js:602:27
    at doNTCallback0 (node.js:443:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:372:13)(anonymous function) @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:52
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:52 Cannot read property 'bind' of null TypeError: Cannot read property 'bind' of null
    at process.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js:82:23)
    at emitTwo (events.js:87:13)
    at process.emit (events.js:172:7)
    at handleMessage (internal/child_process.js:686:10)
    at Pipe.channel.onread (internal/child_process.js:440:11)(anonymous function) @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:52
```

I suspect this is a bug and was not an intended change, but if it was I may point out that this will likely break a lot of packages and should trigger a major version bump.
### Versions

```
> atom --version
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-579b6b7
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: bug

Title: Cycling through windows still not working on French keyboard
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? 
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

As initially reported in #10852 and fixed in #10927, but with `cmd-backtick` as keybinding, using a French keyboard layout (AZERTY). 
The command no longer cycles through the open Atom windows. 
I'm using a modified french layout to remove the backtick dead-key, but I have the same behaviour when using the original layout.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open several Atom windows
2. Use `cmd-backtick` to cycle through them

**Expected behavior:** It should cycle through the open windows.

**Actual behavior:** It stays on the current window.
### Versions

Title: All views (pane?) and tabs are not really visible (very small width)
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Currently, I have one project (folder) that open views with a very limited width, see screenshots below (taken in SAFE MODE).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open [my setup repo](https://github.com/MoOx/setup) (not sure if that's related to some local cache). **Note that this only happen in this folder** (from what I see), didn't find any other yet).
2. Open a new document (cmd+n) or about or settings page

**Expected behavior:** Normal (full) view width, with correct tab visibility

**Actual behavior:** View/tabs are not visible as they used to be

_Screenshots taken in safe mode_

![screen shot 2016-03-13 at 06 34 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/157534/13727146/fff9d3da-e8e6-11e5-8e4e-088105cffdf5.png)
![screen shot 2016-03-13 at 06 35 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/157534/13727148/0002249a-e8e7-11e5-9b6a-9253f1e60c00.png)
![screen shot 2016-03-13 at 06 35 12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/157534/13727147/fffd3ec6-e8e6-11e5-8082-72c0951ce0c3.png)

Here is a detailed view. I don't see anything that might take some space here

![screen shot 2016-03-13 at 06 47 01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/157534/13727163/7aeae02a-e8e7-11e5-931a-b29ef82121f3.png)

Is there a way I can find some local cache about the opened folder to see if that can fix the issue?
**I previously installed nuclide**, so maybe that is related ?
This bug did not happened when I installed nuclide, but some days after, after I changed some nuclide  config. I disabled nuclide and a lot of plugin, reverted my atom config (from the one versionned in setup repo) and still have the issue in safe mode.
### Versions

? atom --version
1.5.4

? apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.2
Label: bug

Title: Atom Crashes on Windows 10 (Every Time)
Body:
![atom-error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5718820/13702476/dcbf04f0-e786-11e5-9917-a351d9aafedd.jpg)
In the last week or so Atom has stopped working on my Windows 10 machine. I use the same packages/extensions as on my mac machine and that's working fine, so I don't think it's a package problem.

The Editor loads but appears blank. Once I resize the window the black editor screen appears along with the tabs of opened files from my last session/project. But nothing responds.
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)
  Yes it happens in Safe Mode. Here's the output:

[http://resource-centre.net/files/atom-error.jpg](http://resource-centre.net/files/atom-error.jpg)
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
  Yes.
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
  I can't load any of the config screens, but the menus appear.
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
  I think so.
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
  Yes, different people have different causes/solutions.

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

[Description of the bug or feature]
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [First Step]
   Load Atom in Windows. 10
2. [Second Step]
   Nope that's it!
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The last project opens and I can get on with work.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The screen is blank until I resize it, then the tabs/editor appears but nothing's clickable and no menus work. They appear but clicking a menu item does nothing.
### Versions

1.5.4
You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.
Label: bug

Title: Selection.onDidChangeRange callbacks do not get an event passed
Body: According to [the docs](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.5.4/Selection#instance-onDidChangeRange), a callback should get an `event` as argument. However, [Atom doesn't do this](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.5.4/src/selection.coffee#L784).
Label: bug

Title: Atom should provide a tabbed panel system
Body:
Currently atom does not have a panel (tool window) layout manager ( ref docs https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.5.4/Panel ).

I use follow packages they all provide a panel:
- https://github.com/noseglid/atom-build by @noseglid.
- https://github.com/jeremyramin/terminal-plus by @jeremyramin
- And there is also build-in search package.

When they show up together, I got follow panels stacked and takes up too much space of my screen (Picture 1).

How about a panel layout manager like android studio does (Picture 2), make every panel has its proper place, the features include:
1. Stack panels in tabs.
2. Have at least left and right group of panel tabs (like android studio does in Picture 2).
3. Drag move for manually manage panel group.
4. Panel size, group ... should be saved across atom sessions.

Picture 1: Atom panels are not managed

![panels](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20248/13658366/4a238d30-e6b1-11e5-8e3e-813b9feff3d1.png)

Picture 2: Android Studio panels are managed well

![android-studio-panels](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20248/13658490/53a2976a-e6b2-11e5-9cd6-dfdc428ea39b.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Identical folders are opened as separate projects on case-insensitive filesystems
Body:
### Description

On case-insensitive (but case-preserving) filesystems, opening a project by passing its folder to the `atom` command will not restore the project, if the path given has the wrong case.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a project in Atom with 1 folder (e.g. `~/Foo`).
2. Open some tabs in that project.
3. Close the window.
4. Reopen the project using the `atom` command with a name differing only in case (e.g. `atom ~/FOo`).

**Expected behavior:** Atom restores the previously open tabs for that project.

**Actual behavior:** Atom creates a brand-new project with the wrongly-cased root folder `CApe`, and does not restore the tabs from the original project.
### Versions

OS X.11 x86_64, Atom 1.5.4.
Label: bug

- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Files that have conflicts in them after a failed merge are not detected as modified in the Tree View or Status Bar, but Git Diff shows the changes correctly.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Find a branch that has conflicts with another branch
2. Attempt to merge the two
3. Open a file that has conflicts
4. Observe that the Tree View does not color the file as modified, and the Status Bar also reports no changes

**Expected behavior:** Tree View and Status Bar to detect changes

**Actual behavior:** No changes are detected other than Git Diff
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-8472f91
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

/cc @joshaber here's another one for you!
Label: bug

Title: Atom should warn on non-dev-mode launch when a default-installed package is overridden in ~/.atom/packages
Body: ### Prerequisites - [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? (duplicated packages aren't loaded in Safe Mode) - [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)? - [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide. ### Description Having an additional copy of a default-installed package in `~/.atom/packages` can cause hard-to-diagnose bugs: - https://github.com/atom/git-diff/issues/85 - among others Sometimes having an overridden version of a default-installed package is useful for Atom developers but it seems to be causing problems and frustration for unsuspecting regular users. The proposal here is to show an error notification on launch if Atom is not in Dev or Safe Mode. Something like: ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Install a duplicate Core package (ignore the warning) using `apm install git-diff` 2. Launch Atom **Expected behavior:** A warning to appear **Actual behavior:** No warning is shown ### Versions You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. ``` Atom : 1.7.0-dev-f88051e Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 ```
Label: enhancement

Title: Better selection
Body: Please add in the ability to double click in between quotes and that would select all the text within the quotes instead of the whole line if double click again then the whole line would be highlighted as it does now.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom build env and apm use `ATOM_ACCESS_TOKEN` env var for different things
Body:
Both atom's build process and apm use the `ATOM_ACCESS_TOKEN` environment variable for different things. [Atom's build env](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1d72fc8a455d6fec628a32f05639bb943b916f75/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L255) is looking for a GitHub token, while [apm](https://github.com/atom/apm/blob/9fb023196f1631d5ab2d6375991ee747db5e96d7/src/auth.coffee#L24) is looking for an atom.io token. So if I set it for building, I cant publish packages, and if I set it for publishing, I have trouble building (from scratch for electron donwload; at HQ cause unauth'd API access is saturated).
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-fa6905f
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: bug

Title: Suggestion: Reopen Window in Dev Mode
Body: There's currently an _"Open in Dev Mode..."_ command under the _Developer_ submenu: I can't speak for other developers, but there've been numerous times when I've started working on something Atom-related, and I need to reopen the current project in dev mode. For instance, I'm working on a [language package](https://github.com/Alhadis/language-apl), so I need to see changes to pattern-matching expressions instantly... but stupid me keeps forgetting to open a project in dev-mode before I start working on it. Since I don't usually need to do that. ## What would be ace: A shortcut under _"Open in Dev Mode..."_ called _"Reopen window in dev mode"_ (greyed out if already in dev-mode) that does exactly what that 25-byte sequence implies. I understand this could be achieved with a package, but to be honest, this functionality feels too rudimentary to omit from Atom's core command-set.
Label: enhancement

### Description

### Description

Atom beta hangs when an open file is clobbered and continuously written to
### Steps to Reproduce

```
touch out.txt
atom-beta --safe out.txt
(for i in $(seq 100000); do echo "yyyyyyyyyy"; done) > out.txt
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

atom changes to new file, and continues to work (atom stable does handle this fine)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The two 'atom helper' processes hit > 260% CPU, and stay there. Eventually I am asked if I want to "keep waiting"
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
bash-4.3$ atom-beta --version
a1.6.0-beta6
bash-4.3$ apm-beta --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.2
```

Title: Building Atom Beta releases so they can be installed simultaneously, on the same machine, to stable releases
Body:
Hi,

I realize you's are probably getting sick of me by now, but I was wondering if there is some option one can pass to `script/build` or `script/grunt install` to build Atom beta with different installed file paths, so that Atom beta and Atom stable releases can be installed simultaneously on the same machine. See running `script/build && sudo script/grunt install` in the beta branch of this repo will install Atom in the standard file locations (that are also used by the stable releases of Atom) on Linux platforms, at least, as those used by stable Atom releases. So you will get `/usr/bin/atom`, `/usr/bin/apm`, _etc._ files installed at those exact locations, while the Debian and RPM packages provided by this repo for Atom beta releases will install the same files to `/usr/bin/atom-beta`, `/usr/bin/apm-beta`, _etc._ instead and let Atom stable releases use the aforementioned installed file locations (i.e., `/usr/bin/atom`, `/usr/bin/apm`, _etc._) for their installed files. 

This issue means that presently the `atom-editor` and `atom-editor-beta` PKGBUILDs in the Arch User Repository cannot be installed simultaneously, even though `atom-editor` and `atom-editor-beta-bin` can be installed simultaneously because `atom-editor-beta-bin` builds its package from the Debian binary provided for Atom beta releases. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton
Label: enhancement

Title: Can't open multiple non-text files in Atom 1.7.0-dev-a7e43fe
Body:
@BinaryMuse @kuychaco @nathansobo @lee-dohm Wondering if you could take a look at this one :pray: -- I _think_ it might be related to https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10959.

Here's what the behavior was prior to  #10959 being merged (at 606dc0299c9e8f2a80a0321ef5cdcc89e933012c, in safe mode):

![problem1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/13378484/982fcb62-de08-11e5-901d-9362a3ee53fd.gif)

Notice that I click through several images, and every one of those opens in a separate tab. 

And here's the behavior on latest master (at a7e43fef7a2dd11ad90c691870aac517fd12ced7, in safe mode):

![problem2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/13378523/88569b98-de09-11e5-867d-3d6a4deca62d.gif)

Notice how each image is replaced and I can't have more than one open. This happens regardless of whether I opened the files with a single click or double click, and regardless of whether I double click the tab after opening a file. In other words, I can't seem to open multiple image files currently. This is also seems to be true for other non-text files (e.g. zip archives). For text files, I can get the expected behavior by opening them with a double click.

Reading [this comment](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10959#issuecomment-188920474) by @BinaryMuse, it seems that this behavior might partially be expected. However, I believe users will expect the same behavior for text and non-text files, especially non-text files handled by core packages (e.g. image-view and archive-view). If this isn't something that should be handled in Atom core, I think we should update our packages and possibly warn other package authors about this change and tell them how exactly they should update their packages.
Label: bug

Title: Suggestion: "Smart Tab" behaviour
Body: If somebody asked me to imagine a perfect world, it'd be one where coders used hard tabs for indentation, and spaces to align all code after a non-whitespace character. While this world will never exist, it does illustrate a potentially useful addition to Atom: a fourth tab-type option, which I'm calling _"smart tab"_ for the purpose of this issue: Basically, the editor switches between hard tabs for indentation and spaces depending on whether or not there's a non-whitespace character before the cursor.
Label: enhancement

Title: atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(name) works incorrectly when directory with given name exists in current working directory
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(name) works incorrectly when directory with given name exists in current working directory. 
### Steps to Reproduce

Run the following commands in Developer Tools Console.

``` js
> packageName = atom.packages.getAvailablePackageNames()[42]
< "autocomplete-html"
> atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(packageName)
< "/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/autocomplete-html"
> require('fs').mkdir(packageName)
> atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(packageName)
< "autocomplete-html"
```

**Expected behavior:** Resolved path must be an actual package path.

**Actual behavior:** Resolved path may be a relative path to existing directory.
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
1.5.3
```

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
```
### Proposal

[This line](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3b309792a531fb809d29c6742de956f50b3acec5/src/package-manager.coffee#L173) may be changed to the following:

``` coffee
return name if name !== path.basename(name) and fs.isDirectorySync(name)
```
Label: bug

Body:

Title: Set Chromium log_level To Suppress Chromium Logs
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Currently, the chromium `log_level` is not explicitly set. This means that the `log_level` is implicitly `0`, which is the most verbose setting. We should set [1] the `log_level` to a level [2] that suppresses INFO and WARNING messages, at a minimum.

[1] `app.commandLine.appendSwitch 'log-level', '<SOME VALUE HERE>'`
[2] https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/base/logging.h#292
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch atom from the terminal / command line
2. Observe messages like `[852:0224/093645:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command` and `[2804:0224/093645:ERROR:renderer_main.cc(200)] Running without renderer sandbox`

**Expected behavior:** Show only meaningful log messages when atom is launched from the terminal or command line

**Actual behavior:** Spurious log messages are displayed when atom is launched from the terminal or command line.
### Versions

<= 1.7.0-dev
### See Also
- https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/1905
- https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10950
Label: bug

Title: Darwin: "kernel: file: table is full" / ENFILE: file table overflow
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When opening a few projects, Darwin or Atom run out of file descriptors.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open atom in safe mode (or not in safe mode), and Console.app to keep an eye on things
2. Open a few Node projects, containing node_modules folders so there are lots of files in the repos
3. Either you get `kernel: file: table is full` in Console.app or `ENFILE` errors in Atom

**Expected behavior:** Atom should only open the files that it needs, hard to imagine it needs so many that the kernel stutters.

**Actual behavior:** System becomes unstable, needed to reboot
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
$ atom --version
1.5.3
$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.0
```
Label: bug

Title: ELSE error when running Atom commands through the command prompt
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] ~~Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?~~ - Not applicable
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When running certain `atom` commands through the command prompt, the following error will be displayed:

``` cmd
'ELSE' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open `cmd.exe`
2. `atom --test` or `atom --version` or `atom --help` or `atom --foreground`...looks like everything but `atom`, `atom --dev`, and `atom --safe` will reproduce.
3. Observe above error

**Expected behavior:** Program to run without errors

**Actual behavior:** See above error
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
'ELSE' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-e39d200
Electron: 0.36.7
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
Label: bug

Title: UNKNOWN error when saving files
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When saving a file after the first time, Atom throws an UNKNOWN error:

```
Unable to save file 'C:\Users\username\Documents\GitHub\markdown-preview\lib\markdown-preview-view.coffee'
UNKNOWN: unknown error, open 'C:\Users\username\Documents\GitHub\markdown-preview\lib\markdown-preview-view.coffee'
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open file
2. Save for the first time
3. Save for the second time

**Expected behavior:** File to save successfully each time

**Actual behavior:** The file saves on the first time but on subsequent tries throws the above UNKNOWN error until the computer is restarted.  The backups of the original file get successfully created.

Additional info: After the initial save, it seems like Atom locks the file, and any other programs are unable to save either.  Notepad++ will error on attempting to save _until Atom is closed_, at which point it will be able to save the file.  This started happening Saturday.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
'ELSE' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-e39d200
Electron: 0.36.7
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

(Also note the ELSE error, which I'll be reporting separately shortly after this)
Label: bug

Title: Make non-standard line-endings more visible (stylable)
Body:
Could it be possible to make more visible lines ending who aren't the line ending by default?
In the status bar, on the left of the LF/CRLF/Mixed, I could see a warning icon or the text in red . (yes Mixed would be always with a warning)
And make in color: red; (or whatever easily seen) and always visible in the file each EOL who aren't the line ending by default.

I often receive file with which I have to work from many source. And they aren't always well formed. If Atom could warn me when it happen and where, I could more easily correct it or ask for the sender to correct it by pointing the error.

You can see https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector/issues/23 my first issue on this matter. With an answer from Lee dohm who is a good start.

But that means having all invisible, visible. Not only the one who are an issue.
Label: enhancement

Title: syntax themes: rendering issues with fontsizes > 100%
Body:
![ppc_lineissue2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1710598/13176596/c362319a-d713-11e5-9896-a94048b5106b.png)

Defining a fontsize of more than `100%` for a certain css scope, such as `.heading-1` results in several rendering issues:
- Displaced lines, resulting in overlaps.
- gutters and cursor height does not match the actual line size / font height
- Bigger fontsized lines don't _soft wrap_ properly

This is no new issue and it's possibly difficult to prevent, as a lot depends on measuring lines heights etc. and having different sized characters certainly won't make it easier.
Some issues, such as a displaced cursor have been fixed previously eg. via https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8811, but the above ones still exist, that's why I decided opening this issue to collect thoughts and to link connected issues here.
If those issues were nonexistant, some interesting/useful things would be possible in syntax themes.

Some discussion has happened here: https://github.com/nylki/pen-paper-coffee-syntax/issues/20
Label: bug

Title: Splitting/Closing panes results in crash
Body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [?] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

```
Error:Pane has been destroyed
    at Pane.module.exports.Pane.activate (C:\Users\XXXXXX\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\pane.js:631:15)
    at Pane.module.exports.Pane.focus (C:\Users\XXXXXX\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\pane.js:207:21)
    at atom-pane.<anonymous> (C:\Users\XXXXXX\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\pane-element.js:50:23)
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start with only one pane
2. On the pane: Right click > Split Left
3. On the right pane: Right click > Split Down
4. On the left pane: Right click > Close Pane
5. On the upper pane: Right click > Split Down
6. On the lower pane: Right click > Close Pane

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
1. After step 5: There are supposed to be three horizontal panes
2. After step 6: There are supposed to be two horizontal panes (the two upper ones)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
1. After step 5: There are (still) only two panes
2. After step 6: The pane is not closed properly (the tab bar remains or the "empty" background is shown)
### Version

1.5.3 (atom-windows.zip) on Windows 7
Label: bug

Title: Tooltips do not appear/disappear correctly.
Body: If you (on Mac) command+tab to Atom, and your cursor just happens to land on a tab, the blue hover dialog pops up. This is distracting and hovers should only ever be triggered if the mouse _stopped_ on a hover target.

Title: Create `atom` Babel Preset
Body:
By creating an `atom` babel preset that core and packages can use, we introduce the possibility for slowly dialing back the number of transforms required during transpilation as the version of node bundled in Electron progresses.

It also provides a vector for possible optimizations to be introduced across all atom packages using babel, by writing new transforms focused on performance.

Related to #10860.
Label: enhancement

Title: Update CI To Node 5.x
Body:
#9627 introduces Chrome 47 and Node 5.1.1. It would be nice to have CI match the node version bundled with Electron.

Given that:
- Electron bundles node
- Electron doesn't only use stable node, it tries to track v8
- Atom is comprised of Electron, core code, bundled packages, and npm modules
- apm is really just a wrapper around `npm`

Then I think we should formulate a strategy to:
- Try to lock in the same version of node in CI for core, bundled packages, and npm packages
- Try to use the same npm version bundled with the aforementioned version of node in apm
- When specifying node versions in CI, try to lock to the major / minor, but allow later patch versions (e.g. `~5.1.1`, as opposed to `5` or `^5.1.1`)

The goal of this would be to try to be somewhat deterministic in the builds, but this is somewhat dependent on the core Atom build servers being upgradeable, as releases are still generated there.

Doing this consistently would also have the side effect of allowing us to establish an `atom` babel preset, that can be used to slowly dial back the transforms required during transpilation as the version of node continues to progress and more ES6 functionality is bundled in.
Label: enhancement

Body:
On `master` (41161dd462a1be9073752a34b4809612f933da6e).

This is a regression, presumably introduced by https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/9627.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld

Body:
The new "Recent documents menu" in the dock provided by #9606 seems to grow without end, some of them multiple times, ignoring my system setting to never show these menus at all. This is troublesome for me as I normally have forty or more files open at once across a half dozen projects or so:

![screen shot 2016-02-16 at 14 15 55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/881572/13092981/9bdcdbb0-d4b7-11e5-9fab-347c31f3b28d.png)

(Running Atom 1.5.3 on Mac OS X 10.11.)

Title: Error: Cannot find module '../build/Debug/nodegit.node'
Body:
When launching Atom, I get nothing but what appears to be a Chrome JavaScript error page.
![atom_057](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17238705/13039235/2aa28ec8-d362-11e5-8f61-920eb6bbf178.png)

I'm unfamiliar with NodeJS, but it appears to me that perhaps there may be an omission in the [build instructions](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md). It looks like I'm missing something that I need, but what is it?

Title: Missing delete in edit menu
Body:
Hi,

i an copy, paste, copy path from edit dialog. But if i am viewing a file i cant delete it via that menu... please add an delete option which closes the current tab and deletes the file.
Label: enhancement

Title: Improvements on file deletion dialog
Body:
Hi there,

i would to suggest to add a few improvements to the file deletion dialog.
![atomeitordeletedialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16868514/13030065/4576cd64-d29e-11e5-872f-0a4812828373.jpg)

**First:**
if deleting a bunch of files it gets hardly to read... so please put the filenames into a x/y scrollable area.

**Second:**
if I detect a "wrong" filename, i need to cancel the dialog, and search for it in the tree nav... and start deletion again... so please put checkboxes in front of the file name which allows to deselect a file to exclude it from deletion

**Third:**
Add a dialogtitle :) currently the dialog has a blank title bar... 

**Forth:**
The lightbulb indicates a hint... Add an exclamation mark which would indicate a dangerous operation, or a question mark that indicates its a question...

**Fifth:**
Don't switch phrasing... i start the operation with an option that's labelled "delete", i read delete in the dialog text, then i need to "move it to trash" instead of simple "delete" it. Name the button please "Yes, delete" or change wording on action and dialogs. Oh, and i'm about to delete the files... i am not currently deleting them if the dialog is displayed
Label: enhancement

Title: Beta: change value of "name' in package.json (for wm_class)
Body:
In linux, the way that the system knows how to group application icons for their application is via the WM_CLASS property that gets set on the X11 window. In electron, this is set by reading the `"name": "atom"` in the package.json.

I'm proposing, that during a build of beta, this gets changed to `"name": "atom-beta".

Related: https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/atom-editor-beta-bin/?comments=all#comment-532582
Label: enhancement

Title: Trigger event on pane resize
Body:
I don't believe there currently exists an event when a pane is resized?

If it existed, this would facilitate things like scaling content to fit the pane size, as in izuzak/atom-pdf-view#112.

I'm not sure of the implementation, but I'd suggest this could be added to [PaneResizeHandleElement#resizeStopped](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/8fb4e887df800438b2deeb23a2c23004b9ff358a/src/pane-resize-handle-element.coffee#L28-L31):

``` coffee
resizeStopped: ->
    document.removeEventListener 'mousemove', @resizePane
    document.removeEventListener 'mouseup', @resizeStopped
```
Label: enhancement

Title: findOrCreateBottommostSibling not working as expected
Label: bug

Title: Spawn/ENOENT thrown if the app is moved while it is open
Body: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9594 is a good example of this.
Label: bug

Title: Feature Request: Open project from within Windows Libraries view
Body: I just noticed that when attempting to open a project that also shares a location within a Windows Libraries location (Windows 7 in this case) a context menu option to open with Atom is not present when selecting within the directory area (blank space in the right pane). I'm fairly certain this is either something overlooked or possibly due to the way Windows treats these directories as symbolic links. Right clicking for the context menu option for a directory within the tree view for a project presents the "Open with Atom" context option, just within the right pane it does not.
Label: enhancement

Title: Moved/renamed files (via tree view) with open tabs not linked anymore after operation
Body:
If I have a file open in Atom that I want to rename/move, and use tree view to do this, the tabs of the files lose track of where the file source is, and continuing to edit in the file tab causes the old file to be re-created on save.

Is it possible to have tree view inform the tab package of the file rename/move somehow, so that the source of the tab is updated and we can keep editing the file?

Having to close the tab and reopen it for the new file seems a bit 1990's :)

Possibly related: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9875
Although I would not propose to close the file buffers, just point them to the right folder/files again.

Maybe this is not something that's normal/common in Windows apps, but on Mac it's pretty common. Any file that I'm editing, I can just move it around or rename it freely, and any app using the file will still have a pointer to the correct file location.
Label: bug

Title: Tooltips on tabs show at incorrect times.
Body: If you command+tab switch to Atom from another application, and your mouse just happens to be on top of a tab (GUI Tab at the top of the screen), then the tooltip appears showing the file name. This should not be the case. The tooltip should only show if you explicitly moved your mouse onto the tab (or in the tab) and stopped moving on the tab.
Label: bug

Title: Command+a is picked up by editor while typing in the help search field
Body: While editing a file, attempting to select search text in the _Help_ menu bar item (using `cmd+a`) closes the menu and instead selects all text in the editor pane.
Label: bug

Title: Invisibles hard tab after indent is misleading
Body:
I've just noticed that hard tab after indents shows a tab invisible followed by however many space invisibles which is normally blank. I assumed it was being smart with space insertion, but upon opening the file in another text editor, they are in fact tabs with no spaces.

Example:

``` JS
->  ->  test->..->..
```

The space invisibles should not be rendered. That said I'd really like it if there was a way to insert soft tabs after indents and use hard tabs for indents, at first I thought this rendering issue was a feature improvement :P

Atom 1.4.3
Antergos(Arch Linux)
Label: bug

Title: Alt + menu hotkey doesn't work, closes menu on Windows
Body:
When trying to save a file by hitting the key sequence: alt+f alt+s the menu closes and the file does not save.

In every other Windows application I tested, this works. This is done to compensate when typing alt+f s quickly, the release of the alt key does not register before the s key is pressed, or the user does not release it in time.

It is expected that opening the menu, then pressing the hotkey OR alt+hotkey should trigger the action, as this behavior is present in virtually every other Windows application.
Label: bug

Title: Restored window size set to maximized after exiting maximized
Body:
When I exit Atom and window state is restored, its size is remembered; so when I start Atom again, the window starts restored and remembers its size. However, when I exit Atom maximized, the restored window size is set to maximized size; so when I start Atom again, it start maximized and when I click restore, the window size remains just the same (maximized size).

Simply said, nonmaximized window is too often set to maximized size and is just too big to normaly drag around and I have to manually resize window to smaller size each time.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Exit Atom maximized
2. Start Atom again and click "restore window"
3. The window size is same as maximized

**Expected behavior:**

Restored window size should be remembered correctly, so you can actually restore window to its last size, not restore it to maximized size.

**Observed behavior:**

I am unable to test this on different OS than Windows 10. I think it's not Electron bug, since VS Code behaves correctly. The reason why this bothers me is that I can't just grab maximized window and drag it, because it's size is same as maximized (= just too big for dragging around screen).

**Screenshots and GIFs**

![output_qijguj](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6060970/12868449/857bc078-cd07-11e5-9b7b-768d7669e253.gif)

**Atom version:** 1.4.3
**OS and version:** Windows 10

**Installed packages:**

minimap

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: No
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes
Label: bug

Title: Graphical glitches that occur under Arch Linux
Body:
Hi,

I have noticed that Atom 1.4.3 (have not noticed this issue with earlier releases of Atom) keeps experiencing graphical glitches, wherein tab titles, the toolbar and file windows become invisible or otherwise visually obstructed. Now to be clear by "file windows" I mean the windows (under the tab handles) wherein the contents of the file being edited is shown and can be edited, if my terminology is incorrect please correct me so that in future I can use the correct terminology when reporting Atom issues. In case my explanation is unclear I have taken screenshots of these bugs. These bugs seem to be plugin-independent as running Atom in safe mode makes no difference to these bugs. 

In this first example, you can see the second tab is partially obstructed in its view from the glitch.

![](http://imgur.com/a9IO6Sn.png)

In this second example, you can see parts of the file window and the left and centre tabs obstructed in their view:

![](http://imgur.com/a31M6oZ.png)

I know that some things seem to trigger its appearance, like scrolling down on larger files, switching between presently-opened windows, _etc._ If you want to know how I installed Atom well I installed it from my own PKGBUILD (which builds the Atom package from source code not from a Debian or RPM binary) which you can find [here](https://github.com/fusion809/PKGBUILDs/blob/master/atom-editor/PKGBUILD). I have observed this bug under two different desktop environments: Cinnamon and KDE Plasma 5 and with several different GTK themes. 

Oh and yes these bugs seem to be limited to just Atom. All other programs seem to be devoid of this bug. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton
Label: bug

Title: Proposal: API enhancement for editors with block decorations
Body:
I fiddled with the block decoration features to check how this would affect the minimap and as I suspected it completely breaks the sync between the two views.

The biggest concern I have for the moment is that there is no public API to get the height and the y position of a line with a block decoration attached. Since I guess these are quite costly operations that are already handled by the editor's view I would expect it to expose these informations publicly so that we don't need to traverse all the editor's layers and decorations to compute these values. 

Another approach would be to have two sets of scroll values, one that account for the decorations and one that doesn't. For instance with a block decoration of 100px height at one line, the first method would return a scroll height equal to the height of all lines + 100 and the other one would return the just the height of all lines. Same goes for the scroll position, the first one would returns the scroll as it's used in the view, the other one would return the scroll position ignoring the block decoration (clamping the value to the start/end y of the line depending on whether the block is displayed before or after the line).

A third possibility is to have a scroll position defined as a couple of value: the first visible line index and a position within the line (in the range 0-1). If we have access to the line y position and height through an API, we can compute the corresponding scroll top, or map this to any other type of grid and still be in complete sync with the editor.

Another concern for the minimap is that block decorations breaks the assumption that an editor's lines all fit on a predefined grid. It means that I can no longer use a ratio to transpose a line height and position and still get an integer value at the end - let say a line takes 17px in the editor, and 3px in the minimap, I can always assume that line 11 will be at y=30px in the minimap. Now with block decorations, a line can have an arbitrary height, which means that if I apply this ratio to get the line height I'll probably end up with a decimal value. And as the minimap is using a canvas, decimal values need to be avoided at all cost to preserve the crispness of the minimap render. To workaround that I would probably need to map every line heights from the editor to a rounded value more suited to the minimap. But same thing here, it would better if I could avoid traversing all the editor's lines to make this computations. 

How do you feel about this?

cc/ @nathansobo, @as-cii
Label: enhancement

Title: atom is ignoring files that shouldn't be ignored
Body:
atom is ignoring files that begin with a `test_` for me on Mac. eg. `test_function.js`. These files are greyed out in the tree-view sidebar, and my linter isn't linting these files.

If i go to atom -> packages -> tree-view -> settings, and check "hide VCS ignored files", `test_function.js` disappears from tree-view side bar.

Neither the `.gitignore` in the repo nor my `~/.gitignore_global` has have anything that matches `test_*`. I ran git check-ignore in the working directory to see what rules git was applying from where.

```
$ git check-ignore -v *
<user>/.gitignore_global:7:**/_*    _tmp
.gitignore:1:node_modules/  node_modules

$ git status
On branch master
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/master'.
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

    test_function.js
```

Curiously, git status _is_ tracking the same file.

It seems that there isn't anything that would cause `test_*` to be ignored by atom, yet it is. The effect seems to be global. I've tried adding similar files to other repos and viewing the directory structure in atom, and atom ignores them everywhere.

Is there anything else I can do to find a cause ?
Label: bug

Title: Make OS X CFBundleIdentifier distinct between stable and beta channels
Body:
On OS X, Atom.app and Atom Beta.app should have different `CFBundleIdentifier`s set in their respective `Info.plist`. Doing so would allow both "Atom" and "Atom Beta" to appear in OS X's Launchpad, among other benefits.

**Current behavior**

The [beta download page](https://atom.io/beta) claims users can have stable channel releases and beta channel releases installed side-by-side. However, both have the same `CFBundleIdentifier` value set in their `Info.plist` file: `com.github.atom`. Because of this, even though the two releases have distinct file names (`Atom.app`, `Atom Beta.app`), parts of OS X can't differentiate between the two apps. 

In particular, only one of the two apps will ever show up in OS X's Launchpad (among other oddities relating to opening files from Finder, setting default file associations, and so on).

**Suggested behavior**

Beta channel releases should have a `CFBundleIdentifier` distinct from stable channel releases, e.g. `com.github.atom-beta`. (It might also be useful to change the identifiers of bundled apps, like `Atom Helper.app`, but I can't personally speak to this one way or another.)

When I manually made this change, I saw both "Atom" and "Atom Beta" appear in Launchpad simultaneously. Both apps seemed to function properly on my cursory checking.

**Atom Version:** stable 1.4.3, beta 1.5.0-beta3
**OS and Version:** Mac OS X 10.11.3, "El Capitan"
Label: enhancement

Body:

What am I supposed to do - retype a long long path character by character (since cut and paste do not work here..) ?

This is hopefully easy to fix but is otherwise a showstopper.

Title: custom entity transformation plugin
Body:
Hi, I'm a heavy wiki user. It would be interesting for me having a **plugin for text transformation**.
All entities listed in a local file (just for clarity, as _entities.local.conf_ in wiki environment configurations)
could be processed to search/replace in the current loaded file, even better if the local file contains a list of regex expressions to process sequentially.
I was thinking this for markdown-like plugins, then I thought a general plugin could be more useful, also for html/xml editing. For source files the output would be saving/updating the transformed file in the project directory. For other plugins (mark-down and other text precessing ones) it could be a further text processing stage (after the standard one), to add user customizations.
Netsaver Paul, Rome
Label: enhancement

Title: On reload, window cascades
Body:
1. Open an atom window
2. Open another atom window
3. Move the windows so one is on the left of the screen, and one is on the right of the screen

Try this in Pages/Numbers/Keynote/TextEdit. This should be possible in Atom.

Title: apm test/atom --dev --test displays wrong file names
Body:
How to reproduce this bug:
1. Open a package or create a new one.
2. Run `apm test`. If you created a new package with package-generator, the specs will fail and display an error like `Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20)`.
3. Rename `spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee` (I renamed it to `testing-package-view2-spec.coffee`).
4. Run `apm test` again.

The specs fail (as expected), but instead of showing the new file path, it shows the old one.

I assume this is a caching issue, because clearing `~/.atom/compile-cache` fixes the bug for me.

```
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20)


Finished in 0.306 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ mv spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee spec/testing-package-view2-spec.coffee 
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20) <--Wrong path


Finished in 0.185 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ rm ~/.atom/compile-cache -R
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view2-spec.coffee:5:20)


Finished in 0.316 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ atom -v
1.4.1-2cf2ccb
$ apm -v
apm  1.5.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.1
git 2.6.4
```

Title: Temp files are created on Samba shares that aren't deleted on close, can't be deleted manually, and are only deleted upon unmounting the share
Body:
Atom 1.4.0 on OS X 10.10.5.  The Samba share is on Windows 7 SP1.

I didn't see this behavior in 1.3.x.

Repro:
1.  Edit a plain text file on a Samba share.
2.  (Atom creates a `.tmp` file in the same directory.  Sometimes.  Not always.  I don't know the repro steps to force it to do so.  "Back Up Before Saving" is off, so this must be some kind of special temp file.)
3.  Close the tab for the plain text file.  Temp file isn't deleted.
4.  Close Atom.

Expected:

Atom deletes the temp file.

Actual:

Atom doesn't delete the temp file.  The file can't be deleted either via Finder in OS X or via Windows Explorer on the Windows box where the Samba share resides.

Finder gives the error "The operation can’t be completed because an unexpected error occurred (error code -8072)."

Windows Explorer says that the deletion can't complete without administrative rights and shows the elevation dialog.  Elevating doesn't help: another dialog is displayed saying that the file can't be deleted.  (I didn't capture the exact error text of the dialog.)  Attempting to take ownership of the file via `takeown` and modifying its ACLs via `icacls` fail:

```
> takeown /s MYBOXNAME /u MYBOXNAME\MyUsername /f . /r

WARNING: User credentials cannot be used for local connections.
ERROR: The current logged on user does not have ownership privileges on
       the file (or folder) "E:\work\current".

> icacls . /grant MYBOXNAME\MyUsername:f /t
processed file: .
processed file: .\notes.txt
.\notes.txt~RF449e304.TMP: Access is denied.
Successfully processed 2 files; Failed processing 1 files

>
```

`handles.exe` v3.46 (a Sysinternals tool by Mark Russinovich) shows that System has open handles on the temp file.

The temp file only gets deleted when the Samba share is unmounted from OS X.

Multiple temp files may be created, so reference above to "the temp file" are also applicable to "the temp files".  Again, I'm not sure under what circumstances Atom creates them, but the end result is that heavy Atom work on a Samba share leaves un-deletable temp files scattered about which screw up directory diffs, syncing directories, moving things around, uploading directories to other places, deleting directories that are no longer needed, recursively adding directories to source control, etc. etc. etc., and force an unmount and remount to resolve.
Label: bug

Title: editor:*-to-next-word-boundary commands can't cross CRLF line boundary on OS X
Body:
Atom 1.4.0 on OS X 10.10.5.

`editor:move-to-next-word-boundary` and `editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary` will not move/delete across a CRLF line boundary on OS X.  I haven't tested on other platforms.

`editor:*-to-previous-word-boundary` work fine.

This is a fairly recent regression, as the commands worked properly in 1.3.x.

FWIW, #7662 - "ctrl-delete does not remove CRLF" - was closed after PR https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/9937 landed in early December 2015.  That change was released with 1.4.0-beta0.  I haven't done a `git bisect` - but that could potentially be a place to start looking.
Label: bug
