Title: apm test Fails on Windows
Body:
This has to have been already reported, but I can't seem to find it...

When running on Windows it seems that `apm test` will report that the tests failed regardless of the actual state of the tests.

For example if the spec consists entirely of this:

``` CoffeeScript
describe "Test package", ->
  it "has one valid test", ->
    expect(true).toBe true
```

Running `apm test` on that produces the following output:

```
PS C:\Users\Landon\github\test> apm test
[48536:1024/140634:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(185)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[48536:1024/140634:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(185)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[48536:1024/140634:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(185)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[48536:1024/140634:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(185)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[49320:1024/140634:INFO:renderer_main.cc(200)] Renderer process started
[48536:1024/140636:INFO:CONSOLE(46)] "Window load time: 1020ms", source: file:///C:/Users/Landon/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.0.19/resources/app.asar/static/index.js (46)
.

Finished in 0.079 seconds
1 test, 1 assertion, 0 failures, 0 skipped


Tests failed
```

I have seen this behavior on Windows 8.1 x64, Windows 10 x64, and Windows Server 2012 R2 (AppVeyor), all on Atom 1.0.19. The exact same tests work perfectly fine on Linux and OS X builds.

If there is any further information you need please let me know.
Label: bug

Title: Editor:move-to-end-of-word does not move beyond end of line if CRLF line ends in file
Body:
I am on windows 7 64bit, running atom version v1.0.19, I have reset my atom config to make sure it is not related to my config and it still exhibits this behaviour.

For keystroke ctrl-right which maps to editor:move-to-end-of-word, it will not move the cursor beyond the end of any line it is on if the file ending is CRLF terminated. If I convert the file to LF termination it then works as I would expect and will move to end of the next word on the next line appropriately.

I checked ctrl-left mapped to editor:move-to-beggining-of-word and it works and moves off start of the current line to previous line without a problem.
Label: bug

Title: Weird scrollbar behavior on OS X
Body:
It almost seems as if the hide/show logic for the scrollbars is inverted somehow; initially when loading Atom, no scrollbar is visible (as expected), upon scrolling no bar shows up. Then when scrolling stops , the scrollbar suddenly appears even though it should now be hidden.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Build Atom from master (also present in beta).
2. Open some file that allows scrolling, but do not scroll. Verify that there's no scrollbar visible.
3. Begin scrolling. Most likely no scrollbar will appear, but when you stop scrolling, one will likely appear.
4. Scroll once more and the scrollbar (if visible) will most likely go away.
5. Repeat ad infinitum.

I have the `editor.scrollPastEnd` option set to `true`, and running OS X 10.11.1.

I'm also experiencing scenarios when it doesn't show up at all.
Here's a screen recording where I'm attempting to illustrate what's happening. It almost seems as if it's showing up every other time. Although it also seems almost random at times.

![weird_scrolling](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3622/10704972/d055eea0-79da-11e5-8181-e810c96adf1b.gif)

In summary, a bit hard to explain, but easily reproduced. I'm checking stable now to see if the problem is present there as well. Either way, I'll probably start bisecting to figure out when this regression was introduced.
Label: bug

Title: `atom.workspace.open()` with `split: 'left'` does nothing when a single pane is visible
Body: I would expect splitting left to match the behavior of splitting to the right, but instead it opens items in its own pane emulating `split: undefined`.
Label: enhancement

Title: File auto reloading with untracked git files during branch change
Body:
Firstly:
Atom 1.0.19
Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS

The file buffer autoloading fails to load changes from `git stash pop`s on files that didn't exist in the previous branch you were on.  That's kind of a confusing sentence so I'll elaborate.  In this repo https://github.com/acb/Atom-Test there is a branch `master` with the file `master.txt` in it.  There is also a branch `dev` that has a file `dev.txt` in it that does not exist in `master`.

Now perform the following steps (leaving `dev.txt` open in Atom the entire time):
1. `git checkout dev`
2. Alter `dev.txt` in some way
3. `git stash` -- changes in `dev.txt` are stashed and the buffer in Atom changes appropriately
4. `git checkout master`
5. `git checkout dev`
6. `git stash pop` -- changes in `dev.txt` are `pop`ped to disk, but the buffer in Atom **does not** update

No errors are shown in the console.

If this goes undected by the user they could accidentally save `dev.txt` and blow away their stashed changes without any warning.  The solution as of now is to close the file (and DON'T SAVE CHANGES when prompted) and reopen.  In Sublime Text in this situation you get a prompt stating that the file changed on disk and asking you if you would like to reload.

Attached is a gif of the behavior.  Please let me know if I can provide any more information, and feel free to use the repo linked above for any testing you may need.

![atom-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4690898/10678022/bcda2682-78dd-11e5-830e-c29b223c1763.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Add an option on atom-text-editor to make it read-only
Body:
Currently in Nuclide, we create a subclass of `TextEditor` named `ReadOnlyTextEditor` to try to make a read-only version:

https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/1fdf2b98/pkg/nuclide/ui/atom-text-editor/lib/ReadOnlyTextEditor.js
1. This is pretty hacky and tough to maintain because it's hard to be sure that we have blocked off all reasonable entry points that could mutate things.
2. Currently on master, the new refactoring of `TextEditor` that frowns on using the constructor directly and strongly pushes for the use of `atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()` breaks our existing use of `extends TextEditor` in implementing `ReadOnlyTextEditor`.

We can work around this using a new hack (will link once the diff is up), but it would be nice to have proper support for this in Atom. We use `TextEditor` in a number of places as a UI element to show things like console logs.

I'll try to put up my own fix for this when I get a chance, but I'm filing this to have a placeholder for now.

/cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld
Label: enhancement

Title: --profile-startup flag doesn't record a profile when launching Atom for the first time with no path
Body:
More context here: https://github.com/atom/docs/pull/136#issuecomment-149606128

@kevinsawicki mentioned:

> Hmm, I wonder if the timeout needs to be bumped in https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/806b46bb6c981f110a34ed20f566de50288900d0/static/index.js#L143-L145
> 
> There seemed to be issues in past Electron versions where you needed to wait a bit to start profiling after the devtools opened event fired.

I tried bumping the timeout to 500ms and that did fix the problem for me. But I'm not sure what a good timeout would be so opening this to track the issue.

cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo
Label: bug

Title: Possible memory leak w/ cut & paste operations.
Body:
As suggested in issue #1827, I'm opening a new issue.

I've had to do alot of refactoring recently, which has required a lot of cut and paste. I've had to restart Atom more frequently, leading me to ask "why now?"

When I run a heap dump, the events object seems to just grow and grow, suggesting a leak. I haven't been able to test extensively, but a quick inspection of the events object suggests the text snippet is stored in memory, but never seems to be released. I would expect a cut operation to copy the snippet, but when I cut another snippet of text, I would expect the content of the original cut to be released from memory.

My tests have been pretty unscientific, but suggestive. I am cutting/pasting an average of 40-50 lines of code at a time. When I cut several larger snippets in reasonably quick succession, say 400 lines of code, memory consumption appears to increase more rapidly (and remain high).

I've disabled every 3rd party plugin and several core plugins. Copy/paste appears to work decently... so I've been able to work around things by copying code and deleting it, then pasting it. It's an annoying way to work though a refactor though.

I've also noticed the Atom helper typically reaching 1.9GB according to the activity monitor, but my overall RAM consumption hits 31.2 GB (of 32GB). As soon as I kill the process, it drops to 20GB total consumption.

All of this was primarily experienced on OSX (Mavericks & El Capitan) with an i5 CPU and 32GB of RAM. I've also experienced these issues on my Windows 8.1 laptop (i7 with 12GB RAM) with no change after upgrading to Win 10.

Finally, I do a fair amount of work with Electron and do not see memory issues like this in many of my apps, albeit my text editors are substantially less complex than Atom. I bring this up only because this (to me) suggests an issue with the Atom app, not the underlying Electron platform. 

I hope this helps in some way. It's reaching a point for me personally where I may have to abandon Atom due to sheer lack of productivity with it. I really hope I don't have to do that!
Label: bug

Title: Blurry rendering when switching between Retina/Non-retina screens
Body:
I use Atom on a MBPr (15" Late 2013) plugged into an Apple Thunderbolt Display. When I unplug the external display while Atom is running the editor goes all blurry. And when I plug it back in again I see a weird rendering issue where only the top-left quarter of the editor is rendering.

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 21 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605783/77360c78-772e-11e5-93d0-99784452f44e.png)

_Atom running on an Apple Thunderbolt Display._

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 21 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605844/e829cf14-772e-11e5-8c66-06017cadab20.png)

_Atom on retina display after unplugging the Apple Thunderbolt Display. (The blurriness is most noticable when comparing the text in the window bar and the text in the editor)_

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 22 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605886/3b5a4498-772f-11e5-8c07-fd549a373452.png)

_Atom running on Apple Thunderbolt Display after being disconnected and then re-connected._
## Repro Steps
1. Connect external monitor with different dpi than internal monitor
2. Start Atom
3. Disconnect external monitor
4. Connect external monitor

**Expected:** Atom should transition seamlessly between different DPIs.
**Actual:** Editor is blurry when switching from LDPI screen to HDPI screen and fails completely when transitioning back to LDPI again.
## Versions
- **Atom:**       1.0.19
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.11

---
Label: bug

Title: Pass parameters to Atom commands.
Body:
I was thinking in something like

```
package:command->parameter
```

This way you would be able to run literally any command in Atom.
Imagine the two next examples:

**Git-Plus:**

```
Git-Plus:run-> string*
```

*where string is any git command.

**Terminal-plus**

```
Terminal-Plus:run->string*
```

*where string is any shell command.

This approach is specially powerfull if you think that you can create toolbar buttons using [tool-bar](https://github.com/suda/tool-bar). Imagine a button to compile C# like:

```
Terminal-Plus:run->mcs myproject.cs
```

I don't fully understand the internal architecture of atom. It would be technically possible/logical to do something like that?
Label: enhancement

Title: Enable regular expressions in core.customFileTypes
Body:
Since the functionality of [atom-file-types](https://github.com/execjosh/atom-file-types) is being [absorbed into core](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.0.8) (related to #1718), can we have the ability to specify regular expressions in `config.cson` in the same way also?

For a basic example, with `atom-file-types`, putting `"jsx(inc)?$": "source.js"` will work on both `.jsx` and `.jsxinc` files.
Label: enhancement

Title: F-keys keybindings uppercase/lowercase confusion
Body:
When copying an existing keybinding from the `Settings->Keybindings` Page using the icon:
![copying a keybinding](http://i.imgur.com/0xrRbcX.png)
it pastes like this in the keymap.cson:

``` cson
'body':
  'F11': 'window:toggle-full-screen'
```

However, in order to get my keybinding for a command to work, the `F11` has to be lowercase: `f11`
When it is `F11` it still shows up when typing the command in `CTRL-SHIFT-P` but pressing the key has no effect.
So, summed up:

``` cson
'body':
  'Fxx': 'my:command'
```

does not work, but

``` cson
'body':
  'fxx': 'my:command'
```

does.
Label: bug

Title: VCS ignores not respected when searching inside of a particular project folder
Body:
It seems like the 'included' paths for a search are overriding the VCS ignores in an unexpected way.
#### Repro
1. Enable the `core.excludeVcsIgnoredPaths` config setting.
2. Add two project folders: `atom` and `scandal`
3. Perform a project search for `dependencies` with the `File/Directory Pattern` field set to `scandal`.

The search results will include files in `scandal/node_modules`, even though `node_modules/` is set as ignored in `scandal/.gitignore`. I would expect `scandal/node_modules` to still be skipped, even though I've scoped my search to `scandal`.
Label: bug

Title: File content erased upon save when system ran out of disk space
Body:
# Description

If a disk containing a file being edited with Atom runs out of disk space, atom erases existing file content as well as edit buffer in memory upon attempt to save the file.
# Steps To Reproduce
1. Create a file with atom, add some content to it and save it to disk
2. Fill the disk with something so that you run out of disk space
3. Now in atom, modify the file you created in step 1.
4. Save the file again to store the modifications. As disk is full, atom fails to save the file but erases the existing file content upon save attempt. Atom then automatically refreshes the file content from disk, effectively erasing the file from both memory and disk upon save attempt. There is not way to recover the file content.
# Expected behavior

If there is no space on disk, the save operation should fail, the original file on disk should stay intact and most importantly the edit buffer in memory should stay intact so that the user can save the file to another disk with space
# System and Version Information

Atom 1.0.1.19
Windows 7 x64
Label: enhancement

Title: Fix preview tabs
Body:
_From @benogle on October 15, 2015 22:46_

There have been a lot of issues created related to preview tabs. It seems like nearly all of these issues could be solved by a couple things:
1. Create all tabs as 'permanent' by default and only open in a preview tab in a couple cases:
   - Single clicking in the tree-view
   - Single clicking in project find results pane
   - And eventually (when open files is suuuper fast) opening preview tabs when arrowing through the fuzzy finder
2. Close the preview tab when it loses focus

The issues
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/170
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/206
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/202
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/196
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/180
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/173
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/170
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/164
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/207
- https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/163
- https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/issues/108
## The short term approach

Currently preview-tabs is implemented entirely in the tabs package. When a new pane item is opened, the tabs package closes the old pane item associated with the preview tab, and creates a new tab. So atom core (or other packages) has no idea that there are preview tabs. This is kind of crappy as
- There are hacks in the tabs package to handle things like double clicking in the tree view to make a tab permanent.
- There is no way for other packages to open preview tabs, or even know about them without accessing the tabs package
- Along the same lines, a couple folks want an API, and the only way to provide an API would be to add a service or hack to the tabs package.
  - https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/188
  - https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/185

That said, we could probably do a quick fix to change the default behavior to open a 'permanent' tab, and hack the other packages to open preview tabs in the exceptions listed above.
## The long term approach

A cleaner and more robust approach would be to bake the notion of a preview pane item into atom core. Packages could then decide to open preview items if they so choose. Then there would be no hacks: tree-view and the find results could open a preview item on single click; tabs could watch for preview items and have them all share one tab element.

@nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld not sure how much effort this longer term approach would be. Can you estimate how long it would take to add a new option to `open()` indicating the notion of a preview pane-item + related events?

cc @atom/feedback

_Copied from original issue: atom/tabs#218_
Label: enhancement

Title: Fix auto update UX
Body:
Our automatic update process is pretty bad. We release once a week, and every week over a half million people need to go through this process.

There are [errors](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7854), [bugs](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6482), folks want [better feedback](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8038), and the squirrel icon + release notes are really really confusing:
- https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/511
- https://github.com/atom/release-notes/pull/38
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5692
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6922
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3757
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8265
### What happens now
- Download an [old version](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.0.18)
- Start it
- Notice there is a blue squirrel in the status bar, and it says 'view release notes'
- Click the squirrel
- See the release notes, note that they are showing notes for an old release
- Click the restart and update button
- Atom quits, notice that there is no feedback as to what is happening.
- It's still not back. What's up?
- Atom restarts again after 5 - 15 seconds
- Notice that the release notes are up in the reloaded window. They are still out of date, and still have the 'Restart and Update' button showing and enabled
- Notice that the squirrel icon is still showing, and still blue, with the same tooltip text
- I click the squirrel because it's still there, and not going away. It focuses the release notes. Ok.
- I'm thinking: is there another update??!? What is happening?
- I check the atom menu
  - Click the 'About' item, theres no information saying it's the latest version
  - I notice there is a version number, and a 'Check for update'
  - Nothing indicates I'm at the latest version
- On reload, squirrel goes away; still nothing tells me I'm at the latest version. But no squirrel, so I guess so?
### A 70% fix

tl;dr: fix the squirrel icon, remove the release notes package, use the about package for update status (similar to chrome).
- An update becomes available
- The blue squirrel shows, its tooltip says "Downloading update for version 1.0.20..."
- Clicking the squirrel shows the about page which shows
  - the current version
  - new version detected
  - some text indicating that the update is being downloaded
- When it's finished downloading:
  - the blue squirrel turns green, with a tooltip of "Version 1.0.20 is available"
  - the about page now shows that an update is available, and has a button to restart the editor
  - The menu item now takes you to the about page
- Clicking the green squirrel still shows / focuses the about page
- Clicking reload reloads the editor like today
- On reload the about page is shown.
- The about page indicates that you are up to date, and has a link to the release notes
- The squirrel is _gone_ after reload as the about page has the relevant information

Additionally, take a stab at the bugs:
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7854
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6482

Bonus:
- In the about page, indicate which release rail you are on. beta? stable? development?
### An extra 10%

Add some kind of feedback when atom is reloading. A small window with an infinite spinner would be sufficient. The goal is to indicate that it is working.
### That last 20%
- Add progress to the download in squirrel (cc @joshaber, is this possible today?)
  - Add progress to the menu item in %
  - Add progress to the squirrel icon
    - Could add a progress bar to the tooltip
    - Could make the blue squirrel "fill up" with green as it progresses
- Add an option to turn off automatic downloads in the about page to fix https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1882
Label: enhancement

Title: Allow a new Decoration type to represent ticks on the vertical scroll bar

Title: Multiple applications running simultaneously
Body: Every now an again when I use the `atom` command line tool to open a directory in Atom it starts a new process instead of opening it in the already running process. I don't see any pattern to it, more than that the first time it happens Atom has been running for hours, maybe days. If I just do `atom .` in two different directories after each other it opens in the same process, just as expected. Maybe it's just that I notice it more often when I get back to the computer in the morning or after I haven't used it for a long time, but it seems to happen more frequently in those cases. Here's two Atom processes in my Dock just now, one of them contains the projects I was working in yesterday, and one of them contains a project that I just opened through `atom .`.

Title: Configuration option for text-rendering: optimizeLegibility
Body: Implement a configuration option for `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility` as that is required for ligatures to work. See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3821#issuecomment-146474764
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom and external screens
Body:
I don't know how to describe this accurately, but I will give it a try.

**Background**
I use a laptop with a dock at work to use two extra screens. When connected to the dock I use Atom on an external screen and it works great.

**Problem**
The problem is when I close Atom and disconnect the laptop from my dock and later starts Atom again, it thinks that it's still on the external screen. Normally I just use `Windows`+`Left arrow` key to move the window to the laptop screen, but this do not work. Nothing happens.

The only think that do work is going to full screen mode. If I press `F11` then Atom shows up as expected on my laptop screen, but as soon as I exit full screen mode, Atom disappears to the (now non existent) external screen.
Label: bug

Title: Bad cursor positioning when mixing RTL and LTR characters
Body:
Using RTL characters only works just fine as of the latest Atom version:

![arabic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/10359927/1b30b5a8-6d9d-11e5-8b81-7c195c18c69e.gif)

However, as soon as we add LTR characters _before_ the RTL ones, Atom won't position the cursor _inside_ the RTL text. The following does in fact work just fine:

```
اثر کارآزمودگی test test
```

Whereas the snippet below does not:

```
test test اثر کارآزمودگی 
```

With the new character measurement mechanism we now degrade gracefully, but the cursor can only be placed before and after the arabic text. This _seems_ like a limitation in the `Range` API which gets confused when mixing the two: I think this kinda makes sense 'cause I believe that, in order to provide a full RTL editing experience, we should need to go beyond character measurement.

/cc: @nathansobo @izuzak
Label: bug

Title: Allow grammar to override suggestedIndentForTokenizedLineAtBufferRow
Body:
This would allow languages like Python to provide proper indentation. Current regex approach is not enough to provide proper PEP8 indentation:

``` python
foo = [
    'one', 'two']

bar = ['three',
       'four']


def bazzzz(
        param1,
        param2):
    pass


def icanhaz(bacon,
            cheezburger):
    pass
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Cannot save readonly file
Body:
When trying to save a readonly file I get an error:

```
Unable to save file 
EPERM: operation not permitted, open 'D:\file.h'
```

Atom version: 1.0.19
OS: Windows 7 x64

I'd expect to get a message box reporting about the readonly flag, and asking to overwrite the file anyway or cancel.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom serializes DisplayBuffer scroll position correctly but overwrites it when re-opening workspaces
Body:
Atom serializes the scroll position (`scrollTop` and `scrollLeft`) of each DisplayBuffer, but when you close a project / workspace and re-open it, it fails to restore the scroll position. This happens because the bounds check on `setScrollTop` doesn't have the correct data yet, and clamps every `scrollTop` value to 0:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/stable/src/display-buffer.coffee#L255

I'm not sure exactly what the fix should be:
- Delay applying scroll position until after the editor is attached and bounds are accurate.
- Apply the deserialized scroll position without a bounds check if the bounds are invalid.
- Do a third, better thing.
Label: bug

Title: Migrate from legacy GConf to dconf
Body: Atom relies on the legacy GConf (gconf2) which is deprecated in favour of the new dconf.
Label: enhancement

Title: Warning in specs: Error setting item in object: Validation failed at editor.useShadowDOM...
Body:
Running any package spec produces this warning:

![screen shot 2015-10-02 at 5 12 37 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/10260300/d747734a-6928-11e5-8e95-9fee152d3803.png)

Here's why it's happening:
- `config.set "editor.useShadowDOM", true` is used in the [spec-helper](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/37503b4d03f3f0162738332ff9693641b9ffdd40/spec/spec-helper.coffee#L138)
- true is the default value for this setting, so [`value = undefined if _.isEqual(defaultValue, value)`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/37503b4d03f3f0162738332ff9693641b9ffdd40/src/config.coffee#L835) in config.coffee:setRawValue() is run
- At this point `atom.config.settings.editor.useShadowDOM` is actually set to undefined.
- When the package is loaded, it resets the config schema, and pushes `atom.config.settings` back through the schema validators. **But** `atom.config.settings.editor.useShadowDOM` is `undefined`, which is not a valid value! So warning

Not sure what to do here. I assume the undefined value is supposed to remove the key from the settings, but I dont know the current state of things. @maxbrunsfeld @nathansobo any insight?
Label: bug

Title: Windows Installer icon broken in Win 7
Body:
I downloaded and run the latest atom installer (v1.0.19) from official site, and the task bar icon is broken.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3479453/10239517/5fc9aed6-6901-11e5-9fe1-3b6be8d89be2.png)

Let't me know if there's more information I can provide.
Label: bug

Title: Can't catch unhandled promise rejection
Body:
Since Atom 1.0.18, we can't use

``` js
process.on('unhandledRejection', ...)
```

to catch unhandled rejections.

How to reproduce: in console of latest Atom build, type in 

``` js
setTimeout(function(){Promise.reject(1)}, 100)
```

And verified we get following errors:
![screen shot 2015-10-01 at 1 34 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/837180/10233100/61e53f20-6841-11e5-8942-840cb4a3c90a.png)
whereas It is supposed be something like 
`'Unhandled promise rejection %o with error: %o', promise, error)``
according to https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/0a67cb97298eadd16a1d2fae91f9c40566cb879b/static/index.js#L13
Label: bug

Title: Dialog for read-only files does not go away on Esc
Body: There seems to be some focus issue -- RET or Esc doesn't act on the dialog.
Label: bug

Title: Hitting space before a soft-tab doesn't move cursor but moves content
Body:
I think this is new behavior, so I'm wondering if it's an intentional, but very odd change.

If you have the cursor before a soft-tab and hit space, the cursor won't move but the content following all spaces will.  Until you hit space again then it jumps:

``` js
// Tab-width = 2

|••foo: 42
|•••foo: 42
••|••foo: 42
••|•••foo: 42
••••|••foo: 42
```

Atom 1.0.19
Label: bug

Title: Suggestion: Select Next (CMD + D) Case Insensitivity Option
Body:
I think `Select Next` (`CMD + D`) should respect the case sensitivity option of find and replace.
I.E. if find and replace search is set to case **insensitive**, all the following should be treated the same and selectable by `CMD + D`:

```
FooBar
FooBar

fooBar
fooBar
```

This is how Sublime Text does it and for me it's more useful to have as an option.
Label: enhancement

Title: Consider an `onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem`
Body:
Similar to the motivation behind [`TextEditor::onDidStopChanging`](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.1.0-beta.0/TextEditor#instance-onDidStopChanging),  clients of `onDidChangeActivePaneItem` should nearly always wait for a small time period before acting on the new pane item. If the user is quickly switching through tabs or closing several tabs in quick succession, work done on [`Workspace::onDidChangeActivePaneItem`](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.1.0-beta.0/Workspace#instance-onDidChangeActivePaneItem) is likely wasted and can become a bottleneck for giving feedback to the user if they are switching/closing tabs quickly.

There's at least one candidate in core that could defer its actions until the active item has stopped changing: [`FileInfoView`](https://github.com/atom/status-bar/blob/master/lib/file-info-view.coffee#L71) in the status bar.

Nuclide wrapped `onDidChangeActivePaneItem` to get this effect: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide/atom-helpers/lib/atom-event-debounce.js#L29

I think a `DidStopChangingActivePaneItem` should be recommended similar to the one in `TextEditor` if it's created.
Label: enhancement

Title: [Windows] bash: /dev/tty: No such a device or address
Body:
Hi! I developed a package for atom, and when trying to publish it from windows I get this error:

```
bash: /dev/tty: No such device or address
error: failed to execute prompt script (exit code 1)
fatal: could not read Username for 'https://github.com': No error
```

After running `apm publish minor` from the repo I'm storing the package into. 

Why is this happening?
Label: bug

Title: Consider adding 'editor:remove-last-selection' (& first)
Body: This is a feature request.  This happens to me all the time -- I'm adding cursors on 10 lines and I accidentally go one line too far and there's no keyboard shortcut to remove the last cursor I created.
Label: enhancement

Title: Blurry text when scrolling
Body:
![blur](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/10148101/b620c8e6-65ff-11e5-8d29-450b3450fb47.gif)
It's much easier to see if you open the GIF in a new tab.

Basically what's happening is whenever I select enough text to scoll the editor (ie the scrollbars are moving), the text becomes blurry and stays that way until I scroll a bit out of its range and then back (guessing this has something to do with tiles).  Both horizontal and vertical scrolling are affected.

Also tested in safe mode.  Windows 10 x64, Atom 1.0.19, though this has been happening for a _long_ time.

/cc @as-cii
Label: bug

Title: ALT+F opens File menu item, but only if no file is open
Body:
On main menu, the File item is underlined on the F letter. ALT+F opens it, but only if no file is open. If a file is open, Atom instead advances to the next word, like CTRL+Right.

I understand this may be a terminal/vim-like behavior. However, a shortcut's behavior should be consistent. Either it opens the File menu item, or it doesn't.

ALT+H (for the Help menu item) has this problem, too.
Label: bug

No dev packages

Title: Emojis count as two characters
Body:
Expected behaviour: Emojis should only be counted as one character, to make counting easier. As you can see from the screenshot, Atom claims the cursor to be at position 1:5, even though it's at 1:3.

![screen shot 2015-09-28 at 14 44 49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2098462/10135611/ab3bfd16-65ef-11e5-8ac1-1c6f81a60364.png)
Label: bug

Title: Hitting Esc on a dialog box should perform the most conservative option
Body: For instance, on Cmd-Q, a dialog box comes up, and I hit Esc because I hit the keybinding by mistake in the first place. No changes are saved and my editor quits!
Label: bug

Title: need a md5sum hash value of release packages
Body:
I downloaded AtomSetup.exe(1.0.18) . After a while I forgot I downloaded ,so I downloaded AtomSetup.exe(1.0.18) again .
Now I have to setup_packages in my download_folder, but I find they don't have the same size .I use HashMyFiles to checksum them ,and ,of course , they don't match to each other.
I don't know why they are different .I think there may be some network problems .

But I cann't verify which package is the right package, I think there should be a hash value list of release packages .Just like centos.org  ,they provide a md5sum.txt to tell the md5 of the iso files.

There is already a RELEASES ,but it only about the nupkg files, and is that SHA1 or what ?

Some days ago a malware called 'xcodeghost' cames out .XcodeGhost is a compiler malware in OS X. Its malicious code is located in a Mach-O object file that was repackaged into some versions of Xcode installers. I'm afraid there may be someone do the same to Atom in the future .

So I think there should be a md5sum.txt or something like that in the page of releases page for users to verify the setup_files.
Label: enhancement

Title: Make it easier to add top/bottom bars
Body:
From this discussion: https://discuss.atom.io/t/placing-element-at-top-of-atom-for-package/21118
#### Problem:

Currently you can't easily add a bar to the top or bottom that spans across the whole width. If you try, it pushes down the status bar. I guess because `atom-workspace-axis` has `height: 100%`.

![screen shot 2015-09-25 at 3 22 20 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/10094309/40c5935a-6399-11e5-92df-bc56f4986499.png)

An option is to add it above/below the editor, like `tool-bar` currently does, but that might not be desired for all packages.
#### Possible solution:

Add two empty `<atom-panel-container>` as children of `<atom-workspace>`. They're just placeholders and won't take up space if they are empty, but it would allow other packages to fill them.

![atom-panels](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/10159023/c0848db4-66d0-11e5-9cbe-fadbfa2bd110.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom 1.0.18 flashing window on Ubuntu 14.04
Body:
Hi,

I just updated from Atom 1.0.15 to 1.0.18, and now it's completely unusable.
The atom window "flashes", showing the editor for one sec, and then showing the desktop wallpaper, and again.

FWIW, the same happens if Atom is run with the `safe` option.
Any idea ?
Label: bug

Title: private config type
Body: There should be a setting in the configuration api to make a config item _private_. With this flag activated when generating an automated bug report it won't print out any _private_ config keys. Specifically if the config api is being used to store api keys a user could accidentally report a bug that reveals their api key.
Label: enhancement

Title: Context menu doesn't open at mouse cursor position
Body:
See this image:

![context-menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3612514/10071091/4e0f6ca8-62b7-11e5-8b8f-7e3483e827b0.gif)

When I right click to open the context menu, there's a few pixels in between the mouse cursor and the top-left corner of the context menu. It seems to get worse on the right side of the screen. I would expect the context menu's top-left corner to coincide with the mouse position. I could replicate this in safe mode, but not in google chrome v45.0.2454.99.

System details:
Atom 1.2.0-dev-0145ae3
Debian 9 with Openbox window manager
Label: bug

Title: Custom Gutter component does not accept space in class list
Body:
In linter, we need to provide a base class `linter-highlight` along with the error type as the class. Not being able to have a space in class pretty much cripples the abilities, furthermore, we are allowed spaces in classes in highlight markers so I believe it's an inconsistency.
I am talking about `custom-gutter-component` on lines https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/custom-gutter-component.coffee#L84-L88
cc @nathansobo
Label: enhancement

Title: Find in Project - click on result fails to highlight line, if file was not open yet
Body:
Atom: 1.0.15, OS: OSX 10.10.5, Added Packages: atom-beautify, atom-pair, blame, color-picker, editorconfig, git-log, jshint, merge-conflicts, pretty-json, tabs-to-space

If I search using "Find in Project", I get a tab "Project Find Results" listing the results it found.

When I click on a result, the corresponding file is opened. BUT only if the file was already open, the cursor jumps to the line with the search result. If that file was not open, the file is opened BUT the cursor is always found on the last line in the file.

Expected Behaviour: When clicking on a result, the file should be opened - if not open, yet - and the cursor should be placed on the line where the result is that I clicked on.

Title: gitignore of a file with the same name as the containing directory ignores the entire directory
Body:
If I have a project structure like so:

MyProject
|   .gitignore
|   helloworld
|   |   .gitignore
|   |   main.go
|   |   helloworld (this is an executable called helloworld)
|   otherdir

In the MyProject/helloworld/.gitignore I add the line 'helloworld' to ignore the generated binary.

Atom then ignores ALL files in the MyProject/helloworld directory (even though git still recognizes them all). This causes some issues, for example, you can't use fuzzy search to open the files

However if I instead edit MyProject/.gitignore and add 'helloworld/helloworld' everything works as expected.
Label: bug

Title: Drop text from external application
Body:
It would be great if atom would accept dropped text from another application. I haven't found a package that implements that functionality. 

My usecase is when I am writing a scientific paper in markdown. In gedit, I can easily drag citations from zotero into gedit and they get pasted in in the correct format (format selectable within zotero). This behavior is what I am looking to replicate in atom. 

Thanks,
Chris
Label: enhancement

Title: Markdown breaks code folding in Literate CoffeeScript
Body:
Atom supports [Literate Coffeescript](http://coffeescript.org/#literate), but the code folding breaks when presented with Markdown content, which is the entire point of Literate Coffeescript. A function which contains Markdown text will not fold correctly; the Markdown and anything following is considered immune to the fold.

![code-folding-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3488572/9997786/0ff2ee48-605c-11e5-8ff6-c33ffdf6db17.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Loading large file with many lines sometimes hangs or crashes the editor
Body:
File that has 140000 lines can reproduce this issue.
Sublime Text 3 release version has no this problem.
Label: bug

Title: Atom can be pinch and tap zoomed on OS X
Body:
It is possible to zoom in the whole editor on OS X using the pinch zoom gesture on the trackpad. If you do this accidentally I can be really hard to zoom out back. I don’t believe this is an intended feature, is it? 

Occurs in Atom 1.0.13.
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5495918/9968820/0bfcc77c-5e4b-11e5-878d-6fe32a5413d8.gif)

Title: Interface is blank on 3/4 of screen
Body:
Just updated to 1.0.13 on OSX 10.10.5. When I open up atom through the command line(`atom`) or through the dock icon 3/4 of my screen is white: 

![screen shot 2015-09-18 at 10 29 36 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4634290/9964914/2e1b8d58-5df0-11e5-80df-d68122e063ca.png)

It looks like it is only happening if I have it at a certain size on my external monitor (thunderbolt display running @ 2560-by-1440). The window size in that screen shot is around 2400x1300

This also happens if I run it in safe mode from the command line (`atom --safe`)

It does fix itself if I resize the window
Label: bug

Title: CustomEvent inheritance change breaks vim-mode in 1.12
Body:
[This commit](https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/e3f9074f4a98f15a4436a79a2209e2fdece85dd4), added in 1.12 released a day ago, removes `originalEvent` from dispatched events. This breaks vim-mode's use of the same event for multiple different keys:

``` cson
  '1': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
  '2': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
  '3': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
```

I've poked around at the new events from the vim-mode point of view, and without the `originalEvent`, there's no way to fix it other than to create tons of unique events, like in [this commit](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/commit/d73e0916c51374c22c36fb4fd9931e7ded0b4c17), which is so bad I can't bring myself to make a PR out of it.

It seems like the breaking commit is attempting to keep the API the same, but the original event keys are part of the event prototype, not the event, so they're not copied. It looks like there's been [some work on that file](https://github.com/atom/atom/commits/master/src/command-registry.coffee) since the breaking commit, but nothing in the last day or two, so I'm hoping this isn't a duplicate.

For reference, the vim-mode code that's referencing the missing `originalEvent` is [here](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/blob/master/lib/vim-state.coffee#L587-L588) and [here](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/blob/master/lib/vim-state.coffee#L575-L576). And the break is pretty dramatic, making vim-mode more or less unusable.
Label: bug

Title: Text rendering on OS X
Body:
Text rendering on OS X could be improved, by using `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;`
The issue is especially visible on a Retina display.
With `optimizeLegibility`, letter spacing is more homogeneous.

![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/YbaKeLW.png)
`text-rendering: auto;`

![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/v2JX6Gl.png)
`text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;`
Label: enhancement

Title: Can't rebuild package after updating to 1.0.13
Body:
The 'red bug' appeared in the bottom right corner of the status bar after updating to 1.0.13, and led me to an UI where I could rebuild my package. Rebuilding kept failing with the following error message:

```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/bin/node-gyp-bin/node-gyp: line 3: node: command not found

npm ERR! Darwin 14.5.0
npm ERR! argv "/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/bin/node" "/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/bin/npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "/Users/david/.atom/.apm/.apmrc" "--userconfig" "/Users/david/.atom/.apmrc" "rebuild" "--target=0.30.6" "--arch=x64"
npm ERR! node v0.10.40
npm ERR! npm  v2.13.3
npm ERR! file sh
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno ENOENT
npm ERR! syscall spawn
npm ERR! oniguruma@4.2.2 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! spawn ENOENT
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the oniguruma@4.2.2 install script 'node-gyp rebuild'.
npm ERR! This is most likely a problem with the oniguruma package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR!     node-gyp rebuild
npm ERR! You can get their info via:
npm ERR!     npm owner ls oniguruma
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /Users/david/git/language-markdown/npm-debug.log
```

Eventually, after discussion in the #atom channel on Slack with @as-cii and @simurai, and after `apm rebuild`-ing numerous times via the command line, and after a re-install of Atom, rebuilding finally worked. So, my problem is fixed, but I suppose this isn't intended behavior.

The package that caused this was [language-markdown](http://atom.io/packages/language-markdown/).

`npm-debug.log` got unfortunately erased once the rebuild succeeded.
Label: bug

Title: Changing UI/Syntax theme colors 3 times reverts ALL settings to defaults
Body: I just started using this today, running version 1.0.13 on Windows 10 64-bit. I was messing with the theme settings after I had my other settings (which plugins were enabled, editor settings, etc) configured. I changed the theme three times, then the UI became very screwed up. ![Weird UI](http://i.imgur.com/6xPhzMv.png) It stayed screwed up whenever I changed the theme again, so I tried closing and reopening Atom. Then I was greeted with the welcome screen which I got rid of, and all my tabs were gone. I checked my settings, and sure enough, they were back to the defaults.

Title: Configurable number of lines below cursor-line
Body:
As you navigate downwards in a file Atom always keeps two lines below the current cursor-line. In the screenshot pressing <kbd>ctrl-n</kbd> or <kbd>⬇︎</kbd> once will bring line 55 into view.

![screen shot 2015-09-14 at 16 12 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7944/9890626/a0168ce0-5bc6-11e5-8d79-de6fd1307c9b.png)

Could this number of lines be made configurable?
Label: enhancement

Title: Expose monospace font-family as UI variable
Label: enhancement

Title: Warn users when one keybinding's keystroke is a prefix of another
Body:
See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8706 and https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6233 for context.

When users define two keybindings, and one keybinding's keystroke is a prefix of another -- then [a timeout is used](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/blob/411ae894194e6563019498c7a9b60a28f22513b7/src/keymap-manager.coffee#L56-L64) as a way of determining what to do next if the user hits that prefix (execute the command for that prefix or wait for more keys so that the longer keystroke can be matched).

In such situations, some users are confused that it takes so long to execute the command. Perhaps a warning (in the form of a [notification](https://github.com/atom/notifications)) might help reduce this confusion?

/cc @nathansobo
Label: enhancement

Title: No way to go from a TextEditor to a File
Body:
A `TextEditor` has a `TextBuffer` which likely (but is not guaranteed to) have a `File`. `TextEditor` has a public `getBuffer()` method, but there is no public API on `TextBuffer` to get to the corresponding `File`.

As a result, instead of passing around a `File`, most packages pass around a string `path`, which is assumed to be a local file path. This can lead to bugs like:

https://github.com/gandm/language-babel/issues/66

because it's not safe to assume you can call things like `require('path').dirname()` on the path from the `TextEditor` because it might be a URI rather than a local file path:

https://github.com/bolinfest/language-babel/blob/b3fe5a544b2c707f5094a327788b0eb438cf0f25/lib/transpiler.coffee#L174

If we want to encourage more packages to be agnostic as to whether files are local or remote, we should make it easier to use a `File` rather than a path.
Label: enhancement

Title: squirrel-update-spec not really testing desktop shortcut
Body:
It looks like test _keeps the desktop shortcut deleted on updates if it was previously deleted_ in [squirrel-update-spec](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/spec/squirrel-update-spec.coffee) is not really doing its job.

We tried removing a meaningful bit of functionality in code under test (see 
[this commit](https://github.com/BrainCrumbz/atom/commit/b34d9c50312158a675017b06600c0c04872c45af)) and the test still passes.

Now having a look at possible cause. Probably that's because ~~the _ChildProcess_ is being mocked _too much_ [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/fb3cc5554c1913c6002c76bf3d12967bdde72d1f/spec/squirrel-update-spec.coffee#L20). Or, maybe~~ there's no test _really_ checking that desktop shortcut is created in the first place? (otherwise expectation on [line #82](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/fb3cc5554c1913c6002c76bf3d12967bdde72d1f/spec/squirrel-update-spec.coffee#L82) should fail).

Is this test behavior intended?
Label: bug

I search for some text, then clicking within the matched region, then press `a`. Since the cursor was shown, I expected `a` to be inserted at that point, but it instead replaced the character before the cursor.

Not really sure if this is a find-and-replace problem or an Atom problem, so opening it here.

@nathansobo you're my :spades: for these kinds of weirdness -- any ideas on this one or how serious it is?

Title: Snippet auto complete disappears at last character
Body:
I discovered this strange thing. I am on Ubuntu.
I created a snippet for "public function" with the prefix "pufu". When i type "puf" auto complete appears fine. But if i type all prefix like "pufu" auto complete window disappears. 
![screenshot from 2015-09-14 18 40 24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1254613/9854480/b173d9c6-5b11-11e5-9c1c-7a2b37a1548c.png)
I am aware if i type pufu and hit tab it works.

This is expected for complete code but in snippets this should work differently.
For example: if i type "function" i don't need to see it since i already typed all. But hey just tested it, it appears. I already typed all.
![screenshot from 2015-09-14 18 58 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1254613/9854651/8dd9a74c-5b12-11e5-9122-ece4026b8a0d.png)

There needs to be a switch.

Since you may ask, here is my snippet.
![screenshot from 2015-09-14 19 03 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1254613/9854800/511dac80-5b13-11e5-89da-bbfbf1b4c69f.png)

Edit: I found some more interesting things. if prefix is "pff" it works fine. I don't understand the logic there.

Title: Atom not visible under "Other programs" in order to "open with" or set as default in Ubuntu
Body:
I installed the latest Atom 1.0.11 on Ubuntu 14.04 by opening atom-amd64.deb in Ubuntu's software center and installing from there. Next, when right-clicking a plain text file, Atom is not listed for "Open with", nor is it listed under "Other applications". This means it also wasn't possible to set it as the default program for .txt.

Adding `%f` at the end of the line `Exec=/usr/share/atom/atom ...` in ~/.local/share/applications/atom.desktop made Atom available in the `Open with` menu/tab. (not sure if this is Ubuntu-specific).
Label: bug

Title: Opening a file and triggering an undo removes all content from the file
Body:

![undoooo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/9821745/8823d5be-58bc-11e5-9e7a-879013ffe65a.gif)

I start Atom, open a file, type something, and then trigger undos -- after the text I added is removed another undo removes all content from the file. Title: A block of code which is folded and made as comment cannot be unfolded right after
Body:
The following block of SCSS code cannot be unfolded right after having folded it and made as a comment:

``` scss
.foo {
  display: none;
}
```

Steps to reproduce the issue:
1. Paste the provided snippet in a new SCSS-formatted tab
2. Select all
3. Fold the block
4. Make as comment
5. Try to unfold 😕

IMHO when we click the "unfold block" icon it should be unfolded and every line should be a comment, but it just does nothing.
Label: bug

Title: TokenizedBuffer#bufferRangeForScopeAtPosition appears to be using incorrect position
Body:
I run into this with https://github.com/blakeembrey/atom-dash/issues/26 and solved it using https://github.com/blakeembrey/atom-dash/commit/750f84560f62e824b87fbd2012699d50dd3446e2. It seems a method are using the wrong position object. I suspect `TokenizedBuffer#bufferRangeForScopeAtPosition` is not calculating the position correctly.

The issue starts with https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/278e988cca2bba2b0f5f13d1833786ac59cb989e/src/text-editor.coffee#L2565-L2566 and ends up using https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/4ff3b6d5efd213f491b82317316bdbffd39efbdf/src/tokenized-buffer.coffee#L478. As it passes cursor buffer position, if you have tabs enabled it will never get the position back correctly and it ends up being off by however much your tab spacing is.

Edit: Here's an image in action:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1088987/11289914/4a6d38e0-8ee6-11e5-88cd-b67a85b6dd9c.png)
Label: bug

Title: Support external tokenizers
Body:
Formalizing [this forum question](https://discuss.atom.io/t/custom-grammar-based-on-external-tokenizer/19537) as a feature request here. Some languages don't lend themselves very well to regex-based grammars, and there are several languages out there that expose their tokenizers.

I'd love if Atom supported syntax highlighting based on external tokenizers. It would allow, for example, highlighting Swift code using the same mechanism Xcode uses (see https://github.com/jpsim/SourceKitten#syntax).
Label: enhancement

Title: Windows "Open with Atom" context menu shortcut for files and directories is broken for paths with spaces
Body:
Related to issue #6400.

Please wrap the Atom path in quotes within the registry key strings for the "Open with Atom": shortcut.  It currently fails for paths containing spaces (e.g., when Atom is installed for a user whose user name contains a first and last name).  Given that the reg key strings are now updated with every release (#6400), manual fixes which wrap the paths in quotes are overwritten with every Atom release.

e.g.,
"C:\Users\John Smith\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.0.11\atom.exe" "%V"

registry keys:
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\Background\shell\Atom\command
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\shell\Atom\command
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT*\shell\Atom\command
Label: bug

Title: Atom does not use the system font on Linux (and Mac and Windows)
Body:
Atom does not actually use the system font for its UI. [The "font stack" solution currently implemented](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8612) hardcodes a bunch of fonts in the hope that the default font for every possible installation is included. This is not a big issue on Mac and Windows where it is ~~impossible~~ almost impossible – and very unusual – to change the system font.

Not so on Linux. As an example, I use Fedora which comes with Cantarell by default. I don't like Cantarell and have changed my system font to Source Sans Pro instead (easily done in GNOME). All of my desktop applications respect the change, except Atom because it has Cantarell hardcoded in its font stack and since Cantarell is still present on my system it is used instead.

The solution is to make Atom use the system fonts like other desktop applications. Instead of guessing which font the user wants, it should query the system for the default font to use. IMO this should also extend to the fixed-width font and themes explicitly setting the font family should be the exception rather than the rule. No matter which theme I choose, there is almost never a good reason for one application to use a different font than the others.
Label: enhancement

Title: Subpixel anti-aliasing failing on tiles with very specific last lines
Body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a new Markdown document with the content below
2. Use mentioned syntax theme and typeface
3. Notice the color difference between quote 10 and 11
### Cause

Normally, with my settings, all lines are 21px high, and normal text is rendered with a height of 16px. In the example however, the #-sign, scoped as `markup heading marker gfm`, whose `font-weight: bold` inherited from being a heading, is reset to `font-weight: normal`. This causes the #-sign to be rendered as **17px** high, making the line itself **22px** instead of 21px, and pushing a single pixel outside the tile, causing the entire tile to lose subpixel anti-aliasing. Furthermore, as far as I have been able to deduce, this only happens when the `font-weight` is reset from `bold` to `normal`, although this could be a coincidence of course.

Heads up to @as-cii who I've already discussed this with on Slack. And can someone give me a detective's badge, cause I certainly feel like one! : )
### Screenshot

![schermafbeelding 2015-09-01 om 15 48 14](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3703530/9605943/e8ab3138-50c0-11e5-9bb2-30ecbdb65a5a.png)

Notice how the tile is 1px higher than the gutter-tile next to it.
### Sample code

``` markdown
> Awesome quote 1
> Awesome quote 2
> Awesome quote 3
> Awesome quote 4
> Awesome quote 5
> Awesome quote 6
> Awesome quote 7
> Awesome quote 8
> Awesome quote 9
> Awesome quote 10

# I am a header that's screwing things up

> Awesome quote 11
```
### Environment

**Atom**: 1.0.9
**Theme**: https://atom.io/packages/minimal-syntax
**Typeface**: https://github.com/chrissimpkins/Hack
**font-size**: 14px
**line-height**: 1.5
Label: bug

Adding `--safe` option and resetting Config, Init Script, Keymap, Snippets, and Stylesheet don't change anything.  The problem still occurs.

This is the screen capture.  I am not dragging.  I just click several times while moving the cursor on the editor.  Though there's no cursor in the movie, it is capture app's issue.

Title: Atom has many unavailable menus with no windows open
Body: It sure would be nice if more (most) of Atom's menus were available with no window open. One such case would be using project-manager to open a project if it had a sub-menu in the Packages menu.
Label: enhancement

Title: ctrl-alt-b conflicts with `build` package
Body:
Recently, `Atom` takes the key `ctrl-alt-b` for `editor:move-to-previous-subword-boundary` (https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/keymaps/emacs.cson#L7). This conflicts with the [`build` package I am maintaining](https://atom.io/packages/build).

Would it make more sense to have an `emacs-mode` package for people who wants this? This would be akin to the `vim-mode` package which adds `vim` functionalitites to `Atom`.

Right now I am getting reports this keymap takes precedence over mine (https://github.com/noseglid/atom-build/issues/168). Doesn't seem to be that way for everyone though.
Label: enhancement

Title: Race condition when opening files leads to data loss
Body:
I have had this problem happen in other circumstances (disconnected windows into the same file), but I seem to be able to reproduce it reliably this way.

Open a terminal, type `atom file.txt & ; atom file.txt` (make sure file.txt does not current exist)

Two windows into file.txt will open. In the top one, type some text, save and close.

The text is not reproduced in the second. Closing this window will prompt to save the file even though you have not typed anything. This will save a blank file, overwriting your text.
Label: bug

Title: Random "Error compiling Less stylesheet" errors when switching syntax themes
Body: Just noticed this on Atom 1.0.9-020c11d on OSX 10.10.5 after I tried to switch the syntax theme from One Dark to Base16 Tomorrow Dark: Notice how two errors are thrown first for the Base16 Tomorrow Dark, and then for the One Dark UI (which was already set as the UI theme). I haven't touched any of those files. After I restarted Atom, Base16 Tomorrow Dark was successfully loaded at startup and I could switch themes just fine (no errors thrown). I remember this happened once a few weeks/months ago as well, but I couldn't reproduce it back then either. I noticed one other similar issue (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6797), but that's related to styles.less. cc @kevinsawicki in case you have any :thought_balloon: about this

Title: Atom won't start after upgrade
Body:
OS: Windows 7 64-bit

This morning, I tried to upgrade to Atom 1.0.8 from 1.0.7. Although the updater didn't say that there were any updates available, after I closed and reopened atom, I got this error message:

![atom-javascript-error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9618670/9555509/56293486-4d82-11e5-8a6e-94560a9325cb.PNG)

The taskbar shortcut had been changed to point to the new atom-1.0.8 directory.

I'm not the only one who's experienced this: see [https://discuss.atom.io/t/a-javascript-error-occured-in-the-browser-process/20306](here).

I can roll back to 1.0.7 for now, but it would be nice to upgrade.
Label: bug

Title: Add API for custom "virtual" lines (like those used in soft-wrap)
Body:
Following this [discussion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/inserting-fake-blank-lines-in-the-editor-like-softwrap/18547/8)

Atom has the ability to create and set content for lines that don't exist in the buffer. This is used for soft-wrapping text. Package creators would benefit from an api to do this manually, for example "to add some virtual lines for references" (Ominisharp-atom) or to make space for custom/temporary UI elements (preview-inline).
By using the existing line rendering system the performance tuning is maintained, unlike in a solution that would allow arbitrary 'inline block' elements.
Label: enhancement
