Title: highlighting of soft wrapped line
Body:
Current line is highlighted, which is nice. 
When a line is soft wrapped, the whole line should be highlighted and
the wrap differently highlighted. This would allow to see what is going on
instead of watching the gutter to realize that the line is wrapped.
Label: enhancement

Title: Multi line mouse select breaks in text editor when editor is small enough
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open text file with lots of lines of code.
2. Resize text editor vertically so only 5 lines is visible.
3. Try to select two lines with the mouse.
4. As soon as two lines are selected the text editor begins to scroll rapidly in a state that is only possible to exit by stop selection.

The practical use case for me is when you split the editor vertically it's nothing strange to have just 5 lines in one of the panes.

Suggested solution is to use a relative auto vscroll select area instead of an absolute.

OS: Mac OS X 10.10.5
Atom 1.0.7
Label: bug

Title: Cannot block comment code that starts with a comment
Label: bug

Title: Key binding for comments should insert cursor within comment
Body:
Hi,

Apologies for the long title. The bug is actually quite simple: when I prepare to add a comment via Atom's default key binding (`cmd+/` for me), the text cursor is not placed _within_ the comment as I would expect (so I can begin typing). Instead, the cursor is placed _after_ the comment, which I find rather unintuitive.

_Before:_  
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/872474/7287217/60d99a18-e907-11e4-9894-b62d177c1303.png)

_After:_  
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/872474/7287241/88825aa0-e907-11e4-8607-f65423cd5f12.png)

_What I was expecting:_  
![ideal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/872474/7287256/b1c6c9f0-e907-11e4-93ea-8b4fe09aafa0.png)

Could this be fixed?

Thanks,
Caleb

_P.S. I first [posted this issue on atom/language-css](https://github.com/atom/language-css/issues/25), but it seems the issue affects all languages with start/end components for comments._
Label: enhancement

Title: Stack trace support still getting overridden by CoffeeScript
Body:
It seems that another copy of CoffeeScript is a deep dependency of the line ending selector package's test setup, and it's screwing up stack trace support when running its specs.

I'm wondering if we should make `Error.prepareStackTrace` read-only, then offer a different Atom-specific way for Grim to get access to the raw stack trace, like `Error.atomPrepareStackTrace` or something. Relying on CoffeeScript to never be required seems fragile so far.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld
Label: bug

Title: Allow us to block popup's from addons.
Body: The same way that Android allows us to silence apps it would be nice to silence addons with glaring bugs that keep causing errors but we do not wish to remove.  Such as a recent bug with linter that causes a file with a simple name to popup an error, it would be nice if we could block those messages because as a whole it works but in one part it's broken.
Label: enhancement

Title: Problem installing Packages/ Themes and Updates (Corporate SSL Proxies)
Body:
Hello. This is related to #4974, #4975, and #4122.
## The Issue:

Trying to use Atom at work (to hopefully replace Notepad++), and was able to install Atom fine without a problem. However, when I went to install some packages, I received the following error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7026750/9408312/9fad910e-47df-11e5-8bb3-ff1230a1939f.png)

Same thing for themes:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7026750/9408324/bcc3a9ae-47df-11e5-8f5b-16b14509cc4c.png)

And same thing for the featured packages:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7026750/9408333/d64225cc-47df-11e5-93d7-2526ee7d3339.png)

And featured themes:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7026750/9408336/e8349b98-47df-11e5-84d9-e235e9b05ccb.png)
## Background:

We use [Palo Alto Security Appliances](https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/platforms/firewalls/pa-5000/overview.html) to protect our ingress and egress network traffic from malware and other threats to our network and data. Palo Alto does this by using a wildcard certificate that has been generated from our Enterprise PKI and which is trusted on all Company-owned workstations and servers.

> Not looking to get into a debate about SSL decryption or man-in-the-middle attacks for SSL. This is at my work, and we have legal and regulatory requirements to break SSL, inspect the traffic, and then re-encrypt it before it leaves our network.

I know _why_ Atom is failing here. It's seeing what it thinks is a bad certificate in the mix, and that the traffic is being attacked (MiTM). I understand _why_ Atom is failing here. But in this case, the traffic is _legitimately_ being broken, for _legitimate_ reasons.
## Feature Request:

I would like to request the addition of a hidden configuration option that, when enabled, would cause Atom to **ignore SSL certificate errors**.

> Yes I know this is risky for end-users. Yes, I know this reduces the overall security, which is why I don't think the configuration setting should be easily "discoverable" or that there shouldn't be a UI element for it. Hopefully that wouldn't allow a non-technical user to accidentally enable it and potentially reduce their security.
### Alternately:

If Atom would show the actual URL that's being blocked, or that raised the error, we could then add the URL to a white-list to bypass SSL decryption on our side, allowing packages and themes  to be installed.

Of course, it would be helpful if packages and themes were distributed from a central repository with a common organizational structure and naming convention. :smile: 

---

Thanks so much for considering this feature request.

Running Atom 1.0.7 on Windows 7 Enterprise SP1.
Label: bug

Title: Leave tab open when file deleted
Body:
When a file is deleted from the filesystem, atom closes the tab automatically.
This may not be the best solution as it may have been deleted accidentally.

It would be nice if the tab was left open, and upon close notify the user that the file no longer exists and offering one last chance to save the file.
Label: enhancement

Title: un-highlight non-directory files in directory pane ui
Body:
I opened another file (test.java) from the terminal via `atom test.java`. It opened in my previous working directory, and it would be more intuitive if it unhighlighted in the working directory pane as well. 

A minor but helpful enhancement! 

![screen shot 2015-08-19 at 11 56 29 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5819303/9366004/95fe2d3e-4669-11e5-8b45-57364ec30178.png)
Label: bug

Title: Make persistent fullscreen optional
Body: The persistent fullscreen feature (#245) should be optional. For anyone alternating between a laptop screen (fullscreen) and a large external screen (windowed), persistent fullscreen makes for a frustrating experience. In this case you have to wait for the window to go fullscreen, then toggle it off, then wait for the animation out of fullscreen to finish, which is slow and unnecessary.
Label: enhancement

Title: There is no naming convention of scope selectors
Body:
I assume Atom follows TextMate [naming conventions](http://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars#naming_conventions), but there is no mention about it. It causes misunderstandings([1](https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/issues/47), [2](https://github.com/atom/solarized-dark-syntax/issues/21), [3](https://github.com/atom/language-coffee-script/issues/33) etc.) Also many language packages don't follow it. Syntax theme looks awful for these languages. Syntax-theme developers must create a syntax rule for each language. It's a real headache.
##### I suggest:
- Add docs for grammar naming conventions
- Mention about naming conventions
  - ... in generated `syntax.less`
  - ... in grammar files
- Make sure general languages follow naming conventions:
  - [Javascript](https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/issues/201) atom/language-javascript#206
  - [C#](https://github.com/atom/language-csharp/issues/33) atom/language-csharp#34
  - [Go](https://github.com/atom/language-go/issues/62)
  - ...

Mention in files might be something like this:

``` less
// See list of scopes in "Naming Conventions" section of the
// TextMate Language Grammar Guide:
// http://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars#naming_conventions
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Unable to change installation directory
Body: Limited drive space considering more packages to be installed. Need to change default windows directory to D drive. I can't find anything on forums or documentation. It is curious how Atom claims to be "hackable" but I can't find a way how to do a very basic functionality :)
Label: enhancement

Title: Support Babel in all of the same ways as CoffeeScript
Body:
We want to move toward writing new code in javascript, not coffeescript. For example: https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector. But before we start bundling packages written in Babel, we need to improve some infrastructure around it.
### Tasks

[The CI script](https://github.com/atom/ci/blob/master/build-package.sh)
- [x] Make sure it runs specs properly for packages that use babel
- [x] Somehow detect when packages are using [Standard Style](http://standardjs.com/) and lint them properly

Bundled Packages
- [x] Make the [build script](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/build/tasks/build-task.coffee) treat babel source files the same as coffee-script files
- [x] Make the Gruntfile compile babel files

Opting in to Babel
- [x] Create an alternative to the `'use babel'` string that fits in better with other babel directives. Maybe this:

``` js
/** use babel */
/** @jsx dom */
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Icons in small buttons increase button height
Body:
The style guide shows regular buttons with icons via `<button class='btn btn-primary icon icon-cloud-download inline-block-tight'>Install</button>`:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 53 00 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311917/5989e0e2-44ce-11e5-94a3-33e6f2e00c1e.png)

However, small buttons styled the same way are too tall, making text not vertically aligned, because `.icon` has a static height and font-size of 16px `<button class='btn btn-sm btn-primary icon icon-cloud-download inline-block-tight'>Install</button>`:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 53 26 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311918/5d3580d4-44ce-11e5-8749-8346e0a335aa.png)

Icons should shrink when inside a `.btn-sm`, something like this:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 56 29 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311957/a1313e2c-44ce-11e5-9c77-f16e017ff23a.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Ability to open file in new tab multiple times
Body:
There is a neat little feature in ST called "New View for File", which basically opens the file a second time in a new tab. Atom Editor has support for this by "splitting" the view, but this isn't always the desired behaviour.

For example, if I have two panes already split and all I want to do is create a new view of a file, then I'd have to split then drag the file back out to destroy the newly created pane.

There should be an option to just open the file in a new tab, in the same pane which it exists in.
Label: enhancement

Title: Rendering errors: scoped character widths getting incorrectly assigned to zero
Body:
I got into a state where certain scoped character widths were getting set to zero.

I'm not sure how to get back into this state. I was editing [this C file](https://github.com/maxbrunsfeld/tree-sitter/blob/master/src/runtime/parser.c), I had folded some text, and I was using both of the `One Light` themes, with the `Source Code Pro` font.

For one scope, all of the assigned character widths were zero. For another scope, it was just one character.

``` js
b = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().displayBuffer

// this scope had all zero widths
b.charWidthsByScope["source.c"]["meta.function.c"]["meta.block.c"]["storage.type.c"].charWidths
{b: 0, o: 0, l: 0, i: 0, n: 0}

// for this scope, just the 'u' character had zero width
b.charWidthsByScope["source.c"]["meta.function.c"]["entity.name.function.c"].charWidths["t"]
8 
b.charWidthsByScope["source.c"]["meta.function.c"]["entity.name.function.c"].charWidths["u"]
0
```

/cc @as-cii @nathansobo has anything changed with measurement recently?
Label: bug

Title: Change `editor.softTabs` to `editor.defaultTabType`
Body:
With the advent of #3719, we now have two settings: `editor.softTabs` and `editor.tabType`. When the `editor.tabType` option is set to `auto` it uses the `editor.softTabs` setting to determine tab type in new, empty files. IMO, this setting should stick around but have its name updated to be more consistent with `editor.tabType`. 

One other bit of associated work could be updating the schema description to be clear about how the two options work together.
Label: enhancement

Title: stack trace in spec window should be hyperlinked
Body: It would be great if file pointers in reports of failed specs were hyperlinked so that clicking on them opens the file on the right line. For example, I'd love a hyperlink on this: ``` at operators-spec.coffee:259:32 ``` in the screeshot:
Label: enhancement

Title: Add classes for unsaved changes in the editor?
Body:
Currently, Atom supports line classes when a line has git modifications/additions, etc, but doesn't have classes for when it simply has unsaved changes.

When you've deleted lines, it should have a `.removed` class on the line prior to the lines removed.
When you've edited a line, it should have a `.modified` class on it
And finally, when you've added a new line, it should have a `.new` class on it

Knowing git changes is definitely a helpful thing to have, but it's not anywhere near as important (to me, at least) as knowing changes before I commit to a file save. =)
Label: enhancement

Title: osx dragging multiple files onto dock icon inconsistency
Body:
When Atom has an open window and I drag two files onto the icon in the dock, the two files are both opened in the existing window. When Atom has no window open but is running, the two files open in two separate windows. When Atom is not running, the two files open in a single new window. 

I would expect the behaviour when Atom is running but has no windows open to match the other two cases.
Label: enhancement

Title: Gutter line-number width minimum two characters
Label: enhancement

Title: Strange selection problem in latest master version
Label: bug

Title: Copy-paste doesn't work properly with Unix-style line endings under Windows
Body:
Copying (Ctrl+C-Ctrl+V) from a file with Unix-style line ending (LF) doesn't work as expected, since line endings are _preserved_ on the clipboard.

This causes a wide range of issues:
- you can't paste text in an application that doesn't handle LF (notepad for example, but if you're using vim over PuTTY that also doesn't work)
- even if the other app handles LF, you have to be consistent, so you can't paste text from an CRLF file into a LF one or vice versa

This issue is briefly discussed in #2822, and it is the reason of #5808.

**All other editors convert line endings in text placed on the clipboard** (Sublime Text, jEdit, etc.), so in this regard Atom behaves rather strangely compared to other editors.

The proposed solution in #2822 (configurable line endings) is insufficient since it's based on the assumption that _all_ files edited by the user are using the same line ending.
For example, if I've got a file with LF line endings and I'd like to use copy-paste, then I **have to convert it to CRLF** and then **copy the text** I want, and **then convert it back to LF** to preserve the original format. I wouldn't call editing LF files on Windows a rare use case, especially among Atom's users.

Atom should convert any text's line ending to the platform's native line ending _before_ it is placed on the clipboard. This conversion should only be done on the content that is placed on the clipboard—the text in the buffer should not be changed.
Label: bug

Title: Windows 10 - Crashes
Body:
## Apologies in advance

I apologize if this has already been reported, but I couldn't find it anywhere.  Please close this issue if that's the case.  It's an oddball case.
## Platform and Version

**Platform** Windows 10
**Version** Atom 1.0.7
**Safe Mode?** Yep, that crashes too.
**Remote FileSystem** SMB Share from Mac machine (Yosemite) (as a mapped drive or as just the share itself).
## Steps to Reproduce
- Create a samba (SMB) share on a Mac machine.
- Navigate to that share on your Windows machine and authenticate.
- Tell Atom.io to open a directory within that share.
- With Windows Explorer, change a file name within the share, or simply re-navigate to the share by going to a directory above the one you opened with Atom.io and then back into the opened directory.  There are many, many things you can do at this point.
- Atom.io crashes.
## Other Tests

My situation might be a bit _unique_ so again I will apologize if it makes it hard to debug. I have tested this same setup using a linux samba share as well as a Windows file share and Atom.io behaves very well and **_never crashes**_ in those setups.  It might be something to do with how the Mac (Yosemite) samba shares are created.

All shares I used required authentication different from that of my Windows workstation.  All shares were on an AD domain using domain credentials.
Label: bug

Title: Windows scripts not updated after updating
Body:
`C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\atom\bin` doesn't seem to be updated after an update has been installed. Though atom added this directory to the PATH variable so atom is available from the windows console.

So then there is a update and this is showing up in the console:

```
> atom .
The system cannot find the path specified.
```

So it happens that atom updated to version 1.0.6, but when I look at the files in `C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\atom\bin` I can see that these ~~binary~~ executable files all refer to `app-1.0.4`. By having this issue multiple times, I know I can fix this by rewriting this to `app-1.0.6`, but it would be very convenient if the updater all does this on instead of wasting time on figuring out why its not working.
Label: bug

Title: Cannot scroll/move cursor to the end of the line when using the "Base16 Tomorrow Dark" syntax theme.
Body:
### Description:

With soft-wrap disabled and a long line of text that exceeds the available viewport width of the editor pane, erroneous behaviour is observed when attempting to go to the end of the line either via the (bottom) scroll bar or through the doesn't work properly and requires a repeat invocation to work as expected.
### Steps to reproduce:

You can reproduce this either using the scroll bar or using a keyboard command (e.g. `editor:move-to-end-of-screen-line` with whatever key shortcut applies on your platform/configuration).
1. Open Atom with an empty file. Make sure soft wrap is disabled.
2. type a long string on a single line --- your string should exceed the width of the editor viewport.
3. Press <kbd>End</kbd> or try to scroll (using the scrollbar at the bottom of the editor pane) as far right as you can.
### Actual results:

In the case of the end-of-line keyboard shortcut, the cursor does move to the end of the line, but both cursor and end of line content is not visible.

In the case of the scrollbar, you cannot go past a point which is just before the end of the line. The cursor remains hidden, as does the end of the line.
### Expected results:

In the case of the scrollbar event, you should be able to actually read the content at the end of the line, with some appropriate padding.

In the case of the keyboard commands, you should see both end of line content and the cursor blinking there.
### Notes:
- Repeating the `editor:move-to-end-of-screen-line` command one more time does move to the end of the line. I couldn't find a way to achieve this using the scroll bar.
- This issue was consistently reproducible on OS X.
Label: bug

Title: Idea: make restoring from cache easier
Body:
I have to start by saying that `~/.atom/storage` just saved my ass after I overwrote an untracked file in a project, and I'm very grateful for that! Would it be a worthwhile idea to implement a restore feature for people who do dumb things like me?

Proposal:

``` bash
# Lists projects saved, and last save timestamp
atom-restore --list-all
# Lists files in a project, and last save timestamp for each file
atom-restore list {project_name}
# Restores the project files in the current folder
atom-restore {project_name} [-o dest_dir]
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Page Up and Page Down don't move correctly with the window.
Body:
Each page up and page down move the contents of the screen up a full amount but it's offf by one line. For each page down, the cursor also moves down a line relative to the window.

If you open [this file](https://github.com/smparkes/sphinxsearch/blob/upstream-trunk/src/sphinx.cpp) and start at line 1, then hold page down you will see that cursor on the screen creeps down the window until it's off the bottom of the screen instead of holding its position. By line 7968, the cursor is off the screen.

Atom 1.0.0
Fedora 22
Gnome Shell 3.16.3
Label: bug

Title: Copy project path (keyboard shortcut + command)
Body:
The tree view has _Copy full path_ and _Copy project path_. In the edit-menu there is _Copy path_ (which copies the full path). The latter can also be used via a keyboard shortcut and the command palette [cmd+shift+p].

It would be great if the edit-menu (as well as the command palette) would could be split into a _Copy full path_ and _Copy project path_ — I find them very useful, but currently they are only available using the mouse. :mouse:
Label: enhancement

Title: Update to Octicons 3.0
Body:
The Octicons got [updated to 3.0](https://github.com/github/octicons/pull/58). There are some visual changes, but also some icons got removed and some new ones added.

It's not that straightforward to update them, since some of the community packages might use some of the icons that got removed.. like the `alignment`, `move`, `jump` icons.

A few options:
1. Update to Octicons 3.0. Packages might need to make changes or add their own icons.
2. "Manually" update to Octicons 3.0 and still keep the ones that got removed. There should be no name conflicts.
3. Keep the current Octicons as is.
4. Keep the current Octicons as is (at least until Atom 2.0). And add an additional "Atom icons set". Could be a fork of the Octicons 3.0 and modified to Atom's needs. Class names could be `atom-icon` or so. The find + replace already uses some custom icons. Also having custom icons for autocomplete-plus would be nice.
Label: enhancement

Title: activationHooks: grammar-used doesn't work when restoring a session
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Take a package with `activationHooks: grammar-used`
2. Verify that it activates when a file with given grammar is open
3. Restart Atom, e.g. with ctrl-alt-r (or platform equivalent)

Here is a video that should hopefully illustrate the problem:
https://youtu.be/0viUxFNS-jc

Notice how bottom panel shows up when I open/reopen a file, but NOT when I restart Atom
Label: bug

Title: allow package developers to create OS global keybindings
Body:
It seems like Electron has API for this (https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/global-shortcut.md) but you cannot use it for package creation.

Any way to fix that?
Label: enhancement

Title: pane:move-item-left/right, tab jumps two places
Body: When I use the key bindings ctrl-shift-left and right, the tab jumps two steps. It looks like the key binding is defined in two places and is called for each one. The screenshot is open in safe mode and my keymap.cson is empty. Atom 1.0.5 OSX 10.10.4
Label: bug

Title: Specs window is not maximized
Body:
When opening the Run Atom/Package Specs window, it is not maximized, but the window itself is the same height and width that a maximized window should be.  The result is that parts of the window are slightly offscreen:
![specs window maximized](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/9155561/ee5b57be-3e89-11e5-95d1-25602d939efd.png)

Also, it starts out at a nice size in the center of the screen, but I'm guessing once the window initializes it automatically tries to maximize itself:
![specs window normal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/9155594/6bffeec8-3e8a-11e5-9ab7-4ace1b6a3091.png)

Refs #3276 which fixed the general Atom window bug.

Also, while I'm on this topic, it would be nice if Atom windows could maximize _immediately_ after showing up - they currently start as un-maximized until everything loads.
Label: bug

Title: New option: Update checking interval
Body:
As per [discussion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/questions-about-update-checking/19688), notification in the status line is bugging to install updates every single day (packages are updated often).

It takes focus away from real work to the application ("action is needed").

The option would go great with the motto:

> Atom - (...) a tool you can customize to do anything but also use productively without ever touching a config file

This should also help a little with startup performance.

Default setting could be 24 hours or 1 week.
Label: enhancement

Title: Having both "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths" and "Hide VCS Ignored Paths" settings is confusing
Body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/753919/9144836/8b9fc460-3d04-11e5-8a93-7f1e4a62c348.png)

The _Exclude VCS Ignored Paths_ setting under Core Settings commonly gets confused with the similar setting under the Tree View package, _Hide VCS Ignored Paths_. I believe the first is for excluding files from search and the latter is for the tree view itself. 

For an idealized UI I'd vote for removing both settings and adding a new one that is a Select box where we can select to _exclude_ (from search and tree view), _exclude from search only_, and _show_. It doesn't make sense (to me) to allow not showing in the tree view but showing up in search.

We could also just add some explanation text to both settings if the above is too radical a change.

// ref #8270
Label: enhancement

Title: global.Function cannot be replaced on Atom 1.0.5
Body:
Okay, so guys. People have been commenting on less-autocompile about it not being able to compile .less that uses javascript. It seems y'all did something to break the global.Function on 1.0.5. Anything lower than 1.0.5 works just fine.

In less-autocompile I use loophole on the global.Function such as:

```
var oldFunction = global.Function;
global.Function = loophole.Function;
.... //do stuff here while replaced
global.Function = oldFunction; //restore to default global
```

However, this does not appear to work in Atom 1.0.5. At least, it used to affect the less compiler parse Function, but it doesn't appear to anymore. I have proven that it is indeed 1.0.5 causing this issue again. I was on Atom 1.0.4 and lower for awhile and it still worked. The minute I updated to 1.0.5 it no longer works.
Label: bug

Title: "Check for update" says no update is available although a new one is available.
Body:
I'm running version 1.0.4. If version 1.0.5 has been detected in the background, opening the release notes menu would show a "restart and update button" plus the 1.0.5 changes.

However, clicking on "check for update" will say "No update available. 1.0.4 is the latest version.":

![atomupdatewindows](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/9133086/f9d04498-3cf8-11e5-8048-4dc7ea637dec.png)

This happens in Windows 10.
Label: bug

Title: Cannot easily specify variable Tab Length
Body:
Why does Atom feel the need to choose which tab lengths I'm allowed to use? So many other editors let you specify this value (XCode/ST2/ST3/TW/KE/VisualStudio/even Word). And it's useful for all kinds of random tasks: sometimes I need to view/edit a massive variable-length TSV, so, elsewhere, I just throw my tab length to 40/60/whatever and edit faster than Excel thanks to regexes and [column selection](#2306).

The Tab Length item in the Settings panel should be a field, like Font Size, Line Height, and every other reasonable option: not a dropdown.
Label: enhancement

Title: Window decorations corrupted by workspace switching on XFCE
Body:
When I switch workspaces on XFCE 4.10 the Atom window decorations go all glitchy.
### Software
- Linux Mint XFCE 17.1
- XFCE 4.10
- Atom 1.0.3
- Firefox 39 (other GTK apps work too)
### Steps to Reproduce
- Open Atom in one workspace and something else in another (Firefox for example). 
- Switch from the Atom workspace to the other workspace and back.
### Result

Atom's window decorations aren't rendered, rather the contents of the other workspace are shown in their place. It looks like Atom needs to redraw. Switching focus to another application in the same workspace returns Atom to normal. No messages or errors are shown in the terminal used to launch Atom.

Here's a video of this behaviour: http://sproul.xyz/atom-xfce-render-bug.ogg

This doesn't happen on my Arch Linux machine (with XFCE 4.12) so it could well be a bug in this slightly old XFCE version. I'll try to upgrade it and update this thread accordingly.

Related but distinct from #3593 (which I can also reproduce).
Label: bug

Title: Settings view color bug
Body: The install packages tab of the settings view has a search box for finding new packages, and the text within this box is hard-coded with colors.  If you highlight the text in the box, it is impossible to read.
Label: bug

Title: Unable to add a folder to project if that folder's parent is already in the project
Body:
Assume you have the following directory structure:
- MyFolderA
- \- MyFolderA1
- \- MyFolderA2
- \- aFile.txt
- MyFolderB
- \- MyFolderB1
- \- MyFolderB2
- \- anotherFile.txt

Atom will not let me add MyFolderA and MyFolderA1 to the "root" of the project.  Of course if I add MyFolderA, then MyFolderA1 is still in the project, but if I want to add a folder that is more deeply nested than that, I am wasting sometimes a significant amount of horizontal space on the project tree having multiple nested folders open.  Additionally, I would like to have quicker access to some folders, since I work more in certain folders than others for a given project.
Label: enhancement

Title: editor:delete-to-beginning-of-word is too greedy
Body:
Similar to #3816, but I have the same complaint about whitespace in general -- I believe that the command should act as follows (which is how ST3 acts):
- Delete trailing whitespace if any, up to newline
- Delete newline only if there is no whitespace on the current line
- Otherwise act as it currently does (delete previous characters until word boundary, case change, etc)

If I have the following text (`|` being the cursor):

``` json
foobar    |
```

and tap ctrl-backspace, atom deletes the entire line.  ST3 yields:

``` json
foobar|
```

I believe ST3's behavior makes more sense and is easier to use.

Atom 1.0.3, OSX 10.10.4
Label: enhancement

Title: Improving Atom's release notes / changelogs
Body:
## Challenge

Being a very modular project, Atom has a lot of changes happening across a lot of repos. This can make it quite a challenge to keep track of all the changes being made in Atom from version to version. Unfortunately, that has sort of meant that our release notes end up being rather bare-bones summaries of what's changed in any particular version, rather than complete, well, changelogs. In addition, none of our bundled packages or libraries have any release notes at all right now - it's only Atom core. 

I think it's important to publicly document every significant change we make to Atom across all of our repos, which should make it a lot easier for users to know what to expect from each release, and hopefully help prevent surprises like https://github.com/atom/toggle-quotes/commit/8899f00c846d9e1525985f551f79cfb134f1bf5b#commitcomment-12552713 or https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8226.
## Proposal
1. Add `CHANGELOG.md` files to each package and library repo (or leverage GitHub Releases)
   - I'm personally :+1: for `CHANGELOG.md` files - they're version-controlled, simple to update, easy to discover, and will be displayed properly in settings-view.
2. Add a `CHANGELOG.md` to atom/atom to be used exclusively for core changes
3. Update them individually with each significant changes as they are made
4. Concatenate and organize all changelogs for atom.io/releases
   - For UI here it might be nice to take some inspiration from [Firefox release notes](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/39.0/releasenotes/) - default to the short summary display, and offer a "view full list of changes" option for those who really want to dig deeper.
   - Maybe even add the ability to filter by package / library?
5. atom/atom release notes (ie. the notes used in GitHub Releases, rather than the `CHANGELOG.md`) can continue to work as the short summary of what changed.

/cc @atom/feedback
Label: enhancement

Title: Provides APIs to limit Atom autoupdate version in a specific range.
Body:
Hey guys. I am working on [Nuclide](https://github.com/facebook/nuclide) and one thing I am doing right now is improve the quality of Nuclide.  

As it happened to us previously that Atom auto-updated a new version and made a non-backwards-compatible change and caused bugs and regressions, it would nice to have APIs to set the autoupdate version range for Atom programatically so that we can control the version of Atom user is using.

What's your guys thought about this? I am willing to write up PR's if it does make sense to you.
Label: enhancement

Title: Path for atom.workspace.open is case sentive
Label: bug

Title: UTF16 encoded files save aren't really UTF16
Body:
Atom does not properly save UTF16 files, and here are steps to reproduce. 

Create a windows scheduled task, and export it. Windows will gladly create an XML file for you that is encoded as UTF-16 (Little Endian).

![screenshot 2015-08-04 11 57 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/242382/9068402/8762c78c-3aa0-11e5-9341-4279a50b3db3.png)

Open that xml in atom. Tell atom that it is a UTF-16 LE file (if it doesn't automatically recognize it)

![screenshot 2015-08-04 11 58 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/242382/9068436/b00120d0-3aa0-11e5-961d-3052bdadd323.png)

Verify that the XML windows task scheduler created is infact a UTF-16 file

![screenshot 2015-08-04 11 58 17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/242382/9068447/c2f39c18-3aa0-11e5-9b7f-50e9c05cee3d.png)

Change 1 letter or word anywhere in the file

Save it as file2.xml

Try and import that back into windows task scheduler. 

You will get an error

```
The format of the task is not valid. The following error was reported: (1,2)::ERROR: one root element
```

![screenshot 2015-08-04 12 03 53](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/242382/9068465/e3469c4a-3aa0-11e5-84be-82b4c247cf10.png)

If you open the exported file in another editor (Like notepad++) and make a change, it will be formatted properly and windows task scheduler won't freak out. 

Atom : 1.0.3
Windows Server 2012R2
Label: bug

Title: Introduce scheme to `npm dedupe` npm dependencies of Atom packages
Body:
Currently, the organization of the `~/.atom/packages` directory makes it impossible to dedupe dependencies, potentially causing a lot of bloat.

Specifically, in the case of Nuclide, we have our [`nuclide-installer`](https://atom.io/packages/nuclide-installer) package that is used to install our collection of Nuclide packages. In the most recent release of Nuclide (v0.0.26), there are 17 such packages to install: https://github.com/facebooknuclideapm/nuclide-installer/blob/v0.0.26/lib/config.json.

The way `nuclide-installer` works is that it starts up and then runs `apm install` for each package in that `config.json` file. On my machine (where `~/.npm` was already populated with all of the dependencies used by these packages), it took `nuclide-installer` 6 minutes to install all 17 Atom packages and the resulting `~/.atom/packages` directory was 903M! That's enormous! This is bad for several reasons:
- 903M is an order of magnitude more disk space than is necessary if dependencies could be de-duped.
- The installation process is much slower than it has to be.
- Much more JavaScript code has to be loaded at runtime.
- I suspect that the JavaScript in `~/.atom/packages` is not loaded as efficiently as the JavaScript in `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar`, putting third-party code at even more of a disadvantage.

I suspect that the only thing I can do right now without any changes to Atom is have `~/.atom/nuclide-installer` create a special directory structure under itself. Maybe something like:

```
~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/
~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/atom_packages/
```

where npm packages common to multiple Nuclide Atom packages would be written to `~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/` (obviously there could only be one version per common dependency) and then each Atom package would be in its own directory under `~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/atom_packages/`. Under that scheme, only an npm dependency that already had an entry under `~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/` would also have to exist under `~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/atom_packages/<ATOM PACKAGE>/node_modules` if a different version were required.

Once everything was in place, `nuclide-installer` would run `apm link` for each entry in `~/.atom/nuclide-installer/node_modules/atom_packages`.

While I'm [rubber ducking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_duck_debugging), I would probably add another directory of indirection so that the directory structure would be parameterized by version number:

```
~/.atom/nuclide-installer/v0.0.26/node_modules/
~/.atom/nuclide-installer/v0.0.26/node_modules/atom_packages/
```

This way, `nuclide-installer` could be writing out v0.0.27 and would not switch over until all of the files were in place.

This is really important for Nuclide, so I'm willing to hack this into `nuclide-installer`, but it would be nice if there were a way for Atom to support this natively so that others could also provide package bundles efficiently for Atom.
Label: enhancement

Title: Browser preview inside Atom?
Body:
Atom is based on Chromium, right? So does it provides the same developer console as in other chromium based. 

What I was looking for was preview of my current HTML file working on. I know there are some [discussions](https://discuss.atom.io/t/browser-live-preview/612/48) already been discussed on this issue, and I know there are packages that issue the same. But when is it coming native in Atom?
Label: enhancement

Title: UX: Add link(s) to package management to "Packages" menu
Body:
It would be more intuitive for a user to be able to manage their packages under the "Packages" menu, since one is provided.  This would be in addition to the package-specific shortcuts currently in that menu.

user should be able to access the following in two clicks:
- search/install new packages
- view/configure installed packages
- update installed packages

There also does not appear to be an easy way to see a complete list of currently installed packages.  At least not without going to the command line.
Label: enhancement

Title: Extract `GitRepository` into its own npm package.
Body:
This is necessary to fix https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/158.

From a cursory look through https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/git-repository.coffee, the dependencies appear to be the following "ordinary" npm packages:

```
event-kit
fs-plus
git-utils
grim
underscore-plus
```

and also:

```
repository-status-handler.coffee
task.coffee
```

There are also some Atom-specific calls to `atom.config.get` and `atom.confirm`.

We would probably also want to extract https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/git-repository-provider.coffee, but that would be trivial.

Would GitHub be open to such a refactoring?
Label: enhancement

Title: The scroll bar doesn't respond sometimes in zip files
Body:
I'm very happy that Atom actually supports viewing zip files (among many other things). But, there's some trouble while scrolling a pane. Here's a (~7 MB) GIF demonstrating what I did:

![GIF](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6691262/9026385/ec12a0aa-394a-11e5-83f4-f8e492736e5b.gif)
- I can click and drag the scroll bar from the start of the zip file (I can also use my mouse wheel).
- But, I can't click & drag the scroll bar when it's somewhere in the middle. When I do that, the scroll bar simply goes upwards! (as you can see)

**Note:** This works only while viewing zip files. Other files work just fine...

**OS**: Ubuntu 14.04 (x64)
**Atom version:** 1.0.0

<sup>**Sidenote:** I use Atom almost everyday and it's really helpful as a text editor. Thanks for making it possible! :)</sup>
Label: bug

Title: Option for zero-indexed line numbers
Body: I've always wanted zero-indexed line numbers. That's what I'm used to: other than nutty environments like Excel/AppleScript/Matlab/etc, arrays are always zero-indexed. But perplexingly no programmer's editor supports them. Zero-indexed line numbers make counting lines, sets of lines, and newline characters easier, since the line number is literally the index of the line. The correspondence is so well suited that pointer/index arithmetic carries over seamlessly. And this would be exceptionally easy to implement in the core.
Label: enhancement

Title: Undo/redo doesn't change cursor position after multiple block edit
Body:
May be related to: #6915 and #2158.

Atom: 1.0.3
OS X: 10.10.4

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open some long file (2+ pages)
2. Edit something on the top of file
3. Scroll down and edit something using multiple selection
4. Cancel multiple selection with ESC
5. Try to undo/redo changes

Cursor will be always in the same position (in the latest multiple selection place).
Label: bug

Title: Atom does not recognize git worktree repositories
Body:
When `git-repository-provider.coffee` searches for the git repository it looks for the `.git` directory, however `git worktree` creates repositories that have `.git` file that has `gitdir: path/to/gitdir` as contents. As a result atom cannot currently work with repositories created with `git worktree`. Unfortunately even making `.git` a symlink doesn't work, since worktree gitdir doesn't have `objects` or `refs` subdirectories.

Atom should recognize `.git` files that start with `gitdir:` as valid git repositories.
Label: enhancement

Title: Pop Up Showing the Opening Tag in HTML
Body:
This was the third part of the issue #7938.
#### Pop up showing the opening tag in HTML

Clicking on a closing HTML tag shows the opening tag and its class(es), id(s), line number in a popup. It would be much more helpful than using _go to the matching bracket_.

![pop-up](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11135104/8740520/6112274e-2c68-11e5-9b29-9a049a642470.gif)
Label: enhancement

Title: Make it easier to find crash reports
Body:
Atom crashed a lot for me. Normally I would post the crashes up as issues, but there were no logs, or error messages, just a generic "I've crashed" and options to close, ignore, or restart. This leaves me at a bit of a loss as to how to contribute the issue to the community, rather than just ditch atom.

I understand I can potentially get at the error messages by using the internal debugging tools, but that seems a bit obfuscated. Can't it show more information about crashes when they occur? I realise that this is a more of a hacker-oriented tool, but you're reaching wider audiences with the adverts, etc, I personally don't want to run it in dev mode 24/7 just to get info on the crashes :)

(unless there's another way of getting info on past crashes?)
Label: enhancement

Title: Handle `did-insert-text` and `will-insert-text` events in `Selection`
Body:
Text insertion is routed through `Selection` and we think it may be beneficial for the code to start emitting text related events (such as `did-insert-text` and `will-insert-text`) right there instead of `TextEditor`.

Refs: #8105
Label: enhancement

Title: Visual change to indicate when editor loses focus
Body:
I think there needs to be some visual clue when the editor pane has lost focus (eg. to the tree-view), particularly when some editor text is currently selected. Ordinarily if the editor loses focus the cursor disappears to give some indication, but when text is highlighted the cursor has already gone. If you now switch the focus to the tree-view there is no change in the editor appearance.

Highlighting then clicking on the tree-view taking focus away from the editor:
![editor_selected_text_focus](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11758299/8920195/1c0eb884-34be-11e5-829f-5dea77d2bc05.gif)

I had a couple of issues when highlighting with the intention of deleting text, then clicking on the tree-view (expand a sub-folder or something minor without changing the active file), then having been distracted, coming back to press backspace to delete the text and nearly lost a file. :( (thankful for the confirm deletion dialog! :+1:)
Label: enhancement

Title: Uncommenting block comments not behaving as expected
Body:
If a block of code is commented out, and I place my cursor within the block and press `CMD + /`, I think the desired behavior here is to uncomment it. This is how it works in Sublime and I think it's very intuitive.

This is what happens in Atom:

![block_uncomment_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9244728/8892463/63db13cc-330d-11e5-99c5-c8d4f82e2b30.gif)

I can't imagine a situation where this is ever what I needed to do. I think it would be great if the 'toggle comment' command actually uncomments code if your cursor is placed within a commented block.
Label: enhancement

Title: [feature request] Display non-breaking space character when showing invisibles.
Body:
It would be really nice if the editor displayed an "invisibles" symbol for the character UNICODE NON BREAK SPACE `U+00A0` as it most often is added by mistake and gives pretty perplexing error messages. It is currently visually indistinguishable from the normal space. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/765647/8891079/ba5cf786-3319-11e5-9786-75be7a4b618f.png)

(You can't see it but it's there...)
Label: enhancement

Title: TextEditor::pasteText does not emit did-insert-text
Body: `insertText` calls `@emitWillInsertTextEvent(text)` and later `@emitter.emit 'did-insert-text', didInsertEvent`, but `pasteText` only does the former and never the latter.
Label: bug

Title: Shrink or scroll editor when panels at bottom open up
Body:
If this has been raised before or if this is the wrong repo, please correct me. I couldn't find a previous issue for it. I've raised this issue at the atom linter repository originally, see https://github.com/atom-community/linter/issues/758, but we felt this was a more widespread issue and not the responsibility of the linter package.

Considering that [linter might get integrated into the atom core](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7353), it's probably a good idea to handle this issue in atom core anyway.

The problem is with panels that open up at the bottom of the Atom window (e.g. find & replace, linter) while you are working on code which is at the bottom of a file. These panels overlap your code when they open, hiding the code from view and forcing you to scroll up.

Type something erroneous at the bottom:
![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/aplhj66dn0mohfv/Screenshot%202015-07-21%2011.57.04.png?dl=1)

Panel shows up and overlaps your code:
![ss](https://www.dropbox.com/s/qqren1bvolmc2l9/Screenshot%202015-07-21%2011.57.35.png?dl=1)

The problem is particularly troublesome with automatically opened windows, like linter. The find & replace panel never bothered me like that, because it's triggered manually with a keyboard command, so you're not focussed on typing code anyway. But with the linter panel, you are, and it's very disturbing to have the panel suddenly show up and block your view of your code.

A proposed work around has been to enable the setting "Scroll Past End", but while this alleviates the issue a little bit, it doesn't solve it and it can still happen when you forgot to scroll further up.

A better solution would probably be for the panels to not overlap the editor window, but rather push it up causing it to shrink. I realize this might cause the opposite problem though, e.g. if you're typing at the top of the file, then that code would be pushed out of view.

Any idea's?
Label: bug

Title: Enable Dictionary lookup in OS X
Body: On OS X, the standard Dictionary service does not work (usually set to ctrl + option + D or three-finger-tap). While there is a package that provides a workaround (https://atom.io/packages/dictionary), this should not be necessary, and the system-provided version of this is much less intrusive.
Label: enhancement

Title: At the building stage, Running "download-atom-shell" task ends without errors
Body:
Atom: v1.0.2
Node: v0.12.6
npm: v2.5.1
Archlinux (4.0.7-2-ARCH, x86_64)

At the building stage (script/build), the script ends at the following task without dumping any errors:

`Running "download-atom-shell" task`

If you are facing on the same issue, it is probably due to a bug with the request module failing with users behind proxy (https://github.com/atom/node-github-releases/issues/2).

You can add the `--stack` option to the file `script/utils/run-grunt.js` to dump the hidden error to your console (@ the line 14):

`var args = ['--gruntfile', path.resolve('build', 'Gruntfile.coffee'), '--stack'];`

Then rebuild Atom thanks to the same command line `./script/build` will probably dump a similar error:

```
TypeError: Request path contains unescaped characters.
…
```

I temporary fixed the issue by removing my *_proxy env variables (bash):

`unset http_proxy https_proxy ftp_proxy HTTP_PROXY HTTPS_PROXY FTP_PROXY no_proxy NO_PROXY`

and then everything goes well:

```
Running "download-atom-shell" task
Running "download-atom-shell-chromedriver" task
Running "build" task
Running "coffee:glob_to_multiple" (coffee) task
>> 333 files created.
Running "prebuild-less:src" (prebuild-less) task
Running "cson:glob_to_multiple" (cson) task
>> 170 files compiled to JSON.
Running "peg:glob_to_multiple" (peg) task
Running "generate-license:save" (generate-license) task
Running "generate-module-cache" task
Running "compile-packages-slug" task
Running "set-version" task
Running "generate-asar" task
Done, without errors.
```

It will be preferable to definitely fix the issue by replacing the version of the `tunnel-agent` package (https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/4569#issuecomment-62051308).

Thanks.
Label: bug

Title: Add a status when Atom is downloading a new update
Body:
When I know there is a new update available for Atom, I can run "Check for Update" in the Help menu. Sometimes it is already running. The problem is lack of feedback: it seems, if it found an update, and is now downloading one, it doesn't tell the user it is doing this. Which would be useful.

Instead, as it is downloading the update, it simply looks like it is stuck checking for one. It would be nice if the Menu item could change to something like "Downloading Update (1.0.2) 43%..." or similar while it is doing this, to give feedback to the user that something is actually going on.
Label: enhancement

Title: open new file in an already open window
Body:
I'm using atom 1.0.0 in Ubuntu. 
When i run `atom nonExistantFile`, a **new window** is opened for it.
As atom is slow on start-up, that's very inconvenient. Is there an option to open in an already open window?
Label: bug

Title: editor:cut-to-end-of-line on empty line above fold deletes the whole fold
Body:
I feel there are a couple of inconsistencies with code folding. At least I can prove this one:

`editor:cut-to-end-of-line` is by default bound to `ctrl-k` on darwin, so I use it a lot for deleting current line.

The default behavoiur when cursor is on an _empty_ line is to delete the current line (delete the newline).

But if the line below is folded, that one is deleted as well (and not even cut. It's deleted). I've tried to make a demonstration in this gif. It first demonstrates normal behaviour, and then what happens when the line below is folded.

![Demo](http://zippy.gfycat.com/ShortWeightyHorseshoebat.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Soft wrap setting does not affect soft wrap when new file is opened
Body:
I've been having this problem for a while and I just `rm -rf`'ed Atom.app and `~/.atom` then installed fresh from a new download from the atom website. It still has this problem:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5728307/8814127/097705a0-2fbe-11e5-898f-ca44b30ee84b.png)

In both checked and unchecked positions of this checkbox, new documents I open still have soft wrap on by default. Even after I restart it, it still has this problem of not following the settings by default.
Label: bug

Title: One PackageManager::activate() spec fails due to local ~/.atom/styles.less file
Body:
_(See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5763#issuecomment-123460390 for more context)_

Running `apm test` from the root directory of a local clone causes the following spec to fail if `~/.atom/styles.less` exists:

```
PackageManager
  ::activate()
    it calls callbacks registered with ::onDidActivateInitialPackages
      Error: Leaking subscriptions for paths: /Users/izuzak/.atom/styles.less
        at ensureNoPathSubscriptions (/Users/izuzak/github/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:194:15)
        at [object Object].<anonymous> (/Users/izuzak/github/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:187:3)
```

If the file doesn't exist, the spec doesn't fail.

cc @kevinsawicki
Label: bug

Title: DisplayMarker doesn't dispatch a change event when a line gets wrapped
Body:
Here's a demonstration: 

![marker-change](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/8806074/2f921bfa-2fd5-11e5-98a6-4a66b857ac5a.gif)

I've attached a listener to the change event of a marker created using `TextEditor::markBufferRange`. As you can see in the console, I do receive the event when adding/removing lines but not when the line I'm editing gets wrapped.

As the range of the underlying buffer marker did not change, it doesn't emit a change event. But the screen range of the display marker did change, so I believe it should emit an event on its own in this case.
Label: bug

Title: click-to-open on package URLs tries/fails to open non-existent Chromium, then proceeds to DE's default/defined webbrowser
Body:
I run 

```
atom --version
    1.0.3-bb1fa7f
iojs -v
    v2.4.0
node -v
    v2.4.0
npm -v
    2.13.0
node-gyp -v
    v2.0.2
```

on

```
lsb_release -rd
    Description:    openSUSE 13.2 (Harlequin) (x86_64)
    Release:        13.2
uname -rm
    4.1.2-1.g5ccacb4-desktop x86_64
rpm -qa | grep -i plasma5-desk
    plasma5-desktop-5.3.91git~20150713T211720~61fe1bc-108.1.x86_64
```

It's launched as

```
/usr/bin/kdesu /usr/local/atom/bin/atom -w
```

If I list installed or available packages in the UI, and click on any item to open the URL, a dialog is opened every time

> Chromium can not be run as root.
> 
> Please start Chromium as normal user. To run as root, you must specify an 
> alternate --user-data-dir for storage of profile information.

If I click "OK", the URL is then simply correctly opened in my DE's default browser, Firefox.

Chromium does not exist on this machine.  It's never been installed.  It is not assigned as an option in any FileAssociation, nor is it set as Default browser. For any user on this machine, root or otherwise.

Title: editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor('link') returns undefined
Body:
How to reproduce, given an empty markdown file:

``` markdown
[link](http://example.com)_
```

Where `_` represents the cursor position (at the end of the link)

And I try to get the buffer range for scope `link`:

``` javascript
editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()

// check link scope selector is there
cursor = editor.getLastCursor()
cursor.getScopeDescriptor().getScopesArray()
// => ["source.gfm", "link", "markup.underline.link.gfm", "punctuation.definition.end.gfm"]

// since link scope is there, when i try to get the buffer range
editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor('link')
// => undefined
editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor('markup.underline.link.gfm')
// => undefined
```
Label: bug

Title: setting to open files as tabs/windows
Body: While many voted for the changes in #3355, there should be an option to select the behaviour of Atom when opening individual, unrelated files (e.g. from the Terminal or dropping onto the dock icon in OS X). There could be a simple checkbox in the settings to "open files in new window", which restores the previous behaviour.

Title: Branch undo
Body:
One very useful feature that vim has is undo branching. This feature can be a real life saver. Let's say I make some changes, undo them, and then start typing again, only to realize that I needed some of those other changes. Without undo branches, those changes are gone. With them, I am free from worry about losing work!

See: http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Using_undo_branches

It would be so nice for Atom to have this as well!
Label: enhancement

Title: [Feature request] Dialog with unsaved changes should accept "Don't save all"
Body: Hey, when working on a large project I often find myself opening lots of files that I often forgot to close (and sometimes they are deleted from the filesystem while still being opened). When I am about to close the project, I need to click "Don't save" more than 30 times to close it. It would be really nice to have "No to all" option that I can just click (in my case, I am using source control so I am pretty sure all changes I wanted to save were already committed). That's the dialog I am talking about:
Label: enhancement

Title: Showing line numbers disables sub-pixel AA on tabs, status-bar etc.
Body:
In https://github.com/atom/one-dark-ui/issues/82, @wiox noticed that sub-pixel anti aliasing is not only disabled for the tabs, but also on the fuzzy finder and the status bar.

![sub-pixel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/8694250/9299865a-2b18-11e5-8f8d-936466ccedf6.png)

It seems it's caused by the line number tiles getting promoted to a GPU layer and probably related to #7101. Kinda strange that it affects different areas.

Something that might be worth looking into is using `will-change`. It also adds a GPU layer for the line numbers, but doesn't affect the rest. Notice the orange "composited layer borders" only appear in the status bar with `-webkit-transform: translate3d(0px, 0px, 0px);` but not with `will-change: transform;`.

![tiles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/8694309/0dae2350-2b19-11e5-8506-7201ba42ae5e.gif)

Now, I _heard_ that `will-change` should only be used when interacting, like on hover or so.. and not kept permanently enabled. So not sure if that would help. /cc @as-cii @nathansobo 

**Edit:** Sorry, I just realized that the `transform` is needed to actually move line numbers. So can't be replaced. :grin:
Label: bug

Title: [Bug] Several language fonts (Japanese, Chinese, Hebrew, ...) not displaying in Ubuntu 14.04+ with Atom v1.0.2
Body:
Does anyone use Atom with foreign characters (e.g. Japanese)? I found one post on this, but no one had replied (https://discuss.atom.io/t/japanese-encoding/17871)

Is there a package to install or something? I have Japanese Anthy installed, so I can type Japanese characters in other programs (LibreOffice, Chrome, etc), and I'm saving in UTF-8. Just in Atom these characters appear as squares.
Label: bug

Title: Vertical resize only/resize to fit content
Body:
Feature suggestion: on OS X general window resizing behaviour is to resize the window to fit the content inside (reduce scrollbars) instead of filling the entire screen (for example Finder, Chrome). The advantage is that the maximum amount of needed space for the text window is used (leaving little empty background) while leaving screen real estate for other apps/windows.

This would be a use preference. 
Scaling options would be to scale to fit content (longest line) or to fit word wrap boundary (wrapping long lines in the process). 
The resize process would scale to fit horizontally and scale to fit the screen height vertically.
Label: enhancement

Title: zoomFontWhenCtrlScrolling causes surprising behavior when pressing Ctrl with inertial scrolling
Body:
Due to inertial scrolling, `mousewheel` events may continue to be fired even after the user has stopped "actively" scrolling. This is expected. What may be surprising is that while this inertial scrolling is happening, pressing/holding Ctrl will behave the same as if the user is "actively" scrolling.

Try this on a Mac to see how surprising it feels: enable zoomFontWhenCtrlScrolling, then quickly swipe up/down on your trackpad in a file. Shortly after, hold Ctrl. Due to the file still being scrolled, the font size starts changing.

It seems like zoomFontWhenCtrlScrolling handling could be "smarter" about detecting whether the user intended this by detecting whether Ctrl was pressed first or if scrolling was already happening before Ctrl was pressed.
Label: enhancement

Title: Highlight code folding section on mouse over
Body:
Similar to https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/issues/30 but with code folding.

Here's a feature currently present in the Kate text editor that I think would be a great addition to Atom. When you hover your mouse over the code folding icons, it highlights the section that will be folded to give a quick and easy visual indicator.

Here's a screenshot:

![code_folding_highlight_crop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/901732/8658870/c3dd9488-2963-11e5-9993-b91b5874cfdc.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Creating a new pane without cloning the current file
Body:
When I create a new pane, it automatically pops with the file of the previous pane I was in. I’d like to pop an empty pane – a bit like in `vim`, because I always load another file and close the duplicated one each time, and that’s boring.

Is there already something to fix that? Thanks.
Label: enhancement

Body:

I had the vim-mode package installed but disabled. I manually clicked the "update package" button (not the "update all" button). After the package had been updated, it seemed that it re-enabled itself. I would have expected it to remain disabled.

Not a large issue but might catch some people out if they had a larger number of disabled packages.

Title: Opening nonexistent file should provide feedback to the user
Body:
Exactly as the title says, when the user tries to open a file that doesn't exist, they should be presented with some sort of warning message / feedback that it is a new file. If the file name was misspelled, the user could have the false assumption that the file contents were emptied.

Steps to reproduce:
1. File > Open
2. Type random text as the file name and click "Open"
3. Bask in the silence
Label: enhancement

Using Atom 1.0.1 on Windows.

When summoning a context menu with the keyboard menu key, expected behavior (from visual studio, sublime, google docs, etc) is for the menu to be rooted at the input cursor. Instead, the Atom context menu is rooted at the position of the mouse cursor.

![atom-cm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10780590/8635149/f51dd40a-27f0-11e5-988d-7057a6106984.png)

In the picture, the context menu should be positioned with the input cursor on the misspelled word.

Title: Atom on ARM Information
Body:
_Hi :wave: This issue is an informational issue about the state of running Atom on computers with ARM processors (like those in Raspberry Pis and some Chromebooks)._

---

**Atom does not _effectively_ work on ARM** (July 9th, 2015)

![atom-10-launch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1305617/8609239/94cbf112-2657-11e5-8381-d6b5c74e6bd7.png)

It does, however, now _build_ and _launch_ on ARM (see image above from ARM Chromebook). This is due to the fact that [Electron](http://github.com/atom/electron), as of `v0.29.0` now builds an [ARM compatible distribution](https://github.com/atom/electron/releases/tag/v0.29.0) :sparkles: (as an aside, this is really, really great news for future applications and tinkerers). But the latest versions of Electron use a newer version of Chrome and have not been tested against Atom which [currently uses](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/package.json#L15) `v.22.3` of Electron (at this time Electron was still named Atom-Shell). Typing and clicking don't work at all and/or trigger lots of exception notifications and render the application pretty useless. This could be because of the new Electron compatibility issues, but we can't be quite sure as we don't really know yet what those issues are. 

**What will it take to get there?**

These errors will have to be sorted out and fixed. This is not on any roadmap right now and could be a lot of work (patches welcome! :raised_hands:). Getting Atom upgraded to the latest Electron will help answer this question but it's not there just yet (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6877). 

It's worth noting that  even if Atom were on the latest Electron, you will still need to build it yourself because it requires some other adjustments (see below). 

**Want to try it out?**

Maybe it will _just work_ on your machine! I have a [gist with the steps](https://gist.github.com/jlord/7ffaf94d041982346934) to build. It involves using forks of both apm (Atom's package manager) and Atom so that you can build apm with [io.js](https://iojs.org) instead of Node.js since the later does not support ARM.
Label: enhancement

Title: Cannot open files or folders on Mac OS X El Capitan beta
Body:
You cannot open a file or folder on Mac OS X El Capitan. This has been the case with the first, second and current third developer release.

Also, after opening the file dialog, cancel does not close it. Command Q does, then Command Q to close Atom. 

Interestingly, Visual Studio Code, built on the same Electron code base, runs perfectly fine on these builds of Mac OS X El Capitan.
Label: bug

Title: Support for keymap text in context menu
Body: If you have a keymap for a specific action and that action is used in a context menu, I would like the keymap to display right-justified on the context menu entry. This seems to work for file menu items, just not context menu items.
Label: enhancement

Title: `BufferedProcess` doesn't yield an error running a not existing command on Windows
Body:
According to this [spec](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/spec/buffered-process-spec.coffee#L15-L31) `BufferedProcess` should call the handler defined using `onWillThrowError` if the spawned command doesn't exist. However, this is not the case on my Windows box.

Since the command is spawned in a sub-shell `cmd.exe` (which is an aweful default setup, this should be optional), the handler is never called but the default error message of `cmd.exe` is logged on `stderr` and the process (in this case `cmd.exe`) exits with status code `1`. This means the above mentioned spec should fail running on Windows, which seems to me like a bug in `BufferedProcess`.
Label: bug

Title: Suppress display of end-of-file newlines as blank lines
Body: Atom by default inserts a new line (a line break actually) at the end of file (and it's cool), but it also shows this newline as an empty line at the end of file, but it's prefereably don't do this. How can I fix this? Thank you very much.
Label: enhancement

Title: Opening single file when Atom is not open – existing projects and open files are closed/removed
Body:
1. Have some project folders in the sidebar and some open files. When you start Atom by itself, these are always restored.
2. Close Atom
3. Open a single txt file

**Expected:** The project folders and open files from last time are restored, and the new single file is open in a new, now focused tab. Exactly what happens when you open a single file while Atom is already open.

**What actually happens:** The project folders are wiped, as are the open files. The sidebar just shows the parent folder tree of the newly opened file, and only a single tab for said file.
Label: enhancement

Title: 'atom is not defined' is thrown when opening an 'atom://' URL
Body:
Whenever I try to open an 'atom://' URL, I get this exception in the console:

```
ReferenceError: atom is not defined
    at Function.module.exports.Package.isBundledPackagePath (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package.coffee:31:11)
    at Function.module.exports.Package.loadMetadata (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package.coffee:61:16)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.getAvailablePackageMetadata (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package-manager.coffee:252:128)
    at AtomApplication.module.exports.AtomApplication.openUrl (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/browser/atom-application.coffee:769:35)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/browser/atom-application.coffee:406:24)
    at emitTwo (events.js:87:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:169:7)
'
```

Apparently atom is not defined in https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/5dee3ce5950d972d3f275ad1a93d62f542d42aeb/src/package.coffee#L22. Interestingly, atomApplication is defined and contains the properties needed by isBundledPackagePath().
Simply adding `atom = global.atom || global.atomApplication` at the beginning of isBundledPackagePath() fixes this, but there may be an underlying issue that needs to be addressed here.
Label: bug

Title: Preserve CSON formatting
Body:
This one may be a long shot, but I'd still like to mention it.  Is there any way to preserve the formatting of a CSON configuration file whenever Atom needs to write and save to it?

The reason I mention it, is because I'm a big fan of having comments in config files so I know what each config does, and it also helps with organization and readability.

Say this is my `config.cson`

``` cson
#
# Config
#

'*':
    # --- MAIN ---

    # WELCOME
    welcome:
        showOnStartup: false

    # CORE
    core:
        disabledPackages: [
            'autocomplete-plus'
            'wrap-guide'
        ]
        themes: [
            'one-dark-ui'
            'solarized-dark-syntax'
        ]

    # EDITOR
    editor:
        invisibles: {}
        tabLength: 4


    # --- PACKAGES ---

    # REPORTING
    'exception-reporting':
        userId: 'ddaafd07-dffd-b252-48db-612909a97759'

    # BRACKET MATCHER
    'bracket-matcher':
        autocompleteBrackets: false
        autocompleteSmartQuotes: false

    # WHITESPACE
    whitespace:
        ensureSingleTrailingNewline: false
```

Once Atom saves it, it's changed to this:

``` cson
"*":
  welcome:
    showOnStartup: false
  core:
    disabledPackages: [
      "autocomplete-plus"
      "wrap-guide"
    ]
    themes: [
      "one-dark-ui"
      "solarized-dark-syntax"
    ]
  editor:
    invisibles: {}
    tabLength: 4
  "exception-reporting":
    userId: "ddaafd07-dffd-b252-48db-612909a97759"
  "bracket-matcher":
    autocompleteBrackets: false
    autocompleteSmartQuotes: false
  whitespace:
    ensureSingleTrailingNewline: false
```

I completely understand the reason for why it happens, which is why I said it's a long shot.  But I think one of the nice things about having our own custom configs is being able to organize it the way we want, so if there could be any way to preserve it that would be great.
Label: enhancement

Title: "Search Issues" menu item doesn't work when not signed in into GitHub Website
Body:
The Help / Search Issues menu item opens https://github.com/issues?q=+is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom in a browser. If I've not signed in into GitHub beforehand, this link returns a 404 for me.

I understand that you want users to search in _all_ Atom-related repositories, but it's probably more user-friendly to open https://github.com/atom/atom/issues instead, which works for anonymous users as well.

Probably the best solution would be for GitHub not to return a 404 but to redirect to the Sign In page instead. And you folks _are_ GitHub, right? :smiley: 

(Atom 1.0.0, Xubuntu 15.04)
Label: enhancement

Title: ATOM erases PATH Variable when installing on Win7
Body:
When I installed ATOM 1.0.0 and one of the previous versions on Windows7 using the Windows installer it erased the user PATH Variable instead of appending it to the existing PATH variable, which is kind of annoying. Sorry I forgot which was the version I installed before, but that behaviour is still present in 1.0.0.
Not sure if this behaviour is intended, I sincerely hope not!

Cheers,
Jan
Label: bug

Title: Add support for disabling context menu items
Body:
I don't see a way in the contextMenu.add API to dynamically disable/re-enable a menu item: https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.0.0/ContextMenuManager#instance-add. 

Can we get a way to disable (shown but not selectable) and enable context menu items? Something like .shouldEnable(event) - takes a function with event?
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature Request: Pressing `esc` on multiple cursors returns you to original cursor location.
Body:
After selecting multiple words by pressing `cmd-d` multiple times, then pressing `esc` key to go back to a single cursor, it seems to place the single cursor at the position of the last cursor that was added.  I would like it to place the single cursor at the original selection.

Explanation:
I got used to Sublime positioning the single cursor at the original cursor location.  At first, I thought it was an arbitrary decision and that I would adjust to atom's way of doing it.  Now I've decided that it's not entirely subjective.  In many cases, my original cursor was intentionally placed at the original position, and that's where I would like it to return to.  For example, maybe I was editing something in-line and thought that this particular word (variable name) I was editing should be edited in a few places at the same time.  After doing this, I would like to return to my original train of thought - editing that line that I was on before creating multiple selections.  I would also think that in any cases where I didn't intentionally place my cursor on a particular instance, the decision is arbitrary whether it takes me to the original or final cursor upon pressing `esc`, so this might be a safe change to make for all use cases.  At least an option for altering this behavior would be much-appreciated.
Label: enhancement

Title: The async repositoryForDirectory calls directory.getRealPathSync()
Body:
There should be an async `getRealPath()` in https://github.com/atom/node-pathwatcher/blob/master/src/directory.coffee and that be called here instead.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/645139f452a7a261a77c6413ec4c1fe9cfee6cf5/src/project.coffee#L144

This doesn't work for the remote development use case, because you can't get the real path of a directory synchronously (could be a symlink).

/cc @maxbrunsfeld @bolinfest
Label: enhancement

Title: window:show-next-item, window:show-previous-item
Body: Now we can move with shortcuts to next/preview tab only inside focused pane with `pane:show-previous-item, pane:show-next-item`. It will be useful if we have global window shortcuts for moving to next/preview tab through all panes. Something like `window:show-next-item, window:show-previous-item`. This shortcuts must work on window level no matter where focus is. (for example if focus on tree-view)
Label: enhancement

Title: Confusing project path on windows bar
Body:
Hey,
When more than one projects are opened on the editor, if we edit a file on the project added after the first one, the path shown just after the name of the opened file in the windows title bar is always the path of the first opened project.
This can cause confusion for the user if the same file name is present in multiple projects.

Step to reproduce:
- Add projectA, and projectB.
- Open a file on projectB.
- Look at the windows title bar :
  `file - /home/statelesscat/projetAPath - Atom`
Label: bug
