Title: Unsaved changes lost if permission denied when saving on exit
Body:
If I open a file that I do not have permission to save and try to save it I get a popup telling me I lack permissions, e.g. `Unable to save file: permission denied '/etc/hosts'`. This seems reasonable (although I wish it would ask me for my sudo password instead).
However, if I modify it and then close it, Atom will ask me if I want to save it, and when I click "yes", it closes the file and gives me that same popup that it failed to save. This means my work is lost. I don't think I have used an editor before that doesn't keep the file open if it fails to save and I believe this should be considered a bug, right?

I am on Chakra linux running 1.0.0 via http://chakraos.org/ccr/packages.php?ID=7252
Label: bug

Title: Allow separate config for dev mode
Body:
As I was working on https://github.com/atom/atom-dark-ui/pull/48, I realized that it would be really helpful to have a window with Atom Dark UI _and_ a window with One Dark UI up at the same time, to be able to compare differences in styling between the two. 

Currently that's not possible, because dev mode windows necessarily share the same config with regular Atom windows, so changing the theme in one window will always change the theme in all windows.

It would be awesome if you could scope config to dev mode, so you can tailor Atom as needed for your development windows.
Label: enhancement

Title: Toggle Soft Tabs command: tweaks for improved user experience
Body:
When toggling soft tabs through the command palette, there's no UI feedback about if it worked and what the new state is.  The only way to tell is to turn on invisible characters and try hitting tab.

Suggestions:
- emit a notification which displays the new state of the setting
- add two new commands "Enable soft tabs" and "Disable soft tabs" to avoid this issue altogether
- an icon in the status bar showing softness of tabs?

Also, the command could be named "Toggle Soft Tabs **In Current Editor**" since this local behavior may be surprising -- the soft tabs checkbox in settings is a global setting.
Label: enhancement

Title: ctrl-delete does not remove CRLF
Body:
By `ctrl-delete` I mean `editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary`, `editor:delete-to-end-of-word` or  `editor:select-to-beginning-of-word` (which is probably used by the first two commands).

I.e. when issuing the above commands in this position:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5153846/8487587/5285ae6e-210d-11e5-868b-e41bb9378dd0.png)

**Nothing** happens, the `CRLF` windows line-ending is not consumed.

Linux's `LF` works fine, though (`editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary`):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5153846/8487775/7565e1b4-210e-11e5-9206-085256a411e9.png)

Also, the other way round (`editor:delete-to-previous-word-boundary` etc.) works fine.

Windows 7, Atom 1.0
Label: bug

Title: When a file change is detected retry loading it when locked
Body:
```
Unable to read file after file change event. Make sure you have permission to access C:\CI-Cor\ks\bolt\build\ConfigStatusBolt.py.
EBUSY: resource busy or locked, open 'C:\CI-Cor\ks\bolt\build\ConfigStatusBolt.py'

```
Label: bug

Title: Atom hangs when "}" is deleted when editing .thrift file
Label: bug

Title: Invalid packages settings because of config.cson
Body:
For example,
I install the package `xpto` and this package has two settings declared on init.coffee `foo` and `bar`. And then I decide to change the value of `foo`. So my preference will be stored on config.cson. But after a while the package developer decides to deprecate the setting `foo` and removes the setting `foo` from package settings. Now when I go to the settings page of `xpto` package I will still see the `foo` setting because it is still stored on config.cson. 

Shouldn't Atom at boot check if there is any dead/invalid settings from packages?
Label: enhancement

Title: Sign Linux releases
Body: Could you please provide a signed checksums file or sign the files themselves for releases so we can cryptographically verify them.  Thanks
Label: enhancement

Title: Path doesn't update in title bar when current working directory changes
Body:
Tested on OS X Yosemite:

The path shown in Atom's title bar when current working directory changes. For example:

```
mkdir TestDeletion
atom TestDeletion
```

Then move the `TestDeletion` directory to the trash.

I would also recommend somehow indicating it is in the .Trash, but I'm not gonna put that in as an issue.

I also had an issue deleting a directory once (as some .pack and .idx files were open?), but I haven't been able to duplicate that yet.
Label: bug

Title: Deactivate multiple cursors feature (on Ctrl+mouse click)
Body:
I searched already several times but I cannot find out how to deactivate multiple cursors or how to change/deactivate the key binding. Finally, I open the issue here.

If there is an option for this, how could I possibly find it; or rather, how can I find and search available configuration options in my version of the editor?
The compiled coffeescript may make it hard to find options by using `grep`.
Label: enhancement

Title: Cannot install shell commands if no window is open
Body:
Atom 1.0.0
Mac OS X 10.10.3

_Description_

If there are no windows open, the menu command **Atom > Install Shell Commands** is not available. This command should always be available.

_Step to Reproduce_
1. Launch Atom
2. Close all windows
3. From menu bar, choose **Atom > Install Shell Commands**

_Expected Behavior_

The command should be available (black text).

_Observed Behavior_

The command is not available (gray text).
Label: bug

Title: "Save" or "Save All" on unmodified, opened files results in "Unable to save file: permission denied" error
Body: When working with a project under Perforce revision control, it is normal for unmodified files to be read-only on the file system.  Currently, I get several errors when I do "Save All" when I have several unmodified files open.  It would be nice to not get the error when the files are unmodified.  There are cases where there be several opened files, some modified and some not.  "Save all" would only have to save the modified files.  Of course, if the modified files are still read-only, it makes sense to report the "Unable to save file" error.
Label: enhancement

Title: Window position not remembered after Reload
Body:
Atom 1.0, Mac OS 10.10.

Steps to reproduce:
- Launch Atom
- Move the Atom window to a secondary monitor and resize the Atom window
- Go to View > Reload
- (BUG) When Atom is reloaded it's moved back to it's original position and size

Expected behaviour:
- Atom should remember where the user can moved the window and what size it was between reloads

This is not an issue on Windows (where the window reloads in the correct location). Not sure if this is Atom-specific or an issue with Electron.
Label: bug

Title: Ctrl+<arrow> move of line should update its indentation
Body:
Being able to move a line with Ctrl+arrow is very useful.

I suggest this feature be improved so the line matches the indentation in its new scope, e.g. being "unindented" if moving out of a FOR loop.
Label: enhancement

Title: Possible to accept commands/key bindings without Atom window?
Body:
For example when using the [Atom project manager](https://github.com/danielbrodin/atom-project-manager), it's very inconvenient that when you've closed all your windows and want to open a new project, you have to open a new Atom window first before the command to open a new project can be used.

Seeing how this command is more of a "global" command, and shouldn't really need a window, is it possible for Atom to somehow accept such commands without window (but with the app itself having focus) and just open a new window as needed?

The work around now is to either remember not to close your last project window, open a new project, and then switch back to close the last one, or close all of them, open a new window, and then open a new project. Since opening a new window takes quite a bit of time to load, it's a bit of a hassle whichever way you do it, and it would be much more optimal if you could just open an existing project, and for that command to open the new window for you.
Label: enhancement

Title: Move cursor when transposing characters
Body:
One subtle but unexpectedly cool feature of Emacs's "transpose" functionality is that it moves the cursor.  As of 1.0.0, Atom doesn't do that.  But it allows me to move a character by using transpose.

If you position the cursor to the right of x and then invoke transpose multiple times, you get the following.  (First line shows the starting point, second line shows after the first transpose, third line after the second transpose, and so on.)

```
aXbcde
abXcde
abcXde
abcdXe
```

Note that the user has just used <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, no other key was pressed.  In Atom, I have to <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, <kbd>right</kbd>, <kbd>Ctrl-T</kbd>, <kbd>right</kbd>, ... to achieve the same effect.

This is related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5410 which also asks to improve the behavior of transpose.
Label: enhancement

Title: Selects are rendered unusable with HiDPI scaling
Body:
#### Summary

The theme chooser does not appear to work on my system. I cannot select a theme.
#### Setup

Ubuntu 15.04 with atom 1.0.0 amd64 freshly installed from .deb package. 
#### Observed behaviour

Themes show up in the list of Core Themes and Installed Themes. However, when I click the drop-down selectors for UI Theme and Syntax Theme, they only show an empty white box, with 'One Dark' remaining selected.
![screenshot from 2015-06-28 09 53 40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7723154/8395764/8a14958c-1d7c-11e5-91b7-4b53dd41e2b0.png)
#### Expected behaviour

I would have expected the names of installed themes to appear in the drop-down box so that I could select another theme.
#### Notes

Not sure if this is relevant or a separate bug, but searching for themes using the 'filter themes by name' box does not return any themes.
Label: bug

Title: Freeze when changing file encoding
Body:
I opened a subtitle file with Turkish (Windows 1254) encoding in Atom, and it opened it as UTF-8 by default.

Then I tried changing the encoding to Turkish (Windows 1254), but the editor froze and even displayed a dialog saying that it's not responding. I pressed on "Keep waiting" and after a while the file was re-loaded with my selected encoding.

It's very very slow... not even usable. 

Atom 1.0.0
Machine: Intel i7 4790K with 16GB RAM.
OS: Mac OS X 10.10.3

Sample file to reproduce:
http://www.filedropper.com/dannycollins2015720pweb-dldd51h264-playnow
Label: bug

Title: 'Toggle Developer Tools' doesn't toggle if opened in separate window
Body: Typing cmd-alt-I or selecting View -> Developer -> Toggle Developer Tools displays the developer tools just fine.  But it doesn't hide them.
Label: enhancement

Title: Touch version of Atom for mobile OSes
Body:
A touch version of atom with builds for jail broken iOS devices and Android devices.

This will probably take a lot of work to get done but would be worth it. Since atom is a web technology based in nature just making it touch capable would be the only thing needed.

This could be done as a separate branch of Atom and also a version that doesn't have as much of the hack ability as the regular version for release on the iOS App Store.

The iOS version would have to support x-callback-urls for compatibility with coding apps that have them like an app called Working Copy which is a great Git client for iOS.
Label: enhancement

Title: pane resize handles overflow over editors
Body:
If you have a vertical split, the resize handle overflows to the right, possibly over an adjacent editor. This messes with drag-select. I haven't found out how to solve this. 

The layout to reproduce this:

```
---------------------
|         |         |
+---------|         |
|         |         |
---------------------
```

cc @simurai 

![screen shot 2015-06-26 at 10 52 04](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2543659/8373997/fff9d38e-1bf1-11e5-92d5-c23ddedaa700.png)
Label: bug

Title: Windows uninstallation is too silent
Body: When uninstalling Atom from the Windows control panel, after clicking "uninstall", absolutely nothing appears to happen. Then, several seconds later, the "Atom" entry suddenly disappears from the list of installed packages. This total lack of feedback is not very user-friendly, IMO.
Label: enhancement

Title: cmd+n should default to cmd+shift+n when no windows are open on OS X
Body:
Atom: 1.0
Mac OS X: 10.10.3

On OS X, if you close all windows so only the menubar is active, cmd+n does nothing at all. It should default to cmd+shift+n if no windows are open in Atom.app.

Apple mention suggestions for default keys here: http://support.apple.com/kb/HT1343
Label: enhancement

Title: Pinning Atom to the Windows taskbar duplicates the icon
Body: Since 0.210.0, it appears that Atom gets two icons instead of just one if Atom is pinned to the Windows taskbar. Clicking the pinned icon will open another icon that represents the running app. I would expect the first instance of Atom to reuse the pinned icon rather than adding a new one.
Label: bug

Title: Bundle linter in the core
Body:
Atom is a Code Editor/IDE for Developers and those developers make mistakes. A base linter provider is something that everyone needs. There was a time when `linter` API and codebase wasn't shiny enough for it to be made a part of core.

But now we have rebuilt the `linter` package from the ground and consumed the latest technologies (i.e services) to provide API to linters. It's [API](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus/wiki/Linter-API) and other docs can be found in the [linter-plus](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus) wiki. It's API is inspired from the awesome `autocomplete-plus`. The rewrite also features a completely new UI based on suggestions from the AtomLinter Org members and styles from @simurai . Furthermore it accepts anonymous objects as messages allowing the providers to write unit-tests.

It also has a UI to show errors from the current file or project. Which is very important for the Nuclide IDE and project-based languages like FlowJS, HackLang and others. and the Error Objects can contain traces that expand over the lines. It is also extremely easy to style. and It doesn't have to save a temp file to disk to lint files. It also supports `lintOnFly` and `onSave` linters.

It even exports it's self service to packages who have daemons in separate processes and want to trigger lint without waiting for a save or change in the buffer. Also in the tooltip and bottom panel are positions that user can click on and be directed to the file:line:col instead of just jumping to the next error.

All these features remove all of the known limitations of old `linter` package.
**Note:** It's also backward compatible, so all the linters using the old API will still work.

Here is how it looks like at the moment
![screenshot from 2015-06-20 19 09 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4278113/8269940/e232c69c-177f-11e5-8710-8b2acf1380fb.png)

There are a lot of packages that have re-invented the wheel and written their own error UIs. If we merge `linter` in the core, all those packages can consume a similar API and eventually reduce their code complexity.

Things to be done
- [ ] Make the code shine bright (We have been working [hard](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus/graphs) on this one)
- [ ] Move it to the `atom` org.

Let us know what you guys think.
Label: enhancement

Title: Proposal: Improve tab titles when opening files with the same name
Body:
When opening multiple files with the same base name (but in different directories) it is hard to distinguish which tab is associated with which file. Currently, when Atom detects that multiple files with the same name are opened it appends the complete project path after the filename, but it is cut off (making it not very helpful). The user must use their mouse to hover over the tab to know the full path. I think the logic can be improved by including the parent directory name to the left of the file name as shown below:
# One tab

![one-tab](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/978214/8258063/4da379d8-166f-11e5-937f-e7b1e8f9413f.png)
# Two tabs (current)

![two-tabs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/978214/8258067/517bbc5a-166f-11e5-88a9-867c8e91acdc.png)
# Two tabs (proposed)

![two-tabs-good](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/978214/8258068/53509da2-166f-11e5-8e08-a6bc5552ba23.png)

Thoughts?
Label: enhancement

Title: strange behaviour when pasting
Body:
I'm copying and pasting text from a PDF.
(I will post images because it seems the Github's textarea also converts characters)

This is the text on the PDF
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226483/8249657/33c6e550-1632-11e5-917c-edc6457a8eae.png)

Look at the word `podría`.

This is what I get when pasting in Sublime
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226483/8249663/3f3f8ff4-1632-11e5-9427-91a66723f379.png)

This is what I get when pasting in Atom
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226483/8249678/680fd8d0-1632-11e5-80a0-f519f7b0d599.png)

The problem is that this character  `i´` that you can see in Sublime breaks something in Atom. Look where the cursor is when I paste.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226483/8249722/c0fadca6-1632-11e5-9ffa-4c8deb669258.png)

Also I press space where the cursor is, and look where the spaces are added.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226483/8249756/0ca1000e-1633-11e5-8810-0f0309209a3d.png)

This diabolical character triggers a Gremlin mode in Atom!

If I remove the character  `i´` in Sublime and then paste in Atom, everything goes back to normal.
Label: bug

Title: Wrong Folding Operation
Body:
Originally reported by @maxbrunsfeld:

> I'm seeing another weird gutter behavior, and I'm wondering if you think it's the same bug. Occasionally the fold buttons in the gutter cause incorrect fold operations:
> 
> ![fold-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/8244236/4c4d7c6a-15d3-11e5-8876-10ecb7d95a8e.gif)
> 
> Unfolding works as expected, but when I click the fold icon next to line 9 to create a fold, instead of creating a fold at line 9, it scrolls the editor slightly, and then creates a fold at line 6.
> 
> Creating folds from the keyboard (via editor:fold-current-row) works correctly, so the problem seems to be related to the gutter.
> 
> This only happens to me intermittently. Is there any code that I can run when I get into this state to verify whether or not it's the same bug?

I am able to reproduce this similarly to the bug we had in #7306:
- Write a few paragraphs of text (ensure it enables vertical scrolling).
- Scroll to the very bottom.
- Split the pane (I split it right, but I think left or anything else will do).
- Ensure that splitting the pane has caused the editor on the left to scroll up.
- Scroll the left panel again to the very bottom.
- Close the right panel.
- Fold any line.
- The wrong line was folded. :boom:
Label: bug

Title: Add Resize - Panel Keyboard Commands
Body:
References: https://github.com/santip/resize-panes/issues/21#issuecomment-113251749 

Before the resize-pane project was consumed by core it had shortcuts for resizing the panes. I know many people here use the mouse to resize, but this was a **key** feature for those of us who love the speed of the keyboard. 

Can we add this back somehow? 

@mnquintana
Label: enhancement

Title: Uninstalling on Windows "forgets" to remove Explorer context menu item.
Body:
I used your official installer, downloaded yesterday. I uninstalled today, rebooted, but the "Open with Atom" context menu item is still there.

Please provide detailed instructions on how to remove it, fix your uninstaller and let me know if there is other stuff left around that must be removed manually.

I find this kind of issue particularly annoying: if all programs would do the same, the Explorer context menu would need three monitors stacked vertically to be displayed.

Title: Renaming a file closes it
Body:
- **Behaviour expected**: renaming a file keeps the file with it's new name opened.
- **Behaviour found**: the file is closed and you have to open it manually.
- **Main problem**: if you have not an opened project you have to search again for the file in order to open it.
- **Errors**: no error found at developer tools or running Atom from console.
- **Tested on**: Atom 0.209.0 installed on Archlinux from Aur.

Use case:
![Renaming file closes it](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/800645/8200424/1ed8fbce-14c5-11e5-9539-921e50ebfa10.jpg)
Label: bug

Title: Open file by clicking on some/file/path:columnNumber should search among all open files first
Body:
I can open a file in atom by clicking on some file path in console output like this:

```
# ./spec/models/user.rb:42:in `block (6 levels) in <top (required)>'
```

Click on `./spec/models/user.rb:42` -> atom open this file and travels to the line 42. 
If I have this file opened already then it just goes to the line 42. But not always.
It works like this only if this file is located in the active(last used) pane in atom. But if I'll activate (just click inside) another pane and then click on the path in console output then atom will open the file in a new tab in that pane.

I think it would be much more convenient if it will search for the file among all panes before opening the file in a new tab.
Label: enhancement

Title: Frequent recurring freezing on Windows
Body:
I am getting random freezes and crashes on Windows 7. I am using Atom version 0.209.0.

Freezing occurs randomly (i.e. not all the time) when:
- changing values in the settings window.
- opening files (infrequent, big files seem to cause crashes more often).
- installing packages
- uninstalling packages
- closing tabs

I can't find any log files to get more information. The program is completely unresponsive and devtools console is not updated.
Label: bug

Title: Better indicate preview tab
Body:
It would be clearer to indicate preview tab by adding some visual effects.
This allows user to easily distinguish from normal tabs.
e.g. A different background color, text color or adding a special symbol.
Label: enhancement

Title: Thin or small fonts rendered on Windows appear colorfully blurry.
Body:
![Image of blurry/colorful font rendering](http://i.imgur.com/Crkn7gz.png)

Until looking through the code, I had thought Atom was using Microsoft's WPF graphics rendering interface for the GUI. In which case the solution is simply setting the text-formatting option to "Display" rather than the default "Ideal".

www.hanselman.com/blog/WPFAndTextBlurrinessNowWithCompleteClarity.aspx

I don't know what's causing blurry fonts on Atom, but it's certainly not my system configuration to blame; I'm not using any unusual settings/hardware; default DPI with a 1440x900 display. Other software (Notepad++, Visual Studio, Eclipse, etc) render fonts just fine.
Label: bug

Title: Code sometimes improperly marked as comment
Body:
Sometimes, when copy/pasting some code around with comments, I notice that part of my code becomes improperly marked as comments. You can see it happened here, and it becomes normal again when you play around with the comment above it:

![ex](https://www.dropbox.com/s/74wmso8114588gg/commented%20code.gif?dl=1)

Unfortunately, I have not yet found out how it can consistently be reproduced, but I've seen it happen at least 5-6 times already. 

I suspect though that it has to do with comment blocks starting with /*. As you can see in the screen recording, the marking seems to end at the */ in the path definition, so it looks as if it's thinking the code above it is part of a comment block still.

This is on Max OS X, Atom 0.209.
Label: bug

Title: Un-styled scrollbars appear after waking from sleep if external mouse is plugged in
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Ensure that no external mouse is plugged in
2. Put computer to sleep
3. Plug in external mouse (preferably a non-Apple mouse with a scroll wheel)
4. Wake computer from sleep
5. Atom will have un-styled scrollbars
- OS X 10.10.3
  - System Preferences > General > Show scroll bars > Automatically based on mouse or trackpad
- Atom 0.209.0 (but I've noticed this for many versions now)

Can anyone else reproduce this? (@atom/feedback?)
Label: bug

Title: Mini atom-text-editor doesn't handle horizontal overflow unless a space is used
Body:
Here’s an illustration of the issue:

![texteditor mini horizontal overflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/517889/8112251/a813a3d4-1034-11e5-97eb-392c4c7bdad9.gif)

Basically, the text you’re typing becomes invisible until you type a space. This is particularly problematic if the mini TextEditor is being used for something like a long URL, which you wouldn’t expect to have spaces.

Using Atom v0.208.0 on Mac OS 10.10.3
Label: bug

Title: All windows not remembered if exiting with unsaved files.
Body:
With multiple windows open and some of them with files with unsaved changes, when quitting Atom it prompts about those unsaved files. Regardless of the option chosen for the prompt, only the window with the last prompt to close is reopened.

Experiencing this on _OS X 10.10.3_ and _Atom 0.208_.
Label: bug

Title: Fullscreen state is forgotten for all but one window.
Body:
With multiple fullscreen windows open, exit then start Atom and notice only one of them is opened in fullscreen.

Experiencing this on _OS X 10.10.3_ and _Atom 0.208_.

Title: Atom doesn't respect saved session if opened with file arguments
Body:
If Atom opens without arguments, it restores session with all tabs and project folders. If launch Atom with file arguments (via terminal or shorctut association) and it's already opened, it only opens a new tab for file and keeps current project folders and other tabs.
But if launch Atom with file arguments and no other instance is opened, all saved session becomes lost, it changes project folder to file's root and opens only one tab for executed file.
For example, Sublime respects saved session in that case too.

Arch Linux x64, Atom 1.0.10 x64.
Label: enhancement

Title: ctrl-0 conflicts on Windows and cannot reset font size
Body:
When I hit `ctrl-0` in an editor pane, I expect the font-size to reset. Instead, the tree view focus is toggled. The `ctrl-=` and `ctrl--` keystrokes both work to increase and decrease the font size, and `ctrl-0` is listed under the "View" toolbar menu as being the appropriate keyboard shortcut for resetting font size.

There are no errors in the Developer Tools. The issue appears simply to be a keystroke conflict. For `.platform-win32, .platform-linux`, `ctrl-0` toggles tree view as well as resets font size, and tree view toggle apparently wins.

I'm using Windows 8.1 and Atom 0.207.0.
Label: bug

Title: Resize pane cursor is inconsistent with tree view cursor
Body:
As noted by @trkoch in the https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/5902#issuecomment-95063910 thread, the resize pane cursor is inconsistent with the resize cursor. Specifically the tree view cursor uses the col-resize cursor where the resize panes use the ew-resize for horizontal and ns-resize for vertically split panes. This should be updated to using the split panes leverage col-resize cursor for horizontal and row-resize for vertically split panes.

The following screen capture highlights the issue:
![atomresizepanecursorbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/119151/8053169/e7d78bbe-0e42-11e5-9048-00cccbd61ca8.gif)
Label: enhancement

Title: Enable/disable depends on package directory name, not `name` from package.json
Body:
We have some packages whose directory names do not correspond to their package name (e.g. `nuclide/file-tree` for `nuclide-file-tree`, `nuclide/hack` for `nuclide-hack`), and I noticed that the Package Manager (i.e. Settings > Packages) doesn't allow me to enable/disable them.

I looked at `~/.atom/config.cson`, and it seems like just the base name of the directory is being written into the `core.disabledPackages` config. I believe it needs to be the `name` field from the `package.json` for it to work properly.
Label: bug

Title: New file command does nothing with no windows open
Body: I'm running Atom 0.207 on Mac. I ran into a weird scenario today where hitting cmd-n and clicking "File -> New File" did absolutely nothing. Unfortunately, I'm not sure exactly what caused this. I was adding and renaming folders and maybe using Git Plus a little bit but that's all. Anyways, here's a gif of the behavior: http://g.recordit.co/njk9NwI6M8.gif.
Label: bug

Title: Project Tree Erased
Body:
The project tree gets erased and replaced with the containing folder when you select "Open in Atom" from the right click menu when right clicking on a file. This is happening on Windows 7 with 0.207.0 .

Steps for reproduction:
1. Add several project folders to the tree view.
2. Close down Atom.
3. In a file explorer, right click a file and select "Open in Atom".
4. All of the projects you added before to the tree are removed, leaving only the containing folder of the file you just opened.
5. Close down Atom.
6. On reopening atom, the project tree still only contains the folder present in step 4.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom cursor position is broken
Body:
Copy this text in a new atom instance (`atom --safe`) and change the type of the text from `Plain Text` to `GitHub Markdown`: ```
``` Now place the cursor at the end of the second line (`
Label: bug

Title: editor:select-to-end-of-line should work similarly to editor:move-to-end-of-line
Body:
I'd normally use the `Shift + End` buttons to select the text from the current cursor position to the end of the line, but this doesn't seem to be working with Atom.

Let's say I have this long line:

```
This is a very long line of text that is used to test a bug report in Atom.
```

Now let's say I resize Atom's window so the line can't fit in a single row, specifically, the text `port in Atom.` is forced on a new row.

Now,  I'd expect that if I place the cursor at the beginning of the line and hit `Shift + End`, the entire text is selected. I'd even accept as a reasonable behavior if Atom selects everything up to the `test a bug re` part, but that is not the case. Atom is actually selecting everything on the first row of the line, except the last character. That is, in my example, after placing the cursor at the beginning of the line and hitting `Shift + End`, Atom is selecting this:

```
This is a very long line of text that is used to test a bug r
```
Label: bug

Title: Restore session after install upgrade and relaunch
Body:
When 'install upgrade and relaunch' atom can reload all opened files before.

Liu Jiang.
Label: bug

Title: [Feature Request] A way to diagnose freezes
Body: Similiar to timecop, I'd like something to diagnose and log the random freezes and lag problems that have been happening to me and a few friends on a random basis. If there is already something like that in place, please excuse and close me :)
Label: enhancement

Title: Give "items" more control over how they are saved.
Body:
Currently there is no way for "items" (API level) to control how they are saved. For example some items might require that they are always saved with a particular file extension, but right now that's impossible to specify.

This pull request addresses the issue: #7145
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom reopens files on reload but doesn't check to see if they still exist, opens empty tabs
Body:
Atom 0.207

Scenario: open files in Atom for editing, close Atom, move files, reopen Atom and it attempts to open the files but it cannot because they have been moved but it still opens empty tabs with the same names as the files previously edited.
Label: bug

Title: Running Atom from shell fails on Windows
Body:
**Version:** Atom v0.207
**OS:** Windows 8.1

Hello. Recently, when I tried to run `atom somefile.txt` from [Git for Windows](https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases), I got an error in the `atom` script that said `No such file or directory`. When I opened the `atom` script file, I saw this:

```
"$0/../../app-0.204.0/resources/cli/atom.sh" "$@"
```

Realizing that `$0` should instead have been `$(dirname $0)` instead, I replaced it and tried again. I also found this problem in the script it pointed to (atom.sh).

The problem is that **when Atom updates it erases the fix**, which is why I filed this bug report.

As someone [in the forums](https://discuss.atom.io/t/running-atom-from-shell-doesnt-work-on-windows/17496) noted, `atom.cmd` works fine.

Image:

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9159214/8021375/8a9ab616-0c6b-11e5-9efc-c7b1511a5f7b.png)

**NOTE: This applies to apm and the script it points to, as well.**
Label: bug

Title: application:open-file should default to the directory where the currently viewed file resides
Body:
The title says everything. If you have several files open, and press CTRL-O, at the moment the open dialog will default to "Recently Used". However, it makes a _lot_ of sense to default, as a starting point, to the directory where the file currently viewed is.

For example if you are working on the file `youtRepo/auth/button/facebook.js`, and you want to open `youtRepo/auth/button/local.js`, you should be able to press CTRL-O and find yourself in `youtRepo/auth/button/`. Again, this is what happens in Sublime and I find it immensely helpful.

I tried to do it myself, but I am not familiar with Atom's code. However, the relevant lines seem to be https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L225-L227 and https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L171.
Label: enhancement

Title: request: `atom config` CLI command similar to `git config`
Body:
I have a script that I run a few times a week to synchronise and update my dot files and all sorts of other things across all the bash-compatible machines I use (desktops, laptops, etc):
- https://github.com/jokeyrhyme/dotfiles/blob/master/scripts/update.sh

One of the things it does it ensures that basic `git config` is uniform across my machines:
- https://github.com/jokeyrhyme/dotfiles/blob/master/packages/git-config.sh

Note that I can't just wholesale clone configuration files like this between machines, because there are still machine-specific details (e.g. OS X and Linux directory structure is different, etc).

Thankfully, I can just use the [`git config`](http://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Customizing-Git-Git-Configuration) CLI command to specifically set the common values and leave everything else alone.

Is this something that would be welcomed in a PR or otherwise developed for Atom? I can't just clone my entire `.atom/config.cson` file between machines, due to machine-specific settings. And I'd write my own CLI tool for manipulating CSON, but that seems brittle in the event that Atom's configuration structure changes.
Label: enhancement

Actual behavior: Nothing happens and no indication is given that the operation failed

This problem also occurs when changing tabs if you don't click inside the editor before selecting Toggle Soft Wrap.
Label: enhancement

Title: Require just lsb-core in rpm specfile, not whole lsb
Body:
In #6988 the rpm spec file got changed to:

```
Requires: lsb 
```

However, that pulls the _whole_ lsb package, including all submodules. On Fedora 21, this pulls:

```
redhat-lsb                   
redhat-lsb-core              
redhat-lsb-cxx               
redhat-lsb-desktop           
redhat-lsb-languages         
redhat-lsb-printing          
redhat-lsb-submod-multimedia 
redhat-lsb-submod-security   
```

and those packages in turn pull a lot of other dependencies. That seems to be completely unnecessary. IIUIC, you just need `lsb_release` to be present, nothing else, so just the lsb core module.

Please adjust this to:

```
Requires: lsb-core-noarch
```

That should ensure that only lsb core module is required, nothing else. I tested this in Fedora 21 (`sudo yum install 'lsb-core-noarch'`) and in OpenSUSE 13.2 (`sudo zypper install 'lsb-core-noarch'`) and it seems to work just fine.

Thank you.
Label: enhancement

Title: Default install location of windows system.
Body: Why the default install location is "C:\Users\name\AppData\Local\atom" , that's sh!t. Hope that can choosing by users.
Label: enhancement

Title: Enable packages to intercept click events on the editor
Body:
Currently, we don't have a good story for enabling packages to handle click events in the editor, that I know of. How should we do this?
- One idea is to enable packages to register click event handlers for the lines and the gutters. For every click, their handler would be invoked. They would need a way to tell us not to continue processing the event. Do they call `stopImmediatePropagation` on the event? Return a boolean from their handler?
- @maxbrunsfeld mentioned in #6843 something even more general based on commands. Max if you have more thoughts on that maybe you could edit this and add them here?
Label: enhancement

Title: Indentation glitch in certain scopes but not others.
Body:
Hey there! I've just noticed a somewhat strange glitch in how Atom responds to <kbd>Tab</kbd> in certain scopes---in particular Markdown, but I haven't cycled through them all yet. Setting the tab length to four spaces, either in `.gfm.source` or globally, causes Atom to insert four spaces but visually snap the cursor back to the middle of the tabstop, roughly two spaces in. From there, typing causes the cursor to jump back and insert text at the expected position about half of the time, and about half the time to drop text right where it appears to be, with two spaces before the insertion and two spaces trailing it. This also happens when I type four spaces the old-fashioned way.

I dropped a quick screencast demonstrating the hiccup at https://cloudup.com/cUq4wn72BsS. It was recorded with a brand-new, untampered-with Atom setup: I reinstalled the binary to be safe, and moved my `~/.atom` folder out of `$HOME`. The same behavior occurred, both without any third-party packages present and in safe mode.

So far I can attest that this _doesn't_ happen in plain-text mode, in Python, or with the scopes created by the `language-latex` package, but I can't generalize beyond that yet.

Please let me know if I can provide any more or any better information about the problem! And thanks in advance for your help.
Label: bug

Title: Setting toggle for default atom command line behavior
Body:
Atom's default `atom` command behavior isn't going well with my workflow. From the discussions I've seen, a lot of people want the old behavior and some people enjoy the new behavior, making it the perfect candidate for a toggle setting. The behavior can be worked around by hacking a bash script, but I don't think that's a good user experience for a common workflow.

Before the implementation I'd like to get some input on where the setting should live. My thought is the setting doesn't have a good place on the GUI settings page, so maybe just a field in the config file will work for now.

Title: load $PATH when launched as an app
Body:
When Atom is launched as an application, it doesn't get the user's PATH, because it was launched by `launchctl`. This means that packages like [script](https://github.com/rgbkrk/atom-script) and [hydrogen](https://github.com/willwhitney/hydrogen) have to tell the user to launch Atom from the command line. Some packages (like hydrogen) can't even be installed without the PATH because their dependencies use native extensions built with [`node-gyp`](https://github.com/TooTallNate/node-gyp). There exist tools such as [`fix-path`](https://github.com/sindresorhus/fix-path), but they clobber the user's PATH even if they've set something on purpose (with e.g. a virtualenv).

Having access to the user's PATH will become more and more important as people build packages that interface more deeply with languages, other tools, and the user's environment. Forcing the user to configure each package with complete paths to the binaries it needs is possible, but inelegant, and becomes intractable with general-purpose tools.

This seems like a clear situation where making this change to Atom itself would dramatically simplify life for many packages and eliminate many bugs arising from poor attempts to capture the PATH.
Label: enhancement

Title: EISDIR crash when opening
Body:

Title: ctrl + up/down inserts  or ?
Body:
I'm on OSX. Pressing `ctrl` + `up`/`down` inserts a  or ? into the document, both show up as a square in the editor.

This is a problem for me personally because. `ctrl` + `left`/`right` is the key combo used to switch between spaces. And my keyboard's arrow buttons are a single square directional button. Which often results in my space switching between browser and Atom to be a combination of both a horizontal and vertical `ctrl` + arrow keypress.

OSX doesn't switch focus away from Atom till after it has finished transitioning to the other space. Because of this I'll often find myself switching away from Atom. Then switching back to find an edited file with an extra square sitting next to my cursor.

Once in awhile I forget to `⌘Z` and I end up saving one of these into a file and have to hunt down the location of the script error it causes.
Label: bug

Title: Towards unobtrusive notices and notifications
Body:
This is more of a discussion than a concrete list of actionable items.  Since Atom's launch, I've started to notice more things seeking my attention in an increasingly aggressive manner.  They seem small in isolation, but when you add them up and make them recurring, Atom can begin to nag you.  

Below is the most recent example.  I wanted to take a quick look at some docs, so I run `atom .`  

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 10 30 25 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800438/3c7af9e6-02ca-11e5-8dbe-b321bf2f7cde.png)

a. **Non-fatal errors are blocking content** - Is this dialog necessary given b.?
b. **Duplicate update notices** - How can Atom minimize these or get rid of them completely? 
c. **The `!` feels unnecessary** - Deprecation and update notices now contain an `!` mark.  It's small, but this changes the tone of the message from informing me, to shouting at me. 
d. **More packages.  more notices** - It seems logical that the longer you are an Atom user, the more package you install, the more notices you are going to get. 
#### Deprecation notices

When you click on the deprecation notice text in the status bar, you are taken to this screen:

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 10 55 40 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800595/a39f238e-02cc-11e5-8864-90a7e4d5bf04.png)

This screen feels unnecessary to anyone _using_ Atom.  Unless I'm a developer or I'm specifically trying to debug packages, I'm not too concerned with what methods in what packages are deprecated.  I would like the deprecation message to go away so I can get back to work.  How can Atom help me do that?  Could the "Check for updates" step happen automatically?  Could updates be installed during relaunch or during idle time?
#### Package updates

![screen shot 2015-05-25 at 11 07 37 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25/7800708/52e0e5fc-02ce-11e5-86ca-9e0fb9bc78df.png)

There's 1 update available.  When I click the notice in the status bar, I'm taken to this screen that runs an additional check for updates and then lists the packages that have updates.  Does Atom need to run this check again since it knows I have a package that needs an update already? 
#### Some considerations

In the spirit of GitHub Zen, here are a few things to consider:
- Atom should strive to not block content for non-fatal errors. 
- Atom should strive to keep notifications to a minimum.
- Atom should strive to reduce manual administrative overhead (updating packages, atom, etc.). 

:bow:  Thanks for the fantastic work
Label: enhancement

Title: Surrounding multiple words with ` characters is broken
Body:
I'm not sure which package is responsible so I'm reporting the issue here. Tested with 0.202.0-ec5b807 in `--safe` mode.

When you select multiple words and surround them with " or ' signs everything works perfectly. However, when I try to do the same with `-signs something weird happens (gif is easiest to show). First the words disappear, then I press Space and they reappear - wrapped - but the words are wrong. Note that Cmd-Z removes the `-signs but can not restore the original words.

Title: Atom may open windows off-screen if resolution/monitors have changed
Body:
### Reproducible Steps
- Use a laptop with docking station connected with dual monitor setup.
- Move atom editor to second screen.
- Quit atom editor.
- Remove laptop from docking station (or use single screen setup).
- Try open atom editor again.
- Atom editor displayed on second screen, regardless whether second screen exist.
- No easy way to force atom to display on first screen.
### Tested Environment

Atom 0.201.0
Windows 7
Label: bug

The [selectLeft documentation](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.201.0/Selection#instance-selectLeft) implies that this should not happen:

Selects the text one position left of the cursor.

But it's coloured even when there is no update but just to point you to the release notes. I find this behaviour confusing.

I think it should act as follows:

Title: Not possible to move cursor within last screen line of soft wrapped line
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. open new tab
2. enable soft wrapping
3. trigger the `lorem` snippet (type `lorem` and press `tab`)
4. try to click somewhere within the last line of the wrapped paragraph, and notice that the cursor will always be placed at the end of the line. It's possible to delete characters from the end of that line using backspace, but not move the cursor within it.

Here's a gif where I try to position the cursor within the last line, but it always ends up at the end of the line (and when I press `left` with the cursor at the end of that last line -- the cursor doesn't move):

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/7743436/1596be28-ff9b-11e4-83bb-e6ad167b7a8e.gif)

cc @nathansobo any chance some of your recent changes affected this somehow? :thought_balloon:

Body:
Hi,

Is it possible to enable middle mouse button scrolling on the text editor?

I see that middle button scrolling is possible in various places, e.g. in the `tree-view` component,  so I'm guessing that this default behavior (at least on Windows) was somehow blocked on the text editor. From what I've managed to understand so far, [this](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/75d02cdbc92b4ed5ef0139a4abe24fddd8d0e397/src/text-editor-component.coffee#L369) is the line responsible for it. Is there any way to override this behavior as a plugin?

Thanks.

Title: TextEditor should have a setReadOnly function

Title: More flexible open path location parameters?
Body:
When you open an Atom path you can optional include an initialLine and initialColumn using the following syntax:

```
/my/path/to/open/test.txt:<line>:<column>
```

During the opening process those line,column values are stripped off the path and provided as metadata to the workspace opener handler. This is useful, but the problem is that the syntax is fixed, no other values can be passed in other then line, column.

I would like Atom to also read in URL query parameter syntax and send those values through as options to the workspace opener. I don't mean we should break the existing syntax for line column, but instead provide an alternative syntax using query parameter syntax.

For example these would all be equivalent:

```
/my/path/to/open/test.txt:10:1
/my/path/to/open/test.txt:10?initialColumn=1
/my/path/to/open/test.txt?initialLine=10&initialColumn=1
```

The reason for making this change is because then other workspace openers could could read in similar values that apply to them. For example I have an outliner editor (https://atom.io/packages/foldingtext-for-atom) that can filter the outline view with a search. I would like the option to provide an initial search value when opening an outline file, similar to how initial line and column is now provided to the default editor. If query parameter options were available in Atom I could then open a path like this:

```
/my/path/to/open/test.ftml?search=stuff
```

And `search: stuff` would get passed through to my opener as an option.

The implementation would be pretty strait forward:
1. In `atom-application.coffee::locationForPathToOpen` strip and store query parameters key values from the path right before the code that does: `pathToOpen = pathToOpen.replace(/[:\s]+$/, '')`.
2. Include those key values along with the initialLine and initialColumn key values that are being returned.
3. In `window-event-handler.coffee` process the `open-locations` handler a bit differently so that all location metadata gets passed through to `atom.workspace.open` instead of just the line and column.
Label: enhancement

Title: API request: file created event
Body:
Hi,

I have created a function to watch changes in the project by a given pattern.
Due to the usage of patterns, I'm forced to use the `::onDidChange` of the individual files. 
The problem is, that I'm not able to fetch the file created events this way.
I could watch the directory and refresh all watchers on each change, but I would prefer
either a own event like `::onFileCreated` or some parameters passed to the callback of `::onDidChange`, so I can filter the created events

This is far from high priority, but maybe it is easy to implement?
I have looked into the `PathWatcher` and I think this feature could be implemented in this [line](https://github.com/atom/node-pathwatcher/blob/v4.4.0/src/main.coffee#L96) ?

thanks
Label: enhancement

Title: Deprecated selector warning for unmodified styles.less file
Body:
Howdy!

This issue cropped up (or at least I noticed it) around 0.199, but it remains in 0.200.

I have one deprecation warning (which sticks around even in safe mode):

```
your local styles.less file
  /Users/tylersticka/Dropbox (Personal)/Atom/styles.less
  Style elements within text editors using the atom-text-editor::shadow selector or the .atom-text-editor.less file extension. If you want to target overlay elements, target them directly or as descendants of atom-overlay elements.
```

If I click that error, I am taken to what appears to be an empty file:

![screen shot 2015-05-20 at 9 49 07 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69633/7731460/7ba50650-fed5-11e4-9929-3354acc7043a.png)

If I go to the Atom menu and select "Open Your Stylesheet," this is what it looks like:

``` less
/*
 * Your Stylesheet
 *
 * This stylesheet is loaded when Atom starts up and is reloaded automatically
 * when it is changed.
 *
 * If you are unfamiliar with LESS, you can read more about it here:
 * http://www.lesscss.org
 */

.tree-view {

}

atom-text-editor {

}

atom-text-editor .cursor {

}
```

I thought maybe I had _inherited_ this stylesheet from an older version, so I tried commenting out everything within it... but the deprecation warning remains.

(Apologies if this issue is duplicated, I swear I searched for it before creating a this one!)

**Edit:** I should also mention that I have my `.atom` directory symbolically linked to Dropbox (if you're wondering why my paths aren't simply `/Users/tylersticka/.atom`).
Label: bug

Title: Find in project when using symbolic links
Body:
I have a project that has a `project/test-app` folder in it in which `project/test-app/node_modules/depmodule` is sym linked to the root `project` folder

This creates an infinite path depth in the path of: `test-app/node_modules/depmodule/test-app/node_modules/depmodule/...`

The find function in Atom will recurse this forever. An useful feature would be to be able to specify a max path depth.
Label: enhancement

Title: Create a viewer API
Body:
We already have Markdown and ASCIIDoc files that have their respective viewers for the rendered version of the document. We have viewers for images and there is a package for "viewing" audio files. And then I saw the [perldoc package](https://atom.io/packages/perldoc) today, which extracts the documentation from the current file, renders it and views it.

We should have one API with, most importantly, **one** keybinding to be used to view or preview _any_ file type. So no matter what the active file is, if I hit <kbd>Ctrl+Alt+P</kbd> (for example) the registered viewer for that file type opens up in a new pane. If more than one viewer for that file type is registered, you can select the default one ... or press, for example, <kbd>Shift+Ctrl+Alt+P</kbd> to bring up a viewer list and select one.
## Requirements

> The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED",  "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC 2119](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2119.txt).
- **MUST** allow packages to register viewers by scope name using the services API
- **MUST** offer a command `file-viewer:open` to open the single (or default) registered viewer for the file in the active editor (or selected file in the tree-view)
- **MUST** offer a command `file-viewer:listViewers` to open the list of registered viewers for the file in the active editor (or selected file in the tree-view)
- **SHOULD** allow the single (or default) registered viewer to be opened for files that do not have an "opener" registered, such as image, archive or audio types
- **OPTIONAL** offer a hex viewer as an option for all file types (see the [hex package](https://atom.io/packages/hex) for an awesome example)
## Questions
- When preview tabs are enabled, how should viewer tabs behave?
  - Should they be preview tabs? Only sticking around permanently if the tab title is double-clicked?
  - Should they be permanent tabs?
  - Should they be preview tabs, but of their own class so only other preview tabs override them?
Label: enhancement

Title: Unable to auto-update from 0.198.0 to 0.199.0 on Windows
Body:

   at Squirrel.ReleaseEntry.GetReleaseNotes(String packageDirectory)

What's wrong here?

Was the `nupkg` file just generated wrong?

### Commands

```
     -0:01.0 core:save (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)
```
### Config

``` json
{
  "core": {},
  "editor": {
    "invisibles": {},
    "fontSize": 15,
    "showIndentGuide": true
  }
}
```
### Installed Packages

``` coffee

autoclose-html, v0.16.0

# Dev
No dev packages
```

Body:
Pressing <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> through <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> will attempt to switch tabs. [See code here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/44db3e7d2b56cc4ca32b24d47d3964e60ff761ab/keymaps/win32.cson#L80-L88)

When entering an alt code, the tabs switch. It's hard to enter alt codes.

**Workaround:** Open a file in a separate pane, and enter alt codes there.

Title: Overflow CSS property in `.status-bar-right` causes unnecessary scroll bars
Body:
Since about a version or two ago (that I noticed anyway, I'm on 0.198.0) I noticed that the bottom right section of the status bar has been adding unnecessary scroll bars. And ironically ends up hiding some of the data since the scroll bars take up space.

Setting the `overflow` CSS property of the class `status-bar .status-bar-right` from `auto` to `hidden` fixes the issue, but I'm not sure if this rule serves some other purpose. The theme I'm using is the One Light UI but it might carry over to others as well.
Label: bug

Title: Atom should specify which incompatible native module caused `require` to fail
Body:
It would be nice in a package with many native modules, if the logged message in the console was not:

> Failed to require the main module of 'git' because it requires an incompatible native module.
> Run `apm rebuild` in the package directory to resolve.

but was instead:

> Failed to require the main module of 'git' because it requires 'module-name', an incompatible native module.
> Run `apm rebuild` in the package directory to resolve.

Title: Ctrl-O should open the file chooser in the current directory
Body:
This is exactly the same issue as #3618 .  I'm re-submitting an issue because the old fix does not work anymore as a result of AtomWindow.projectPath no longer existing (assumed to be the result of #770 where multiple project paths are now supported.

I was unable to figure out how to get console.log statements or errors reported to the dev console.  If someone can shed some light on how to get that working, then I can submit a PR.
Label: bug

Title: Keymaps file is a hot mess to deal with.
Body:
At the end of the day a user has to track down where and what needs to be overriden and it makes it hard considering there are a lot of things that scope in a lot of places, right now my keymaps file has 6 different selectors to override a few short keybindings I don't like.

Could we please get an easier way for users to override keymaps in that we shouldn't have to track everything down, \* should override all (which it currently doesn't at all...) and can the keymaps file support sub-selectors as a sub-key on the cson?

Here, let me clarify:

``` cson
"*"
  "ctrl-:": "comment-headers:insert"
```

The above should override anything that wants to use ctrl+shift+; but it doesn't, I have to scope under ".platform-linux atom-text-editor" but then things become a mess because in order to override "pageup" and "pagedown" I have to scope under ".platform-linux", which means I have two similar keys but one with an added scope.

Now I could be doing it wrong but when I tested with sub-selectors in the CSON it didn't work and neither did just doing "*".  It would be nice if this could be sorted out because users are used to working in specific ways so it becomes a side-job to manage a keybinding that has so many different scopes in so many different places.
Label: enhancement

Title: When in fullscreen mode, it should be possible to easily click on a tab
Body:
The fullscreen mode must be active (<kbd>F11</kbd>), see this screenshot:

![screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1285361/7552615/f8a561b4-f6be-11e4-963f-02efbb5f0efd.png)

The cursor is at the "uppermost pixel" of the screen, and the inactive tab is not hovered. However, if I lower it down a bit, then the tab becomes hovered.

I think that, when the fullscreen mode is active, the tab should be hovered even when the cursor is at the uppermost pixel (other apps behave this way, like gnome-terminal).

Title: Change open buffer file path when cutting and pasting files #feature

When you save it recreates the old file, even if you didn't actually change the contents of the buffer. I would like to be able to chose the language immediately after having opened a document, not after having started editing it.

Title: scrolling behavior while mouse-selecting whole lines of text is hard to control
Body:
Atom v.0.196.0
Mac OS X 10.10.3

Trying to select text that spans more than just the visible scroll region is much more difficult in Atom than in other editors when selecting entire lines because of the auto-scrolling behavior.  When you stretch a selection past the edge of the scroll region, the editor scrolls to accommodate you, but once you overshoot your destination, pulling back starts scrolling back in the other direction even though it's not necessary.  Most other editors will only scroll when necessary.

Steps:
1. open a file that is at least twice as long as what you can display in your window
2. make sure you're scrolled to the top
3. triple-click and hold somewhere to begin selecting entire lines
4. drag down just past the bottom of the window, causing the window to scroll
5. once you've scrolled all the way to the bottom (it's important here that you scroll at least past the point where the top of the selection scrolls out of the window), pretend you overshot the bottom of what you wanted selected by a few lines and you actually want the selection to end at the 10th line from the bottom of the file.  continue to hold the mouse button down while you move your mouse back up to that line.
6. observe that if you move your mouse up past about the 4th line from the bottom of the window, it actually starts scrolling back up and will keep going until the top of your selection is visible.  This makes it difficult to get the selection to stop on a specific line because you have to time the scrolling to get your target line within 4 lines of the bottom of the window.

Expected: after mouse movement downward causes a scroll, moving the mouse back up into the window should not cause scrolling back in the other direction unless you attempt to move the end of the selection past the top of the visible part of the file.
Label: bug

Title: Show invisibles only when selecting text
Body:
I tried searching for a similar issue here and I didn't find anything that directly addresses what I want, though #3249 (which I have subscribed to) is what I want, just asked for in a very roundabout way.

In short: we should have an option to only display invisibles within a selection. Showing them all the time is too noisy, not showing them at all loses their power, and turning them off and on when I want to see them is annoying. I'm aware that with CSS we cannot achieve what is required (hence unresolved #3249, and accompanying [forum post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-is-so-powerful-that-it-blows-my-mind/294/17?)) due to the underlayer controlling the background highlight. So this will presumably be something that atom must provide from within the core.

If this request appeals more as something that's more generic (and allow us to achieve what we want with CSS) you could actually just attach a `.selected` class to all elements (scopes) that are within the selection (obviously a selection part-way through an element will require an inner span injected with just the `.selected` class). This way, we can do what we want in regards to the invisibles, but package developers may find interesting ways to use this selection class/scope for other purposes.
Label: enhancement

Title: no mnemonics in menus (File, Edit, ...)
Body:
My system:
Linux
Desktop: KDE 4.14.6

In the menus there are any mnemonics shown at all!
(the menu buttons themselves show mnemonics when pressing ALT)
E.g. in File menu:

```
New Window
New File
Open File
...
```

don't show any mnemonics. Also when pressing "ALT" while menu is opened.
Nevertheless, mnemonics seem to be there (but not shown). If I press "n" while in File menu (found out by guessing) Atom opens a new file.
Label: bug

Title: Option-Click on code fold arrow (bug/enhancement)
Body:
When option-clicking an arrow in the gutter for code folding I expect it to do a recursive fold at that level, as of right now that functionality is not implemented. As an example if I am at the root of a class with methods and I option click on the class-level arrow I would expect it to act as the "Fold All" command. But if I were to only option-click on the private label (in say a ruby class) I would expect it to fold the entire private section AND all underlying methods.

Unsure if this would be a bug or enhancement, assuming the latter.
Label: enhancement

Title: Cursor position forgotten between tabs
Body:
When you are working in multiple files and going back and forth between the file tabs, the cursor position for that tab is forgotten and you can't type text right away.

This is rather frustrating behaviour, as it forces you to grab your mouse and click somewhere in the code before you can start typing.

Sublime remembers the cursor position per tab/file, so that when you go back to a tab, the cursor is at the position where you left off, and you can start typing right away.

Can this be enabled for Atom as well? I couldn't find a package that does it.
Label: bug

Title: Autoindent not working properly
Body:
Version: 0.192.0
## Problem

1) `autoindent` fails to indent parameter lists. Note: If I hit enter after `fake_function(`, `param=` would be indented 3x -- class > def > foo.

``` python
class Bar(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_indentation(self):
        foo = fake_function(param='hello',
        second_param='world', # should have indented this line
        ) # and this one, too
```

After saving, `atom-beautify` correctly indents the parameters

``` python
class Bar(unittest.TestCase):

    def test_indentation(self):
        foo = fake_function(param='hello',
                            second_param='world', # fixed!
                            ) # me, too!
```

2) But now, `autoindent` fails to reset indentation back to the beginning of the line

``` python
        [...]
        foo = fake_function(param='hello',
                            second_param='world',
                            )

                            bar = 'after_continuing typing' # ach!!
```

Unfortunately `atom-beautify` doesn't quite fix this ever time.

``` python
        foo = fake_function(param='hello',
                            second_param='world',
                            )
            bar = 'after_continuing typing'
```
## Note

I recently updated atom-beautify as an attempt to help resolve the issue, but I am now getting errors there. The problems mentioned above still exist, but I will update if anything changes.
## Update

Here's some testing in 
#### Sublime3:

``` python

def testing_indentation_in_sublime(some_var):
    first_line = "works"
    second_test = func_indentation(multiple_param,
        auto_indents,
        still_here,
        ) # parenthesis auto matched when typed!

    third_test = alt_indentation(
        looks_just_like above,
        which_was_wrong,
        but_this_works,
        )

        fourth_line = existing_indentation('retry last pasting',
                                       'broken') 
        and_indent_is_kept

    fifth_line = backspace_only_does_one_space('testing existing indent',
                                               'testing')
    indentation = "working!!"

    if check_nested_indent is not None:
        basic_indent = True
    elif check_indent:
        also_works = True
        if nested:
            so_far = so_good
        else:
            also_good = True
        else:
            uh_oh = 'is this really that hard?'

    return end_of_function

    def still_indented():
        '''sigh.'''
        indentation = 'not perfect here, either (but way better)'
```
#### Eclipse

``` python
def indent_test_eclipse(some_var):
    first_line = 'smoke test'
    second_test = func_with_param(style_one,
                                  hey_it_works,
                                  )
    back_to_the_beginning = 'holy crap.'
    third_test = func_with_alt_style(
                                     hrmmm,
                                     )

    if nested_indent is not None:
        basic_indent = True
    elif reindents_on_space_not_colon:
        still_okay = True
        if nested:
            so_far = so_good
        else:
            also_good = True
        else:
            must_be_difficult = True

    return end_of_function

def correctly_indents_after_return():
    '''Woo hoo'''

    return True
```
Label: bug

Title: Default CSS for `<progress>` element causes CPU to spike.
Body:
This is on OS X, version 10.10.3 (Yosemite).

As shown in the animated GIF, enabling the following CSS style (which is present for `<progress>` elements) causes the CPU usage to spike:

``` css
-webkit-animation: animate-stripes 5s linear infinite;
```

From the Chrome profiling tools, you can see that all of the `<progress>` elements are being redrawn continuously while this CSS is being applied. Once it is removed, the CPU usage goes back down to zero and the redraw ends.

Outright removing this style only affects the display of indeterminate progress bars, as they appear to be designed to have a "barber poll" animation.

Something should be done so that package developers who introduce the use of a `<progress>` element do not inadvertently burn CPU.

![progress-causes-cpu-spike](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/655869/7463670/3f5f18d2-f270-11e4-8d12-886ab9b90829.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Atom window can get stuck in "dev mode"
Body:
- Atom will now restore your previous window state on restart.
- The serialization of the Atom window includes the "dev mode" flag.
- When you create a new window the "dev mode" flag is taken from any existing window. 

Together these things can have the effect of locking a user who doesn't know what's happening into dev mode.

https://discuss.atom.io/t/tip-how-to-stop-atom-from-always-opening-in-dev-mode/16576
Label: bug

Title: Feature request: Option for max file-size for syntax highlighting
Body:
Hello!

I am a web developer so I sometimes need to handle concatinated files within my editor. This often locks atom from a few seconds to up to a minute, which is pretty hard on my workflow. Would it be possible for you guys to add an option for max-file size for syntax highlighting?

Problem files are often concatinated JS/CSS. Try [pasting this into Atom](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/misoproject/dataset/master/dist/miso.ds.deps.min.0.4.1.js). If you paste into new tab with no syntax highlighting it's fine. When you try to save as JS it locks up the editor.

Thanks!
Label: enhancement

Title: Request: map cmd/alt + 9 to show last (rightmost) tab
Body:
I wanted to see what people thought about remapping this key combination to instead to to the last tab open in a pane. Currently, it is set to [view the ninth tab](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/keymaps/darwin.cson#L103): `'cmd-9': 'pane:show-item-9'`

My reasons for suggesting are as follows:
- I believe it is easier to have a dedicated key to always go to this specific position, as compared to counting how many tabs from the left your desired tab is
- if someone has more than nine tabs open, a keymapping to go directly to the end would be beneficial
- Atom shares many existing keyboard shortcuts with Chrome, and Chrome uses this key combination to navigate to the last tab

Curious to hear your thoughts on it. Thanks.
Label: enhancement

Title: Minor oddity: installed in the future?

It says it's installed on October 1st this year (Dutch date notation is `dd-mm-yyyy`). That's in the future, cause it's May 1st today. I installed it a couple of weeks ago (April 15th).

> Atom 0.196.0

Title: Add setting to disable restoring last session

It's useful that atom can remember the files/folders you had open last time and then re-open them next time you start atom. I can't seem to figure out how to turn off this behavior though, I generally _want_ to start clean each time I open atom.

Is there a config option to enable/disable this feature? Or could we implement a dialog box when closing atom that asks if you want it to remember what you had open?

Title: Add a "package load paths" config for using packages in custom locations
Body:
Atom should load packages in the specified folders in addition to the packages in "~/.atom/packages" on startup.

Internally, we've been developing packages in a custom folder and symlinking them into "~/.atom/packages" when we want to run them. The symlinks get out of date when we add packages, move them around, or delete them. It would be nice if we could just point Atom to look for packages in our development folders.
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature request: Remove multiple project folders.
Body:
Add a project folder, add a different project folder, right click on both.

No option for "remove project folders" appears.
Label: enhancement

Title: Needed: an event when all grammars are loaded
Body:
I'm writing a package to let the author of a source file put in a comment to force the file to use a certain grammar (aka "mode" in EMACS). This was the goal of the existing package `file-mode` but that package is severely broken and a total rewrite is needed.  The ruby grammar already has this feature [built-in](https://github.com/atom/language-ruby/pull/90) but my package will work for all grammars.

I have a problem that the grammars are loaded asynchronously and a texteditor can be loaded before all the grammars are loaded.  See my issue #6586.  I can find the mode comment when the texteditor is loaded but there is no way to look up the grammar.

For now I'll kludge it and not look for the grammar list until after a time delay but this will cause the user to see the grammar switch after that delay which is not a good UX.

To finally get to the point, I need an event telling me when the grammars are loaded.  I'll wait until then to look in all the files for the mode comments.
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature request: Add built-in support for EditorConfig
Body:
There is an [Atom](https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-editorconfig#readme) plugin for EditorConfig, but native support (such as is included in BBEdit, Coda, WebStorm, etc.) would make the EditorConfig experience much easier for teams with Atom users.

Maybe this could be part of the per-project configuration file task (#5168)?

Disclaimer: I am biased as one of the EditorConfig project maintainers
Label: enhancement

Title: Disable application menu items when they don't apply to the focused element
Body: Currently, all application menu items are enabled no matter what element is focused, even if their commands aren't bound to that element or its parents. This can contribute to strange behavior / bugs like #6587. If a command isn't bound to a focused element or its parent elements, then it should be disabled (and maybe also removed from the Command Palette? I think that might be better off in another issue though).
Label: enhancement

Title: Uncaught TypeError: undefined is not a function on Undo operations for special panes
Body:
Steps to recreate.
1. Open Timecop or the Styleguide
2. Perform an Undo (Redo also causes problem in Timecop)

**Atom Version**: 0.193.0
**System**: linux 3.19.3-3-ARCH
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

Title: 0.195.0 made the editor unsuable for php files
Body:
Recent update to .195 doesn't let me edit php files. It hangs and after a while displays the "Keep waiting" or "Close" message

I started in safe mode to make sure it's not some plugin. Let me know how I can help to debug
Label: bug

Title: Scroll veneer + selection = odd behavior
Body:
I posted about this on the discussion boards (https://discuss.atom.io/t/automatic-scroll-disable/16460).

It has been reproduced in `--safe`!
1. Start a new file and add enough text to allow for scrolling vertically.
2. Scroll to the very top of the file.
3. Try to select the last two lines on the screen.

It appears that the scroll veneer takes over and starts to move the screen into view. But because you are still down there, it continues to apply and selects while scrolling rapidly, which is hard to control. This also happens at the top of the screen and must be within the 3 edge lines for the issue to happen.
Label: bug

Title: Extra quote is added when backslash is present in a string
Body:
Not sure how to actually put this in words, but see this:

![Animated GIF](http://i.imgur.com/DaZkgtj.gif)

On each line, right before the (original) last quote, I pressed on the key to insert a quote. A quote should not be added for lines 2 and 3, just like line 1, no?
Label: bug

Title: Add String as type that Project.getRepositoryForDirectory can accept
Body:
See #6324 and [this post on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/t/logic-for-requiring-atom-api-classes/14760/4)

In the case of anything in the API that accepts a Point or Range, one can pass a Point-compatible or Range-compatible Array. I feel like things in the API that can accept a File or Directory should be able to accept a String containing either an absolute or project-root-relative (if possible) path.
Label: enhancement

Title: Can't scroll right when unfolding causes content to be wider than the editor's scroll view
Body: If the longest line is folded, we clip the screen position at the end of the line to 0 before translating it to a pixel position. This is due to the fact that we clip cursors to the beginning of folded lines, a decision I'd actually like to revisit in its own right.
Label: bug

Title: Atom crashes my system due to linux nVidia drivers
Body:
_I originally asked this question in PR https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/2789 , but since I've been told on [atom-discuss/#13975](https://discuss.atom.io/t/disable-gpu-acceleration/13975) that `editor.useHardwareAcceleration` is deprecated, here's an issue._

I'm in a nVidia driver hell since upgrading to Ubuntu 15.04, and though Chrome's `--disable-gpu` does prevent it from crashing my whole system, Atom's (0.196) `editor.useHardwareAcceleration` doesn't, ending in a rather painful way: cursor jitter, screen flickering, regular keyboard/mouse input loss, impossible to switch to a non-X tty → restart with [REISUB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_SysRq_key).

Is there a workaround or a way to be more drastic about disabling gpu acceleration like the Chrome flag does? Or is it too antagonistic to improving performance?

~~I'll be glad to provide debug info.~~ EDIT I no longer have access to the nVidia machine and can no longer help, unsubscribing from this issue I created.
Label: enhancement

Title: Don't ask if I want to save empty (new) files
Body: Simple, if I'm closing a file an empty file which has never been saved before, don't prompt me to save. It's never been saved before and it's empty thus there is nothing to save.
Label: enhancement
