Title: Strange gutter behavior (diff information not updating, line numbers overlapping)
Body:
I have a repro for the diff information not updating:
1. Ensure that Atom is your editor for command-line Git commands `core.editor = atom --wait`
2. Check out a git repository (I used a random Atom one)
3. Open a file in the git repository
4. Add a bunch of text (my mechanical keyboard sounds awesome when monkey typing in random characters :grinning:)
5. Save the file with <kbd>Cmd+S</kbd>
6. In a Terminal window, type `git commit -a`
7. Wait for the new Atom window show up
8. Type "DELETE THIS COMMIT" as the commit message
9. Save the file with <kbd>Cmd+S</kbd>
10. Close the Git Commit Atom window with <kbd>Shift+Cmd+W</kbd>
11. Switch back to the original Atom window with <kbd>Cmd+Tab</kbd>

**Expected:** Git diff information to disappear
**Actual:** Git diff information remains

![screen shot 2015-04-27 at 10 27 40 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/7363350/f72b852e-ed2d-11e4-85a0-5f3877f432d7.png)

![screen shot 2015-04-27 at 10 28 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/7363358/115fc392-ed2e-11e4-8264-946406f6f839.png)

Some things that got Atom to clear the diff info (but not reliably):
1. Keyboard tabbing to Slack and back
2. Closing the dev tools pane
Label: bug

Title: Confusing behavior of Cursor.getCurrentWordBufferRange()
Body:
I have a very simple file containing nothing but the text `-12`.
When I execute the `getCurrentWordBufferRange()`-method on this text with the cursor on different positions of the text I get 3 different results:
- "-" cursor position [0,0]
- "-12" cursor position [0,1]
- "12" cursor position [0, 2]

Is this really the expected behaviour of `getCurrenWordBufferRange()`? I would expect it to always return the string `"-12"` or at least not different results for the same word.

I tested it on atom 0.194.0 on Mac OS X.

Here is a simple jasmine spec with the confusing results which all pass on my machine:

```
getEditorElement = (callback) ->
  textEditor = null

  waitsForPromise ->
    atom.project.open().then (e) ->
      textEditor = e

  runs ->
    element = document.createElement('atom-text-editor')
    element.setModel(textEditor)
    callback(element)

describe 'getCurrentWordBufferRange tests', ->
  editor = null

  beforeEach ->
    getEditorElement (element) ->
      editorElement = element
      editor = editorElement.getModel()
      editor.setText('-12')

  describe 'getCurrentWordBufferRange tests', ->

    it 'current word at position [0,0] is "-"', ->
      cursor = editor.addCursorAtScreenPosition([0, 0])
      cursorText = editor.getTextInBufferRange(cursor.getCurrentWordBufferRange())
      expect(cursorText).toBe('-')

    it 'current word at position [0,1] is "-12"', ->
      cursor = editor.addCursorAtScreenPosition([0, 1])
      cursorText = editor.getTextInBufferRange(cursor.getCurrentWordBufferRange())
      expect(cursorText).toBe('-12')

    it 'current word at position [0,2] is "12"', ->
      cursor = editor.addCursorAtScreenPosition([0, 2])
      cursorText = editor.getTextInBufferRange(cursor.getCurrentWordBufferRange())
      expect(cursorText).toBe('12')
```
Label: bug

Title: Feature request: Create multiple files at once
Body:
Hello, and thanks for the great editor. I just thought that it would be nice to allow user to create multiple files at once, like typing {one,two,three}.txt into create file "dialog" and it would create one.txt, two.txt and three.txt

Thanks,
Miika
Label: enhancement

Title: Install from source on linux creates desktop entry with wrong icon location
Body:
When installing from source by following [this guide](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md) the following `.desktop` entry is created in `/usr/local/share/applications/atom.desktop`:

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Atom
Comment=A hackable text editor for the 21st Century.
GenericName=Text Editor
Exec=/usr/local/share/atom/atom %U
Icon=/usr/local/share/atom/resources/app/resources/atom.png
Type=Application
StartupNotify=true
Categories=GNOME;GTK;Utility;TextEditor;Development;
MimeType=text/plain;
```

However, `/usr/local/share/atom/resources/app/resources/atom.png` does not exist.

```
$ ls /usr/local/share/atom/resources/app/
apm  atom.sh
```

I solved it by simply copying the atom icon in `atom/resources/atom.png` over to the expected path.

```
cd atom
sudo cp --parents resources/atom.png /usr/local/share/atom/resources/app/
```

I didn't find this bug last week when installing release 0.192.0. Maybe this was introduced on 0.193.0 because of the `asar` archive file.
Label: bug

Title: Tooltip API enhancements
Body:
Here are a few ideas I've had for enhancing the Tooltips API:
- Be able to pass in an `HTMLElement` _or_ a selector:

``` coffeescript
atom.tooltips.add('.btn.has-tooltip', {title: 'This is a tooltip'})
```
- Be able to pass in an `Array` of `HTMLElement`s:

``` coffeescript
tooltipButton = document.createElement('button')
tooltipText = document.createElement('span')

atom.tooltips.add([tooltipButton, tooltipText], {title: 'This is a tooltip'})
```

This would all be in addition to the current behavior.
Label: enhancement

Title: Contextmenu and Atom menu not in sync
Body:
It looks like the contextmenu and Atoms' main menu aren't in sync with their methods and features. I noticed that the main menu supports radio and checkbox menu-items, while the contextmenu doesn't. Wouldn't it be better to make both menu's share the same code and logic...

Ref: https://discuss.atom.io/t/contextmenu-and-atom-menu/16353
Label: enhancement

Title: Support OSX's 'Option + Command + Q' to quit the app without saving the application state
Body:
I loved https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1603! Thank you so much for adding it!

However, as far as I can tell, there is now currently no way to quit the Atom _without_ saving the application state.

Most OSX apps support the native menubar/shortcut for `Quit and Close All Windows` (hold down option to see it in the menubar):

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1469659/7299076/9374b07e-e9cb-11e4-883d-10dedb4bcd77.png)

It would be great if Atom supported it too! This way, if I know that I don't want to open the same project next time I can just `⌥ ⌘ Q` out of it.
Label: enhancement

Title: "Unhandled promise rejection" no longer shows up in the console.
Body:
This is a regression. Up to and including Atom v0.188.0, if you had code like:

``` coffee
setTimeout(
  () -> Promise.reject('haha rejected'),
  0)
```

you would discover your error via the following in the console:

```
Unhandled promise rejection Promise
     __proto__: Promise
    [[PromiseStatus]]: "rejected"
    [[PromiseValue]]: "haha rejected"
```

which you could use to help debug your issue.

As of Atom v0.189.0, you see nothing. You can have chains and chains of `Promise.then()`, and if there is a failure in the middle, you now have no idea and have to start adding `.catch()` calls everywhere. It's madness.

I don't know what specifically causes the change, but here's what I have discovered thus far:
- Atom v0.189.0 (Apr 1) is built on atom-shell v0.22.3 (Mar 29) whereas Atom v0.188.0 (Mar 24) is built on atom-shell v0.21.3 (Mar 3).
- atom-shell v0.22.0 mentions **Upgrade to Chrome 41** in its release notes.
- https://github.com/iojs/io.js/pull/758 is a PR with a massive history, which I will not even to pretend to have read, but I believe it was closed on Feb 24 and it includes the following text in its initial comment:

> Implement unhandled rejection tracking for promises as
> specified in https://gist.github.com/benjamingr/0237932cee84712951a2
> 
> Fixes https://github.com/iojs/io.js/issues/256
> 
> Note that I did not implement any default action - so errors are still
> swallowed by default and many developers are therefore not going
> to discover the hooks.

Seems suspicious.
Label: bug

Title: Selecting text with option + shift + arrow behaves differently to other Mac apps
Body:
Atom doesn't seem to follow Mac convention in certain cases. To reproduce:
1. Double click to highlight a word
2. Option + shift + left arrow
- In other apps, both words are now selected.
- In atom, the selection is cleared and the cursor is now at the start of the original word.

Similarly, if the 2. is replaced with command + shift + left arrow, in Atom the extended selection doesn't include the originally selected word as it would in other apps.

(This is clearly a minor issue; but it's frustrating if you're used to this pattern. Atom is fantastic overall!)
Label: enhancement

Title: rendering issue with submodules
Body:
I have a repo that contained a number of submodules.
All my submodules have been listed in the .gitignore file.

When I open a submodule with atom, it's not recognized as a git package and all its folders are greyed out. I assume it's because the parent .gitignore mentionned it.
Label: enhancement

Title: Up/down should move cursor to beginning/end in mini editor.
Body:
This is a similar issue/request as #6445. Though as noted in the comments on the associated PR (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6456), this issue might be trickier to get right because up/down are overloaded to do additional things in the select list (used to scroll through the options) and the `find-and-replace` UI (used to select among previous searches).

Thus, in the process of introducing new cursor behavior, the overrides in those UIs must be maintained.
Label: enhancement

Title: Option to load entire file into memory.
Body:
There are times (like when we use Nautilus to edit files on our server) that it would be nice to load the entire file into memory to prevent any kind of lag (such as the lag we often receive with Atom Editor when editing these files.)

Can we please get an option (or detection) that allows us to load remote files into memory for efficiency?
Label: enhancement

Title: Reopening windows feature from 193 not working
Body: Does the Desktop shortcut on Windows need updating for this to work, maybe? Because it does not work for me atm, see video: https://youtu.be/SETJog-VnkY
Label: bug

Title: open previous window from command line?
Body:
> Opening Atom without the command line (e.g. using the dock on OSX) now re-opens any previously opened windows

Would it be hard for me to do a PR to add a command-line option to open atom with the previous windows?  I know my use-case is rare but I open X11 windows from the command-line and I have no desktop at all.

I know this isn't going to happen but logically using `atom` would open previous windows and `atom .` would open the working directory.
Label: enhancement

Title: triple-click+scroll doesn't work properly
Body:
On Atom 0.193, OSX 10.10.3
Triple-clicking (to fully select a line), then letting the left mouse button pressed and scrolling (with mouse wheel or two-finger swipe on the trackpad) doesn't work properly: it should scroll and expand the selection, but the scroll jumps back to where it was.
Label: bug

Title: Distinguish whether a Marker is visible on screen (versus fully folded)
Body: Here's a scenario to illustrate the problem: Let's say we create a Decoration on a certain Marker. This Marker spans buffer rows 2-3. Row 0 is then folded, and let's say this collapses buffer rows 0-5. What We Expect The Decoration should not be visible at all, because buffer rows 2-3 are entirely contained within the collapsed range. Actual Behavior The `decoration.getMarker().getScreenRange()` returns row 0 (i.e. the row that rows 2-3 were collapsed into), which indicates that the Decoration should be visible on screen at row 0. Possible Solutions In discussion with @nathansobo, it seems like changing `Marker::getScreenRange` to return null in this situation is not a viable option now, because that's likely to break many packages. One solution could be to add a `visibleOnScreen` property to `Marker`.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom will not launch from a USB flash drive when setting `ATOM_HOME`
Body:
Most of the details can be found at this post:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/starting-atom-via-command-line-does-not-launch-it-correctly/16279/2

I recently tried to run atom portable. I would like to keep all my themes and packages on the drive as well, so I created a .atom folder on my flash drive using `md .atom`. After that, I extracted the latest zip distribution of Atom into an `Atom` folder on my flash drive. To set `ATOM_HOME` and launch atom, I used the following script:

```
@echo off
set ATOM_HOME= "E:/.atom"
start E:/Atom/atom.exe --safe
echo ATOM_HOME currently at %ATOM_HOME%
echo.
pause
```

When trying to run this script, I got

```
[4924:0421/080402:INFO:CONSOLE(67)] "RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
```

The rest of the stack trace can be found at the above link. Oddly, after I `REM`ed out the `set ATOM_HOME= "E:/.atom"`, atom launched fine from the flash drive. Is there anyway this can be fixed?
Label: bug

Title: Shift-up at the end of input should select all.
Body: In `atom-text-editor:mini`, when I get to the end of the line, `shift-up` should select all of the text in the input like a native input box would. This is not working in Atom 0.192.0 on OS X.
Label: enhancement

Title: Docs website 500ing
Body:
Hi,

visiting https://atom.io/docs/v0.60.0/publish-a-package gives me a 500 error message and tells me to let you know if a refresh does not solve the problem. Well, it does not. ;)
Label: bug

Title: Notifications affect focus
Body:
> **GIVEN** the editor has unsaved changes,
> **AND** the "save on blur option is on,
> **AND** a notification is set to trigger on save (by some other function),
> **AND** I trigger a dialog to appear
> **THEN** the focus is moved from the editor to the dialog _briefly_ until it moves back to the editor (which is in the background).

The example below was made using the atom-typescript package's rename dialog & compile-on-save. The notification in this example was triggered by the compile-on-save feature. Roughly the same happens with the symbols dialog, the file dialog etc. In these cases though, the focus moves back to the editor and the dialog disappears.

![Example](http://i.imgur.com/iP0cEYg.gif)

Atom versions: 0.190 & 0.192
Label: bug

Title: 100% CPU usage when started in the home folder
Body:
When editing a file, after the editor was open for a little while, it started to consume all the CPU and steadily consume more RAM (until all the available RAM is consumed).

The command line of the runaway process was:

```
/usr/share/atom/atom --eval require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/james/.atom/compile-cache/coffee'); require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').register(); require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app/node_modules/coffeestack/index.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/james/.atom/compile-cache/coffee/source-maps'); require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/task-bootstrap.js');
```

This behavior seems to have just emerged after I updated it to 0.192.0 this morning.

Title: when duplicating a folder on a mounted disk a progress indicator should show
Body:
Currently I got the Keep Waiting dialogue and I had to click 3 4 times until the folder was copied.
When I did it using the OS I got something like this
![screen shot 2015-04-17 at 2 35 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/293377/7208504/50f8eb5e-e50f-11e4-9c44-87634206ae9e.png)

It would be nice is a dialogue like this could be implemented
Label: enhancement

Title: No keybinding for editor:split-selections-into-lines on Linux and Windows
Body:
I guess that a lot of atom users are coming from sublime, and we tend to expect some keyboard shortcut like the split-selections-into-lines.

On mac os it's the same keybinding than sublime for split-selections-into-lines, but not on Linux and nor Windows.

I had to add the following lines to my `keymap.cson`:

``` cson
'.platform-linux atom-text-editor':
  'ctrl-shift-L': 'editor:split-selections-into-lines'
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Add a standard 'popover' panel layer
Body:
Currently Atom has panel layers for top/left/right/bottom and modal. I think it would also be useful to have a 'popover' panel layer. This would be an absolutely positioned layer above all other window content (except modal panel layer). Panels would be absolute positioned in it. I've created a starting point pull request with more information here:

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6419
Label: enhancement

Title: Overriding a grammars filetype association
Body:
I wan't to have .tpl files associated with a Smarty grammar, but the default html grammar already specifies .tpl in its file type. Is there a way around this. I have seen the [File Types](https://github.com/execjosh/atom-file-types) package but this specifically says at the bottom of the read me `You probably don't want to assign the same file type to multiple languages...`

Is there any way other than editing the HTML language package and removing the .tpl association to override that? I can't see that would be great though as if you have two packages trying to override, which would be used?
Label: enhancement

2. Quit Atom
3. Open Atom w/ no arguments (e.g. from spotlight on OSX)

Title: CommandRegistry::add docs are missing parameter info
Body: Not sure what we did with our atomdoc here, but [the parameter info for `CommandRegistry::add`](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.190.0/CommandRegistry#instance-add) has been missing [since at least 0.154.0](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.154.0/CommandRegistry#instance-add), despite being [in the code comments](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v0.190.0/src/command-registry.coffee#L55-L82).
Label: bug

Title: Add support for specifying human-readable command labels
Body:
Refs https://github.com/atom/command-palette/issues/36#issuecomment-92618828

Currently, there is no way to specify a human-readable label for a command – when you add a command, you can only specify the command name (/identifier), and Atom will ["humanize" this name](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/command-registry.coffee#L153) (in the Command Palette for instance), but you can't specify a different human-readable name. It would be extremely useful to be able to specify a human-readable name when creating a command.

We already define `displayName` [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/command-registry.coffee#L153) – it could just be a matter of allowing this to be specified on command`::add`.
Label: enhancement

Title: Outdenting should keep the same lines selected
Body:
Unindenting/outdenting/dedenting a block of code can leave you with a selection without one of the lines that you outdented, so continuing to outdent leaves that line behind.

![doublebugger](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3630663/7127253/5f86888c-e20f-11e4-8dff-18dce68689c6.gif)
~~_Also demonstrated in this gif: [gutter highlight stays behind](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6363)_~~

Instead, it should keep part of the selection on that line. Actually, I think it should select the entire line.
If it kept only a single character selected it would be weird especially if using spaces, and if it kept only the leading whitespace selected, it would still have the problem if you dedent all the way.

_Did I miss any keywords? unindent unindented dedented dedent indentation_
Label: bug

Title: Replace Bootstrap CSS with hand-written CSS designed for Atom
Body:
The bootstrap CSS is enormous. It is designed to solve a problem that Atom does not have. That is, a set of CSS rules to normalize presentation across all browsers that may be used for rendering, using whatever browser-specific hacks necessary to achieve that goal.

The project was also conceived before the advent of flexbox, which means that bootstrap has a ton of cruft to deal with pre-flexbox browsers. Such workarounds are verbose and make it difficult to understand what can be removed.

In sum, this puts Atom into a situation where:
- The CSS is much larger than what Atom needs.
- It requires much more work than should be necessary to understand why the current CSS works the way it does.
- Bootstrap is the source of truth, rather than something that is directly under Atom's control.

For example, take a look at the issue I recently filed against Bootstrap: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/16276. The recommended solution is to pile on another hack (i.e., use an even more specific CSS selector) rather than figure out why the existing CSS works the way it does and fix the underlying problem with the model. Presumably this is because trying to untangle why things work the way they do is too hard.

Atom should not be saddled with the baggage of layout engines of old and should be exploiting the fact that it only needs to support Blink (which supports flexbox), and write its own small, specific, and far more maintainable CSS.
Label: enhancement

Title: Mini editor keybindings don't match native text input keybindings
Body:
In particular in a native text field (OS X anyway) I can use Up/Down to move or select to the start/end of my text field. These keybindings/commands ARE properly implemented in the standard TextEditor, it just looks like they've been intentionally left out of the mini editor. In particular if you look in `text-editor-element.coffee` you'll see:

```
atom.commands.add 'atom-text-editor:not([mini])', stopEventPropagation(
  'core:move-up': -> @moveUp()
  'core:move-down': -> @moveDown()
  'core:move-to-top': -> @moveToTop()
  'core:move-to-bottom': -> @moveToBottom()
...
```

I think the following commands should be included in the mini editor to match native behavior:

```
  'core:move-up': -> @moveUp()
  'core:move-down': -> @moveDown()
  'core:move-to-top': -> @moveToTop()
  'core:move-to-bottom': -> @moveToBottom()
  'core:select-up': -> @selectUp()
  'core:select-down': -> @selectDown()
  'core:select-to-top': -> @selectToTop()
  'core:select-to-bottom': -> @selectToBottom()
```

Does this seem like a reasonable change? If so I can make a pull request, just asking first since these seem to have been explicitly disabled in the mini editor.
Label: enhancement

Title: Project.getRepositoryForPath(path)?
Body:
Should the Project API, now that it can return multiple repositories (#3691), have a convenience function to return the repository for a given path?

Use case is https://github.com/diiq/atomatigit/issues/75, which needs to figure out which repo to target based on current tab.

Title: Character positioning/cursor movement breaks with certain emoji characters
Body:
Atom 0.190.0, OS X 10.10
Enter some random emoji, such as :ocean::eyes::relieved:, then add :m: to the end, the preceding characters move and overlap and the cursor position gets weird.

![emoji](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/7049599/9f3f513a-de12-11e4-842e-76ea1a04206e.gif)

Seems to only happen with :m:, but I haven't tried everything.

I think it's something to do with variation selectors. When you enter :m: using the OS X emoji palette, it encodes as `e2 93 82 ef b8 8f`, or `CIRCLED LATIN CAPITAL LETTER M` followed by `VARIATION SELECTOR 16`. If you copy and paste just `CIRCLED LATIN CAPITAL LETTER M` it works fine.
Label: bug

Title: Linux @ VirtualBox mouse problem
Body:
There is a [known issue](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=456222) with Chrome41 engine running on Linux in VirtualBox. It actually became a show-stopper for Chrome42. **TL;DR**: in VB Chrome41 engine _always_ runs in touch-screen mode, even on desktops.

Hotfix in Chrome41 is to pass `--touch-devices=123` to the chrome command line.

Is it possible to pass parameters to Atom’s command line so that chrome engine will understand them?
Label: bug

I can only shrink the volume by 2GB, though. I checked the logs, and the culprit is an immovable file in one of my Atom packages.

`Users\Oliver\.atom\.node-gyp\.atom\.apm\esmangle\1.0.1\package\lib\pass::$SECURITY_DESCRIPTOR`

What to do, what to do?

Thanks!

Body:

![getboundingclientrect-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/7027008/68b59d24-dd4d-11e4-98a0-f9072503696e.gif)

It demonstrates a weird issue with `getBoundingClientRect` method results.
I have put logs in the method that positions the quick settings menu of the minimap, when in the function the returned bounds object has a negative top offset (which is not what it should return).
When calling the same method on the same object from the console, I get a different, but now correct result. 
I can't say when exactly it started doing this but I'm guessing it started with the update to chrome 41.

Anyone has an idea why `getBoundingClientRect` act this way?
Label: bug

Title: Allow a location option when adding menu items
Body:
Right now when you add menu items they get inserted at the bottom of the specified menu. I would like to have some optional way to the specify a location when inserting menu items. From what I can tell this isn't possible now. Is anyone working on this already? If not and I create a solution what are the chances that I can get it merged into Atom?

My basic design would follow how I think Eclipse solves this problem. Haven't actually used Eclipse for years, but I think the basic idea is: Give each item an optional "location" attribute that's used to determine where the item is inserted relative to existing item IDs in the menu.

The ID of existing menu items would be an "ID" attribute if found, otherwise it would fallback to using "label", though that's problematic if menus will ever be localized.

The set of locations specifiers would be:

`location="top"` - The item will be inserted at the top of the menu.

`location="bottom"` - The item will be inserted at the bottom of the menu.

`location="before:id"` - The item will be inserted before the existing item with matching ID.

`location="after:id"` - The item will be inserted after the existing item with matching ID.

`location="endof:id"` - The item will be inserted at the end of the separator group with matching ID. (this means it will be inserted right before the next separator group starts.
Label: enhancement

Title: Reloading on an external monitor moves the window back to the primary monitor
Body:
Steps to repro:
1. Open Atom in the primary monitor
2. Move the window to an external monitor
3. Reload

I expect the window to stay on the external monitor, but it jumps back to the primary monitor.
Label: bug

Title: Multiple file requesters on File -> Open File on v0.189.0
Body: I'm using Debian 64 bit.  I just discovered that one can go to the file menu and choose Open File and a file requester opens.  One can leave that requester open and go back to the file menu and choose Open File again, and another file requester will open **behind** the first one.  This can be especially problematic because the the first file requester (including the cancel button) is non-responsive.

Didn't have this problem in Atom in this environment before the upgrade to use Chrome 41.  Makes Atom very difficult to use in this environment.

Ideally we should be able to provision a cibuild on both Travis and AppVeyor, so that we can check if specs pass on Windows and *nix environments.

Title: Cannot paste into Atom from other apps; cannot paste from Atom into other apps; may crash Atom
Body: I'm using Atom ver. 0.189.0 on Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS. When I copy a piece of text in atom and I try to paste it the right-click menu either won't show up or will show up without giving me option to paste. The paste shortcut doesn't work either and it creates issues even if I try to copy and paste text from other programs (after I have coping something from atom). I have disable all the extra plugins, so it isn't a plugin issue. I didn't had this issue with the previous version (I am using webupd8 ppa). If I do a right click on a place where there isn't a text entry (meaning a place where it doesn't support paste anyway) the right click menu appears fine.
Label: bug

Title: Modifying files outside of Atom creates ENOENT errors
Body:
Some repro steps that I gathered from the existing issues:
1. Have a file open in branch `something` that doesn't exist in branch `atom`
2. `git checkout atom`
3. ENOENT :boom: 
OR
1. Have a file open in Atom that will be affected by `git rebase`
2. `git rebase`
3. ENOENT :-1:
OR
Just simply rename a file outside of Atom that's currently open inside of Atom.
Label: bug

Title: Atom Editor Doesn't Come to Foreground
Body:
Hi,

My OS is Ubuntu 14.10. I use Unity as my window manager. Atom version is 0.188.0. 

If I open a file from Nautilus file manager by pressing "Enter" or by double-clicking, Atom often doesn't come to foreground. (Its icon wobbles in Unity dashboard.) To see it, I have to switch to Atom manually. Only after that, I can work on the file. 

I made some tests. It happens when Atom is already open and if I use Alt+Tab key combination. If I never use Alt+Tab to switch between windows, then there's no problem. Otherwise, first I've to open file, then manually switch to Atom window. Unfortunately It's inefficinet way to work.

What I want is, Atom should always come to foreground, if I open a file. Is there a workaround or a patch for this problem?

Kind regards,
Cagatay
Label: bug

Title: Canceling multiselect should retain first selection, not last
Body:
Coming from Sublime, I'm expecting that canceling a multiselect retains my original selection, rather than the final match.

**Atom**

![atom-cancel-multiselect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4323180/6932292/485e2216-d7e5-11e4-9c76-4b7b2748dc2f.gif)

![sublime-cancel-multiselect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4323180/6932303/6ecba18a-d7e5-11e4-9457-836342cfc128.gif)

Not that Atom should necessarily behave exactly like Sublime, but I thought it was a difference in behavior that was worth bringing up for discussion.

If the current behavior is intentional, expected behavior, any chance someone could be so kind as to point me in the direction of how I could write a plugin to override this for my own setup? Having a hard time figuring out where the "cancel selection" behavior is defined.

Thanks! :)

Title: core should use services when provided
Body:
When the `web-browser` package is installed the user clearly wants web pages opened internally.  I can only think of one way to handle this situation.
- If a web service is offered then the internal webpage open, like menu help, should use it.  Would  a PR for this be accepted?  
- Does it make sense for core to consume services or should services provided by packages only be used by other packages?
- Is there a better way to handle this?
Label: enhancement

Title: Help menu doesn't work if no browser is installed
Body: None of the Help menu items (except for Release Notes) works if the user does not have a web browser installed. The default on CentOS 7 is not to have a browser. It wouldn't be so bad if at least an error message popped up informing that the user needs a browser. As it is right now, there is no error message, no help, no nothing. It would be nicer if the help was not 100% dependent on an external browser.
Label: enhancement

Title: Issues when editing .reg files
Body:
When editing a .reg file, you have to press the **del** key twice to delete a key. This is the same with **backspace**.

Also, when you highlight text, the amount highlighted is half the position of the cursor.

For example, trying to highlight _I am using Atom to edit text_, would only highlight _I am using At_.

Note that typed text after opening the file and before saving isn't affected by this issue.
Label: bug

Title: Text wiggling
Body:
The text on the tabs and certain panels (such as settings) wiggles around a bit as I mouse over and off it.

![](http://i.imgur.com/HOqeBsZ.gif)

Produced on Win8.1 running at 4K.
Label: bug

Title: Selecting text in atom based text editor doesn't work like native platform
Body:
In particular on Mac OS X if you:
1. start creating a drag selection.
2. Drag to above the text editor.
3. Then the text selection will always extend to the 0 column of the text.

But in Atom this doesn't happen. Instead the selection extends to the column based on the mouse x position, even when the mouse y position is above the text editor. (Atom does correctly handle the case (set selection to end of text) when the mouse extends below the text editor... it's only the above case that's not working correctly).

This pull request fixes the issue:

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6167
Label: enhancement

Title: Support `block` as a decoration type for TextEditor.
Body: There should be a `block` decoration type that can span the entire width of the editor, appearing below a line and forcing subsequent lines to appear below it. This could be used to display UI for things like inline comments, as you can in a GitHub pull request.
Label: enhancement

Title: Automatically install package updates option
Body: Could there be an option to automatically install package updates? When I see package updates, I usually just install them blindly, so I would like to have it just keep everything up to date for me. It would also be nice if there could be a notification when it updates something.
Label: enhancement

Title: Folding toggle command
Body:
Hi,

Currently Atom has 2 different commands for folding/unfolding the current row: 
1. editor:fold-current-row 
2. editor:unfold-current-row

But it seems more logical to have just one row folding toggle command, and use to fold/unfold a block.

This is more like a feature request, it seems that both Atom and SublimeText are missing this, and Visual Studio gets it right. The fold all behaviour of Atom is much better than Sublime's though.

Thank you.
Label: enhancement

Title: Conflict ignored when changing file outside of Atom when it has unsaved changes in Atom.
Body: I have a clean local file `foo` open in Atom, and I modify the file outside Atom. Atom reloads the file, which is fine. But if I have unsaved changes in file `foo` in Atom, and `foo` gets modified externally, Atom does not tell me about external changes, even when I try to save the file.
Label: enhancement

Title: Weird scroll jump when scrolling and then clicking in a buffer
Body:
When a scroll in the editor put the cursor out of the screen and then clicking in the buffer to put the cursor somewhere, the editor's scroll unexpectedly changes.

![atom-scroll-jump-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/6872742/66c042ee-d4ab-11e4-8a31-f80abdf2835f.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Add support for checkmarks in the menu
Body:
It would be really nice if there will be support for adding a checkmark in front of a menu item in Atom API. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11520795/6871957/cf4b211e-d4ae-11e4-8a3f-2d827fd9323b.png)

It may be useful to easy access some setting that change very often for an Atom package.
Label: enhancement

Title: Rename / Disable "Reopen Last Item"
Body:
Suggestions:
1. Disable "Reopen Last Item" until a document has been closed.
2. Rename "Reopen Last Item" to "Reopen Closed Document"

Justification:
In the absence of a "Open Recent...", the wording of the "Reopen Last Item" menu option is confusing. Nearly every time I use Atom as a new user, I launch Atom and go to File > Reopen Last Item. It doesn't do anything. See #5718.

As I understand it, it seems to actually be more similar to a browser's "Reopen Closed Tab", no? Chrome has "Reopen Closed Tab". Until this is made moot by #4241, we should rename that menu item to "Reopen Closed Document" or something to that effect.

Part of the confusion is that "Reopen Last Item" has the same placement as the standard "Open Recent..." menu option, but they don't operate the same way. We should disable it until Atom is in a state where the menu item actually does anything.
Label: enhancement

Title: Editor does not autoscroll to undo location
Body:
- Open `package.json` from atom/atom in Atom
- Type an `a` on the first line
- Scroll to the botom
- Undo

Editor is still scrolled to the bottom instead of to the top where the edit was just undone.
Label: bug

Title: Delete Line deletes more than one line if the line has multiple selections
Label: bug

Title: Add Root Folder from command line
Body:
The tree-view command "Add Root Folder" is very useful. Frequently I want to open multiple projects in one editor window, with each project as a root folder. This enables things like tree-view's "Hide VCS Ignored Files" to actually work. Other packages also require the root of a repository to be a root folder in tree-view, such as git-blame, for example. Currently, opening a directory from the command line results in opening a new Atom editor window.

``` shell
atom /foo/bar # creates new window with /foo/bar the single root folder in tree-view
atom /foo/baz # creates another window
```

I have a feeling issue atom/tree-view#393 would block implementing a feature like this, but it would be very nice to support something like the following.

``` shell
atom /foo/bar # creates new window with /foo/bar the single root folder in tree-view
atom -a /foo/baz # adds /foo/baz as a root folder to an existing window (most recently used?)
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom should save new files where the last opened/saved file was
Body:
When you create a new buffer and hit save, Atom will present me with a save dialog and the default selected folder is the project root. That's almost never the place I want to put a file.

Sublime Text was a lot smarter with this -- although I do not remember the exact heuristics. For example, it would propose saving the file in the same location where the file you last had opened was. This worked really well for me: Usually I create a new file by splitting an existing file, creating a test for a module (and those two are in directly adjacent directories) or similar.

Even if I want to save to the root directory, which is the current behavior, navigating upwards in the file save dialog is really simple.

PS: I am using Atom 0.187.0
Label: enhancement

Title: Warn before quitting
Body: It'd be nice to have an option to warn before quitting when hitting Cmd+Q as its too easy to close all your editors when trying to close a single tab. Chrome has this option and its a time saver.
Label: enhancement

Title: Show the unsaved file while displaying the 'unsaved changes' alert at closing.
Body:
If you have several files with unsaved changes, when you try to exit the application you will only see the current open buffer when clicking discard. Atom should show you the particular buffer about to be saved or discarded.

I have atom 0.144.0 on an ubuntu 14.04

Similar problem here: #5823
Label: enhancement

Title: Wrong conversion from screen to pixels and screen to buffer with soft wrap enabled
Body:
A screenshot is more telling so let's start here: 

![color-marker-element-spec_coffee_-__users_cedric_github_pigments_-_atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/6770695/4f9e5164-d0c8-11e4-9e85-529dfcfa7c04.png)

This is the only wrapped line of the file. As you can see, when querying the pixel position for the first column of the first line after the text wrap, the pixel position is still the one of the last char of the line above. This is true for every columns of the hanging indent (see the screenshot below). I guess the issue comes from the handling of the hanging indent, but the result shouldn't be a position at the end of the line above anyway.

![color-marker-element-spec_coffee_-__users_cedric_github_pigments_-_atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/6770769/35679794-d0cb-11e4-912b-95831c192dff.png)

But, it's not the only problem, converting position from the screen to the buffer space coordinates gives also weird result:

![color-marker-element-spec_coffee_-__users_cedric_github_pigments_-_atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/247140/6770718/7bc4199e-d0c9-11e4-8741-6554240be401.png)

As you can see, here the converted buffer range starts one character before what's the editor element displays.

Config: 

Atom Version 0.188.0-f42a62d
OSX 10.10.3
Label: bug

Title: Incremental find
Body:
Here's another Sublime Text feature Atom doesn't have that Sublime users may miss.

{`Cmd`,`Ctrl`} + `i` starts an incremental find, which works like {`Cmd`,`Ctrl`} + `f` but jumps to the first match as you type and closes when you hit enter.

It's great for quickly getting to a different part of the file.
Label: enhancement

Title: Indicator to control per-document indentation options
Body:
Atom needs an indicator in the lower right displaying the current spaces/tabs setting for the document. Which should also give access to options that control the per-document indentation settings.

Attempting to auto detect indentation is fine. But for a developer that works on projects all over, indentation practices are anything but reliable. User, syntax, and project settings just don't cut it for picking up a random library, making a small tweak, and then submitting it. Changing the per-document settings should be a few quick clicks.

This is standard in other editors like Atom. And I find it is used even more often than the encoding indicator Atom has already added.
Label: enhancement

Title: Converting spaces <-> tabs should only apply to a selection when one exists
Body:
When the user has made a selection, the convert spaces to tabs and convert tabs to spaces options should only apply to the selected lines.
((If you have some reason to dislike this behaviour, please at least make it a preference))

I had the unexpected experience of trying to correct the spaces in a small spot of a file and finding that not only were the leading spaces elsewhere in that file converted, but spaces in the middle of the line that were used for `=>` alignment were converted into tabs (and into the wrong number of tabs).
Label: enhancement

Title: Tab length spaces are treated as tabs
Body:
My settings have `tab spaces` set to 4. I also have `soft tabs` enabled - as well as `Show invisibles` so I can see that spaces are being inserted instead of tabs.

If I hit space bar 4 times (or hit tab once).

![space-4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1747643/6747444/7ed62c82-cf2d-11e4-96d4-ad0e763e28ba.png)
That's good, it appears 4 spaces have been inserted. Now if I hit the left key, I'm taken to the start of the line (and not back one space).
![left-arrow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1747643/6747454/b5721a80-cf2d-11e4-8e1f-2bc29afbd729.png)
Or, if I hit backspace, all four spaces are removed.
![backspace](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1747643/6747466/e1d0af06-cf2d-11e4-8139-ca42b9f3e42d.png)

Similarly if I try and highlight one of those spaces with my mouse, I can only highlight all or nothing of the 4 spaces.
![hightlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1747643/6747648/6cd283e8-cf30-11e4-907a-58db5a7add3d.png)
In other editors I use (gedit, brackets), the behaviour I've found is that backspace, or left, will only go back one character, not the whole 4 (or what's configured) spaces.

I'm running on Ubuntu 14.04 (x86_64) and with version 0.187 of Atom.
Label: enhancement

Title: Update should disable the package in all open atom windows
Body:
Currently it only disables it _only_ in the window where you click the update button. 
# Motivation

Atom-TypeScript runs a separate atom instance (as node) in the background to do the heavy lifting away from the UI thread. We kill this background worker if we get deactivated. 
- _The happy case:_ This means if you only have one atom window open, and run update : the worker is stopped and the files can be deleted and updated by apm. 
- **The issue:** If you have two atom windows open we will have two workers (one with each atom instance). If you start an update in one atom window, the worker will still be running for the other atom window and therefore apm will fail to delete the directory. Furthermore it will delete just enough to leave the whole plugin unusable. 

refs https://github.com/TypeStrong/atom-typescript/issues/195
Label: bug

Title: Add support for VIM-like jump lists
Body: Currently Atom has supported for bookmarks but I must manually set a bookmark and then navigate back to it.  I would like to have support built-in the editor so that I can navigate backwards/forwards through my file navigation and editing.  For example, if I have file "A.js" open and I do a project-wide search for symbols and navigate to a symbol in file "B.js", I would then like to be able to issue a command (like Ctrl-o) to navigate back from B.js to A.js.

Title: Add option for hanging indent for soft-wrapped lines.
Body:
Please consider adding an option for hanging indents for soft-wrapped lines. It's really helpful for identifying wrapped lines, especially for languages like LaTeX where lines tend to be long and frequent editing makes manual hard wrapping needlessly tedious.

Example (adapted from @AlexLog's nicely-done example from Discuss): 

``` latex

% Current behavior
\begin{itemize}
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
    aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
    aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
\end{itemize}

% Proposed behavior with 4-space hanging indent specified
\begin{itemize}
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
        aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
        aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
\end{itemize}

```

I'd add a variable to the soft wrap indent formula whose value is added to the indent level of the first line. By default, the value could be zero. In the UI, it should be on the `Settings` tab below `Tab Length` and named `Soft Wrap Hanging Indent`. If it uses a dropdown list like `Tab Length`, the options could be the same as the tab length options with the default zero option added.

While it could be designed as adding a configurable number of tab stops, it may be simpler to just make it a number of spaces, as there may be people who want a hanging indent level to be distinct from tab stops. Since the default would be zero, any level would have to be configured, so the number of spaces option would be no more configuration effort and more flexible.

Related discussions:

Discuss thread: https://discuss.atom.io/t/indented-soft-wrap/4808/1
Indent soft wrap (PR, Merged): https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/5567
Label: enhancement

Title: The insanity of Unicode's "RTL override"
Body:
This is a bug report mostly based on [this neat article](http://habrahabr.ru/post/252813/). I'll summarize the essence that relates to Atom, right here. Consider this snippet of Python:

``` python
def maps():
    print "maps maps maps"

def spam():
    print "Erasing everything..."
    print "done."

s = "spam‮" ,spam ,"‬spam"
# ^ attention to this line: try selecting it with your mouse
s[1]()
```

That line, properly escaped:

``` python
s = "spam‮" ,spam ,"‬spam"
```

The symbols of interest, in order of appearance, are `‮` or RLO (right-to-left override) and `‬` or PDF (pop directional formatting). They, respectively, reverse text direction and set it back.

Atom expands this combination just like a browser would, it actually displays that RLO-PDF piece in reverse. However, interaction with it is... awkward. Start with the fact that you can't (at least visually) move your cursor inside that gap in any way.

Look at this. With "Plain text" grammar on, I've selected that line:

![Screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/q6KKB0M.png)

Noticed that? 10 units of extra space. Notice also, that between RLO and PDF are exactly 10 characters. That's a hint. However, once I switch on Python grammar (and RLO-PDF interval is now contained in multiple elements), things get even more awkward.

![Screenshot 2](http://i.imgur.com/QpOpCDm.png)

Not 10 units, as before. Now we have only 4. And from that moment, I don't have a slightest clue about what's going on, but something needs to be done about that.

This needs a discussion. I can immediately come up with these two general directions:
1. Interpret as designed in Unicode. Fix the UI, make the cursor work properly and not introduce gaps like the ones above.
2. Represent Unicode control characters with some sort of "placeholders" and don't let them act as designed in Unicode.

Personally, I stand for placeholders, as Atom is mostly a code editor, and code is a raw sequence of characters. It makes sense for Atom to display it as closely as possible to how the parser will see it.

In those cases when plain text is used to author a document that makes use of these sequences to display properly, "preview" plugins come into play and let you preview the document as it will look after processing.

Thoughts?
Label: bug

Title: Support HTML-first workflow
Body:
Google Polymer takes an "HTML-first" approach to defining custom elements. Rather than calling a JavaScript method to register an element, you instead use a custom `<polymer-element>` tag to declare elements. The Polymer team had difficulty using this approach in Atom for a couple of reasons.
### Issues running inline scripts due to our content-security policy

This is the biggest hurdle. There's currently no way to white-list script tags in an imported HTML document. A content security policy can be associated with a nonce value that can be inserted into scripts to indicate they are runnable, and it would be nice if we could cascade this nonce through an HTML import to script tags in the imported content.
### Needing to manually insert HTML-imports into the `<head>`

This is easily solvable via a service that presents a function like `loadHTMLDocument(fullPath)`. I'd rather do it with `require`, but Node-style requires are expected to be synchronous and waiting for the imported content to load is async. This would therefore still require a tiny bit of boilerplate in `activate` to interact with the service and load the package's main document.
Label: enhancement

Title: incorrect cursor placement on lines with accented characters
Body:
There seems to have been a recent regression in the placement of the cursor and end-of-line marker on lines with accented characters. For example 

ὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤ

Has ten _characters_ but if you ctrl-E to the end of the line the cursor is in the wrong place:

![screen shot 2015-03-15 at 5 18 12 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24426/6658154/54d492a6-cb37-11e4-88da-f370ee0b9d59.png)

This may seem obscure but is making it very difficult to use Atom for natural language processing applications with non-ASCII character sets. It worked fairly recently so is likely a recent regression.
Label: bug

Title: Three finger tap for definitions doesn't work on OS X
Body:
In a Mac text view or web view, when you three finger tap a word it becomes yellow and a popover window with definitions (from country specific dictionaries and wikipedia) appears. Not so in atom.
I find this very annoying since I use that feature a lot. I'm not sure if this is a bug or a feature request since it is standard in all (not strictly) other similar apps.
Label: bug

Title: Paragraphs selection misses nonempty lines
Body:
rowRangeForParagraphAtBufferRow misses nonempty lines

From the comment "Right now, a paragraph is a block of text bounded by and empty line or a block of text that is not the same type (comments next to source code)."

But the code will not match lines which contain non-word characters such as punctuation.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f7bb8aab9e33090cc8455cfdf045efe6257568d9/src/app/language-mode.coffee#L183

This means that blocks of code are incorrectly selected if there is for example a trailing bracket on its own line.
Label: bug

Title: Window resizes to 1px wide sometimes - Usability Issue
Body:
It is not consistently reproducible - happens randomly. I have first noticed in 0.186.0 build and seen in 0.187.0 build. I am using Ubuntu 14.04 LTS. 

Did some trial and error when this happens: 
- if i try to open another window from command line like another folder using `atom` the new window opens normally.
-  If try to quit it will close normally. 
-  If i reopen the folder whose window is like 1px wide it will open with same dimension 1px wide. 
  Uploading a screenshot.

![screenshot from 2015-03-11 17 09 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2712395/6595702/a17d2db6-c812-11e4-9e39-ea46fdbf7013.png)

I feel the user able to minimize window(or because of bug) to such small size is a usability issue as the 1px wide window is difficult to locate and causes confusion to user.
Label: bug

Title: It would be great to have a packages.cson for the apm packages
Body:
The benefit of keeping packages information in a separate file like packages.cson, is that we can easier to create a portable environment.

So basically (and ideally), I can just need to sync these files to setup up a new atom environment
- config.cson
- keymap.cson
- snippets.cson
- init.coffee
- styles.less
- packages.cson (new)

Title: Add "New Window" on dock context menu on OS X.
Body:
Please consider adding a "New Window" option on the dock context menu for Atom. This change would make working with many spaces much more pleasant.

Post-change:
1. Change to intended space for new window.
2. Click and hold (or Ctrl-click, or right/two-finger click) on the Atom icon.
3. Select "New Window".
4. Work.

Currently:
1. Change to intended space for new window.
2. Click and hold (or Ctrl-click, or right/two-finger click) on the Atom icon.
3. Curse because there's no "New Window" option, using an irreverent compound "swearword" with another swearword added (and presumably set off by hyphens) in the middle.
4. Click the Atom icon and watch transition to another space.
5. Press Shift-Cmd-N (or use the menu).
6. Use the Mission Control gesture (three finger upward swipe).
7. Drag the new window to the intended space.
8. Click the intended space.
9. Work.

I'm having a little bit of fun with the procedure above, but the change would be really helpful.

Examples of current behavior and the context menu option in Safari:

![screen shot 2015-03-10 at 12 35 58 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3935135/6579687/22f65e40-c722-11e4-9d05-2e5c3837528d.png)
![screen shot 2015-03-10 at 12 36 32 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3935135/6579688/2305ce52-c722-11e4-84b5-760d5c4256b3.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Configurable stylesheets through user-variables.less
Body:
We were having [this discussion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-allow-users-to-override-my-packages-less-variables/15243/7?u=braver) and jessegrosjean came up with the idea of a `user-variables.less` file.

There have been attempts to set Less variables through config and they have failed for various reasons. While config would be preferable for discovery and ease of use, if it doesn't work perhaps there is a another way.

Users can now overrule styles with their own stylesheet, but that's very limited. It's impossible to change the overall hue of let's say one-dark-ui because those colors are everywhere throughout the stylesheet and the selectors would just be insane. If you can change the variable however, it's just a single number.

The idea would be to have a user-variables.less file in addition to the syntax-variables and the ui-variables. Theme and package authors can choose where to place the import, thereby maintaining control over which variables can be changed by the user. What can be changed can be communicated in the package's readme. This doesn't change the user stylesheet behaviour and would be added in addition to that stylesheet.

So while I think we can agree this is not the ideal solution, the ideal solution being unavailable this could be a brilliant compromise that opens up a lot of options.
Label: enhancement

Title: Make Windows shell integration opt-in via Settings
Body:
Hello all
we're on windows 7 64bits. After installing Atom, basically everywhere I right-click in windows explorer I see a "Open with Atom" item. We tried cleaning those many elements manually from registry, but at the next update of course they're back again.

How can we opt-out from the Winsows shell integration? Possibly at install time and, also, afterwards through some program preferences,

Thanks

Title: Implementing download accelerator into update functionality of Atom
Body:
Hi,

I'm just wonder anyway to implement a multi-threading download accelerator alike wget into update functionality of Atom editor. This will make the update process take less time to download rather than traditional update. Whenever I update Atom, I feel like it never complete.

Conclusion: A functionality that allows Atom to update itself including major and plugins with:
1. secure https download accelerator + 
2. integrity check (md5, sha512 hash).

How do you think about this?
Thanks for consideration.
Label: enhancement

Title: Initial non-English character is multiplied inside automatically closed quotes
Body:
I can't explain this behaviour in words only, so here's the gif:

![weird](http://i.imgur.com/QiaT2vL.gif)

On line 2, I'm typing a single Russian letter '?', but it gets displayed many times in the string. If I press Backspace after that, the whole string of ?'s is erased.

Whatever I'm typing after the first letter is added to the end of the line after all the repetitions. I can delete the first letter, but then the next letter gets repeated etc. 

The only way to get rid of this is to break the line, but as soon as the closing quote is on the same line, weird behaviour reoccurs.

I've tried Japanese and Kazakh characters as well, with the same result.

My OS is Crunchbang Waldorf. I don't experience this issue in Atom for Windows.
Label: bug

Title: autoIndentOnPaste should allow pasting white space
Body:
I enjoy the autoIndentOnPaste feature but when I'm working on a markdown file I sometimes want to paste whitespace.

It would be nice if this feature would exclude any "pastes" that contain only whitespace.
Label: bug

Title: Backslashes disappear from "find in project"
Body:
To reproduce:
1. Shift+command+f to bring up the 'find in project" pane
2. Ensure the regex option is selected
3. Search for a regex that includes a backslash (e.g. `console\.log`)
4. Click any result to go to the file in which it appears
5. Press shift+command+f again.

The backslash has disappeared from the input field. It now says `console.log`.

This has been present in atom for me for months, as long as I can remember. I just reproduced this with `--safe`.

Mac OSX, Atom 0.186.0
Label: bug

Title: cmd-e from outside atom is not recognized
Body:
It is fairly common on OSX to use cmd-e to select text to search. This usually works across applications, but not with Atom.

Expected result:
In terminal: select some text, then press cmd-e
In atom: the search expression should match the selected text
Label: enhancement

Title: Make atom.notifications public
Body: Currently the `atom.notifications` property and the `NotificationManager` class are marked experimental.
Label: enhancement

Title: "Close Tab" menu item is enabled when no tabs are open
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open a project
2. Close all the tabs
3. Select the menu item File > Close Tab

Selecting the menu item does nothing. I expect it to be disabled.
Label: bug

Title: Close startup untitled buffer on opening another file
Body:
When Atom is opened, an "untitled" buffer is created. This makes sense.

However, most of the time, after opening Atom, I then proceed to opening the files I want to edit. At this point, the "untitled" tab remains open even if I haven't changed anything in it.

This is slightly annoying, because it means I have to close a tab that I never wanted in the beginning.
Label: enhancement

Title: Additional fold behaviors when pressing modifier keys
Body:
It would be great if we could get some additional behaviors for folds while the user is pressing modifier keys like in [ACE](https://github.com/ajaxorg/ace/).

I use these pretty extensively while working with complex JS files or lengthy JSON streams and I'd like to see them in Atom someday.

The main ones that I use in ACE are:
- fold children (`shift-click` fold decoration)
- fold children recursively (`shift-cmd-click` fold decoration)
- fold recursively (`cmd-click` fold decoration)
Label: enhancement

Title: Add method for packages to extend command-line interface
Body:
I see a lot of issues and suggestions around people wanting new command-line options. It would be great if people could write their own command-line option handler. Perhaps something like this:
- keymaps
- lib
- options
  - standalone.coffee
- spec
- styles

`standalone.coffee` contains:

``` coffee
module.exports = (arg) ->
  # Do something with the argument here
```

See: 
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1433#issuecomment-76732628
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/add-z-command-line-option-to-ignore-next-parameter/13879
Label: enhancement

Title: copy multi line selection to external application
Body:
When copying a multi line selection to another application, the line breaks are removed. Is this intended?

![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4062007/6437266/8b7ded96-c0bc-11e4-9095-c28f3a8534e5.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Atom gets caught in loop, can't escape until force quit.
Body:
I cloned anchor-cms without creating a fork. So, I don't actually have permission to push to the repository. If I make a change to any of the files, I am prompted for a password. Entering my password, or canceling just causes another error, and another password prompt. I can't interact with any of the red error box's because the password prompt blocks the rest of the editor from responding.

If I just wait and do nothing long enough, I am given the option to close the editor.

![screen shot 2015-02-28 at 9 58 03 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1014630/6429281/bad777d8-bf95-11e4-95a0-e398f7d4b6b7.png)

```
Windows 10 Build 9926
```

Title: Feature Request -- Ability to open new files straight into a new pane
Body:
I really like having different panes but that aren't very friendly to the keyboard.

For example if I want to open a new file into a split right pane, I have to open an EXISTING file into the pane, have two copies of it open long enough for me to CLICK into the new file then open the file I want on the right side of my screen. Then I close the duplicate file that allowed me to have the pane open in the first place. 

Alot of effort.

I'd love the ability to open a new pane at least from the Fuzzy File Finder, something like maybe an alt-enter or command+1 for "Open in nth pane" would be such a huge improvement.
Label: enhancement

Title: Select all very slow when lots of folded content
Body:
Doing <ctrl>a to select the complete buffer, when most of the content is hidden in folded sections is very slow, and it unfolds everything.

I do not see why either of those should happen.

I do this regularly with some javascript files.  I start with everything folded, expand a small section, make changes, then select / copy the whole buffer to paste into jslint.com.  I have not gotten around to installing the jslint package.
Label: bug

Body: How to close atom without save file like sublime text?
Label: enhancement

Title: can't drag tab to window without anything open.
Body:
How to reproduce: open two Atom windows, open one or more files in window 1, close all tabs in window 2. Drag a tab from window 1 to window 2. Window 2 doesn't appear to accept this tab. If window 2 does have one or more tabs open, it does accept tabs dragged onto it.

I'm not sure if it's a bug or a feature, but I can't think of a reason why an empty window shouldn't accept tabs dragged onto it.

(I'm on Windows 7 with Atom 0.182.0)
Label: enhancement

Title: Support running atom commands from CLI
Body:
It would enable a number of useful scenarios to allow specifying commands to execute from the CLI when opening Atom.

For example, using the [merge-conflicts](https://atom.io/packages/merge-conflicts) package, it would be possible to use Atom as a merge resolution tool that could be launched from a source control client:

```
atom --exec 'merge-conflicts:detect' path/to/repository 
```

There are undoubtedly other, better ways for this syntax to work, but using the same commands that appear in Keybinding settings in the UI would be good for usability. 

If there are other scenarios people can think of that would benefit from being able to do something more complex than running a single command, that feedback would be useful here as well to help define how this could work.
Label: enhancement

Title: Allow html imports with inline scripts
Body:
I'm trying to use html imports to pull in custom element definitions that have inline scripts, but running into CSP restrictions.

Adding `'unsafe-inline'` to `script-src` would solve this issue.

Eventually Chrome might add a `'unsafe-static-inline'` to allow only static inline scripts: those that are created directly by the parser, not via script like `innerHTML = ...`. See: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=393307
Label: enhancement

Title: Do something about UI pause when switching themes
Body:
Currently, when you switch themes in the settings view, there's no visual feedback and (at least in my case) the UI seems to briefly pause while it recomputes the styles. We could attack this a few ways, like;
- A spinner in the Themes section of the settings view
- A 30% opacity overlay  with a message over the _whole window_ while styles are recomputed (drastic, but changing the theme is a relatively drastic action that users won't do often)
- other?
Label: enhancement

Title: Manual change of font size leads to visual frobnication in Atom 0.184
Body:
A recent build of Atom seems to have introduced a race condition when manually changing font size with `Cmd =` and `Cmd -`. 

To reproduce, simply repeatedly and rapidly press `Cmd =`, for example.
Label: bug

Title: Cursor.isInsideWord returns incorrect results if only whitespace is to the right of the cursor
Body:
Discovered this while looking into https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5712

Steps to reproduce:

Paste this text into an editor (notice the whitespace after bar):

```
foo bar         
  baz
```

Put the cursor right after `bar` and run this in console:

```
> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].getBufferPosition()
Point {row: 0, column: 7, copy: function, negate: function, freeze: function…}

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isInsideWord()
true
```

Not what I expected. Now, put the cursor a few spaces to the right on the same line (so, it's _surrounded by whitespace, but not at the end of line):

```
> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].getBufferPosition()
Point {row: 0, column: 11, copy: function, negate: function, freeze: function…}

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isInsideWord()
true

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isSurroundedByWhitespace()
true
```

That can't be right -- a cursor can't be surrounded by whitespace _and_ be within a word.

Move the cursor all the way to the EOL:

```
> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].getBufferPosition()
Point {row: 0, column: 16, copy: function, negate: function, freeze: function…}

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isInsideWord()
true

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isSurroundedByWhitespace()
true
```

Same story.

Now, put a character at the end of the first line, so that the content is:

```
foo bar         1
  baz
```

Now put the cursor to the right of `bar` or between `bar` and `1`, and you'll get expected results:

```
> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].getBufferPosition()
Point {row: 0, column: 12, copy: function, negate: function, freeze: function…}

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isInsideWord()
false

> atom.workspace.getActiveEditor().cursors[0].isSurroundedByWhitespace()
true
```

This is tripping up some movement and selection commands (e.g. [getBeginningOfNextWordBufferPosition](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/c9ce9f41c235d9b72a117ef4a682d1e63462e471/src/cursor.coffee#L553-L563)), but I'm not sure if it's the only thing tripping them up. Another thing I noticed is that the same method [doesn't pass `options` to the `wordRegExp()` call](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/c9ce9f41c235d9b72a117ef4a682d1e63462e471/src/cursor.coffee#L559) like other methods do.

cc @benogle @maxbrunsfeld @nathansobo
Label: bug

Title: switch to disregard hidden folders (on Windows)
Body:
In using the project folder view, and search over files in a project, it's inconvenient that folders marked as hidden get shown and traversed as well. In some projects that use transpilers and intermediate files, some folders for these files are hidden so editors can skip them or hide them from view.

(I know in the Unix world there is the convention to start names with dot "." to mark them hidden, but in Windows there's a specific file metadata flag 'hidden' for this)
Label: enhancement

Title: Let's choose a view framework for docs, generated packages, etc.
Body:
(This is an attempt to restate #3752, explain the current position and present options)
## A blessed view system for Atom

We're in an interesting place with respect to generating views in packages and core. We wrote [space-pen](https://github.com/atom/space-pen) and used it heavily, but ultimately decided to discontinue using it for new views ([though some base views still use space-pen](https://github.com/atom/atom-space-pen-views) we are no longer recommending it). So now we find ourselves in an unfortunate position of using the DOM APIs directly, and suggesting package authors do the same, choose a framework themselves, or ╮(. ? ᴗ ?.)╭ - Not a great place to be, and makes it hard to write docs with nice examples.

We used React in the editor component for six months or so, and it was a good experience, but it has a bit of a learning curve.

We experimented with a few things inspired by React and Polymer, and have done some research on 3rd-party view frameworks, but haven't come to a decision. As we work on better docs for the run up to 1.0, we have to start taking this seriously.
## Requirements
- Embrace modern browser features (custom elements, `Object.observe`, etc) as much as possible
- It absolutely does not pollute the global namespace
- Data-binding preferred to imperative updates if templates are used
- View model / MVVM-style separation of rendering and logic
- No dependencies on jQuery-like helper libs
- Small learning curve
  - somewhat self-explanatory when used in docs examples
  - in other words, most web developers will be able to recognize the concepts that are applied without reading a book on it
## Contenders / experiments
- [React](http://facebook.github.io/react/)
- [Etch](https://github.com/nathansobo/etch) - a library for writing HTML-based view components that provides the convenience of a virtual DOM while at the same time striving to be minimal, interoperable, and explicit - written by @nathansobo and @maxbrunsfeld 
- [rivets](http://rivetsjs.com/) for templating+data binding plus some basic JS object glue for Atom
- [television](https://github.com/atom/television) - "Television aims to cleanly integrate the virtual DOM approach of React.js into HTML 5 custom elements." - an experiment from @nathansobo
- [virtual-dom](https://github.com/Matt-Esch/virtual-dom) this library is used by `television`, but could be a component in a similar solution that accomplishes the above goals.
- [elmer](https://github.com/atom/elmer) - An experiment from @benogle based on Polymer's template binding
- [vue.js](http://vuejs.org/) - simple, component-based, simple & small
- Something custom, delightful & new from your friends the Atom team (but we don't reallllly want to maintain another view frameowrk)
## Want to help?

One way to help speed this along is to do some experimentation with using your favorite framework in a package. See https://github.com/benogle/template-explore as an example package using https://github.com/atom/elmer.

A couple questions I would try to answer with the package:
- How does it handle model/DOM updates? Data-binding? Imperative + virtual-dom like react?
- How does it handle events? i.e. How do I bind a click handler to an element?
- Can it work with `Object.observe` and not it's own model system?
- Does it inject _any_ globals?
- How does it interact with web components, both in terms of creating new ones and using existing components written using different frameworks?
## Discuss

We're interested in hearing the pros and cons of the various ways we can satisfy the items listed under requirements, recommendations for solutions we don't have listed, and questions about the reqs and how and why we arrived at them.

Also, I encourage @atom/core and maintainers to edit the Contenders section in the issue body as more come in, and let me know if I missed / misstated anything in Requirements
Label: enhancement

Title: Quick file/folder add disappears when Atom loses focus
Body:
**Version**: 1.184.0
**OS**: OSX
**Problem Description**: I am using the quick file/folder add feature when I use the file explorer right-click functionality to add a new file. When the dialog appears, if, for any reason, I move away from the app, it disappears. On OSX, this can be if I switch applications, three-finger swipe away, etc. Minor, but annoying from a UX perspective.
**Expected**: With most other dialogs, the dialog stays around despite loss of focus of the application.

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Right click on a folder that is showing in the file navigator.
2. Chose _New File_
3. Swipe away/switch away from the app.
4. Dialog is gone.
Label: bug

Title: Failed to activate package - can we improve user notification ?
Body:
I am the developer of a package https://atom.io/packages/supercollider

Recently the package stopped working due to 6to5 raising an issue with unsafe use of eval in a dependency of a dependency of a dependency of atom-supercollider. Its functionality that is not even being used in atom-supercollider
1. The user isn't informed that the package failed to activate, has to look in console 
2. There is no report in the Packages pane for atom-supercollider
3. Developer (moi) who uses apm link does not experience this particular issue

For 1 I think that the nice red pop up panel should have been activated and allow the user to report the issue.

For 2 I suggest marking the package as "failed to activate" in some way. But maybe handling 1 is enough.

For 3: As a developer I was unaware that this was happening. I'm using the package with apm link so it doesn't get processed in the same way.  I had to unlink and then install it to see the error.

I can separate these issues if you want.

Error posted below. 

Its depd (which ironically is a package for reporting deprecations) which is in express which is used by supercollider.js (my npm module). Express isn't used by my atom package, so I can factor that functionality into a separate npm module.

```
 Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script in the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'self'".
```

Body:
Taken from https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/5567#issuecomment-75758499.

When I click on the line's number in the gutter, I expected to see the whole logical line to be selected (that's the behavior in Sublime, for example). Instead, only the physical line is selected (kind of, it strange):
