Title: alt-f and alt-h default keybindings
Body:
By default, alt-f is bound to `editor:move-to-end-of-word` and alt-h to `editor:delete-to-beginning-of-word`. These conflict with activating `File` and `Help` menus in Windows. 

Suggestions:
- Reserve alt-f and alt-h for menu bar access and change editor shortcuts.
- Focus and activate menu bar via a single alt press so user can navigate through the menus using arrow keys (customary behavior in Windows).
Label: enhancement

Title: Most pane text is not selectable.
Body: I have noticed in a number of packages with dialogs that the text can't be selected and copied.  This is true with my packages also.  I admit I haven't tried to fix it but even if there is a simple fix I'm curious why this is a default that every package has to fix?
Label: enhancement

Title: Has branch, getShortHead returns null on fresh repository
Body: Hi, If I have fresh repository with no commits functions like hasBranch('master') or getShortHead() returns null which seems like mistake. When I looked at the code atom seems to be checking refs/heads folder inside of .git which is empty if there are not commits.

Title: How to truly disable "auto indent on paste"?
Body:
It will still indent even when "auto indent on paste" is off. Here's how to reproduce:

CoffeeScript:

``` coffeescript
a = ->
    3
```

Copy the above lines, insert an empty line and a tab, and then paste. It will be:

``` coffeescript
    a = ->
        3
```

But I think it should be:

``` coffeescript
    a = ->
    3
```

Title: Pane split also splits file
Body:
When splitting a pane you end up with the same file open in two panes. While splitting a file is a useful feature it should be separate from splitting panes. It is frustrating having to close the extra file view every time I split a pane.

I should be able to split panes without ending up with duplicate views of the same file, but I should also be able to split a file into multiple views if I want.

Title: How to build without downloading modules?
Body:
I'm trying to package Atom for a distribution I use called [Exherbo Linux](http://exherbo.org/), which is a source-based distribution akin to Gentoo, and it's package manager uses a sandbox when building packages so that they do not mess with the system outside when not expected. This includes sandboxing the network, so that it can not contact the outside world and is only allowed to use any whitelisted IP addresses, or instead has to fetch dependencies outside of the compilation process.

Atom presents a problem here, because it's build script fetches dependencies while installing, which is not allowed in the sandbox.

To get the point, my question is: is there a supported way to fetch dependencies of the build script, disable any network related operations during compilation, and then build as normal?
Label: enhancement

Title: Issue with String.localeCompare in Atom Helper
Body:
I am writing a plugin that uses `vinyl-fs`, one of it's node modules uses `String.localeCompare`.  In the new version of atom I am having an issues with this function that does not exist in my local version of node 0.11.14

``` bash
~/g/atom-typescript-tools: /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom\ Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Helper
> process.version
'v0.11.14'
> 'asdf'.localeCompare('sd')
fish: Job 1, '/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom\ Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom\ Helper' terminated by signal SIGSEGV (Address boundary error)
drwxr-xr-x jonathanpark:staff typescript-1.4-update ✗
~/g/atom-typescript-tools: node
> process.version
'v0.11.14'
> 'asdf'.localeCompare('sd')
-18
```

As you can see if I open Atom Helper as a node process, run the localeCompare test and it throws a segmentation fault.  In my local node 0.11.14 install it works fine.   I suspect that there is an issue where the localeCompare code utilizes some system library that isn't compiled correctly for my os version.  I am running OSX 10.10 and have not updated to 10.10.1 and the new command line tools yet.
Label: bug

Title: Auto-indent misbehaving inside a script handlebar template tag
Body:
**Issue:**
When writing HTML inside an Handlebar template tag, the auto-indent doesn't work

**To reproduce:**
- Write the `script` tag and open a `div` tag

``` html
<script type="text/x-handlebars-template">
  <div>
</script>
```
- Insert a new line

Expected result:

``` html
<script type="text/x-handlebars-template">
  <div>
    The line is indented here
</script>
```

**Actual** result:

``` html
<script type="text/x-handlebars-template">
  <div>
  The line is indented here
</script>
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Renderer process hogs CPU after opening and closing settings tab
Body:
1. Open a new instance of Atom.
2. Check the CPU usage of all Atom processes. They should be close to 0%, with occasional spikes.
3. Open the settings tab (Ctrl+,), then immediately close it. Repeat this step 20 times.
4. Check the CPU usage of all Atom processes. The renderer process (`atom.exe --type=renderer ...`) will now be constantly consuming CPU time (~12% on my quad-core PC).

If you repeat step 3 enough times, eventually the renderer process will consume 100% CPU time on a single core, and Atom becomes very unresponsive.

This is on Windows 7 after a fresh install of Atom. The only settings I have changed are to set the theme to Atom Light/Base16 Tomorrow Dark.

I took some profile measurements using the Developer Tools. After performing the above steps, Atom is spending 86× more CPU time in `React.createClass.toggleCursorBlink` and 61× more CPU time in `React.createClass.pollDOM`. I guess that Atom is failing to clean up some `setInterval`s, or similar.

I wanted to attach profile measurements, but the ‘save’ button in the profiler just saves an empty file.
Label: bug

Title: Add Downloading Update progress
Body: Basicly what the title says, I don't know how much it downloaded now because it has no progress indicator but I've had atom open for over 30minutes now and the update has not finished downloading. That seems wrong.
Label: enhancement

Title: Option for "Open with Atom"
Body: Is there an option to disable the "Open with Atom" shell entry? I can't find one, if there isn't, see this as a feature request :)
Label: enhancement

Title: SCSS :nth-child marked as syntax error
Body:
In an SCSS file when you use the psuedo-selector `:nth-child` after the `&` selector atom sometimes marks the syntax as incorrect.

Examples:

1.
`&:nth-child(4n-1)`
`n-` is highlighted as a syntax error.

2.

Title: Atom doesn't respect/update OSX's find pasteboard / clipboard
Body:
In OS X there's a separate pasteboard, NSFindPboard, used to keep search fields in sync.  The pasteboard gets updated when a search field changes or the user hits ⌘-E with text selected.  It can be pretty handy when you're searching through code for the same keyword, and most apps seem to generally respect it (Safari/XCode/Chrome/etc).  In general it seems like apps check it when they become active and update their search fields.

Chromium definitely supports NSFindPboard ([with some of the impl here](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/git-svn/ui/base/cocoa/find_pasteboard.mm)), but I'm not sure that stuff is accessible at all from the Javascript layer.  

One option is just to shell out to pbpaste/pbcopy to get/update the pboard's contents, as in:

```
 pbpaste -pboard find
```

will dump the contents of NSFindPboard to stdout.

You could also technically get at it with NodeObjC, but that seems like overkill.
Label: enhancement

Body:
Hi,

It seems that the clipboard support in linux is broken
For example, I can not paste after deleting a character or to be more precise the deleted caracter is pasted.
It seems that internaly Atom uses a selection to select the character to delete and this updates the clipboard

Steps to reproduce:
1) type foo on a new editor window
2) select the text using the mouse or keybord
3) press ctrl + c
4) go to the end of line
5) hit backspace 1 time to delete the last O
6) press ctrl + v

I should get fofoo instead I get foo

I'm using fedora 20 and atom 0.157.0

Title: Incorrect git status on OS X when accented characters are used in file names
Body:
When an accented character (e.g. åäö, but probably other unicode characters as well) is used in a file name the git implementation in Atom on OS X thinks that the file is new, even though it exists on github. You can test with this repo (small, markdown files only):

`git clone https://github.com/morberg/recept.git`

Open root folder in atom and look at the incorrect status in the left tree navigation.

Problem is seen with Atom 0.158.0 on OS X 10.10.1:
![screen shot 2014-12-16 at 09 03 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/956034/5450195/84f191da-8502-11e4-9f01-685719d6dc47.png)

Problem is _not_ seen with Atom 0.158.0 on Windows 7 SP 1.
![screen shot 2014-12-16 at 09 04 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/956034/5450203/a25e5c1c-8502-11e4-977f-3f64a6bbb69a.png)
Label: bug

```
C:\> apm list --installed --bare
go-plus@2.1.1
gocode@0.2.1
```

Now when I run the same command the program simply returns with no output. Running just `apm list` will display "Built-in Atom packages (79)" (`--bare` also works).

Here is the version information for APM

```
PS C:\> apm --version
apm  0.114.0
npm  1.4.4
node 0.10.33
python
git
visual studio
```
Label: bug

Title: Hide system window title bar
Body:
Hi! Could it be possible to implement system window title bar/borders hiding like Chromium/Chrome has?

If you have used Chromium/Chrome you can notice it lacks the "system window title bar" by default (ie, the bar that says the name of the window and has the minimize, maximize and close buttons), while at the same time providing its own tiny minimize, maximize and close buttons in the top, rightmost part of the window.

Some window managers for Linux let you hide the window title bar, but since Atom lacks its own minimize/maximize/close buttons, it becomes inconvenient. Besides, it would be something nice to have in Windows/OSX too.

IMHO, this feature manages to save (precious!) vertical space, and looks much more pleasant.

EDIT: Made a discussion thread about this https://discuss.atom.io/t/hide-system-window-title-bar/14578
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom crashing reproducibly immediately after update
Body:
This morning, I clicked the blue squirrel in the corner, opted to update and restart via the button at the bottom of the release notes, and now whenever I launch atom I see an empty window, and a disembodied alert pane telling me I should report the issue. Screenshot:

![2014-12-12 at 12 12 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/296432/5411452/80be8422-81f8-11e4-8b1b-4da8e2b294e0.png)

Notes:
- I can’t get to a usable atom editor by clicking any of the three buttons in the alert pane.
  - clicking "reload" just makes the alert pane show up again (this time connected to the atom window).
  - clicking "keep it open" just dismisses the alert pane, leaving me with an empty atom window.
  - clicking "close window" hangs for approx ~1s and then closes the window, leaving atom running, but with no open windows.
- The behaviour is the same whether I start atom from the terminal, or via Finder.
- `atom --safe` and `atom --dev` both produces the same behaviour.
- `atom --version` shows `0.157.0`.
Label: bug

Title: UTF-8 problems: characters mysteriously incorrectly encoded
Body:
Atom 0.155 / Mac OS X 10.10.1

I’ve encountered a problem that I am reasonably certain was caused by Atom, but which I cannot reproduce (and therefore I have no test case to submit). I know how unuseful such a bug report is, but thought you should be aware of the issue.

99% of the time I am programming, and so am pretty much just using ASCII. However, everything is saved in UTF-8, as is usual nowadays and is Atom’s default. During the last couple of days I needed to update a bunch of strings/locales files (de, es, fr, it, ja, pt-BR, zh-Hans, and zh-Hant) and now see several garbled characters have been introduced into lines which previously were good and which I had not edited. (I can tell this from the SVN history, for example in a de file I edited, I can see the line I changed, but also in a line I did not edit I see a ö converted to �.) (The files in question had only been edited by me, only using Atom.)

If I do a Find in Project for � (not scientific, I’m sure, but I’m not sure what else I can do) and restrict it just to the locales directory, I see a lot of results from files that previously were good. I can’t find any way to copy-and-paste from the Find in Project results pane, so here is a screenshot:

![screen shot 2014-12-10 at 17 05 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7255543/5393735/1d7b4a94-8135-11e4-8576-5c4b5502326f.png)

Confusingly, some of those files are in fact fine. If I open them by clicking on the line in the Find in Project results pane I do not see the garbled character and the result then disappears from the results pane.

This only happens with seemingly random characters, not all. For example in one pt-BR file a ç became garbled but other instances of the same character did not. Similarly in a de file one ö became garbled but others did not.

Please let me know if there is anything I can do to help pinpoint the issue. Unfortunately I can’t attach the actual locale files as they are private.
Label: bug

Title: getting red notifications when saving keymap.cson with parse error
Body:
Yet another notification annoyance.

I save all the time with errors.  If I am in the middle of edits and I need to do something else I automatically save.  Now I'm getting red notifications when saving keymap.cson with parse error.  This is very annoying.

There has to be some way to control the notifications better.  At least let them be turned off.
Label: enhancement

Title: Update Chocolatey package to call the new Squirrel based installer
Body:
I understand that Chocolatey is no longer required due to the new Squirrel installer for Windows, but many Chocolatey users prefer to manage their installs using Chocolatey to allow scripted box builds.

I don't see a repo for the Atom Chocolatey package, but I'd just change the Install.ps1 to this:

```
$packageName = 'Atom'
$url = 'https://atom.io/download/windows'
$installerType = 'exe'
$installArgs = '/quiet'
Install-ChocolateyPackage $packageName $installerType $installArgs $url
```

Note that this calls the [/quiet install arg](https://github.com/Squirrel/Squirrel.Windows/blob/master/src/Setup/winmain.cpp) on Squirrel's Setup.exe.
Label: enhancement

Title: "Reveal in Tree View" does not work when there is no folder selected.
Body: Wouldn't it be nice to have this open the tree view in directory the file is located in?
Label: enhancement

-->  |
-->  |
-->  |
```

Title: Reloading styles in shadow DOM on focused editor causes craziness
Body:
1. Turn shadow DOM on
2. link a syntax theme, and make sure you're using that theme
3. `atom -d` in the syntax theme dir
4. Edit a stylesheet 
5. save
6. The editor goes gray and is unusable

It looks like the height is infinitely growing:

![crazy-height](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/5365038/690f5b06-7f9d-11e4-818d-a69c9f659c09.gif)
### Notes
- You can close that editor and everything is fine
- It only happens on the active editor when the window has focus. Change the file out side of atom with atom _not_ focused, and it's fine.
Label: bug

Title: Search box shoud have focus on directory search and not create a new file dialog
Body: When one right clicks on a folder and select search directory the keyboard focus should be in the search box. It used to be so a few versions ago but stopped a few months ago for unknown reasons. It makes it a bit of a pain as the tendency is to type right after selecting search but this now causes a new file  dialog to open instead. Current version is 0.153
Label: bug

Title: Interacton of marker overlays
Body:
Marker overlays are a great new addition to atom.  I have a few cases I would like to see handled in the future. 
- when I have multiple overlays on screen, some options for how you would like the overlays to interact
  - attempted to layout such that they don't overlay each other
  - when they are attached to the same marker attempt to dock overlays together such that they appear in concert
- when a cursor or other editor driven marker would be obscured by an overlay we could push it in a different direction.
- when a mouse intersects an overlay it would be nice to have some standard interaction options.  
  -  hide on mouse intersects
  -  fade out on mouse intersects,  ideally this level would allow you to place a cursor behind it and highlight text ranges.
  -  fully interactable with mouse
- in order to better prioritize multiple overlays for positioning and or removal there should probably be a priority setting
  - low: used for informational overlays that can be obscured or removed by higher priority items
  - medium: used for errors and warning overlays that should be prioritized over other informational overlays
  - high: used for interactive popups that can have mouse, and keyboard interactions associated with them, these are positioned very aggressively removing any informational popups if they don't fit in.

Ideally we would have some patterns to follow regarding how to create overlays.
Label: enhancement

Title: Undo grouping is too eager
Body:
Undo grouping seems to group any editor changes no matter what kind of change it was, which results in confusing/unexpected behaviour.
1. Create a new file
2. Paste some text into it
3. Immediately begin typing
4. Undo

Atom will group both the pasting and the typing, so the undo removes everything. Ideally it should only remove the typing, with the paste being a separate undo. ST2 has this behaviour and its much nicer. I'll often start typing after pasting some code, and want to undo something I just typed. It's infuriating when the whole lot disappears!

The same problem happens for many editor commands such as `editor:auto-indent`. Perform an auto indent, then begin typing (or run another command). Undo will revert both.

My suggestion is that Atom should only group sequences of identical commands. Disparate commands should never be grouped.

Are there cases where grouping disparate commands makes more sense than keeping them separate?
Label: enhancement

Title: Menu reads "Downloading update ..." even when it is only checking for an update
Body:

Perhaps it should read "Checking for updates ..." and only change to "Downloading update ..." if an update is available.
Label: bug

Title: Autocomplete Next
Body:
We're not quite ready to tackle a new autocomplete yet, but I wanted to start the conversation as there are several folks interested in working on autocomplete: @mark-hahn, @lee-dohm, @joefitzgerald, @abe33.

Once we finish with API related things, I was planning on:
- Looking at `autocomplete-plus` code
- Checking out all of the existing providers out there.
  - How many are out there? What are the popular ones?
- Looking at code @mark-hahn and @lee-dohm produced recently
- Looking at other editors. How do they do it? Do they have APIs?
- Are there autocomplete daemons out there we can use (e.g. https://github.com/nsf/gocode for Go)

Then I would come up with a plan of attack for the new version. In my mind, we have a couple options:
- Extend `autocomplete` with an API
- Take over `autocomplete-plus` with some modifications and API changes
- Write something completely new

I am not sure what the best way forward is right now. I do feel, though, that the hard part is not the UI that pops up the completion box, it's having great language support, and a nice API for adding completions.

It would be great if you guys could help me / us work through the research phase. Off the top of my head, I'm thinking these would be a big help:
- Your opinions and suggestions for the provider API.
- Your architectural suggestions (I know @mark-hahn wrote one recently)
- Comments explaining the pitfalls and your frustrations of the current `autocomplete-plus` API. Maybe suggestions on improvements.
- Links to autocomplete providers for languages (either generic providers or for other editors)
- Explanations / links to APIs in other editors
- General autocomplete API related frustrations and desires
## Resources
- Discuss thread: https://discuss.atom.io/t/what-can-we-do-to-improve-autocomplete/13001
- @mark-hahn + @lee-dohm's autocomplete: https://github.com/mark-hahn/autocomplete-generic
- https://github.com/atom-community/autocomplete-plus
- https://github.com/HaxeIDE/atom-autocomplete-plus-async
### Providers
- Ruby provider: https://atom.io/packages/rsense
- Rust provider: https://atom.io/packages/racer
- Go generic provider: https://github.com/nsf/gocode
- Python generic provider: https://github.com/davidhalter/jedi
- JS: https://github.com/marijnh/tern ; https://github.com/majutsushi/tagbar/wiki#javascript
- Coffee: https://github.com/lukaszkorecki/CoffeeTags ; https://github.com/mntmn/tern-coffeescript
### Autocomplete+ providers

https://github.com/atom-community/autocomplete-plus/wiki/Autocomplete-Providers
Label: enhancement

Title: Soft tabs setting is not syntax-scoped
Body:
This may be causing confusion with folks that use hard tabs much of the time.
## Repro Steps
1. Start Atom
2. Set `editor.softTabs` to `false`
3. Set `.source.gfm` `editor.softTabs` to `true` (Must be done in the `config.cson` because the UI doesn't offer this setting)
4. Set `.source.gfm` `editor.tabLength` to `4`
5. Open a new file
6. Open Developer Tools
7. Execute:
   
   ``` javascript
   editor = atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()
   editor.getSoftTabs()                       # => false
   editor.getTabLength()                      # => 2
   ```
8. Execute:
   
   ``` javascript
   grammar = atom.grammars.grammarForScopeName('source.gfm')
   editor.setGrammar(grammar)
   editor.getSoftTabs()                       # => false
   editor.getTabLength()                      # => 4
   ```

**Expected:** Editor's soft tabs setting should update when tab length does
**Actual:** Editor's soft tabs setting only changes when `TextEditor::setSoftTabs` or `TextEditor::toggleSoftTabs` is called
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.153.0-71228a5
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.4
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.10.1
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.111.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.6
  - git 1.9.3

Title: Font size too small in the settings GUI.
Body:
As other people have reported, Atom comes with a small font size can only be fixed by editing config files (see #3792). I had the same problem with the Settings GUI. Unfortunately, this is very difficult to fix by editing `styles.less`. In particular, you cannot simply change `@font-size` in your local `styles.less` file. To make Atom usable for me, I had to locate my Atom installation, locate my theme, locate `ui-variables.less` and edit `@font-size` there directly. I still have not managed to get the check buttons to have a reasonable font size.

Clearly, fixing the font size is far more difficult than it should be. I ask that you add the UI font size and font family to the settings menu so that people can change them easily.
Label: enhancement

Title: atom command line tool doesn't work when Atom.App is installed into a directory with a space in the name

The title pretty much summarises the issue.

I have resolved this by replacing the line that searches for atom.App with the following:

ATOM_PATH="$(mdfind "kMDItemCFBundleIdentifier == 'com.github.atom'" | grep -v ShipIt | sed '{s#/[^/]*$##; q; }')"

Title: Improved "Show Invisibles"
Body:
I'm not a big fan of eclipse, but regarding the "show invisibles" feature, it provides some realy nice configuration:
- changing the opacity of the invisible chars
- specify which type of chars to display (tabs, spaces, line endings etc)
- specify which type chars to display depending on their position (leading, enclosed, trailing)

That's awesome, since I like to reduce the opacity and hide the line endings, enclosed whitespace and stuff (I just want to see the the leading whitespace type with a low opacity).

It would be awesome to have similar options in atom.

![invisibles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/107634/5183318/0e366e44-74ae-11e4-8f6c-1d2274129f8d.png)

Title: Make programmatic scrolling more transitional and less jumpy
Body: The autoscroll option for many programmatic methods right now is way too jumpy and really negatively impacts UX. It would be nice to be able to say `.setBufferPosition(position, { autoscroll: true, transitionDuration: '0.5s', transitionTiming: 'ease' })` or something similar that will provide developers a way to transition the editor how they see fit. If the transition duration and timing aren't provided, then fall back to a nice `'0.3s'` and `'ease'` or something like that.

Title: Single file handling still unfriendly
Body:
While #3355 was a significant improvement in editing individual files without opening the entire containing directory, this is only true when a project directory is already open.

On the other hand, I often create short, temporary bash scripts or quick Haskell experiments in small files in $HOME.  If I try to use Atom to edit these, then inevitably it slows to a crawl trying to deal with the many thousands of files in that directory.  If I accidentally try to pull up project symbols, or similar it will hang long enough to justify killing manually.

It would be lovely if there were a way to differentiate between opening a directory/project and opening a file.  I realize that some people consider this a feature rather than an issue, or will tell me not to put such files in $HOME, but it would be unfortunate to exclude some use cases without reason to do so.
Label: enhancement

Title: Middle mouse paste needs an extra click
Body: The middle mouse paste that was discussed in #2244 and implemented in #4211 does not work when there is still a selection. When the cursor has been moved away from the selection pasting using the middle mouse button works. Since a middle mouse click does not set the cursor, the obvious workaround of clicking middle mouse twice on the desired location does not work.

Title: Open files from browser with atom://
Body:
It would be very useful if atom could open files from the browser like `atom://open?URL=/Users/me/myfile.txt.`, like sublime text's `subl://open`

This would be great for people writing/debugging web apps like me :)

Title: Doing a TextBuffer.scan with replace wipes out bookmarks?
Body:
cc @benogle since decorations are your thing ...

Someone reported an Issue on my [tabs-to-spaces package](https://atom.io/packages/tabs-to-spaces) at lee-dohm/tabs-to-spaces#13 that bookmarks were being wiped out on every save. I've cobbled together a relatively simple repro ...

![bookmarks](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/5153157/0a8d764e-71ce-11e4-8e67-a99c9e91efda.gif)
## Repro Steps
1. Open up a file
2. Add a bookmark somewhere in the text
3. Open up the JavaScript console
4. Execute: `editor = atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()`
5. Execute: `buffer = editor.getBuffer()`
6. Execute: `buffer.scan(/^ /g, function(obj) { obj.replace("\t") })`

**Expected:** The bookmark remains
**Actual:** The bookmark disappears
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.151.0-85fae83
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.2
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.10.1
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.111.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.6
  - git 1.9.3

---

Title: Cannot update or view packages in preferences window: tunneling socket errors
Body:
I'm running OS X Mavericks with Atom 0.150.0 behind a corporate firewall. My (anonymized) `.apmrc` is as follows:

```
https-proxy = https://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
http-proxy = http://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
proxy = http://[user]:[pw]@[host]:[port]
strict-ssl = false
```

Fetching outdated packages and themes fails with this error message:

```
Request for package information failed: tunneling socket could not be established, cause=140735230071568:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:795:
```

Fetching featured packages fails with this error message:

```
tunneling socket could not be established, cause=140735230071568:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:../deps/openssl/openssl/ssl/s23_clnt.c:795:
```

Googling and further searching doesn't seem to bring up anything immediately relevant and helpful. I'd really like to use Atom as my primary text editor, but I have no idea how to get past these issues. Thank you in advance for your time and help.
Label: bug

Title: Indentation wiped out on paste
Body:
Hi, I just checked out and built v0.150.0 and I'm seeing an issue where indentation is being broken on pasted lines regardless of the setting of Auto Indent,  Auto Indent On Paste, and Normalize Indent On Paste.  With all these settings off  it doesn't preserve the existing indentation of the copied rows, it strips all indentation from the first row then removes that same amount of whitespace from the indent on subsequent rows.

Additionally if I turn on Auto Indent On Paste it moves all rows in the pasted text to the same indent level, being that of the most indented line in the paste, instead of preserving the original heirarchy.

eg, when editing HAML:

```
|    %table
|      %tr
|        %td
|        %td
|  %table.reqs
```

if I copy and paste the tr and tds with all indent options off I get:

```
|    %table
|      %tr
|        %td
|        %td
|%tr
|  %td
|  %td
|  %table.reqs
```

And with auto indent on paste enabled I get:

```
|    %table
|      %tr
|        %td
|        %td
|        %tr
|        %td
|        %td
|        %table.reqs
```

Note that last line in the last example - that's actually pre-existing text after the paste that also gets pushed out to the new indent level :scream:
Label: bug

But it wasn't obvious how to get to this page - I had to click "See All" next to "Newest" on [this page](https://atom.io/packages), then change sort settings.

Maybe you could add a link like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/992008/5138648/d0f61070-7106-11e4-8680-5a4db0c4fb3d.png)
- This could link to "most downloaded" or "most starred," I don't really mind either way
- This could be added next to **Trending** section instead of **Featured** section, I don't mind either way

Title: `Shift` key breaks multikey bindings on Linux
Body:
If you press `<shift>` during a multikey binding, the keybinding is unable to resolve.  To demonstrate, here are the results in Atom 0.147.0 on Ubuntu Linux 14.04 x86-64.

In dev tools, do:

```
atom.keymaps.add("test", {"body": {"o P": "core:confirm" }})
```

Keybinding resolver output:

`o`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/333673/5119915/be6c93ca-703e-11e4-8f79-0e109e0c4dc8.png)

`o<shift-down>`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/333673/5119922/e4f022dc-703e-11e4-9d51-075f5dcf92c5.png)

`o<shift-down>p`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/333673/5119935/212d72d6-703f-11e4-940d-d5c7e3b07a37.png)

Also tried another keybinding `O P`:

This works. `<shift-down>op<shift-up>`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/333673/5119963/70ea2b3e-703f-11e4-816e-cf18259332fe.png)

However, if I released shift and pressed it again, then once again, the keybinding would fail to resolve. When I tested a third keybinding, `O p`, I found that it always succeeded, unless I pressed shift at some point before typing `p`.

This seems to indicate that the `<shift-down>` event is breaking multikey bindings.

See also atom/vim-mode#442
Label: bug

Title: Improve user messaging
Body:
Status: Implementation

The main goal here is to improve exception user experience (e.g. #3715). This can be extended to general user messaging. Say when the config file has an error, or info messages like when a theme has reloaded in dev-live-reload. 

In addition to showing the error message, the exception flow should either have
- A way to submit a bug report with the stack trace and related atom info
- A way to copy the entire stack trace
### Current state

A repo at https://github.com/atom/notifications results in growl-like messages:

![notifications](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/5152024/6e5ef102-719c-11e4-851a-f28a0be91d72.gif)

Title: Command editor:log-cursor-scope no longer cleanly logs the scopes
Body: In older versions of Atom (before the `ScopeDescriptor` change by @benogle), the `editor:log-cursor-scope` command, activated by <kbd>Cmd+Alt+P</kbd> on OS X, would log an array of simple strings to the debug console like `['foo', 'bar', 'baz']`. Now it logs a `ScopeDescriptor` object which, while it can still be opened up to get the same information as always, requires a few mouse clicks to do so. It would be better if the command logged the `ScopeDescriptor.scopes` value instead.

Title: Reload causes cursor/selection misalignment (for @font-face fonts)
Body:
Possibly related to #3201, if you have fonts loaded through `@font-face` (e.g. using my fonts package), a reload causes the cursor/selection alignment to misbehave. Switching to the default font (i.e. empty the font family box in settings) restores it. You can then switch back to an `@font-face` font and it will work properly again.

Steps to reproduce:
- Use an `@font-face` font as outlined here: https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-do-i-load-google-fonts-into-my-editors-styles/8321/7 (or by using http://atom.io/packages/fonts).
- Put the name of the font in settings (e.g. 'aka-coder').
- Open a file in Atom: all should look well in the new font.
- Choose View > Reload.
- Cursor and selection should now misalign. You can check this by double-click-selecting a word or by typing a row of characters.
- Switch to settings.
- Empty the font-family setting.
- Switch to the file and all should look well again in the default font.
- Switch to settings. 
- Put the name of the font in settings (e.g. 'aka-coder').
- Switch to the file and all should look well again in aka-coder.
Label: enhancement

Title: Bug when starting editor under certain conditions
Body:

Later in the day I tried to start up Atom again, it failed to the debug screen. It was throwing an error saying that this file was now a directory. I ended up having to rename the directory temporarily to be able to open the editor, then close the tab in the editor, rename the directory again to it's original name and all was well.
Suggestion: the editor should fail more gracefully in this circumstance. When a directory replaces a file of the same name, the editor should just close the tab or gray it out with an explanation or alert.

Title: documentation improvement suggestion - how to see your changes to the source code without building
Body:
I'm the one who asked a question in this link: https://discuss.atom.io/t/do-you-use-atom-while-hacking-on-the-core-editor/13207

All the answers were very valuable, but I think @postcasio's answer would be especially very helpful for newbies like me who just started contributing to Atom. I copied the answer to here for your convenience:

"-r sets the resources path, which is normally Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app. Your working copy is your local copy of the atom repository. So if you cloned to /Users/yjw9012/github/atom you would run:
atom -r /Users/yjw9012/github/atom
Then instead of loading the code bundled in Atom.app, it will load the code you're working on.
Also, looking at the source, dev mode will load from ~/github/atom it exists. So if you have your copy stored there, you can just run atom -d."

I was curious if there was a much faster way to see your code changes to the source code than rebuilding it by executing 'script/build'. It's true that building Atom takes a very few minutes (probably, less than 2 minutes), but I believe that some people might consider it's even too long.

My suggestion would be that we need to modify the answer above a little bit and put that in the build instruction for OS X(https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/os-x.md) or other contribution guide pages at least.
Label: enhancement

Title: Implement Chromium task manager
Body:
Users frequently report issues with high CPU or memory usage, and the typical response is that it must be a package that is the root cause, not Atom itself. Presently, the operating system task managers just show a bunch of Atom Helper processes, so it is impossible to determine which package is associated with the offending process.

Since Atom is based on Chromium, it would be beneficial to implement the Chromium task manager so that a user can see resource usage by package. Here is what Chromium's task manager looks like:

![screen shot 2014-10-25 at 8 46 34 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/157270/5021790/eb491578-6a97-11e4-81b5-feb2330f2360.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Allow canceling update download
Body: Sometimes it is not preferable to download the update, such as when using cellular tethering or airplane wifi where bandwidth is constrained. It would be nice to be able to click on "Downloading Update" in the Atom menu and be shown a dialog that would ask if you want to cancel the update. I don't know how often update checking occurs, but in my mind, it should be canceled until the next time Atom is started.
Label: enhancement

Title: Renaming a File
Body: When trying to rename a file from tree view (right click > rename), the app crashes each time.
Label: bug

Title: Feature Request: add crash restore
Body:
Today my Atom crashed and I realized that there is no such thing as restore your unsaved work.
Since this is more than standard nowadays - please add this!
Label: enhancement

Title: Correctly detect the encoding
Body:
Atom should try to guess the encoding when opening a file as best as it can and only if it fails, fallback to the default encoding option (which was implemented a few days ago).

Missing libraries (that would presumably help with this issue) shouldn't be a factor here. If there isn't any library that could be used, one should be created from 0 or maybe patch the one that could get the job done with as little amount of work as possible.

The main issue here is that Atom will try to open files in UTF8 (or the default encoding, if set), which will potentially break any non-UTF8 files. And that, imho, is not an acceptable/valid behavior for any editor.

This should be tagged as 1.0 blocker.

Also, maybe this could help:
- https://github.com/mooz/node-icu-charset-detector
- https://www.npmjs.org/package/detect-encoding
Label: enhancement

Title: Project-wide find and replace with regex does not replace
Body:
The find and replace with the project-wide tool (Cmd-Shift-F) is refusing to make replacements. I can replace with a standard find and replace, but not with the regex option enabled.

Atom 0.145.0, OS X 10.10
No errors were logged in the Atom console, or in Console.app.

![atom_find_and_replace_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1648967/5002757/5f8ba2fa-69b9-11e4-88cf-17219802da41.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Unsaved pane's content dissapears after moving in split mode
Body:
The content of a pane/buffer that hasn't been saved to a file will dissapear after moving the pane to another place (in split-mode).

Video: http://youtu.be/Mp2R8vqFUdY
Label: bug

Title: Tab characters slightly larger than they should be with invisible character
Body:
Using Consolas, size 16, tabs appear to be a pixel or two wider than they should be.

![screen shot 2014-11-11 at 09 58 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/4991295/a15a42ac-6989-11e4-9251-4e7ecc8eccf8.png)

The vertical bars should all line up, but the more tab characters on the line the further away the vertical bar is from its correct position. Changing the font to Menlo works fine:

![screen shot 2014-11-11 at 10 02 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/4991317/efcea0a4-6989-11e4-8dcc-d02388d80308.png)

Here's the content of this file, tab width is 2: https://gist.github.com/postcasio/74ba42babd8995e87ec0

All in safe mode, 0.144.0
Label: enhancement

Title: Collapsing Multi-line comments does not work at all
Body:
If I write comments without a empty new line, it works. But if I don't do that, Atom only collapses the part before the new line (instead of the whole comment), like if they were single-line comments (I have to click the two arrows of the multi-line comment to semi-collapse it):

(I' using Atom 144 and my OS is Linux Mint 17)

Before collapsing them - After Collapsing
![before collapsing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6506988/4986198/11e0a0dc-6937-11e4-9291-b35dda49d859.png) ![after collapsing2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6506988/4986199/11e7829e-6937-11e4-8d8e-cfb3e54b04c9.png)
Label: bug

Title: Report more information about task processes on the process line
Body: We see a task running but we're not sure where it came from. Is it in a valid state?
Label: enhancement

Title: Make project.getRepositories pluggable to support VCS other than Git
Body:
Right now, Project populates "@repo" only with the result GitRepository.open. There is no way to make Atom support other VCS like Subversion or Mercurial from a plugin because of that. Also, subclassing GitRepository is difficult because it does far more than simply forwarding Git status information, for example subscribing to window focus changes in the constructor.

There should be a simple, generic base class for VCS support, with a mean for Project to ask each VCS module if the current project has any repository for its directory, and a clean API to refresh any item status.
Label: enhancement

Label: bug

Title: Selection artifact
Body:
Using atom dark ui/syntax themes I'm seeing a small 1-2px bar at the top of the editor when there is a selection.

It extends the width of the editor.

![selection-artifact](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/4984296/714ae20e-6922-11e4-8f6f-6f6a60519a57.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Dead keys and diacritics are not working
Body:
Hi,

I've been using atom in Ubuntu 14.04 for a while and I've never been able to make my diacritics and dead keys work. I'm using a Spanish keyboard (es_ES) and the diacritics which are entered by pressing a dead key + a vowel (áéíóúü ?É?ÓÚÜ) don't work. There's no problem with other Spain's symbols (ñ Ñ € ¿ ? ¡ !) so I guess this issue is related to dead keys.

I just built atom 0.145.0-3462d99, but as I said I've had this problem for a couple of months.
Label: bug

Title: File readable in atom is unreadable in vim and gedit
Body:
In Atom 0.145 I had some problems with the file encodings. A file with special characters (umlauts -> ü,ä,ö) was readable in atom after saving and trying different encodings. But in vim and gedit, it looks like 
`@d^@t^@ ^@a^@n^@d^@ ^@t^@h^@e^@ ^@e^@p^@i^@p^@h^@a^@n^@y^@ ^@o^@f^@ ^@t^@h^@e^@ ^@f^@a^@c^@e^@ ^@(^@K^@o^@e^@r^@n^@e^@r^@)^@
^@K^@o^@e^@r^@n^@e^@r^@ ^@a^@n^@a^@l^@y^@s^@i^@e^@r^@t^@ ^@d^@i^@e^@ ^@I^@n^@t^@e^@r^@p^@r^@e^@t^@a^@t^@i^@o^@n^@m^@ö^@g^@l^@i^@c^@h^@k^@e^@i^@t^@e^@n^@ ^@d^@e^@s^@ ^@G^@e^@s^@i^@c^@h^@t^@s^@ ^@i^@n^@ ^@d^@e^@r^@ ^@K^@u^@n^@s^@t^@,^@ ^@i^@n^@s^@b^@e^@s^@o^@n` etc.
Label: bug

Title: Copy (ctrl+c) copies only the first character of selection
Body: In 0.145 on linux, after some encoding trouble, I also noticed the problem that i can't copy selected text anymore. Also the file saved as UTF8 is unreadable in eg. gedit or vim (might be an additional issue)
Label: bug

Title: Inconsistent environment and behaviour
Body:
# Problem

Various tools don't operate correctly depending on the order and the manner with which Atom is started.

Also, persisted state is not restored consistently.
# Cause

Depending the manner in which Atom is started, a different environment is inherited.
- **launchd event**: inherits launchd mostly blank env, which means no shell env vars
- **`atom` in the terminal**: inherits currently set vars

This applied to when the app is _started_, not when a new window is opened, in which case that window will inherit the current process env (which is normal OS X behaviour)

I venture the creation of the `atom` command this way is on purpose to work around the lack of env when run from launchd. But please, dear reader, continue on to the next step.
# Current workaround / Anti-feature

Manually control Atom startup each time you want to use it in a specific environment.

Why is it an anti feature? If you want two projects open at the same time but with different environments, you're busted.

Also, long running sessions and _"wait what env was that started with already?"_ (session can also mean the idiomatic "document != app" OS X way: "Atom.app is started but no windows are opened") .

Also also, frustration quickly sets in when you start it up the wrong way and have to quit and restart halfway through your work and notice your linter does not actually run (manual config does not cut it because 1. it's manual and 2. constantly changing versions means constantly changing path).
# Possible solution
1. wrap Atom.app startup in a login shell (i.e make `Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom` a script that calls whatever the user shell is† as a login, non-interactive one before calling the real `Atom` binary), to inherit global env, so that chruby/rbenv/GOPATH/whatever works.
2. make `atom` command send a signal to `Atom.app` instead of starting atom itself via `Contents/MacOS/Atom`. Basically, `atom foo/bar` has no reason to be different from `open -a Atom foo/bar`. ~~Precisely, it _does not_ inherit the local environment.~~
3. local environment management is bestowed to package implementor (meaning detection of `.git`, `Gemfile`, `.rubocop.yml`, `.gopath`, which they have to do anyway else at least starting via launchd is broken, if not more), not to manual handling by developer.
# Consequences
- `PATH` & al. is properly set and tools like linters can leverage the env to use chruby/rbenv/whatever.
- Clicking the icon, starting via spotlight, opening a file from Finder, using `open -a Atom` and using `atom foo` on the terminal are all consistent, whatever the order they are executed in.
- Everything is now consistent and we can now rejoice as glittery roses spontaneously bloom out of Bose-Einstein condensates.
# Additional note

Pet peeve: `atom` is currently equivalent to `atom .`. While I can see how this could be ok on other platforms, this is subtly wrong on OS X as `atom` is expected to be equivalent to `open -a Atom`, i.e start the app and don't open anything (unless it's set up to open a new document when no document is opened, otherwise merely focus the app, and if the app is not started, start it)

On another planet, I don't know if this issue applies to other OSes as well besides OS X. Everything depends on how process management and app/doc/task GUI model is handled there.
# Final word

All of this really matters daily when you juggle between projects and makes Atom feel like an unfinished, brittle product, making angry coworkers throwing nails at me for having pushed Atom on them.

† think fish-shell or (god forbid) csh.
Label: enhancement

Title: "SELF_SIGNED_CERT_IN_CHAIN" in packages and themes tab of settings
Body:
Hello,

I've been using Atom now as my main code editor for months and I love it. However, I've noticed in the last couple of versions that there seems to be a problem with accessing the packages and Themes tab of the settings. Whenever I search for something, I get this error come up:
    SELF_SIGNED_CERT_IN_CHAIN
I have tried uninstalling Atom and reinstalling it, and the same problem comes up.
Is this an Atom problem, or more likely something to do with my laptop, and if so, what?
I'm running a MacBook Air on Mac OSX 10.10 Yosemite with Atom version 0.144.0.
Any help would be most appreciated, since I don't seem to be able to add extensions any more.

Many thanks,
Dominic Ross,
Label: bug

Body:
seems to happen with any/all addon even after deleting the .atom dir

Title: Ask for root password when required
Body: Some files require root permissions to be edited, but sometimes those files are already modified when one realizes those files require said permissions. It would be nice if Atom could ask for the root password and apply the changes instead of having to close the file, close Atom, open Atom with root privileges and re-edit the file.
Label: bug

Title: Error while loading shared libraries; Package atom-amd64.deb missing dependencies
Body:
The application fails to start in the Ubuntu 14.04(Trusty) (in the LinuX Container) - Running the application from the command line shows:
$ atom

> /usr/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

It seems that the package (downloaded from https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/download/v0.144.0/atom-amd64.deb) has missing dependencies: libgtk2.0-0 libgconf2-4 libasound2 libnss3 libxtst6 (libgnome-keyring0)

$ ldd /usr/share/atom/atom | grep "not found"

>   libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0 => not found
>     libgdk-x11-2.0.so.0 => not found
>     libatk-1.0.so.0 => not found

>     libcairo.so.2 => not found
>     libpango-1.0.so.0 => not found
>     libgdk_pixbuf-2.0.so.0 => not found
>     libgconf-2.so.4 => not found
>     libX11.so.6 => not found

>     libnss3.so => not found
>     libnssutil3.so => not found
>     libsmime3.so => not found
>     libplc4.so => not found
>     libnspr4.so => not found
>     libgconf-2.so.4 => not found
>     libpangocairo-1.0.so.0 => not found
>     libcairo.so.2 => not found
>     libpango-1.0.so.0 => not found
>     libX11.so.6 => not found
>     libXi.so.6 => not found
>     libXcursor.so.1 => not found
>     libXext.so.6 => not found
>     libXfixes.so.3 => not found
>     libXrender.so.1 => not found
>     libXcomposite.so.1 => not found
>     libasound.so.2 => not found
>     libXdamage.so.1 => not found
>     libXtst.so.6 => not found
>     libXrandr.so.2 => not found
>     libcups.so.2 => not found
>     libgdk_pixbuf-2.0.so.0 => not found

$ dpkg -s atom

> Package: atom
> Status: install ok installed
> Priority: optional
> Section: devel
> Installed-Size: 194788
> Maintainer: GitHub atom@github.com
> Architecture: amd64
> Version: 0.144.0
> Depends: python (>= 2.6), libc6
> Description: A hackable text editor for the 21st Century.
>  Atom is a free and open source text editor that is modern, approachable, and hackable to the core.

$ uname -a

> `Linux ntb 3.13.0-39-generic #66-Ubuntu SMP Tue Oct 28 13:30:27 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

workaround:
$ sudo aptitude install libgtk2.0-0 libgconf2-4 libasound2 libnss3 libxtst6
Label: bug

Title: Changing a tab from pane doesn't display it's content.
Body:
I have my screen in split view (2 panes) and, when changing a tab from 1 pane to the other the file doesn't seem to show, after I switch tabs the content of the file show, there aren't errors in the developer tools. And a gif is included to demostrate the bug in `atom --safe`
![change editor of pane](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1993929/4965892/8fef5ce4-679c-11e4-9a8a-a203c03493da.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Multiple-window menu bug on Windows
Body:
On Windows only, when I open multiple Atom windows, then jump from one window's menu to the other window's menu, the menu actions affect the former window.  It should affect the latter window.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open two windows in Atom.
2. In Window 1, click the "View" menu.  Leave it open.
3. In Window 2, click the "View" menu.  The menu in Window 1 will close when you click it.
4. Click something like, say, "View -> Developer -> Toggle Developer Tools".  The tools are toggled on Window 1, even though you clicked the item in Window 2.

I noticed this problem while looking at https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/802.  In that case, I noticed that I could open two Atom windows, launch "File -> Open File..." in Window 2, then apparently open Window 2's menu by first clicking on Window 1's menu.  Selecting something in Window 2's apparent menu actually affects Window 1.
Label: bug

Title: Native Chromium scrollbars after reload
Body:
Whenever I reload Atom with a file opened that triggered a scrollbar, native Chromium scrollbars will appear until another file/tab has been used. For Windows, it only appears to be the vertical scrollbar. In Ubuntu also the horizontal scrollbar loses styling. 

![atom-scrollbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8148535/4965025/aca0ad0c-6779-11e4-817b-597338fef281.gif)

Seems similar to #4090, but this is without shadow DOM enabled, and also happens when using `atom --safe`. Also no errors in the console.
### Steps to reproduce
1. Open a long file in Atom that causes a scrollbar to appear
2. Choose View > Reload
### Details

Theme: Atom Dark
Safe mode: verified
Atom version:
- 0.144.0 on Windows 8.1 x64, not using Chocolatey
- 0.142.0 on Ubuntu 14.10
Label: bug

Title: Settings view missing styles
Body:
I'm opening this in core since no recent style changes were made in the settings view that I can see so I'm thinking this may be a shadow DOM related regression.

The packages/themes in the settings view are missing their borders and some other styles

/cc @nathansobo
Label: bug

Title: Packages with a context-specific stylesheet and normal sheet: normal sheet is not loaded
Body:
With shadow DOM turned on. 

This is such a package: https://github.com/atom/decoration-example

The `decoration-example.less` file is not loaded. Removing the `decoration-example.atom-text-editor.less` file fixes.
Label: bug

Title: Folding broken after splitting
Body:
- Open an editor
- Fold a function
- Split the pane
- Unfold the function in the new pane
- Fold something inside the initially folded function
- Gutter shows it as folded but is isn't

Title: ~/.atom/styles.less no longer loaded last
Body:
Styles from the syntax theme with the same specificity are overriding styles my `~/.atom/styles.less` file.

![screen shot 2014-11-07 at 12 00 03 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/4959484/b4eef688-66b8-11e4-920d-192b90eae908.png)

Title: Close Pane closes Tabs despite Cancel
Body:
In a window with several tabs, some of them _dirty_, using Close Pane (from File menu) pops the "Changes will be lost" dialog. However clicking the Cancel button still closes the _untouched_ tabs. 

Expected behaviour: do not close anything.

Additionally, clicking Cancel should also immediately stop the processing of the command. At the moment it carries on prompting for each _dirty_ tab.
Label: bug

Title: Tree view show files greyed out that should not be greyed out
Body:
Freshly checking out a project I'm working on via `git clone https://git.swift.im/review/swift` and opening it via `open -a "Atom" swift` it shows all source files (.cpp/.h) under Swift/QtUI as greyed out ( https://www.dropbox.com/s/hpb089qah49itsl/Screenshot%202014-11-07%2019.04.41.png ), as if they were covered by .gitignore, but they aren't. This also prevents them to be easily opened via `CMD+P`.

OS: OS X 10.9.5
Atom Version: 0.141.0
Label: bug

Title: Closing pane clobbers unsaved files
Body:
Closing a pane closes unsaved files without prompting or saving
- **Atom Version:**       0.143.0-b29a61e
- **Atom-Shell Version:** 0.19.1
- **OS Version:**         Mac OS X 10.10
- **Misc Versions**
  - apm  0.109.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.32
  - python 2.7.6
  - git 2.1.2
## Repro Steps
1. Open a file `a.txt`
2. Open second pane <kbd>Cmd+K RIGHT</kbd>
3. Open a file `b.txt`
4. Make a change to `b.txt`
5. Select `File | Close Pane`

**Expected:** Dialog is shown
**Actual:** No dialog is shown, file is closed without prompting

Title: `Cannot read property 'observeActiveItem' of null` when opening a specific project

And it may be connected to the git plus package and the commit panes it opens, because before that I got some `EventEmitter` error while committing (hitting `ctrl-s` in the commit message pane/buffer), so it might have serialized that pane as well and can't deserialize it.

Title: Paste Chinese character problem
Body:
I copied several Chinese characters and wanted to paste them into atom. If I used `mouse right button -> Paste`, everything is fine. But if I used `Ctrl+V`, atom showed messy codes. 
So, is there something different between `Paste` and `Ctrl+V`?
Label: bug

Title: Should be able to use Page Up / Page Down in dialogs
Body:
With a vanilla install of Atom 0.141.0 in Windows 7 Home Premium x64 I find that I'm unable to use Page Up / Down in dialogs, such as the command palette (Ctrl+Shift+P) and symbols (Ctrl+R). Key Binding Resolver shows:

```
core:page-down    body     resources\app\keymaps\win32.json
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Alt+{letter} menu shortcuts and arrow key navigation don't work on Windows and Linux
Body:
The normal Windows `Alt+{letter}` menu shortcuts don't work in Atom. Holding `Alt` highlights the relevant letter in each menu name, but then pressing the letter doesn't open the menu. For example, `Alt+F` should open the File menu, but instead the Key Binding Resolver shows it invoking the following:

```
editor:move-to-end-of-word    atom-text-editor    resources\app\keymaps\emacs.json
```

This is a vanilla install of Atom 0.141.0 in Windows 7 Home Premium x64. I haven't opted in to enabling anything Emacs related.

Pressing Alt also doesn't focus the menu bar and allow it to be navigated by arrow keys like it normally does in Windows.

I'm reporting this per [this suggestion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/alt-key-menu-bar-interaction-overrides-shortuts/9192/5)
Label: bug

Title: Atom version in rpm, deb, and dmg packages
Body:
Can we get the version appended to the rpm, deb and dmg packages as they are built.

I can't speak to dmg for mac, but it is considered standard practice to include the version and release as part of the filename in rpm and deb packages, especially since atom doesn't update itself and there are no YUM repos (yet).

Title: `cmd-L` should scroll
Body:
I had originally submitted https://discuss.atom.io/t/scroll-to-bottom-on-selecting-lines-cmd-l/13017 but it was suggested that it is a bug rather than a feature.

If I hit `cmd-L` multiple times to select multiple rows, when I reach the bottom of the visible portion of the window, then `cmd-L` will select lines that aren't visible.  Since I've already seen the first lines when doing I started doing `cmd-L`, may I propose that the view scrolls to keep the bottom line visible?  (I guess it would also be nice to see some of the lines that aren't selected yet.)

`cmd-L` refers to the "Editor: Select Line" command available in the command palette.
Label: bug

Title: Reverse delete consumes too many characters
Body:
![rev-del-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/440132/4870418/ed6416ca-6167-11e4-99e6-4166a63ff9c4.gif)

Atom 0.141.0, Mac OS 10.9.5. When using `alt-delete` to delete to end of word, I feel like the natural thing should be to erase all the whitespace in one stop, without removing any visible characters. As you can see above, if I wanted to eliminate a bunch of whitespace by hitting `alt-delete`, it eats up some of the code in the process.
Label: enhancement

Title: Possible to change the html's bg to be dynamically set on theme apply/change?
Body:
System:  Arch Linux GNOME 3.14.2 | Linux Kernel 3.17.2 | Lenovo i7, 16gb ram, intel 4000
See it here: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/2f82fb2ceb5501f2df7e839af467fbfd4bec47ad/static/index.html

---

On Linux sometimes artifacts are left momentarily on the screen after a resize completes or when closing the app. However this is probably less prevalent in the Mac version because Chromium interacts better with Cocoa than it does w GTK. 

This has a been a persistent problem in Chromium since they've gonre to Aura. 

Reference bug: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=326995&q=linux%20resize%20window&colspec=ID%20Pri%20M%20Iteration%20ReleaseBlock%20Cr%20Status%20Owner%20Summary%20OS%20Modified
Label: bug

Title: Atom takes over keyboard shortcuts in Help menu search box
Body:
Not sure if this is an issue with Atom or atom-shell. If you focus the search box in the Help menu, keyboard shortcuts are still handled by the editor.
1. Enter some text in the search box
2. Press cmd+a. The search box loses focus and the text is not selected.

Similarly,
1. Enter some text in Atom and select it
2. Enter some text in the search box and select it.
3. Press cmd+c. The editor text is copied instead of the text in the search box.
Label: bug

Title: Atom protocol for files in .atom directory
Body: Currently the `atom` protocol only looks in the two `packages` directories and Atom's `node_modules` directory. I have a replacement background image in my `styles.less` that I store in `~/.atom/resources` but I have to use the full path to the file. It would be nice to be able to use the protocol for cases like this as well, e.g. `background-image: url(atom://resources/transparent-background.png)`
Label: enhancement

Title: /* */ comment on a single line inside braces keeps trying to un-indent
Body:
If I have a `/* comment */` on a single line, Atom automatically un-indents the line immediately when I type the closing `*/` and after various edits elsewhere on the line.

![outdent-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120506/4844110/e771aa82-6038-11e4-970f-4dd21e48f05f.gif)

(the re-indentation in that gif is me hitting `ctrl+]` to fix it)

It only seems to occur if the comment is inside some manner of braces or parentheses, for example:
- `/* foo */` (comment only thing on the line) perfectly fine
- `foo /* bar */` also fine
- `if( /* foo */` is fine but as soon as I type the closing `)` it outdents (and then again for subsequent additions to the line), or if the `)` was already there thanks to auto-insertion of closing brackets

I _think_ this may be specific to JavaScript syntax, so apologies if the issue should be on language-javascript instead.

Happens in atom built straight off master, but has been happening for a while now, definitely at least since 0.120 or so. Also happens with `--safe` so it isn't a package issue.
Label: bug

Title: Problems with selection and cursor position in complex non-latin scripts
Body:
Atom has a problem in dealing with Devanagari, in that the cursor position does not always reflect the actual position if there is some Devanagari text in the current line. Same goes for selecting within lines containing Devanagari. I can also see that Atom renders Devangari as fully formed Devangari with half-forms, conjuncts (ligatures), and so on. For an editor I would much prefer the Sublime Text approach, where Devanagari text is treated as a string of characters with no attempt to render half-forms, conjuncts, and do the other advanced OpenType compositing features. Instead the text is rendered the way it is typed, which is much much easier to edit. Here is some sample text that borks Atom: ``` NO LANG ‘रृ’ “रॄ? ल- लृ–!!!???,.
``` (Try here to select the ??? and delete them…) ``` रृ रॄ ल लृ लॄ ऌ ॡ ``` (Try here to select the Devanagari characters and delete them…) Also try to paste those strings into Sublime Text and see how ST renders the Devanagari as full-forms + halants/virama + matras in sequential order, which I would prefer. Because the monospaced fonts we use often do not have Devanagari, the Devanagari is rendered in a proportional fall-back font. If you did as in Sublime Text you could force the advance-width of all the Devanagari glyphs to be the same as the default monospaced font. That way you could preserve monospaced text and get around the whole – very thorny – issue of mixing in complex non-latin scripts in a monospaced environment. Just an idea, so up to you to find out if that would actually be a way to go. I note that you have partially fixed the issue in 0.140, but it’s still not perfect. Take this example line: ``` क ख ग घ ङ च छ ज ? ञ ट ठ ड ढ ण त थ द ध न प फ ब भ म य र ऱ ल ळ व श ष स ह क़ ख़ ग़ ज़ ड़ ढ़ फ़ य़ ॹ ॻ ॼ ॾ ॿ

``` If you try to select it with the mouse, from the end towards the beginning of the line, then the last br> is not selected. If you select the Devanagari text and press delete, then you end up with this: ``` pan>

``` (notice the missing
Label: bug

Title: Unable to open Atom from command line
Body:
Hello All, 

I recently updated the operating system to OSX Yosemite (10.10) and I'm now not able to open atom from the command line. Every time I try to open Atom, I get an error.

```
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.
```

Please help.
/Ven
Label: bug

Title: Opening Atom in Windows 7
Body:
Just downloaded Atom to use at Uni but it's not opening like usual.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5865044/4789063/f4194706-5dc0-11e4-9dd5-eae699125c0c.png)

Is all I see.

Have I done something wrong, or do the uni computers have something missing.
Label: bug

Title: Can't access pane view within onDidAddPane
Body:
With this script:

``` coffee
atom.workspace.onDidAddPane ({pane}) ->
    console.log atom.workspace.getView(pane)
```

Splitting panes results in an exception:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'onDidChangeActivePane' of undefined /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:122
module.exports.Pane.onDidChangeActive /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:122
module.exports.Pane.observeActive /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:131PaneElement.setModel /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-element.js:158
module.exports.ViewRegistry.createView /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/view-registry.js:54
module.exports.ViewRegistry.getView /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/view-registry.js:33
module.exports.Workspace.getView /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace.js:705(anonymous function) init.coffee:17
module.exports.Emitter.emit /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:71
module.exports.PaneContainer.didAddPane /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-container.js:305
module.exports.Pane.setContainer /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:100
module.exports.PaneAxis.addChild /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-axis.js:125
module.exports.PaneAxis.insertChildAfter /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-axis.js:178
module.exports.Pane.split /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:628
module.exports.Pane.splitRight /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:596addCommands.pane:split-right /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-element.js:128(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane-element.js:78handler /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/space-pen-extensions.js:107jQuery.event.dispatch /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4681elemData.handle /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4359
module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:253(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:3
module.exports.CommandRegistry.dispatch /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:166jQuery.fn.trigger /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/space-pen-extensions.js:56
module.exports.CommandPaletteView.confirmed /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/command-palette/lib/command-palette-view…:118
module.exports.SelectListView.confirmSelection /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/select-list-view.js:331(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/select-list-view.js:113handler /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/space-pen-extensions.js:107jQuery.event.dispatch /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4681elemData.handle /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4359
module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:253(anonymous function) /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:3
module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:544
module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:386
module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:151
```

The problem seems to be in [`Pane::setContainer`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/pane.coffee#L65). The event is fired before the container is actually set. Modifying it to set the container before firing the event allows the view to be accessed.
Label: bug

Title: Atom default font does not look the same on Linux as on Windows and Mac
Body:
I just cloned the latest version of Atom after being away for a few weeks and I noticed that the font rendering looked a bit weird. 

On Mac OS X, I found that the font Atom was using was (very close to if not the same as) `Inconsolata, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', Courier` and when I entered that for the font style on Linux, I got a rockwell looking font which has the following CSS `Rockwell, "Courier Bold", Courier, Georgia, Times, "Times New Roman", serif`. 

Here is a screenshot of the font on Linux in the settings (which appears to be the same as on Mac and Windows) 
![screenshot from 2014-10-25 12 01 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6335521/4780265/5cd00e0e-5c60-11e4-89c1-f3ea30485336.png)

and here is the font rendered in the editor itself which looks completely different
![screenshot from 2014-10-25 12 02 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6335521/4780267/67ef54de-5c60-11e4-9274-01e2ce250e4f.png)
Label: bug

Title: Bug in Markdown Links where URL has Parenthesis
Body:
In Atom 0.139.0 on Macintosh Yosemite 10.10:

This link doesn't work correctly – the internal parenthetical should be ignored for closing the markdown link. Instead, the closing parenthesis in the valid URL closes the entire markdown link, causing the link to be bad and the closing .pdf to be rendered as text.

```
["A Taxonomy of Privacy"](https://www.law.upenn.edu/journals/lawreview/articles/volume154/issue3/Solove154U.Pa.L.Rev.477(2006).pdf).
```
Label: bug

Title: hitting carriage return results in indentation changes
Body:
See this GIF, in which only one thing happens: I hit the return key.  The number of indentation spaces changes in the selected line.

![hit-carriage-return-atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/224739/4775573/31d6f78c-5bb9-11e4-85ba-8d26ea49860c.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Open multiple files from fuzzy finder
Body:
Hi guys, 

from another IDE I am using I like the feature to have multiple files opened at one time. This works by pressing Shift and Arrow up/down to mark them and then simply Enter to open. A new tab for each file will then be opened. 

Regards Benedikt
Label: enhancement

Title: Getting extra line when breaking a long string (Python)
Body:
Getting weird behaviour when breaking a long string in python. I would expect the text to appear to the right of the cursor on the next line, not a new line.

Windows 0.139.0.

![weird](http://i.imgur.com/XsqBME3.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Feature request: GitRepository needs a method list all remote Url's
Body:
GitRepository has only the ability to `getOriginUrl` this is a fairly limited use-case, so I propose adding:
- `getRemoteUrls`: Returns a list of all remotes urls
- `getRemoteUrl(name)`: Returns URL for named remote
Label: enhancement

Title: Disable activation command listeners and key bindings when package activation fails
Body: In https://github.com/emmetio/emmet-atom/issues/155, Emmet is failing to activate due to a change in core, but it continues to eat key bindings which causes `enter` and `tab` to be rendered useless. It would be better if a package that failed to activate had its activation commands and key bindings unloaded.
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature: OSX - Recent Projects on right click in Dock
Body:
Other editors (e.g. Textmate) give a list of recently used projects/files when right clicking on the icon in the dock.

See these screenshots:

![screen shot 2014-10-23 at 00 36 31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7480/4745559/f54196de-5a3b-11e4-905c-7cdd97f11dd9.png)
![screen shot 2014-10-23 at 00 36 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7480/4745560/f542b992-5a3b-11e4-8a03-95bc82685ef8.png)

It would be great if Atom would do the same.

I was not sure what package to post this issue in. Maybe it belongs to atom-shell.
There needs to be some code that can hook into native OSX APIs, since that is how i believe that it works.
Label: enhancement

Title: Add .dmg for OSX
Body: It would be nice to have an .DMG to install on OSX
Label: enhancement

Title: 139 broken in dev mode
Body:
Everything works fine in normal and safe mode.  If dev mode the tabs and file tree are missing.  The console says ...

```
Error compiling Less stylesheet: 
Line number: 47
variable @light-gray is undefined 
Error compiling Less stylesheet: 
Line number: 28
variable @very-light-gray is undefined

Line number: 3
'variables.less' wasn't found

Line number: 3
'variables.less' wasn't found

Failed to activate theme 'atom-light-ui' because it isn't installed. 
```

I'm one windows 8.0 and atom 139.  this didn't happen in 138

Title: ctrl+alt+f2 does not add a bookmark
Body: I'm having trouble adding / removing bookmarks using ctrl+alt+f2. According to my keybindings that should toggle a bookmark for a certain line which isn't the case. When I go to the menu and click Edit > Bookmark > Toggle bookmark it works. Please advise. Thanks.
Label: bug

Title: Syntax highlighting for PHP file disappears briefly on save
Body: ![](http://cl.ly/image/2o2u3h0M2N2t/Screen%20Recording%202014-10-22%20at%2010.38%20AM.gif)
Label: bug

Title: can't get rid of untitled tabs
Body:
There are two problems with untitled tabs.  These untitled tabs are created with `atom.workspace.open()`.
- When there is an untitled tab with contents, and you close Atom and select `Don't Save`, when atom reopens the untitled tab reappears with no contents.  This happens even when there are multiple normal tabs.  If you do this over and over you get more and more untitled tabs.
-  When my code executes `editor.delete()` for an untitled tab the contents are deleted but the tab view doesn't go away.

These seem like the same bug to me.

windows 8.0   --  atom 0.138.0
Label: bug

Title: No command line help no --version, no --help
Body:
I run "atom --help" and get no help.

Could be a windows / shimgen issue.

I tried multiple shells including powershell, msys bash, cmd.

When I run it directly it works:

```
"C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib\Atom.0.138.0\tools\Atom\atom.exe" --help
[4888:1020/152630:INFO:CONSOLE(0)] Atom Editor v0.138.0

Usage: atom [options] [path ...]

One or more paths to files or folders to open may be specified.

File paths will open in the current window.

Folder paths will open in an existing window if that folder has already been
opened or a new window if it hasn't.

Options:
  -d, --dev             Run in development mode.                                             [boolean]
  -f, --foreground      Keep the browser process in the foreground.                          [boolean]
  -h, --help            Print this usage message.                                            [boolean]
  -l, --log-file        Log all output to file.                                              [string]
  -n, --new-window      Open a new window.                                                   [boolean]
  -s, --spec-directory  Set the spec directory (default: Atom's spec directory).             [string]
  --safe                Do not load packages from ~/.atom/packages or ~/.atom/dev/packages.  [boolean]
  -t, --test            Run the specified specs and exit with error code on failures.        [boolean]
  -v, --version         Print the version.                                                   [boolean]
  -w, --wait            Wait for window to be closed before returning.                       [boolean]
```

```
$ "C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib\Atom.0.138.0\tools\Atom\atom.exe" --version
[4440:1020/153010:INFO:CONSOLE(0)] 0.138.0

```
Label: bug

Title: Atom doesn't load dev packages in dev mode
Body:
I don't know if it was an intended change and I missed the announcement or if it's just a side effect of the changes in the ways packages are now loaded but Atom no longer loads packages from `~/.atom/dev/packages` when running with `--dev` option.

After running `atom --dev` to work on a package that is in my `~/github` directory and then symlinked in `~/.atom/dev/packages`, then I try the following in the console: 

```
minimap = atom.packages.getActivePackage('minimap')
=> Package {path: "/Users/cedric/.atom/packages/minimap", metadata: Object, emitter: Emitter, name: "minimap", stylesheets: Array[1]…}
```

As you can see the package version that is loaded is the one in `~/.atom/packages` and not the one from `dev`.
Label: bug

Title: Atom 138 broken on Unity (Ubuntu.)  No longer integrates with indicator-appmenu.
Body: It happened somewhere in https://github.com/atom/atom/compare/v0.137.0...v0.138.0
Label: bug

Title: Add Option to "Do Nothing" when Atom Becomes Active
Body: Right now, Atom opens a blank file at launch. It would be great if users had the option to do nothing when Atom becomes active (i.e., don't open a blank file at launch). Many other text editors have this option, so it seems a bit odd that Atom doesn't.
Label: enhancement

Title: apm rebuild-module-cache aborts on error
Body: When I got an error from `apm rebuild-module-cache` because of an empty directory it dropped out and quit processing,
Label: bug

Title: Version menu entry in help menu isn't grayed out since 0.137
Body:
Since version 0.137 the version menu entry in the help menu isn't grayed out like in prior versions. I'm running on Windows 8.1.

![atom-138-help-menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/190154/4685673/dcbaf18a-563c-11e4-9a61-fdd4b32064fc.png)
Label: bug

Title: Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script in the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'self'".
Body:
Since Atom 0.137 (On OSX 10.10) I see this when I try to upgrade, edit the settings or view a package.

![screenshot 2014-10-17 01 08 54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4365/4674681/4fc1e9a2-559a-11e4-9ccf-d89fb55309de.png)

I've run atom --safe and the same error appears.
Label: bug

Title: [OSX] Erroneously clicking on Atom icon in dock multiple times freezes app and launches several instances
Body:
If Atom is closed completely and its dock icon clicked multiple times before the editor has time to render, the application takes a long time to load and several windows are spawned (based on the number of clicks). I noticed this when erroneously double-clicking the icon to launch.

Tested on OSX Mavericks and Yosemite.
Label: bug
