Title: Ligatures aren't spaced correctly
Body:
I'm using the Atom for Windows Alpha from the Atom website (not Chocolatey), version 0.136.0 (as viewed in the Help menu and with `--version` in the command line, the `version` file in the Atom folder says v0.17.1; it was downloaded around 12:30AM US Eastern on October 14, 2014 if that helps) on Windows 8.1. I set `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;` for `.editor` in `styles.less` (because otherwise the ligatures aren't in effect and I get each individual character). This happens regardless of whether hardware acceleration is enabled. It also happens in `--safe` mode, and the developer tools console shows no errors.

![temp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4254261/4624455/bad18f5a-5364-11e4-9a0f-8c59596bcd59.png)

```
(<*>)::Functor f=>(a->b)->(f a->f b)
fmap::Functor f=>(a->b)->(f a->f b)
```

in [Hasklig](https://github.com/i-tu/Hasklig), which has ligatures for `<*>`, `::`, `=>`, and `->`.

![temp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4254261/4624502/6b794cee-5365-11e4-8d85-a129dee8ae1d.png)

```
fifififififififififi
```

in Calibri, using the ligature for `fi`. The cursor is at the end of the line, and the misspell underline only leads up to that point as well. The ligature for `ff` in Calibri has the opposite effect; the cursor and underline extend farther than text on the screen if you put enough f's on a line.

I can provide more details if you need them.
Label: bug

Title: Selection::insertText: undo skip doesn't work
Body:
The [documentation](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.136.0/Selection#instance-insertText) says:

> .undo
> if skip, skips the undo stack for this operation.

but it doesn't work.

I looked into the source code. The [only line](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v0.136.0/src/selection.coffee#L362), which does anything with `undo`, is:

```
newBufferRange = @editor.buffer.setTextInRange(oldBufferRange, text, pick(options, 'undo'))
```

In [`setTextInRange`](https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/blob/v3.2.8/src/text-buffer.coffee#L512), the `undo` option becomes `normalizeLineEndings` (default: `true`). It looks like `normalizeLineEndings` has nothing to do with undo.

This means the `undo` option gets interpreted as something totally unrelated to undo.
Label: bug

Title: Snippets should be displayed in autocomplete
Body:
I'm using Atom V0.135.0 for web development. When working in a HTML file, I wrote `ta` and pressed `ctrl+space` hoping to autocomplete it to `table`. I was surprised to see no `table` in autocomplete suggestion. My initial thought was that Atom does not support HTML autocompletes and I was very disappointed. But I could not believe Atom missed such a basic functionality. So I digged deeper. I found that atom has HTML _snippets_ which can be used by writing `ta` and pressing `tab` key to use the `table` snippet.

This behavior is very counter intuitive. Behind the scenes, I do not care if it's implemented as _autocomplete_ or _snippet_, but when I write a half-word and press the _autocomplete_ key combination, I expect everything to be displayed there as a suggestion, even the snippets. What do the devs think about it?
Label: enhancement

Title: Add new editor.tabType scoped setting
Body:
While digging into scoping `editor.softTabs` in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/3718, it's pretty clear that the setting has very little influence on the actual value chosen. It's effectively the worst-case fallback: it only works on an empty file.

I propose doing a couple things:
- adding a new `editor.tabType` setting that accepts 3 values: Auto, Hard, Soft. With the default being `auto`. Then in the scoped settings for each language, they can set it to whatever they want. 
- Changing `TextEditor::setSoftTabs` to being a settings override accepting 4 values: unset / use-the-settings, Auto, Hard, Soft
- Reading the settings on each time we need to get the tab type. Something like (pseudo code): 

``` coffee
getTabType: (scopeDescriptor) ->
  @userTabTypeOverride or atom.config.get(scopeDescriptor, 'editor.tabType') or atom.config.get(scopeDescriptor, 'editor.softTabs') or 'soft'
```

See https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/4231d6942101c3e77a1d0371cf3b61045b8fa6fb/src/text-editor.coffee#L93 and https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/4231d6942101c3e77a1d0371cf3b61045b8fa6fb/src/text-editor.coffee#L2319 for reference.

Refs 
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3584 

Comment if you know of more issues, complaints. I know there have been several complaints about this, but cant find issues.
Label: enhancement

Title: Config gets stuck to default if config.cson has a syntax error
Body:
I somehow managed to get a syntax error in my config.cson (completely unable to reproduce what caused it now), which caused Atom to fail to parse it, and instead just used defaults.

Thinking I'd managed to delete some config somewhere went and set stuff back to how it was, but nothing was persisted and everything was reset on next restart. I'm guessing this is Atom refusing to overwrite the existing file, though I couldn't see any errors to that effect in the dev tools.

The behaviour of not completely clobbering an invalid config is good but maybe there could be a warning in the UI and/or the invalid config.cson be copied somewhere else so that subsequent changes can be persisted properly.
Label: enhancement

Title: Problem in handling hierarchical .gitignore in the treeview
Body:
Hi, and first, thank you so much for your project.

This problem first appeared in my work project which is unfortunately private. All my files was considered as ignore and appeared in grey in the treeview. I took some time and finally succeed to isolate and reproduce it.

In a Git project, if a .gitignore from a subdirectory match a path from the root of the project, the treeview will use the rule and ignore the path while it's incorrect. Indeed, Git will not do the same mistake and the `git status` will be different as what Atom show.

You can easily test on this repository I create to demonstrate the problem:
https://github.com/Swiip/atom-git-tree-test
The `test.txt` file inside the src directory should not be displayed grey as it's not ignored in git.

If it's needed, I tested on a Mac with OSX 10.9.5, Atom 0.134.0, I tried several times to delete cached files and it change nothing. I have no error in the developer panel.
Label: bug

Title: getCurrentWordBufferRange doesn't seem to work correctly for words like change-case
Body:
I'm trying to get the current word under the cursor and the default options of `getCurrentWordBufferRange` should AFAIK enable matching words with non-space separators, but currently the regex seems to have been misconfigured so that it doesn't match word correctly.

Current code:

``` coffee
wordRegExp: ({includeNonWordCharacters}={}) ->
includeNonWordCharacters ?= true
nonWordCharacters = atom.config.get('editor.nonWordCharacters')
segments = ["^[\t ]*$"]
segments.push("[^\\s#{_.escapeRegExp(nonWordCharacters)}]+")
if includeNonWordCharacters
  segments.push("[#{_.escapeRegExp(nonWordCharacters)}]+")
new RegExp(segments.join("|"), "g")
```

Correct code:

``` coffee
wordRegExp: ({includeNonWordCharacters}={}) ->
includeNonWordCharacters ?= true
nonWordCharacters = atom.config.get('editor.nonWordCharacters')
segments = ["^[\t ]*$"]
if includeNonWordCharacters
  segments.push("[#{_.escapeRegExp(nonWordCharacters)}]+")
  segments.push("[^\\s]+")
else
  segments.push("[^\\s#{_.escapeRegExp(nonWordCharacters)}]+")
new RegExp(segments.join("|"), "g")
```
Label: bug

Title: Insane amount of max_user_watches required to run Atom on Ubuntu 14.04
Body:
Follow up to #3617 . Ubuntu 14.04 with latest updates and Atom 0.130.0.

Problem was fixed as instructed in #3617 and re-appeared later and `max_user_watches` is still being set at new value 32768.

```
$ cat /proc/sys/fs/inotify/max_user_watches 
32768
```

While Atom was open, it just failed to open any new files. After closing it, it has reverted to state I first reported #3617, failing to open at all.

Setting `max_user_watches` to `131072` allowed me to run Atom again. But why such high values are required for a simple text editor? Is code leaking watches, or establishing watches too widely?
Label: bug

Title: Editor crashes on saving or on opening a file that has been modified
Body:
In the last 2 days, Atom has started to:
- Crash immediately after saving an edited file
- Crash whenever you try to open a file that has been modified but not committed (according to git) - verified by committing the file and then trying to open it, which then works

It appears to have issues reconciling the git status of the file on opening or saving, maybe? I'm not using any complex arrangement of plugins.
Label: bug

Title: File chooser dialog is not modal and does not have focus on Ubuntu 14.04
Body:
On Ubuntu 14.04, Atom 0.130.0, if you do "ctrl-o" to open a file, the file chooser dialog does not become focused nor modal. 

It means you cannot cancel the dialog with quick press of "esc" or you cannot choose files with keyboard input only, but you need to be clicking it with a mouse to get focus.

Checking Sublime, gedit, Firefox or basically any app, file chooser dialog is always modal and has focus.
Label: bug

Title: cmd-l in multi-line selection doesn't select beginning of first line
Body:
When you you have no selection, with a cursor in the middle of a line, `cmd-l` selects the entire line, from the left side of the editor to the right side, including the ending newline.

When you have a selection that spans a few lines, `cmd-l` selects the end of the last line, but doesn't select the beginning of the first line.  I expected it to select the beginning of the first line too.
![Screen capture](http://cl.ly/image/042j0S2T1t04/Screen%20Recording%202014-09-24%20at%2007.47%20PM.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Cursor position disappears when window loses focus
Body: I'm on Ubuntu 14.04 and every time I alt+tab or make Atom lose focus in any way, the cursor position disappears.  I have to click on the window to make it reappear.

Title: ctrl-o in Ubuntu always opens "Recently Used" in file chooser
Body:
Using keyboard shortcut `ctrl-o` in Ubuntu launches open file dialog with "Recently used" as default folder. The default in basically all other apps (including Sublime Text) is to open the currently open file's folder as default.

Yes, the tree view is there to quickly open files from current directory, but breaking convention is bad.
Label: bug

Title: Atom not focused correctly on launch
Body:
I'm using Atom 0.130 on Ubuntu 14.04 with Unity.  When running Atom the application will come to the foreground but it isn't correctly focused - the title and left launcher show the previously focused application.  Steps to replicate:
- Open an application that isn't atom
- Run atom from the dash
- See the title bar/launcher still thinking the previous application is focused.

The image below shows the issue - I had Firefox focused before opening Atom.

Title: Cursor getBeginningOfCurrentWordBufferPosition seems to produce incorrect results
Body:
Take this snippet of code:

```
var express = require('express'),
```

When I place my cursor right before the first 'r' in require, and I call `getBeginningOfCurrentWordBufferPosition()`, I get the '=' as the beginning of the current word...but there's a space in between.

When I place my cursor right before the first 'r' in require, and I call `isInsideWord()`, I get true..but I'm really at the beginning of the word.

Am I just expecting different results, or are these methods actually a little confusing..?
Label: bug

Title: Notify when file has changed outside of atom on unsaved buffer
Body:
today i worked on a project with sublime text and atom. i edited a file on sublime text, saved the changes and opened atom(the same file). both editors were open at the same time. but when i go to atom, there was no change detection to the file and all the changes, made in sublime text, were gone.

what i miss is a popup, mentioning that the file has changed and ask whether reloading.
Label: enhancement

Title: Crash on Ubuntu when dragging a Firefox window over Atom
Body:
Atom Version: 0.129.0
Video of me triggering the bug: http://ara.sh/private/atom-crash.ogv
Reproducible every time.

Environment:
Ubuntu 14.04 (all updates installed as of filing this issue)
Unity desktop environment

Repro steps:
1) Launch atom from the Terminal
2) Open a Firefox window (or use an existing one)
3) Drag the Firefox tab anywhere over the Atom window

Actual behavior:
It crashes

Expected behavior:
Not crash :-)

Additional Information:
The terminal prints out the following after the crash:

```
[7950:0920/180947:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(161)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
```

This would be nice to have in Atom for Java and possibly other languages.

Title: Tab rendering fails during theme package update
Body:
After updating the in-use theme, the tabs appear to lose their styles.

![screen shot 2014-09-18 at 12 32 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122102/4325180/8b1c521a-3f62-11e4-8672-1817a9bf7516.png)
Label: bug

Title: Can't indent line following line with bad indentation
Body:
Safe mode, with soft tabs off and a tab length of 4:

![screen shot 2014-09-18 at 14 51 47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/4320850/f5774c46-3f3a-11e4-8a39-dc7bc11e4fbc.png)

Pressing tab at the cursor position results in nothing happening. Indenting with `cmd+]` works normally.

It seems that you can only indent a maximum of `floor(spaces / tabLength)` times.

e.g. if I use 6 spaces with a tab length of 4, I can indent once, then it stops working:

![screen shot 2014-09-18 at 14 49 46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1759837/4320815/adc08d72-3f3a-11e4-8e31-9a48be2b8a8d.png)

If the number of spaces is a multiple of the tab length, it works normally.
Label: bug

Title: Ability to log in with GitHub account to sync Atom config
Body:
It would be great if I could login with a GitHub account and have Atom store my settings either in Dropbox, or GitHub as a repository, or in some way that is easy to access and maybe even sync them across all my installations of Atom so that when I download a new package, it is downloaded everywhere. Another suggestion is to be able to manually export a .atomconfig JSON file that I could just import to Atom at any point to configure settings, install packages, change themes, etc.

I think having the first would be more important for most people, but for anyone who is offline and for anyone who likes to keep their own backups in other places, the manual settings export is really useful.

If this sounds like a good idea to Atom contributors and consumers, I'd like to help out with the PR to make this happen.
Label: enhancement

Title: "Invisible" devtools mode
Body:
When I have the devtools closed, sometimes they pop up to tell me about an error that occurred. But there's never a stack trace, so this error message isn't very actionable. It's my understanding that stacktraces are only captured when the devtools are open before the error is thrown.

One solution to this is to always have the devtools open, but that takes up screen space. Another is to pop them out of the Atom window, but that gets confusing if you have multiple windows open.

It would be nice to have some kind of "invisible" devtools mode where it will still capture stacktraces (and do whatever else it does), but otherwise have the editor work normally. There's probably some kind of performance penalty incurred by having the devtools open, so maybe this could be behind a flag like `atom --debug`.
Label: enhancement

Title: Soft wrap broken around 127/128?
Body: It looks to me like the soft wrapping of lines broke somewhere about 127 or 128.  On 129, I see the grey guide out at 80 characters but no wrapping is occurring. "Soft wrap at preferred line length" is checked and the default at 80 character statement is visible in grey in the box.  Thanks.
Label: bug

Title: Scroll bar problems
Body:
I've had some problems with the scroll bars in more recent releases.  I posted the issues in the atom discussion board (https://discuss.atom.io/t/scroll-bars-are-missing/12152) and was directed to post here.

The issues:
- When code lines in a given file extend beyond the preferred line length, the vertical scroll bar does not appear.  If the file is edited so that no lines extend beyond the preferred line length, the vertical scroll bar immediately appears.
- The horizontal scroll bar is only present when scrolled all the way to the bottom of a file.

These problems have occurred for me since at least v0.127.0 (and possibly older) on Mac OS X 10.9.
Label: bug

Title: normalizeIndentOnPaste deletes indent
Body:
`normalizeIndentOnPaste` is supposed to [convert tabs to spaces, or spaces to tabs](https://atom.io/docs/v0.59.0/customizing-atom#configuration-key-reference).  Instead it [removes all indentation from the start of the line](https://discuss.atom.io/t/normalize-indent-on-paste-doesnt-work-as-expected/3503/5).

In a coffee file, try cutting and then immediately pasting the middle line:

```
    console.log "foo"
    console.log "bar"
    console.log "baz"
```

You get:

```
    console.log "foo"
console.log "bar"
    console.log "baz"
```

which is definitely note what `normalizeIndentOnPaste` should be doing.
Label: bug

Title: Register commands to disable/enable packages
Body:
Instead of having to dig deep into the settings view, there should probably be top level commands to enable/disable each package.

That way if you want to turn of something like spell check, you can do it from the command palette (`Cmd-Shift-P`) instead of having to click around the settings view.

Refs https://github.com/atom/spell-check/pull/33
Label: enhancement

Title: unexpected behavior (focus on the folderview)
Body:
when i select a file in the folder view (left side)... why this do not change the focus to the content of the file??

because my workflow is:
1. select a file
2. press Ctrl+f to search something (but nothing happens because the focus is still on the folder view)

everytime i have to click on the content of the file to get the focus... this is a bit disadvantageous

Title: Atom close the process "Explorer" on Windows when saving a file.
Body:
Hello,

I have a little problem with Atom. When i save a file, **sometimes** Atom (or maybe a plugin) kill the process "Explorer" on Windows. I have trying to disable 95% of all my plugins, but still the same. The problem is that it's not all times, but just sometimes. And i'm 100% sure that is Atom and not another soft, because when i use PhpStorm, it's never happened.
![xdcc0sd](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8210023/4262196/7a885e5e-3b92-11e4-83ee-9c135f08d556.png)

Windows : 8.1

(Sorry for my english, i'm french.)

Title: If Auto Indent is off, it should not insert a blank line
Body:
Auto Indent off implies that we should input every character manually.
But now, if we write

```
a={}
```

Then type RETURN between "{" and "}", it will insert a blank line. That's inconsistent, because this line is not manually, but auto inserted.
I tested Sublime Text. As I expected, it doesn't insert a blank line when auto indent is off.

Now:

```
a={

}
```

Should be:

```
a={
}
```
Label: bug

Title: Click Under Text Moves Cursor Incorrectly
Body:
Just a minor issue; when you click to move the cursor **underneath** the section with actual text in it, the cursor clamps to the last line but stays in the correct column. In most editors, clicking beyond the text region moves the cursor to the last letter of the last line.

![atom_screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4193418/4255095/9e18e71c-3ab1-11e4-938d-33edd72be0eb.png)
Label: bug

Title: Print document
Body: Would be nice to have a Print feature. Unless I'm mistaken, there is no such menu option or plugin.
Label: enhancement

Title: Add option to disable "open devtools on error"
Body:
Hi, I understand the need to open the devtools on errors, Atom is constantly being fixed and improved, and I agree that it should be the default behavior.

But for users like me who are trying to give this awesome editor a chance, when working on a project (not working on Atom itself), the behavior of the devtools to pop on every single error is very annoying. I am aware that packages might have problems and they need to be fixed (or disabled to stop the errors), but since I'm working on a project I don't have the time to do this. If things get critical I might debug and start disabling and debugging every single package installed, but if you keep popping that screen on my face every single time I'm gonna ditch Atom for a long time.

So, after my whining, I propose this:
At least there should be an option to disable it, probably accompanied by a warning like "procceed at your own risk, if Atom starts to misbehave, follow the debugging procedure described here >link<".

PS: I searched through the issues and didn't find a similar request, only bugs that referenced this behavior. So, in case this is a duplicate, sorry.
Label: enhancement

Title: install shell command menu item
Body: I've installed apm etc but still have the menu option to install shell command item showing up, with no visual cue that I have indeed installed these. Might be a nice idea to grey these options out.
Label: enhancement

On Ubuntu, most apps respect the "menu and title bar" scaling in the system preferences, but Atom appears to ignore it.

Title: Horizontal scrollbar styling loss on refresh
Body:
I am seeing a OS-styled scrollbar upon doing a refresh (`ctrl-alt-r`) in Atom but only if the scrollbar is visible during the refresh. I most often get this while doing split pane coding. I would assume it would keep the styling of the theme. Swtiching themes reapplies the theme and is a temporary fix for the issue.

OS: Ubuntu 14.04
Atom: 0.126.0-f6545d4
Label: bug

Title: Mouse click unable to move cursor after certain events
Body:
I've had a strange issue lately, and finally managed to reproduce it reliably. I noticed that at times I was unable to move my cursor around text with a single-click, requiring a dragging motion to actually move the cursor.

System is Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64, with atom version 0.126.0-f357f69, although this issue started a couple weeks ago.

The way I found to reproduce it, is starting Atom, click around on some text. Expected behavior here, cursor jumps around where you clicked.
Now after opening another pane (like a markdown preview in this case), clicking around on text will do nothing, requiring a click+drag to move the cursor, as little as possible, so you don't end up selecting text instead. Closing the pane doesn't return it to normal behavior.

I'd include a screenshot, but it would be superfluous as it's barely something you can "see", and it'll look like I am just clicking when click-dragging.
I've seen similar issues that might be related, but aren't exactly this behavior. Please let me know if this issue is more related to atom-shell instead.

EDIT: More information.
I use "alt+space" to open the command palette. I am having the odd feeling this is related to the alt key still being considered down after the pane creation. If I open the markdown preview via menu, it will not happen.
alt+tab-switching out of the window will at times cause this as well.
Label: bug

Title: Add chorded keyboard shortcuts to OS X menu
Body:
It took me a while to realize there were shortcuts for operating on panes because there are no keyboard shortcuts listed in the OS X menu:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4427/4207503/2c822b06-3857-11e4-85e3-6821ec6afca7.png)

Because a lot of other menu items have keyboard shortcuts, I assumed that the items without shortcuts in the menu had no shortcuts by default.

Is there some API limitation that prevents chorded shortcuts from appearing in the menu bar?
Label: bug

Title: Cursor doesn't move on right mouse down
Body:
The cursor doesn't move, so the context for the context menu isn't updated or so to speak, which is a problem when pasting or [correcting spelling](https://github.com/atom/spell-check/issues/32).

Fixing this breaks ([at least](http://xkcd.com/1172/#You-should-have-known-I-was-linking-you-here)) the workflow of right-clicking outside of the selection to perform actions on it.
Label: enhancement

Title: Cursor positioning on certain Unicode characters
Body: As a Haskell programmer, I like the ability to use Unicode character in names. However, I've noticed that the character "?" with the default font causes Atom to place the cursor too far to the right, creating a gap.

Title: Selection merging doesn't behave as expected sometimes
Body:
It seems that selection merging gives different results based on how a selection was made exactly. Here are two scenarios which give different results, even though the selections involved are the same.

First, I double click to select a word, then cmd-click-draw to create another selection and merge it with the first one:

![1se](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/4178878/2c66b85a-36ac-11e4-95b4-d9fce85dc50b.gif)

Notice that the selection which survives the merging is the one I created first.

Second, I click-draw to select a word, then cmd-click-draw to create another selection and merge it with the first one:

![2se](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/4178879/35ebcf5a-36ac-11e4-8455-a981baa99f57.gif)

Notice that the selection which survives the merging is the one I created second.

In the first case, I expected that the selection which I was currently dragging would survive the merging (as in the second case).

cc @benogle and @nathansobo (who was recently looking at how merging works)
Label: bug

Title: Spell check does not work if word is not selected.
Body:
Spell check only works if the cursor is over the incorrectly spelled word.

STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
1. Type something where a word is misspelled.
2. Have the cursor on a different word.
3. Right click the incorrectly spelled word, and click "Correct Spelling"

No menu will popup with correct spelling suggestions.
Label: bug

Title: Cursor's event 'moved' not triggered properly.
Body:
This issue can be reproduced as follows:

This code will move the cursor `right`, when it's `moved`

``` coffeescript
editor.cursors[0].on 'moved', =>
  editor.moveCursorRight()
```

If you manually move the cursor `right`, the event will be triggered properly and the cursor will just go all the way to the end of the buffer. It's all good.

if you manually move the cursor `left`,  the event will be triggered properly, the cursor will be moved back to where you started.

```
1. initial cursor position

   *
   ^

2. manually move left

   *
  ^ 

3. 'moved' triggered, cursor move right

   *
   ^
```

But then, when you manually move the cursor `left` **again**, the event `moved` is not triggered at all. 

```
4. manually move `left` again

   * 
  ^

```

I think it has something to do with the state of the cursor position, it is not modified properly when `moveCursorRight` is called, so when we move the cursor `left` manually again, the editor will think that the cursor wasn't moved at all.

I'm on Darwin and I'm using `0.124.0`, thanks!
Label: bug

Title: Tweak to linux Edit menu, preferences entries
Body:
This is a low-priority feature request.

![snapshot12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/4160398/d3ea1ed6-34b9-11e4-936b-2208fa2ed984.png)

This is how the Edit menu looks in Linux currently. It's perfectly serviceable, although the recent move of the Preferences entry in there looks a bit out of place. I suggest moving it and the config-file entries to the bottom, with a separator between it and the reflow, bookmark, goto and grammar entries, so it looks a bit more organized.
Label: bug

Title: "Show Line Numbers" option removes the gutter when turned off
Body:
Which is very rarely what the user wants. The gutter is a location that shows much other useful information, disabling it necessarily disables all that other functionality. The Show Line Numbers option should just hide the line numbers and _not_ remove the gutter completely.

See Discuss topics:
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/use-the-gutter-without-enabling-linenumbers/2461
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/hide-line-numbers/11987/2
Label: enhancement

Title: Horizontal scrolling bug with soft wrap of many spaces
Body:
When the soft wrap setting is turned on, horizontal scrolling should not happen. In special case of having abundant spaces, we can horizontally scroll it even though there is no character is shown.
- Atom version: 0.124.0
- OSX 10.9.4 and 10.10 (preview 2)
- Can reproduce it in the safe mode
- Using a monospace font. Tested in Menlo and Monaco.

Reproducing steps. Pleaser refer (http://pastie.org/9522131)
- Create a new file.
- In one line: put one word followed by about 80 space, and put another word in the end.
- Turn on soft wrap and try various window sizes.
- You can do horizontally scrolling; it shouldn't be.
Label: bug

Title: After moving Tab: scrolling issue (auto scrolls to top)
Body:
When moving a pane item to a new tab the scrolling becomes near impossible as it auto scrolls to the top. I have to close the tab and reopen it stop the issue.

I do get the warning: `EditorScrollView scrolled when it shouldn't have.` in `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/editor-component.js:943` however, this doesn't get logged when it auto scrolls to the top. 

I'm not sure if this issue is also related to the atom/tabs so I have opened an issue there to ([atom/tab#80](https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/80))

Title: Documentation / guides we should write
Body:
This is another stab at https://github.com/atom/api/pull/6, but in more concrete terms of guides / docs I think we should write to place on atom.io.

Many of the APIs these rely on are very in flux at the moment, though, so we'll probably need to write them near or after the API freeze. 
## Bit of background: links to problems / talk about package writing
- http://gnuu.org/2014/03/10/my-week-with-githubs-atom-editor/
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-speed-up-your-packages/10903
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/looking-for-best-practices-for-iterative-development-on-atom/10889
## Guides We Should Write
### Events

Events seem to be the number one issue folks have with the API. There is confusion around
- Which classes produce which events?
- What is the difference between events and commands?
- What is a subscription object? 
- Subscribe? on? which one? Where am I? It's dark in here!

This guide (and new APIs!) should address these things.
### Serialization
- WTF is it?
- How does it work?
- How to use it?
### Inter-package communication

(API needs to be written!)
- How to use
- Best practices
### Testing your package
- Setting it up
- Best practices
### Grammar scopes

Creating a language package? A syntax theme? It's impossible to know what scopes to generate / select for in common cases. What are the scopes for a function? Punctuation? Class names? I have no idea. Currently, the only way to know what to do is to look through several other lang packages and themes to get an idea of the scopes involved.
### Decorations

Currently the best docs are the example package and the blog post.
## List of cookbooks / recipes

Cookbooks / Recipes (have not decided on naming) are small snippets that solve a specific problem. Often package authors (and me!) want to know "how do I do That Common Thing that I saw in package Y". They can also be an entry point into a related guide. 

This list should be exhaustive. If you have ideas, let me know and I will add them.
- Observing all the editors
- Observing the active editor / pane item
- Adding a pane item in a tab (like settings view)
- Adding a panel (like find and replace)
- Subscribing to a command
- Highlighting a line / gutter-number (decoration)
- Adding something to the status bar
- How to get user input (like jump to line)
- How to display a filterable list in a dialog (like command palette)
## Changes we should make to existing guides
### In [Creating a package](https://atom.io/docs/latest/creating-a-package)
- This could provide more of an overview and be the entry point / index into other guides (like the one on events or serialization).
- Section about activation events
## Less concrete ideas for guides

Here are some ideas from https://github.com/atom/api/pull/6 and from the summit that are less fleshed out. 
- Making your package fast: common pitfalls
- Debugging your package
- Package manager guide
- Theme manager
- Syntax/Grammar
- Editor
- Workspace/Panes
- apm
- ~/.atom
- cross-platform
- dependency management in packages (where do I get the things I need?)
## Updates

Writing these is getting closer, so I will be updating the body of this issue as comments roll in and we think of things.
Label: enhancement

OS: 10.9.4

this window (untitled, 85983233) doesn't belong to any class, skip it.
Please report this bug to the application's devs.

Is there a way to have this fixed?

Title: Update to atom-shell@0.15 breaks atom for linux users
Body:
**Note**: This issue stems from a support issue: https://discuss.atom.io/t/cannot-run-atom-on-ubuntu-built-from-source/11611/10

On Ubuntu linux (it appears to only be some variants), the current master/HEAD of atom results in:
LaunchProcess: failed to execvp:
/proc/self/exe
[14050:0819/192435:ERROR:child_process_launcher.cc(329)] Failed to launch child process

When running `atom -f` on the command line. The atom editor itself never launches, but it appears to still be running in the background.

I've bisected this to the following revision:

```
3274ef9fb92766cfd998035b834ef5c562183315 is the first bad commit
commit 3274ef9fb92766cfd998035b834ef5c562183315
Author: Cheng Zhao <zcbenz@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Jul 29 14:27:32 2014 +0800

    Upgrade to atom-shell@0.15.0

:100644 100644 3edf94dc4fc5a21edc943d426d628e34d4a709c5 e4cd0d840374a0e7e46bc86858dc1a865996dbf5 M  package.json
```

This appears to only happen on some versions of ubuntu linux (mine is 12.10). I don't exactly know how to include an existing atom-shell into a build of atom, so I don't know how to bisect atom-shell for more information.
Label: bug

Title: Make application:about open internally
Body:
Similar to chrome, map the about menu internally instead of using the Mac OS X-only API that shows a simple dialog with only the version and app name.

Possible other content to put in this view:
- Packages bundled
- Packages installed

This would enable the about command to work on all platforms, refs https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2536

Other ideas welcome.
Label: enhancement

Title: Unable to use some git commands from atom or sub-packages.
Body:
git-pull, merge so far don't work from within packages in atom.

To fix this I did the following (OSX):
- cd /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/
- mv Atom Atom-bin
- vi Atom
- paste:

```
#!/bin/sh
${0}-bin
```
- save
- chmod +x Atom

When I start Atom it can now use git commands like no ones business but updating fails.

Here is the error I get when using git-pull:

```
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/libexec/git-core/git-pull: line 11: git-sh-setup: No such file or directory
```

I am using Yosemite at this point DP6. I had this issue on DP5 and PB1 as well.

Another way to fix it is to manually modify a few git-core files and hardcode a few file locations.

Please let me know if there's any more info I can provide. Thanks!
Label: bug

Title: Atom can lock files or folders under some circumstances
Body:
Instead of vaguely explaining, here are the steps for reproducing the bug:
1. If you have a Yeoman-created project folder i.e. `generator-webapp` created project, run `grunt serve`. It'll create a .tmp file, and I'll assume you haven't had one at first.
2. When everything goes well expand the folder .tmp in Atom so you can see the subfolders inside.
3. Stop the grunt process.
4. Run `grunt serve` again, and it will run `grunt-contrib-clean` to delete .tmp. 

It won't. .tmp will still exist as a "corrupted file" and you can't delete it by the Windows Explorer. Command line will show `Warning: Unable to create directory [path to .tmp folder]" (Error code: EPERM). Use --force to continue.` when trying to create a new .tmp folder.

Go to Atom and try to delete it, and the Dev Tools will show the same error: `Uncaught Error: EPERM, operation not permitted: [path to .tmp folder]`. All you need to do is close the folder again on the sidebar to remove the folder. I also tried the same method to Sublime Text, and it doesn't do the same, so I assume there's a clash between `grunt-contrib-clean` and Atom's way of handling files.

Atom is 0.123.0, and Windows is 8.1. Command line running Grunt is running as Administrator.
Label: bug

![](https://s.kpvp.in/gifs/WfVaC.gif)

([https://s.kpvp.in/gifs/WfVaC.gif](https://s.kpvp.in/gifs/WfVaC.gif))
Label: bug

Title: Title-bar drop-down menus sometimes don't drop-down
Body:
Atom 0.123.0 -- Ubuntu/Linux 14.04 (Unity) -- bug

Occasionally (and I cannot yet tell what triggers this), clicking on a main menu title (e.g., File, Eidt, View, ..., Help) fails to drop-down the corresponding menu.  Instead, the windows underlying title (temporarily replaced with the menu-list when the mouse-cursor hoovers over) is flash-revealed in response to the menu click... and this repeats for each subsequent click _on that first-chosen menu title._

If you move to select/click an adjacent menu title and click, then that menu drop-down is realized... e.g., start by clicking on View, it flashes the window title, click again, another flash... move mouse sideways to Edit and click there, get the Edit menu drop-down, then without selecting there, move/slide back over to View to see its drop-down, and make your original selection.

This is not easily repeatable, and I cannot yet discern any editing action which precipitates it.  But it does happen frequently enough, though seemingly randomly.  Once a menu selection is made (somewhere!), it all seems to work again... for a while.  Then another random glitch.

Anyone have any ideas about how to help isolate this bad behavior for a fix?
Label: bug

Title: set width of a individual character
Body:
I'm making a plugin to vertically align operators in the view of the code. These alignments will not actually be saved to the disk - they're purely stylistic alignments in the editor. In order to do this, I need to change the width of the space character in front of each `=`, depending upon the position of the `=` in the surrounding lines. However, I'm not sure how to set the width of a specific character.

It looks like I can change the width of a type of character for a given scope using `displayBuffer.setScopedCharWidth`, but I don't think that the scope includes the line/column number or anything I could use to select a specific char. Also, the docs for the displayBuffer are pretty sparse, so I might be misinterpreting what this does.

Anyway, how should I go about changing the width of an individual character?
Label: enhancement

Title: Add note for publishing UI themes (mine got published in "packages")
Body:
Hey, 

yesterday I published my first UI theme and followed all the steps in [Creating an Interface Theme](https://atom.io/docs/v0.123.0/creating-a-theme). That means I forked **atom-dark-ui** and when I tried [publishing](https://atom.io/docs/v0.123.0/publishing-a-package) my theme finally it was listed as package because some weird things happened during older commits of the forked repo. 

I would like to help others and add a note that if they have the same problems and their theme appears as package they should create a new repo and everything will work fine then. 

I hope this is the right place for telling you guys that or is there a way to contribute to the documentation directly? I found something but had no idea if it would have worked.
Label: bug

Title: Add TUI
Body: Atom is great, and there is no doubt. It already has a good gui, if you could add a ncurses/termbox tui to it, it would be a lot better and more useful. I think this could be done by using lime's backend/frontend model, it would also help performance.
Label: enhancement

The cursor position in input fields is miscalculated when the editor font is not the same as the `input` element font.  This screenshot is with an editor font of Source Code Pro and input font of Lucida Grande, provided by the [Unity UI](https://github.com/orderedlist/unity-ui) theme.

![cmd-t-cursor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122102/3985882/2b9ff90a-2896-11e4-926f-ddc15bbb60c0.png)

The stock Atom Light theme works fine because the fonts are the same in both the editor and input fields.

Body:
I keep attempting to split my view while the directory tree has focus, rather than a pane, which leads to nothing happening.

It might be intentional, but I find it frustrating when split fails when there is only one pane in the editor.
Label: bug

Title: Snapped Atom window does not resize properly after being displayed on an external monitor that is disconnected, OSX
Body:
I use an external monitor with my MacbookPro (OSX 10.9.4 Mavericks). I use this monitor as an extension of my desktop on the laptop. During the day I make Atom fill the entire screen (I snap the window, a feature I have enabled using BetterTouchTool). When I disconnect the external monitor and attempt to use Atom on the laptop's screen it is too large, as if extending off the screen. To find it again I have to click into Atom, go to the top bar, Window -> Zoom. Once I do this it properly fills (again, not fullscreen) the laptop's screen.

At first you might dismiss this as saying the 3rd party app (BetterTouchTool) is responsible. However, Atom is the only application that this happens to. I also keep Chrome and Outlook in the same - window filled via snap mode on the fullscreen. Both of these apps will extend too far, but the height will be correct and I can again "grab" the window by the window title bar.

Thus I am led to believe there is something going on with the window settings for Atom, but I don't know enough about this topic to dig any farther. I was able to replicate the issue on a co-workers Mac, but we have similar environments so I can't promise that this isn't being caused by something else.

The issue: Atom window title bar cannot be found after external disconnect
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 04 31 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975693/82d7a7fe-280f-11e4-88f4-56ab7dc24f42.png)
How to fix: Window -> Zoom
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 05 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975697/b2b3abee-280f-11e4-8409-790c8c747d17.png)
Fixed: Atom window title bar now properly showing
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 05 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975700/b2b6f89e-280f-11e4-947b-228bc1d4a489.png)
What should happen: Chrome after external disconnect (all other apps on external look like this also)
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 07 28 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975701/b2b8a996-280f-11e4-9b4c-9652ef0f71f2.png)
Resizing Chrome: easy because the title bar is showing - I just snap it to the top and it fills the screen
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 07 35 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975699/b2b63382-280f-11e4-8f42-ef7873ca07d8.png)
Chrome properly resized
![screen shot 2014-08-19 at 7 07 37 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1287375/3975698/b2b61b18-280f-11e4-9ee9-432331c0ca35.png)
Label: bug

Title: scrollToBufferPosition is pretty much useless
Body:
`scrollToBufferPosition` scrolls to anywhere it wants as long as the position specified is somewhere in the visible window.  It should scroll such that the position appears as the first line visible.  This killed a package I was working on.  

Even more importantly it makes any kind of synchronized scrolling impossible, which is a feature many users want and I was going to implement.

EDIT: It appears that the `center` option can be used to solve this problem.
Label: bug

Title: Selected text is deselected when opening the contextual menu with CTRL-Click
Body:
This issue was original opened as #2350 fixed with [pull request #2626](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/2626) but that solution only fixed the issue if the contextual menu was opened using a mouse button other than mouse button one (e.g., opening it with mouse button 2). On OS X, contextual menus can also be opened by CTRL-Clicking, when the contextual menu is opened this way the selection is still lost.

Gif from #2350 illustrating the issue
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/3053202/81614dea-e1a5-11e3-9baf-2c6caf2403a3.gif)
Label: bug

Title: "Window" menu is pointless
Body: Leave window management to the window manager. Move "Bring all windows to front" to the file menu or remove it altogether as it's a very niche command.
Label: bug

Title: keybindings with multiple combined keys doesn't work since v0.121.0
Body:
I have this on Ubuntu 14.04.

When I use the following default keybindings `'.workspace .editor':  'ctrl-k ctrl-u': 'editor:upper-case'` and `'.workspace .editor':  'ctrl-k ctrl-l': 'editor:lower-case'`, the second ctrl gets registered as a first key press. I have this with all bindings that have multiple ctrl's.

This is a recording of Keybinding resolver with `atom --safe` taken from ebbea64b3de1c41336b386d76a7f0dad70a7af88.

![ebbea64b3de1c41336b386d76a7f0dad70a7af88](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4266355/3941644/b6f8320c-2539-11e4-91bc-4b603507f0b8.gif)

![b3c241757801cf7a90d9e119f42e7a8ac498db10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4266355/3941646/cd092880-2539-11e4-95e1-54f7e82a12d3.gif)

Title: error msg: EditorScrollView scrolled when it shouldn't have
Body:
Sometimes when I tell the editorView to scroll the log shows `EditorScrollView scrolled when it shouldn't have`. This has happened on older versions and 0.123.0.

It doesn't do any harm but it is a bug since I'm using a legitimate method of EditorView. The log is being cluttered up and I can't use the error indicator because it always has errors. 

This is my only code related to scrolling. I don't see anything wrong. I'd try to isolate the problem but that would be quite hard.

```
setViewPos = (pos, view) ->
  if pos and view
    [topLine, cursPos] = pos
    view.scrollToBufferPosition [topLine+2, 0]
    view.getEditor().setCursorBufferPosition cursPos
# called by
      setViewPos pos, atom.workspaceView.getActiveView()
```

and

```
@buffer.setText @curText
@editorView.scrollToBufferPosition [lineNum+2, 0]
lineOfs = @buffer.characterIndexForPosition [lineNum, 0]
cursPos = @buffer.positionForCharacterIndex lineOfs + charOfs
@editor.setCursorBufferPosition cursPos
atom.workspaceView.focus()
@statusView?.setMsg @getState()
```

windows 8.0 with atom 120
Label: bug

Title: Apple’s Text to Speech stopped working in a recent update
Body:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/apples-text-to-speech-stopped-working-in-a-recent-update/11518

I am visually impaired and I use OS X's feature "Speak selected text when the key is pressed" located in the Dictation & Speech preference pane. I just noticed that this feature no longer works in Atom as of one of the last two versions. It now only reads the window's title bar no matter what text I have selected. It was working just fine before. It also works just fine under Chrome itself.

I'm not sure what caused this to break, but I depend on this feature all the time and can't really do without it. Does anyone have any ideas as to why?

I'm currently on v0.122 and I know it was working on v0.120 or v0.119. I'm also pretty sure I had enabled the React Editor before I noticed this being a problem, so I don't think that caused it.
Label: bug

Title: Spawned processes with BufferedProcess don't get killed
Body:
Running Atom 120. 
Windows 8.1 (64bit).
Node.js v0.10.30

I am using the grunt-runner plugin to run grunt within atom. With my own fix to actually let the plugin work (issue https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3200 fix: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/3208), I can see in the task manager that a separate node process is being started for the grunt task I am executing. However, stoppping the grunt task, which on this line of code https://github.com/nickclaw/atom-grunt-runner/blob/master/lib/grunt-runner-view.coffee#L71 happens, doesn't kill the node process (that call to kill() is simply the kill call in BufferedProcess, so it's not a plugin issue).

![gif](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/37237580/Various-Pictures/not_killed_node_process.gif)
Label: bug

This would make it much easier to open and edit system environment variables from within Atom. Please add this feature.

best,

—  faddah wolf
     portland, oregon, u.s.a.
     github.com/faddah

Title: BufferedProcess adds too many quotes for command arguments
Body:
Took me a while to actually understand what's wrong with @nickclaw's grunt-runner. The BufferedProcess is constructing the command like this:

(this is inside a modified Atom editor to see how the arguments are constructed)
![insane](http://puu.sh/aIXJa/438e34e0ac.png)

As you can see, it puts double quotes on the arguments and therefore the command/process will fail on Windows to execute.

If you would execute that command constructed like BufferedProcess does, you get an exception:
![nabanab](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/78361533f9f340bd5436f2efa56e0bb1dd2decad/687474703a2f2f7075752e73682f6149577a302f613331653866346361372e706e67)

Running the command with right put quotes of course works:
![bsdf](http://puu.sh/aIXTz/c175323420.png)

Changing:

```
   cmdArgs.unshift("\"" + command + "\"");
   cmdArgs = ['/s', '/c', "\"" + (cmdArgs.join(' ')) + "\""];
```

To:

```
  cmdArgs.unshift("\"" + command + "");
  cmdArgs = ['/s', '/c', "" + (cmdArgs.join(' ')) + "\""];
```

Would fix the issue.
Lines: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/buffered-process.coffee#L58

https://github.com/nickclaw/atom-grunt-runner/issues/18
Label: bug

Title: Missing menu bar on KDE if using icon-tasks plasmoid
Body:
Related to issue #3114 

Using KDE 4.13.2, on Ubuntu 14.04 64 bit.
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807925/7f4b555a-1c6f-11e4-824b-3c878f3343f4.png)
Tagged version 1.120.0 displays menus properly using the exact same setup:
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807924/7bea8dc2-1c6f-11e4-96eb-452017505684.png)

After commit 4a7e98e398422a5783d26d7a8944ec6e405bce53 , menus won't show in KDE4 if using the "Icons-only task manager" plasmoid.
This task manager identifies itself as an Unity component (as seen in here http://projects.kde.org/projects/kde/kdeplasma-addons/repository/revisions/master/entry/applets/icontasks/unity.cpp) for compatibility purposes, such as displaying quicklists and counters. It doesn't however, interact with appmenus in any way. And it doesn't seem to request them either. (unity.cpp lines 34 to 36).
My KDE desktop is configured to show all menus inside applications, so there's no global menubar active. So, despite the menus being exported, they are never displayed anywhere. It appears to be mistakenly confusing the plasmoid's presence (in DBUS perhaps?) as a global menu.

Disabling Unity support in the plasmoid does allow Atom to show menus normally, as illustrated here.
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807946/f3796b74-1c6f-11e4-9f55-3a8d531ba564.png)

Any way to attempt to prevent Atom from exporting its menus (blacklisting in Unity's dconf, environment variables, etc) doesn't seem to prevent the disabling of the normal menu.

Please let me know if any other information is required.
Label: bug

Title: App name in windows
Body:
There are a number of places in windows where apps are listed. For some bizarre reason Atom is listed as "The Hackable Editor" instead of "Atom". You have to go down to the T part of the list. For a long time I thought Atom wasn't available in app lists. I know of no other app that doesn't use its name for this. It's a nuisance.

![hackable](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/811455/3803928/2ce6bfe2-1c20-11e4-95d2-8cd9fb1155ed.jpg)

Title: Add an option to disable "quick jump" between indents
Body:
In Atom, it's not possible to begin or end a selection at the midpoint of an indent, because the caret can't be jumped there. But as a text editor, I think it should be able to do anything a normal text editor can do, regardless of whether it's meaningful or not.

My suggestion: leave the default "as is", but add an option to disable the "quick jump".
Label: enhancement

Title: Load default theme when running in Safe Mode
Body:
This is what I see when I launch in safe mode ...

![screen shot 2014-08-03 at 7 42 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/3792706/02301e28-1b81-11e4-8469-17983f7eb281.png)

Because I use custom themes that are in the `~/.atom/packages` directory, all style information is lost when I launch in Safe Mode ... meaning I need to change my configuration when I need to use Safe Mode and then change it back when I'm done.

It would be much nicer if Atom would do this for me :grinning:
Label: bug

Title: Make `editor:checkout-head-revision` redoable
Body:
Related to #3168 

Given that the standard keyboard mapping on all platforms is a variation on Undo, this command should affect the Undo stack as an Undo command _not_ like a regular command. To illustrate:
1. Executing the command  should revert the contents of the file to the last committed contents in Git
2. Executing Undo again should do nothing
3. Executing Redo should reset the contents of the file to where it was before the `editor:checkout-head-revision` command was executed
Label: bug

Title: Default keyboard mapping for Checkout Head Revision problematic
Body:
The default keyboard mapping for `editor:checkout-head-revision` is <kbd>Cmd+Alt+Z</kbd> or <kbd>Ctrl+Alt+Z</kbd> on Windows/Linux. This is pretty easy to fat-finger and there is no confirmation dialog. Also, the Redo command doesn't restore what was lost ... but Undo does ... which is confusing when this command is accidentally triggered.

We should probably display a confirmation dialog for this command to be certain it is what the user wants and since data loss (or perceived data loss) can result.

See Discuss topics: 
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/sometimes-s-or-z-does-buu-buu/11186?u=leedohm
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/a-seriously-nasty-problem/11286
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/undo-redo-broken/10658
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/undo-defect-undo-make-my-file-back-to-status-when-i-open-it/10512
Label: bug

Title: Broken links in API Docs
Body:
Clicking a "Source" link in the [API](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.120.0/api/) leads to a 404.  Biscotto generates links like:

```
https://github.com/atom/atom//blob/v0.120.0/src/task.coffee#L48
```

When it should be

```
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v0.120.0/src/task.coffee#L48
```

The repo name has an extra slash at the end.  I don't think it is a bug in biscotto, rather a bug in building the api docs, so I added it here.
Label: bug

Title: Make indent guides indicate changing indentation earlier
Body:
The current indent-guides _lazily_ indicate when the indentation level changes. By "lazy", I mean that the indentation guides keep showing up until a line appears with different content. Example of lazy indentation guides:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4427/3789451/b265f116-1aa3-11e4-91eb-123e73337590.png)

Contrast this to _eager_ indentation guides, which disappear as soon as they can:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4427/3789447/a5430e06-1aa3-11e4-8665-55b190872467.png)

Lazy indentation guides work well in curly-brace languages because there is content on the line to indicate when a block finishes. However, in CoffeeScript and Python, they don't work well because there is no closing brace, and we end up with confusing guides that don't seem to match up with blocks.

This issue is asking that Atom indentation guides are changed from lazy to eager. Another way of describing it is to change the indentation guides so that they end where the closing brace would be in a curly-brace language.
Label: bug

Title: Atom erasing the content of files when there is not enough disk space
Body:
I have a hard time replicating this issue since it will require me filling up the disk again, but in a nutshell the problem is that when I edit a file in Atom, if the disk space is not enough to save it, I find that the file content is erased. 

This happened to me more than once (yeah I need more Gbs of disk space) so I can certify that it is Atom the one causing the issue. The issue appears whenever I edit the file, not when I just open it. The problem is not that Atom is not being able to save the file (that would make sense if there is no disk space available), the problem is that Atom _removes all the content_, and of course I'm afterwards not able to recover it.

I have no clue of why may this be happening
Label: bug

Title: Sort Packages menu by name?
Body:
Is it possible to sort the items inside the packages menu by name?

In my case it looks like this:

Packages
- Beautify
- Project manager
- Term 2
- Bracket Matcher
- Command Palette

....
(the rest is in order)

When you right click a file in windows explorer and select "Open with Atom" if the file was previously opened it will open it a second time.

Title: Broken link in docs
Body:
Please visit https://atom.io/docs/v0.120.0/advanced/view-system and click on "v0.120.0 Home". I won't load due to the missing `/` at the end.

```
$ curl -v https://atom.io/docs/v0.120.0
...
< Location: https://atom.io/docs/v0.120.0
...
```
Label: bug

Title: Window state not being saved during refresh
Body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Start Atom
2. Open a new tab
3. Press the View > Reload menu
4. Tab is not reopened after the window is reloaded

If you do this a second time with a different tab it appears to work which seems strange.

@zcbenz did anything change in atom-shell regarding the `beforeunload`/`unload` handlers on the window?
Label: bug

Title: Atom Helper processes building up
Body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Launch Atom from the command line
2. 3 `Atom Helper` processes are shown in the Activity Monitor while the window is opened
3. Close the window (but don't quit Atom)
4. 2 `Atom Helper` processes are shown in the Activity Monitor
5. Launch Atom from the command line
6. 4 `Atom Helper` processes are shown in the Activity Monitor while the window is opened
7. Close the window (but don't quit Atom)
8.  3 `Atom Helper` processes are shown in the Activity Monitor

This total number keeps going up as windows are opened and then closed.

/cc @zcbenz
Label: bug

Title: Add context menu to checkout HEAD revision
Body:
Currently it is only doable via a keystroke (cmd-alt-Z), would be good to add a menu on the editor, tree view, tabs, etc.
- [ ] editor context menu
- [ ] tree view context menu
- [ ] tabs context menu
Label: enhancement

Title: Auto-Indent not working when element name includes a dash/hyphen
Body: AutoIndent is not working for elements that include a dash/hyphen in the element name (e.g. <tab-heading>some text</tab-heading>
Label: bug

Title: Move Line Down/Up Bugs
Body:
move-line-down (and up) seem to be pretty buggy (and slow).  I will try to summarize the different issues I've come across (some are enhancements depending on your perspective):
- move-line-down with cursor in column 0.  Then press undo.  The cursor will start going down below the buffer and exceptions will start being thrown from tokenized-buffer.
- Select entire penultimate line, won't allow you to move it down (whether or not there is a trailing newline at EOF).
- Moving folds will cause it to unfold (and generally cause lots of problems).  The fold markers can be corrupted if you try to undo.
- Moving lines past a fold can cause it to unfold and have issues.
- Slow with large number of lines (issue #3128).
- Only supports 1 cursor (issue #2470).

I attempted to rewrite the moveLineDown function, and solved most of these issues except for the undo problems (which became much worse due to my approach).  Generally, undo gets very confused if you have `selection.setBufferRange` or `editor.createFold` in conjunction with insert/delete.  The only reason I can see that rebuilding the selection or the folds is necessary is because there is no way to insert text just before the cursor without it becoming part of the selection or fold.

If someone can point me towards a way to insert just before a selection or fold without the text becoming part of that selection or fold, then I can simplify the code and not run into any undo problems.  Alternatively, perhaps it is a bug that undo can cause problems, but that may be more difficult for me to know how to fix properly.

I can provide more details or test code if desired.

I tossed my initial prototype up here: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/aaaa9ec5bb642dab8d26

atom 0.121
Label: bug

Title: Cursor not visible while typing
Body: Sometimes the cursor will disappear while typing or selecting text, and it will show again if I click a few times.
Label: bug

Title: Package generator doesn't create grammars folder
Body:
The current version of Atom.io 0.120.0 doesn't create the `grammars` folder when "Package Generator -> Generate Atom Package" is used.
I just created a new package layout and it's not present. See below image:

![screen shot 2014-07-30 at 20 30 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7456624/3754047/a6a20ccc-1817-11e4-9c31-4f34575b40cc.png)

Title: Leaking TextBuffers after using Atom for a while
Body: Here is a [heap snapshot](https://www.dropbox.com/s/vsa35jzsn42gr5e/Heap-20140729T232903.heapsnapshot) I saved with 96 text buffers in it before I restarted.
Label: bug

Title: Cursor::moveLeft & Cursor::moveRight should take column variable
Body: I think that you should be able to move the cursor left or right a certain amount of columns.  Right now, the functions only can move right or left 1 column.  Which made me confused at first, until I looked them up.  A work around is to wrap the functions in a loop.
Label: enhancement

Title: Integrate Atom API lookup
Body:
This is to track the [idea](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3122) to allow package developers to conveniently access Atom API documentation for classes, methods etc, directly from the source code.

This might be done via a second pane for each call, showing the docs HTML page for the selected method/class etc.
Or maybe via an inline tool-tip kind of implementation, similar to popular IDEs.
Label: enhancement

Title: Feature Request: add setup panel for proxy settings
Body:
User should have a settings panel in Atom Settings for proxy.

PS: 
i know can can add manually a proxy here:

 `~/.atom/.apmrc` 
(Windows: `Atom\resources\app\apm\node_modules\atom-package-manager\.apmrc`)

but for newbe users of atom it would be better to have a settings panel
Label: enhancement

Title: Cannot open a file through Webdav on Windows
Body:
Hello,

I'm working with some webdav file repository (actually a SharePoint server).

I'm trying to open a file from this repository with Atom (Windows 8.1 X64), but this does not works. Atom opens, but the editor is empty.

For example, if I try to open `http://myserver/Style%20Library/XSL%20Style%20Sheets/rss.xsl` it fails.

Using Fiddler, I can trace these http paquets:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/184604/3733446/0fb204ee-1708-11e4-983d-f48d7a02269a.png)

(the process is svchost because of Windows "WebClient" service to wrap WebDav access).

I guess the 404 errors may be ignored, as it's only a _try to find a file_ request.

Title: File rename issue
Body:
With Atom 0.120.0, on OSX (with case insensitive filesystem).

What I did:
First i left-click the file "test.php" in the Atom editor tree view to open it.
Next I right-click the same file and select "Rename".

What happens:
When i rename "test.php" to "Test.php", the opened file tab label does not update, and still says "test.php".
If I now click this file (to open it, it was already open in a tab) - i end up with two tabs, one "test.php", one "Test.php". Due to the case insensitivity of the file system I use, they happen to point to the same file.

What I expected to happen:
The opened file tab label to change to "Test.php" when i renamed the file.
Label: bug

Title: Close all tabs but not the window
Body:
Atom seem to copy this very annoying behaviour from recent builds of Sublime Text 3 where it was in fact fixed in the latest build.

I propose `Cmd+Shift+W` to close all tabs but not the window. It is really annoying to close all tabs one by one before starting a new feature.

And even then `Cmd+Shift+W` in fact just closes window so when you reopen the project – all tabs stay and you have to close them one by one anyway.

Suggestion:

`Cmd+W` - Close tab
`Cmd+Shift+W` - Close all tabs but not the window
`Cmd+W` - Close window if there are no tabs left
Label: enhancement

Title: Using 'sudo atom' can cause application errors due to root permissions on new compile-cache files
Body:
Just a moment ago I stumbled upon a similar issue to #3056. As a background: I do like atom so much, that I started it to use it as a drop-in replacement for gedit. Even to edit system configuration files. In this scenario it's quite common to invoke editors via sudo.

Atom will start in a broken state if you it was previously launched i.e with something like `sudo atom /etc/hosts`,  because in this case `$HOME` still points the original user directory, though the process is started under root privileges. This seems to be [a distribution specific default behavior of sudo](https://security.stackexchange.com/a/18399). 

As result **any file created** in this Atom session will become unwriteable for the original user and will lead to application errors inside Atom: 

```
[30615:0724/202223:INFO:CONSOLE(29)] "Error: EACCES, permission denied '/home/ben/.atom/compile-cache/less/62b7a669af25a948e0632eac5cb2bf860f9c0e6e/imports.json'
```

To be honest: You are able run into similar issues on other programs too, but most of them tend not to create new files unless triggered. I'm not aware which actions trigger Atom to create new files under `$HOME` _after the initial first launch_ for a user.
### Steps to reproduce
1. Start `atom` and exit
2. `rm -r ~/.atom/compile-cache/less` to provoke Atom creating new files
3. `sudo atom` and exit
4. `atom`

This will be the case on all plattforms, where sudo keeps the original $HOME setting which can be tested i.e. by calling `sudo sh -c 'echo $HOME'`
Label: bug

Title: GrammarRegistry should have a reload method
Body:
I want to work on grammar but I find it's painfull to reload the whole thing via `Window: Reload`. So I decided to work on a plugin to have a faster developpement cycle.

I'm extending https://github.com/coryroloff/atom-live-editor-reload (https://github.com/MasseGuillaume/atom-live-grammar-reload)

I have something like this now

```
toRemove = atom.syntax.grammars
  .filter (g) -> return g.packageName == projectPkg.name
  .forEach (g) -> atom.syntax.removeGrammar(g)

delete atom.packages.loadedPackages[projectPkg.name] # force reload
updatedPackage = atom.packages.loadPackage(projectPkg.name)
updatedPackage.loadGrammarsSync()
updatedPackage.grammars.forEach (g) ->
    atom.syntax.addGrammar g

atom.workspaceView.eachEditorView (editorView) ->
  if editorView.getEditor().getGrammar().packageName == projectPkg.name
    editorView.getEditor().reloadGrammar()
```
Label: enhancement

Title: Open folder on linux is broken
Body:
**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Select File -> Open Folder.
2. Navigate to folder where you want to open (E.g. Double click on 'File System', then 'tmp', then 'blah'. Blah will be opened in the file chooser window.
3. Click 'Ok'.

**Expected Results:**
:white_check_mark:  Atom opens folder /tmp/blah for editing.

**Actual Results:**
:x: Atom opens user's home folder (in my case, /home/sjohnson).

In order to actually open the folder I want, I would have to navigate to /tmp and then select (but not double-click) blah. I think that, if nothing is selected in the current folder in the navigation window, it should use the current folder instead of the user's home folder.

Title: Atom does not start after running once as root due permission of /tmp/atom-nohup.out
Body:
## Problem

Atom does no longer start after it has been run by root or probably any other user with a restrictive umask. This is because the `atom.sh` script pipes out the output to the same shared file  `/tmp/atom-nohup.out`
## Steps to reproduce

Run

```
 $ sudo su - root -c atom
 $ atom
 /usr/bin/atom: Zeile 84: /tmp/atom-nohup.out: Keine Berechtigung
```

The second call fails because nohup cannot write/access the file. This might work if root has a very permissive umask.
## Solution

Probably atom should create and use tmp-Dirs per user, which is common style in Debian or at least allow global writing on the lofgile (hacky version).
Label: bug

Title: Make invisibles tab character span multiple spaces
Body:
In other editors I'm used to have a wide character (em dash) representing a tab and while Atom has something like that, it doesn't work quite how I'd expect it to work.

Currently, if you set an em dash in "Invisibles Tab" field and "Tab width" to 4 spaces, the em dash would be painted with the width of a single character. Here is a screenshot showing this:

![alt text](https://virtual-host-discourse.global.ssl.fastly.net/uploads/github_atom/23682/5e3564883ffa487d.png)

Note that the em dash should have the width of 4 spaces.

Brackets fixed this in a really cool way, VIM has it also. This way, IMHO, should be how this should work:

The "Invisibles Tab" setting should have 2 fields. The first field is for the character that should be used to fill the space of the tab. And the second field is for the character that should finish the drawing (if any).

Practical examples of this setting:

Example A
First character: -
Second character: >
Result for 4 spaces: --->

Example B
First character: -
Second character: -
Result for 4 spaces: ----

Regards
Label: enhancement
