Title: Request: Treat .Rmd files like .md files
Body:
First, Thanks for Atom!

It would be wonderful if `.Rmd` files, which can be processed by `R` (`knitr`) into .md files for reproducible research, would be recognized and handled like other `.md` files.  In particular, toggling `html` like comments on and off with the usual mechanism would be very helpful.
Label: enhancement

Title: Tab Length Detection
Body:
Default setting for tab length is 2 spaces.
- When I open a file that uses 3 spaces for indentation, and press `Tab`, I expect editor to insert 3 spaces (currently 2)
- When I open a file that uses 4 spaces for indentation, and press `Tab`, I expect editor to insert 4 spaces (currently 2)

There already were discussions to allow custom settings [per language](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1723) or [per project](http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Knapsack_problem/Bounded#JavaScript), although **this issue is do detect indentation automatically on file open**, because there can be different guidelines for same language files on same project. It is also handy when editing unrelated files.

Default 'tab width' setting is to be still used when creating new files and for `\t` display width.

---

Here is a screenshot from proprietary Sublime Text (some of these features are for [atom/whitespace](https://github.com/atom/whitespace), but I think initial detection should be handled in core.

![tab_size](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7157049/3666025/3ab2ba06-11ec-11e4-81c3-d125259a0eef.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Horizontal scrollbar is over the gutter
Body:
![img](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/997659/3604984/2d58618c-0d26-11e4-93fa-9fcd912f00a6.png)

See #1711
Label: bug

Title: If else statements do not correctly auto-indent in JavaScript
Label: bug

Title: Drag tabs between windows results in untitled tab.
Body:
So, in my attempt to work around the current fact that opening a file opens a new window, I figure I could drag that file from the new window into the original window that I had open.  Turns out that doesn't work.  I get a new tab in the old window that is empty and untitled.  The original tab in the "new" window disappears.

I was using atom 2f82fb2ceb5501f2df7e839af467fbfd4bec47ad, on ubuntu 14.04 32-bit.
Label: bug

Title: Linux unable to edit commit message from atom
Body:
Ubuntu 14.04 x64
Atom 0.116.0-4960a63

[Forum Post](http://discuss.atom.io/t/linux-edit-commit-message-automatically-aborts/11004)

I have tried setting atom as my git editor with

```
 git config --global core.editor atom
 git config --global core.editor atom -w
 git config --global core.editor atom --wait
```

and whenever I go to commit atom will open but git automatically cancels via `Aborting commit due to empty commit message.`

![atomgiteditor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5893112/3651703/67f0c136-112c-11e4-82c9-85dfe0eae101.png)
Label: bug

Title: Clicking file quickly opens the file twice
Body:
If you click the same entry in the tree view a second time before the first one opens, it will open two editors for that file.

Noticed this while testing a slow network drive on Windows but it isn't Windows specific since it can happen whenever loading a file is slow.
Label: bug

Title: Insert @-Symbol in editor version0.115.0 / Windows 7
Body: When i open a file with atom editor and try to insert the "@" symbol the editor does a horizontal text alignment instead of inserting the "@" symbol
Label: bug

Title: Collapsing code causes issues with right-arrow navigation
Body:
Windows 8.0, Atom v0.115.0, occurs in safe mode

To replicate: open a file (confirmed in php and js files), collapse a relatively good sized code block and move cursor below the collapsed block; now attempt to use the right arrow to navigate to the end of various longer lines of code/text.

The cursor stops in seemingly arbitrary places, and not in the same column of each line. Some lines might not allow right arrow navigation at all, some might do it all the way to the default 80 char line guide, generally somewhere in between though.

Not seeing any errors in dev tools console.

[See here for video.](http://discuss.atom.io/t/collapsing-code-causes-issues-with-right-arrow-navigation/10932/3?u=rosseyn)
Label: bug

Title: Cursor disappears after changing keyboard layout using a custom shortcut.
Body:
This happens on Ubuntu 14.04. I have set the shortcut for changing the keyboard layout to `ctrl+shift+space`. When pressing these buttons the cursor disappears. It can be restored by clicking on the editor. Also, when using this shortcut, some accents (in French) don't work until the file is saved once. 

This is most likely related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2122. However I find it interesting that in this case the `alt` key is not used to cause this issue. It seems that Atom doesn't play well with certain Unity keyboard shortcuts.

Build number is 2bd8015a9d69bbc4dd4b7c8f32848073b458a182. I am also using the React editor.
Label: bug

Title: Overtype mode isn't working
Body:
After pressing `Insert` key, editor should engage overtype mode, in which the cursor, when typing, overwrites any text that is present in the current location.

![out2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7157049/3642782/b7a43272-10c7-11e4-8472-fe555df4f1e5.gif)
Label: enhancement

Title: Path environment variable is not inherited
Body: Hello! When I export PATH variable in my bash shell, Atom does not see it (it uses the default env for new shell). This causes for example the script package not to see my custom commands exported to the path.
Label: bug

Title: Chromium's font rendering color inaccurate
Body:
Font rendering in Chromium has a problem: the color is inaccurate. While it's not serious for a web browser, it's serious for a code editor. I was so frustrated when writing a syntax theme. Can GitHub do something to tweak Chromium's font color to what it should be?

To show everybody the problem, I made a comparison between 3 browsers. First, take a look at 13px font in Chrome (same effect as Atom). Left is black, right is rgb(0,128,0) green:
![chrome-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636927/84ec4c5e-0fe9-11e4-9030-3946b770c852.png)

It's a little darker. What's the correct color? Let's take a look at Firefox and Safari's:

Firefox:
![firefox-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636952/16ee5862-0feb-11e4-924a-531b0da204ab.png)

Safari:
![safari-008000-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636953/21753de6-0feb-11e4-94e8-95ea1506f344.png)

Chromium has a -webkit-font-smoothing css property, set to "subpixel-antialiased" by default. If changed to "antialiased", it becomes too bright:
![chrome-008000-13-antialiased](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3636964/4ad44d5c-0fec-11e4-879b-04560558416e.png)

My conclusion is: whatever smoothing strategy I choose, it's inaccurate. Either too dark or too bright. It will become more serious if the font is even smaller.

Let's look at an extreme case (8px using default smoothing. not practical, just to show the problem):
![chrome-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637003/1c362b0c-0fef-11e4-8820-5680288feb41.png)
In Chrome it became completely black.

Firefox:
![firefox-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637018/de517a02-0fef-11e4-9a9d-42d65e6a1976.png)

Safari:
![safari-008000-8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/731796/3637019/e6e1e012-0fef-11e4-8ea0-df4ac245ec95.png)

Before my test, I thought it's a Webkit problem, but now I tend to think it's a Chromium problem, because Safari is OK.

Update:
Seems it's caused by anti-aliasing. If you set `-webkit-font-smoothing` to `none`, then the color is correct, but the font looks ugly. Maybe Webkit has some internal parameters that control the anti-aliasing, but Chromium did not tune it to its best? That's why Safari's font color is OK? I don't know.

Update:
If React editor is enabled (default in v0.117), then it will be too bright rather than too dark.
Label: bug

Title: RPM Spec file
Body:
I've got a spec for atom rpm packages written up which seem to be working fairly well. Would this be useful as the basis for an official fedora/rhel/centos package?

The spec/patch can be found [here](https://github.com/TsukasaUjiie/benjamin-rpmbuild) along with a current [srpm](https://github.com/TsukasaUjiie/benjamin-rpmbuild/releases/download/atom-0.115.0/atom-0.115.0-0.fc20.src.rpm). I'm happy to provide a current RPM if required.
Label: enhancement

Title: BSOD on Windows with NFS share
Body:
This occurs intermittently (but regularly) when browsing an NFS shared directory through tree view. It has also happened when closing tabs  with files opened from the NFS share.

Atom version is 0.115.0.

The opened directory contains several gigabytes of code, but it also seems to happen on opened subdirectories that are much smaller.

The files are perl, though that probably does not matter.

![bsod](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/869495/3627732/a6eb791e-0e8c-11e4-8e74-c391b34e26f8.jpg)

Additional information provided on Windows startup after the crash:

```
Problem signature:
  Problem Event Name:   BlueScreen
  OS Version:   6.1.7601.2.1.0.256.4
  Locale ID:    1033

Additional information about the problem:
  BCCode:   27
  BCP1: 00000000BAAD0073
  BCP2: FFFFF8800F14A7C8
  BCP3: FFFFF8800F14A020
  BCP4: FFFFF8800C06BDA0
  OS Version:   6_1_7601
  Service Pack: 1_0
  Product:  256_1
```
Label: bug

Title: Atom crashes when opening files
Body:
I've got an issue with Atom on OSX. Every time I attempt to open a file, a gray window appears and behind it a dialogue that reads "The editor has crashed Please report this issue to atom@github.com" appears behind it. (The file never opens).

This issue started when I attempted to open a file that did not appear immediately. I thought perhaps the window had opened underneath the current window that I was looking at, so I entered OSX's "Mission Control." While I was in Mission Control, the new Atom window appeared as a gray window over Mission Control. I exited Mission Control and the Atom window remained gray. I was unable to close that window and the editor was unresponsive so I force quit it. After that, all subsequent attempts to open any file in atom resulted in the gray window problem.

Starting Atom in safe mode seems to solve the problem, but I have no external packages installed, so it must be one of the packages that ships with Atom that is causing the problem.

The crash produces the following two messages in Console.app:

```
WindowServer[90]: _CGXGetWindowOrderingGroup: Invalid window 0xffffffff
```

Title: delete a html file with no response [windows version]
Body: i  delete a html file ,but there is no response   and the file is still exist,then repeat the operation ,it remind me if move the file to trash,but  there is no response when i do it
Label: bug

Title: Cmd + Shift + D should duplicate currently selected word
Body:
Cmd + Shift + D should duplicate not only current line, but current selection if available.

Sublime Text allows it !! :hushed:
Label: enhancement

Title: Invisible newline shown when no newline is present
Body:
Very small issue. When invisible characters are turned on, the newline character is shown on lines that don't actually have a newline character. Occurs in default + react editors.

To reproduce: turn on invisible characters, create a new file. The newline is shown even though the file is empty.
Label: bug

Title: cmd-< keybinding overwrites OS X shortcut to focus next window
Label: bug

Title: Atom v0.117.0 on Windows 7, black screen
Body:
I just installed Atom v0.115.0 on windows 7 x64 using chocolatey. Installation seemed to work fine, but When I launch the app ( with or without elevation ) I can see the menu bar but the editor area is black and just remains black. I tried `New File`, `New Window`, `Reload` but nothing seems to have any effect.

EDIT:
Updated to v0.117, same results

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1042463/3610190/8fa31cf4-0d87-11e4-8f70-ad80547af158.png)
Label: bug

Title: Rightclick in the treeview doesn't focus the selected item directly
Body:
I was not sure if this belongs to treeview, or to the atom context menu, so i decided to open it directly here.

If i press rightclick on a treeview, the item behind my mouse won't be selected. If i click it again, it gets the selected item. So im not sure which one is selected currently and i always have to do left-click and then a right click.

![rightclick in treeview](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5446019/3599270/eae7ef68-0cec-11e4-8138-02e78b9d8367.gif)

Atom Version: 0.115.0
Label: bug

Title: Windows behaviour Ctrl+Shift+Home and Ctrl+Shift+End
Body:
On windows I expect that pressing Ctrl+Shift+Home or Ctrl+Shift+End selects all text from the current marker position to the start or beginning of the file.

This same behaviour exists in all windows native text editors from MS Word to notepad and Sublime Text.
Label: bug

Title: 'ctrl-shift-z': 'core:redo'
Body: `Ctrl+Shift+Z` should be mapped to redo by default on Windows. It works in Sublime Text, Notepad++, Notepad, Chrome, _Atom's keybindings search field_... You get the idea.
Label: enhancement

Title: Dragging shortcuts to folders
Body: Currently, dragging a shortcut to a folder in Atom (on Windows) opens the `.lnk` file itself rather than the target of the shortcut; the latter behavior would make more sense. I keep a bunch of shortcuts to project folders on my Desktop and it would be nice to be able to drag the shortcuts directly into Atom and have the project itself be opened (rather than the `.lnk`)
Label: bug

Title: Text moves half a pixel when using multiple apps in fullscreen
Body:
With a two-screen setup on OSX, where Atom in fullscreen is displayed on the first screen, and several other fullscreen applications are displayed on the second, toggling between desktops on the second screen (command + arrow left/right) causes all the text in atom to move half a pixel down or so, making the text become blurred and hard to read.

This error consistently happens, but only if the fullscreen Atom-window is currently up on one of my screens. Whatever instance of Atom that is in fullscreen, but not visible at the time does not appear to display this bug.

Toggling both safe mode and the react editor does nothing to stop this form happening.

The only way I can reset my editor is by exiting fullscreen.
Label: bug

Title: Editor shakes when I have two panes and tree view open.
Body:
![This happens](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1277553/3584335/5bc6d1bc-0c17-11e4-9276-8afef246a999.gif), when I have 2 panes and tree view open. does not happen on other panes. Just on this one.
Running OS X yosemite, Retina MBP 15 inch.

```
atom --version
0.110.0
```
Label: bug

Title: Make numeric keypad mimic regular keypad
Body:
I'm used to working with the numeric keypad instead of the 'regular' one. In all the editors I've used, the two have acted the same. 

In Atom, numeric keypad keys are recognized as separate keys and thus require their own keybinds. If one wants to use the numeric keypad, one needs to tediously add custom keybinds for everything from up and down to ctrl-home and shift-del. 

Is there a way to make the numeric keypad keys be recognized as their non-numeric counterparts, or, alternatively, introduce custom key-remapping?
Label: enhancement

Title: Packages menu in windows doesn't show F3 in command
Body:
When creating a new package it shows up fine in the package menu with one exception.  The key binding is ctrl-F3 but it the command is missing the F3.  It only shows "Ctrl+".

Here is my key binding  ...

```
'.workspace':
  'ctrl-F3': 'find-selection:find-next'
```

... and the menu code ...

```
'menu': [
  {
    'label': 'Packages'
    'submenu': [
      'label': 'Find Selection'
      'submenu': [
        { 'label': 'Find Next', 'command': 'find-selection:find-next' }
      ]
    ]
  }
]
```

This is with atom 0.115.0 and windows 8.0 installed with chocolatey.
Label: bug

Title: Atom crashes immediately after opening on Windows 7 x64
Body:
Hi,

I installed Atom via Chocolatey (and also tried the ZIP file), but I cannot use it. The installation runs fine, but whenever I run the executable, I get a popup window with a _"The editor has crashed"_ error message, which includes 3 buttons: Close Window, Reload and Keep It Open:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/724969/3572974/377779e2-0b6d-11e4-9b80-146a35193ddc.png)

Quickly searching through the code repo, I found out that this error message is generated by the handler of the `@browserWindow.webContents.on 'crashed'` event (in `/src/browser/atom-window.coffee`), but I don't know what could be causing the browserWindow to crash, since my teammates' computers are identical to mine, and they can all run it just fine.

I've just updated to version 0.115.0, but the error persists.

Thanks,
Luciano.
Label: bug

Title: Autosave duplicates file when renaming file in tree-view
Body:
when i use rename command at tree view, it will make a new file with new name.

but i want change the old file's name.
Label: bug

Title: [OS X] Atom shell command should not show a (temporary) second dock icon when Atom is already open
Body:
Having _Atom_ running, when you open additional files (or try to open a file that you have already open) from the _Terminal_, _OS X's Dock_ will show a temporary second _Atom_ icon (and then it goes away). This should not be the case.

See how _TextMate_ 1.5.x doesn't do this when you use the _mate_ shell command. Same for opening _Sublime Text_ running _subl_ from the terminal.
Label: bug

Title: Installing packages fail
Body:
When I try to install a package form gui or command line I got an error 

PS C:\Users\grmsevf8> apm install atom-beautify
Installing atom-beautify to C:\Users\grmsevf8.atom\packages

PS C:\Users\grmsevf8>

Title: Item(s) missing from keybindings list in Settings view
Body:
v115 on Win8

Not sure about other platforms, but on WIndows we have at least two confirmed cases where searching for the keybinding for the Settings View does not show it in the list:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7287076/3568418/457223fe-0b30-11e4-9eff-502cb865d8f7.png)

Described in [this topic](http://discuss.atom.io/t/key-binding-to-bring-up-setting/10748/7) on discuss.

The key binding still works (if not previously overwritten), i.e. `Ctrl-,` opens the Settings view:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7287076/3568430/771b9f34-0b30-11e4-89f4-34086e35fe8a.png)

I do not know if there are any other items missing from the list, might just be the only one.
Label: bug

Title: Add --reset option for wiping ~/.atom/storage
Body:
Occasionally we get instances where someone's editor has some wedged serialized state that is preventing them from opening Atom properly. When this happens, they need to be instructed on how to find `~/.atom/storage` (or the platform-specific equivalent) and to delete or move it. It would be very helpful to have an `atom --reset` command, like the `atom --safe` command that would either:
1. Delete `~/.atom/storage` prior to loading the rest of Atom
2. Package up `~/.atom/storage` and send it off to GitHub before deleting it (with the user's permission)
Label: enhancement

Title: Add Linux software repositories for app update support
Body:
launchpad.net
would you please release atom for ubuntu , as a launchpad ppa repository?
Label: enhancement

Title: Clicking toolbar menus doesn't work until after I open them through keyboard
Body:
I'm on Ubuntu 13.10. The toolbar menu is attached to the top of the screen rather than the window as is usual. However, clicking on the buttons in the toolbar doesn't work. The button in the toolbar stands out as it should when it's clicked, but no menu appears below. If I press alt and the first letter of the menu entry (like alt+v for the view menu), then the menu opens, but attached to the window instead of the toolbar, and without the dark-gray toolbar styling. Then after that, I can open that menu by clicking it through the toolbar normally. Though other menus and submenus are still broken until I open them through the keyboard.

Here's a series of four screenshots: https://imgur.com/Ud5hFbv,LJpcCdQ,rWAcCKK,FAOI2q8#0
Label: bug

Title: Cannot select folded block of code
Body: Folded block of code can't be selected (in order to delete, copy or move folded) as in ST. It unfolds when clicked.
Label: bug

Title: Changed File Close Dialogue not usable with keyboard
Body:
(this is possibly windows only, tested with 0.113.0)

**Steps To Reproduce**
- Open Atom
- Type something into a new editor or change an existing file (doesn't matter which)
- Attempt to close the tab (for example `Ctrl+W`)
- Correctly, a dialogue opens, that will give you a choice how to proceed

![close-dialog-keyboard-lacking](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/124909/3550749/38cadc72-08dd-11e4-8d71-83e665a150cd.png)

**current (faulty) behaviour**

The Keyboard is pretty much useless for this dialogue. You can only Hit `[Enter]` to save.

**Desired Behaviour**

These interactions all don't work, but would be very much needed, all of these are very much standard behaviour for any application:
- [X] `[left]` and `[right]` should switch focus between buttos (so we can select a different thing with keyboard only)
- [X] `[esc]` should Cancel
- [ ] `[alt]` should bring up shortcut labels (much like it does for the application menu, i.e. _F_ile, which means press `[Alt+F]`)
- [X] `[tab]` should cycle between the buttons, `[shift-tab]` should cycle backwards.
Label: enhancement

Title: Enabling the 'Use React Editor' option causes ligatures not to render with Hasklig font
Body:
I have my `styles.less` set up so that it renders the [Hasklig font](https://github.com/i-tu/Hasklig)'s ligatures:

``` css
.editor {
    text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;
}
```

This is with the 'Use React Editor' option unchecked in the settings:

![Without React](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/695077/3526878/c7be5f58-077f-11e4-8939-62988188cffa.png)

When I enable the React option and close/reopen the file the ligatures no longer render:

![With React](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/695077/3526903/046d0396-0780-11e4-974e-93822e35e9e9.png)

This only occurs when opening old files. A new React editor will render the ligatures fine as you type.

Interestingly the `::` operator alone renders ok in all instances when in React mode.
Label: bug

Title: window:save-all touches all the opened files
Body: Due to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1690 now when you call `window:save-all`, all the files opened by the editor get touched. That is definitely not a good idea, since it can trigger file watcher for files that didn't change, and it can cause performance problems when you have a lot of files open and you are working on a slow disk, or with third party programs that monitor your filesystem (Dropbox, anyone?)
Label: enhancement

Title: Register split or close action
Body:
It is currently possible to register an opener for a URI but nothing is available for split or close actions. This would be useful if you want to prevent splitting for specific panes or change the behaviour when it is split. 

**Use case**
A user just reported [a bug for my Ask Stack package](https://github.com/Chris911/Ask-Stack-Atom/issues/8) where nothing is rendered when you split an answers view and it is not possible to close that pane afterwards. By design, there should always only be 1 answer view so I would like to prevent splitting that pane or at least have a little bit of control when if it happens.
Label: enhancement

Title: displayBuffers not destroyed properly
Body:
1. open a file (let's call it id `1`)
2. open another file (lets give this one id `2`)
3. split the file with `cmd-shift-|` (this one can be id `3`)
4. close the file just split in the first split (editor with id `2`)
5. try to paste or add new lines to the end of the file

You will get one of two errors:

![screen shot 2014-07-08 at 3 52 06 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/3518205/19961d68-06fc-11e4-9249-b5cce01a6e15.png)

Or the same error originating from `git-diff`. 

@nathansobo and I stepped through this, and the error happens in the displayBuffer assigned to the file that was closed (id `2` in the above example). The `displayBuffer` and it's markers are not being destroyed properly when closed.
Label: bug

Title: Linux: Messed up chmod/chown for apm
Body:
Most recently `sudo script/grunt install` fails to set the correct rights for apm. `atom` itself works. After a fresh build it always looks the same for me:

``` sh
$ sudo script/grunt install
Running "install" task
Done, without errors.

# squirtle @ ~/github/atom on git:ms-fixChmodAPM x [17:14:14]
$ which apm
/usr/local/bin//apm

# squirtle @ ~/github/atom on git:ms-fixChmodAPM x [17:14:16]
$ apm
/bin/bash: /usr/local/bin//apm: Permission denied
```

chmod itself seems to be okay:

``` sh
$ ll
total 35120
drwxr-xr-x   2 squirtle root        4096 Jul  4 17:14 ./
drwxr-xr-x  11 squirtle root        4096 Jun 27 12:52 ../
lrwxrwxrwx   1 root     root          53 Jul  4 17:14 apm -> ../share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/.bin/apm*
-rwxrwxr-x   1 squirtle root        2397 Jul  4 17:14 atom*
-rwx--x--x   1 squirtle squirtle    1748 Jun  6 19:54 byz*
```

`chowning` the `/usr/local/bin/apm` itself isn't enough:

``` sh
# squirtle @ /usr/local/bin [17:24:32]
$ sudo chown $USER apm 

# squirtle @ /usr/local/bin [17:25:19]
$ apm

fs.js:427
  return binding.open(pathModule._makeLong(path), stringToFlags(flags), mode);
                 ^
Error: EACCES, permission denied '/usr/local/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/lib/cli.js'
    at Object.fs.openSync (fs.js:427:18)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (fs.js:284:15)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:473:44)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:497:10)
    at startup (node.js:119:16)
    at node.js:902:3
```

One possible solution is to `chown -R $USER /usr/local/share/atom` after installing (my build script does this now) but I don't know if that's really what you want?
Label: bug

Title: Concept of multiple projects alive (but not active)
Body:
``` coffee
# Empty workspace
atom.projects.push {"name": "x", "path": "...."}
atom.projects.activate "x"

# project "x" is now active in the tree view 
# and its "state" (open documents, etc.) is being stored

atom.projects.push {"name": "y", "path": "...."}
atom.projects.activate "y"

# project "y" is now active in the tree view but the 
# state of "x" was not lost

atom.projects.activate "x"

# switch back to project "x" exactly as you've left it
```

Something like that (of course the API could be something else). This would allow for something like https://atom.io/packages/project-manager to be able to switch projects seamlessly in the same window.

If we can agree on the API I'll take a crack at implementing (unless someone already has this under way and I didn't notice the issue).
Label: enhancement

Title: Add support for inline editors.
Body:
Brackets (based on CodeMirror) provide an interface for inline editors so the plugins can provide specialized editors for colors and such or even to provide a way to edit another file without opening it.

Currently Atom plugins need to either open a popup (e.g. different color pickers) or use a panel (e.g. Regex railroad graph plugin).
Label: enhancement

Title: Embed git and detect system git without PATH
Body:
As of now, installing atom on windows involves cloning the repo and building it from source. This assumes you already have git because the build system uses git to download other parts of the program.

As atom gets an official windows build, however, git may or may not be installed on users machines. A user may also choose between github's Git for Desktop or msysgit. There should be 4 operating modes for atom based on these cases.
1. Integrate with github's Git for Desktop.
2. Detect the user's msysgit installation WITHOUT using the PATH environment variable. First check the default installation location, and if it's not there, prompt the user to supply a path where it's installed. Call the binaries directly from that path.
3. Operate with an embedded version of git. This can be accomplished in the same way atlassian's SourceTree works: Download a portable release of msysgit, and use the binaries from that.
4. Operate without git integration and not complain.

The user should have the option to choose any of the 4 modes in the the settings dialog, and by default, atom should attempt to use them in that order.

This suggestion is mostly based on the windows version of atom, but could apply equally across all platforms with minor modifications. Remove the github desktop option, substitute msysgit for git, etc.
Label: enhancement

Title: When building atom, the install directory should be configurable or installation should be optional
Body:
The default behaviour when building atom using `script/build` for platforms [other than Linux](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/8a377c9339d58ee3bdc42f7a38964362d2b4cdbd/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L228), is to [install to a pre-configured folder](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/8a377c9339d58ee3bdc42f7a38964362d2b4cdbd/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L45-L52).

It would be useful to be able to either configure the installation directory with an argument to `script/build` (eg: `script/build --install-path /some/path`) or alternatively, to either remove the install option from default build tasks or accept a command line argument that prevents installation (eg: `script/build --no-install`).

I think an even better option is for `script/build` to stick to just _build_ and another script (like `script/install`) could be responsible for installation.

See also: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2688
Label: enhancement

Title: Weird cursor position
Body:
Since i'm working with Atom the cursor, sometimes, has a strange position. Mostly after autocompleting a function. I wanted to submit this issue for a long time but I can't reproduce the bug when I want to.

I disabled the autocomplete and autocomplete plus packages for a while and it didn't solved the problem either. I finally got a really bad screen capture .. and i'm still trying to figure out how to reproduce this bug. Take a look at the cursor position when typing.

![5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/823283/3443327/359dea76-0121-11e4-8d5c-0297ba112375.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Add quick skip next for multi select
Body:
When you're using the keyboard to do multi-select SublimeText (cmd-d on mac), you can skip the next occurrence of the selection with a hotkey combo (cmd-k, cmd-d on mac).  I find this immensely useful and would love if it was incorporated into atom.

I think done properly, this would be paired with a visual indication of where the next occurrence of the selection is (like the little outline around tokens you get when doing a text find (cmd-f) in atom), as is done in SublimeText.

More info on what's done in SublimeText here:

http://www.sublimetext.com/docs/3/multiple_selection_with_the_keyboard.html
Label: enhancement

Title: Find markers don't adjust with font-size
Body:
If I do a "find" in a file, it provides little marker squares throughout the file to identify the matches.

![screen shot 2014-06-30 at 12 52 17 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122591/3433408/4acdb716-007f-11e4-8305-2eadc34cf1af.png)

However, if I change the font size during a find, the squares no longer match.

![screen shot 2014-06-30 at 12 52 40 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122591/3433415/5e610832-007f-11e4-9dbe-e9d2e0ad2ae6.png)

OSX: 10.9.3
Atom: 0.106.0
Label: bug

Body:
Version 0.106.0

Language: C

How is it:

![how-it-is](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/75517/3433041/70d34e48-007b-11e4-85a4-20c6cd9d32d8.png)

How it should be:

![how-it-should-be](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/75517/3433044/7aa1d994-007b-11e4-81af-55a90e3e6898.png)
Label: bug

Title: Flickering when opening files
Body:
The Editor is flickering a little bit when i open a new file.

Demo:
![flickering](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5446019/3428676/36654c84-0044-11e4-88df-636196d3a539.gif)

The flicker starts at the position of the last tab, so if the tab-bar is full, it doesn't flickers anymore.

Version: Atom 0.106.0 OS X
Editor: React (I haven't tested it in the default Editor)

Seems that just a min-width or something simliar is missing.
Label: bug

Title: seti-monokai theme package needs to be removed from repository, not in creators repository any more
Body:
the Seti Monokai theme is no longer available in the repositories of its creator, @joaoafrmartins (https://github.com/joaoafrmartins). he's removed the repository. when you try and download it through the Settings pane in Atom, you naturally get the following error —

```
Installing “seti-monokai@0.0.0? failed. Less…
Unable to download https://www.atom.io/api/packages/seti-monokai/versions/0.0.0/tarball: 400 Bad Request Repository inaccessible
```

@joaoafrmartins provides no e-mail or method of contacting him on his github page. the Seti Monokai theme should be removed until such time as he reposts it and is more communicative.

best,

—  faddah wolf
     portland, oregon, u.s.a.
     github.com/faddah
Label: bug

Title: Multiline-mini-editor
Body:
It's possible to create a single-line mini-editor, but it is not yet possible to create a multi-line mini-editor.

Creating a full-fledged editor in small Atom packages is overkill, while the mini-editor is far too small.

Hereby I pledge to the Atom gods to give us a way to create a multi-line mini editor.
Label: enhancement

Title: Unix process substitution displays nothing
Body:
[Process substitution](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_substitution) is a feature common in Unix derivatives that allows one process' `stdout` to be fed into another process' `stdin` as a file descriptor. Here's the canonical `diff` example:

``` sh
$ diff -u <(echo 'Hello wrold') myfile.txt
--- /dev/fd/63  2014-06-28 23:41:39.000000000 -0700
+++ myfile.txt  2014-06-28 23:41:37.000000000 -0700
@@ -1 +1 @@
-Hello wrold
+Hello wrold!
```

(where the `echo 'Hello wrold'` can be any command, run within a subshell)

Thus, the following should work:

``` sh
$ atom <(echo 'Hello wrold!')
```

The expected result of this is that Atom should open a file descriptor containing "Hello wrold!" (which works in both `vim` and `nano`). While `/dev/fd/63` is successfully opened, the file is always blank (when run in `--safe` mode). No errors appear in the WebKit console.

I tested this on OS X 10.9.3, in Atom 0.106.0
Label: enhancement

Title: random scrolling when add-selection-above or add-selection-below
Body: There is a bug: it always scrolls the text view if I do add-selection-above or -below in the middle of a file that has more lines than my screen can show. It seems to scroll the cursor line to be approximately the first or last line in screen.
Label: bug

Title: shift-delete does not cut text to clipboard
Body:
In chromium and in almost every software I have encountered, shift-delete acts as ctrl-x -> it cuts selected text and places it into clipboard. I have used this key combination for great many years, in Dos, Windows and now in Ubuntu 14.04, so it being missing is single most missing feature in Atom for me. 

Can it be fixed? Or maybe there is a way for me to configure it somehow, if nobody else needs it?

thank you in advance!
Label: bug

Title: Handle line breaks for Chinese and Japanese properly in automatic wrapping
Body:
I've found two problems of Atom's soft wrapping:
1. Chinese and Japanese language does not use spaces to separate characters, it causes that Atom treats Chinese sentence as a extremely-long "word" and does not perform correct wrap. According to [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_breaking_rules_in_East_Asian_languages], a "CJK Word" is something like `(Opening punctuation)*(Han character | Kana)(Trailing punctuation|Traialing Kana)*`.
2. Atom cannot handle non-monospaced fonts correctly. Han characters and Kanas are much wider than Latin characters.
Label: bug

Title: Calling setText() on Editor while it is not attached has no effect
Body:
I'm currently working with a View that has a mini EditorView as a subview. I'm trying to change the text in the EditorView while it is not attached to the screen. I've been debugging this and it seems that when I call this function: `editorView.getEditor().setText("")` the `editor` member of the EditorView is actually updated and the text is changed to `""`. However the problem is that the EditorView itself is not updated and it still shows the cached text the next time the parent View is attached to the workspace. 

Let's consider this example where I subscribe to a config change event. I added some variables so it's easier to understand what is what. 

``` coffeescript
@subscribe atom.config.observe 'ask-stack.autoDetectLanguage', callNow: false, (autoDetect) =>
      view = this
      editorView = @tagsField
      editor = editorView.getEditor()
      @tagsField.getEditor().setText("") 
```

The `View` is **not attached (or visible) to the workspace when the event is triggered but has been created previously**. The next time the `View` is attached to the workspace I expect the `editorView` text to be blank. What really happens here is that the `editorView` is still showing the previous text (cached I assume). 

Just for the sake of giving more context here's what I get in the debugger:
![Debugger](http://i.imgur.com/m8D4V0y.png)

At this point the `editor` text is empty so this is what we should see when the `view` is attached to the workspace. But this is what I see: 
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/9ZXpODJ.png)

**Important**: When I focus in that mini EditorView the text goes away. I'm guessing this is because the editor is back to an active state and looks for the actual text and the cache is cleared. However I think the text field should be empty before having to focus. 

I also tried to call `redraw()` on the `editorView` after changing the text but **the editorView will completely disappear when calling `redraw()` while the view is not attached to the workspace**. That might be another bug. This is what happens if I call `editorView.redraw()` after setting the text (the 2nd EditorView or text field is gone):
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/jhIeEeU.png) 

A work around is to call `redraw()` right after the next time the `View` is appended to the workspace. However I think this should be done internally and not explicitly in the package code.
Label: bug

Title: process.cwd() behaviour

When I first open up Atom and try to use one of my custom snippets they don't seem to be loaded and the Language Rspec ones are used instead. If I then open up my snippets.cson file and hit cmd+s Atom picks them up and starts using my snippets.

Title: on packages' "activated" event getActivePackages() returns an empty list
Body:
This is pretty easy to test.  Create a package, remove the activation trigger from packages.json and fill activate method:

``` coffee
    activate: ->
        atom.packages.once "activated", =>
             console.log "activated", atom.packages.getActivePackages()
```

I expected this to print a list of all active packages.

I found out, that "activated" event is triggered right after all activations are promised.  At that time, the dictionary of
activated packages is still empty, they all drop in one by one, as soon the activate method returned.

Is this by design?  Then there should be another event, as soon all packages' activation methods returned. Maybe packages "ready" event?
Label: bug

2. Start to drag the tree resize border. Press and hold the mouse button.
3. Move the cursor over the developer tools window.

Title: Rename the editor.projectHome config option
Body:
We should rename this config option to something that describes it better. It is not easy to figure the intent via the name. Also, Atom has a class named `project` which adds to the confusion.

This option is currently describes:
1. Where projects and themes are created by Package Generator
2. Where projects are assumed to be stored by Atom. So if there was an "Open Project" command and I gave it "foo" it would look for a "foo" directory in this path.

@lee-dohm also suggested that `core` would be a more appropriate namespace than `editor.

/via https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1648
Label: enhancement

Not possible as far as I can tell:

Title: Hide .pyc and other common generated files by default?
Body:
Some programming languages leave binary compiled files to the source tree by default. `.pyc` files in Python being the most notably example.

Together with `tree-view` `hideIgnoredNames` being false by default this makes navigation in the source tree little bit cumbersome due to scrolling through unnecessary `.pyc` duplicates, as demonstrated in the screenshot below:

![screen shot 2014-06-18 at 12 27 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/49922/3311919/c71be7c0-f6ca-11e3-90b4-e39d89fcb45d.png)

What is Atom stance towards "sane defaults"? Could it be acceptable patch to have `.pyc` in the ignored files by default (thus giving better out of the box experience), or should things like that go to a separate package which all Python developers then install? (Though Python highlighter comes with the default installation.) I am not sure if I want to make a pull request on this, as I am not aware of the authors stance on the matter like this. 

For comparison, Sublime Text & co. seem to hide `.pyc` files by default.
Label: enhancement

Title: Events in different order
Body:

Also `editor:display-updated` seems to be firing 3 times more with the React editor vs. the old editor when soft wrapped lines are updated.

Title: Wrong markdown preview

The preview shown is not correct, see the headers:

![captura de pantalla de 2014-06-17 14 54 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6054951/3304246/84f880ec-f648-11e3-869a-e9285934bad4.png)

The line below the first level header is shown below the second level header instead.
Label: bug

Title: text-rendering: optimizeLegibility causes erratic caret behaviour
Body:
Hi all,

If I apply the ‘text-rendering: optimizeLegibility’ directive to the stylesheets on .editor or .workspace, any subsequent command palettes, text fields or tabs have a visually broken/erratic caret:
- In text fields, such as the command palette or settings view, the caret appears before the first character even though it's actually pointing to the end of the text;
- Moving the caret left and right in an editor tab sometimes causes it to jump several places left and right of where it should be, there doesn't seem to be any discernible pattern and reloading the tab causes different breakages to happen.

This issue only affects new tabs/palettes created after the stylesheet change occurs, it seems.  Similarly, removing the stylesheet change only takes effect for new tabs/palettes.

I'm running Atom HEAD on Gentoo Linux, 64-bit, not using the react editor.

Not sure which part of Atom this applies to, so I've filed it against atom/atom (sorry!)
Label: bug

Title: automatic reporting of config, active packages for bugs
Body:
I like helping to squash all those little :bug: but it's a little cumbersome to always gather all the config data and currently enabled packages to file a good bug report (especially since it's often unclear which package or combination thereof is at fault).

Any chance we can get a feature in atom to automatically save said info to the clipboard?
Label: enhancement

I also can't click there or select (my frantic mouse movements are indicating that I'm trying).

I'm running:

- Atom 0.103.0
- 2 Panes at the same time
- softwrap fixed at 80
- not sure which other package might be relevant.

This might be a duplicate/related to #1894 and also atom/markdown-preview#92

Title: Provide a simpler way to act on files by extension
Body:
A very common question in IRC is "How can I make files with some extension set a certain behavior / use a certain grammar". As far as I know the state of the art is to put something like this in `user.coffee`:

``` coffeescript
atom.workspaceView.eachEditorView (editorView) ->
  editor = editorView.getEditor()
  if path.extname(editor.getPath()) is '.md'
    editor.setSoftWrap(true)
```

Perhaps we could provide some syntactic sugar nicer than iterating over every EditorView, like say an object of path matchers and functions that get the current editor added to their context and run when initializing a new editor?

``` coffeescript
atom.fileActions = #terribly named
  '\.md$': -> currentEditor.setSoftWrap(true)
```

Along the same lines it might be worth encouraging configurable file types in packages like e.g. atom/language-c
Label: enhancement

Title: Select all + backspace doesn't always delete everything.
Body:
Selecting everything in a file and quickly pressing backspace doesn't delete everything as it's supposed to, but leaves the last line of the selection untouched. Here's a demo: 

![atom-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2262772/3260452/57b398e0-f24e-11e3-8d97-030857f51582.gif)

The first `cmd+a+backspace` is very quick, and the last line stays in the editor. The second one has a ~1 second pause between `cmd+a` and `backspace`, and everything gets deleted as expected. Everything works fine on the third time too, which is mildly surprising since the pause is quite brief. On the fourth time the bug resurfaces again and nothing gets deleted, since the only line in the selection is the last (and first) line.
Label: bug

Title: Delete file causes crash, erases project and rolls back to an earlier "cached" version
Body:
I don't have much in the way of debugging information.  

MacBook Air, Atom v0.99.0
- I right clicked on a file and selected "delete".  
- Window pops up asking if I want to delete or move to trash.  I select Delete
- Main editor window partially blanks out and a firebug window opens on the bottom third of the screen.  Firebug window is empty, scrolling in main window remains blank.
- I restart Atom, since this has happened before (seems like just a UI painting problem)
- Upon restarting, my entire project has been "reset" to an earlier version, perhaps several days ago.  I can only assume that Atom maintains a cache somewhere and upon crash decided to restore from this...instead of just leaving the files alone.
- Strangely, some newly created files (from tonight) remain 100% intact.  It's just the files that I've been editing for the last several days that were overwritten with a much earlier version.

I was just hacking around on my laptop and hadn't started a git repo yet, soo...Atom effectively nuked my project.  

Not really a big deal (other than being irritating) but this is certainly a frightening behavior.  Deleting or corrupting files is one thing, but completely overwriting an entire project wholesale is scary. :(
Label: bug

Title: Open files only when they exist
Body:
Hello,

I'm writing an extension and I need to open one of two files, depending on if the first one exists or not.

Currently I'm synchronously testing if the first exists, then testing if the second exists, and if one exists I'm opening with `workspaceView.open` (which is actually [`workspace.open`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/workspace.coffee#L81-L115). 

I image that  other developers might also enjoy this option. Any chance of having this implemented? I can write the patch myself if is interesting for you.

Title: Atom suddenly not launching anymore
Body:
Windows 8.1

So I built it just yesterday, and after initial hiccups it built successfully and launched fine. Ran it a few times, used it for a few code files to play around, and then also installed one or two packages (javascript-related code completion etc).

Now, out of nowhere, it won't launch an editor window anymore. It opens partially in the task bar:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7287076/3209965/6f2dc794-ee97-11e3-8ccb-098b5b5d2879.png)

But no actual window opens, no matter how often I click on the partial snippet in the task bar, or alt-tab to it.

And if I try to run it from command line, I get this error:

> [11128:0607/235050:ERROR:crash_reporter_win.cc(69)] Cannot initialize out-of-process crash handler"

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7287076/3209955/ea9c4780-ee96-11e3-842d-0c448624ce44.png)

I suppose I'll have to re-build it, which will probably fix this. I just wanted to log the issue.

Update: I have just rebuilt it from scratch. Still the same issue.
I suppose that points at something outside of Atom being wrong.
Label: bug

Title: Integrating Atom and Github for Windows
Body:
So I am in awe of the aesthetics of the Github client for Windows. It's minimalist, neat, clean, functional, just very pleasing all around.
And it successfully abstracts from the nitty bitty pieces of command-line git.

Atom seems to want to be the same thing for code editing, only allowing for all that extra customizability via packages and css styling etc...

Now that I have been trying both for the last few days, it seems to me a logical next step to open and edit files directly from the github client. I can imagine both: Atom being just another module or "page" inside the github client, or the github client gets removed and all its functionality integrated into the Atom tree view, via context menu entries or a second tree view pane with repositories etc...

Has any thought been given to this kind of thing?
I'd love to see that, and given Atom's extensibility, I'm sure a package is just around the corner.
Label: enhancement

Title: Support configurable, non-uniform, visually aligned tab stops
Body:
I would like to raise the issue of configurable tab stops.

A proposal has been floating around the web for a few years, called [Elastic tabstops](http://nickgravgaard.com/elastictabstops/), that promises to usher in the "next generation" of source code alignment.

It aims to make it easy to align code blocks and side comments, both for traditional coders using monospaced fonts, and for those of us who prefer proportional fonts.

It would also make it easy to edit tabular data, be it TSV (tab-separated values) or a table in Markdown or other markup languages.

I would gladly write an extension myself to realize elastic tabstops, but unfortunately it's one of those things that require a very specific feature in the editor component: **the ability to specify non-uniform tab stops, as a list of visual positions (eg. pixel or em, _not_ characters) that may be different for each line.**

Right now the tab support in Atom is just a trick (a span with a certain number of blank characters), it's not even a true tab stop, as is painfully evident when using a proportional font:

![screen shot 2014-06-06 at 15 38 14](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/48756/3200906/0830fd42-ed82-11e3-9b00-b39a15ac2fd9.png)

Seeing as work is currently underway to write the newer React-based editor component, I just wanted to throw this feature request out there to the clever people writing such code.

I'm fully aware that it is not a simple task, because it transcends the character-counting nature of the current code. Doing it without triggering a reflow for each tab stop (to query the current width of the line being composed) is even harder. It would require pre-caching the em-width of every character for the current font, or something along those lines.

But it's one of those features that would set Atom apart from any other editor.

Again, the tricky part is just the configurable tab stops. That would allow extension writers to align code, tables, and other data with various algorithms, including Elastic tabstops.
Label: enhancement

Title: Themes are updated approximately 300ms after window focus/unfocus
Body:
This bug really becomes apparent with you use themes like `unity-ui`.

The theme lags behind 300ms after you focus or unfocus the window, and in the case of unity, the active tab background is not updated in the same frame as the window titlebar, which results in a "flicker". This is very visually annoying.

There are bugs similar to this on Phonegap, but since no touch events are being issued, I'm not sure why it even exists...

Title: font-size weirdness / suggestion
Body:
This isn't necessarily broken, but just something odd I've run into. I teach a class, and use Atom for my editor to show examples of code. Since my code is being projected on a screen to a classroom, I have my font-size set crazy high. Like, ridiculously high. The issue is that when I create a new file or folder, the text inside that field is that same size in which no one is able to see what I'm typing.

Here is a screenshot of what that looks like. Maybe as a suggestion, that text field could remain a normal size?

![screen shot 2014-06-04 at 1 45 21 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2391/3179005/cf98c436-ec20-11e3-9193-469b210d39a7.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Log error when a command fails
Body:
## The problem

When brand-new, like me, the problem could be anywhere, so I'm clumsily looking at **everything** to try and figure out where the issue is. All I can see is that nothing happens. The specific issue was that I had the command correctly loaded into the `activationEvents` in the json file, and my "lib/my-project.coffee" worked correctly, but I didn't have the `main` set up to load the file (because I generated it with `$ apm init --convert` to load my TextMate plugin rather than with `generate:package`).

I assume what happens is that when I run the command, it goes to find the command, which should be there because it is added in the `activate` key. But it is not there since the file did not get loaded. Because it is not there, it silently fails and removes the commands from the list of commands.
## The desired behaviour

Ideally, the system would log enough information for me to figure out where the issue is.

Keep in mind that I'm very very new so I have very little ability to troubleshoot based on reasoning about the system. I'd like to know it's not in my keymap file, it's not in my package.json. Something like this would be helpful: "my-package:my-command was registered as an activationEvent, but could not be found as a command." maybe also a link to common reasons this could happen such as: the command was never, the name is wrong (describing a way to see the list of registered commands in the given namespace would help a lot here), the file was never required, the file wasn't specified in the main command of package.json.
## Another Possibility

I don't know if it's reasonable to have .coffee files in lib without having a main in package.json, but maybe a linting of package.json would catch this? Or maybe there's a combination of things: files in lib, no main, commands in activationList. If this is something that could be caught, it would also be nice if it would run automatically on saving of package.json
Label: enhancement

Title: Opening empty folder crashes
Body:
When attempting to open an empty folder in Atom, the editor turns grey and hangs indefinitely. The output looks something like:

```
[18805:0603/115749:INFO:CONSOLE(1)] "Uncaught ReferenceError: start is not defined", source: file:///<folder-path>/ (1)
[18805:0603/115749:INFO:CONSOLE(2)] "Uncaught ReferenceError: addRow is not defined", source: file:///<folder-path>/ (2)
```

I'm on Ubuntu and version 0.98.0-d1ed176.
Label: bug

Title: keybinding pane:show-item-# doesn't work in linux
Body:
Trying to bind pane switching by number doesn't work in linux, e.g.

```
'body':
  'alt-1': 'pane:show-item-1'
  'alt-2': 'pane:show-item-2'
```
Label: bug

Title: "TypeError: cannot call method 'executeJavaScript' of null"
Body:
I believe I got this error while trying to open a folder but I didn't notice it until I had closed a few windows. I'm running on Ubuntu.

![atomerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/226872/3163640/b5de8e20-eb41-11e3-931d-1abd58fcdcd4.png)
Label: bug

Title: Inside of an html tag opening and closing a script tag produces unwantde
Body:
When closing a script tag </script> the editor automatically adds another "script" to the end - before the closing caret.  Screenshot attached.

![screen shot 2014-06-03 at 11 06 35 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/486049/3161971/fc6033be-eb30-11e3-8b8c-56a4785169af.png)
Label: bug

Title: "Find in Project" action (Cmd+Shift+F) ignores currently selected text
Body: When I select a text and hit Cmd+F then currently selected text is already copied to "Find in current buffer" input field. However, the same is not happening with Cmd+Shift+F ("Find in Project"), forcing one to copy-paste a text there. This not only takes longer but also destroys a previous clipboard content.
Label: bug

Title: Toggle comment (cmd + /) doesn't work
Body: Atom v0.100.0 on Mac 10.9.3, toggling comments doesn't work when multiple lines are selected. There are no errors in the console.
Label: bug

Title: Can't open editors in dev mode
Body: Tabs show up empty and mini editors show up as 1px high.
Label: bug

Title: Closing spec windows quit Atom
Body:
On Windows 8.1
1. Open a package
2. Run the package specs from the View menu
3. Close the spec window

Atom quits at this point, I'd expect the spec window to close without quitting the app.
Label: bug

Title: "Reveal in Tree  View" does not work in "Project Find Results"
Body:
I have searched for a string in the project, which results in a list of results. Right-clicking a result gives option "Reveal in Tree View", which I assume should highlight the file it was found in the project tree view.

However it only moves the focus to the tree view. It does not matter if the tree is collapsed or not. Even if the file is visible, it does not get selected.

The same problem seems to affect "Reveal in Tree View" in the context-menu for the active tab.
Label: bug

Title: Unable to upgrade built-in packages
Body:
### System Configuration

**OS:** Windows 8.1 pro
**LANG:** Traditional Chinese
**node version:** node-v0.10.28-x86
**python version:** 2.7.6
**MSVC:** With both 2010 and 2013 pro version installed
**Atom version:** 0.100.0-00987f3
### Step to reproduce
1. open atom
2. File->Preference->Packages
### Actual Behavior

Available Updates shows "All of your installed packages are up to date!"
### Expect Behavior

Shouldn't the built-in packages be able to upgrade too?
Find And Replace 0.106.0->0.110.0
Fuzzy Finder 0.51.0->0.54.0

Note: I'm not trying to build any newest master again cause the packages will be updated too.
Label: enhancement

Title: Auto Indent should look further for a preceding line that is not '\n'.
Label: bug

Title: "Move Line Up" and "Move Line Down" with multiple selections
Body:
After making multiple selections, "Move Line Up" (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd> <kbd>Cmd</kbd> <kbd>Up</kbd>) and "Move Line Down" (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd> <kbd>Cmd</kbd> <kbd>Down</kbd>) works only on the last selected line, instead it should move all the lines.

![atom-multiple-selection-move-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/50681/3138639/e528d254-e8a2-11e3-9608-e67da60182cf.gif)
Label: enhancement

Title: Some sort of loader should be there while searching packages
Body:
Some sort of loader should be there while searching packages.
Feels like its hanged!
Label: enhancement

Title: Native menu item locations?
Body: It took me a second to figure out where "Settings" was because it was in File and I never go into the "File" menu at all, can we please get native item locations for Menu's?  On Linux "Settings" or "Preferences" is normally located in Edit and on Windows it's typically located in "Tools".
Label: enhancement

Title: Humanized keystrokes render as boxes
Body:
`alt` and `ctrl` should probably be used on Windows instead for these labels to match the system menus.

![screen shot 2014-05-30 at 5 41 55 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/3137751/70ec1068-e85c-11e3-8398-94a47b0c4a69.png)
Label: bug

Title: Spell check is enabled in all editors, no mater what grammar it is using
Body:
It was previously enabled for a subset of grammars.

![git-diff coffee - _users_corey_github_git-diff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/596/3136480/e883d620-e842-11e3-97ad-c3b62dc1df97.jpg)
Label: bug

Title: Atom over sshfs Unusably Slow
Body: When editing files over an sshfs connection, it takes long periods of time to perform basic actions (directory expansion, file opening).  This is likely because git is running locally, but querying a remote repository many times -- can these behaviors be migrated into a non-blocking request?  e.g., allow the file to open before the git repo has been read for any changes.
Label: bug

Title: atom.workspace.getActiveEditor() returning editor with no cursors
Body:
We are seeing a lot of these in bugsnag:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot call method 'getBufferPosition' of undefined
app/src/editor.js:1321:31 Editor.module.exports.Editor.getCursorBufferPosition
app/node_modules/status-bar/lib/cursor-position-view.js:40:46 CursorPositionView.module.exports.CursorPositionView.updateCursorPositionText
app/node_modules/status-bar/lib/cursor-position-view.js:3:61 <anonymous>
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676:9 jQuery.event.dispatch
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360:28 elemData.handle
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4594:12 jQuery.event.trigger
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:5119:17 <anonymous>
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:590:23 Function.jQuery.extend.each
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:237:17 StatusBarView.jQuery.fn.jQuery.each
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:5118:15 StatusBarView.jQuery.fn.extend.trigger
app/node_modules/status-bar/lib/status-bar-view.js:44:24 <anonymous>
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676:9 jQuery.event.dispatch
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360:28 elemData.handle
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4594:12 jQuery.event.trigger
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:5119:17 <anonymous>
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:590:23 Function.jQuery.extend.each
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:237:17 PaneContainerView.jQuery.fn.jQuery.each
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:5118:15 PaneContainerView.jQuery.fn.extend.trigger
app/src/pane-container-view.js:87:19 PaneContainerView.module.exports.PaneContainerView.onActivePaneItemChanged
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/emitter.js:132:47 Signal.module.exports.Emitter.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/signal.js:82:19 Signal.module.exports.Signal.emitValue
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/emitter.js:132:47 Behavior.module.exports.Emitter.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/behavior.js:44:38 Behavior.module.exports.Behavior.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/signal.js:82:19 Behavior.module.exports.Signal.emitValue
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/emitter.js:132:47 Behavior.module.exports.Emitter.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/behavior.js:44:38 Behavior.module.exports.Behavior.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/signal.js:82:19 Behavior.module.exports.Signal.emitValue
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/emitter.js:132:47 Behavior.module.exports.Emitter.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/behavior.js:44:38 Behavior.module.exports.Behavior.emit
app/node_modules/emissary/lib/signal.js:82:19 Behavior.module.exports.Signal.emitValue
app/node_modules/theorist/lib/model.js:166:21 Pane.module.exports.Model.set
app/node_modules/theorist/lib/model.js:57:23 Pane.accessor.set
app/src/pane.js:175:32 Pane.module.exports.Pane.activateItem
app/node_modules/delegato/lib/delegator.js:67:61 PaneView._results.push._this.(anonymous function) [as activateItem]
app/node_modules/tabs/lib/tab-bar-view.js:148:24 <anonymous>
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4676:9 jQuery.event.dispatch
app/node_modules/space-pen/vendor/jquery.js:4360:28 elemData.handle
```

The offending lines in status bar look like this:

``` coffee
updateCursorPositionText: =>
    editor = atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()
    if position = editor?.getCursorBufferPosition()
      @text("#{position.row + 1},#{position.column + 1}").show()
    else
      @hide()
```

This seems to suggest to me that `atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()` is returning an editor with no cursors which might imply that is has been destroyed already.

It would be easy to check for this explicitly in status bar but the fact that `atom.workspace.getActiveEditor()` is return an unusable editor is worrisome.

@nathansobo any thoughts on this?
Label: bug

Title: Selections do not always disappear immediately, causing overwrites.
Body:
Occasionally when selecting text and typing over it, the selection remains and selects the next text of the same length (or sometimes one character). Because of this, typing over a selection causes the original text AND the new selection to be overwritten. In the case that the selection is replaced by the one character selection, typing continually replaces the same character until a delay in typing occurs.

The expected behavior is that the selection and selected text both disappear immediately when beginning to type.

Using Atom 0.99 on OS X 10.9.3
Label: bug

Title: Strange double cursor when using split panes
Body:
After splitting right, I tried to edit the file and my changes were added to both my old cursor location in the file in the new pane and my new cursor location in the same file in the old pane. Even when I clicked to focus in one pane, the old cursor would disappear but the changes still were still made in both.

I'm running on Linux.
Label: bug

Title: TokenizedLine::isComment returns the wrong value for javascript blockquotes
Body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Make sure Atom's soft-tabs configuration option is off (we want to insert hard tabs)
2. Clone git@github.com:iandotkelly/atomissue.git and open `sample.js`
3. Insert a new line at the end of the file and press tab.

You expect a hard tab to be inserted, but a soft tab is inserted. This is because `TokenizedLine::isComment` returns false for the first and second lines of the file.

**moved from https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/issues/11**
Label: bug

Title: Pane:Show Next Item Disappears In Settings Page
Body:
With the settings page open, if the "Settings" or "Themes" section is selected, "pane: show next item" (ctrl+tab), the command to switch between open documents, is broken. It works as expected if the "Keybindings" or "Packages" section is selected, but not for "Settings" or "Themes".

Expected output (shown with "Keybindings" selected):
![atom expected view](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7651077/3093462/c473a946-e5b2-11e3-82e5-19bc857cc8f9.png)

Output with "Settings" or "Themes" sections selected:
![atom unexpected view](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7651077/3093466/cd8fb0d8-e5b2-11e3-820d-5194ef9f1f2a.png)

Interestingly, show next item works when you first select the "Settings" or "Themes" sections, but will disappear if you cycle back to it. Also, if you take focus away from the Settings page (the entire page, not just the "Settings" section) by clicking on another file or switching to another program on your computer, returning to the Settings page brings back the show next item command. Clicking the Settings tab at the top of the screen (again, for the entire settings page, not just the settings section) also brings the functionality back.
![atom after clicking settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7651077/3093584/08ab6b20-e5b4-11e3-9a82-e695891b2b09.png)

I am using version 0.110.0-00987f3 on Windows 7 here on my work computer. I installed Atom through [alfredxing's](https://github.com/alfredxing/atom/releases/) installer because I could not install all of the dependencies needed to build it myself, so this may be an issue only present in this installation.
Label: bug

Title: [Windows] LICENSE.md is not in the correct location.
Body:
When clicking `Help -> View License`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1251005/3093447/8e1f8e82-e5b2-11e3-958e-6826a026ecc0.png)

Atom opens up a new editor pane with the path:
`c:\Program Files (x86)\Atom\resources\app\LICENSE.md`

After a fresh installation, `LICENSE.md` is not there -- instead it's sitting in `C:\Program Files (x86)\Atom`.  If I copy the file into place manually, it works.
Label: bug

Title: Package manager should allow dependencies to be placed on other plugins
Body:
Currently, packages that are pluggable (such as autocomplete-plus, and AtomLinter) are dependent on their own implementations of plugin style functionality.  In order to better support packages like this I think that we should be able to support packages having dependencies.  

What I would like to see is capabilities added for the following.
- Subscribe to package manager to get instance of package when it is loaded
- When loaded a subscribed package should expose instance of package created so sub modules can execute against loaded package, for instance if the workspace was a separate module we would get the workspace by subscribing to the workspace load rather than it being available globally on the atom object.
- Ability to subscribe to loaded packages by metadata filter, something like what atom linter does to find linters that have been loaded, but subscribed like we subscribe to all current and future editors.
- A simple interface for verifying version (via semver) of the subscribed package(s) are of the correct version, and when not alerting the user that the modules need updating.

This would give us the ability to dynamically, and bi-directionally link modules to each other.
Label: enhancement

Title: Wrong line width calculation on unicode characters
Body:
Atom seems to calculate line width of Unicode characters incorrectly. The following is the result of atom 0.95 on Fedora 20,
![2014-05-26 21 07 16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/32396/3082659/d16b7e80-e4d6-11e3-8272-8a365a776d49.png)

![2014-05-26 21 08 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/32396/3082668/fe22a494-e4d6-11e3-8b26-e84289022665.png)
It shows that atom calculated the wrong display width.

The same problem is reported in the forum by ZhangHanDong and more investigation into the problem is offered by Blaisorblade at [Forum](http://discuss.atom.io/t/preferred-line-length-dont-support-chinese/4666)

Title: React editor cannot open this file
Body:
``` css
/*
 * This is a manifest file that'll be compiled into application.css, which will include all the files
 * listed below.
 *
 * Any CSS and SCSS file within this directory, lib/assets/stylesheets, vendor/assets/stylesheets,
 * or vendor/assets/stylesheets of plugins, if any, can be referenced here using a relative path.
 *
 * You're free to add application-wide styles to this file and they'll appear at the top of the
 * compiled file, but it's generally better to create a new file per style scope.
 *
 *= require_self
 *= require_tree .
 */
```

Apparently it's tokenizing with an indent level of `0.5`.

![screen shot 2014-05-24 at 8 21 52 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/3074848/90adaf60-e357-11e3-8ada-3829bc5ff9f8.png)

![screen shot 2014-05-24 at 8 22 20 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/3074849/939f15b0-e357-11e3-8c45-c38699c6f2af.png)

Changing the file to 

```
/*
  This is a manifest file that'll be compiled into application.css, which will include all the files
  listed below.

  Any CSS and SCSS file within this directory, lib/assets/stylesheets, vendor/assets/stylesheets,
  or vendor/assets/stylesheets of plugins, if any, can be referenced here using a relative path.

  You're free to add application-wide styles to this file and they'll appear at the top of the
  compiled file, but it's generally better to create a new file per style scope.

  = require_self
  = require_tree .
*/
```

Allows it to open.
Label: bug
