Label: bug

Title: http 404 on http://atom.io/docs/
Body: http://atom.io/docs/
Label: bug

Title: Opening Atom.App from terminal [Bug]
Body:
Atom is open but then subsequent windows and instances cannot be opened from the terminal and receive this error.

```
Cannot locate Atom.app, it is usually located in /Applications. Set the ATOM_PATH environment variable to the directory containing Atom.app.
```

Found instance of it in the Atom Script 
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/atom.sh#L58

```
 # Exit if Atom can't be found
  if [ -z "$ATOM_PATH" ]; then
    echo "Cannot locate Atom.app, it is usually located in /Applications. Set the ATOM_PATH environment variable to the directory containing Atom.app."
    exit 1
  fi
```

Edit: On,  OSX 10.9, ZSH, Atom .96
Label: bug

Title: Create an `atom bisect` command for determining which package is causing a problem
Body: Similar to the `git bisect` command, this command would load Atom with a subset of the packages available to it. It would launch Atom, then when Atom exits it could ask for "good", "bad", "reset" or "quit". It would perform a binary search of the packages until only one package is left and is marked bad (the most likely scenario) telling the user which package it is.
Label: enhancement

Title: Is there a way to override syntax/ui variables in user stylesheets?
Body: I find that syntax/ui variables are used in some packages. But in my own user stylesheet file, I override some variables, but it can't effect them in the packages. Is there a way to solve this?
Label: enhancement

Title: Impossible to write some chars on Windows with a German keyboard
Body:
On a German keyboard, you can't type `@` (this is `ctrl-alt-q` in the keybinding resolver, and mapped to `autoflow:reflow-selection`) and `\` (this is `ctrl-alt-[` in the keybinding resolver, and mapped to `editor:fold-current-row`).

_Expected:_ The chars appear in the editor.
_Actual:_ The mentioned actions happens, but the characters don't appear.
Label: bug

Title: Selected text is deselected after right-click context menu is closed
Body:
This is a continuation of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1619. Right-clicking on selected text correctly opens the context menu now. However, the selection is canceled if you just want to close the context menu (by clicking somewhere outside of the menu's area or hitting `esc`).

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/3053202/81614dea-e1a5-11e3-9baf-2c6caf2403a3.gif)

Other apps (Chrome, ST3) keep the selected text selected even after the context menu is closed this way.
Label: bug

Title: May I swap command and option key in osx when using emacs keymap
Body: I use osx, when using Emacs, I always swap command and option key, may I do this in atom?
Label: enhancement

Title: Enhance view system to easily allow adding of panes inside a tabbed editor
Body:
Currently to add panes inside a tab - one that 'lives' with that file - you have to manually search and manipulate the DOM and managing everything yourself. Atom already provides a nicer more maintainable way for adding panes around the tabbed editors, it would be great if it also provided a way to do it for each tab editor.

This will make some packages easier to write and more stable as the DOM changes over time.

Is this something planned? I'd happily lend a hand if so.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom text edit pane went unresponsive and then overwrote file with only my typed characters on save
Body:
I was working in Atom 0.96.0 with a horizontal split screen. 1 file open at the top and 2 files in the bottom. When I went to select some text in the top pane the chrome developer console popped up. There was no error in the console, so I figured I must have triggered a shortcut. I closed the console and tried to select again. It wouldn't let me select or type or move the curser, but the curser was still flashing. I mashed the keyboard in an attempt to see changes on the screen. When nothing worked, I closed the file and it prompted me to save my changes. Figuring it just got stuck on a keyboard shortcut or mouse gesture, I said save and then reloaded Atom. On reload I opened my file and it was just 8 characters, which I'm pretty sure were the keys I mashed after the window was unresponsive ('asdfasdf').

The only indication that Atom had issues was the developer console popping up. But there was no error in the console so no indication that anything was actually wrong. If there were some kind of error message or warning I would never have saved my work.
Label: bug

Title: Word wrap and bracket highlight
Body:
Minor bracket highlight issue:
![snapshot24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1240012/3038804/cf5bbb08-e0d2-11e3-829b-8dfc39de1f42.png)

"Some random text here Some random text here {" is on the same line. It wraps the last symbol as should since the line doesn't fit the window width because of it, although Atom highlights that bracket at the wrong place then.

Behavior in the Kate editor:
![snapshot25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1240012/3039017/ff498752-e0d5-11e3-8085-94e4234ff4e3.png)
Label: bug

Title: Multiple user run
Body:
When an instance of atom is running with the current user, running a second instance of atom with sudo does not make it run with root access.

Reproduce : 
$ atom
$ sudo atom

$ ps -aux | grep atom // shows no instance of atom with root user

Same problem in the opposite case.
Label: enhancement

Title: Delete key not working on Ubuntu
Body: Built from source at 5690d9fe8151f51a96a0acef327abaf4e5e3eb0f. Everything else seems to be working fine, backspace too, but not the Delete key (works in other programs).
Label: bug

Title: Atom Not in Start Menu after Windows Build
Body:
I would make a pull request, but I'm not sure of the correct way to do this since the path to the Start Menu shortcuts differs on Win XP and newer Windows versions.

On Windows Vista, 7, & 8, it should be:

```
C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Atom
```
###### While it is the default, it may not be `C:\` on some systems.
Label: enhancement

Title: Open file from `Open With` dialog messes up file URL
Body:
I opened a file from the `Open With` dialog in PCManFM. However, this messes up the file URL and thus causes the editor to open just an empty file.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/170947/3032736/9ac95dea-e05b-11e3-929b-804b00197807.png)

Basically it constructs an URL path in the form of:

`/home/<username>/file:/home/<username>...`

I am using the latest git version on Arch Linux.

Let me know if I can provide you with more information.
Label: bug

Title: Indent guides mess up with mixed indentation
Body:
Definitely an odd situation that coders shouldn't be getting into I grant you, but if the indentation mode of the current file is tabs and the indentation actually mixes tabs and spaces, the indent guides go a bit funny:

![indent-guides](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412784/3029068/6900d09c-e031-11e3-877f-3e534d303dda.gif)

(Similar with invisibles shown:)

![indent-guides-invisibles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412784/3029078/7bd675d2-e031-11e3-8cd1-552b3bc02e1a.gif)

Version 0.95.0. Will test with updated version later.
Label: bug

Title: Editor Does Not Preview / Edit Files on Network Drive
Body:
OS: Windows 7
Atom Version: 0.95.0-3f0640f

Hosting files on a network drive (i.e. \network\private\myfiles) and opening files in atom does not show anything.  Files list on left pane and a tab opens up in editor, but tab is empty and shows nothing.

Additional Note:  I tested using a mapped drive and it worked.  It appears there's an issue running atom in Windows and trying to open files on a network path.
Label: bug

Title: Can't install behind HTTP proxy -- can't clone git:// URLs
Body:
_Somebody_ is trying to `git clone` a `git://` url. Because of the proxy, I can only clone `http://` urls.

I configured `git` to translate the urls (thanks, @stefanpenner!):

``` bash
git config --global url."https://".insteadOf git://
```

-- but even so, the problem remains...

``` bash
$ script/build 

Removing envify ✓
Installing modules ✗

> atom@0.97.0 preinstall /home/tfga/temp/atom
> node -e 'process.exit(0)'


npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/atom/slick.git Cloning into bare repository '/home/tfga/.atom/.node-gyp/.atom/.apm/_git-remotes/git-github-com-atom-slick-git-fe3034e1'...
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/atom/slick.git 
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/atom/slick.git fatal: unable to connect to github.com:
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/atom/slick.git github.com[0: 192.30.252.129]: errno=Connection timed out
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/benogle/jsdiff.git Cloning into bare repository '/home/tfga/.atom/.node-gyp/.atom/.apm/_git-remotes/git-github-com-benogle-jsdiff-git-b9e372e4'...
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/benogle/jsdiff.git 
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/benogle/jsdiff.git fatal: unable to connect to github.com:
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/benogle/jsdiff.git github.com[0: 192.30.252.129]: errno=Connection timed out
npm ERR! Error: Command failed: fatal: unable to connect to github.com:
npm ERR! github.com[0: 192.30.252.129]: errno=Connection timed out
```

I realize there's another issue with (almost) the same name (#2297), but the problem there seems to be different (having to do with npm).
Label: bug

Title: Add support for block / column selection
Body:
In plenty editors, doing `left-alt` (left option) and selecting text will take a slice of that text:

![sublime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1189716/3020145/21a1ced6-df9b-11e3-9cf2-70371ca5fee1.gif)

Notice that only characters are selected, empty lines are ignored. Also, after selecting with `left-alt`, there should be multi-cursors at the end of each selection:

![reslice](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1189716/3020149/2d06c1c8-df9b-11e3-9a39-226039d0f777.gif)

The GIF are from Sublime, the same behavior is observed in TextMate, IntelliJ, vim (visual selection).

The current behavior in Atom is to perform a normal text selection:

![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1189716/3020155/3bbc4512-df9b-11e3-97a8-1acab2dd686f.gif)
Label: enhancement

Title: "Update download failed"
Body:
**Env***
MBP 15-inch / OS X 10.9.2
Atom Version 0.95.0

**Repo**
Always

**Steps**
1. Click Atom > 'Check for Update'

**Actual Result**
'Update download failed'

**Additional Details**
Issue doesn't reproduce after manually installing Atom Version 0.96.0 downloaded from https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v0.96.0 , though that might be because there is no newer builds. I noticed that Download button at https://atom.io/ no longer starts download, but instead links to https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v0.96.0 

![20140519-atom-95-update-download-failed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/962387/3017972/5be20680-df80-11e3-9cac-8d65828661df.png)
Label: bug

Title: Atom version not properly displayed
Body:
@probablycorey ask me to report this issue from [discuss.atom.io](http://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-version-not-properly-displayed/9390) 

> I managed to build a working version of Atom for Gentoo Linux but I can't get the
> proper Atom version in Help menu (Version 0.1.0 is displayed instead of 0.96.0).
> 
> I tried to understand the way the menu was generated and, if I understood correctly,  it seems to read Atom package.json version which seems good :
> 
> ``` json
> {
>   "name": "atom",
>   "productName": "Atom",
>   "version": "0.96.0-7410f9a",
>   "description": "A hackable text editor for the 21st Century.",
>   "main": "./src/browser/main.js",
>   "repository": {
>     "type": "git",
>     "url": "https://github.com/atom/atom.git"
>   },
>   ...
> }
> ```
> 
> Have I missed something ?

I should mention that atom-shell is build standalone and I run atom this way : 

```
$ /usr/share/atom-shell/atom /usr/share/atom 
$ echo $ATOM_RESOURCE_PATH
/usr/share/atom
```

---

Atom Commit: 7410f9a
OS Version: Gentoo Linux ([Unofficial overlay build](https://github.com/aegypius/overlay/tree/master/app-editors/atom) - aegypius/overlay#7)

**What steps will reproduce the problem?**
1. Launch Atom
2. Click Help Menu 

**What is the expected result?**

Version 0.96.0

**What happens instead?**

Version 0.1.0 is displayed
Label: bug

Title: atom should not override Cocoa text system's buildin word auto-completion
Body:
Mac  has a system-wide word auto-completion key-bindings: `command + .` or `F5`. The TextEdit.app and Mail.app and Chrome(omnibox, the address bar) and many other Cocoa App supports this feature. That is: you can input partial of the word, press  `Command + .`  , a auto-completion drop-down should be triggered,then you can select the target word.

This cocoa text auto-completion is very important for a foreign writers.

ref: [hallelujah_autocompletion](http://daringfireball.net/2006/10/hallelujah_autocompletion)

![cocoa-text-auto-complete](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/112451/3009833/feae0c38-df08-11e3-8d40-e980e4606a62.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Default Directory
Body:
I think it would be cool to have an option to set a default directory if atom is invoked with no arguments. If no value was entered then atom would behave as it does now. There was some talk about removing the Project Home option in the settings dialog but I would vote that it be changed to mean the default directory for projects. This way i just launch atom and I'll be staring at all my projects. I understand this can be done many ways, even with an alias. For now I added this simple hack to atom.sh just under the getopts section.

if [ -z $1];
then 
cd /dir/containing/all/projects
fi

I thought about just adding whatever file contains the "Project Home" entry as a source in atom.sh and calling the value here if not empty. Any thoughts on a more elegant solution?

Thanks!
Label: enhancement

Title: [devtools] Debugging gets silently disabled
Body:
React editor. Happened while trying to debug #2186

Very specific steps to reproduce:

1) Open up `app/src/editor.js` in _Sources_
2) Place a breakpoint on the first line after `Editor.prototype.insertText = ...`
3) Paste using `Ctrl+V`

This breakpoint should fire on every insert. Even if I stop trying to paste, and try to input a single character, insertText should fire, thus this breakpoint should too.
Label: bug

Title: Indent guides are shown even when showIndentGuide is false
Body:
Reports:
- support/2dbd3512dacc11e390e1995db10fd10e
- http://discuss.atom.io/t/indent-guides-off/8512

> Since 0.92.0, typing new lines will output the 'indent-guide' class for whitespace-only lines even though Show Indent Guide is set to false in the settings. Typing stuff on the line removes the class, as expected.

As far as I can tell, this is still an issue in 0.95.0.

cc @daboe01 (thanks again for the report!)
Label: bug

Title: [devtools] Right clicking inside editor in Sources tab freezes most operations
Body:
Linux, 0.96.0-e3dbd41

Adding conditional breakpoints is impossible. Other parts of devtools also freeze up.  

In scenarios like these, remote devtools would be helpful.
Label: bug

Title: :penguin: IME doesn't work directly after activating it
Body:
On Linux (Ubuntu 14.04, Unity desktop environment) when I activate the Japanese IME (anthy), it doesn't work in Atom directly after activating it. All text typed is ignored. When I switch to another program such as Gedit and use the IME there to input some Japanese text, and then switch to Atom again, I _can_ input text in Japanese in Atom, as you would expect.
### Steps to reproduce
- Start Atom
- Place cursor in some file in Atom
- Activate IME by keyboard shortcut¹
- Type something → **no output at all**
- Switch to some file opened in Gedit, type something → works
- Switch to some file opened in Atom, type something → works

¹ This bug does not appear when activating the IME by clicking on its task tray icon and selecting the input method from that menu.
Label: bug

Title: Please consider adding an API in Atom that allows for interception of  the window creation process.
Body:
After hacking on Atom for the past week, I was able to simulate custom client-side window decorations (ala GNOME) and was hoping I could propose an official api.

My proof of concept is here (the hack was quick and dirty): https://github.com/nikolowry/atom-csd. 

The api could possibly detect if a global menu is present (Mac, Unity, Mate, etc), which would then ensure the original menu api functions as expected. However in OS's/DEs that don't use global menu's (Fedora, Ubuntu GNOME, WIndows, etc) it would both detach the menu and serve a frameless window.

Another idea could be to place some optional settings/flags in the api that would make the end-user ultimately responsible for choosing if they want a frameless window/detached menu or only the frameless window.

I have no qualms with writing a clean/modular/logical solution and issuing a pull request when I'm finished, but would only start with the blessings of the atom team.

Before writing this request for consideration, I made sure to check if it was possible to intercept window creation at run-time in the atom-shell and was informed it was not: https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/302

I know how difficult it is to optimize cross-platform and to propose custom/experimental designs/solutions in a corporate setting (regardless of whether said organization is horizontally or vertically integrated), and appreciate your consideration either way.

If we could implement this, Atom would surely become the "champion editor" for us developers that prefer to run a non-traditional-OS/DE.

Your support for either a full blown "offical window theme api" w default styles (ala the ui/syntax manager) or just a simple api intended exclusively for package developers, would be amazing.
Label: enhancement

Title: No OSX menu highlight on keyboard shortcuts
Body:
When using keyboard shortcuts the corresponding menu in the menu bar does not highlight. Pretty minor detail but inconsistent with other OSX applications.

For example when pressing command+s for save, the "File" menu should flash blue as feedback that a keyboard shortcut was pressed from that menu.

Title: Touchscreen support (with high DPI)
Body:
I have a Microsoft Service tablet and I tried Atom on it. With mouse it works like a charm but when I use the touch screen it doesn't work that well. I think it is something like 100 pixels wrong on the  x-ax and 60 on the y-ax. So the cursor moves 100px more to the left and 60 to the top.
Note: I do have DPI scaling enabled at 150% after changing it to 100% (and logging out) it did work

Note: The menus do work correctly with touch, just the editor (and tabs don't)

I do not know if it is Windows specific because I don't have another OS with touchscreen.

Edit: I changed the issue I didn't logout the first time so my DPI settings didn't change.

Title: Move .atom config to $XDG_CONFIG_HOME on linux
Body:
From feedesktop.org:

$XDG_CONFIG_HOME defines the base directory relative to which user specific configuration files should be stored. If $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is either not set or empty, a default equal to $HOME/.config should be used.

Source: http://standards.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html

Thanks!

- This behavior goes against user expectations

Title: Sometimes scrollbars will change from Atom-styled to Windows-style
Body:
Details of Build:

```
  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>git --info-path
     C:\Users\Dev\AppData\Local\GitHub\PortableGit_054f2e797ebafd44a30203088cd3d58663c627ef/share/info

  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>node -v
  v0.10.28

  C:\Users\Dev\Documents\GitHub\atom>npm -v
  1.4.9
```

Atom Version: 0.94.0-c79ef04 from [my own builds](http://blog.someguy123.com/atom-builds-for-windows/) running on Windows 8 (not 8.1)

I think the issue is caused when opening a big folder. Although I can't confirm this. If I open a source code folder from my desktop (atom on the right), I get the default scrollbars as it's not fully expanded in the tree when first opened as there are only 3 folders (at least not until I expanded them by hand). 

However (atom on the left) larger folders like my entire desktop fill the sidebar vertically, and seems to cause windows-native scrollbars to appear instead of atom-style.

Here's a screenshot to show the difference:
![Example](http://i.imgur.com/RHqVdSb.png)

NOTE: This may be related to the other scrollbar issue where the cursor goes invisible when resizing. Filed as issue #2165
Label: bug

Title: Resizing sidebar gives invisible cursor
Body:
It looks like the Chromium build for windows is missing some cursors. I am on Windows 8 (not 8.1) using my own [nightly builds](http://blog.someguy123.com/atom-builds-for-windows/). Specifically I am on version 0.94.0-c79ef04

The issue happens when you place your mouse in the resizing area of the sidebar:
![Screenshot of Resizing area](http://i.imgur.com/dMLZ6r8.png)

This appears to be caused by Chromium missing certain cursors, including the default sidebar resize cursor `col-resize`. You can check this by altering the `.tree-view-resizer .tree-view-resize-handle` style. By changing the cursor to `pointer` or `all-scroll` we can get some form of cursor when resizing.

![Example of all-scroll cursor](http://i.imgur.com/mXAz5MY.png)

I don't know if this affects the other versions such as the Mac and Linux versions, but a possible fix for the Windows version would be to use the `e-resize` pointer instead of `col-resize` as I have gotten success from that:
![e-resize example](http://i.imgur.com/CDqzV9o.png)

If you're looking for what to edit in the dev tools, here's a screenshot:
![Chrome Dev Tools](http://i.imgur.com/T1k55ta.png)
Label: bug

Open the Test.txt with Atom (mine is 0.94.0), then you see unrecognized characters: ��������

Vice versa. Create a text file in Atom, input Chinese characters and save it. Then use TextEdit open the file, you also can see unrecognized characters:  娴嬭瘯

I think the problem is about the default plain text encoding. Anyone has similar problem?

Title: Opening files containing only numbers from the Terminal
Body:
Hello,

if atom tries to open a file from the prompt containing only numbers leads to a crash of the program with the following message:

``` bash
$ touch 123
$ atom 123

TypeError: Arguments to path.resolve must be strings
    at Object.exports.resolve (path.js:327:15)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/browser/main.js:63:21
    at Array.map (native)
    at Application.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/browser/main.js:61:43)
    at Application.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:98:17)
    at Application.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/atom/browser/api/lib/app.js:47:16)
    at Application.g (events.js:190:16)
    at Application.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:101:17)
```

The method causing the problem `path.resolve` is also mentioned in some other issues. This function does only work for strings, but only-numbers-filenames should also be valid.

![atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1507474/2936756/f5e105a0-d86f-11e3-9eb4-c202f32e0a61.png)
Label: bug

  at Function.Module._load (module.js:311:12)
  at Module.require (module.js:363:17)
  at require (module.js:379:17)
  at window.onload (file:///Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/static/index.js:20:5)
```

I deleted and recreated the directory multiple times, ensured permissions were right etc. No dice. If I opened atom inside the directory (via the terminal) using the 'atom' command it barfed. I also tried the directory with and without a git repo in it and it made no difference. It's always that EXACT error too, not different for various files inside the directory, regardless of if I open the directory itself or a file inside it.

Any other directory name is fine, anywhere else I create 'unconf' so far seems to be fine too. Very odd :\
Label: bug

Title: Where to post package suggestions?
Body:
Where can we post suggestions about new packages? 
For example, I would suggest the creating of a package to support Fortran 77, 90 and others. Creation of a package for such an essential language should be undertaken by the atom authors, or at least hosted by them. How do we work that out? Among all the packages that provide similar functionality, the "official" one (by the authors) should be the most preferable one. How does that fit in the apm ecology?
Label: enhancement

Title: Quoting too much causes syntax highlighting to screw up
Body:
Consider a series of quoted strings in an array in ruby:

``` ruby
states = ['AL', 'AK', 'AZ', 'AR', 'CO', 'DE', 'FL', 'GA', 'HI', 'ID', 'IL', 'IN', 'IA', 'KS', 'KY', 'LA', 'ME', 'MD', 'MI', 'MN', 'MS', 'MO', 'MT', 'NE', 'NV', 'NH', 'NJ', 'NM', 'NY', 'NC', 'ND', 'OH', 'OK', 'OR', 'RI', 'SC', 'SD', 'TX', 'UT', 'VT', 'VA', 'WA', 'WV', 'WI', 'WY']
```

In atom, if this list stopped at `MI` syntax highlighting would resume as normal. However, it acts as if the rest of the file has a single quote at the top:

![quote-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/49549/2928565/eb0b968c-d77e-11e3-934c-1b7c165ada03.gif)

I'm using the [Tomorrow theme](https://atom.io/themes/tomorrow) but it shows up in others as well. This also happens in python, but the quote limit is one less and only the rest of the line is unquoted. Same with C, although again the quote limit changes. Very odd.
Label: bug

Title: in Packages pane, remove the updated packages in 'Available Updates' section
Body:
In Packages pane, the updated packages in 'Available Updates' section should probably be removed once the update is done, as of 0.94.0 version, here's the following behaviour:
- clicked update icon for package eg. fizzy
- once update is done, the check icon appears on the top right
- then the fizzy package stays in the update section forever or until atom is restarted

Also, the update button should be disabled once the update is in progress or done with the package update.

Title: Build fails if user's npm doesn't recognize the version format ^X.Y.Z
Body: The newest version of npm [1.4.10](https://www.npmjs.org/package/npm) has [read-package-json](https://github.com/npm/read-package-json/blob/master/package.json) as a nested dependency. Unfortunately read-package-json's package.json has a version string with the ^X.Y.Z pattern. This means that Atom's script/build will fail on version of npm that don't support that pattern.
Label: bug

Title: [react] If there are exactly ten lines of code, the line numbers display incorrectly

Title: Gutter selection issues
Body:
(Ported from http://discuss.atom.io/t/gutter-selection-bug/8719, issue occurred on 0.93.0, as-yet-untested on 0.94.0, though the release notes for 0.94.0 don't say anything about selection issues being fixed.)

I have found a few issues with selections. Over the course of the beta a few have been solved but one remains, and it has an ugly cousin.

The simple point is that when making a selection, if the cursor (which still held down in  a drag) crosses over the gutter between the line numbers and the editor area itself Atom seems to take this as 'the cursor is at the end of the line'. If you move the mouse beyond this gutter into the actual line numbers, we're back to normal.

The ugly cousin is that if the line being selected is longer than the editor window (and there's no wrapping), thus selecting the end of the line would cause the editor to scroll, there's a nice back-and-forth game it likes to play.

I am currently unable to upload a gif, but see [my original post](http://discuss.atom.io/t/gutter-selection-bug/8719) for now if you want to see both of these in action.

Update: Gif!

![crazy-selection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412784/2913979/3e3eed40-d694-11e3-97d8-e28f78dec64c.gif)
Label: bug

Title: TokenizedBuffer::lineForScreenRow actually takes buffer rows.
Body:
`TokenizedBuffer::lineForScreenRow` actually uses buffer rows.

It makes the method `Editor::lineForScreenRow` confusing. It should probably be broken up into `Editor::screenLineForScreenRow` and `Editor::tokenizedLineForBufferRow`.
Label: bug

![screenshot 2014-05-07 11 44 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6206210/2902534/33490e7e-d5e6-11e3-948d-82a0b7f77694.png)

Title: Atom opens a new window for file that is outside of current working directory
Body:
Suppose that I open atom in my home directory. The working directory shown on the left is my home directory.
Now if I want to open a file that is not in the working directory then Atom opens a new window with that file and its directory. Same thing happens if I want to open a third file that is outside of those two working directories.

Is this the intended behavior? Because it's bugging me that I cannot open a file outside of the current working directory in the same window.

Also dragging the tab from one window to the other only creates an untitled tab in the destination window and the source tab remains in the source window. (I guess this is another issue, but it probably has something to do with Atom only allowing opening a file that is in the window's current working directory).
Label: enhancement

Title: Bolded text displaces cursor.
Body: Bolded text does not alight correctly with text below it and will mess up the position of the cursor.
Label: bug

Title: "You must assign a non-zero lineHeight before calling ::getVisibleRowRange()" with React

Title: Support subword navigation
Body:
SublimeText supports navigation by subwords (underscore separated or hills in camelcase):

```
{ "keys": ["alt+left"], "command": "move", "args": {"by": "subwords", "forward": false} },
{ "keys": ["alt+right"], "command": "move", "args": {"by": "subword_ends", "forward": true} },
{ "keys": ["alt+shift+left"], "command": "move", "args": {"by": "subwords", "forward": false, "extend": true} },
{ "keys": ["alt+shift+right"], "command": "move", "args": {"by": "subword_ends", "forward": true, "extend": true} }
```

It would be nice if Atom also supported `move*`, `delete*`, `backspace*`, `select*` editor commands based on subwords.
Label: enhancement

Title: Editor window height decreases after each run. Ubuntu 14.04
Label: bug

Title: Ignored names doesn't accept .* as a valid input (to hide all files beginning with a '.', standard unix philosophy)
Body:
Inputting `.*` into the Ignored Names setting does not read it as a valid wildcard for any files/folders beginning with a `.` 
In unix and things based off/designed around, files and folders beginning with a `.` are classed as hidden and by default should be hidden by things listing the directories unless they are explicitly told to list the hidden files. I'm not asking for this, but at least a way to achieve this, through the use of `.*`. 

I believe the Ignored Names setting should be accept any form of wildcard, be it `*.file`, `*somefilename*` or `.*`. And currently believe that this is a bug in the system currently implemented.
Label: enhancement

Title: Pasting clipboard created from a multiple selection doesn't keep the track of original selections
Body:
When a copy/paste is made when there's many selections, Atom fails to preserve the selections at paste time. 

This is how Sublime text behave in that case: 
![Sublime reference](http://s3.postimg.org/gp7bx5xir/sublime.gif)

This is how atom behave: 
![Atom reference](http://s27.postimg.org/sivs2oi3n/atom.gif)

This behavior should only be available if the number of selections is the same between the copy and the paste, in every other cases Sublime Text paste the clipboard in the same way Atom does, it paste the whole clipboard at each selection's position.
Label: enhancement

Title: Use SHA-1 as prerelease for dev builds
Body:
Not having a valid semver version in dev builds causes certain `apm` commands to not work.

So instead of using `abcdef12` as the development version, we should use something like `0.93.0-abcdef12` to make it a valid semver string where the pre-release segment is the partial SHA-1 of the commit built.
Label: enhancement

Title: Emit Git status results in chunks
Body:
Looks like really large repositories have issues sending across a giant status object, we can just stream them back in chunks like the fuzzy finder does.

Support ticket 86eddc26cb5011e38ee058b670f95585
Label: bug

Title: Dialogs are closed when Atom loses focus
Body:
Halp reports:
- support/a3fbafb2d0c011e3855fe03a98b207e5
- support/4068a4a4d08f11e39bd83f5315db0b57

Related Issues
- https://github.com/atom/feedback/issues/22
- https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/issues/37

> If you have opened up the Command Palette (Command-Shift-P) in Atom v.0.92.0, and then switch to another app, say the Mac OS X Terminal app to run something you've been working on, the Command Palette is gone when you switch back (this is also true of this "Send us feedback" drop-down pane). It would be preferable if, on switching back to the Atom app v.0.92.0, that the Command Palette were still open where you left it.

I've noticed this myself, but never fund it particularly annoying. Also, some other dialogs are affected by this as well, such as the fuzzy finder. Unsure if this is something that's handled on a per-package basis or in Atom core, so opened an issue here. :pizza: 
- It seems that SublimeText doesn't have consistent behavior with these dialogs -- the command palette is closed similar to Atom, but the fuzzy finder is not (it stays open even after the app loses focus).
Label: bug

Title: Triggering Markdown preview with split panes throws an error
Body:
Reported via Twitter: https://twitter.com/sbellware/status/462009964634972160

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start Atom
2. `cmd-k right` to split panes
3. `cmd-k down` to split panes again
4. The pane configuration should now be: one pane open on the left, two on the right
5. Position the cursor into the pane on the left
6. Trigger Markdown preview

A `Uncaught TypeError: Object #<PaneAxis> has no method 'itemForUri'` will be logged in the console.

![screen shot 2014-05-02 at 11 18 41 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2861200/cec732e6-d1da-11e3-8156-6a2732150a3e.png)
Label: bug

This seems like it may have regressed on the atom-shell 0.12.0 upgrade

/cc @zcbenz

Title: Atom doesn't support OSX proxy icon and title bar menu
Body:

> 
> This is one of those little OSX gems that can change your life. Please save mine and implement it.

Also, a similar description from a [related issue](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2301):

> More details of what a proxy icon is and how it works can be found in [OS X Human Interface Guidelines: Windows](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/userexperience/conceptual/applehiguidelines/Windows/Windows.html) under "The Proxy Icon and Title Bar Menu" (I could not figure out how to link to the subheading).

> 
> ![proxy icon](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1301625/3016609/3253d6b4-df70-11e3-808c-12fba38ad58c.gif)

I've already seen a couple of similar requests before, so finally made an issue to track these requests.

Title: Deleting folded code not working as expected
Body:
Halp ticket:
- support/11bdd39ac40011e3954faf564804671b

> When you fold a code chunk, then go to the line below the folded code and hit backspace, you expect it to delete the newline and jump to the line with the folded code. It deletes the newline AND the folded code. Probably not the behavior most people are expecting (caught me by surprise the first time).

Currently, I can't reproduce exactly this behavior. However, deleting folded code does not work as I would expect either -- when I press backspace, not only is the folded code deleted, but also the whole line containing the ellipsis representing the folded code as well.

Here's a GIF of me pressing backspace once to delete some folded code:

![foobar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2748043/85ca7064-c7a1-11e3-89d9-2b1ea1be8a05.gif)

Title: Show toggle state in menus
Body:
This keeps coming up in user requests every now and then, so I'm opening an issue. 

Here's the latest Halp ticket:
- support/124a7058c5a811e394e860ec75e6d26f

> On OS X (at least) it is standard practice for menus that "toggle" settings to indicate the current state.
> 
> For example:
> Wrong:
> Toggle Soft Wrap
> 
> Right:
> Soft Wrap
> ✓ Soft Wrap
> 
> Wrong:
> Toggle Command Pallet
> 
> Right
> Show Command Pallet (when hidden)
> Hide Command Pallet (when shown)

I would find this very helpful myself, even if done for just the core packages we control. 

Also, I remember seeing a similar request for the command palette -- that it should show the toggle state as well somehow.
Label: bug

Title: Downloading an update without asking causes problem for users on mobile data plans
Body:
Halp ticket:
- support/95b88d8ac5d011e388dbf5393005f408

> Please make Atom ask before downloading an update or make the auto-update configurable.
> 
> I am working on the road a lot and it ruins my mobile data package.

So, asking before downloading an update or providing an option to turn off auto-updating might be helpful in these cases, I suppose.
Label: bug

Title: Atom::open could be better.
Body: Atom::open uses an option with `pathsToOpen` to open a file. But `pathsToOpen` is the only valid option. I think it would make more sense to match Workspace::open.
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom::open and Workspace::open should handle column numbers
Body: Currently a link like `/Users/mrawesome/github/atom/src/project.coffee:458:7` fails to open.
Label: enhancement

Title: Reject any non-string valued keys when reading packages and themes from config
Body:
@thedaniel's config somehow got into this state:

```
'core':
  'themes': [
    null
    'atom-light-syntax'
    'atom-light-ui'
  ]
```

It was giving him a confusing error message from `fs-plus`. Might be good to ensure these values are strings to prevent this issue from confusing users.
Label: bug

Title: alt-up/down doesn't do anything, and ctrl-shift-a is confusing
Body:
Halp ticket:
- support/d8c483c6c4af11e3900abd3beebdf506

Pressing `alt-up` and `alt-down` doesn't move the cursor at all, which isn't what some of our users expect. The same is true for `alt-shift-up` and `alt-shift-down`.

As far as I can tell, SublimeText3 uses `alt-up/down` to jump to the beginning/end of the line, and `shift-alt-up/down` to select to the beginning/end of the line. Might this be a good default in Atom as well?

This behavior of jumping to the beginning of the line is currently bound to `ctrl-a` (`editor:move-to-beginning-of-line`), while `cmd-left` jumps to the beginning of the physical line (`editor:move-to-first-character-of-line`).

However, `ctrl-shift-a` doesn't select to the beginning of the logical line but to the beginning of the physical line (`editor:select-to-first-character-of-line`), which is the same thing as `cmd-shift-left`.

In other words, if `ctrl-shift-a` was consistent with `ctrl-a`, it would select like this:

![screen shot 2014-04-15 at 7 33 13 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2710664/4e4bfff2-c4c4-11e3-8bfa-78748503f9aa.png)

while it currently selects like this:

![screen shot 2014-04-15 at 7 33 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2710666/53c7b8c2-c4c4-11e3-8ddc-5d961800e834.png)
Label: bug

Title: Snippets aren't detected when the snippets.cson file is created for the first time
Body:
Halp ticket:
- support/c7984784bffc11e3936c51033c8a3e07

> Snippet system needs to be worked on, when i setup a snippet in the config file, and then i save it and go back to my work, i use the short word and hit tab, and nothing ever expands.

I could reproduce this:
1. quit Atom
2. remove ~/.atom/snippets.cson
3. start Atom
4. go "Atom > Open your snippets", and add a snippet to snippets.cson
5. try triggering the snippet you just added -- it won't work
6. quit and restart Atom
7. try triggering the snippet again -- it will work
Label: bug

Title: Quitting Atom by right-clicking on the icon in dock does not work
Body:
User reports:
- support/c599b070c11a11e3842f79cc314f043b
- support/17387238c21811e3919e26079ed8d270

> in Mac OSX 10.9, I can't close the program directly from Dock. Wenn I close it, the process will take 100% CPU and does not quit. There is no problem, wenn I use the hotkey cmd-shift-P and type 'quit'.

I can reproduce this. Just started Atom from Spotlight, right-clicked on the icon in dock, selected "Quit" and nothing happened. `cmd-q` works, though.

EDIT: Sooo, when you first select "Quit" (from the dock) -- Atom's window closes, but Atom doesn't really quit and the CPU does indeed show Atom at 100% (in Activity Monitor). Starting another Atom window and selecting "Quit" again doesn't close the window.
Label: bug

Title: All non-visible characters should be displayable when `showInvisibles` is enabled
Body:
Halp ticket:
- support/b6556d18b6f511e396195226a240cace

> Control characters aren't showing up. For example, create a file in vim and type ctl+v,ctl+h to insert a backspace character in a shell script and notice that it is invisible in Atom. Maybe not _all_ invisibles should be hidden. Then again, I just started using this today, so maybe I haven't discovered the proper setting.

Screenshot time! Here's Vim:

![screen shot 2014-04-04 at 3 15 27 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2615541/51595b3a-bbfb-11e3-91ed-0868ab97cb1d.png)

And here's Sublime:

![screen shot 2014-04-04 at 3 15 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2615543/595eeebc-bbfb-11e3-9179-efed992b065c.png)

And Atom:

![screen shot 2014-04-04 at 3 16 47 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2615549/697823cc-bbfb-11e3-9603-0a65a61bb8b5.png)
Label: bug

Title: Quitting (cmd+q) invokes the not responding dialog
Body:
This happens every time I quit atom now. I just pulled and built 10 seconds before this issue was created.

![screen shot 2014-04-03 at 10 15 28 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/2612103/3096e72a-bbb8-11e3-9727-8bd7b3a08809.png)
Label: bug

Title: Resource errors when opening dev tools for source maps
Body:
Not sure when this started happening but every time you open the dev tools, many errors are logged about loading the source maps. ~100 errors are logged each time you open it.

![errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/2610780/6234f164-bb90-11e3-8989-ec676a1b550d.gif)

/cc @zcbenz
Label: bug

Title: Duplicate lines sometimes wrongs
Body:
I'm seeing this occasionally where even with one cursor, the duplicate lines command duplicates more than one line. This GIF shows it happening twice in a row:

![duplicate-lines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/2610759/e3fef9c0-bb8f-11e3-8f53-f054a62c5ccf.gif)
Label: bug

Title: I no longer receive Atom updates
Body:
I was lamenting this to @thedaniel and @nathansobo a few days ago, and I'm wondering if this problem is getting to be more serious. 

I was running 0.76.0 and couldn't update to 0.79.0:

![screen shot 2014-03-28 at 12 19 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/64050/2610771/45b69074-bb90-11e3-96c0-1b8ecfaeb791.png)

I manually downloaded 0.79.0 and happily chugging along. I discovered now that there's a 0.83.0 release. 

The file menu tells me it is "Downloading update...", but I never see the blue squirrel, and subsequent restart attempts don't bring me a new editor. 

Launching with `atom -f` does tell me the download finished:

```
[master] ~/.atom/packages/documentation-tools $ atom -f
[57544:0403/172403:WARNING:dns_config_service_posix.cc(188)] dns_config has unhandled options!
2014-04-03 17:24:04.101 Atom[57544:507] App load time: 142ms
[57546:0403/172404:INFO:renderer_main.cc(227)] Renderer process started
[57544:0403/172405:INFO:CONSOLE(18)] "Window load time: 785ms", source: /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-bootstrap.js (18)
2014-04-03 17:24:41.068 Atom[57544:12d03] Download completed to: file:///Users/garentorikian/Library/Application%20Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.Oicp5uh/download
```

But I guess the temp directory cleans up after itself, because the download is no longer there.
Label: bug

Title: Atom doesn't scroll up as you move a line towards the top
Body:
Halp ticket: support/d73c7e3cb62711e39de3bc5d49e4d3e8

> Hi, when moving lines up by pressing command + ctrl up key, the view does not scroll up as you move to the top of the current view.

True story, just tested this. :up: 

More tickets:
- support/562b9850bf4111e39edb10b02703bd69
- support/29650c3ec48c11e3893e3708689e9f8c
Label: bug

Title: Paste with formatting
Body:
When I paste a snippet of code that has indentation I want my editor to be smart enough to correctly indent things for me.
### Example 1

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/clipboard.coffee
2. Copy some indented text but on the first line just go to the beginning of the text, not the beginning of the line
3. Paste the text into Atom at an indentation level different than what it should be indented at

![](http://cl.ly/image/3G1A3u3P043a/paste.gif)

When you go across windows it loses the indentation magic.

![](http://cl.ly/image/1R0T2J0j111z/paste2.gif)

Title: Support native browser copy operation for non-editor text
Body:
People expect to be able to copy selected text from subclasses of `ScrollView`. We could suggest they always use the `native!` binding, but I think we can do better. I can think of two options:
1. Copy text based on the current browser-level selection when a copy command reaches the top of the workspace.
2. Invoke the browser's native copy behavior when a copy command reaches the root of the workspace.
Label: enhancement

Title: CSS selectors are insufficient replacements for TextMate scope selectors
Body:
We've borrowed TextMate's scope selector concept, but since we're a web-based editor, we've gone with CSS syntax rather than TextMate's proprietary scope selector syntax to blend in with the web.

Unfortunately, CSS on its own doesn't fully support the concept of a scope. CSS is focused on identifying _individual_ elements, whereas scope selectors are focused on identifying _subtrees_ of the document, which could include multiple elements.

We've attempted to encode TextMate's `-` operator using `:not` pseudoclasses, but it falls down. Say we're describing the following TextMate scope in CSS:

```
text.html .meta.tag - entity.other.attribute-name
```

This basically says, I want this to match inside HTML tags, _except_ for inside attribute names. We attempt to translate it to the following incorrect CSS selector:

```
.text.html .meta.tag:not(.entity.other.attribute-name)
```

Say we're matching against the following scope chain:

```
.text.html .meta.tag .entity.other.attribute-name
```

We first try matching the `attribute-name`, which fails because no selector matches, so we pop it. Then we try to match the `meta.tag`, and this _does_ match, regardless of the negation.

So you see that TextMate's `-` operator really can't be encoded with negation. It's operating on subtrees, whereas `:not` operates on individual elements.
Label: enhancement

Title: We should give deference to system-level menu shortcuts
Body:
support/0979ef84aac411e39eff76f26af6d7ef#C4

If a user assigns `cmd-m` to zoom, we still end up assigning it to minimize. The window menu then has two menu items with the same shortcut, and `cmd-m` still causes minimize.

Maybe we should do the following:
Get a report of all _system-defined_ shortcuts for the window.
Avoid loading bindings from `darwin.cson` that conflict with these shortcuts.

Seems like we need to add the menu items without bindings, get a report of what bindings map to which commands, then add the bindings for all items that don't conflict.
Label: bug

Title: Atom needs a better security model
Body:
If we're going to add GitHub integration to Atom, we need to cache credentials inside the app. We had previously implemented GitHub auth for our Gists package, but we removed both the package and GitHub authentication from the beta release because we were afraid of providing GitHub credentials to every random Atom package people installed. We can't avoid this forever, though. To realize Atom's full potential, we need to solve the security issue in a robust way.
### What would the ideal security model look like?
- Every package is loaded in its own context.
- Every package's metadata includes a whitelist of the following:
  - Security-critical properties of the `atom` global requested by the package.
  - Security-critical built-in modules (such as `fs`) requested by the package.
  - Whether the package is allowed to load custom native modules.
  - GitHub permissions the package needs access to and any other credentials.
- When installing a package, the requested permissions are clearly presented.
- If a package attempts to reference or require a resource that isn't white-listed, the user will be explicitly prompted to grant the package that permission.
### How can we implement this?

There's a fairly mature project called [Google Caja](https://developers.google.com/caja/), whose goal is to allow multiple mutually-suspicious JavaScript modules to run on the same page securely. To support older versions of JavaScript, they employed a complex whole-program transformation to achieve this. But ES5 incorporates several standard features that allow a context to be secured by running a small JavaScript library called [SES](https://code.google.com/p/es-lab/wiki/SecureEcmaScript) (short for Secure ECMAScript).

My understanding is still evolving, but it seems like we should be able to run the SES script in a fresh context to tamper-proof any globals that we inject into it and secure them from malicious modification or any other kind of privilege escalation. To do this, we'd basically need to provide our own alternative module loading mechanism, which I  started experimenting with this weekend with a fork of Node's built-in `module.js`.
### What if we miss something?

Security is tough because you only have to screw up once to get exploited. We probably will make a few mistakes. But based on my reading about ES5 and the Caja project, security should be possible in theory. If we implement a security model that leaks, we can fix the problems as we discover them. But if we don't even try then things will never be secure. I think it's worth trying, then subjecting our best effort to an internal and possible external audit.
### What haven't I thought of?

This is all new territory for me. Let me know what I'm missing.

/cc @github/security @zcbenz @ptoomey3
Label: enhancement

Title: Cursor blinking gets out of sync after expanding selection with ctrl-cmd-g
Body:
support/d54136a0a43311e3864cea6b683823bd
# What's the bug?

When I select some text and expand the selection to all other occurences of that original selected text (using Ctrl-Cmd-G), the cursor from the original selection flashes out of sync with the others. I've noticed that this happens intermittently.
# How to reproduce the bug
1. Copy and paste the example text below in a new Atom tab.
2. Toggle soft-wrap from the View menu (just to make it more easy to see).
3. Select two random characters that occur more than once in the text (e.g., the "em" from "Lorem ...").
4. Press Ctrl-Cmd-G to expand the selection to all other occurences of those two characters in the text.
5. Notice that the cursor from the original selection (e.g., the "em" from "Lorem ...") flashed out of sync from the other cursors.
6. I've noticed that this happens intermittently. If you don't see the out-of-sync flashing on the first time, repeat steps 3 through 5 ten more times. You should see it happen.
# Video Demo

I might as well include a quick video demo of the bug, in case you can't reproduce it. You can see it here: http://recordit.co/VKRa3e
# Example text

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nullam vestibulum luctus arcu, ac suscipit sapien viverra vel. Maecenas lorem nisl, viverra in sodales ut, vehicula sit amet augue. Morbi a turpis ipsum. Fusce ultricies justo non ligula semper quis gravida leo sodales. Aliquam posuere, ipsum at molestie ullamcorper, mi lectus commodo elit, ut tempus diam dolor sed nisi. Mauris vel tortor libero. Aliquam ultrices lacus sit amet felis aliquam eget malesuada erat rhoncus. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos himenaeos. Title: Open file in current window
Body:
Seems reasonable

> cmd-o AND file -> open is always opening a new window, there is a separate command for that. It's quite the nuisance. <3

---

> This is perhaps a BIG one that undermines the foundation of Atom...but I find it quite irritating after coming from Sublime: I would like to be able to drag random files into a project/Atom instance so I can reference code side–by–side. Currently if I drag a random file from the finder into an Atom instance it automatically opens a new instance with the folder containing that file as the project root. Since I like to code in fullscreen, this means switching between a number of fullscreen Atom instances to look at or copy snippets of code. This isn't a particularly desirable workflow.

_(from https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1721)_

... 

> Suppose that I open atom in my home directory. The working directory shown on the left is my home directory.
> Now if I want to open a file that is not in the working directory then Atom opens a new window with that file and its directory. Same thing happens if I want to open a third file that is outside of those two working directories.

...

> I'm coming from Sublime Text 2 and the default behavior there is every file in a new window. There is a configuration file that can be tweaked to make all files open in the same window.

...

> I, too, would love to have files open in a new tab. It is absolutely crucial to my workflow. In the meantime I will continue using Sublime Text for this reason alone.

...

> This is probably my single biggest annoyance and the reason why I can't use Atom full time. 

_(from https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2005)_

Also related issues:
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/770 - Multiple folders in projects
- https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/63 - Add option to configure multiple root folders in tree-view
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom crashed
Body:
So Atom just crashed on me.

I was trying to update Bracket Matcher. I didn't see an update available via the Settings view, so using @kevinsawicki's [suggestion](https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/issues/7#issuecomment-36926407), I updated the package via command line. Then I switched back to Atom, and it didn't appear to have been updated (the view for the package in Preferences still showed version `0.23.0`), so I restarted.

Once I restarted, I got a blank screen, and then this: ![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319791/2350670/5bb32f82-a573-11e3-9a01-af14b8a99d15.png)

Then moments later, OS X Problem Reporter, which generated [this report](https://gist.github.com/jglovier/c376ed285cc87dbeb107).
Label: bug

Title: Make word regex language specific
Body: As is discussed in atom/autocomplete#13, for a language like CSS, a `-` character needs to be considered part of a word. Allowing the word regex to be overridden with a syntactic scope would allow the autocompleter to work more intuitively in CSS.
Label: enhancement

Title: Provide a "untrusted html view".
Body:
In addition to [locking down iframes](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/193#issuecomment-36634975) and [enabling CSP](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1682) I think it might be nice to provide a top level API that extensions can use to render HTML safely.  Extensions such as markdown-preview take a string of HTML and render it in a div within the main Atom UI.  As a result, the HTML is rendered in the same context as the rest of Atom (with Node integration).  While CSP should mitigate much of the risk associated with this, it doesn't totally solve the "render untrusted HTML" issue.  For example, user content could potentially still break the DOM of the main Atom app. So, we could just ask that markdown-preview use a sandboxed iframe to minimize the issues that could arise from rendering user provided content.  But, I was thinking it might be a nice API primitive if we allowed any extension to hand us a string of HTML and we render it for them. I'm not sure how extensible this would need to be (ex. does the rendered HTML inherit CSS styles from the outer frame, etc), but it does seem like a nice security API.

@kevinsawicki @mcolyer @nathansobo @gregose @mastahyeti
Label: enhancement

Title: Enable CSP by default
Body:
XSS in Atom can directly lead to local command execution on a user's machine. So, in addition to fixing the specific instances we identify, we really need to find an additional line of defense to protect Atom users. I have had it enabled since yesterday and have not really noticed any issues other than a few errors in the debug console related to jQuery feature detection. I ran all the Atom specs and nothing seems to have broken. So, this seems like a good path to go down before we leave beta. I think CSP combined with [locking down iframe security](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/193) should get us in a much better spot regarding security.  

@zcbenz @kevinsawicki @gregose @mastahyeti
Label: enhancement

http://spotvin.com/atombug.mov

Body:
I opened a Python file with the following line (#963):

``` python
                    PrintAndLog(u"SSID: " + RememberedNetwork["SSIDString"].decode("utf-8") + u" - BSSID: " + RememberedNetwork["CachedScanRecord"]["BSSID"] + u" - RSSI: " + str(RememberedNetwork["CachedScanRecord"]["RSSI"]) + u" - Last connected: " + str(RememberedNetwork["LastConnected"]) + u" - Security type: " +  RememberedNetwork["SecurityType"] + u" - Geolocation: " + Geolocation, "INFO")
```

Which led to the following bug:
![screen shot 2014-03-03 at 2 52 40 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/2313778/76bb4bba-a30d-11e3-9a64-81f6f91c25c4.png)

Title: Dvorak - Qwerty ⌘ support
Body:
I've been typing in Dvorak for a long time and have come to rely on the Dvorak - Qwerty ⌘ keyboard layout on OS X. This layout is nice because it not only allows me to type in Dvorak, but it also allows me to use Qwerty keyboard shortcuts while holding down the ⌘ key. Unfortunately, the latter does not work as expected in Atom.

Would you consider adding support for this?

/cc @benburkert
Label: enhancement

Title: Add screenRangeForTokenElement?
Body:
http://github.com/madebysource/atom-color-highlighting

He's trying to hide the color highlighting when the selection hits one of the highlighted objects. A little info about this project:
- he's searching for all the `.numeric.css` and similar nodes on each `editor:display-updated` event
- he is setting background color on each one of these elements
- he wants to unhighlight them when the selection hits them
- the idea is for each node to check if in a selection, then render/not (could be slow??)

This might be better served with marker views. Then we could just z-index them lower than the selection. They might not be fast enough, though.
Label: enhancement

Title: Restore state after restart (and/or reboot of the machine?)
Body:
Something like Chrome does would be ideal, but I'm not super picky. Also, this is pretty low priority for me so consider this issue me planting a seed for a future date where you'll have the time to work on it ;)

The title is a bit misleading given what I _actually_ would love to have - But very specifically, upon reboot (in OSX at the very least) it would be _amazing_ to have Atom remember which directories/projects and which files I had open scrolled to whatever position I left them.

If I remember correctly, I'm pretty sure we already keep track of and possibly even already serialize this state, somewhere. If so, I'd love to be able to reboot my machine and have Atom reopen right where I left off.
Label: enhancement

I don't think you can take a screenshot of the cursor, so here's some crazy photos.  Top is Atom, bottom is Sublime.  Both are using a dark solarized theme.

Title: Allow the gutter to show relative line numbers
Body: https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/issues/54#issuecomment-36278523
Label: enhancement

Title: Define additional variables in syntax-variables.less
Body:
@benogle and I think `syntax-variables.less` we should define:
- cursor-color
- selection-color
- text-color
- background-color

So that plugins can choose appropriate colors that will have the proper contrast and avoid the white on white problem as seen in atom/solarized-light-syntax#2 (and various other tickets).

Every syntax theme will need to override them so we'll need to update the docs as well explaining this.
Label: bug

Title: Source map support for stylesheets
Body: I was looking through the history #1448 looks like coffeescript got sourcemap support. I would love to see support for sourcemap stylesheets.
Label: enhancement

Title: No more character by character undo
Body:
https://twitter.com/gnb/status/439155269432774657

Use a debouncer or something. SImilar to the way `content-edited` event works.
Label: enhancement

Title: Reopen windows when relaunching Atom
Body:
A feature I love about ST2 and iA Writer, which I'm missing in Atom, is when you quit the app with open windows (including unsaved documents), they all appear again when you reopen. 

This has saved me countless times in my workflow to handle having to do a system restart for software update, etc and not have to take time to save all my unsaved docs, etc. 

It's also nice because I generally have five or six open projects that I just keep minimized in the editor for ease of access. It would be great to have such a feature in Atom.
Label: enhancement

Title: open new file on double click in tab blank space
Body:
One of the features of the ST2 interface that I miss is being able to double click the blank area of a nav bar beside the tab to get a new file.

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319791/2287621/20e63108-9fef-11e3-8ffe-6152601d5290.png)

Title: display file location on tab hover AND context click
Body:
I love that you can view a file's location when hovering on the tab, but waiting for things to appear on hover is not the strong suit of most devs I know. :smile:

Seems context click (two finger, right click, etc) is not being used for anything on tabs currently, what do you think about adding support for displaying that info on both hover AND context click?

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319791/2287616/15a257b8-9fef-11e3-85df-4c9ea60c100e.png)

5. Got the "Editor not responding" error sheet.

Body:
@jglovier reported the following problem running apm as installed by Atom. I'm not sure what's going on, but I'm wondering if we're trying to run apm with a system-installed Node but loading a version of `keytar` that's compiled against atom-shell's Node?

```
joels-air:~ joelglovier$ apm help publish

/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/keytar/node_modules/bindings/bindings.js:83
        throw e
              ^

    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)

Title: Locking up.
Body:
Atom locks up a number of times per day for me. Oh man is it frustrating.

This might be hard to reproduce, but it's pretty consistent for me with these steps. I have no idea if any of these things actually contribute, but do them.
1. Open a repo with a bunch of markdown and an edited file. 
2. cmd+t an edited markdown file with long lines
3. cmd+p -> soft wrap
4. edit the file a bit
5. click on another file in the tree view to open it
6. Freeze!

You might have to edit -> click to open -> close the file -> click to open a few times to get it to happen.
Label: bug

Title: Any method with a comment is added to the public API
Body: I'm not sure if this is an Atom or Biscotto error, but any method with a comment is put into the public API. For example: [Project::eachEditor](https://github.com/github/atom/blob/v0.51.0/src/project.coffee#L326) is in the [API docs](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.51.0/api/classes/Project.html#eachEditor-instance).
Label: bug

Title: Syntax parsing gets tricked on some values
Body: For example, in this LESS file, take `overflowElipsis` for instance. It should be wrapped with `span.property-name`, but is getting parsed as: ``` overflowElipsis ``` ![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1319791/2223466/ae802bd6-9a72-11e3-9739-3d24af90080a.png) The result is that syntax highlighting doesn't work right. There are a few other instances I've caught: - text-overflow should be wrapped in .property-name, but gets broken into `span.property-value + span.operator + span.property-name` - `100%` as a property value should all be wrapped in span.constant.numeric, and ideally the span around `%` should be a child, but instead they are siblings (granted, that one might be a bit idealistic)
Label: bug

Title: Atom should fail gracefully if `core.themes` references a theme that doesn't exist
Body: I advised @jglovier to move his in-progress theme out of `~/.atom/packages` when debugging an issue, but the config still pointed at the theme he was working on. This caused Atom to raise an exception.

Log a message about this to make it more clear.

Title: I'm refactoring. I press cmd-shift-f, type some characters, press enter, click on one of the search
Body:
I'm refactoring. I press cmd-shift-f, type some characters, press enter, click on one of the search results, and replace the matching line with a new implementation.

I press cmd-shift-f again, press enter again because it's the only way I can see the search results without tabs, and the old version line I just changed is _still_ in the search results.

Occasionally the results will mix it up by giving me duplicate results for the same match: One with a path relative to the current project root and one with an absolute path.

I've reported this and related issues a few times now without getting much insight. I'd really like to know what I'm doing that makes search usless for me and OK for everybody else. What am I doing wrong?

Atom Version: 0.49.0
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Atom/0.49.0 Atom-Shell/0.8.7 Safari/537.36
Label: bug

Title: Select next instance isn’t working correctly
Body:
Using `cmd + d` to select multiple instances isn’t working correctly for me:

![multi-select-fail](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/2109692/33305c30-8ff5-11e3-99fb-cbc4fdcf42d6.gif)

Note that the first two selections work fine, but when it goes to find the third instance of `h3`, it instead ends up selecting a linebreak or two and an angle bracket `<` immediately prior to the next instance of `h3`.

Also note that repeating the command again after the third (incorrect) selection _skips the next three instances_ of `h3` (the closing tag of the "Payload" heading, and both occurances of the "Headers" heading), and repeats the same incorrect selection on the next `h3` opening tag.
Label: bug

Title: Save project state periodically
Body: The other day I had 4 panes and 2 dozen tabs open representing a particulary dumb / complicated refactor. Then my laptop hard locked. After rebooting and reopening the editor, I was presented with zero panes and zero tabs. This ruined my afternoon. We should probably save project state periodically rather than just on quit, as I only have so many laptops to throw out the window before I run out.
Label: enhancement

Title: Build sizes are too big
Body: Atom's size jumped to over 300mb.

Title: Spell check does not work
Body:
Or I'm doing something terribly wrong. I've noticed this for a while now, and figured the key bindings had changed, but today finally broke down and looked them up, and I fear spell check may be a bit off.
## Bug 1: Bad keybindings
### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a markdown file
2. Misspell a word
3. See that it's misspelled (red underline)
4. Press `cmd-:`, which per preferences is spell check
### Expected
- Context menu comes up with spelling suggestions
### Actual
- Nothing
### The Screenshot

![screen shot 2014-02-05 at 10 43 17 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/282759/2088535/41831eaa-8e7c-11e3-9894-18ae01f47e5c.png)
## Bug 2: Suggestion menu doesn't correct the word
### Steps to reproduce
1. Repeat steps 1-3 above to set up
2. Press `cmd-shift-P` to open the command menu, type "spell" and select "correct misspelling"
3. Suggestions come up as expected
4. See the correction is highlighted
5. Press enter to select
### Expected
- Word corrected
### Actual
- Line break inserted at cursor
### The Gif

![atom](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/282759/2088514/1762ade8-8e7c-11e3-9dc1-3e31f43d913c.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Add syntax/ui metadata to theme's package.json
Body:
Perhaps just reuse the `theme` key with:

``` json
{ "theme": "ui" }
```

``` json
{ "theme": "syntax" }
```

Or add a new `themeType` field.

Something needs to happen since the settings view just checks the theme name for this info which causes issues for themes with neither `ui` or `syntax` in their name.

Any thoughts @probablycorey  ?
Label: enhancement

Title: Both search and cmd-T continue to be intermittently unreliable for me any time file manipulation is
Body:
Both search and cmd-T continue to be intermittently unreliable for me any time file manipulation is happening outside the editor, especially when files are moved into place via the terminal (a simple file move, create, or git stash pop). Not sure how to be more detailed here without spending a ton of time on it.

I suspect this has to do with the number of files in the project since I see it happen a lot more with github/github.

Project find is still trolling me hard, frequently showing old content and deleted/moved files. It's also still a pain to bounce back and forth without tabs turned on. If there's already a "Project Find Results" "tab" open, why do I have to hit <enter> in the panel as if I'm searching again?

Atom Version: 0.48.0
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Atom/0.48.0 Atom-Shell/0.8.5 Safari/537.36

Title: Don't ask me if I want to reload a file, especially if I haven't made any changes
Body:
Can't seem to find the relevant code, but as of version 0.48.0, this dialog started popping up:

![screen shot 2014-01-31 at 11 53 11 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/282759/2052521/43c94d02-8a98-11e3-9fb1-0a08760e30b8.png)

Imagine this not-unlikely scenario:
1. Open up a bunch of files
2. Make some changes
3. Commit, push, pull request
4. Change branches

I then have to click "reload" for each open file, even those with no changes since the last save.

Not sure if it's a bug or if there's rationale (cool if so), but here's what I'd expect: if the file's changed on disk and I haven't touched it in Atom, just reload the thing. If something's changed, perhaps prompt me when I focus on that tab to prevent confirmation bombardment.
Label: bug

Title: Recreate template ~/.atom files when opened and non-existent

Title: Soft-wrap incorrectly applied to buffer with weird results
Body:
I have no idea how I got into this situation, but it’s a strange one. In the following `.gif`, what I’m doing is simply pressing the left arrow key repeatedly.

![2014-01-21 at 5 38 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1966105/64be3a40-82c3-11e3-8d14-7d6a20a821d3.png)

Note the following:
- When the cursor reaches the start of the initial line, the next leftwards movement jumps up an incorrect number of lines (should go immediately above).
- In the gutter, the soft-wrap indicator dots (if that’s what they are?) and line-numbers are completely out-of-sync with the contents of the editor’s buffer. For example, if I attempt to click my cursor onto the word "Sorry" a couple of lines above the one labelled as line 23, the cursor jumps to the end of the line labelled as line 12.
- (Not shown in the gif) I can’t click my cursor into any of the text with a dot in the line’s gutter. Doing so results in the cursor jumping upwards to the nearest line with a number in it’s gutter.

I’ve had soft-wrap enabled by default for a good week or so now, and haven’t run into any problems until now. I have no idea what combination of things led my editor into this state.
Label: bug

Title: Overwriting default keyboard commands is confusing
Body:
If I want to overwrite `ctrl-a` I have to make an overly specific selector (`.platform-darwin .editor` instead of just `.editor`)

![keymap cson - _users_corey_ atom](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/596/1965638/c6a1d372-82bc-11e3-895b-e8c9820d09ce.jpg)

I propose we get rid of the `.platform-darwin` selector and instead use filenames to selectively load keymaps. So all OS X specific binding files would end in `darwin` or `osx` and all windows specific binding files would end in `windows`
Label: bug

Title: Need spinner for long delayed actions
Body:
Today I did a regex find and replace on a 600 line document in which there were 600 matches. The action took approximately 8-10 seconds at which time Atom was completely locked up. While I'm a patient person, I did have a moment of "is it taking a while or has it crashed?". I'm not sure if it's possible but could we show a spinner for long actions like that?

Since the entire UI locked up, I'm guessing that we can't do it but I figured I'd mention it here.

- Take a heap snapshot

Title: Cursor being placed inappropriately when pressing down
Body:
## Atom Version

0.43.0
## Behavior Expected

When pressing the down arrow while at the end of a line, the cursor should be placed at the end of the line below it.
## Behavior Observed

When pressing down at the end of the last line in a css rule or the last line of a java method, the cursor is placed before the closing } instead of after.

![before-not-after](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/152198/1729539/f2fa416c-62c2-11e3-9047-e6ad6cf7e738.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Unindenting html tags
Body:
## Atom version

0.43.0
## Behavior expected

Pressing return should have no affect on the indentation of a closing html tag that's already correctly indented.
## Behavior observed

When closing an html tag on the line below the opening tag, it is automatically indented to match the opening tag like so:

![screen shot 2013-12-11 at 3 25 53 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/152198/1729196/15dcdb56-62bc-11e3-9fdd-0c238245b283.png)

However, if you position the cursor before the closing tag and press return, the tag un-indents itself like so:

![screen shot 2013-12-11 at 3 26 00 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/152198/1729203/2fb73aee-62bc-11e3-830a-09cc9ce45ea3.png)

and the process will repeat itself until the closing tag reaches the left-edge of the buffer:

![screen shot 2013-12-11 at 3 26 05 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/152198/1729207/40beee4a-62bc-11e3-8d19-e073aead0db9.png)
Label: bug

I then positioned my cursor before the first h1 tag and pressed return which removed the < before the h1 and left the html looking like so:

Title: Save tree view scroll position on close
Body: What do you think about adding the ability to save the scrolled position in the tree view when Atom is closed, so when that project is reopened you are back to where you were when you closed? Currently it saves which folders were opened, which is nice, but saving the position scrolled down in the view, especially on large projects could be a nice touch.
Label: enhancement

Title: Move by paragraph
Body: In emacs, `forward-paragraph` and `backward-paragraph` are super handy, and in native OS X text areas, something very similar is mapped to opt-down and opt-up. This moves the cursor to the end of the current paragraph - in code (in emacs) these are delineated by newlines that are empty or only whitespace, and wrapped prose in native textareas, by newlines. Is there something like this available in Atom? If not, it might be worth adding to the platform keybindings for os x.
Label: enhancement

Title: Serialized markers are unserialized at the bottom of the buffer
Body:
You can see this in bookmarks:
1. Make a bookmark.
2. Reload the editor
3. See bookmark at the bottom of the buffer. Why?

My assumption is that the buffer is reloaded / set again after the markers are deserialized. If anyone has any insight into this, lemmie know. I'm going to dig in a bit. 

atom/bookmarks#3
Label: bug

Title: Handle installation of `atom` script for users without system privilege
Body:
This came out of the discussion on #1226 and it became clear that we don't handle the case well where users don't have proper permissions. 

Either we can ask for additional privileges or provide a way to put it in their custom path (like `~/bin`), not sure which is the best approach here.

Derived from https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1195

something do |<cursor here>|

response.each do${1/(^(?<var>\s*[a-z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*\s*)(,\g<var>)*,?\s*$)|.*/(?1: |)/}variable${1/(^(?<var>\s*[a-z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*\s*)(,\g<var>)*,?\s*$)|.*/(?1:|)/}

end
```

Several other tab completion things do the same in ruby.

Title: How can I have two consistent panes?
Body:
I don't think this is a bug, but I'm not sure where to ask. I use my editor with two side-by-side panes. For me, **structure** of my editor (the fact that it's divided up into two panes, split vertically, or the fact that I've disabled the treeview and tabs) has _nothing to do_ with the **contents** of it (the open buffers). I manage them separately. When things are working smoothly I don't manage them at all.

Atom seems like it continues to tie the idea of splits, etc to the idea of buffers, and I don't understand why. I'm consistently frustrated by this, whether it's an inability to manage panes when there are no open buffers, an inability to unsplit panes, or the fact that a pane disappears when its last buffer is closed.

I feel like we've talked this over a ton of times, but things don't feel any different than they did nine months ago.
Label: enhancement
