Title: Proposal: add a way for packages to communicate with one another
Body:
I added an API to the status-bar. Other packages that want to use the status bar have a bit of an awkward time getting a handle on the `statusBar` object. For reference see: https://github.com/atom/grammar-selector/pull/2 Here's how it works now:

In the status bar, I do this:

``` coffeescript
statusBar = new StatusBarView()
atom.rootView.statusBar = statusBar
```

And in the package using status-bar:

``` coffeescript
# This is dumb:
createStatusEntry = ->
  view = new GrammarStatusView(atom.rootView.statusBar)
  atom.rootView.statusBar.appendLeft(view)

if atom.rootView.statusBar
  createStatusEntry()
else
  atom.packages.once 'activated', ->
    createStatusEntry()
```

I dont want to have every package author that wants to use something to the status bar to have to do this.
### Proposal

I want to have some mechanism in one of the readily available objects (`atom`, `rootView`) for storage/retrieval of arbitrary objects. This is generally what I want to do:

In status-bar

``` coffeescript
statusBar = new StatusBarView()
atom.rootView.setChild('statusBar', statusBar)
```

In the package that uses status-bar

``` coffeescript
atom.rootView.getChild 'statusBar', (statusBar) ->
  view = new GrammarStatusView(atom.rootView.statusBar)
  atom.rootView.statusBar.appendLeft(view)
```

If `statusBar` is already there, it calls the callback, or it waits til `statusBar` is available.

I have no idea what to call these functions, and have no preference which object it should hang from.

Feedback, please.
Label: enhancement

Title: Getting into state where some files will not open
Body:
Occasionally I am getting into a state where I can click on a file any number of times in the tree view and it will not open. It will also not open using command p so it seems like the underlying file open is actually having issues, not tree view specifically. When this happens, other files will open. It only seems to effect some of them.

No error pops up but if I look at the console there are errors that happen each time I click on one of the files that will not open.

![screen shot 2013-11-19 at 4 47 02 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/235/1576973/37c8cc52-5164-11e3-8f1d-a056bbd9da9d.png)

Title: Softwrap should match indent
Body:
Ok, this one may be a personal preference, but it drives me nuts that softwrap doesn't match the indent.

![screen shot 2013-11-18 at 5 18 17 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/72919/1568843/7c5b0c10-50b8-11e3-961b-0650f94008c4.png)

Title: Softwrap unindents, drops the line
Body:
Lines 6 and 7 are soft wrapped, which is forcing them down a line and lines them up with the left side, regardless of indent depth.

![screen shot 2013-11-18 at 5 03 40 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/72919/1568699/722fd790-50b6-11e3-9dc1-a0a8b69d5aa2.png)
Label: bug

Title: begin/end of line movements don't respect wrapped lines
Body:
1. Enable soft wrap.
2. Write a long line. Wrap over a few visual lines.
3. Press `ctrl-a`.

I expect the cursor to move to the beginning of the _wrapped_ line. Instead, it moves to the beginning of the current _visual_ line. Same thing happens for `ctrl-b` and for `cmd-{left,right}arrow`.
Label: bug

Title: Can't split up/down
Body:
When I try to do a split up/split down in the view, all that happens is the dev tools open up:

`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'getState' of undefined /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:80`
Label: bug

Title: Pasting JS Object properties
Body: Try pasting magic words like `constructor` or `toString` that are properties on a JS object. You get weird output. I'm assuming Atom is taking the clipboard and doing `cache[pasteText]` somewhere which is returning a built in function.
Label: bug

Title: Remove use of emissary namespaces
Body: I'm coming to the conclusion that emissary namespaces are an anti-pattern, and we should use the `Subscriber` mixin instead of strings to unsubscribe. The namespaces complicate the code and too often lead to unexpected behavior.
Label: enhancement

Title: Renderer process sometimes doesn't terminate when quiting
Body:
After quitting Atom, the renderer process sometimes still keeps running, the main thread seems to be waiting for something:

```
wow64cpu.dll!TurboDispatchJumpAddressEnd+0x598

ntdll.dll!LdrInitShimEngineDynamic+0x2383
ntdll.dll!memset+0x11ca4
ntdll.dll!LdrInitializeThunk+0xe
ntdll.dll!NtWaitForSingleObject+0xc
KERNELBASE.dll!WaitForSingleObject+0x12
atom.exe!uv_thread_join+0x12
atom.exe!?Initialize@Buffer@node@@SAXV?$Handle@VObject@v8@@@v8@@@Z+0x111aa2
atom.exe!?Initialize@Buffer@node@@SAXV?$Handle@VObject@v8@@@v8@@@Z+0x106f15
atom.exe!?Initialize@Buffer@node@@SAXV?$Handle@VObject@v8@@@v8@@@Z+0x106175

```

```
$ atom
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.

$ atom .
```

Title: Markdown: wrapped line + **strong** cursor position bug
Body:
1. Turn on line wrapping.
2. Write a line that wraps.
3. After the wrap, add some `**strong**` emphasis

Result: the cursor's displayed position is off by about one character.

![ws2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/39902/1491652/5107f112-47b3-11e3-91f3-8214539f51ec.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Storage serialization inside .atom making dotfiles yucky
Body:
Ok so, I keep .atom in my dotfiles. I keep a dotfiles repo mainly because I have multiple computers. This makes the /storage dir create a mess for me. It makes ~/dotfiles constantly dirty for me, not to mention, I dont really want those things synced across computers.

It'd be nice to see that stuff actually get stored in `~/Library/Application Data/Atom` on OS X. This is where common application data goes, especially device specific things.

A lot of the stuff inside `.atom` would be useful to sync across computers and in dotfiles. This includes app settings, plugins, etc. Environment things. 

It seems to me that state like window size (per project) isn't something anyone would want. Not to mention how often it changes.

I'd love to know if there is consideration being made about `.atom` and people putting it in their dot files. There is currently device specific things in there, as well as things you'd WANT to sync, like settings and plugins. It'd be a shame to just not be able to sync with dotfiles just because of the state that's being saved inside there.
Label: enhancement

Title: Every time I search it errors
Body:
v34.

cmd shift f, enter term, hit <enter>. :boom:
Label: bug

Title: Add an API to disable selectively disable IME dialog
Body:
If a user long presses `l` while in vim-mode an IME dialog appears. We want to keep IME support on by default, but it would be nice to allow vim to disable it while in command mode.

Therefore I propose we adding `editor.setImeVisible(boolean)` to the public API so that packages can control it.

Refs atom/atom-shell#47
Label: enhancement

Title: Pasting pastes twice on windows
Body:
For some reason when pasting using the keyboard things paste twice.

Also the keybindings in general seem really flaky, sometimes `ctrl-s` will work and sometimes it won't.
Label: bug

Title: Open doesn't work sometimes
Body:
If I use command + shift + o to open a directory, sometimes it doesn't open. Not only that, but if it doesn't work and I then go to the command line and use `atom`, that will not open it either. 

Atom seems to get in a stuck state where it thinks that project/dir is open, but it is not and it just fails to open. If I quit and re-open using `atom` it seems to work again.
Label: bug

Title: Biscotto doesn't like object key in editor.coffee
Body:
@gjtorikian can you take a look at https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/editor.coffee#L1723-L1753 and see what's causing biscotto to throw 

```
Cannot parse file /Users/mcolyer/github/atom/src/editor.coffee: Invalid object key
```

(I'd make an issue on biscotto but it's public).
Label: bug

Title: Global find sometimes puts Atom into unstable state
Body:
Sometimes when I bring up the project-wide search pane, type in a query, and hit enter, I wind up with an editor that is missing tabs.

Then once in that state, things start to behave weirdly. Closing the remaining tab that’s open makes the next one in the stack of ones I had open become visible (but not the rest) and so forth. The only thing that seems to fix this problem is quiting Atom, restarting it, and rerunning the search then usually works without a problem. I’ve been running into this about once every 30 minutes or so. Any thoughts on what could be going on?
Label: bug

Title: directories don't include symlink information on windows
Body: Which causes our symlink spec `spec/directory-spec.coffee:74` to fail.
Label: bug

Title: Installing commands fails on windows
Body:
The "install(commandPath, callback)" spec fails and atom fails to install commands when atom is running.

I believe this is related to permission issues.
Label: bug

Title: Launching atom.exe immediately closes stdout/stdin
Body: Currently the executable closes stdout/stdin immediately which makes it difficult to use command line option flags like `-h`. I'm not exactly sure what needs to change to allow this to happen.
Label: bug

Title: Dev tools can only be opened once
Body:
:white_large_square:  On Windows :white_large_square: 
1. Open Atom
2. Select the View > Developer > Toggle Developer Tools menu item
3. Close the Dev tools window
4. Select the View > Developer > Toggle Developer Tools menu item

Dev tools window does not reopen.

/cc @zcbenz
Label: bug

Title: Cannot call method 'replace' of undefined
Body:
I'm getting a lot of errors like the screenshot below. This is on Version 34.0, though I used it a good bit yesterday without a single error.

I've restarted it, and it's doing the same thing.  I haven't seen any particular pattern or activity that triggers it, though, so this may not be very helpful. :(

Title: Bracket matcher and the whitespace stripper dont work in splits
Body:
I run into this all the time.
- split an already open file, and that new editor no longer has ability to strip whitespace or bracket match. 

Maybe something to do with the fact that there is one editsession between the two?
Label: bug

Title: Gutter rendering effed when folds
Body:
![screen shot 2013-10-30 at 4 57 09 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/69169/1442612/c3c9bf10-41c2-11e3-9be5-92e42334e33b.png)
See last fold line. It's not in the right spot. Ugh.

This is cause it doesnt redraw them unless the screen lines change. So if you create new lines above a fold, it will not insert a gutter line num. :poop:
Label: bug

Title: Alignment extension
Body:
When dealing with languages where hashes are really common (Ruby, Puppet, JS), folks tend to like to align the separators used so that scanning is easier.

I'd love an alignment extension so that a single keybinding can turn this:

``` puppet
class { 'elasticsearch::config':
    ensure => $ensure,

    cluster => $cluster,
    user => $user,
    configdir => $configdir,
    datadir => $datadir,
    executable => $executable,
    logdir => $logdir,
    host => $host,
    http_port => $http_port,
    transport_port => $transport_port,
  }
```

into this:

``` puppet
class { 'elasticsearch::config':
    ensure         => $ensure,

    cluster        => $cluster,
    user           => $user,
    configdir      => $configdir,
    datadir        => $datadir,
    executable     => $executable,
    logdir         => $logdir,
    host           => $host,
    http_port      => $http_port,
    transport_port => $transport_port,
  }
```
Label: enhancement

Title: New files on disk don't appear in tree-view
Body: For some reason file events aren't getting through to `tree-view`, as creating a new file on disk doesn't appear in the tree-view.
Label: bug

Title: Saving a new file in windows fails
Body: This is from an anonymous project, when I got to save a file to my desktop it fails. After waiting a while the `editor is not responding` alert appears.
Label: bug

Title: External tasks fail on windows
Body: They seem to be exiting uncleanly but it's unclear as to why. `spell-check`, `git-diff` and `fuzzy-finder` are affected.
Label: bug

Title: Can't open command palette on windows
Body: Meta maps to the windows key in windows. Unfortunately `meta-p` attempts to launch the project in windows 8 and it doesn't launch the command palette.
Label: bug

Title: Windows Installer
Body:
Since things are progressing on getting atom running on Windows we should figure out how we're going to install it. My gut says we should use an exe or an msi but I don't know what the cool kids do these days.

/cc @paulcbetts @aroben @zcbenz ideas about how we should do this?
Label: enhancement

Title: Crashes when all plugins are loaded on windows
Body:
So @kevinsawicki and I are chasing a crash that seems to be memory related. @paulcbetts or @zcbenz any insight here would welcomed.

To trigger the render process crash, just launch atom/master on windows and wait several seconds (everything appears fine until the atom crash dialog appears and the memory usage spikes in taskmgr). 

I can isolate this down to just loading three packages,  `autocomplete`, `archive-view` and `bookmarks`. However if you load these packages independently they work fine.

Unfortunately I can't seem to get a backtrace in windbg because chrome/brightray/atom-shell intercepts the crash before the debugger can grab it. So if I run windbg in `-I` mode it never gets opened. 

The other fun thing is that if you run windbg in the mode where it attaches to all child processes and launch atom from within it the crashes stop happening.

@kevinsawicki also notes that, the packages activate just fine if he activates one package per second using setTimeout.

@aroben suggested disabling breakpad as a way to allow windbg to be called but this is starting to get beyond my current windows abilities.
Label: bug

Title: Paths on Windows
Body:
## We should always use forward slashes

So windows accepts forward and backslashes for folder separators. Linux/OSX only accept forward slashes. Therefore we should always use forward slashes. Unfortunately some APIs in windows return backslashes, we should find all of those cases and convert them to forward slashes so the rest of our path
## Absolute path detection

Looking for `/` at the beginning of the string is no longer sufficient, we should find all of the cases where we do that and make sure that they handle `C:/`
Label: bug

Title: Fork cpplint and coffeelint
Body:
They both use the following in there package.json (which isn't cross-platform):

```
"install": "[ -e lib/commandline.js ] || npm run compile"
```
Label: bug

Title: Add icon for windows
Body: @paulcbetts what would be the best way to handle this?

Title: Cursor x position is miscalculated in certain situations

@benogle: Is something going wrong with the caching for editors that can be created in a hidden/detached state?

Title: Should sign windows executable
Body: Once we have Atom running on windows we should sign it so users don't receive the SmartScreen warning.

Title: Marker.getScreenRange() is empty on top-level folded row
Body:
- Create a marker on a folded row
- `marker.getScreenRange().isEmpty()` returns true

It seems like this should return false. Note this example in find and replace:

![marker-view](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/69169/1403163/013f3bdc-3cef-11e3-9377-25427c4587fb.gif)
Label: bug

Title: Second pass on sublime text keybindings
Body: We almost have parity with the common keybindings, let's clean the rest up.
Label: bug

Title: Atom settings set using the UI are not saved.
Body:
1. Toggle Autosave under Core Settings.
2. In the console verify that `config.get('core.autosave')` is not being toggled.
## What should happen

`config.get('core.autosave')` should reflect the state of the UI.
Label: bug

Title: Every clicked file opens
Body: I imagine this is by design, but it's annoying that every file in the tree that I click gets opened. Being trained on Sublime where you can click view a file without "opening" it, in Atom I tend to end up with a million open tabs just because I'm trying to find something. It'd be nice if a file clicked on only opens if a change is made, or if I double click on it or something.
Label: enhancement

Title: Add some security precautions to package installation
Body:
- [ ] When installing a package, display a warning dialog that describes how packages have the capability of being malicious.
- [x] Link GitHub identities closely with packages (will be easy because everything in the package store will be hosted on GitHub.)
- [x] Ability to flag package as malicious and convey this message to users who have installed package.
- [ ] **Possibly** Log I/O, shelling, keychain access, etc... so people can see what is going on without their knowledge.
Label: enhancement

Title: Show path to file in tooltip on long hover of tab
Body: Sometimes you have several files open in a window and two or more of the tabs share the same file name (e.g., subfolders of examples with many index.html files). Just like Chrome and Sublime (and perhaps other OS X apps?), when you hover of the tab for a couple seconds, we should show additional context. In this case, the full path to the file.
Label: enhancement

Title: Difficult closing Find in file panel when all files are closed
Body:
Open up a file, hit Cmd+F to find something, and then close the file. The find panel stays open and hitting Cmd+F to focus on it either toggle it or close it does nothing.

![screen shot 2013-10-20 at 9 20 51 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/98681/1369887/5cccc17a-3a08-11e3-9688-c97eaca55987.png)
Label: bug

Title: Tab indents 3 levels instead of 1
Body: I've only noticed this in .less files when indenting a nested rule. Instead of indenting another 2 spaces or 1 soft tab, it jumps to 6 spaces (3 soft tabs). Backspacing it erases by the same amount, so I have to manually use space bar to indent nested CSS.
Label: bug

Title: Mysterious 'sers' in path causing errors
Body:
I just updated Atom and am seeing some strange bugs related to saving or interacting with files. When the console refers to a path, it begins with `sers`, and often complains that it can't find that file.

For example:

![](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/4590/1367524/28fbab3c-393a-11e3-8165-708fd203c3c7.png)

You can also see that Atom can't run the markdown preview on a buffer, only a saved file. If that's the case, it might be cool to have some error message somewhere. Is there a status bar on Atom that could contain stuff like that?
Label: bug

Title: Auto-Complete Concepts
Body:
We've had  talks from many about the auto complete in several threads and so I want to toss out some ideas and workout the beta launch experience. @jnunemaker @thedaniel @benogle @nathansobo just a few that have been part of the conversation. 

While I understand @nathansobo does not want the auto-complete menu to show automaticly it seems to be the most common experience and most likely the one we should start with, however, I think if its an issue it should be optioned-off if needed.

I think the auto complete should first show the 'suggested/most used' item inline with the lighter text so that it can be tab completed: 

![](http://c.gr4m.com/image/0A0C0w3I0Q3s/image)

Secondarily we should show (fast) the drop down menu thats accessible using the up/down keys:

![](http://c.gr4m.com/image/1a2e1X110023/image)

If for @nathansobo's situation we want to add a preference to shut off the autocomplete unless keyed that may work also, however, to start I think we make it default as most will be used to this interaction. 

Open for thoughts. and go!
Label: enhancement

Title: Opening double curly quotes troll designers when using Inconsolata
Body:
Feel free to close if this is an issue with Inconsolata, but since installing it on my system, all opening double curly quotes appear to actually be closing double curly quotes.

I'm not even remotely opinionated about typography, and it's driving me crazy. :smile:

![screen shot 2013-10-18 at 6 41 19 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/282759/1364801/7cfc5a46-3846-11e3-8b91-3dcbd9fc62e9.png)
Label: bug

Title: Need a flow for updating non-bundled packages
Body:
When we have an API breaking Atom release, users of non-bundled packages (like vim-mode) don't have the greatest experience. Currently they:
- See an update
- Restart to get the update
- Have a broken editor

We should have some way of ensuring that when we update Atom that we automatically check for updates of packages so that they can have a seamless upgrade experience. At the very least we should auto-disable packages based on the Atom engine field and prompt to update or remove those plugins on start.
Label: enhancement

Title: Silent shell.beep()
Body:
`shell.beep()` is cool, but I prefer mine quiet. MacVim had an option that would flash the screen instead of make a noise. Loved it.

What are the odds the settings page could get an option for 'visual bell'? With CSS transitions it could be much more awesome than MacVim ever was.
Label: enhancement

Title: Prevent duplicates in the system menu
Body: Dupes of label -> command menu items should be gracefully handled.
Label: enhancement

Title: Sometimes soft wrap doesn't work
Body:
Sometimes soft wrap doesn't update itself to reflect changes in the content or side of the window.

In this example, I cannot scroll horizontally, but the content clearly runs off the screen and is not wrapping. I have no idea how I got here honestly—I was just typing stuff and noticed it. Re-opening the file doesn't change that line either, but disabling soft wrap and re-enabling it worked.

![screen shot 2013-10-17 at 2 17 51 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/98681/1356133/ff44eea8-3771-11e3-9192-b3954d3304b9.png)

In another situation, where I had to once again disable and re-enable soft wrap to trigger it, the document doesn't refresh when a pane becomes wider after say hiding the tree view. The soft wrap doesn't take up more of the available space—note the gap on the right of the right pane.

![screen shot 2013-10-17 at 2 26 53 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/98681/1356196/ff7feb06-3772-11e3-9461-3fa383755400.png)
Label: bug

Title: Jump to changes
Body:
Was thinking more about that Git integration we talked about in the interview the other day and this popped into my head.

We have the orange change doodad in the bottom right of every window. It'd be awesome if clicking that triggered a menu with a list of the blocks of changes so you could easily open a file and jump to a change.

Jumping around changes in the entire directory would be fucking fantastic as well.
Label: enhancement

Title: Preferences menu item opens blank document
Body: When all windows are closed and a user clicks on the preferences menu item, a window is opened with a blank document (and not the settings view).
Label: bug

Title: Undo/redo should keep active line in focus
Body:
If you're undoing a change to a specific line, that line should automatically come into visible focus within the window.

Currently Atom doesn't focus on the line with changes being undone—it just does them. This makes for a rather disorienting experience of undoing something, and then trying to find where you just undid that change.
Label: bug

Title: Wrap selection in tag
Body:
This is mostly for HTML, but being able to highlight a selection of text or code and wrap it in an HTML tag is immensely useful.

For example, you write out a sentence and then go back to bold a few words. Snag the phrase to bold, hit a keyboard shortcut (`Ctrl-Shift-W` in Sublime), and insert an HTML in no time.

I also imagine this being useful for Markdown, only in a slightly different flow. Instead of wrapping phrases in tags, you're performing quick text actions. Hitting `Cmd+B` with a phrase selected should wrap it in `**`.
Label: enhancement

Title: Clicking line number should select the entire line
Body: Just like in Sublime, clicking a line number (or perhaps even double clicking it, if there's aversion to this behavior) should select the entire line's contents for easy manipulation.
Label: enhancement

Title: Don't auto-shrink tree view
Body:
Navigating through the tree view that keeps expanding or shrinking is rather annoying, especially if you have some split pane action going on. When I have the tree view open, it's usually not there to get _more_ in the way, but to provide context.

Perhaps I just need to get used to it, but it feels invasive right now.
Label: enhancement

Title: Unicode in strings breaks ERB parsing
Body:
Create a new file with the `.html.erb` extension and switch to `HTML (Ruby - ERB)` using `cmd-shift-L` then enter this as the body: ``` html
Something
``` The `"name"` in `class="name"` should be highlighted but isn't: ![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/1346553/bfb04fc4-36a1-11e3-8e38-ce77cb640dac.png) If you remove the "…" from "something…", everything works as expected: ![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/1346556/c6bd9ede-36a1-11e3-8a7f-dc6afe6ab44f.png)
Label: bug

Title: Files with large extremely long lines cause hangs
Body:
May be a known issue, but files with large embedded images such as github's public/enterprise/maintenance.html will often cause Atom to freeze (MacVim actually struggles as well). 

Seems some of them (github's public/maintenance.html for instance) work fine when in soft wrap mode, or until you move your cursor to the long line when out of soft wrap.
Label: bug

Title: Tab indents way too far, requires lots of backspacing
Body:
Encountered this when working in a nested `link_to` block. Might be a bug with the way indentation is handled inside ERB?

![atom-tab-indent-bug](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1338248/90e27406-35e3-11e3-9597-44505c326607.gif)

Basically it was just predictably indenting way too far each time I hit `tab`. I haven’t been able to reproduce it since restarting Atom :frowning:
Label: bug

Title: Capitalized string mess with syntax highlighting
Body:
No idea if this is the right place for this bug or not (is there a package that does the highlighting? is it the responsibility of each theme?), but I’ve run into this bug a couple of times recently.

This code seems to highlight correctly:

![2013-10-15 at 10 36 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1338145/d7fd3044-35e1-11e3-8634-ae9239bd5f84.png)

Now, if I change the "e" from the "edit" string of the link to a capital "E", it seems to interpret it as a constant or something and ignore the closing quotemark as the end of what should be green text for the string contents:

![2013-10-15 at 10 37 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1338157/0c96e296-35e2-11e3-9e1e-9b2bf71df334.png)

Note that:
- The internal string "Edit" turns purple.
- Everything else after the string turns green.

In a more real-world-sized partial, this is pretty annoying:

![2013-10-15 at 10 38 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1338169/5073a7e2-35e2-11e3-9d89-543c4e4339ab.png)

I also noticed this in a plain Ruby file on the weekend too:

![2013-10-15 at 10 40 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/1338191/c6daa28c-35e2-11e3-890d-36f1e95e33a5.png)
Label: bug

Title: Installed Packages show up in Available Packages
Body:
The Available packages tab seems to show all packages, installed and not. Notice Autocomplete and Autoflow:

![packages](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/47749/1335055/cb1681b6-35b2-11e3-944a-8f47f09d3c09.gif)

This may be by design, but I found it a little confusing. I expected Installed to be what I have installed and Available to be the ones I haven't yet installed. Basically: "What I got" and "Let's go shopping!"
Label: bug

Title: Error'ed tab issues with CSS in an ERB
Label: bug

Title: core.ignoredNames complete?
Body: The documentation indicates that this isn't fully implemented. Is that still true?
Label: bug

Title: "Non-native" Fullscreen on OSX?
Body:
This is not a huge priority and may even be a "wontfix" (which is completely ok)

Currently when using Fullscreen in Atom it does what nearly every Mac app does post 10.7, creates a new space, and goes full screen over there. 

This is a bummer since it kills your second screen, and any cmd-tabs will cause screens to flip back and forth. Also can't have a browser, Chat, or what have you up side by side with it, etc.

MacVim has this as an option (which I keep off): 
![advanced 2013-10-14 16-13-08](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/47749/1328928/0a8f68ea-350d-11e3-93ba-64df6da09eeb.jpg)

Is it possible to have this in Atom or even just something like it in my ~/.atom/user.coffee?

Totally recognize that this is a little finicky. :grin:
Label: enhancement

In looking into the shortcuts/discoverability and such I want to toss out the idea of 'disconnecting' the command pallets from the top bar as your using. I often times currently the pallet conflicts with the tabs etc on top and makes it less ideal to read/access.

This is an attached wireframe (that we'll theme/design according to their UI prefrence) similar to AlfredApp's concepts. I've shown both command and file pallets: 

Thoughts?

Title: Support for vim-style insert transactions
Body:
Vim has the interesting property that insertions are actually transactions. Batches of typing can be repeated, undone, and generally messed with atomically. For example:

`2iabc<esc>` will enter insert mode, let you type `abc`, and when you leave insert mode, `abc` will appear a second time, having been entered twice.

Much more usefully:

`iabc<esc><move around>.` will enter insert mode, type `abc`, leave insert mode, move to a new location, and repeat the last insert at the new location. Great for things like strings in tests.

I poked around at adding this tonight. Up in vim-mode land it's actually not that complicated, but  I ran into the weeds when I started to look at the telepath library SharedString underlying text buffers. It sure looks like these classes are just _aching_ to support this kind of thing, what with their patches and transactions, but the transactions I see in the undo history are all associated with particular locations.

Is it possible to expose the concept of patches somehow? Something like 'apply the patch in undo location `n` to the current cursor location'?
Label: enhancement

Title: Upon initial file load, soft wrap does not wrap until window is resized when soft wrap is enabled globally
Body:
Possibly related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/858, if you enable soft wrap globally, it does not wrap upon opening a new file until the window is resized.
### Steps to reproduce in Atom 31.0:
1. Toggle soft wrap via preferences (not meta-p)
2. Open a file which would require soft wrap, such as a markdown file
### Expected

Dat soft wrap goodness
### Actual

Text goes beyond the right margin, resizing the window restores the expected behavior.
Label: bug

Title: Native Menu's
Body:
After continuing to look through usability and discoverability issues and talking with other random Hubbers about Atom I believe we need to get the 'Native OS' menu items worked into Atom. 

I Say native because I think the styles and functions need to be native to whatever OS they are using, OSX, Linux (prob Ubuntu stylings) and Windows. These are some of the menus from another editor, however, I'm studying through the other editors to see which make sense for Atom. Please chime in on both the concepts of nav discoverability and each menu item. 

![](http://c.gr4m.com/image/2A0o402t3W2y/image)
### Atom OS Menu
- File
- Edit
- Selection
- Find
- View
- Tools
- Projects
- Packages
- Help

Obviously, the end user will not use the edit menu to copy/paste something but having the app experience for discoverability makes sense. Its part of both education and discoverability.
Label: enhancement

Title: Auto-save untitled buffers
Body:
One feature I love of an increasing number of Mac OSX Lion and above apps is the auto-saving of untitled buffers.  If I quit an app that supports this behavior and re-open it, even untitled buffers (never explicitly named and saved) are restored. This lets me have greater confidence about using these apps as "clipboards," knowing that even if I crash or accidentally close the app, I'll have some reasonably up-to-date copy of the file restored.

Sublime is the front-of-mind example for this in my daily workflow.

Title: Collaboration first run experience
Body:
So currently collaboration needs a bit of explanation as to how it works for first time users. The basic premise is that a host will start a session by clicking on the collaboration icon in the bottom right of their status bar of an open editor. This will then create a link in their system clipboard which they can copy to another user via chat or other means.

The other user (which will now be referred to as the "guest") clicks on the link and opens a new window. As long as the following are true, they will wind up with a wind where they can type and they can see the other user's cursor.
- The guest and host must be logged into github.
- The host's project must be in git.
- If the project already exists on the guest's computer at `~/github/<repo>`, it must have been cloned from the same origin.
  - Your trees must not have diverged (IE you can't do clever things with rewriting history on the host but not the guest).
- If a project doesn't exist on the guest's computer at that location, it's copied from the host and saved there.

Also if something fails we need to explain how a user can correct it so they don't feel lost.
Label: enhancement

Title: First run experience
Body:

Title: Update jquery
Body:
Atom currently uses jquery 1.7.1 which came out in November 2011.

We should consider upgrading since it now supports node module loading out of the box via jquery/jquery#1103 so we should be able to use it unblemished.

This would require either no longer using `data('events')` or use the [jquery migrate plugin](https://github.com/jquery/jquery-migrate/).

We might want to wait a bit since it looks like jquery plans to release to npm in [2.1](http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/13119).
Label: enhancement

Title: Add option to have cmd-w close the window when there are no editors open
Body:
When I have multiple buffers open in tabs and a tree view, my past editors (TextMate, Sublime) have conditioned me to expect that a repeated ⌘+w close each buffer's tab, then close the frame and its tree list after the last buffer has been closed.  Atom does not behave this way, and I'm curious if this is by design.

It is worth noting that Brackets does also hold the frame open after repeated ⌘+w presses. Is this similarly by design in Atom? Must I switch fingers to ⌘+⇧+w to close the frame?
Label: enhancement

There's two ways to do this: `cmd-shift-l` and clicking on the file type next to the file location in the bottom bar. Neither is perfect, because:
- `cmd-shift-l` corresponds to a command I can't find using `cmd-p`. 'type', 'filetype', 'syntax' and 'format' all come up empty. I'm still unsure what I'm doing.
- The file type at the bottom looks as unclickable as the path and git branch do. Maybe a little 'down arrow' so I can tell this is a selectable list?

In other news, supporting `# vim:ft=ruby` would be pretty swell too.

Title: Lock down requires
Body:
If packages can require anything from `src` then essentially everything in there is public.

If we want to prevent this we need to remove this folder from the require path and instead just export things that are in public API such as:

``` coffeescript
{Editor} = require 'atom'
```

instead of:

``` coffeescript
Editor = require 'editor'
```

This will also allow us more freedom to rename things internally without breaking backwards compatibility in packages.
## Impact
- Files in `src` and `spec` would start using relative require paths; `./text-buffer` instead of `text-buffer`
- Need to decide how many top-level requires we have and what is in them.
- Do we replace globals with this construct? i.e `{syntax, config} = require 'atom'`
Label: enhancement

Title: Don't trim me, bro!

The same goes for newlines at the end of a file. After the last line of text, hit return a few times. Five is a nice number. Now save the document. You've got one newline at the end of the file.

Save be gettin' hangry for them whitespace characters at the end of lines and documents, yo!

Title: Themes can be installed
Body:
Currently if a user wants to use a 3rd party theme it's necessary to copy it into ~/.atom/themes/. However we can make that easier by leveraging our handy packaging system, apm.
## TODO
- [ ] Determine whether the apm package format should be extended to include a theme directory or whether we should reuse the stylesheets directory and depend on metadata.
- [ ] Extend package.json with metadata to indicate that the package contains a theme.
- [ ] Make the theme loader aware of apms containing themes.
- [ ] Extend the preferences pane within atom to know about themes installed via a package.
- [ ] Extend the preference package manager such that users can search/install themes.
Label: enhancement

Title: Markers sometimes do not fire events when buffer contents modified
Body:
Occasionally, (immediately) after I create markers, I can no longer get events from them when the contents of the buffer are updated. Check this screenshot:

![screen shot 2013-08-19 at 5 25 26 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/69169/990478/0608da4c-0932-11e3-967a-38dd3bc50a87.png)

I've marked `resourcePath` then added some new lines. They didnt move. On invalidation, no changed event either. 

I am binding to the `DisplayBufferMarker`. In all cases, both the string and array markers would emit the proper events, but my `DisplayBufferMarker` would not. 

This happens ~40% of the time. And usually after creating these bad markers, I can create a new set that work as expected. I cant find a consistent way to repro this. I do the same steps every time after a refresh, sometimes it works as expected, sometimes it is broken. Race condition?

Relevant creation/bind code:

```
marker = @editor.activeEditSession.markBufferRange range, 
  class: 'search-result'
  invalidation: 'inside'
  replicate: false

marker.on 'changed', _.bind(@onMarkerChanged, this, marker)
marker.on 'destroyed', _.bind(@onMarkerDestroyed, this, marker)
```
Label: bug

Title: Multiple Lines Paste as One in Soft Wrap Mode
Body:
I pasted in some text from Wikipedia:

```
irection[edit source | editbeta]
Intelligence requirements are determined by a decision maker to meet his/her objectives. In the Federal government of the United States, requirements can be issued from the White House or the Congress. In NATO, a commander uses requirements (sometimes called 'Essential Elements of Intelligence (EEIs)) to initiate the intelligence cycle.
Collection[edit source | editbeta]
In response to requirements, an intelligence staff develops an intelligence collection plan applying available sources and methods and seeking intelligence from other agencies. Depending on the organization and its access, sources may include HUMINT (human intelligence), IMINT (imagery intelligence), ELINT (electronic intelligence), SIGINT (Signals Intelligence), OSINT (open source, or publicly available intelligence), etc.
Processing[edit source | editbeta]
Once the collection plan is executed and information arrives, it is processed for exploitation. This involves the translation of raw intelligence materials from a foreign language, evaluation of relevance and reliability, and collation of the raw intelligence in preparation for exploitation.
Analysis[edit source | editbeta]
Analysis establishes the significance and implications of processed intelligence, integrates it by combining disparate pieces of information to identify collateral information and patterns, then interprets the significance of any newly developed knowledge.
Dissemination[edit source | editbeta]
Finished intelligence products take many forms depending on the needs of the decision maker and reporting requirements. The level of urgency of various types of intelligence is typically established by an intelligence organization or community. An indications and warning (I&W) bulletin would require higher precedence than an annual report, for example.
Feedback[edit source | editbeta]
The intelligence cycle is a closed loop; feedback is received from the decision maker and revised requirements issued.
```

into the editor while soft wrap was enabled (it makes it easier to write prose). When I did I got a weird visual bug at line 17+:
![screen shot 2013-08-10 at 8 08 25 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/942505/dd29bf8c-01b7-11e3-819a-051fecc55166.png)

When I toggled soft wrap it went away, but it was at first a pretty jarring visual bug.
Label: bug

Title: Soft wrapping breaks and duplicates lines in certain situations
Body:
Soft wrapping breaks apart completely and creates a big mess if a certain sequence of actions is performed. I'm on OSX 10.8.4 and Atom 17.0.

To reproduce:
1. Start Atom, open a blank new file, and turn on soft wrapping
2. Enter text until it wraps to the other line:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 27 54 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928220/9fc0a024-ffb0-11e2-9a71-ff8e5c034dcc.png)
3. Your cursor being at the end of line 1, press ENTER to go to the next line. This correctly creates a newline character and moves the cursor to the beginning of the next line:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 29 19 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928227/d228929c-ffb0-11e2-9cbf-d1a0742f17d9.png)
4. Press BACKSPACE. This deletes the new line that was just created and correctly moves the cursor back to the end of line 1. Screenshot same as in step 2:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 27 54 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928287/04a372d6-ffb2-11e2-8c08-82801985b4ef.png)
5. Press ENTER again, as if to repeat step 3. This messes everything up:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 30 13 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928234/ef9865c8-ffb0-11e2-94c3-db980f90c8c4.png)

So, the first "virtual" line was duplicated. Also, this duplicated first line is now non-selectable and non-editable -- I can't even put my cursor there (it's frozen). 

DevTools console doesn't show any errors.
Label: bug

I write me some prose and shit. I soft wrap. Don't hate. I got some long multi-line shit going on, let's say 4 lines. My cursor is after the last character on the 4th soft-wrapped line. I realize I don't know what the fuck I'm saying on this line, so imma delete line 4 and start again.

Title: Panes within tabs?
Body:
I have a Vim workflow that I am having trouble recreating in Atom. Most of my tabs consist of a split, for a file and its tests:

![srt_imports rb _github_talks_app_concerns_talk - vim](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/12676/896074/195b3ef8-fad9-11e2-8bcb-80e85ab7ab8e.png)

Thus I can `{` and `}` my way through tabs and `[` and `]` my way through splits within them, and all was right with the world. My splits are about keeping related files together, not separate panes or editors.

The modeling of `Pane` and `EditSession` doesn't really allow this right now. It's fairly easy to see a number of ways to do it, but I was stymied when I started to edit core stuff by things marked as internal. @kevinsawicki said to ignore that, so I'm going to slowly work on something that works for me. But he also said to make an issue, so here it is. I'm hoping that one of you core guys sees a super easy way to do it :)
Label: enhancement

Title: Keymap Improvements
Body:
So @nathansobo and I were talking about how to handle complex keybindings for first class vim support during summit.

I've run into several issues while thinking about it. The first is issue are vim's `dd` and `d{motion}` (like `diw`) commands which ideally would have separate lines in the keymap file so users could remap them as they wish. Something along the lines of this:

```
".vim-mode":
  "d d": "vim-mode:delete-line"
  "d" : "vim-mode:delete"
  "i w" : "vim-mode:motion-inner-word"
```

Unfortunately the keymap currently fires the first binding that matches. Therefore if a user types 'd d' it will trigger `vim-mode:delete` twice instead of triggering `vim-mode:delete-line` once.

Another issue I've found that I wish we had a way to do some basic globbing:

```
".vim-mode":
  '" [a-zA-Z]': "vim-mode:register-prefix"
```

This syntax would allow me to restrict the possible keys entered without exhaustively listing them. If it's easier maybe we could just accept regexps here rather than trying to create a subset?

Note: This is also required for `f` and `t` motions.

I'd like to hear what others think about these proposals.
Label: enhancement

Title: Stop including bundled packages directly in the source tree
Body:
Currently, we store the packages that we bundle with the Atom binary directly in `src/packages`. It would be great to pull these out in separate repositories and reference them from Atom's `package.json` instead.

**But** in order to do this we need efficient tooling for running tests on all bundled packages when we change Atom's core APIs and editing them in situ.

We're thinking of some apm commands like the following:
- `apm update` This prunes anything in `node_modules` that isn't mentioned in `package.json` and upgrades/installs anything that is mentioned.
- `apm develop [package-name]` This clones, checks out the correct revision, and symlinks all Atom packages in the `package.json` or the named package.
- `apm outdated` This looks for any new published versions of packages mentioned in `package.json` and lists them. It might also be nice to have a command (maybe a flag to `apm update`) that automatically writes to `package.json` and pulls the updated packages into `node_modules`.
Label: enhancement

Title: grunt-lesslint dependency error
Body:
@kevinsawicki So I saw that message again that we saw when @benogle and I we're setting up.

```
npm WARN unmet dependency /Users/mcolyer/github/atom/node_modules/grunt-lesslint requires less@'~1.4.0' but will load
npm WARN unmet dependency /Users/mcolyer/github/atom/node_modules/less,
npm WARN unmet dependency which is version 1.3.3
npm WARN unmet dependency /Users/mcolyer/github/atom/node_modules/grunt-lesslint requires async@'~0.2.9' but will load
npm WARN unmet dependency /Users/mcolyer/github/atom/node_modules/async,
npm WARN unmet dependency which is version 0.2.6
```

Upon digging in it appears that grunt-lesslint never worked with the version of async 0.2.6 (as it used 0.2.9 when added). So I'm guessing the thing to do here is to update async and less in atom (which will require rebasing nathan's forked less copy). 

Before doing that I wasn't sure if there was a specific reason that those two npms were locked at those versions and how you guys typically handled upgrading dependencies.
Label: bug

Title: Scroll position jumps to cursor location after expanding a fold by clicking
Body:
- 1) Create a fold at the top of a large file
- 2) Place the cursor at the bottom of the file
- 3) Scroll up with your mouse and click the fold to expand it
- :facepunch:) The view scrolls back down to the cursor's location

This is because the cursor's location on screen changed, triggering an autoscroll. I'm not quite sure what to do here... disable autoscroll for fold expansions?
Label: bug

Title: Emmet package
Body:
[Emmet](http://emmet.io/) (formerly known as "zen coding") is a plugin for text editors working with HTML and CSS. It’s fucking awesome and it there should be a package for Atom.

There are versions of it written for just about everything—including:
- [Sublime Text](https://github.com/sergeche/emmet-sublime#readme)
- [Textmate](https://github.com/emmetio/Emmet.tmplugin#readme)
- [CodeMirror](https://github.com/emmetio/codemirror#readme)
- [Brackets](https://github.com/emmetio/brackets-emmet#readme)
- [All sorts of other editors](http://emmet.io/download/), including Coda, Vim, plain old `<textarea>`s and more.

I’ve been using Atom for so long now that I’d forgotten how much I depended on this plugin when I used to use Sublime. I saw that there is a repo for converting `.tmbundle`s to npm packages, but the textmate version of emmet is a `.tmplugin` so I figured that probably wasn’t going to happen. 

Basically I have no idea myself how to go about writing an Emmet package for Atom, but it needs to happen, and I think this would be a pretty important package to be able to launch with (and possibly include with Atom by default?). There’s so many existing implementations of it, and all of them are open source, so I figure it shouldn’t be _too_ hard to hijack code from one of them for Atom.

How can we make this be a thing?

/cc @gjtorikian because I remember him mentioning something about a version of this for Ace? That should also be something we let people have when editing HTML via dotcom’s Ace, by the way.
Label: enhancement

Title: Make auto-comment respect current indentation level
Body: Currently, pressing the comment key binding with a selection always inserts the comment characters at the beginning of the line, which hoses up folding and other things. It would be nice to always insert the `//` or `#` character at the current indentation level for the lines.
Label: enhancement

Title: Score fileTypes matches differently
Body:
Currently if a grammar has a `fileTypes` entry for `foo.txt`, it is scored the same as the plain text grammar which just matches `txt`.

Exact `fileTypes` matches should probably be scored higher than suffix or extension matches when deciding which grammar to use by default for a file.

This affects the CMake bundle since it registers for `CMakeLists.txt`.
Label: bug

Title: Paste isn't normalizing indentation correctly
Body: When you paste text with indentation level metadata, the indentation should be normalized to the current cursor column. Currently, we're always normalize to the indentation depth of the original copied text.
Label: bug

Title: Exception when editing after splitting and closing
Body:
Step 1: Open an edit session
Step 2: Split it
Step 3: Go back to the original edit session, close it
Step 4: Go to the split, start inserting newlines
Boom: There's an exception, originating from the destroyed edit session's display buffer when its markers are updated because it's missing screen lines.

This is because we don't properly destroy markers when an edit session is destroyed. When we tried the simple fix of destroying them, it created problems with the cursor on the surviving edit session.
Label: bug

Title: Push a release
Body:
- [x] Ensure updating works
- [x] Ensure crash logger works
- [x] Integrate with constructicon
Label: enhancement

Title: Integrate keymap into menu and finalize API
Label: enhancement

Title: Basic Collaboration
Body:
There are many possibilities with collaboration. This issue covers a simple case, where one user can invite another user to share their entire workspace. The host will start a session which will copy an identifier to their clipboard. Other people can paste that id to connect to the host and share their session. For now we will assume that the joiners already have a copy of the repository they are joining at a standard location on disk, checked out at the correct location.
- [x] Create concurrently mutable document library
- [x] Share basic pane splits and items peer to peer via copied/pasted guid
- [ ] Open a new window when joining a sharing session
- [ ] Share active pane item
- [ ] Make absolute paths relative to repository for sharing on different machines
- [ ] Share buffer contents
- [ ] Share cursor positions in buffers
- [ ] Assign numeric site ids to documents instead of guids
Label: enhancement

Title: Less doesn't auto indent after {
Body:
Hitting `enter` after a `{` in `.less` files doesn't indent the next row.

http://manual.macromates.com/en/appendix#increase_pattern

This is due to the fact that we aren't loading preferences for bundles with no grammars and also we aren't including [source.tmbundle](https://github.com/textmate/source.tmbundle) which defines an [indent pattern](https://github.com/textmate/source.tmbundle/blob/master/Preferences/Miscellaneous.plist#L8-L14) for the `source` scope.

/cc @orderedlist
Label: bug

Title: Odd behaviour when backspacing over UTF-8 symbol
Body:
![atom-utf8-backspace-bug](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/599193/2ff00fc8-cc48-11e2-988c-56b3826a7a6b.gif)

The above GIF shows the following things in a loop:
1. Paste a UTF-8 character (the one found [here](http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/1f512/browsertest.htm)) into Atom.
2. Pressing backspace once, the unicode character is deleted, along with everything else up until the end of the string.
3. Pressing backspace a second time gets things back into the initial state.

What should happen: The state you get into in step 2 should not exist. Pressing backspace after pasting in the symbol should take you back to the pre-paste state.
Label: bug

Title: Atom on OS X "canceled restart"
Body:
If Atom is running and I choose Apple...Restart, the restart is always canceled.

![screenshot_5_31_13_11_55_am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/60566/592428/45b232c0-ca1b-11e2-9cff-71a2b8430b88.png)

To reproduce:
1. Launch Atom; an empty Atom with no open buffers is fine.
2. Choose Restart from the Apple menu.

Atom quits immediately, but the system restart aborts and displays the above dialog.

Also, this acts like choosing Quit from the Atom menu, which means that if you have unsaved but modified buffers, you lose them without a confirmation (cc #492).
Label: bug

Title: Meta-t to index files can be cancelled
Body:
If you hit meta-t, the file indexing kicks off. But if hit meta-t again to close the fuzzy finder, then hit it again, it'll start reindexing.

Expected: it keeps indexing in the background, or resumes where it left off. It should probably just index on startup, anyway.
Label: enhancement

Title: Text Paste Glitch
Body:
Pasting in multiple paragraphs from a Word document I had opened in Pages gave me a weird line ending/highlighting glitch:
![screen shot 2013-05-20 at 3 26 27 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/538148/7019e9c2-c183-11e2-902a-67b9f1e8911d.png)

I would have expected this to be pasted as individual lines and to not have split highlighting.

The text pasted was:

```
Assessment:  Friendly discussion with local contacts to assess whether the subject has information of value and to identify any personal attitudes, beliefs, problems or needs that could be exploitable. 

Elicitation:   A ploy whereby seemingly normal conversation is contrived to extract intelligence information of value.  Advantages of this technique are: (1) Puts someone at ease to share information, (2) Difficult to recognize as an intelligence technique, and (3) Easily deniable. 

Eavesdropping:  Listening to other people’s conversations to gather information. Frequently employed in social environments where attendees feel comfortable, secure and, therefore, more likely to talk about themselves or their work. Frequent venues include restaurants, bars, and public transportation. Eavesdropping can occur in a radius of six to eight seats on public transportation or ten to twelve feet in other settings. 

Technical Eavesdropping:  Use of audio and visual devices, usually concealed.  This technique is relatively cost efficient and low risk.  Concealed devices can be installed in public and private facilities, such as hotel rooms, restaurants, offices, and automobiles. 

Bag Operations:  Surreptitious entry into the subject’s hotel room to steal, photograph, or photocopy documents; steal or copy magnetic media; or download files from laptop computers.  Often conducted or condoned by host government intelligence, security services, or operatives for local corporations.  Frequently done with cooperation of hotel staff. 

Surveillance:  An act of following the subject to determine contacts and activities.  This method is labor intensive, if done correctly, and not usually employed unless suspected of improper activity or a target of great interest. 

Theft of Information:  Stealing of documents, briefcases, laptop computers or sensitive equipment.  Laptop computers are especially vulnerable as they may contain key information.  Foreign service has plausible denial since the laptop may have been stolen for the value of the laptop rather than the value of information.  This makes it difficult to determine if the information was compromised or not. 

Intercepting Electronic Communications:  Method of electronically monitoring telephones, facsimiles, and computers.  Subject is particularly vulnerable while communicating to, from or within foreign countries, as most foreign telecommunications systems cooperate with their country’s security service.  Office, hotel, and portable telephones (including cellular) are key targets. 
```

Console:

Title: Potentially wrong block comment behavior
Body:
When I select a large block of code that starts with one or two lines of comment and then has many lines of code, I expect the entire block to be commented and uncommented as i toggle line comments with m-\ or the panel. instead, it just uncomments the first two lines and does nothing to the rest.

![toggle-line-comments](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1476/518838/a1070eae-bf06-11e2-8de2-eb770b81165c.gif)

Title: Fuzzy finder regression
Body:
This bug affects version 9.0

I often try to match puppet module files with the fuzzy finder. These files are located on disk here:

```
modules/foo/manifests/bar.pp
```

They're referred to in code as classes like this:

```
foo::bar
```

So my use case here is typing `foo/bar.pp` into the finder and attempting to match on the basename.

For example, typing `github/god.pp` into the Finder used to bring up `modules/github/manifests/god.pp` as the first hit. Now it seems to prefer
`modules/god/manifests/init.pp`.

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/47/512536/da854d58-be2a-11e2-840f-3e7daf9f8fff.png)

@probablycorey says:

> that's a bug. Can you file an issue? It is supposed to weight a matched basename very highly

:heart:
Label: bug

Sort of like how RDoc does it: http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ERB/Util.html#method-c-html_escape

I can't decide if it'd be useful or annoying.

Title: Moving cursor with status bar enabled repaints the whole screen
Body:
Some time ago, @kevinsawicki and I discovered that the entire screen was repainting whenever the cursor moved. We tracked the issue down to updating the cursor position text in the status bar, which was combining with the legacy flexbox implementation to cause the entire screen to relayout and repaint. When we upgraded to the new flexbox spec implementation, the issue went away. We concluded that the newer flexbox code must have been smart enough to know that the rest of the elements hadn't changed and didn't need to be repainted. At some point since then, the situation has regressed.

With the show-repaint-rects option enabled in the dev tools, here's what it looks like to move the cursor without the status bar enabled:

![screen shot 2013-05-10 at 3 15 17 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/490314/f8df3c0a-b9b6-11e2-8f85-c3b4386fe826.png)

Note the multiple colored outlines around various lines. These indicate that the lines are being repainted two-at-a-time due to the line-highlight class being added and removed. This is the repaint you would expect and is extremely low-overhead.

Now with the status bar enabled:

![screen shot 2013-05-10 at 3 14 58 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/490324/26f744fc-b9b7-11e2-8cf5-f3cbf55dc633.png)

Note that now there is _only_ a colored outline around the entire window, indicating that everything has been redrawn. This takes way longer and hurts performance a lot.

I checked out the commit in which Kevin and I made the change, just to make sure I'm not crazy. I had some other issues getting anything but an untitled buffer to load, but the repainting works properly with the status bar enabled:

![screen shot 2013-05-10 at 3 36 19 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/490390/d1fffa40-b9b9-11e2-8dbc-3c0e8d3f2ecf.png)

I'm not exactly sure when this went bad. It's expensive to bisect because of the various versions of cef and cefode I would need to download. My theory is that something changed in webkit to make it slow again.

Perhaps this will change again when we switch to a newer version of Chromium with atom-shell. If not, @zcbenz, do you think this is something you could investigate in the Chromium source code? It would be great to understand if there's an approach we can take to limit repaint or if there's an optimization that could be added to webkit to avoid the issue. If anyone on our team can figure it out, it's you.
Label: bug

Title: Clicking links in Markdown preview navigates whole frame
Body:
When you click a link in a Markdown preview pane, Atom's whole window navigates to the link target, not just in the Markdown preview pane. 

To reproduce:
- Start a new buffer and add some sample Markdown, including a link
- Activate Markdown preview pane
- Click dat link

I would expect clicking the link to either stay within the preview pane (might be tricky as there is no navigation in the frame after you go to the target link), open in an external browser, or simply to do nothing. With the current behavior, I need to close and relaunch Atom to get back to editing, as doing cmd-r to refresh just reloads the existing pane that now has a webpage.
Label: bug

Title: Better cursor movement with line wrap behavior
Body:
In situations where you have line wrapping enabled and a "real line" is spanning more than one "virtual lines", there should be a way to easily get to the end of the virtual line as well as the real line.

Given this scenario:

```
+this is a line with a=
soft line wrap that=
spans multiple=
virtual lines
```

where the = is a soft line wrap and the + is the cursor, you should be able to easily get to the end of line 1 or line 4. Right now what happens is if you press `meta-rightarrow` you end up like this:

```
this is a line with a=
soft line wrap that=
spans multiple=
virtual lines+
```

If you press `ctrl-e`, you end up like this:

```
this is a line with a=
soft line wrap that=
spans multiple=
virtual lines+
```

I like SublimeText 2's way of handling this (and then we could make it customizable). `meta-rightarrow` takes you to the end of the virtual line and `ctrl-e` takes you to the end of the real line.
#### meta-rightarrow

```
this is a line with a+=
soft line wrap that=
spans multiple=
virtual lines
```
#### ctrl-e

```
this is a line with a=
soft line wrap that=
spans multiple=
virtual lines+
```

Users could then flip them or make it so both keystrokes do the same thing.
Label: bug

Title: singleTrailingNewline takes focus unexpectedly
Body:
#399 discussed giving Atom the ability to automatically add a trailing newline, which is awesome. What I find very annoying is the fact that it automatically focuses the newline when it adds it. So, for example, let's say I have two lines of text in a new file:

```
this is line one
this is line two+
```

The + is where the cursor is. Now let's say I save. What I end up with is this:

```
this is line one
this is line two
+
```

when what I expected was this:

```
this is line one
this is line two+

```

Any way we can change this behavior?
Label: bug

Title: Idea: Allow `require` to supply scripts with fake global variables
Body:
Because we're mixing a Node-style synchronous require model with a lot of JavaScript that was designed to run into the browser, we often need to modify scripts that expect certain global variables to be present. For example, jQuery UI expects jQuery to be available in its global namespace, and fails when we require it currently.

It would be nice if we could somehow supply a hash of "globals" that we close over when evaluating scripts that we require, like this:

``` coffee-script
jQuery = require "jquery"
require "jquery-ui", { jQuery }
```

Any free-variable references to jQuery would then be resolved to the passed-in object. One issue with this is the following: what happens when you call require again with different values for the same variables. Should we return the cached value? I'd say we make the caching conditional on the value of the variables, or just throw an exception if it's called a second time with different values. This would also require some modification to Node.

I'm not totally sure it's a good idea, but it might be a nice general solution to what will likely be a very common problem in the early years of Atom. If we become popular enough, people will start writing their JS libraries to run in both modes, but until then it would be nice to have something to help us paper over the awkwardness.

@zcbenz Thoughts on implementing this?
Label: enhancement

Title: Window state not being saved on quitting with command-q
Label: bug

Title: Support back-references in `s/` substitution commands
Body: Currently you can only supply a whole string. We need to be able to supply references to capture groups in the original regex.
Label: enhancement

Title: Can't replace matches with empty string via `s/foo//` command
Label: bug

Title: Project-wide search shows unsaved content when saved content is a match
Body:
I’m changing the name of a feature flag from `addons_area_enabled` to `addons_store_enabled`, and noticed a small bug in the project-wide search. I had modified the feature flag in the main file (but not yet saved that change to disk), and proceeded to do a project-wide search for where that feature flag was used. The results contained the unsaved modification, despite it not matching the searched-for-text:

I’m imagining what’s happening here is that the search finds a match in the file as it exists on disk, but Atom displays that result with the unsaved modification in place of the actual match. I’m not entirely sure what _should_ happen here, but it certainly created a moment of uncertainty in my mind about why a result was turning up that I didn’t search for. Probably the best thing to do would be to show the matched result as it appears on disc, and have a "unsaved changes" label or something next to the filename in the result list? I don’t really know :confused:
Label: bug

Title: Fully support TextMate snippets
Body:
This is what the ruby do snippet expansion looks like. Would be good to go the rest of the distance on snippets support now that we have Node in.

```
do${1/(^(?<var>\s*[a-z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*\s*)(,\g<var>)*,?\s*$)|.*/(?1: |)/}variable${1/(^(?<var>\s*[a-z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*\s*)(,\g<var>)*,?\s*$)|.*/(?1:|)/}
```
Label: enhancement

Title: File should be saved asynchronously
Label: enhancement

Title: Editor scroll position isn't restored after refresh
Body: Pretty sure this is because we serialize edit sessions directly now, and we aren't continually writing the scroll position into the edit session from the editor when it changes.
Label: bug

Title: Escape key binding gets unbound
Body:
I've noticed this a while ago for the first time, it seems that something is unbinding the escape key from a vim action. This usually happens after using atom for a bit. I haven't found a way to reproduce it, but usually I have used the command panel or autocompletion before it happens. I set up an alternate keybinding (ctrl-[) and it seems that that keybinding does not get unbound.

I also noticed that the keybinding disappears from the command panel.

Before:
![Screen Shot 2013-04-03 at 6 38 12 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/829/334832/cc02cedc-9c7d-11e2-8dd2-50f3077e5192.png)

After:
![Screen Shot 2013-04-03 at 6 37 59 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/829/334835/cebaaabe-9c7d-11e2-9305-1992e9150c6d.png)
Label: bug

Title: Indexing... problems
Body:
Description:

Cmd-t never lists any files, just shows Indexing... forever.

Steps to reproduce:
- Check out a repo
- run script/bootstrap
- open the project in atom.

I'm running on master as of last thursday or so, currently on slow hotel wifi that precludes updating CEF and clean && build from scratch.. 

For what it's worth, @atmos isn't having the same problem using an older atom. This could maybe be due to something else specific to my dev machine? If so, I could use some help diagnosing it so that we can maybe get some useful information about the behavior.
Label: bug

Title: Right clicking on a misspelled word should show a context menu of suggested words
Label: enhancement

Title: can't set the cursor on the last line of a file
Body:
![assets go - _Users_rick_github_api-uploader](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/21/314293/47fc97fe-97c7-11e2-851e-05cdfff503d8.png)

So I can click far to the right of line 78 to get the curser after that `}`.  Can't seem to do it on line 79 unless I add an extra blank line at the end.  

Though @rtomayko told me once I should add that extra line anyway (for unix tools like `cat` or whatever).  That's fine, but when I run into this it takes me 30s to figure out why shit isn't working :)
Label: bug

Title: --wait should not auto-focus the next open window but return to where it was opened from
Body:
My scenario to explain my problem:

I have Atom open editing. I commit changes and then `--amend` with `EDITOR="atom --wait"`. When I close the `COMMIT_MSG` file to return to the terminal, it automatically focuses the next open Atom window instead of going back to the terminal.

Not sure if that's possible, but I was expecting to go back to the Terminal window I had open before to continue.
Label: enhancement

Title: End-of-line invisibles render incorrectly with indent guide
Body:
Looks like they're always going at the end of the portion of the line element that's extended to the depth of the indent guide, even though they should appear at the beginning of the line.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-27 at 8 33 27 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/308045/b0532e6e-96da-11e2-8c34-9583872bed87.jpg)
Label: bug

Title: OS X dictionary doesn't work
Body:
Usually you can highlight a word in OS X and hit `cmd-ctrl-d` to see its definition but this doesn't work in Atom.

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/287750/2a48fe7c-925f-11e2-9fae-4f642df36ce6.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Command panel's find selections are misaligned after MS-DOS line-endings
Body:
Seems like we must not be accounting for the extra carriage return character in the buffer at the end of the lines, because the selection is progressively more screwed up on lower lines.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-19 at 10 33 10 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/276683/0d870df4-90b3-11e2-8c66-22e2a77371f8.jpg)
Label: bug

Title: Markdown preview should replace pane (not whole window)
Body:
Markdown preview is hella baller. Can we make it even ballerer? Mayhaps. Here's my desired workflow for Great Justice Markdown Editing:
1. Open Markdown file.
2. Split pane to the right.
3. Switch to Markdown preview on right pane.
4. Edit in left pane and hit save.
5. Have Markdown preview in right pane auto-detect and re-render.

This is only possible if the Markdown preview only replaces the pane of the Markdown file, and not the entire window (as is current behavior). This is how I'd expect it to work anyhow, even outside of a split-pane workflow.
Label: enhancement

Title: On cefode branch, requiring the spec suite takes way longer than on dev (even without devtools)
Body:
I produced these screenshots by inserting a call to measure around the entirety of `spec-suite.coffee` in both branches. I had to require `window` in order to load measure, so its require time is not counted.

These measurements were both taken before the dev tools is opened for the first time, and after all the coffee-script compilation had been cached. The cefode branch is taking twice as long to require the coffee-cached spec suite. Long enough to be annoying. We should try to fix this.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-14 at 6 29 16 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/261894/0e09993a-8d08-11e2-8ba7-00c60d744af4.png)

![Screen Shot 2013-03-14 at 6 33 40 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/261897/1167575c-8d08-11e2-9c3f-75d4193ea067.png)
Label: bug

Label: bug
