Label: bug

Title: Atom is unresponsive after opening contributions.scss
Body:
Every time I open `app/assets/stylesheets/github/contributions.scss` the app becomes unresponsive -- except I can Quit. No amount of waiting seems to allow for it to right itself. I've opened the inspector before opening the file to try to catch some hint of what's going on, but either the app becomes unresponsive before reporting errors or nothing actually errors out.

_Note: This is accompanied with a CPU spike where the Atom Helper process is consuming 100%._

Not sure if this is related to #150 as I am able to load large large files from `vendor/assets` just fine.
Label: bug

Title: Overly long line leads to cursor/line mismatch.
Body:
I pasted in a paper abstract to a Markdown document and it appears that the line is so long that it causes a mismatch of a line between the cursor position and the actual line being edited. When I split the line, which honestly makes it a bit easier to read anyway, this goes away. 

Switching between Softwrap and non-wrapped makes no difference.

I've just split the line for this document, it makes the whole thing much easier to read :book:,  but I thought this was a bug worth noting. Thanks for continuing to kick ass! 
## Example Text

```

## In Depth Introduction to the Cyber Kill Chain
[Lockheed Martin | Intelligence-Driven Computer Network Defense Informed by Analysis of Adversary Campaigns and Intrusion Kill Chains](http://www.lockheedmartin.com/content/dam/lockheed/data/corporate/documents/LM-White-Paper-Intel-Driven-Defense.pdf)

> Conventional network defense tools such as intrusion detection systems and anti-virus focus on the vulnerability component of risk, and traditional incident response methodology presupposes a successful intrusion. An evolution in the goals and sophistication of computer network intrusions has rendered these approaches insufficient for certain actors. A new class of threats, appropriately dubbed the “Advanced Persistent Threat? (APT), represents well-resourced and trained adversaries that conduct multi-year intrusion campaigns targeting highly sensitive economic, proprietary, or national security information. These adversaries accomplish their goals using advanced tools and techniques designed to defeat most conventional computer network defense mechanisms. Network defense techniques which leverage knowledge about these adversaries can create an intelligence feedback loop, enabling defenders to establish a state of information superiority which decreases the adversary’s likelihood of success with each subsequent intrusion attempt. Using a kill chain model to describe phases of intrusions, mapping adversary kill chain indicators to defender courses of action, identifying patterns that link individual intrusions into broader campaigns, and understanding the iterative nature of intelligence gathering form the basis of intelligence-driven computer network defense
(CND). Institutionalization of this approach reduces the likelihood of adversary success, informs network defense investment and resource prioritization, and yields relevant metrics of performance and effectiveness. The evolution of advanced persistent threats necessitates an intelligence-based model because in this model the defenders mitigate not just vulnerability, but the threat component of risk, too.

## Responses
![](http://blandin

```
## Screen Shot

![Screen Shot 2013-03-12 at 12 40 50 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/247241/717cf79a-8acf-11e2-8c6a-80371a5f4dd8.png)
Label: bug

Title: Invisibly add newline to end of file
Body:
Emacs and Vim ensure the last character in a file is always `\n`. Atom doesn't do this:

```
$ cat new-file.vim
new file
$ cat new-file.atom 
new file$
```

This would make a nice setting (enabled by default) because in practice you usually want a newline at the end of files.
Label: enhancement

Title: Add mustache syntax highlighter
Body: Files ending in `.mustache`, `.handlebars`, and  `.hbs` (the extension required by [handlebars_assets](https://github.com/leshill/handlebars_assets)) should use a mustache syntax highlighter.
Label: enhancement

Title: Hide text until syntax highlighting finishes
Body:
When I open atom and it loads a large file I see text without syntax highlighting for a few seconds:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/245094/8e30b650-8a76-11e2-83fa-7f63b4978b31.png)

It'd be nice to show a spinner or just hide text until highlighting is finished so Atom feels faster.
Label: enhancement

Title: Selection gets stuck when toggling dev console
Body: Right click somewhere in the editor and click 'Toggle Dev Tools' then move your mouse around. It's as if you're holding the mouse button down - selection follows your cursor - but you aren't holding any buttons down.
Label: bug

Title: Bad/no syntax highlighting for Perl/PHP files
Body:
The Perl and PHP tmbundles are shipped in the vendor directory of Atom, and Atom is aware of the content type appropriate, however the tmbundle doesn't appear to be working for these languages' syntax highlighting.

Perl appears to get rendered with Ruby's highlighting rules, which causes a highlighting error with symbol names, and PHP is not highlighted at all:

![Screen Shot 2013-03-07 at 4 31 44 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1882/234737/338986a4-877f-11e2-8f1c-0ae7a114762f.png)

![Screen Shot 2013-03-07 at 4 32 17 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1882/234741/4a8f09e6-877f-11e2-9da7-c2bccbeae45d.png)

No errors in the javascript console.
Label: bug

Title: cmd-t stuck 'Indexing…`
Body:
I closed Atom on accident and reopened using `atom .`

Now when I reopen `github/github` `cmd-t` is stuck with "Indexing…"

This happened once before, the way I fixed it was to rerun `rake install` after pulling latest dev branch.
Label: bug

Title: remember full-screen state
Body: Native app uncanny valley thing, I think. Apps with full-screen support remember the full-screen state of the main window when they're exited and preserve it for restart. It'd be cool if Atom did this too. I've faked it for myself right now with an `atom.toggleFullScreen()` as the first command in my `~/.atom/user.coffee`, but I'd like to not do that.
Label: enhancement

Title: How do I unsplit panes?
Body:
Splitting panes is easy: I got `C-|` and `C--` into my fingers quickly. What's hard for me is unsplits. Currently it looks like I have to `M-w` until I've closed every tab in the pane, at which point it goes away.

The problem for me is that I don't use tabs, and I don't think of files being open in a pane. I think of them as being open in _Atom_ and displayed in a pane when I ask for 'em.

When I think about unsplitting I don't connect it to the idea of closing files at all. I'd love it if unsplitting was a pane-level concern like splitting is.
Label: enhancement

Title: duplicate entries in the buffer list with multiple panes
Body:
1. Have two panes open
2. Visit the same file in both of 'em
3. Hit `M-b`
4. See two entries for the file

I expect to see one.
Label: bug

Title: meta-click on top of cursor throws javascript error in console
Body:
Steps to reproduce:
- click in editor
- hold down meta and click again

![Screen Shot 2013-03-07 at 10 52 12 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/235/232733/1616af60-873f-11e2-8e77-a564fe27c289.png)
Label: bug

Title: Strange copy/paste behavior when dealing with whitespace
Body:
I talked with @kevinsawicki and @probablycorey about this earlier today and I'm not sure I'm going to describe this any better this time, but I will try.

When I copy a whole line, including the indenting whitespace, or multiple whole lines, from column 0 to the end including the newline and paste it at column 0 on another line, it strips the whitespace in front of every line and pastes it without the indentation.

For example, if I cut this:

```
  two spaces in front

```

and paste it immediately, this is the result:

```
no spaces in front

```

I would prefer my whitespace selection was honored and the whole line, including indenting whitespace, to be pasted verbatim.
Label: bug

Title: CLI open in existing project
Body:
If you `atom ~/Projects/github`, you get your nice project window. But I'd be nice when you later `atom ~/Projects/github/app/models/user.rb`, it opens in that existing project instead of a new window. TextMate works that way (probably Sublime too).

I got down to hacking the application `open:path pidToKillWhenWindowCloses:pid` method. But I couldn't figure out how to open a file in an existing window. It probably requires some new Obj-C to JS bridge call.

https://github.com/github/atom/blob/dev/native/atom_application.mm#L144-L158

Also, I was relying on `AtomWindowController#pathToOpen` which is just the path that was originally opened. For this, it'd probably be better get the window's tree view path.

Related #104, 35f362df1df5d1438c09e9e98b109742a2016b65

/cc @kevinsawicki
Label: enhancement

Title: Incorrect lineHeight dimensions after setting line-height in user.css
Body:
If you set `line-height` in your `user.css` file, it causes all sorts of problems.

To Reproduce:
- open ~/.atom/user.css and add this rule.  You might need to edit the value until there is a noticeably different line-height than the default.

``` css
.editor {
  line-height: 1.6;
}
```
- Open a new tab and start pressing enter.  Note that the longer you press enter, the further the cursor gets from the highlighted line.

This causes selections, cursor positions, bracket matchers, and spell check indicators to all be in the wrong position.  

/cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo
Label: bug

Title: after quitting, cannot start atom due to missing executable
Body:
Unfortunately, I cannot seem to consistently reproduce this, but I have run across it a handful of times. It seems to happen sporadically after closing some or all of the open tabs, then quitting the application. This is what I see on the command-line:

```
github $ atom
The application cannot be opened because its executable is missing.
```

Then a few moments later I'm able to start the app and everything works just fine.
Label: bug

Title: Visually indicate when running in dev mode
Body: It's hard to remember which editor was launched in dev mode or if it's actually running in dev mode.  It would be great if we can add a body class indicating the the current instance of atom is running in dev mode so we can hook into and add some styles to make it more obvious.
Label: enhancement

Title: Elastic scrolling not working on editors
Body: Can the rubber band scroll effect at the top and bottom of the editor when reaching the end of the scrollable area be enabled?  I'm not sure if this works yet on scrollable divs, but it would be nice.
Label: enhancement

Title: Drag and drop images onto Atom actually works
Body: I accidentally dropped some images onto my Atom editor on the way to the trash can.  Atom dutifully replaced the window contents with the image.  I had to restart Atom to get the editor back.
Label: bug

Title: UI does not refresh on automated resize
Body: Not really sure if this qualifies as a bug or not. I use [Divvy](http://mizage.com/divvy/) for window management. When I use it with atom, the window resizes, but the internal UI stays as it was prior to being resized.
Label: enhancement

Title: Explain what `meta` means in the docs.
Body:
It might be obvious, but there is no place in the documentation where it explains what `meta` is. On the other hand, the second paragraph starts like this:

> If there's one key-command you learn in Atom, it should be meta-p.

So, I read that, I open Atom and my first thought is, where is `meta`? I'm a vim user, so for me it would be `,` or `Ctrl`, but I'm on mac, so following the OS conventions I could thought that `meta` is `Cmd`. But, does Atom follow the OS conventions? So, where is `meta` if I use it on Linux instead?

All in all, I have to think really hard to figure out where the most important key is, even before starting to use the editor.
Label: bug

Title: No way to get tree view back using command palette unless you have file open
Body:
I closed all files and accidentally hit esc in the tree view. At this point, atom was a gaping dark void. The command palette looked like this:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-28 at 3 47 00 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/235/207186/0986ab12-81e8-11e2-94b2-3b7a64d3c156.png)

I couldn't remember the keymap to toggle it. Luckily I opened a file and then I could get to the tree view toggle from the command palette.

Having a few other options in the command palette based on a really blank slate would be super useful.
Label: bug

Title: Show git status in fuzzy finder
Body:
It'd be awesome if this showed icons with the git status (modified mostly):

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/198764/620ed5d6-8065-11e2-9a57-9caf9f698d09.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Support for privilege escalation
Body:
I edit my `/etc/hosts` file a lot to work with Enterprise VMs. My typical workflow for that is to run `subl /etc/hosts`, edit the file, `cmd-s`, and then I get prompted for my password since it's trying to save and my user doesn't have permission to.

In Atom, it opens the file just fine, but when I try saving the dev tools pane pops up and I see this in the javascript console:

```
Uncaught Error: You don’t have permission to save the file “hosts? in the folder “etc?.
```

It would be cool if we had support for nicely handling cases where you try saving files that require privilege escalation to write.
Label: enhancement

Title: Native Emoji Support
Body:
It would be awesome to support native emoji.

Right now I just see nothing when I try to paste one in:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/194137/1ce00c46-7f9d-11e2-93bf-75ee5e37189c.png)

Compare to Safari:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/194139/23bff062-7f9d-11e2-9f3f-37606e39500d.png)

Though unfortunately Chrome is broken too, so maybe this isn't something we can fix:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/194145/3f9ae04e-7f9d-11e2-8371-1145c38601d9.png)
Label: enhancement

Title: Weird state after pressing escape
Body:
I hit `escape` while the File Browser had focus and that caused the File Browser to disappear. After that, hitting `cmd-\` had no effect. Quitting and opening again didn't clear the problem, so it seems like it's saved in the project state. Per @probablycorey I hit `alt-cmd-i` to bring up the dev tools and tried running `localStorage.clear()` to try clearing the project state, but that just returned `undefined`. Opening up other projects displays the File Browser as expected.

I'm able to reproduce this on any project.
Label: bug

Title: Large file support
Body:
So, I use my text editor for all kinds of things (writing code, reading readmes, editing dotfiles, etc). One of the things I do most often during any given day is open up large log files to troubleshoot Enterprise problems. These files can sometimes get as large as 500-800MB.

I just tried viewing a 350MB log file and Atom locked up immediately -- the file selector didn't change and the entire window went completely white 4 seconds after I tried viewing the file. I could still close the top level window, but we should still have better handling for this kind of thing.

Sublime Text 2 took about 55 seconds to open the file, but gave a nice progress indicator while it was loading:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-24 at 4 50 56 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/244/190379/c0abc27e-7ee5-11e2-8ec4-4205cdee0ad0.png)

Once it loaded it was as responsive as any other file I load (scrolled fast, normal text highlight performance, etc). It would be nice if we set this as a baseline for expected behavior (progress bar + responsive after loading).
Label: bug

Title: Add command to change branch in Atom
Body:
I think it's pretty straight forward, but I would love to be able to:
1. Press meta-p 
2. Type something like "Checkout Branch"
3. Either get a set of possible options of branches to change to _-or-_ ability to create a new branch

Just a :thought_balloon: long term. Keep killin' it!
Label: enhancement

Title: Pasting multiple lines to the end of the buffer bugs text rendering
Body:
When pasting in multiple lines from an IM in iMessage to Atom text rendering bugged:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-20 at 1 12 18 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/177120/a049c4ee-7b8a-11e2-9097-0ad3aaff4f4b.png)

For another good example look at the yellow underscores at the end of the line… those are supposed to be the underlines under the () for syntax highlighting, when I delete the last space on the line the () part pops up to the right line and is underscored correctly:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-20 at 1 16 06 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/177122/b25caca0-7b8a-11e2-8748-8464b89a3625.png)

Title: Allow panes to be resized
Body: Panels split the difference between the space available.  It'd be nice if we could manually resize them.  Should take a look at what @nakajima did with the tree view.

Body: Described [in the themes documentation](https://github.com/github/atom/docs/#themes)

Title: Folds should be preserved when cut/copied and then pasted

Title: Persistent fullscreen
Body: Atom remembers my window size and position, but it doesn't remember that it was fullscreen the last time I ran it. It'd be :cool: if it did.
Label: enhancement

Title: Use a CSS preprocessor
Body:
Here are a few.  We use SCSS on .com.
### [node-sass](https://github.com/andrew/node-sass)
- Allows us to use what we're using on .com.
- Everyone understands and knows this.
### [less.js](http://lesscss.org)
- Very similar syntax to SCSS. 
-  Variables and mixins use a slightly different syntax.  
- Looks like it'd be the easiest to implement since it's just a single JS file.
### [stylus](http://learnboost.github.com/stylus/)
- Built specifically for node.  
- Similar syntax as SASS.  
- The most concise syntax

/cc @jonrohan @kevinsawicki @nathansobo @probablycorey
Label: enhancement

Title: Tree selection doesn't extend entire width
Body:
Select an entry and scroll over and the selection color stops.

![Screen Shot 2013-01-31 at 1 02 32 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/671378/116112/a0525c90-6be9-11e2-801e-40c82f0a157c.png)
Label: bug

Title: Support image viewing
Body: It would be awesome if you could click an image in the treeview and it's rendered inside Atom.  Most editors fail miserably at this.  Sublime renders the raw image data and Atom currently just shows the file extension or type.
Label: enhancement

Title: Synchronously load active editor grammar
Body:
All grammars are now loaded in the background which displays a flash between the editor being rendered and the grammar being available to colorize.

Load the active editor grammar up front so this doesn't happen.
Label: enhancement

Title: Browser resource loading should respect the load path
Body: Currently, we have a load path that `require` uses to resolve paths to script files, and we also use this load path in `requireStylesheet`. But resource references in the HTML such as images or fonts don't respect this load path... they are just loading relative to the page's static path on disk. I'd like the browser component to respect the same load path that require does, so that we can resolve relative resource paths to a variety of locations. This will allow themes and packages to easily pull resources that they package for themselves.
Label: enhancement

Title: A wild phantom caret appears
Body:
So I have no idea how this happened, but just now I wound up with a second input caret that isn’t part of the whole multiple cursor functionality thing. It just sits there, blinking soullessly at me, regardless of what I do with the normal caret. An GIF:

![atom-phantom-caret](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/106862/1baa004a-6a10-11e2-97a2-866c1bcc623d.gif)

Note that:
- it doesn’t move or alter text the way it should if atom was in multiple cursor mode.
- Adding to the start of the phantom cursor’s line does not increment the caret position.
- moving the real caret over the phantom caret does not clear it.

Switching to a different tab and back again cleared it for me.
Label: bug

Title: ctrl-k semantics and no ctrl-y
Body:
Text entry areas on OS X implement a few readline/emacs keystrokes, including ctrl-k for "kill to end of line" and ctrl-y for "yank from kill buffer". I use them both a lot and in particular, this is the behavior I expect:
- Cutting a line with ctrl-k goes into the undo manager, but not into the system pasteboard:
- Text cut with ctrl-k can be pasted with ctrl-y to any other window in the same application, but the ctrl-k buffer is per-application

In other words, you can't command-v something you've cut with ctrl-k, and the ctrl-k kill buffer is application-wide.

Right now ctrl-k is bound to `editor:cut-to-end-of-line` in the emacs keymapping, but it affects the global pasteboard and there's no ctrl-y counterpart. 

It might be worth adding a ctrl-y mapping and changing ctrl-k/ctrl-y behavior to make Atom seem more native on Mac.
Label: enhancement

Title: indent region
Label: enhancement

Title: Hide hidden files from treeView
Body: I hate accidentally clicking on `.DS_Store`
Label: enhancement

Title: Having undo buffer outside of window session.
Body: Sometimes I'll `command-R` the editor, then I realize I loose all my `command-Z` powers. It would be excellent if we serialized the undo buffer so that when the editor is reloaded, I don't loose my undo.
Label: bug

Title: Indicate "searching" state in places like "Find across whole project"
Body:
When you pull up the command palette to do a search through the whole project (i.e. `cmd+shift+f` or by entering `:Xx/…` manually), there is no visual indication that once you’ve pressed enter it’s actually doing anything. I’m not sure how best to solve this visually—but my initial gut feeling would be to try maybe having the results pane show up, but to have it contain a message like "searching now...".

It may also be worth allowing people to cancel/abort a project-wide search, because they may have inadvertently done global find instead of "find in this file" (or maybe they meant to use the fuzzy file finder instead) or something.

Thoughts?
Label: enhancement

Title: Atom's duplicating indented lines.
Body:
I had a line over 80 characters, I added a newline and realigned the code. 
I then changed another parameter and the line (the one I originally added the newline to) is again over 80 characters. I added another newline but this time atom duplicated the line below it! 

![atom-line-dupe](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/7492/76739/8ed54b40-60fd-11e2-8ede-8c445498c601.gif)

Title: Add ability to bootstrap themes and packages from the atom cli
Body:
It would be great to have a quick way to generate a basic template for packages and themes from the atom cli.

``` command-line
$ atom bootstrap --package --name=MyPackage
```

This could generate the basic structure for a packages and export the top-level module in your index.coffee file. 

``` command-line
$ atom bootstrap --theme --name=MyTheme
```

This could generate the basis for a theme which contains all the proper theme files with empty selectors for every piece of atom.
Label: enhancement

Title: Consider using nak instead of ack
Body:
Ok, so I'm sitting in Summit and blown the :shit: away by what you guys just showed. The funny thing is, after leaving Cloud9, I toyed with the idea of creating my own text editor with another friend.

Tangential to all that, I wrote my own Find-in-files/search-files module written in Node.js. It's heavily inspired by ack (which you're using) and ag. And it's fast as all hell: https://github.com/gjtorikian/nak (benchmarks available at the bottom) My ultimate goal was to be faster than ack, which I succeed by a large magnitude. 

The tool is _so badass_ that it's also touted on the official ack page: http://betterthangrep.com/more-tools/

At Cloud9, I worked on the backend search implementation, and here's the (long-winded!) discussion on how I moved from ack (in Perl) to ag (in C) to nak (in Node.js): https://github.com/ajaxorg/cloud9/pull/2369

If this is something you're interested in using for 0.1, I'll make the PR for the code.
Label: enhancement

notify.send

Title: Don't consider _ part of a word
Body:
In Atom if I type `def_unkt` and hit option-d, it deletes everything.

If I type `def-unkt` and hit option-d, it deletes `unkt`.

I always love when `_` and `-` are treated the same by the editor because in programming they are often used similarly:

`RATE_OF_CHANGE` vs `rate-of-change`

Is this something we can change in Atom?
Label: enhancement

Title: Fullscreen cmd+n opens fullscreen window
Body:
Right now if you have Atom fullscreen'd in OS X and hit cmd+n, a new fullscreen window opens. It'd be great if a normal, non-fullscreen window opened instead. 

Because Atom is project based making a window fullscreen feels like you're making the specific project fullscreen, not Atom itself. So it's weird that the fullscreen status is not local to the project but universal to the application.

I'm not sure if that's against OS X rules or whatever but it sure would be neat.
Label: enhancement

Title: Buffer mode map
Body:
It'd be nice to be able to define an arbitrary regex to match on a filename that determines which "mode" that editor should be in.

For example, here's some code from my Emacs config:

``` lisp
(defun make-auto (pattern mode)
  "Add a pattern to the auto-mode alist."
  (let ((ans (assoc pattern auto-mode-alist)))
    (if (and ans (equal mode (cdr ans)))
      (print "Do Nothing")
      (print "Added")
      (setq auto-mode-alist
      (cons (cons pattern mode) auto-mode-alist)))))


(make-auto "\\.clj$"                        'clojure-mode)
(make-auto "\\.pp$"                         'puppet-mode)
(make-auto "\\.feature$"                    'feature-mode)
(make-auto "\\.\\(md\\|mkdn\\|markdown\\)$" 'markdown-mode)
(make-auto "\\.mustache$"                   'mustache-mode)
(make-auto "^\\(Puppetfile\\|Gemfile\\)\\(\\.lock\\)$" 'ruby-mode)
```
Label: enhancement

Title: "Shell" mode
Body:
Emacs allows you to run interactive interpreters inside of a buffer. In particular, this is handy with things like a plain shell like Bash, but also works with things like IRB.

Emacs even has keybindings to allow you to execute parts of a buffer inside the related interactive shell.

I'd love to see an extension that would allow running a shell inside a new split.
Label: enhancement

Title: Prompt to create new file if no match found in fuzzy file finder
Body:
Basically if a path input into the fuzzy file finder does not have a match, add an "entry" to the autocomplete list to create a new file.

This would then open up a new buffer that upon save will actually persist something to disk at that file path.
Label: enhancement

Title: Scratch buffers
Body:
Emacs has a really useful buffer opened by default (and the default buffer view if emacs is ran without any arguments for a file or directory) called `*scratch*`.

Not only is this buffer a great place to just store text temporarily, but the really power is that it is an Emacs Lisp buffer designed to allow you to write code and execute within the running context of the editor.

I'd love to something similar for Atom, with keybindings to "run" a selected region.
Label: enhancement

Title: Ability to close splits independent of closing buffers
Body:
I talked with @nathansobo a bit about this in Kona. Basically, one of Emacs' best features is it doesn't couple splits to buffers, which makes opening and closing splits really powerful.

What I'm proposing is:
- Decouple buffers from splits on the backend
- Maintain the current Cmd-W behavior (that closes buffers and then eventually a pane)

This way the crazy Emacs-loving types like myself don't get frustrated with the splits, but the ST2-style behavior can remain default for everybody else. 

Here's basically what I'm proposing to be able to do, in slightly Emacs-ish terms:

```
window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 0': 'editor:close-current-split-unless-last-split'

window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 1': 'editor:close-all-splits-except-selected-split'

window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 2': 'editor:split-down'

window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 3': 'editor:split-right'

window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 5 2': 'core:open-new-editor-for-selected-project'

window.keymap.bindKeys '*',
  'ctrl-x 5 0': 'core:destroy-editor-unless-last-window'
```
Label: enhancement

Title: command+w too many times leads to blank window bug
Body:
How to reproduce:
1.  cd MY_PROJECT
2.  atom .
3. In Atom `cmd+w` until the tree view closes (seems like this could be a bug too)
4. Close atom
5. atom .

You're left with a blank window, but you should see a tree view populated with the files from the directory you opened.
